title: THE MONUMENT GLUT
description: Reston's esthetic dismay at the overcrowding of the Mall is pretentious. The proximity of the Korean and Vietnam War memorials to the Lincoln Memorial does anything but "dilute the importance of Lincoln and the American Civil War." The "nasty, inconclusive, foreign wars" are equally a part of our country's history.

title: ART;Pictures Out of Africa and Out of War
description: AN astonishing photographic odyssey is at the Yale Center for British Art; it is a 120-work retrospective of Constance Stuart Larrabee, who was born in England in 1914, but raised in South Africa. The focus is on South Africa but in the middle of the exhibition is stirring documentation of World War II. Ms. Larrabee photographed the European theater as South Africa's first female war correspondent. The show closes on a genteel note: she now lives in Chestertown, Md., where she raises dogs while continuing to take pictures.

title: Tug of War on the Traprock Ridges
description: MOST residents of central Connecticut and commuters on Interstate 91 and Interstate 84 take for granted the towering faces of the traprock ridges that extend from New Haven to New Hampshire. But conservationists do not, and they warn that the chance to preserve the beauty of a defining geological feature of the Connecticut Valley is slipping away.

title: Sept. 24-30: Italian Politics; Andreotti Will Be Tried For Mafia Ties
description: Italian governments came and went during the decades after World War II, but somehow Giulio Andreotti was always there. As prime minister, foreign minister, defense minister, he was never far from center stage. Now two years after the political system he helped build collapsed under the weight of corruption scandals, he is back again -- this time in court on charges of serving as the Sicilian Mafia's point man in Rome.

description: In a game in which so many drives died on third and long, it was somehow ironic that the big play would come on third-and-10.

title: Sept. 24-30; A Few Pictures For the Country
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Mellon gave the National Gallery of Art in Washington 85 works of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art valued at more than $50 million last week. "This is the largest gift I've ever had the honor of accepting," said the gallery director, Earl A. Powell 3rd. Among the artists: Cezanne, Gauguin, Degas, Toulouse-Lautrec, Manet, Bonnard, Buillard and Braque.

title: COPING;From Rachmaninoff to the Vacuum Cleaner
description: THE baritone who cleans my building, Gene Howard, will perform this afternoon at 4, at Christ and St. Stephen's Episcopal Church on West 69th Street. I found this out while he was vacuuming the hallway, from a flier with his picture he had taped above the mailboxes. It was one of 500 fliers he has been spreading around the city as he scrubs, mops and polishes to pay for his recital.

title: A Dancer Remembered
description: One of the most popular performers in the peak years of Harlem nightclubs was the dancer Charles (Cookie) Cook. Along with his partner, Ernest Brown, Cook was famous for combining tap dancing with acrobatics and comedy. Cook, who died in 1991, will be the subject of an exhibit at the Museum of the City of New York from Nov. 18 through next Feb. 25. "Cookie's Harlem" will include the dancer's tap shoes, hats and playbills, and a 37-minute videotape of Cook's performances. The museum is at Fifth Avenue and 103d Street. Information: (212) 534-1672. JOSEPH SIANO

title: The Right Stuff
description: NEOCONSERVATISM The Autobiography of an Idea. By Irving Kristol. 493 pp. New York: The Free Press. $25. ONE of the most charming anecdotes in Irving Kristol's collection of essays occurs in the opening memoir of his life as a public intellectual. The young Irving -- what a concept! -- was attending his local Trotskyist meeting in Bensonhurst: "At these meetings I noticed a girl -- she was 18, it turned out -- who sat quietly at the other end of the small room. Her name was Gertrude Himmelfarb, but she was called 'Bea.' . . . I noticed her for some weeks before approaching her and asking her out. In truth, I was already in love with her without even knowing her. . . . Thus began what my friend Daniel Bell later described as 'the best marriage of our generation,' a judgment I have no quarrel with. We are about to celebrate our 53d wedding anniversary."

title: Supreme Court To Weigh Gay Rights
description: A revolution of sorts was in progress when the Supreme Court stitched together its final 5-to-4 decisions and recessed in June. The Court's conservative wing accomplished some longstanding objectives, including curbing Federal affirmative action programs, further limiting the use of race in legislative districting and reinvigorating old notions of limits to the Federal Government's powers.

description: This is how old law firms die: with a crash of titanic egos, a splintering of stubborn partners, a skittish flight of lawyers.

title: Less-Crowded Parks
description: Yellowstone, Yosemite and other national parks are at the top of most vacationers' destination lists, as the crowds there demonstrate. But a paperback guidebook published last June helps travelers find some less-crowded gems among the state park systems. "Frommer's America's 100 Best-Loved State Parks" (Macmillan, $16.95) lists accommodations and activities at some of the most scenic parks. Maps and phone numbers are included.

title: P.S. 127 Loses Magnet Funds
description: Nelson thought he saw a million stars. Jamel said, "I'm going to touch a star." Then, the fourth-grade students, huddled in the dark inside Public School 127's inflatable star lab, listened to their teacher and found the North Star.

title: HOME CLINIC;Repairs for Toilet Wear-and-Tear
description: THERE is evidence that the ancient Egyptians, Cretans and Romans had toilets with drainage systems and air shafts for ventilation. In Renaissance England, an early flush toilet was invented but not widely used. In 1778, two inventors, Bramah and Allen, developed a flush toilet that was installed in hospitals. Most doctors disapproved of the toilets, because they lacked a trap system that would keep noxious gases and offensive odors from entering the room through the toilet.

Harbourfront Center and the Tokyo-based, nonprofit Japan Foundation are the primary organizers of the exposition; Canadian Airlines International is the main corporate sponsor.

title: BENEFITS
description: Hospital Fund Gala MONDAY -- The United Hospital Fund, which raises money for 47 private hospitals in New York, will benefit from a dinner-dance at the Plaza. Elizabeth Pforzheimer, a founder and the president of New Alternatives for Children, a service agency, will receive an award for distinguished community service. Suzanne Pincus, a founder of Women in Need, which helps homeless women and their children, will be honored posthumously. Cocktails at 7 P.M. will be followed by dinner and dancing to Lester Lanin and His Orchestra. Black tie. Tickets, $500, from (212) 494-0733. A Jazz Tribute MONDAY -- Frank Foster, who is retiring as the leader of the Count Basie Orchestra, will be honored at a concert at 8 P.M. at Aaron Davis Hall at City College, Convent Avenue at 135th Street. Mr. Foster and his daughter, Jardis, are scheduled to perform along with Jon Faddis, Lionel Hampton, Slide Hampton, Jimmy Heath, Tito Puente, Max Roach and Joe Williams. The evening, which is to benefit programs at Aaron Davis Hall, will begin with a cocktails and champagne at 6:30. A dessert reception with the performers will be at 10. Tickets, $75, from (212) 650-5966. Conversation at Sotheby's MONDAY -- Lynn Sherr, the ABC News correspondent, will be the host of a panel discussion on women in American society at 6 P.M. at Sotheby's, 1334 York Avenue (72d Street). Panelists will be Diana D. Brooks, Sotheby's chief executive; Joan Ganz Cooney, the children's television producer, and Faye Wattleton, the former president of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America. The money raised will go to the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, which provides a variety of community services on the Upper East Side. Refreshments at 5:30. Tickets, $20, from (800) 444-3709. Ralph Lemon's 10th THURSDAY -- The Ralph Lemon Dance Company will celebrate its 10th anniversary with an 8 P.M. performance at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue (19th Street). A champagne reception is planned for 7:30 in the theater lobby, and dinner at 10 at the Viceroy restaurant. Tickets, $125, or $65 for the reception and performance only, from (212) 924-8563. Catching the Wave FRIDAY -- The Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival Gala will begin at 7 P.M. with the premiere of "Alice," a theater work by Robert Wilson, with music and lyrics by Tom Waits, at the BAM Opera House, 30 Lafayette Avenue (Ashland Place) in Brooklyn. Dinner will follow at the Field House of the Chelsea Piers Sports and Entertainment Complex on the Hudson River at 23d Street in Manhattan. Transportation will be provided between Manhattan and Brooklyn. Tickets, $600, from (718) 636-4182. Organ Recital OCT. 10 -- The restoration fund of the Church of the Heavenly Rest will benefit from a performance by John Scott, the organist at St. Paul's Cathedral in London. The recital will begin at 7:30 at the church, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street. A champagne reception will follow. Tickets, $20, from (212) 369-0296. Time in 3-D OCT. 10 -- The premiere of "Across the Sea of Time," an Imax 3-D film, will benefit the New-York Historical Society. The film will be shown at 7:30 and at 9 P.M. at the Sony Imax Theater, 1998 Broadway (68th Street). A black-tie dinner at the society, 77th Street and Central Park West, will follow the first screening, and dessert, also at the society, will follow the second. Bus transportation from the screenings to the society will be provided. Tickets, $500 for first event, or $100 for the second, from (212) 873-3400. Queen Catherine's Statue OCT. 10 -- A black-tie dinner at the Plaza will raise money for the Queen Catherine Monument Project, a plan to install a 35-foot statue of Catherine of Braganza on the waterfront at Hunters Point, across the East River from the United Nations. The borough of Queens was named for Queen Catherine, who was the Portuguese-born wife of King Charles II of England. Cocktails at 7 P.M. will be followed by dinner at 8. Tickets, $300, from (212) 418-0341. Dinosaur Families OCT. 11 -- The American Museum of Natural History will hold a party for adults and children from 6 to 8 P.M. Guests will tour the museum's galleries, including the Hall of the Dinosaurs. Montego Joe, a Caribbean-Creole music group, will perform, and other activities will include mask making, origami, fossil digs and a treasure hunt. Refreshments will be served. Tickets, $100, or $35 for children 12 and under, or $200 for a family of four, from (212) 769-5149.

title: The Real Price of Default
description: President Clinton and Congressional leaders agreed last week to a stopgap spending deal which would keep the Government operating through early November, while their tumultuous budget negotiations continue. But that is when the nation's legal borrowing ability expires, and that is where Congressional leaders are drawing the line. Speaker Newt Gingrich and more than two-thirds of House Republicans say they will suspend Federal borrowings then, unless there is a new long-term budget on their terms -- and if this causes America to default on its debts, so be it.

title: A Lithuanian Resort With a Touch of Magic
description: ABOUT the only famous person to have lived in Nida, Lithuania, was the German writer Thomas Mann. He first visited the small resort village, on a 60-mile skewer of beach called the Courland Spit, in 1929, the year he won the Nobel Prize for Literature. So impressed was he by this "fantastic world of traveling dunes, pine forests filled with elk, and birch groves between the bay and the Baltic Sea" that he had a house built overlooking Courland Lagoon and spent three summers there before eventually emigrating to the United States.

title: A Lithuanian Resort With a Touch of Magic
description: ABOUT the only famous person to have lived in Nida, Lithuania, was the German writer Thomas Mann. He first visited the small resort village, on a 60-mile skewer of beach called the Courland Spit, in 1929, the year he won the Nobel Prize for Literature. So impressed was he by this "fantastic world of traveling dunes, pine forests filled with elk, and birch groves between the bay and the Baltic Sea" that he had a house built overlooking Courland Lagoon and spent three summers there before eventually emigrating to the United States.

title: SO YOU WANT TO WIN A NOBEL PRIZE
description: EACH AUTUMN, ON A Thursday morning, a strange ritual takes place in Stockholm. In an elegant 18th-century room around a long table, under a high chandelier and before a bust of King Gustav III, a dozen or so men and women write down a name on a piece of paper. The pieces of paper are then collected in a stop, an antique silver tankard, and the names are totted up. At 1 P.M., exactly, the group's delegate returns to his office, where a large number of journalists have gathered, and reads out the name that has recurred most often on those pieces of paper. In this way, each October, the winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature is delivered to the world.

I ate my appetizer-sized portion and then wished I could order another as my entree. The dish, like the restaurant, is delicate, and yet, at its core, Chez Nous is pure bistro. title: RETURN OF THE PUNK PANTHER
description: ON A FRIDAY IN JULY, TWO DAYS BEFORE the new musical "Victor/Victoria" opened in Chicago, members of the company were running around the catacombs of the Shubert Theater, trying to figure out whether the next day was Blake Edwards's birthday. Theater people take these things seriously. Birthday lists are prominently posted, and the last member of the company to have one organizes the next celebration. The bulletin board listed July 26 -- the following Wednesday -- next to the director's name, but an assistant to Edwards's wife, Julie Andrews, said his birthday was the 22d, tomorrow. Actors and assistants panicked. Kirsten Sanderson, an assistant director, went to get an almanac. The actor Adam Heller went out to a bookstore. Nobody was keen on asking the director directly. Heller, with whom the farceur Edwards shared great rapport, dreaming up new pratfalls for his performance nearly every rehearsal, had already approached him on stage. "Hey, Blake, I hear it's your birthday Saturday." Edwards had responded with an unprintable expression of two words.

title: Henry Adams, P.I.
description: PANAMA By Eric Zencey. 375 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $24. VISITING Paris in the winter of 1892, the historian Henry Adams notices a strange phenomenon: early frost lies across the streets, not in a sheet but in angled lines and bars. What has caused this eerie effect? It is the sewers and drains, his companion explains; they trap the chilly air overnight, so the pavement above them is colder than the rest of the street. For a few moments on a crisp morning, the whole subterranean world of the city is exposed to the eye. As Adams touches the frost, it melts beneath his hand. The deeper pattern eludes him; truth evades his grasp.

title: DISCOVERING A NEW SIDE OF ISTANBUL
description: AFTER several trips to Istanbul, I had worked out a pleasant routine: a room in a small hotel in the old city; daily strolls to the Blue Mosque, the Covered Bazaar, Hagia Sophia and Topkapi, and a leisurely program nibbling away at the Seven Hills of what sentimentalists call "Old Stamboul." On each visit, I made a ritual excursion across the Golden Horn -- studiously ignoring the sprawling new city of 10 million -- to sip a nostalgic dry martini in the venerable Pera Palace Hotel, where generations of Orient Express passengers once stayed.

title: Burning Desire
description: By embroidering on the brief life of an orphan girl who was burned at the stake for witchcraft in 1610, Sebastiano Vassalli's novel, THE CHIMERA (Scribner, $24), presents an acerbic, complex, prodigiously detailed rendition of life in rural Italy during the Counter-Reformation. In this translation by Patrick Creagh, Mr. Vassalli glories in minutiae, describing in fine degree the superstitions and religious corruption of the era -- and what 17th-century provincial life looked, sounded and even smelled like. It was a crude, noisy, brutal world, one where "human life bubbled and seethed," where "the work in the fields was hard, grueling in fact, and entertainment was nonexistent," save for gossip and procreation and the occasional witch burning. Into the village of Zardino, in the flatlands of Lombardy, comes a beautiful girl named Antonia, adopted from an orphanage by a childless peasant couple. Resented by the local women, she is also desired by the local men. Appearing not long after is Don Teresio Rabozzi, a hysterical young priest who is determined to wring the devil out of Zardino through a fierce regimen of prayer and donations, and maybe buy himself a parish besides. Within this narrative, Mr. Vassalli distills his extraordinary story -- extraordinary not for what happens to poor, doomed Antonia, but for the intricate formula of events and attitudes that produces her fate. SUZANNE BERNE

title: Tug of War on the Traprock Ridges

But conservationists do not, and they warn that the chance to preserve the beauty of a defining geological feature of the Connecticut Valley is slipping away.

title: IN DEFENSE OF MATERIAL CHRISTIANITY

Pope John Paul II's visit this week will surely flood the market with plastic Jesus statues, glow-in-the-dark Mary prints and, of course, any conceivable item upon which the Pope's image can be emblazoned. For years, critics have blithely denounced such commercialism, claiming that it reduces the spiritual to the trivial. title: CHOICE TABLES;Fish-Loving Madrid
description: DEFYING all logic, Madrid -- set high on the arid plateau of central Castile, far from the sea -- is regarded as Spain's No. 1 "seaport." Up and down the Spanish Mediterranean and Atlantic coasts, hundreds of trucks and vans and even fleets of planes impatiently await the arrival of local fishing boats to speed the day's catch to Madrid -- so fast that the fish is often still twitching when it reaches its destination. With the longest shoreline of any European country, Spain has formidable quantities of the freshest seafood in a dazzling variety not likely to be found elsewhere in the world. And the best of the best is reserved for Madrid.

title: AN END TO WRATH
description: Euripides might have had a hand in this book. In 1942, Eric Lomax, a British signals officer in Singapore, became a Japanese prisoner and later was sent with others to Thailand, to build an impossible railroad into Burma, beyond the infamous bridge on the River Kwai. He was assigned to a shop crew, not to the rail laying that killed thousands. His mates built secret radios to keep abreast of the war, and he, a train enthusiast from youth, drew a detailed map of the planned rail route. Perhaps inevitably, as he says in THE RAILWAY MAN: A POW's Searing Account of War, Brutality and Forgiveness (Norton, $22), in late 1943 camp guards found the radios and the map. Mr. Lomax and other officers were savagely beaten with clubs for hours. Then, after days of grilling about his map, he was put through excruciating water tortures and spent the rest of the war starving and diseased, cooped in filthy cages. In later years he buried most of this in his mind, at hideous personal cost, but cherished real hatred for a Japanese interrogator who had acted as the translator. In 1989 a friend showed him a Japan Times story about one Takashi Nagase, a veteran who had spent his life atoning for Japanese war atrocities and who mentioned his own role in the water torture of a man who had drawn a map of the Burma-Siam railroad. Mr. Lomax, recognizing his interrogator in the newspaper's picture, felt an "icy joy"; he might sneak up and kill him. In fact, almost 50 years after he was tortured, he and his wife arranged to meet Mr. Nagase and his wife at the bridge on the Kwai. Eventually, overwhelmed by the depth of Mr. Nagase's lifelong grief and knowing that this man's Buddhist beliefs made it imperative that he be forgiven before he died, Mr. Lomax wrote a letter forgiving him everything and handed it to him, and the two old men parted comforting one another. In Athenian tragedy there was a point, after the horror and pity passed, when for some viewers the presence of a god was manifest -- not seen on stage, but there, terrifying and exalting. A few plays of Euripides can still let you feel a hint of that sublimity. It is obvious that all this is far from Mr. Lomax's mind. He has a straightforward story and he tells it quietly and with dignity. But at the end one feels the old dramatic shock: an amazed, even fearful suspicion that the curtain on eternity was pulled back slightly, for a moment. D. J. R. BRUCKNER

title:
ENDPAPER;
Keep Out! (A Boy's Bedroom)
description: Keep Out. Keep OUT. THIS MEANS YOU. Keep! Out! But Mom always comes in with the bogus excuse of "Here are some clean socks and underwear, I'll put them in your drawer." As if I can't get my own socks and underwear from the laundry room. But no, she just needs any excuse to come into my room and yell, "This room looks like a tornado hit it!" As if she has ever seen anything hit by a tornado. And then she's coming back dragging the vacuum cleaner, as if she has the right to vacuum my room! I go, "MOM, NEVER VACUUM IN HERE!" I got too many important things of life on that floor. Stuff that dropped that I'll need later. And my tarantula, which I swear to God hates my mom so much that the hairs fall off its abdomen, which is what happens to tarantulas when they get freaked, and Mom is always freaking my tarantula with the vacuum. She said I could have a gerbil, so I got a tarantula. Tell me what is the basic difference? I use the same fish tank that leaked all over the dresser and wrecked it, which I had to hear about for 5,000 years because that was her dresser when she was a kid. LIKE IT'S MY FAULT THE FISH TANK LEAKED AND I DIDN'T NOTICE UNTIL ALL THE WATER WAS OUT! WHAT ABOUT MY FISH, MOM, HUH? So that's why the dresser is all warped. It took a while for the water to leak out. I just thought it was evaporating superfast. I thought it was like a freak of the environment of my bedroom. CAN I HELP IT IF IT WAS LEAKING DOWN THE SIDE OF THE DRESSER I NEVER LOOK AT, MOM? And then you'd think that if it was already wrecked she wouldn't care if I put my eyeball stickers on the mirror and the wood, right? A normal person would normally think, It's Already Wrecked So What's the Dif. But she has a total attack and she has another total attack that I put eyeball stickers on my bed, IT IS MY BED BUT SHE HAS A TOTAL ATTACK, because it was her brother's bed or her cousin's bed or someone of her family's bed WHO IS OBVIOUSLY MORE IMPORTANT THAN HER SON WHO JUST WANTS TO PUT HIS EYEBALL STICKERS WHERE HE WANTS EXCEPT HE CAN'T BECAUSE HE LIVES IN A CONCENTRATION CAMP. Same goes for tape and nail holes in the wall. I go, "Mom, how am I supposed to put up my posters, then?" and she goes, "Oh, I'll buy you a bulletin board." THAT BULLETIN BOARD RIGHT THERE THAT I FILLED UP IN THREE SECONDS! I said, Forget it, man, this is boag, I'm using tape and then she has another total attack and makes me sign a Family Contract that when I leave for college I will personally paint my own room and sand down the tape marks or whatever it is you do with tape marks, which I will have to figure out because as you have noticed there is hardly no wall showing. That is my goal. Total posters. Including the ceiling. Oh, that's another thing. You notice the green light bulbs, right? At first when I bought them WITH MY OWN MONEY, MOM, she totally freaked because "Green light bulbs, green light bulbs? The neighbors will think you are growing drugs!" I go, Mom, what kind of drugs do you grow with green light bulbs? And she freaked and we had to have a family meeting where my dad was even there, which is totally weird because I think the total times my dad has even been in my room is like around zero AND NOW HE GETS A VOTE ON MY LIFE? Mom was freaking because she said it brought the value of the house down because my bedroom used to be in the front where the world could see it so that is how I scored this room that used to be my sister's. It smelled like a girl for around a month, during which I couldn't have no one over, but it was worth it for the green light bulbs. Don't they make you feel so peaceful? Wait. Listen to this song. Isn't it the perfect combination? I want to just listen to my station and lie in the peaceful green light and let my tarantula free. Its name is Dana, for this girl Dana Speers at my school who I swear to God looks just like a tarantula but in a cool way. No one I know knows I named it Dana. They think I named it Boris. It would be embarrassing if people knew. My mom would get all happy. "Oh, a girl in my son's life!" So if she comes in call it Boris. Actually, I snuck the actual Dana Speers up here to meet Dana Speers the tarantula. Dana Speers is a more interesting girl than normal. You wouldn't even think she's a girl from the way she is. She doesn't make no one nervous. I have sat right here and the actual Dana Speers has sat right where you are and we let the tarantula Dana Speers walk from my hand onto her hand, you know, that thing of letting a tarantula walk on you? And it was a trip because no hairs fell off the tarantula Dana Speers's abdomen when we did that. Which shows you what I said about the actual Dana Speers. And she, the actual Dana, has these superlong eyelashes and eyebrows, which some people think is freaky because it does look slightly monstery because there's hair all around her eyes, even right here in the corner par,t which I think looks insanely cool and you know that thing where if you get an eyelash from someone you can wish on it? And maybe even an eyebrow hair counts, too, I don't know. I just know for sure that one eyelash fell off of the actual Dana Speers when she was last over, but it would have been too weird of me to go for it while she was sitting there, so I waited until after she left and I am still looking for it because I got a really good wish I want to make and that's why I don't want my mom to vacuum in here. That and also she might suck up my tarantula.

Watchung Celebrates a Statesman
description: Charles Aubrey Eaton was a citizen of Watchung and the world. Dr. Eaton, who was born in Nova Scotia in 1868 and died in Washington 84 years later, was a Baptist minister before being elected to 14 terms in the House of Representatives as a Republican from New Jersey.

title: In Jimmy Buffett's Steps
description: Jimmy Buffett's songs celebrate a laid-back, unstructured way of life. So what could be more fitting than marketing an organized tour built around them? Beginning Nov. 1, Travel by Design, a Miami Beach company, will offer "Parrot Head" packages to Key West, the Caribbean, Los Angeles and other destinations mentioned in Buffett's songs. There will be plenty of margaritas, of course, on the four-day Key West package, and visits to some of the singer's favorite hangouts, like Captain Tony's Saloon. Through Dec. 21, rates including air fare from New York start at $470 a person, based on double occupancy. For information, call (800) 358-7125.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;Apostles of Cool Search for Higher Ground
description: OLD RIFFS, NEW POSES, BARE CHESTS, great hair -- that's the formula pushing both Lenny Kravitz and the Red Hot Chili Peppers on to MTV and up the pop charts. description: THE Westchester district of the United States Postal Service has announced a partnership with the state police in a program to help find missing or abducted children.

description: BEHOLD THE SUBWOOFER, the anonymous basso profundo of loudspeakers. Squat, faceless, shadowed of voice, typically hidden from view, the subwoofer gets no respect. title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: A FISH IN THE WATER: A Memoir By Mario Vargas Llosa. Translated by Helen Lane. Penguin, $14.95. The author is best known as a novelist, but he had a brief career as a politician. He explores both roles in this memoir, which describes his formative years as well as his 1990 run for President of Peru. The campaign was a debacle, but many predicted Mr. Vargas Llosa would use the experience to write "a good book," Alan Riding said here last year. "And he has." HEADING WEST By Doris Betts. Scribner Paperback, $12. Nancy Finch, an unmarried librarian, is the kind of woman nothing happens to. That is, until her vacation in North Carolina is interrupted by an armed man, who kidnaps her and proceeds to drive toward the Grand Canyon. Issues of responsibility and accountability arise as Nancy realizes she has become a silent partner in her own abduction. Just restored to print, this 1982 novel offers pleasures "infinitely more subtle, complex and memorable than being scared in your armchair," Beth Gutcheon wrote in these pages when it was published. She added, " 'Heading West' is a book of great delights." Ms. Betts's collection THE ASTRONOMER AND OTHER STORIES (Louisiana State University, $11.95) is also in print again. Many kinds of innocence are lost in these pieces, including, in the title novella, that of a retired man who has assumed he is beyond fantasy and desire. In 1966 our reviewer, Benedict Kiely, said the author "displays equally a rich imagination and disturbing vision." A NEW WORLD: An Epic of Colonial America From the Founding of Jamestown to the Fall of Quebec By Arthur Quinn. Berkley, $15. A historian details the many ways in which early America's idealism was either squelched or nonexistent. (John Smith's character, he notes, was not exactly as it is portrayed in Disney's "Pocahontas.") "His book is a scrumptious reminder of the pleasures of historical writing that rises to the level of literature," George F. Will wrote in the Book Review last year. ARABIAN NIGHTS & DAYS By Naguib Mahfouz. Translated by Denys Johnson-Davies. Anchor/Doubleday, $12. Many folk and fairy tales have a dark side, and this Egyptian Nobel laureate finds one throughout "The Arabian Nights." (Scheherazade's marriage to a lecherous murderer was hardly a happy ending.) His retelling can be read as a "daring and biting critique of the corruption of power in the modern Middle East," one critic said earlier this year. The same publisher has reissued Mr. Mahfouz's novel THE HARAFISH, translated by Catherine Cobham ($11), which depicts the fate of numerous generations of a family whose roots are in what Americans might call the underclass (and Arabs call the harafish). In 1994 one reviewer described it as "a whirling dervish of a good yarn." More Arabian tales can be found in DAMASCUS NIGHTS, by Rafik Schami, translated by Philip Boehm (Scribner Paperback, $11). In 1959 a great Syrian storyteller, struck mute by witchcraft, can regain his voice only if he is given seven unique gifts -- which turn out to be stories. The author "writes with wisdom, wit and lightheartedness," Malcolm Bradbury said here in 1993. TRUE NORTH: A Memoir By Jill Ker Conway. Vintage, $12. The author, who wrote of her childhood in the Australian outback in "The Road From Coorain," turns here to her adult challenges in a different wilderness: academia. She "has come a long way from the parched fields" she grew up in, Carol Brightman wrote in these pages last year. A woman's journeys are also the basis of AN UNSPOKEN HUNGER: Stories From the Field, by Terry Tempest Williams (Vintage, $10). This Utah-based writer and naturalist explores her own connections to the earth and those of women like Georgia O'Keeffe and Rachel Carson. In 1994 our reviewer, John Hanson Mitchell, praised the book's "dark strength and power." ONE TRUE THING By Anna Quindlen. Dell, $6.99. The narrator, a young journalist named Ellen Gulden, has to confront both the loss of her mother and the accusation that she ended her ill parent's suffering. As the novel depicts Kate Gulden's final days, "the reader cannot help caring about her, and mourning her death," Frederick Busch said in the Book Review last year. HENRY ADAMS By Ernest Samuels. Belknap/Harvard University, $16.95. This book, a revision and abridgment of the author's 1964 Pulitzer Prize-winning three-volume work, shows its subject to be more appealing as a historian and writer than as a human being. "It is a complete success" and "a remarkable feat of the biographer's art," Hugh Brogan wrote in these pages in 1989. OUT OF SILENCE: An Autistic Boy's Journey Into Language and Communication By Russell Martin. Penguin, $11.95. Speaking is so natural to most people that it is rarely remembered that every conversation is the result of a complex neurological process. The author writes of just how difficult it was for language to take hold in his autistic nephew's seething brain. The result is "deeply moving," F. Gonzalez-Crussi said here last year. THE TRIBE OF TIGER: Cats and Their Culture By Elizabeth Marshall Thomas. Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $12. Felines, by no means all aloof or solitary, are revealed in their complexity by the author of "The Hidden Life of Dogs." Whether writing of the cougar or the house kitty, "Ms. Thomas has an astute sense of the meaning of every meow," our reviewer, David Quammen, said in 1994. LAUREL GRAEBER

description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about injuries to musicians misidentified a doctor observing a violinist's technique. He was Dr. Martin W. Sklaire, not Dr. Peter Jokl.

title: POSTINGS: Work Resumes at Clason Point Site; New Condos For the Bronx
description: It once seemed that the sprawling middle-income condominium colony planned at the edge of the East River in the Clason Point section of the Bronx during the mid-80's construction boom had withered along with the market. But now work has begun on 84 units, signaling the first new construction in four years on the 55-acre site at White Plains Road and Soundview Avenue.

title:
VOICES: VIEWPOINT;
The Storm in This Port: A Battle Over Dredging
description: MANY New Yorkers and New Jerseyans don't realize they have a world-class seaport in their midst, a global gateway that brings them millions of tons of goods and funnels their products to international markets.

title: Sally F. Wright, Jonathan M. Waxman
description: Sally Foster Wright, a food and wine consultant in New York, was married yesterday to Jonathan Mark Waxman, the New York chef. Judge Philip S. Carchman of the New Jersey Superior Court in Trenton officiated at LaFollette Vineyards and Winery in Belle Mead, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the performance of the Kaufmann Fund referred incorrectly to the Montgomery Small Cap mutual fund, which was recommended as an alternative investment. The Montgomery fund is not open to new investors.

title:
NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;
Vendors: Congestion vs. Digestion
description: Call it the midtown food fight. Vendors selling everything from sugar-coated peanuts to gourmet soups want to be where the crowds are. Midtown businesses want the vendors to be where the crowds are not. The customers want a cheap lunch. The Giuliani administration wants to enforce the laws, help the tax base and combat the enemy-du-jour, congestion.

title:
CHOICE TABLES;
Fish-Loving Madrid
description: DEFYING all logic, Madrid -- set high on the arid plateau of central Castile, far from the sea -- is regarded as Spain's No. 1 "seaport." Up and down the Spanish Mediterranean and Atlantic coasts, hundreds of trucks and vans and even fleets of planes impatiently await the arrival of local fishing boats to speed the day's catch to Madrid -- so fast that the fish is often still twitching when it reaches its destination. With the longest shoreline of any European country, Spain has formidable quantities of the freshest seafood in a dazzling variety not likely to be found elsewhere in the world. And the best of the best is reserved for Madrid.

description: The police came sometime after midnight. Farieda Coetzee had been doing the dishes and went to see what the fuss was all about at her gate. There she found herself arrested, hustled into the back of a van and then taken to the local prison. Her crime? She owed $42.

title: EARNING IT;In TV Land, Work Involves a Lot of Play
description: IF this fall's new shows are any indication, American productivity is in trouble.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Psst! Some Chess? Q. I've often wondered this when I see the chess hustlers in Washington Square Park: How good are they? A. Victor Frias, an international master who has been watching the players in Washington Square Park for 15 years, likens the hustlers there to pool sharks. "They're good enough to hustle, good enough to take money of unsuspecting customers, but not good enough to be professionals," Mr. Frias said.

title: REVERSE ENGLISH
description: There is a more nearly canonical version of Jack Rosenthal's tale of the "double positive," and it has names attached. The English philosopher Stuart Hampshire observed that in all languages a double negative made a positive, but not the reverse, and Sidney Morgenbesser was heard to mutter (loudly), "Yeah, yeah." Se non e vero e ben trovato. (If it's not true, it might as well be.)

title: South of the Border
description: "Under that basket of fruit and vegetables, a well-oiled brain is ticking away," says the director Helena Solberg of Brazil's most famous export in her film CARMEN MIRANDA: BANANAS IS MY BUSINESS on P.O.V., FRIDAY at 10 P.M. on CHANNEL 13.

title: Dead Bomb Suspect's Ties Still a Mystery in France
description: The young Algerian fugitive shot by the police near Lyons on Friday was apparently linked to at least three recent terrorist actions in France, officials said today. title: THE CAPITALIST;The Beckner Effect
description: EARLY LAST MONTH, a friend of mine who trades bonds on Wall Street phoned to tell me about something she called the Beckner Effect. As I understood her, there was this journalist in Washington named Beckner whom no one on Wall Street had ever laid eyes on but whose articles about Federal Reserve Board policy regularly sent the whole of the multitrillion-dollar American bond market into epileptic convulsions. "You are sitting at your desk and you think you've got the market all figured out," my friend explained, "and then all of a sudden there's one of these kamikaze events. The market dives, 10 lights start to flash and everyone at once is calling to ask you if you saw the Beckner article."

For DOME Gardeners, New Plot, With Dome

description: With whirring airplanes in the background, taxi drivers waiting at Kennedy International Airport lean against their yellow cabs and tell the tale of the one long trip that made their day. Maybe it was the $200 fare to Riverhead, L.I., or perhaps the $300 ride to Stamford, Conn.

title: To Last Hour, Agency Staff Is On the Job
description: Someone on the staff put up a large sign in front of the building that read: "Unemployed Agency: Inquire Within." Confused by the homemade sign, several people wandered in on Friday, looking for job applications.

title: SUNDAY October 1, 1995; A QUESTION FOR: Gil C. Alicea
description: Q: Did it help to write about your tough times? A: It helped a lot because I know a lot of people will learn from me, get an education. I'm not the only person who went through a lot of those situations. A lot of times I wanted to speak out but I didn't know how. I got lucky -- I got a book deal. The book made the worst situation into the best situation and gave me less pain and more happiness. I can read it, look at it and always learn something new about myself. It's like a bible; you read the Bible and you would think, "Oh, I read the whole book." You go over it again and think, "I missed this," or "Wow, I said this." You think, if a kid can go through this, that gives someone else the willpower to go straight through tragedies. It's a positive thing.

description: From his fifth-floor fire escape facing Washington Street, Zachary Weinstein can watch tug boats plying the Hudson River. But that view will be obliterated if a proposed apartment complex goes up on the parking lot that fronts his building.

title: Ground Zero, 50 Years After the Blast
description: STANDING alone in the wind outside the National Atomic Museum in Albuquerque, N.M., a white-haired visitor from Nebraska took a long look at a replica of Little Boy, the bomb that killed more than 200,000 people in Hiroshima half a century ago. He tapped the bomb's stainless-steel casing and examined its short fins. "I was in the Marianas when that thing went off," he remarked later, remembering his profound relief that the war with Japan might soon be over because of the stunning new weapon.

description: The air was sharp and still last Saturday night, but inside a gargantuan tent here, thousands of Indian immigrants were enveloped by heat, swirling colors and mesmerizing music.

title: STYLENIGHT SHIFT
description: I'd like to grab some shut-eye now, but I'm too pooped. There's too much damage control to do first; all those body parts that run riot without a firm hand. Say I don't do those hundred brush strokes that stimulate my scalp by activating mitotic cell growth? Tomorrow I'll be sporting haglike wisps and parched bangs. In short, a bad hair day.

description: THE Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is beginning a major restoration of the Marine Air Terminal in Queens, a round Art Deco structure, ringed by a frieze of winged fish symbolic of the Pan Am Clippers for which it was built. But the Clipper seaplanes vanished long ago -- if you want to arrive by water, you'll have to come by boat.

title: GIVING DRUGS A GOOD NAME
description: The only useful information I found in the article was a possible explanation for Trexan's high price. What with the Du Pont Merck Pharmaceutical Corporation's paying focus-group participants $100 an hour to consider names, it's no wonder treatment with Trexan will set a patient back thousands of dollars. NICOLE CORDREY Brooklyn

title: Rules of the Road on Pornography
description: Angry debates over sexually explicit movies, pictures and other material are always raging in one forum or another. But with potentially offensive materials readily available on cable television, on-line computer services and other media, many Americans are demanding more and more protections for children and other viewers. The push to create safeguards is understandable, but it should not be allowed to diminish the fundamental right to free expression or the equally basic right of consenting adults to decide for themselves what to watch or read.

title: Towns Just Saying 'No' to Federal Funds
description: IN an era of fiscal austerity, it may seem incredible that any town in Connecticut would reject nearly $1 million in Federal and state grant money aimed at improving a local road. But last month, the town of Guilford did just that. It turned down a package of government aid and opted to fix the road with its own money. Earlier this year, the town of Redding also decided to go it alone, rejecting $347,000 in Federal and state transportation money to fix a beloved historic bridge on a scenic road. Skeptical about traditional approaches to state and Federal road design that a growing number of residents believe are excessive and tend to erode the distinct features of Connecticut's landscape, more and more towns across the state are debating whether to follow the same route.

title: Dark History
description: THE BOOK OF COLOR By Julia Blackburn. 175 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $22. IN Julia Blackburn's first novel, "The Book of Color," the unnamed narrator retreats to her childhood home, an ancestral sanctuary that is, appropriately enough, a vicarage. As the family's holy ground, the place is filled with many crosses to bear -- so many, in fact, that she must undertake a kind of exorcism of memory. Only by imagining her way into her grandfather's tormented childhood on a tiny island in the Indian Ocean will she be able, as she explains it, to "step away from the fear, shuffle it off like a skin that has grown too tight."

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: First Chelsea, Then Moscow. Now, Park Avenue South. David Rabin was a bank vice president. Will Regan was a lawyer at a large Manhattan firm. They hated their jobs but loved going to parties. So the two men, friends since college, quit and opened a bar in Chelsea. Then they helped open a nightclub in Moscow.

But cashing out of the market is not the only cure: buying funds that invest in inexpensive stocks that pay healthy dividends can provide some relief. While these funds tend to suffer when interest rates plummet, as they did last year, they also tend to hold up better in any kind of market drop.

title:
ART;
Pictures Out of Africa and Out of War
description: AN astonishing photographic odyssey is at the Yale Center for British Art; it is a 120-work retrospective of Constance Stuart Larrabee, who was born in England in 1914, but raised in South Africa. The focus is on South Africa but in the middle of the exhibition is stirring documentation of World War II. Ms. Larrabee photographed the European theater as South Africa's first female war correspondent. The show closes on a genteel note: she now lives in Chestertown, Md., where she raises dogs while continuing to take pictures.

Midtown businesses want the vendors to be where the crowds are not. The customers want a cheap lunch. The Giuliani administration wants to enforce the laws, help the tax base and combat the enemy-du-jour, congestion.

title: Elusive Beauty Entangled In the Tides

title: Helping Big Trees Survive
description: You can help out big trees suffering from drought by a process called deep-root fertilization, which is completely different from sprinkling an all-purpose fertilizer around the tree in the spring (an absolute no-no this time of year, because granular fertilizers are high in salts, which can burn roots, and high in nitrogen, which stimulates leaf growth). But with deep-root fertilization, using a soil spear or deep-root fertilizer needle, you can apply organic fertilizers, like Essentials or Roots, to the roots to stimulate growth without burning them.

title: SO YOU WANT TO WIN A NOBEL PRIZE
description: EACH AUTUMN, ON A Thursday morning, a strange ritual takes place in Stockholm. In an elegant 18th-century room around a long table, under a high chandelier and before a bust of King Gustav III, a dozen or so men and women write down a name on a piece of paper. The pieces of paper are then collected in a stop, an antique silver tankard, and the names are totted up. At 1 P.M., exactly, the group's delegate returns to his office, where a large number of journalists have gathered, and reads out the name that has recurred most often on those pieces of paper. In this way, each October, the winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature is delivered to the world.

"I was in the Marianas when that thing went off," he remarked later, remembering his profound relief that the war with Japan might soon be over because of the stunning new weapon.

title: Old Jeff May Be Raising Hourly Voice
description: The Jefferson Market Courthouse, with its fantastical Victorian Gothic clock tower, is one of Greenwich Village's most prominent visual landmarks. Now, a group of residents are determined to make it an audible landmark as well. Old Jeff, as the 12,500-pound bell behind the clock face is called, served as a fire alarm until the 1870's. Since then, it has hung silent in the tower of the building, now a New York Public Library branch. The group, led by the preservationist Margot Gayle, expects to raise $10,000 for an electric mechanism to strike the bronze bell hourly. It is seeking a public hearing to determine whether the bell should sound round the clock or fall silent late at night. The prospect of neighborhood pealing reminds Norma Leavey, president of the West 10th Street Block Association, of when she lived in Europe. "Except for Sundays, you just don't hear bells in New York," she said. "I could use a reminder of the time since I don't wear a watch."

title: DIARY
description: HOTSHOTS How to Lose a Billion What a glorious world they've made for themselves, those hotshots with fancy computers and sleek pocket phones and grim faces, juggling the world's billions with a deftness that chess masters would envy. No one would dare pester these Masters of the Universe with nerdy questions like, "Are you, O Great One, by any chance making up those numbers?" Apparently no one asked Toshihide Iguchi that question -- or at least looked very hard for an answer. For last week authorities charged that Mr. Iguchi, a bond trader at Daiwa Bank, had gone into an 11-year spiral of falsifying records in a desperate attempt to recoup trading losses -- and wound up a staggering $1.1 billion in the red.... So do bond traders tend to do things in a big way? It seems so. For while most baseball fans are content to grumble and munch if their boys let them down, on Thursday a Chicago bond trader ran onto the field and attacked a Cubs pitcher who'd just given up a home run. Ah, sports! INVESTIGATIONS Following Archer-Daniels Money The plot thickens at Archer-Daniels-Midland. Mark Whitacre -- you remember: the Archer executive who turned Government informant and raised cries of price-fixing -- has apparently admitted to crimes related to company money he received, and though no plea deal has been reached, he is cooperating with an inquiry. But what was this money? The company says it was embezzled, but some executives are offering another script entirely: that Archer paid millions -- illegally and off the books -- to a number of executives through foreign bank accounts. If that's true, the "embezzlement" becomes a scheme to let top executives indulge in that all-too-common pastime: evading income taxes. What's true? Stay tuned. EXECUTIVE PAY Ted Turner, Wage-Earner What made Ted Turner give up the power of running his own show? Surely it wasn't money. There's only so much one person can spend in this world. But at a certain level -- way, way up beyond paying the bills -- salary figures take on a life of their own. Mr. Turner's pay is clearly up in that never-never land -- especially for a No. 2 executive. With options and such corner-office goodies, he's said to be making more than $100 million over five years -- far more even than Gerald Levin, his boss at Time Warner. Then again, even that fantasy paycheck seems almost incidental, for Mr. Turner is getting $2.6 billion in Time Warner stock. BUDGET CUTS They're Saying the 'S' Words No, that rumbling you heard last week was not an earthquake, or New Jersey being replaced by a golf course. It was -- brace yourself -- the budget-cutters saying the "S" words. Normally, politicians would kick babies before they'd cut Social Security, but these are not normal times -- austerity is such a passion that babies across the land are surely being named "Newt Smith" or "Budget Cut Jones." So sure enough, senators from both parties suggested shaving cost-of-living increases -- a panel of economists just said, after all, that the Consumer Price Index overstates inflation. Pat Moynihan said $281 billion could be saved over seven years that way. "The money is sitting there," he said, "asking to be picked up." If they pick it up, though, will they be pummeled by retirees? DEBT COLLECTION Your Taxes or Your Kneecaps If Congressional Republicans have their way, it won't just be the I.R.S. knocking on your door wondering if, pretty please, you could pay your taxes. It could be practically anyone. The legislators want to turn over some dunning tasks to private bill collectors to see if they can do it better -- raising all sorts of nasty privacy issues. It's all, of course, part of the whole budget mess -- the Administration wanted to increase the I.R.S. budget nearly 10 percent; Republicans want to cut it. To Margaret Milner Richardson, the I.R.S. Commissioner, this budget-trimming is misguided, for it's accepted wisdom that tax enforcers bring in far more than their salaries. "No sound business person," she said, "would not spend money to make money." TRANSPORTATION A Slippery Road There must be a better way, drivers mutter as they inch through exhaust-fouled air, past perpetual construction, to drop coins in a state toll basket. But are we ready for private highways? Well, ready or not, they're here, with a 14-mile road linking Dulles Airport and Leesburg, Va., opening this weekend -- the first privately financed toll road built this century. With the public sector "just tapped out," as one executive put it, this may sometimes be the only way to build a road. But just think what today's maniacal marketers could do with this. There could be rival thruways, each bombarding drivers with ads for, say, wider lanes, smoother surfaces, better views, free meals, toll sales -- perhaps even drive-by movies, but that sounds risky. EDUCATION Cheaper Than a Luxury Car The bad news: college costs keep rising faster than inflation -- 6 percent last year, the College Board said last week. With total costs at top colleges nearing $30,000, and with Federal grants and loans tight, students face "a deeply mortgaged future," said the head of the College Board. But there's good news too. "There are some tremendous bargains out there," said an official of the American Council on Education. Two years ago, "61 percent of all American college students spent less than $3,000 in tuition and fees." EXECUTIVES An 'Odd Meal' at I.B.M.? It takes a tough man to make a tender computer? No, that doesn't work. A PC in every pot? Oh, never mind. Let I.B.M. figure it out. Louis Gerstner certainly knew what he was doing last week when he picked J. Bruce Harreld, president of Boston Chicken, as chief strategist. Still, one analyst couldn't resist saying, "That's an odd meal -- cookies with chicken, sprinkled over silicon chips." THE PAPAL VISIT The Priceless and the Profane You can't put a price on something like seeing the Pope, an experience presumably far beyond worldly matters. That's why most tickets to this week's Mass at Giants Stadium were given out by lottery at local churches. And yet, in this imperfect world, few things can escape: ads were spotted in New Jersey papers last week offering to swap those priceless tickets for coin of the profane realm.

description: To the Editor:

title: ENDPAPER;Keep Out! (A Boy's Bedroom)
description: Keep Out. Keep OUT. THIS MEANS YOU. Keep! Out! But Mom always comes in with the bogus excuse of "Here are some clean socks and underwear, I'll put them in your drawer." As if I can't get my own socks and underwear from the laundry room. But no, she just needs any excuse to come into my room and yell, "This room looks like a tornado hit it!" As if she has ever seen anything hit by a tornado. And then she's coming back dragging the vacuum cleaner, as if she has the right to vacuum my room! I go, "MOM, NEVER VACUUM IN HERE!" I got too many important things of life on that floor. Stuff that dropped that I'll need later. And my tarantula, which I swear to God hates my mom so much that the hairs fall off its abdomen, which is what happens to tarantulas when they get freaked, and Mom is always freaking my tarantula with the vacuum. She said I could have a gerbil, so I got a tarantula. Tell me what is the basic difference? I use the same fish tank that leaked all over the dresser and wrecked it, which I had to hear about for 5,000 years because that was her dresser when she was a kid. LIKE IT'S MY FAULT THE FISH TANK LEAKED AND I DIDN'T NOTICE UNTIL ALL THE WATER WAS OUT! WHAT ABOUT MY FISH, MOM, HUH? So that's why the dresser is all warped. It took a while for the water to leak out. I just thought it was evaporating superfast. I thought it was like a freak of the environment of my bedroom. CAN I HELP IT IF IT WAS LEAKING DOWN THE SIDE OF THE DRESSER I NEVER LOOK AT, MOM? And then you'd think that if it was already wrecked she wouldn't care if I put my eyeball stickers on the mirror and the wood, right? A normal person would normally think, It's Already Wrecked So What's the Dif. But she has a total attack and she has another total attack that I put eyeball stickers on my bed, IT IS MY BED BUT SHE HAS A TOTAL ATTACK, because it was her brother's bed or her cousin's bed or someone of her family's bed WHO IS OBVIOUSLY MORE IMPORTANT THAN HER SON WHO JUST WANTS TO PUT HIS EYEBALL STICKERS WHERE HE WANTS EXCEPT HE CAN'T BECAUSE HE LIVES IN A CONCENTRATION CAMP. Same goes for tape and nail holes in the wall. I go, "Mom, how am I supposed to put up my posters, then?" and she goes, "Oh, I'll buy you a bulletin board." THAT BULLETIN BOARD RIGHT THERE THAT I FILLED UP IN THREE SECONDS! I said, Forget it, man, this is boag, I'm using tape and then she has another total attack and makes me sign a Family Contract that when I leave for college I will personally paint my own room and sand down the tape marks or whatever it is you do with tape marks, which I will have to figure out because as you have noticed there is hardly no wall showing. That is my goal. Total posters. Including the ceiling. Oh, that's another thing. You notice the green light bulbs, right? At first when I bought them WITH MY OWN MONEY, MOM, she totally freaked because "Green light bulbs, green light bulbs? The neighbors will think you are growing drugs!" I go, Mom, what kind of drugs do you grow with green light bulbs? And she freaked and we had to have a family meeting where my dad was even there, which is totally weird because I think the total times my dad has even been in my room is like around zero AND NOW HE GETS A VOTE ON MY LIFE? Mom was freaking because she said it brought the value of the house down because my bedroom used to be in the front where the world could see it so that is how I scored this room that used to be my sister's. It smelled like a girl for around a month, during which I couldn't have no one over, but it was worth it for the green light bulbs. Don't they make you feel so peaceful? Wait. Listen to this song. Isn't it the perfect combination? I want to just listen to my station and lie in the peaceful green light and let my tarantula free. Its name is Dana, for this girl Dana Speers at my school who I swear to God looks just like a tarantula but in a cool way. No one I know knows I named it Dana. They think I named it Boris. It would be embarrassing if people knew. My mom would get all happy. "Oh, a girl in my son's life!" So if she comes in call it Boris. Actually, I snuck the actual Dana Speers up here to meet Dana Speers the tarantula. Dana Speers is a more interesting girl than normal. You wouldn't even think she's a girl from the way she is. She doesn't make no one nervous. I have sat right here and the actual Dana Speers has sat right where you are and we let the tarantula Dana Speers walk from my hand onto her hand, you know, that thing of letting a tarantula walk on you? And it was a trip because no hairs fell off the tarantula Dana Speers's abdomen when we did that. Which shows you what I said about the actual Dana Speers. And she, the actual Dana, has these superlong eyelashes and eyebrows, which some people think is freaky because it does look slightly monstery because there's hair all around her eyes, even right here in the corner par,t which I think looks insanely cool and you know that thing where if you get an eyelash from someone you can wish on it? And maybe even an eyebrow hair counts, too, I don't know. I just know for sure that one eyelash fell off of the actual Dana Speers when she was last over, but it would have been too weird of me to go for it while she was sitting there, so I waited until after she left and I am still looking for it because I got a really good wish I want to make and that's why I don't want my mom to vacuum in here. That and also she might suck up my tarantula.

title: Medicare Compromise Still Possible
description: Medicare reform might well be the most important legislation the Republicans will pass this year. The G.O.P. promised to protect health care for the elderly and, if possible, apply some of the savings toward deficit reduction. The bill the Senate Finance Committee approved last week turns those priorities upside down. Above all else, it cuts $270 billion out of the program, a figure driven by the need to balance the budget in seven years. The mammoth cuts jeopardize the quality of care provided to the elderly.

description: In convicting Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman and nine others yesterday conspiring to carry out a campaign of bombings and assassinations, a Federal jury vindicated the Government's claim that an Islamic terrorist cell has been operating in the United States for at least four years. But despite eight months of evidence, 125 secretly recorded tapes, a highly paid informer and 200 other witnesses, the trial shed precious little light on the questions that remain unanswered about the bombing of the World Trade Center in February 1993.

title: Combating Gambling in Schools
description: To cope with what it perceives as an emerging epidemic among young residents, the New Jersey Council on Compulsive Gambling will hold a seminar today for high school counselors. Approximately 12 percent of high school students in the state have a problem with gambling, said Ed Looney, the council's director. After the seminar, guidance counselors will be expected to conduct regional seminars for student leaders, Mr. Looney said.

description: The only thing more hateful than the filthy rich may be the filthy poor. That is the pointedly inflammatory premise of "Sixteen Oh Sixty," a taunting comic satire that sinks its teeth into the Brazilian class system and won't let go. The first feature by Vinicius Mainardi, a film maker from Sao Paulo, the movie follows the disastrous events that ensue when Vittorio (Antonio Calloni), a corrupt, porcine businessman, succumbs to a rare pang of conscience.

title: Phone-Line Plan in Japan
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, at the center of a debate over whether its monopoly is stifling competition in Japan's telecommunications industry, said last week that it was ready to give rivals full use of its local phone lines. Competing telephone and data communications services will be able to hook up to NTT lines within two years, NTT said. The decision will have a severe impact on NTT's profits, the company said. The company's rivals said the plan did not alter the fact that Nippon still controlled the lines. The lack of details on how much the company plans to charge service operators makes it difficult to assess the benefits, they said.

title: School Concerned Over Future

Katzenbach School for the Deaf has risen sharply as a result of a steep cut in state subsidies -- to $2.9 million in the current school year, from $4 million in 1994-95. As a result, local districts must pay $18,125 for each day student, 16 percent more than before, and $25,830 for each boarding student, an increase of 20 percent, officials said. At a school picnic yesterday, the New Jersey Association of the Deaf and other groups worried about the school's future said they were joining forces to try to prevent further budget-cutting.

title: Questions Raised in Crash of Parachutists' Plane

title: A VISIT FROM THE POPE: THE FAITHFUL;Vibrant Parishes Find Strength in Diversity
description: The parish demographics have changed wildly, even weekly, in the nine decades since German immigrants built St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in Queens. Last Sunday, a young Filipino woman's voice rang out from the Ridgewood church's choir loft, while down below a Vietnamese grandmother rocked her infant grandchild. Hispanic and Indian schoolchildren stood together, and older Polish and Italian men knelt with their thick arms and rosary beads hanging before them.

description: Small structured handbags to complement fashion's current restrained mood abound. title: Egypt Plays Down Conviction In New York in Terrorist Trial
description: The Government-controlled news media here gave little prominence today to Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman's conviction on conspiring to carry out a terrorist campaign in the United States, apparently in an attempt to minimize public attention on the fate of the militant Muslim cleric.

title: Aditya Vikram Birla, 51, A Leading Indian Businessman
description: Aditya Vikram Birla, the chairman of the $2.3-billion Birla Group and an advocate of expanding Indian economic activity abroad, died Sunday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore of complications arising from pneumonia, according to his business associates.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: SCHOOL SYSTEM SEEN IN STATE OF CRISIS Declaring the New York City school system in a state of crisis, Sheldon Silver, the Speaker of the State Assembly, announced a meeting of top state, city, school board and union officials to plot out a new structure for the Board of Education. [Page A1.]

title: AT&T INTERACTIVE SYSTEM DRAWS TOO LITTLE INTEREST
description: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it was shelving its Home Center interactive television system because it did not attract enough consumer interest. AT&T also said it had failed to sign up enough service providers to make the system affordable. AT&T tested system prototypes this summer and found that most consumers were unwilling to pay for it. The system was to include a remote control and a computer box that sits atop a television set. It was intended to let users look at television listings, listen to their telephone messages, pay bills, check the value of stock portfolios and receive local weather and traffic updates.

title: PLAYOFFS;This Season, TV Doesn't Have It Covered

description: Striving to transform itself from a highly cyclical pipeline, chemicals and heavy equipment company into a smoothly growing manufacturer, Tenneco Inc. announced today that it would acquire the Mobil Corporation's plastics division for $1.27 billion.

title: Correction

title: At Board Offices, The Silence Grows
description: Walk along the executive wing atop the cavernous Board of the Education headquarters in downtown Brooklyn, and what is most striking is the silence. The airy corner office of the deputy schools chancellor has been empty since midsummer. Next door is another vacant office, the former deputy's. Down the hall is the office of the chief operations officer, who is preparing to resign next week. Lost in the recent political sniping was an inexorable fact: Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines leaves office in 10 days, and there is no replacement and few top officers left to run the system.

description: THE members of the most widely endangered family of organisms in the United States have neither fur nor feathers, and hardly any friends. title: JUDGE DENIES REQUEST TO BLOCK A BID FOR BALLY GAMING
description: A Federal judge has denied a request by Bally Gaming International Inc. and WMS Industries for a preliminary injunction to block the Alliance Gaming Corporation's hostile effort to acquire Bally. In a Sept. 5 suit, Bally Gaming and WMS argued that Alliance had not adequately disclosed details about its investors and its ability to complete the transaction. United States District Judge Sue Robinson in Wilmington, Del., ruled that enough public information was available on Alliance for investors to make decisions on whether to support Alliance's bid or Bally Gaming's agreement to be acquired by WMS. Alliance said yesterday that it had extended its tender offer to acquire Bally Gaming, which makes slot and video gaming machines and is based in Las Vegas, Nev., to Oct. 16. Alliance has offered to buy 59.5 percent of Bally Gaming's shares for $13 each in cash.

Although the team would not disclose terms, the contract is believed to be worth $5.6 million. That is the most the 6-11 forward could make under the league's new collective-bargaining agreement. (AP)

description: Southern Electric P.L.C., Britain's second-largest regional power distribution company, agreed yesterday to be acquired by National Power P.L.C., the nation's largest generator of electricity, for $:2.8 billion, or $4.4 billion.

description: Westinghouse has pledged to expand CBS's roster of children's educational programs from one hour a week to three if it acquires the network. The BBC's American branch has just created a children's programming division. Children's Television Workshop, the creator of PBS series like "Sesame Street," is discussing a production deal with a commercial network.

description: Ranking Irish and British officials say that they are close to resolving the issue that has blocked the Northern Ireland peace effort for months -- the dispute over the disarmament of the Irish Republican Army and the scheduling of full-fledged talks.

description: A state investigation into the death of a 4-year-old Manhattan girl several days after she had a routine tonsillectomy has faulted both her health maintenance organization and the hospital where she had her surgery.

description: The Kmart Corporation said today that it would sell all 6.1 million shares it owns of Sports Authority Inc. at $26 a share.

title: Nets and O'Bannon Are Set
description: The Nets have called a news conference for this afternoon to announce the signing of ED O'BANNON, their first-round draft choice. O'Bannon, a 6-foot-8-inch forward, led U.C.L.A. to the National Collegiate Athletic Association title last season, averaging 20.4 points a game. Contract terms were not disclosed, but O'Bannon, the No. 9 pick in the June draft, probably signed a three-year contract worth around $3.9 million, under terms of the new rookie wage scale.

title: Blueprinting Princeton Stadium
description: When Princeton University's Palmer Memorial Stadium was built in 1914 of reinforced concrete, it represented advanced technology. But the 40,000-seat stadium is deteriorating, and yesterday the university announced that Rafael Vinoly, a New York-based architect, would design its replacement.

description: An article yesterday about the impending decision of Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, on whether to seek re-election in 1996 misidentified the chamber in which his great-uncle Carl Vinson served. It was the House.

title: PLAYOFFS;Ex-Yankees Make Good in Seattle
description: If living well is truly the best revenge, then Lou Piniella, Jay Buhner, Woody Woodward and Mike Blowers should be in their glory this week.

title: INTERMET SAYS OFFER WAS UNSOLICITED
description: The Intermet Corporation, a maker of precision iron parts for auto makers and other industrial customers, said yesterday that it had received an unsolicited offer worth $337.5 million from GWM Inc. of Atlanta and Kelso & Company, the New York-based investment bank, to acquire all of Intermet's common stock for $13.50 a share in cash. The stock of Intermet, which has moved its headquarters from Atlanta to Detroit, rose $1.875, to $13.125, on Nasdaq. "It's an absurdly low offer," said Phillip Fricke, a Prudential Securities analyst. Intermet said its board had not yet reviewed the proposal. Intermet reported a loss of $11 million on sales of $501 million in 1994.

title: Gospel Roots Reaching The Heart and the Soul
description: The Dixie Hummingbirds, one of gospel music's most venerable quartets, were preceded on Sunday night at Symphony Space by an opening act that was difficult to follow. It was a documentary film about the group, which has been using the Lord's name in song since 1928, well before gospel helped bring about secular styles like rhythm-and-blues, doo-wop and soul. Directed by Ashley James and titled "We Love You Like a Rock," after the hit song the group sang with Paul Simon in 1973 ("Love Me Like a Rock"), the film showed the group backstage, onstage and at home.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: ON FOOTBALL;The Long Reach of Eddie Robinson
description: Immediately after the Oakland Raiders' 47-10 victory over the Jets on Sunday night, Willie Brown, the Raiders' director of squad development, sought out Curtis Ceaser, the Jets' rookie wide receiver. The two walked off the field and through the tunnel. Brown, 54, did the talking, Ceaser, 23, did the listening. When it came time to part they shook hands and went their separate ways: Brown to the Raiders' black and silver, Ceaser to the Jets' green and white.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Find Their Center: Sweeney Signs at Waiver Draft
description: The Rangers, in search of another center, nearly obtained Bob Sweeney from Buffalo at last season's trading deadline. So the Islanders' timing seemed appropriate today as they claimed Sweeney during the National Hockey League waiver draft, hours before they met the Rangers in an exhibition game at Nassau Coliseum.

description: It must be frustrating for a director to stage an opera as popular and steeped in tradition as Puccini's "Tosca." What can you do that hasn't been done?

title: No Headline
description: BOSTON BANCORP, Boston, appointed Robert E. Lee chairman, chief executive and president, succeeding Peter Hersey, who served as chairman and acting president and chief executive since February. Mr. Hersey, a director since 1973, will remain on the board. CHEVRON CORP., San Francisco, said J. Dennis Bonney, vice chairman, would retire at the end of the year. Mr. Bonney will turn 65, the mandatory retirement age for senior Chevron executives, in December. He has been with the oil company for 35 years.

title: Cains Food Is Sold
description: The Dutch food and beverage company Koninklijke Bolswessanen N.V. said today that it had sold its Cains Food unit to an investor, Denis Keaveny. Terms were not disclosed. Cains, based in Ayer, Mass., produces and markets mayonnaise, dressings and pickles. The company has annual sales of about $60 million.

title: PLAYOFFS;Fans Fulfill Steinbrenner's Wish: Two Sellouts
description: George Steinbrenner apparently still has some public relations flair. Five days after the Yankee owner criticized fans for being fickle and wondered whether they would support the team in the post-season, the organization announced yesterday that the first-round playoff games at Yankee Stadium tonight and tomorrow night are sold out.

title: No Headline
description: BOSTON BANCORP, Boston, appointed Robert E. Lee chairman, chief executive and president, succeeding Peter Hersey, who served as chairman and acting president and chief executive since February. Mr. Hersey, a director since 1973, will remain on the board.

title: PRICES OF SOME SOFTWARE PRODUCTS CUT BY MICROSOFT
description: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that it had reduced prices on some home software products, cutting the prices consumers will pay by as much as 45 percent. Microsoft will offer more than 30 titles for less than $50 each and some for as little as $29.99. A Microsoft spokesman said the new pricing did not apply to Windows 95 software. The company, based in Redmond, Wash., said it based the cuts on research and in-store tests in which some retailers' sales increased when prices were cut.

title: At Long Last, Anderson Quits
description: SPARKY ANDERSON will always follow the Detroit Tigers. He just will not manage them again. Anderson, the winningest manager in Tigers history, resigned yesterday after 17 years that included a World Series championship in 1984 and the American League East title in 1987.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EMMA THOMPSON and KENNETH BRANAGH, the British film stars who were married in 1989, have often been referred to as the next Laurence Olivier and Vivien Leigh. Now, they are following in those venerable theatrical footsteps, not on stage, but toward divorce court.

title: His Broken Leg Healed, Pope Enjoys Good Health
description: Pope John Paul II's recovery from the surgery for a broken leg that forced him to cancel a visit to the United States in 1994 was much slower than expected, but he is now fully healed and in excellent health, the Vatican says.

title: TEXACO TO CUT ITS WORK FORCE BY ANOTHER 1,500
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it expected to post a charge of $55 million against earnings for the third quarter to cut its work force by an additional 1,500 people. Texaco, the oil company based in White Plains, said it had already reduced its work force by 2,500 people under a plan announced in June 1994. The plan, which included the sale of assets and changes in management, has produced $300 million in annual savings, the company said. Texaco said it would extend the plan to save another $150 million a year by eliminating the 1,500 jobs by the end of 1996. The jobs will be cut through continuing efforts to reduce the management ranks and by giving work to outside vendors. The company employs about 26,000 people.

description: LINCOLN By David Herbert Donald Illustrated. 714 pages. Simon & Schuster. $35.

title: Kasparov Steamrollers a Lackluster Anand
description: The downfall of a contender for the world chess championship goes like this. First come second-rate moves that create problems. Then agonizing over the problems produces tension, which produces errors. Then the opponent lights up the board with explosive power. This was Viswanathan Anand's misfortune yesterday in Game 13 of his match against the champion, Gary Kasparov.

title: Weak Manufacturing Data Point to More Slow Growth
description: Consumer spending rose strongly in August, while manufacturing activity remained weak in September, new data showed today, pointing to continued slow economic growth.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Bloomberg Business News in Business Day on Thursday about a Commerce Department report on orders for durable goods in August misstated the previously reported decline in orders in July. It was 2.1 percent, not 2.7 percent.

title: Even Its Allies Castigate U.S. Over Failure to Pay U.N. Dues
description: Britain's Foreign Secretary called it "representation without taxation." Australia's Foreign Minister suggested Washington could lose its United Nations voting rights. The Nordic countries as much as said that American deadbeats were setting a "deplorable" example for the world.

title: After a Long Climb, Emerging at the Top
description: It has been a long, arduous journey for Carl Franklin, a journey in which the 46-year-old movie director and former actor teetered for years on the edge of financial disaster, endured harsh personal ordeals and remained committed to a career that seemed to be going nowhere.

title: No Headline
description: "It's been 26 years since a man walked on the moon, yet here we are still slugging it out with cancer. We need to pull ourselves together as a nation, as we did with NASA, and conquer cancer." JON M. HUNTSMAN, giving $100 million to help the effort. [ A12:1. ]

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants Hardly Ready to Be Buried
description: No, the Giants' season is not over. They hope it is just starting.
