description: The Cigna Corporation announced yesterday a $750 million charge against third-quarter earnings to increase the reserves it holds to pay insurance claims arising from environmental cleanups and asbestos.

title: Study of Chimps Strongly Backs Salt's Link to High Blood Pressure
description: VITAL to life and sought worldwide for its taste, common salt has played a large role in history because of its scarcity in many times and places. Salt has figured in wars, the North African slave trade and an onerous tax in prerevolutionary France. But today salt is cheap and plentiful. Many experts say, in fact, that its wide use is largely responsible for an epidemic of high blood pressure and many resulting deaths from heart disease in the United States and other countries.

title: USAir Exploring a Takeover by United or American
description: USAir, which has been plagued by losses, said yesterday that it was involved in talks with the parent companies of United and American Airlines that could eventually lead to a takeover.

title: Panel Urges U.S. to Apologize for Radiation Testing and Pay Damages
description: After reviewing 30 years of Government-sponsored radiation experiments on humans, a Presidential Committee has concluded that many were unethical and that the Government should apologize.

description: Atlantic Coast Conference

title: Expos' G.M. Decides to Go
description: Unable to find "inner peace" in trying to run a club with the lowest payroll in baseball, KEVIN MALONE resigned yesterday as the vice president and general manager of the Montreal Expos.

title: A COMBINATION OF HEXCEL AND CIBA-GEIGY UNIT PLANNED
description: Ciba-Geigy Ltd. of Switzerland agreed yesterday to combine its composites division with the Hexcel Corporation, creating a company with an estimated $600 million in annual sales. Analysts have valued the merger at about $400 million. The new company will retain the Hexcel name. Under the agreement, Ciba plans to exchange its composites business for about 49.9 percent of Hexcel's common stock. Hexcel also will pay $25 million in cash and $45 million to $50 million in debt, with the amount to be determined after closing. Ciba's composites business supplies lightweight, high-strength materials and structures. Hexcel, which is based in Pleasanton, Calif., makes honeycomb building materials, composites and reinforced fabrics.

title: A VISIT FROM THE POPE: NEW COMMUNITIES;With Every Wave of Newcomers, a Church More Diverse
description: When Pope John Paul II arrives for his latest American visit, he will find a church in the middle of historic demographic change.

title: Finbar Devine, 65; Led Bagpipes In 35 Years' Worth of Parades
description: Finbar Devine, a police sergeant who strutted and pranced up Fifth Avenue while leading kilted Irish bagpipers in the St. Patrick's Day Parade for 35 consecutive years, died on Saturday at Cabrini Medical Center. He was 65 and lived in the Midwood section of Brooklyn.

title: Editorial Notebook; The West Indian Reaganaut
description: The savage welfare cuts that just passed Congress have their roots in the Reagan revolution, which revived the Victorian view of poverty as a moral ailment brought on by sloth and failure of will -- but never, ever by anything so mundane as lack of opportunity. Black Reaganauts brought a welcome diversity to conservative politics. But their main function was to validate moral indictments of the poor. The most obvious case was Clarence Thomas, who trashed the civil rights movement every chance he got and insulted his sister for resorting to welfare during a crisis. Colin Powell figures in this debate as well, both as a black Reaganaut and a self-identified West Indian.

title: Clinton to Meet China's President in New York
description: Having rejected Beijing's request for a formal state visit in Washington, the White House announced today that President Clinton would hold a summit meeting with President Jiang Zemin of China in New York City on Oct. 24, during the 50th anniversary celebration at the United Nations.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When LOUIS J. FREEH, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was asked to be the grand marshal of next Monday's Columbus Day parade, he had one request: that two women from Italy, MARIA FALCONE DiFRESCO and AGNESE BORSELLINO, march with him. Mrs. DiFresco is the sister of Giovanni Falcone, a judge assassinated by members of organized crime in Palermo in 1992 after he was named to head an agency to combat Mafia killings. Mrs. Borsellino is the widow of Mr. Falcone's successor, Paolo Borsellino, killed two months later.

title: IDEX BUYS MAKER OF RESCUE EQUIPMENT FOR $35 MILLION
description: The Idex Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired Lukas Hydraulik G.m.b.H. of Germany for about $35 million in cash, making it the world's largest maker of emergency rescue tools. Idex plans to fold Lukas, the largest maker of rescue tools in Europe, into its Hale unit, which makes firefighting pumps and rescue tools under the brand name Hurst Jaws of Life. The shares of Idex rose $1, to $36.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. Lukas had revenue of $25 million last year. Idex said it planned to expand the rescue tools business by adding products and by entering new markets.

title: Before We Decide To Ignore Biology
description: To the Editor:

title: Sochi Journal;Sea and Sand and Sun (and the Specter of Stalin)
description: In the green hills overlooking the long pebbled beaches of Sochi, Russia's beloved Black Sea resort, Stalin still watches from his once-secret dacha, surrounded by the California pines he imported to disguise his hideaway from prying eyes or offshore artillery.

title: Swords Into Stock Shares
description: Next year, the United States will spend at least $247 billion on defense, a figure that should give pause to those who worry that shuttered bases and silenced production lines are evidence that our military is on short rations.

title: For 3 Flu Strains, $10 Shots
description: Balmy temperatures notwithstanding, the winter flu season is on the way. From now until Nov. 18, the Visiting Nurse Association of New Jersey is offering shots at supermarkets throughout the state for three strains of flu -- Texas, Johannesburg and Harbin, or Beijing. There is a $10 fee.

title: Top Officials to Weigh Problems Of New York City School Board
description: Declaring the New York City school system in a state of crisis, Sheldon Silver, the Speaker of the State Assembly, yesterday announced a meeting of top state, city, school board and union officials next week to plot out a new structure for the Board of Education.

Simpson murder trial had reached a verdict less than four hours into deliberations startled and confounded virtually all of the legal experts following the case, most of whom had confidently predicted that the denouement of this extraordinary trial would take a week or more.

title: TRACOR PLANS TO BUY AEL INDUSTRIES FOR $114 MILLION
description: Tracor Inc., a maker of electronic systems for the military, said yesterday that it would acquire AEL Industries for $28 a share, or a total of about $114.8 million. The stock of AEL, which makes electronic systems like radar equipment, rose 75 cents, to $27, on Nasdaq. The stock of Tracor, which is based in Austin, Tex., fell 62.5 cents, to $15.875. AEL is based in Lansdale, Pa.

title: Digging Beneath Motion to Tap Emotion
description: The Charlatans U.K. came to Tramps on Friday with a sound just familiar enough to recall its origins in the warehouse parties of Manchester, England, in the late 80's and just new enough to show how much the band has grown beyond its dance-rock roots. On its fourth album, "The Charlatans U.K." (Beggar's Banquet), which entered the British charts at No. 1, the band has altered its sound in the same direction as such contemporaries as the Verve (which recently broke up) and the Stone Roses. On their latest albums, these bands emphasize soul and blues grooves, trying to reach deeper than psychedelia and dance-rock and connect with something that has not just motion, but also feeling.

title: OUR TOWNS;A Safe Haven for All Creatures in Need
description: SARA WHALEN'S home provides sanctuary to 80 dogs, 30 cats, 20 birds, several goats, ponies and horses, 2 pigs, a horned steer and now, Maggie Cogan, known to some New Yorkers as the woman living in Central Park.

title: Early Violence Leaves Its Mark on the Brain
description: WITH rates of violence among teen-agers rising precipitously, the argument over the causes of violent behavior has never been more charged. Nature got a hearing last month at a University of Maryland meeting on possible genetic influences on violence. Last weekend, nurture had its day, at a meeting at the New York Academy of Sciences on the childhood causes of violence.

title: At School Headquarters, a Silence Grows
description: Walk along the 10th floor of 110 Livingston Street, the executive wing atop the cavernous Board of the Education headquarters in downtown Brooklyn, and what is most striking is the silence.

title: New York Hearing On Insurance Sales
description: Alarmed by consumer complaints about misleading sales tactics for life insurance policies, the New York Insurance Department announced plans yesterday for a public hearing Oct. 30 about how life insurance agents are paid.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Gains on Talk of Support At Group of Seven Meeting
description: The dollar edged up against the Japanese yen and the German mark yesterday, helped by expectations that the leading industrial nations will affirm support for a strong dollar when their monetary officials meet this weekend.

description: Phil Marinello's grandfather taught him well.

title: Fraud Charges Against Lloyd's
description: Arizona regulators said today that they had filed fraud charges against Lloyd's of London, charging that money from state residents was pooled into investments backing asbestos claims.

title: International Briefs; German Postal Bank Will Fight Takeover Bid
description: The German postal savings bank Postbank A.G. said yesterday that it would fight a takeover bid that was begun over the weekend but acknowledged that its fate lay with the Government. A consortium comprising Postbank's sister agency, Post A.G.; Germany's largest commercial bank, Deutsche Bank A.G., and the Swiss Reinsurance Company offered 3.08 billion marks, or $2.15 billion, for three-quarters of Postbank, which is owned by the Government.

title: KELLOGG TO CLOSE A CEREAL PLANT IN CALIFORNIA
description: The Kellogg Company said yesterday that it would close its cereal plant in San Leandro, Calif., by December, eliminating 325 jobs. Kellogg, the nation's largest cereal maker, said in August that it was considering shutting the plant, which is the smallest of the company's six in the United States. At that time, Kellogg also said it planned to cut 800 jobs in Battle Creek, Mich., where it is based, and eliminate 75 jobs from its plant in Memphis, which employs 600. Kellogg said previously that the California cuts could save $20 million to $30 million annually and that they would reduce overcapacity in the slow-growing domestic cereal market. Kellogg had 15,500 workers worldwide before the August reductions were announced.

title: Cellular-Phone Account in Review
description: Bell Atlantic Nynex Mobile, the cellular-phone venture of the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the Nynex Corporation, said yesterday that it had placed its account in review. Billings for the account, which has been split among four agencies, were estimated at $50 million.

FREEH, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was asked to be the grand marshal of next Monday's Columbus Day parade, he had one request: that two women from Italy, MARIA FALCONE DiFRESCO and AGNESE BORSELLINO, march with him. description: SOMEWHERE on my desk, probably only a few inches beneath the software packages, overnight mail envelopes, old coffee cups and last week's unopened mail, is a faxed news release declaring October to be National Clean Up Your Office Month.

title: Stars Get Carbonneau in Swap
description: The Dallas Stars acquired the veteran center GUY CARBONNEAU from the St. Louis Blues for right wing PAUL BROTEN yesterday. Carbonneau played for the Blues for one season after spending his first 12 seasons in the National Hockey League with Montreal. In 42 games with St. Louis, he had 5 goals and 11 assists. (AP)

title: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK;Cowboys' Woes Quickly Mounting
description: The Cowboys have hit their first bump on the road to the Super Bowl. They lost their first game of the season to Washington on Sunday and they lost Troy Aikman for the next three weeks with a strained right calf muscle. As bad as the injury to Aikman is, the Cowboys (4-1) may have some bigger problems.

title: Lucas Agrees to Pay $88 Million In Settlement With the Pentagon
description: Lucas Industries P.L.C. said today that it would pay $88 million to settle a two-year legal dispute with the United States Department of Defense that resulted in its being banned from American military contracts.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article yesterday about preservation of Cumberland Island in Georgia included scrambled concluding paragraphs in some editions, resulting in imprecise attribution of a critical view of natural preservation. The quotation -- "A lot of natural preservation people have a narrow view of preservation, and it doesn't extend to cultural resources" -- was from Rolland R. Swain, superintendent of Cumberland Island National Seashore. The speaker was not Carol A. Ruckdeschel, a naturalist who has lived on Cumberland for 22 years and who believes that doubling the island's population could destroy the wilderness.

title: Correction
description: A new book by Bill McKibben, the author of an article published yesterday on the Adirondacks, was described incorrectly. The book, "Hope, Human and Wild," examines local efforts around the world to reduce environmental damage.

description: The Food and Drug Administration has approved the first of a new class of nonhormonal drugs to treat osteoporosis, the bone-thinning disease that cripples millions of postmenopausal women, Merck & Company announced today.

description: Rich Kotite hasn't figured out the Jets yet, and after their worst game of the season, the coach suggested today that it was time to concentrate on emotion rather than intellect.

title: A Reunion Of Teacher And Student
description: Two dancers are rehearsing in an upstairs studio at the Dia Center in SoHo. A soft light filters down on them from a skylight in this open, airy dance version of a garret. The two move in their different ways to the sound of cello music by Bach. The woman looks older than the man. Tall, a little gaunt and with cropped hair, she draws the eye immediately. Her meditative trudge and her turn or two manage simultaneously to be velvety, mysterious and offhand. She claws her mouth open at one moment in a gesture that is fierce and unself-conscious. The eye rests on her and stays, as it so often has in her long career in modern dance.

title: International Briefs; Japan Decides to Close 7 Home Loan Companies
description: Japan's seven ailing housing loan companies, which are at the center of the nation's banking crisis with $84 billion in bad loans, will be closed by the companies that founded them, officials said yesterday. Japan has eight of the companies, which were formed under Finance Ministry guidance in the 1970's to meet demand for housing loans. They rely mostly on bank loans to finance their lending.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Sale Agreement Is Reached On Canary Wharf Complex
description: An investor group led by the Canadian developer Paul Reichmann and Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia has agreed to buy the giant Canary Wharf office complex here from the banks that own it, Lloyds Bank announced late today.

description: The growing population of red foxes on the Atlantic County island of Brigantine is posing a threat to two bird species that are on the State Department of Environmental Protection's endangered list, a department official said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article yesterday about the arrival of Don Mattingly of the Yankees in the post-season for the first time in his career misstated the number of games he has played. It is 1,785, not 1,885.

title: PLAYOFFS;Yanks Get Red Carpet as Mariners Get the Red-Eye
description: The Yankees knew they were zealously pursuing their first post-season berth in 14 years, they knew how joyous it would feel if they finally secured it and they were relieved when they experienced those strong emotions on Sunday. But what the Yankees did not know is how often the red carpet would be extended to them.

title: Bomb Plot, Chapter 3: Enter an Accused Master of Terrorism
description: Of the 20 men arrested so far in terrorism cases linked to the bombing of the World Trade Center, only one is thought to be a world-class terrorist.

title: PLAYOFFS: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;The Buck Stops With Showalter
description: IN the festive Yankee clubhouse yesterday afternoon, they were still talking about how Buck Showalter responded to his team's clinching of a playoff spot Sunday in Toronto by sitting in his seat. Which brings to mind that old ball park axiom about the best move sometimes being the one not made.

description: Movement on Medicare

title: Democrats Storm Out of Medicare Session
description: House Democrats today rebelled against Republican efforts to cut projected spending on health care for the elderly, walking out of a committee session on Medicare that they called a charade. Senate Democrats, taking a different tack, offered an alternative that would reduce spending less severely than the Republican plan.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Yom Kippur, alternate-side street cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Wednesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: PLAYOFFS: ON BASEBALL;Yanks May Win It All Or the Yanks May Not
description: The Yankees, tasting post-season Champagne for the first time since 1981, can go all the way to the World Series and emerge as champions.

title: Fashion's Future, in Computer Hues
description: If your goal is to predict the biggest change for fashion in the next decade, you would probably welcome the opportunity to peek inside the minds of Anna Sui and Marc Jacobs. Or at least to eavesdrop on a dinner conversation with a color expert that both designers recounted recently.

title: Kraft Shuffles Agency Roster
description: The Kraft Foods unit of the Philip Morris Companies yesterday announced significant changes in its agency roster, including the elimination of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York by mutual agreement and the shift of the Post Grape-Nuts cereal account from Grey Advertising in New York to FCB/Leber Katz Partners in New York. The combined billings were estimated at more than $90 million.

title: U.S. Moves Convicted Sheik To Missouri Medical Center
description: A day after he was convicted of leading a terror-bombing and assassination conspiracy, Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman was moved from the Manhattan jail where he was held during his trial to a medical center for Federal prisoners in Springfield, Mo.

title: A Time for Wisdom
description: Since he became Mayor of New York City, Rudolph Giuliani has perfected a kind of siege politics, battering away until his opponents are exhausted into submission. The Mayor feels he should control the local school system, and picks a fight with anyone who disagrees. As a result, the present Chancellor is on his way out of town. There is no successor, and most of the candidates under serious consideration for the job have withdrawn their names. Under the force of the Mayor's will, the Board of Education has splintered.

description: Sorghum beer, the first drink served at any African wedding or funeral, is as important to black Africans as wine is to Christians and Jews. It's also big business.

description: Without running for President, without even disclosing a party affiliation, Gen. Colin L. Powell has caused more commotion on the Republican right than any of the declared candidates.

description: Acquiring a great rebounder and a controversial personality, the Chicago Bulls obtained Dennis Rodman from the San Antonio Spurs yesterday in exchange for Will Perdue, a 7-foot backup center.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the impending decision of Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, on whether to seek re-election in 1996 misidentified the chamber in which his great-uncle Carl Vinson served. It was the House.

title: Pete Wilson's California Quagmire
description: Gov. Pete Wilson's withdrawal from the 1996 Presidential race will have deeper consequences for California than it had in the sea of Republican contenders, where his candidacy made hardly a ripple. What's far from certain, however, is which Pete Wilson will now occupy the Governor's office in the largest, most influential state.

title: Somerset Prosecutor Is Sworn In
description: Melaine B. Campbell, a deputy attorney general who helped dismantle the Lucchese crime family in northern New Jersey, was sworn in yesterday as acting Somerset County Prosecutor, the A.P. reported.

title: PLAYOFFS;Braves Have No Cause To Celebrate
description: The Seattle Mariners, with a victory over the California Angels in a rare playoff for first place, won their way into baseball's post-season party yesterday for the first time in their 19-year existence. The Cleveland Indians, whose 100 victories in a 144-game season represented a remarkable achievement, will play a post-season game tonight for the first time since in 41 years.

title: Workers Delayed Reporting Breakdown
description: Workers apparently failed to tell anyone for two days that the digging machine they were using in a Chinatown subway station had broken down -- long enough for the mishap to undermine a century-old building that came close to collapse -- a top transit official said yesterday.

title: Gradations of Gray Among the Soviet Composers
description: The problem for Soviet composers was not that the authorities cared nothing for music. The problem was that they cared too much. The composer held a position of astonishing eminence in Soviet society. With their stipends and dachas, Shostakovich, Prokofiev and Miaskovsky did not face the socioeconomic catastrophe endured by their counterparts in other countries. Their grand hotel had spooks in the corridors, but they did not leave.

description: Susie Tompkins to Close

title: Stackhouse Out Up to 3 Weeks
description: JERRY STACKHOUSE, the prize rookie from North Carolina who was chosen third over all in the National Basketball Association draft, suffered a hairline fracture on his left hand and will be out of action for the next two to three weeks.

title: Officer in Queens Accused of Joining A Car-Theft Ring
description: A police officer in Queens was arrested yesterday after being accused of joining a car-theft ring, the Police Department said. The officer, Erik Campbell, manipulated files so the vehicles would not be recorded as stolen, the department added.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article yesterday about preservation of Cumberland Island in Georgia included scrambled concluding paragraphs in some editions, resulting in imprecise attribution of a critical view of natural preservation. The quotation -- "A lot of natural preservation people have a narrow view of preservation, and it doesn't extend to cultural resources" -- was from Rolland R. Swain, superintendent of Cumberland Island National Seashore. The speaker was not Carol A. Ruckdeschel, a naturalist who has lived on Cumberland for 22 years and who believes that doubling the island's population could destroy the wilderness.

title: Songbird Migrations Tracked With Nocturnal Eavesdropping
description: Bill Evans, a researcher at the Laboratory of Ornithology at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., envisions a day when scientists and birdwatchers will turn on computers on a spring or fall morning and, in addition to the latest weather maps, view charts showing the previous night's migration of songbirds bound for their breeding or wintering grounds.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: SCHOOL SYSTEM SEEN IN STATE OF CRISIS Declaring the New York City school system in a state of crisis, Sheldon Silver, the Speaker of the State Assembly, announced a meeting of top state, city, school board and union officials to plot out a new structure for the Board of Education. [ Page A1. ] Walk along the executive wing atop the cavernous Board of the Education headquarters in downtown Brooklyn, and what is most striking is the silence. [ B2. ] As the school system has been plunged into turmoil once again about who will be its next leader, Jerry Cammarata, the school board member from Staten Island, said he believes he did the right thing in changing his vote. [ B2. ] PARISHES FIND STRENGTH IN DIVERSITY It was Pope John Paul II who once said that "culture must become faith, and faith must become culture," and as he travels through the New York City region, the Pope will see many churches that are living through all the joys and travails of carrying out his dictum. For the Roman Catholic Church in the city, the latest, spectacularly varied surge of immigrants has at once reinvigorated and enriched parishes while straining the church and its resources to their limits. [ A1. ] When the Pope arrives for his latest American visit, he will find a church in the middle of historic demographic change. [ B6. ] Pope John Paul II's recovery from surgery for a broken leg was much slower than expected, but he is now fully healed and in excellent health, the Vatican says. [ B7. ] A BRUTAL END TO A VOYAGE OF HOPE In the middle of the night, a telephone call from New York City woke Gao Linguan and his wife in their tiny house in the Fujian Province of China. An unfamiliar voice told them that their daughter had been kidnapped from her home in Corona, Queens, and that if the family did not pay $38,800 she would be killed. The Gaos are still haunted by the memory of their daughter begging them to cooperate. [ A1. ] NEW YORK CITY WORKERS DELAYED REPORTING MISHAP Workers apparently failed to tell anyone for two days that the digging machine they were using in a Chinatown subway station had broken down, long enough for the mishap to undermine an old building that came close to collapse, a top transit official said. [ B3. ] HIGH COURT DENIES PROFESSOR'S APPEAL The Supreme Court turned back an effort by the former chairman of City College's black studies department, Prof. Leonard Jeffries, to revive his First Amendment lawsuit against college officials for demoting him after he gave an inflammatory speech about Jews. [ B3. ] Autumn in New York has a new hue -- a navy blue blouse, the latest in cop couture, adorning the city's uniformed police officers. [ B5. ] Gary Kasparov won Game 13 of the world chess tournament. [ B4. ] REGION CASINO WINS AN ENDORSEMENT The Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe, which only a decade ago had been considered virtually extinct, is poised to expand its three-year-old gambling empire, winning Gov. John G. Rowland's endorsement to build an $875 million casino in Bridgeport, Conn. [ B1. ] Chronicle B4

description: Autumn in New York has a new hue -- a navy blue blouse, the latest in cop couture, adorning the city's thousands of uniformed police officers.

description: IN three recent cases, the Securities and Exchange Commission has put the nation's investment advisers on notice that they have an extra responsibility to put the interests of clients before their own -- and to alert clients to conflicts of interest, even potential ones.

description: An eight-week strike by car haulers has begun to take its toll on United States vehicle sales, causing the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation to report disappointing September sales today.

description: Jerry York, chief lieutenant to Kirk Kerkorian, meet your latest obstacle: Jerry York, one-time chief financial officer of the Chrysler Corporation.

description: It's perhaps the sexiest zipper trick since James Bond undid one with a magnetic wristwatch.

title: Macedonian President Gravely Wounded in Car-Bomb Attack
description: The Macedonian President, Kiro Gligorov, a close ally of the United States, was gravely wounded today in a car-bomb attack that killed his driver, senior western diplomats in Skopje said.

title: A VISIT FROM THE POPE: THE PAPACY;Pope's Impact Overshadows Shifts in Catholic Thinking
description: For 17 years, Pope John Paul II has been a forceful occupant of the Throne of St. Peter, projecting the papacy onto the world scene with enormous energy, flair and intellectual ambition. So strong is his personal impact that it has obscured a major shift in Catholic thinking about the nature of the papal office itself.

title: NOT GUILTY: A CITY REFLECTS;In the City of the Beautiful People, Trial Hinged on Uglier Issues
description: In the end, trials never happen in a vacuum. Moments after the jury handed down its verdict in the O. J. Simpson murder trial, a group of Los Angeles police officers parading in front of the criminal courthouse building here was jeered by a mostly black throng of spectators.

title: 95 PLAYOFFS;Reds' Batters Tee Off On Dodgers' Martinez
description: He was the losing pitcher by dusk. Ramon Martinez mistook this National League playoff game for batting practice and, by tonight's fifth inning, the Los Angeles Dodgers pitcher was removed in the best interest of his exhausted outfielders.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BIRMINGHAM STEEL CORP., Birmingham, Ala., said it would form a joint venture with Georgetown Industries, Charlotte, N.C., to build and operate an iron manufacturing plant in Louisiana.

title: The Simpson Verdict
description: Whatever one thinks about the shockingly swift acquittal of O. J. Simpson, this "trial of the century" has left a stigma on criminal justice that could take years to repair. There was considerable scientific and circumstantial evidence incriminating Mr. Simpson in the murders of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman. Many people who followed the trial closely on television will continue to believe him guilty. To them, there were simply too many confluences of timing and data to dismiss.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SNOOPY -- World War I flying ace, surgeon, lawyer and aspiring author -- is the quintessential Renaissance beagle, a dog who shows no signs of aging, despite the fact that on Monday he turned 45 (or 315 in dog years).

title: Gone Fishing? Not Lately
description: Plenty of fish were biting close to shore this summer, but business for New Jersey's 400 charter and party fishing boats was off by 15 to 20 percent, said a lawyer who represents the United Boatmen of New Jersey and New York. The lawyer, Raymond Bogan, said potential customers were scared off by news of rough surf, riptides and a high number of drownings. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Harveys Casino Resorts (HVY,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Aug 31
A New Computer Dazzles a Jaded Industry Crowd
description: It may prove a quixotic journey in a computer industry increasingly dominated by the mighty Microsoft and the giant Intel.

title: Personal Health;More of the elderly seek the benefits of exercise.
description: WHEN it comes to adopting health-promoting exercise habits, growing numbers of older Americans are putting their younger counterparts to shame. While the overall share of adults who are physically active has not increased in about a decade (about 30 percent are completely sedentary, and nearly 60 percent participate in fewer than three 20-minute exercise sessions a week), men and women 65 and older are gradually getting the message and becoming more active. In fact, based on the latest Federally sponsored state-by-state analysis of physical activity among older Americans, they are coming closer than younger adults to achieving the Surgeon General's goals for the year 2000.

title: Safeway Inc.(SWY,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 9
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 2,700,000, or 2 cents a share, from early retirement of debt.Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article yesterday about the health of Pope John Paul II on the eve of his American visit appeared with 17 lines misplaced. The last line of column 2 and all of column 3 belonged near the bottom of column 4, after the phrase "As part of that care, John Paul II." Readers wishing corrected copies of the article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1992.

title: NOT GUILTY: THE JURY;One Juror Smiled; Then They Knew
description: Just before the audible gasps, before the exhales of "oh, no" and exuberances of "oh, yes" inside the courtroom, there were a few hints that the 12 jurors who decided the fate of O. J. Simpson were sphinxes no more.

title: Man Convicted On Gun Counts In Graffiti Case
description: A man who shot two graffiti vandals, killing one, in a late-night confrontation was convicted on Monday of weapons charges.

title: Guilty Plea in 1974 Murder
description: The former neighbor of a 4-year-old girl who was found dead in a ditch in 1974 pleaded guilty yesterday in Gloucester County Superior Court to her murder, the A.P. reported.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Federal Farm Credit Bank is selling $45 million of medium-term notes due in 1997 through First Tennessee Bank. The notes, which are callable quarterly beginning Jan. 17, 1996, carry an interest rate of 6.01 percent and are priced at par.

title: Bengals Give Blake a Contract Extension
description: JEFF BLAKE, who emerged as the Cincinnati Bengals' starting quarterback last season when DAVID KLINGLER was injured, signed a contract extension yesterday through the 1999 season. Terms of the contract, which also renegotiated this year's deal, were not disclosed.

title: HORSE RACING;An Early Showdown for Thunder Gulch
description: D. Wayne Lukas flew into New York yesterday with a challenge and a string of racing stars, led by Thunder Gulch, his Kentucky Derby winner, who will force an immediate showdown with Cigar on Saturday in the $750,000 Jockey Club Gold Cup instead of waiting three weeks for the Breeders' Cup.

title: Judy Dearing, Costume Designer And Former Dancer, Dies at 55
description: Judy Dearing, a costume designer for scores of musicals, dances and plays, as well as a dancer and choreographer, died on Saturday at New York Hospital.

title: Revco D.S. Inc.(RXR,N) reports earnings for 1st qtr to Aug 26
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 2,800,000, or 5 cents a share, from early retirement of debt.

title: Journal;The L.A. Shock Treatment
description: As I stood in honest-to-God shock in my kitchen watching the reading of the Simpson verdict yesterday, my first feeling was rage. A few weeks earlier I had heard Vincent Bugliosi, the former Los Angeles Deputy District Attorney who successfully prosecuted the Charles Manson cult, convincingly argue that there was more physical evidence tying O. J. Simpson to the murders of Nicole Brown and Ron Goldman than he had had in his own legal victory. I believed him then, and I still do. So to watch Mr. Simpson slip away from justice -- my idea of justice, at any rate -- as the murder victims' families sobbed all around him was an infuriating sight.

title: Avocado's Leaves Impart a Haunting Flavor
description: WHERE I grew up, in the northern Mexican states of Sonora and Chihuahua, we never heard of cooking with avocado leaves. It wasn't until I first began visiting Oaxaca, in the southern part of the country, 10 years ago, that I tasted their characteristic haunting anise flavor. The glossy oval leaves are about five inches long, darkish- or grayish-green with whitish undersides: they look a little like bay leaves but are not as hard or tough.

title: International Briefs; U.S. Companies Sweeten Their Bid for Norweb
description: Two Texas companies raised the ante yesterday in a fight for control of Norweb P.L.C., one of several takeover targets in Britain's electric industry. Houston Industries and the Central and South West Corporation of Dallas, bidding through a joint venture called Texas Energy Partners, lifted their bid by 35 pence (56 cents), to a total of $:10.85 ($17.25) a share.

title: Giuliani Plan To Abolish School Board
description: After months of withering attacks against the Board of Education, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani outlined his first specific proposal for City Hall to gain control over the school system yesterday. He called for the abolition of the central Board of Education and the post of schools chancellor.

title: No Headline
description: "I can only hope that someday, despite every prejudicial thing that has been said about me publicly, both in and out of the courtroom, people will come to understand and believe that I would not, could not and did not kill anyone." -- O. J. SIMPSON. [ A10:1. ]

description: Latest share earnings included a one-time charge of about 4 cents a share for operating costs.

title: Genentech and Caremark Executives Acquitted
description: A Minneapolis judge today acquitted a Genentech Inc. sales manager and three Caremark International Inc. executives accused of paying kickbacks to a doctor, saying the Government failed to prove its case.

title: Betting on Bridgeport
description: For four years, the movement to build a casino in Bridgeport has grown steadily, winning support from an unlikely coalition of city officials, state lawmakers, unions -- even the state's parimutuel operators, who as part of any deal expected to have slot machines.

title:
INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. and Russia at Odds Over Caspian Oil
description: The Clinton Administration, citing protection of American interests, has sought to counter Russian influence in the oil-rich Caspian Sea by fighting two projects that are being promoted by Moscow.

title: GE CAPITAL REALTY ACQUIRES MACFARLANE PARTNERS
description: GE Capital Realty Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy MacFarlane Partners L.P., the nation's largest minority-owned provider of real estate services. Terms of the purchase, which is expected to be completed by the end of November, were not disclosed. MacFarlane Partners, based in San Francisco, advises public, corporate and private pension plans on their real estate investments. It has $1.8 billion in assets under management. GE Capital, a unit of the General Electric Company based in Dallas, said the MacFarlane management team would remain in place.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Life imitates art imitating life: MICHAEL WILSON and SUSAN NYE, a couple from Harrow, England, are getting married today -- at the church where the Off Broadway show "Tony 'n' Tina's Wedding" takes place. Later they will celebrate with their friends and relatives -- and the rest of the show's audience -- as part of the "Tony 'n' Tina" wedding reception.

title: Moten Signs Two-Year Pact With Grizzlies
description: The former Syracuse guard LAWRENCE MOTEN, selected 38th over all in the draft, signed a two-year contract yesterday with the expansion Vancouver Grizzlies. "I love this game and I'm looking forward to getting started with a brand new organization," said Moten, the Big East's career scoring leader. (AP)

title: Money Back, From a Politician
description: United States Representative Robert D. Franks, Republican of Union, has decided that it makes political sense for an elected official to put his money where his mouth is. He said yesterday that he spent nine months examining how to cut the cost of government before deciding to set an example by returning 5 percent of his take-home pay -- about $3,700 -- to the United States Treasury.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about American Jewish groups lobbying against the policies of the Israeli Government misspelled the surname of the executive vice president of the Israel Policy Forum. He is Jonathan D. Jacoby, not Jacob.

title: Lilly Industries(LICIA,NNM) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Aug 31
5 Seek Presidency in Algeria; Election Violence Threatened
description: Although Islamic militants have threatened to kill anyone who goes to the polls for Algeria's presidential election, the country's Government today announced the five nominees who will be on the ballot next month.

title: NOT GUILTY: AROUND THE NATION -- Atlanta;Roars of Delight
description: It was as if O. J. Simpson the running back, not O. J. Simpson the murder suspect, had eluded a crowd of tacklers and stiff-armed his way to the goal line to score the winning touchdown.

title: ON PRO FOOTBALL;Will the Jets Ever Get This Right?
description: If the Jets ever shake their slump -- the one that began about 25 years ago -- they will need Rich Kotite to be more than just a coach who is a caretaker. But that task seems more daunting than ever this week.

title: Ex-Prosecutor Pleads Not Guilty
description: Nicholas L. Bissell Jr., dismissed last week as prosecutor of Somerset County, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to charges including tax evasion, perjury and conspiracy. Government lawyers told the court they have 13 hours of videotape of Mr. Bissell and his wife, Barbara L. Bissell, as well as 5,000 checks and bank statements relating to the couple's business and personal finances, said Kimberly Guadagno, an assistant United States attorney. Mrs. Bissell also pleaded not guilty to conspiracy and mail fraud charges.

title: International Briefs; Scotland Plant Planned
description: Lexmark International Inc., based in Greenwich, Conn., a maker of computer ink-jet cartridges, said yesterday that it would build a $42 million production plant in Rosyth, Scotland. The company said it expected to start making color and monochrome cartridges in the second quarter of next year, creating up to 500 new jobs over the next three years. (Reuters)

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;For TV's Single Women, Cats and Odd Friends
description: Behold the 35-year-old female as perceived by television executives. Coveted by advertisers, she dominates the very soul of network prime-time entertainment, especially in the laugh-choked land of sitcoms. It's a landscape littered with unattached young women in their 20's and 30's, who, determined to have it all, pursue assorted careers while juggling romantic possibilities who generally get stalled in the category of just friends. Friends. Now there's an idea for a series.

title: A VISIT FROM THE POPE: IN ROME;For Pope, Busy Day at Vatican Before Leaving for U.S.
description: Msgr. Timothy Dolan, rector of the Pontifical North American College here, had been worried that the preparations for Pope John Paul II's visit to the United States, which begins on Wednesday, might overwhelm the Pope's schedule today, forcing him to cancel a planned meeting with 22 recently ordained American deacons.

title: A Bozell Office Gets New Owners
description: Two top executives of the Washington office of Bozell Worldwide along with an executive of Pitney Bowes Inc. have acquired that Bozell office and renamed it Laughlin, Marinaccio & Owens. The terms were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about chemical weapons in Russia misstated the fears expressed by the author of a report on the subject. The scientist, Vil S. Mirzayanov, said the chemical stockpiles were vulnerable to transfer, sale or theft. He did not refer to the further production of such weapons. They are no longer produced in Russia.

title: International Briefs; Owens-Corning Stake
description: The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation said yesterday that it planned to sell its 28 percent stake in a Japanese joint venture to its partner. Owens-Corning said it formed the venture, the Asahi Fiber Glass Company, with the Asahi Glass Company in 1956. Owens-Corning owned 40 percent of the venture at that time, and had been gradually decreasing its stake. Terms were not disclosed. Owens-Corning said it would use the proceeds to pursue new growth opportunities. The venture, based in Tokyo, has three factories in Japan. (Dow Jones)

title: 95 PLAYOFFS;Game 2: Pettitte Has Nerves Of Steel
description: Before Andy Pettitte could set the alarm clock, flick off the light and drift off to sleep Sunday night, his wife, Laura, asked him if he thought he would be nervous when he shuffles to the mound to pitch Game 2 against the Seattle Mariners tonight.

description: The state's Attorney General, Deborah T. Poritz, took aim at the State Commission of Investigation yesterday, saying the government watchdog may need a leash to protect public officials who are subjects of its inquiries. Ms. Poritz said she did not believe the S.C.I. should be dismantled but did suggest changes that could require the agency to seek approval -- perhaps from a judge -- before it released a report or identified the subjects of its investigations.

title: DMR Group reports earnings for 1st qtr to Aug 31
description: DMR Group said it had anticipated weaker results in the latest quarter, due mainly to the implementation of a new worldwide operating structure in the fourth quarter ended May 31.The company said it expects revenues and operating income to improve through the balance of the fiscal year, and is sticking to its previously stated objective of attaining higher earnings than it did in the previous fiscal year.The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: International Briefs; Aegon in Mexico Deal
description: The Mexican financial group Banamex-Accival said yesterday that it had formed a strategic alliance with the Dutch insurer Aegon to provide insurance services in Mexico. The group said Aegon would acquire a 49 percent stake in its insurance unit, Seguros Banamex. Aegon would pay an initial $167 million, of which $109 million has already been paid, with the rest to be paid over 10 years, depending on the value of the business. Banamex-Accival said a preliminary accord setting up the alliance was announced last November but the Mexican economic crisis had delayed the deal. (Reuters)

title: Long Night in Nigeria
description: Nigeria's Gen. Sani Abacha has played a cruel joke on the 100 million people he purports to lead. He chose the 35th anniversary of Nigerian independence to announce on Sunday that black Africa's most populous country is somehow still not ready for self-government. The general grabbed power in 1993, dissolved all political parties and legislatures, and jailed his civilian rivals. Now he says he intends to rule at least three more years before handing over power to an elected government.

title: OPERA REVIEW;'Otello' Outshines All the Accessories
description: Verdi's "Otello" had much to contend with as the Metropolitan Opera opened its season on Monday night. First, there was the literary event of this young musical year, the debut of Met Titles. In this new system, translations appear not above the proscenium but on oblong screens affixed to the back of seats. More on them later.

title: NOT GUILTY: THE DEALS;In the World of Books, a Rush to Publish
description: Moments after the jury in the O. J. Simpson trial delivered its verdict yesterday, telephones rang and faxes beeped at publishing houses and book agents' offices around the country.

title: Laborite Points Down Information Highway to Vision of a Brave New Britain
description: Tony Blair, the Labor Party leader, turned a speech to the party faithful today into a canvas for a glowing portrait of a new-age Britain just around the corner -- spirited, compassionate, high-tech and rejuvenated. Provided, that is, that Labor is voted into power.

title: Brain Surgeon Who Made Mistake Is Reinstated
description: Bridgeport Hospital has restored privileges for a brain surgeon who operated on the wrong side of a patient's skull last month, the hospital announced today.

title: For Taiwan's Frontier Islands, the War Is Over
description: In the dead of night, especially when there is no moon, the boats from mainland China slip through the mists and into the waters of Kinmen, this fortress island once known to the world as Quemoy and still manned by thousands of Taiwan Army troops.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Rubin Says World Economy Is in a Pause
description: The Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, said today that the world economy was in "a pause," but forecast stronger global growth next year and reaffirmed the Clinton Administration's commitment to a stronger dollar.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Lita Annenberg Hazen, a leading philanthropist in medical research, misstated her age in some editions. She was 85, not 86.

title: NOT GUILTY: AROUND THE NATION -- Fairfax, Va.;For Many, Disbelief
description: By 1 P.M. today in this Washington suburb, the Ruby Tuesday restaurant was packed with more than twice the number of usual weekday patrons. It was not difficult to see why.

title: Village Super Market Inc. reports earnings for 4th qtr to Jul 29
description: b-Net loss, and the year included a $ 1.2 million charge related to a change in accounting.(Loss)Village Super Market said fiscal 1995 net income rose despite a decrease in sales because of higher gross margins and lower payroll and coupon costs, and partly offset by higher supply costs.The company said same-store sales fell 0.7 percent in fiscal 1995. In the fourth quarter, same-store sales rose 0.7 percent.Village Super Market also said fiscal-year sales were hurt by new competitors and a sluggish economy. In addition, fiscal 1994 sales were helped by higher promotional spending.

Metropolitan Diary
description: JAY LAWRENCE of Maplewood, N.J., was standing at a bus stop on Madison Avenue just behind a white-haired woman and a little 4- or 5-year-old girl. The child was relating a list of things her mother wouldn't let her do alone. Finally she said: "She never lets me do anything, Grandma! Sometimes I wish she would just go back into your tummy!"

title: Leo J. Damore, 66, an Author Of a Book on Chappaquiddick
description: Leo J. Damore, who uncovered previously unreported information for his 1988 book, "Senatorial Privilege: The Chappaquiddick Coverup," took his life on Monday at his home in Essex, Conn. He was 66.

title: International Briefs; Aran Says ARCO Bid Undervalues Its Worth
description: Aran Energy P.L.C. said yesterday that a study it had commissioned valued its assets at 73 percent more than a $255 million bid made by its hostile suitor, ARCO of Los Angeles. Aran, based in Dublin, said ARCO was not attributing enough value to its fields south of the Shetland Islands, where oil exploration is just beginning.

title: TOKOS MEDICAL TO MERGE WITH HEALTHDYNE
description: The Tokos Medical Corporation and Healthdyne Inc. agreed yesterday to merge into a newly created company to provide obstetrical care. Under the agreement, each Tokos and Healthdyne share will be exchanged for a share of the new company. Tokos and Healthdyne said they expected that the new company, which has not been named, would maintain operations in both Marietta, Ga., where Healthdyne is based, and Santa Ana, Calif., where Tokos is based. The new company will have about 33 million common shares, with about 17.5 million held by former Tokos shareholders and 15.5 million held by former Healthdyne shareholders. In Nasdaq trading, shares of Healthdyne rose $1, to $10.50, while shares of Tokos fell 75 cents, to $9.875.

title: With a Veto, President Tries To Nudge G.O.P. on Spending
description: In an act that carries more political symbolism than practical effect, President Clinton today vetoed a bill that pays for Congress's administrative expenses. He said he would not approve the lawmakers' budget while the other spending measures needed to pay for the Federal Government were "incomplete, unresolved and uncertain."

title: Kasler Holding Co. (KAS,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Aug 31
description: Kasler Holding attributed the increased net income in the latest third quarter to reduced general and administrative costs.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Price of Natural Gas Declines As Gulf Hurricane Threat Eases
description: Natural-gas prices slumped yesterday as Hurricane Opal veered to the northeast, easing concerns that the storm would damage offshore platforms in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Southern Food Expands South (to 125th Street)
description: Copeland's Country Kitchen has opened at 203-5 West 125th Street (near Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard), four years after Calvin Copeland, the owner of Copeland's, 547 West 145th Street, had the idea of expanding his brand of soul food to 125th Street, the heart of Harlem. The tile and wood shop, with booths, serves moderately priced Southern-style food and home cooking for breakfast, lunch and dinner. It also has two areas that can be rented for parties.

title: TVKO Sticks With Holyfield-Bowe Date
description: TVKO's decision to keep its pay-per-view telecast of the EVANDER HOLYFIELD-RIDDICK BOWE fight on Nov. 4 was an all-or-nothing decision. "There wouldn't be a fight if we didn't go Nov. 4," SETH ABRAHAM, the president of Time Warner Sports, said yesterday. "We had no backup date." An advance sale of 8,500 tickets hardened the resolve of Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., against moving the date.

description: Wade Boggs hurried into the Yankee clubhouse, stopped at his locker to take off his uniform, then hurried into the trainer's room. About five minutes later, he returned.

title: CSS INDUSTRIES TO BUY UNIT OF GIBSON GREETINGS
description: CSS Industries signed an agreement yesterday to buy Cleo Inc., the gift-wrap unit of Gibson Greetings Inc., for about $128.5 million in cash and short-term notes. CSS Industries, a maker of printed paper products based in Philadelphia, said the purchase price was substantially below Cleo's net book value. CSS Industries said it expected to complete the deal by Nov. 15. Cleo, based in Memphis, had revenue of $189 million and a pretax loss of $37 million last year.

title: P.& G. Bolsters Its Suit Against Bankers Trust
description: The Procter & Gamble Company provided more evidence to bolster its civil racketeering case against the Bankers Trust Company in court documents unsealed yesterday, asserting that its losses were part of a pattern of fraudulent activity by the bank.

title: A VISIT FROM THE POPE: PREPARATIONS;From Newark to New York, An Elaborate Choreography
description: From Interstate 280 and the New Jersey Turnpike in Newark, which will be closed while his motorcade whizzes by, to a town house on East 72d Street in Manhattan, where he will spend the next four nights, the preparations drew to a well-organized conclusion yesterday on the eve of Pope John Paul II's first visit to the New York area since 1979.

description: Police officials said today that 148 people were arrested and two passers-by were hurt when gangs of youths disrupted an opposition march in the central square on Monday night.

title: NOT GUILTY: THE FAMILIES;In the Seats Reserved for Relatives, Joy and Pain, Relief and Disbelief
description: Sitting inside the courtroom were three families, two that had once been one, and another that came to the circle through a brutal twist of fate. All were faced with a common task -- picking up the pieces of their lives as the murder trial of Orenthal James Simpson came to an end. But when a jury pronounced Mr. Simpson not guilty, their tears flowed for different reasons.

title: Market Place; Zell's Rockefeller deal is delayed and other bids will be considered.

title: Calcutta Journal;A Tradition Facing End of the Road
description: When the last of the year's monsoons swept Calcutta this week, whole neighborhoods became inland seas. But Jageshwar Singh kept moving, pulling his rickshaw around stalled vehicles, managing somehow to find his footing along streets and alleyways where whole sections were swept away by the swirling waters.

title: Foreign Affairs; The French Ostrich
description: A few weeks ago I attended question hour at the Australian Parliament, a raucous weekly event when the opposition questions the Prime Minister, Paul Keating. Mr. Keating was asked about France's claims that it was entitled to test its nuclear weapons in Polynesia because these colonies were actually part of France. His voice dripping with contempt, Mr. Keating said: "Oh, yes. There are Polynesians all the way down from Aix-en-Provence. They pop out of the woodwork. They are doing Polynesian dances in the back end of the Loire Valley, in the walled city of Carcassone, in the lovely humidity of Aix-en-Provence. There are Polynesians everywhere."

title: Henry Smith, 85, Congressman In Vietnam and Watergate Eras
description: Henry P. Smith 3d, who served in the House of Representatives for 10 years, representing the 36th District in Niagara and Erie Counties in western New York, died on Sunday in Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 85 and lived in Washington.

U.S. Surgical, a maker of surgical instruments and wound closures, had sales in 1994 of $918.7 million.

description: Using computers and shoe leather, a team of investigators from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has been following a trail of mass death for the last three months. It winds not through a distant rain forest haunted by an exotic plague but through the brick and concrete valleys of this city.

description: The Clinton Administration, citing protection of American interests, has sought to counter Russian influence in the oil-rich Caspian Sea by fighting two projects that are being promoted by Moscow.

Later they will celebrate with their friends and relatives -- and the rest of the show's audience -- as part of the "Tony 'n' Tina" wedding reception.

description: KEITH TKACHUK became one of hockey's three highest-paid players this season when the Winnipeg Jets yesterday matched the Chicago Blackhawks' five-year, $17 million offer sheet to keep him. Tkachuk, who was a restricted free agent, will earn $6 million this season. Only WAYNE GRETZKY of the Los Angeles Kings ($6.545 million) has a higher base salary. MARK MESSIER of the Rangers has a base of $6 million but could earn more with incentives.

description: Hurricane Opal, which left at least 10 people dead in Mexico, was on a course that could take it southeast of Louisiaended today from Morgan City, La., east to the mouth of the Suwannee River on Florida's northwest Gulf Coast. Officials in the Panhandle's three westernmost counties -- Escambia, Santa Rosa and Okaloosa -- put evacuation plans into effect.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Philosophy Student Who Bites
description: There are no neat, glamorous or witty vampires in "The Addiction." Instead, Lili Taylor portrays the vampire as grungy graduate student in philosophy, quoting Feuerbach before she bites. The pop-culture grittiness and high-minded theme offer the first clues that this is an Abel Ferrara film. Love him or hate him, Mr. Ferrara is one of the few directors who can turn genre movies into something deeper.

title: TRAVELERS GROUP PREDICTS GAIN IN FOURTH QUARTER
description: Travelers Group Inc. said yesterday that it expected a gain of $100 million in the fourth quarter from the sale of its stake in the Metrahealth Companies. Separately, Travelers and another insurer, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, said they had completed the sale of Metrahealth to the United Healthcare Corporation for $1.65 billion. Travelers, based in New York, and Metropolitan Life each owned 48.25 percent of Metrahealth, a managed care company based in Greenwich, Conn. Travelers received $831 million in cash from the sale, which was announced in June, and has an option to receive as much as $169 million more if earnings goals are reached. Metropolitan Life will receive $796 million in cash and stock from the sale of its stake and as much as $169 million in each of the next three years.

description: Shares of Prudential Reinsurance Holdings Inc. gained yesterday in their first day of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The shares were sold for $16.75 each on Monday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Regular trading opened at $18.75 yesterday and the stock closed at $19.625 as almost 10.4 million shares changed hands. The company's parent, the Prudential Insurance Company of America, sold 44 million shares of Prudential Reinsurance, or 88 percent of the unit. Meanwhile, the streets are strewn with rubble and the populace is volatile and anarchic. It is either a scene of devastation or a land or opportunity, depending on one's point of view.

description: A SAN FRANCISCO-BASED men's-wear chain, Rochester Big and Tall, has signed a 20-year, $7 million lease for 15,000 square feet of retail space on two levels at 67 Wall Street.

title: FINAL PRICE SET FOR SALE OF AMERICAN MAIZE-PRODUCTS
description: Eridania Beghin-Say S.A. of France will pay $441.7 million for the American Maize-Products Company under the final version of an agreement reached in July, American Maize-Products said yesterday. Eridania said earlier that it would pay $430 million, or $40 a share, though the company said that price might not include all payments to holders of stock options. A proxy filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission calls for a final shareholder vote on Nov. 6 on the sale of American Maize-Products, a tobacco and corn products company based in Stamford, Conn. The deal will give Eridania, the largest starch maker in Europe, access to the United States starch market, which is the world's largest.

title: 95 PLAYOFFS;Braves Rookie Sinks Rockies With 2 Homers
description: On a team stocked with veterans wise to the ways of major league playoffs, it was the rookie Chipper Jones who was the difference tonight as the Atlanta Braves outlasted the Colorado Rockies, 5-4, in the opening game of their National League playoff series at Coors Field.

title: Sports of The Times;Mariners Don't Blame Red Eyes
description: THE Seattle Mariners wanted to wake up in a city that never sleeps. That would be their reward for winning their playoff Monday afternoon in Seattle -- flying totally across this great big continent to play the Yankees in the hopped-up Bronx last night.

title: Stocks Continue Their Retreat, With Dow Falling by 11.56
description: The stock market retreated again yesterday as investors continued to worry about whether third-quarter corporate earnings would meet expectations.

title: Chatting, Drawling And Repartee
description: Tap dancers often seem to be talking with their feet. There were delightful choreographic conversations on Saturday night when the Peggy Spina Tap Company presented a program called "One Night Only" at the Peggy Spina Studio in SoHo (115 Prince Street).

title: Tommy Tune Breaks a Foot
description: The Broadway opening of "Busker Alley," a $6 million musical that stars Tommy Tune, has been thrown into doubt by an accident in which Mr. Tune broke his left foot during a performance in Tampa, Fla., the show's producers said yesterday.

title: Salonen Extends Term
description: The conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen has signed a contract with the Los Angeles Philharmonic to extend his term as music director to the year 2001, the orchestra has announced. Mr. Salonen has been the ensemble's music director since 1992.

title: Griffey Quiets the Stadium Twice, If Only Briefly
description: Lost somewhere in the euphoria of Champagne, sweat and the sweetness of winning the American League West championship on Monday afternoon, the Seattle Mariners had to deal with a slight problem: Their best pitcher would not start Game 1 of the divisional playoff series against the Yankees.

title: MORE ON THE VERDICT
description: A Free Man

title: Taiwanese Are Wary of Johnson's Arrival
description: Health officials in Taipei, Taiwan, said yesterday that they haven't yet decided to allow MAGIC JOHNSON to visit Taiwan with his touring basketball team because Johnson has the virus that causes AIDS. Under Taiwanese law, the Government can bar the entry of people who have AIDS or are H.I.V.-positive, as Johnson is. Johnson and his team were to arrive in Taipei on Oct. 30 and play two exhibition games against the Taiwanese Hung Fu Rams basketball team before departing on Nov. 2. (AP)

title: International Dairy Queen Inc.(INDQA,NNM) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Aug 25
NOT GUILTY: THE OVERVIEW;Jury Clears Simpson in Double Murder; Spellbound Nation Divides on Verdict
description: Orenthal James Simpson, a man who overcame the spindly legs left by a childhood case of rickets to run to fame and fortune, surmounted a very different sort of obstacle today, when a jury of 10 women and 2 men cleared him of charges that he murdered his former wife and one of her friends.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Celebrating With 'Waiting for Godot'
description: Few, if any, plays revolutionized the theater as did Beckett's "Waiting for Godot." To open the Jean Cocteau Repertory's silver-anniversary season, its founder, Eve Adamson, has directed a staging that, to quote Gogo, is simply "tray, tray, tray bong" (or, as Didi translates, "very, very, very good").

title: A VISIT FROM THE POPE: NYC;And After Sabbath, We Meet the Pope
description: SURE, he is the spiritual guide to a billion Roman Catholics. But what really impresses Rabbi Gary Bretton-Granatoor about Pope John Paul II is that he comes across as "a real mensch."

title: NOT GUILTY: THE MAN;Simpson Walks Out of the Courtroom a Free Man and Into the Lucrative Free Market
description: O. J. Simpson walked out of the courtroom today a free man for the first time in 15 months, saying he was eager to rebuild his life and move on. But it was clear from the way he was driven home to the deals his lawyers were trying to cut that the past and his notoriety are likely to be constant emotional and financial companions.

title: Japanese Stocks Higher
description: Stocks rose at midday, helped in part by higher futures prices. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 10.46 points, or 0.06 percent, to 18,153.45. On Tuesday the Nikkei closed at 18,142.99.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Report Says Plan Could Hurt AIDS Care
description: In a report scheduled for release tomorrow, advocates for people infected with H.I.V. argue that the patients could suffer serious health consequences by being pushed into Medicaid managed care. Almost none of the doctors in New York City's managed care network have experience in treating people with the virus or AIDS, the advocates say.

title: Low-Fat Diet Slows a Cancer in Mice, Study Says
description: A low-fat diet substantially slowed the growth of prostate cancer in a laboratory experiment, and researchers say the findings suggest that eating lean could become a crucial part of treating the disease.

title: Finish Line reports earnings for 2d qtr to Aug 31
Victor Samrock, 88, Business Manager In New York Theater
description: Victor Samrock, a theatrical business manager who in a half century in show business was involved in 150 Broadway productions, died on Saturday at New York Hospital.

title: Simpson Prosecutors Pay for Their Blunders
description: The prosecution of O. J. Simpson was doomed from the start. Not in the sense that the state lacked proof -- the case against Mr. Simpson remains compelling. But the prosecution was a low-road enterprise that began with the kinds of ugly tactics that have aroused suspicions about the criminal justice system among members of racial minorities in Los Angeles and elsewhere.

title: Yonkers Mayor Proposes School Uniform Policy
description: Mayor Terence M. Zaleski called on the Board of Education today to require public school students to wear uniforms.

title: Hired Guns for the I.R.S.
description: House Republicans want the Internal Revenue Service to try using debt collection agencies and law firms to collect Federal taxes. Such a pilot program would make hash of taxpayers' privacy and rights.

title: Laborite Points Down Information Highway to Vision of a Brave NewBritain
description: Tony Blair, the Labor Party leader, turned a speech to the party faithful today into a canvas for a glowing portrait of a new-age Britain just around the corner -- spirited, compassionate, high-tech and rejuvenated. Provided, that is, that Labor is voted into power.

title: Kasparov Keeps On Rolling: It's 8 1/2-5 1/2
description: In a hard-fought battle, in which the advantage first flowed to Viswanathan Anand and later ebbed away, Gary Kasparov struggled through to victory yesterday in Game 14 of the world chess championship. He thus achieved an all but insurmountable three-point lead in the 20-game series. The score now stands at 8 1/2-5 1/2.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Rockefeller Center Trust Delays Deal with Zell Group Rockefeller Center Properties, the real estate investment trust that is scheduled to take ownership of Rockefeller Center, delayed its deal with an investor group led by Sam Zell, the Chicago financier, while it considered two other offers made in the last week.

title: A Pope for Modern Times
description: John Paul II's arrival in Newark today marks his fourth trip to the United States since he became Pope in 1978. The four-day tour, which includes a speech before the United Nations, is profoundly important not only to the Roman Catholic Church but the secular world as well.

title: Park Electrochemical Corp.(PKE,N) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Aug 27
description: All share earnings and shares outstanding data reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Aug. 15.The results included 13 weeks of operations.

title: 95 PLAYOFFS;Yankee Lights Sparkle Bright Amid Power Display
description: From the moment the usually stoic Buck Showalter burst on the field during introductions, waved his cap twice to the sellout crowd of 57,178 and pumped his fist two more times for emphasis, the fans at Yankee Stadium were alive and excited. And it soon became abundantly clear: So were the Yankees.

title: Steinbrenner Blasts Umpire
description: George Steinbrenner complained vehemently about a call in the top of the sixth inning made by the first-base umpire Dale Scott. With the bases loaded, two outs and a 1-2 count on Dan Wilson, Scott hesitated before ruling on an appealed third strike thrown by David Cone. Wilson had appeared to go around with his swing, but Scott ruled he had not. The Mariners tied the game when Cone eventually walked Wilson.

title: Satellite Services Hear the Naysayers
description: The concept has great promise: a string of satellites offering genuinely global wireless telephone service, where the caller is never out of range, from the canyons of Arizona to the canyons of Hong Kong.

title: Dean Witter Alters Broker Commissions
description: Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. said yesterday that it would stop paying higher commissions to its brokers for selling its own financial products. It was the last of the major brokerage firms to make such a change.

title: ON BASEBALL;At Long Last, October Comes in With a Roar
description: Yankee fans let out a primal scream last night, which was their right after having been so stifled for the past 14 Octobers. For the first time since 1981, it was an autumn night in which the Yankees were still around as the leaves threatened to turn brown, playing in a portion of baseball's expanded playoffs, trying to undo the Seattle Mariners' claim of being the American League's Cinderella entry.

description: Big East

title: Hillenbrand Industries(HB,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 2
description: b-Net loss, which included a charge of $ 52.5 million, or 74 cents a share, from settlement of patent litigation.(Loss)Hillenbrand Industries said its funeral services segment reported increases in revenues and operating profit for the quarter as a result of double-digit growth in revenues and operating profit at its Forethought unit, combined with growth in traditional burial caskets and in Options cremation products at Batesville Casket.Revenues in Hillenbrand's health-care segment increased marginally as a result of continued growth in therapy revenues in the long-term care and home-care market segments, which offset continued softness in domestic acute-care products at Hill-Rom.Block Medical and Medeco also reported growth in revenues. Operating profit declined from third-quarter 1994 because of softness in the domestic acute-care capital market, higher expenses for new product development, a shift in product mix and expected losses in some foreign operations at Hill-Rom.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Representatives SUSAN MOLINARI of Staten Island and BILL PAXON of Amherst, N.Y., won't have to look far for a baby to kiss should they run for re-election to Congress next year. They expect to have their own by then.

description: It began four years ago with the Royal Academy's decision to hold a major show of African art from prehistoric times to 1900, but soon something far more ambitious was in the making. After all, if Africa was to be seen as more than an endless source of bad news, its present-day culture should also be displayed. And, with that, Africa 95 was born.

description: Ed O'Bannon has qualities that the Nets sorely need: talent, character, charisma. So after signing a three-year, $3.9 million contract today, O'Bannon greeted the local news media and prepared for his next challenge -- helping the Nets become a winner.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Hampton Expected To Miss One Game
description: The Giants reported good news today about Rodney Hampton, their heavy-duty tailback. They confirmed Hampton's report on Monday night that he would not need screws or plates or pins to stabilize his broken right hand, a surgical process that would probably have sidelined him for four to six weeks.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;Graduates Whose Hero Could Be Peter Pan
description: Like baby birds with brand-new college diplomas, the four graduates in Noah Baumbach's "Kicking and Screaming" are having trouble leaving the nest. They prefer a pleasant limbo filled with witty asides, trivia contests and hair-splitting arguments about matters of no consequence. Girlfriends notice this aimlessness ("the characters in Grover's story spend time discussing the least important things," says one young woman, criticizing the film's would-be writer), but they don't really mind. Audiences won't either, since "Kicking and Screaming" occupies its postage-stamp size terrain with confident comic style.

title: NOT GUILTY: THE RACIAL PRISM;Racial Split at the End, as at the Start
description: The seven workers at the Pasqua Coffee Bar in lower Manhattan like to joke around with one another, to trade stories about family and regular customers, and to help one another out in jams.

title: Musicians Delay Strike Deadline

title: Steelers' Cowher Stuffed With $7,500 Fine
description: BILL COWHER counted 11 and BEN MONTGOMERY counted 12. By the National Football League's count, it adds up to $14,335. Cowher, the Pittsburgh Steelers' coach who angrily reacted to an incorrect too-many-men-on-the-field penalty by stuffing a photo into a referee's shirt, was fined $7,500 yesterday.

title: 95 PLAYOFFS;A.L.'s Angry Man May Be Its M.V.P.
description: The man in the batter's box in Jacobs Field took a swing at the baseball with an economy of motion and a power of execution that was nearly startling. The ball rocketed over the left-field fence virtually before the outfielder had a chance to blink, let alone take a step. This was Albert Belle, the sometime enfant terrible, whacking his 50th home run of the season, his 17th of September, tying Babe Ruth's record for the month, and his 31st in the last two months, also a major league record.

title: HOCKEY;Lemieux Heads to Colorado By Way of Long Island
description: Claude Lemieux was traded by the Devils last night for Steve Thomas of the Islanders and then was immediately shipped to Colorado for Wendel Clark in a three-way deal involving three players involved in contract disputes.

description: In the heart of a gritty urban archdiocese, President Clinton and Pope John Paul II held a warm face-to-face meeting today, a short time after the Pope offered a pointed admonishment against current proposals to restrict immigration and limit services for the poor -- in terms that closely echoed many of Mr. Clinton's own recent warnings.

Simpson was reunited with his two young children today and later spoke publicly when he phoned in to a national television talk show and criticized prosecutors and pundits, saying they had distorted facts to try to prove him guilty of murder.

description: Two women who were being trained for the Federal Bureau of Investigation have complained that a firearms test that measures trigger-pulling strength has been used by the law-enforcement agency to discriminate against women, a lawyer for one of them said today.

description: When Paul Auster creates his characters for novels and the screen, a chance meeting, a chance phone call often changes the course of a life. Just the sort of thing that happens to Paul Auster, too. Even happened to his dog.

title: People
description: * Jeffrey Burch was named publisher at House Beautiful magazine, New York, a unit of the Hearst Corp., succeeding Adrienne Cleere, who resigned after four months. Mr. Burch was previously associate publisher at Cosmopolitan magazine, New York, also owned by Hearst. At Cosmopolitan, Jennifer Gallo was named to succeed Mr. Burch. She was previously advertising director at Esquire magazine, New York, also owned by Hearst. And at Esquire, Susan Plagemann, its advertising manager, was promoted to succeed Ms. Gallo. * Peter Lenahan was named to the new position of publisher at Historic Traveler magazine, Stamford, Conn., owned by Cowles Media Inc. He was previously president at Sales Concepts Associates, New York.

It also plans to expand its new music store concept in Asia with the addition of eight stores by the end of next year. Blockbuster operates 4,000 stores in the United States.

title: Faucets That Pass the Lead Test
description: HUNDREDS of faucet models sold at retail stores around the country will soon carry a new symbol certifying that they meet a safety standard for lead, cadmium, mercury and other toxic substances. Faucets made by six manufacturers passed tests in which water was held in them for specified periods over the course of 19 days. Then the water was tested to determine whether it had picked up any of the substances, some of which are often used in making faucets themselves.

description: NATO's plans for expansion into Eastern Europe, released last week, are the most significant and dangerous extension of United States security commitments since the late 1940's. Before Americans pursue this course, they should understand where it could lead.
