title: HOCKEY;Clark Arrives in Nick of Time for Islanders
description: All through training camp, Islanders Coach Mike Milbury had been hoping to get either Steve Thomas or, as Milbury put it, a Steve Thomas look-alike in his lineup in time for Saturday's season opener in Boston.

title: Teachers' Union Leader Indicted
description: Theresa Lucarelli, a teacher and union leader, has been indicted on a charge of criminal coercion in an attempt to blackmail the schools superintendent, prosecutors said. But a lawyer for the New Jersey Education Association called the charges an attempt to retaliate against Ms. Lucarelli because of her activities as president of the Brielle teachers' union. Ms. Lucarelli, 47, was suspended without pay. A Monmouth County assistant prosecutor, Robert A. Honecker Jr., said yesterday that Ms. Lucarelli threatened to reveal purported "illegal activities" by Superintendent Gerard Russoniello unless another teacher, whose contract had not been renewed, was reinstated. Mr. Burch was previously associate publisher at Cosmopolitan magazine, New York, also owned by Hearst. At Cosmopolitan, Jennifer Gallo was named to succeed Mr. Burch. title: A Tribute To a Sax Workman
description: The saxophonist Frank Foster has spent a good part of the last 50 years as one of jazz's most conscientious workmen. He apprenticed in Detroit during the late 1940's and joined Count Basie's great 1950's Atomic Band, adding arrangements and compositions to its repertory. A be-bop tenor saxophonist, he was one of the orchestra's best soloists, and when he heard John Coltrane he dutifully took note, updating his vocabulary. In 1986, he began leading the orchestra.

Indeed, in some seasons, Dolora Zajick has so far outshone her partners that the opera might well have been renamed "Amneris."

title: New Pact for Finley
description: Passing up a chance to test the free-agent market after an outstanding season, San Diego Padres center fielder STEVE FINLEY agreed to a new two-year, $5.9 million contract yesterday. The contract has an option year that could make the deal worth $9.5 million over three years. (AP)

title: Hurricane Slams Into Florida With Winds of 145 M.P.H.
description: Hurricane Opal roared into the Florida Coast 25 miles east of Pensacola early this evening, pounding beaches with mountainous surf and winds in some places gusting to more than 145 miles an hour.

title: Ford Had 9% Sales Decline For September
description: Following soft September sales reports from its rivals, the Ford Motor Company said today that its sales for the month fell 9 percent, more than what analysts had expected.

title: Currents; Isak Dinesen's Bouquets
description: KAREN BLIXEN, the Danish baroness who as Isak Dinesen wrote "Out of Africa," told a friend, "When I am dead, you should make a book about my flower arrangements." More than three decades later, "Karen Blixen's Flowers: Nature and Art at Rungstedlund" (Christian Eilers, $38.50) celebrates Blixen's homemade bouquets. That friend, Steen Eiler Rasmussen, and his co-authors turn Blixen's vases -- photographed from 1953 until her death in 1962 -- into maps of a tumultuous interior world. The result is a lively look at what the book describes as "magnificent, peculiar or ugly" bouquets "created by an artist who was not often vouchsafed peace of mind." There are nifty ideas, too, like combining peonies with leeks, or gladioluses with cabbage leaves. Also worth noting: Blixen's belief that gift bouquets should be rearranged to reflect the recipient's taste, not the florist's. Available at Archivia, 944 Madison Avenue (75th Street); (212) 439-9194.

title: Margaret G. Cahill, 90, Is Dead; Was First Miss America, in 1921
description: Margaret Gorman Cahill, who became the first Miss America in 1921 and spent the better part of the next seven decades trying to live down the bathing beauty image, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Bowie, Md. She was 90 and had lived her entire life in Washington.

description: For three decades, while he pushed the development of agriculture throughout this country's once thickly forested hinterlands, Ivory Coast's founding father, Felix Houphouet-Boigny, was fond of calling himself the nation's No. 1 peasant.

title: CIRCLE K EXTENDS OFFER FOR NATIONAL CONVENIENCE
description: The Circle K Corporation said yesterday that it had extended until Nov. 1 its tender offer for National Convenience Stores Inc., which is less than National Convenience's current market value. Circle K, based in Phoenix, has offered to pay National Convenience shareholders $20 a share and $2.25 a warrant. National Convenience shares closed unchanged at $23.75 yesterday, and the warrants were unchanged at $6. So far, about 2 percent of National Convenience's shares outstanding have been tendered since Sept. 7, Circle K said. Executives of National Convenience, based in Houston, could not be reached for comment. The company rejected a buyout offer from Circle K last month.

Mr. Powers is the president of a New York institution known as the Blohards (the Benevolent Loyal Order of Honorable and Ancient Red Sox Diehard Sufferers), and he was speaking of the reorganized format of baseball's playoffs, which began on Tuesday. An extra playoff round was added in each league, featuring the three division winners and something new, a so-called wild-card entry -- the non-division champion with the best record.

title: HEINZ ANNOUNCES TEMPORARY PRODUCTION CUTS
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said yesterday that it would curtail production temporarily at five United States food-processing plants and furlough some workers under a plan to pare costs and reduce inventories. About 400 of the 700 hourly workers at its Pittsburgh plant would be idled for 10 weeks over six months, starting at the end of November, said Deb Magness, a spokeswoman for Heinz. There would be sporadic shutdowns in production of baby food and soup at the plant through April. Ms. Magness said temporary production shutdowns were also planned at four seasonal plants: a ketchup plant in Tracey, Calif.; a gravy and ketchup factory in Muscatine, Iowa; a pickle plant in Holland, Mich., and a condiments and ketchup plant in Fremont, Ohio.

title: TRITON ENERGY'S STOCK CLIMBS ON WORD OF GAS FIND
description: Shares of the Triton Energy Corporation rose yesterday after the company, an oil and natural gas producer, said it had discovered a major gas source in the Gulf of Thailand. Triton, based in Dallas, said its Suriya-1 well was tested at a flow rate of 58 million cubic feet of gas a day. The well -- a joint venture between Triton and Malaysia's state-owned oil company -- was the second success for Triton in the A-18 block of the Malaysia-Thailand Joint Development Area. Triton shares were up $2, at $49.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

description: UNC INC., Annapolis, Md., a maker of jet engines and aerospace parts, has sold its Connecticut property to a Mohegan tribe for $28.4 million in cash. UNC will use the proceeds to retire debt. COLUMBIA/HCA HEALTHCARE CORP., Louisville, Ky., acquired Chicago Osteopathic Hospital and Medical Center and Olympia Fields Osteopathic Hospital and Medical Center, also in Chicago. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. PUERTO RICAN CEMENT CO., San Juan, P.R., plans to buy Concreto Mixto Inc. and Ready Mix Concrete Inc. Terms were not disclosed. GOODYEAR TIRE AND RUBBER CO., Akron, Ohio, will spend $26.2 million to increase capacity at the Lawton, Okla., passenger-tire plant.

title: Curse of the Wild Card
description: Kind of ticks me off," Jim Powers said to me. "The team that doesn't win can win. It bugs me." Mr. Powers is the president of a New York institution known as the Blohards (the Benevolent Loyal Order of Honorable and Ancient Red Sox Diehard Sufferers), and he was speaking of the reorganized format of baseball's playoffs, which began on Tuesday. An extra playoff round was added in each league, featuring the three division winners and something new, a so-called wild-card entry -- the non-division champion with the best record.

title: Uncool in School: Dress Code Debate
description: Marc Peyser tries not to be too uncool about the way teen-agers dress. Hey, when he was in high school he was suspended for wearing shorts. He lets his son wear oversized, baggy pants, the kind that make some nervous adults cross the street and others want to grab the waistband and pull up.

title: Calendar: Tree Courses, Talks and a Show House
description: Street Trees New York, 280 Broadway, Suite 432 (Chambers Street); (212) 227-1887.

title: Sandoz Lays to Rest Bankers Trust Issue
description: Sandoz A.G., the Swiss drug company, said today that it had settled a "business dispute" with the Bankers Trust New York Corporation regarding the sale of financial contracts.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The James Beard Foundation has LEONARD PICKELL as its new president. Mr. Pickell, who has been vice president of the foundation for the last five years, as well as the wine director, fills a post that was left vacant in June with the death of Peter Kump, a founder and the first president of the organization.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a proposal by the State University of New York to curtail remedial classes referred incompletely to the new remedial policy of the City University of New York. CUNY students who are judged unable to complete remedial work within a year will no longer be admitted to bachelor's degree programs; they will be shifted to associate's degree programs.

title: Witnesses Sought in Slayings
description: The police were questioning potential witnesses yesterday who might have been present when a 20-year-old woman and 17-year-old man were shot to death on the beach late Tuesday night. A dispute over drugs was apparently the motive, the authorities said. The victims, Lisa Palm and Jordan Zimmer, both of Long Branch, were in a group gathered on the beach when an argument broke out. An unidentified man shot Mr. Zimmer in the head and then pursued Ms. Palm before shooting her several times, the police said.

title: Essay;Orgy of Memoirs
description: If Bill Clinton ever gets the urge to let Jimmy Carter meddle in foreign affairs again, he should read this passage in "In Confidence," the just-published memoirs of former Soviet Ambassador Anatoly Dobrynin:

title: ON PRO FOOTBALL;Bills Are a New Team With Some Old Faces
description: Bruce Smith glances around the Buffalo Bills locker room now, and he sees new faces. The Bills have 14 new players. They have three new starters on offense. And on Smith's side of the ball, there are six new starters.

title: The Papal Visit: An On-Line Report
description: A special on-line report on the Pope's visit, with articles from The Times, additional coverage, color photographs, historical material and forums for discussion, is available to computer users on the Internet. The address, on the World Wide Web, is http:// www.nytimes.com/pope.

title: Go to a Nursery Or to a Giant?
description: THE cozy world of mom-and-pop garden shops is under siege. Mass merchants are encroaching on turf once reserved for traditional nurseries, and apprehension is growing in the world of retail gardening.

title: Pillows of Straw
description: THE handmade pillows on Barbara Pershyn-Davis's bed in Basking Ridge, N.J., are a little firmer than most. They smell sweet, too, and they should: they're stuffed with straw. "It doesn't get saggy like down," said Ms. Pershyn-Davis, a young antiques dealer and decorator, whose idea was inspired by the organic innards of a 1700's Swedish chair she bought.

title: A Special Simple Life
description: To The Home Section:

title: Accounts
description: * Harman Consumer Group, Woodbury, L.I., a unit of Harman International, to TBWA Chiat/Day, New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group, to handle advertising for the marketer of Harman Kardon, JBL and Infinity audio systems and equipment, previously handled by Merkley Newman Harty, New York, also owned by Omnicom. The billings were estimated at $4.5 million. * Trans World Airlines, St. Louis, to Clarion Direct, Greenwich, Conn., a unit of D'Arcy, Masius, Benton & Bowles, to handle its partnership marketing and consumer incentive programs, previously handled in-house. The billings were not disclosed.

title: Man Is Executed for Killing Girl in a Robbery
description: Texas today put to death a man who killed a 17-year-old girl in the robbery of a Dallas supermarket in 1982.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK;Cyberspace Trips To Nowhere Land
description: SPACE, at its best, is comforting. It protects and encloses; it gives definition, it provides support. Even though only the four walls that surround a space are concrete objects, there is still a sense that space, in its way, is as tangible as the walls and doors and floors and ceilings around it. Space has a feel, and the effect of that on human encounters is profound.

title: Nairobi Journal;Kenya's Asphalt Jungle, With a Law to Match It
description: Well-dressed men enter the Argentine Embassy and apply for visas, then brandish weapons and clean out the safe. A drunken man stumbles over a pile of tomatoes, crushing them, and onlookers beat him to death. A crowd of Government supporters whip and beat up leading opposition figures and journalists.

title: Study Finds Vision Tests May Reduce Auto Accidents of Elderly
description: Efforts in many states to make it easier to renew driver's licenses may be misguided, according to a study that shows screening programs help reduce fatal crashes among the elderly.

title: NATO, Citing Self-Defense, Bombs Bosnia Serb Missile Batteries
description: NATO warplanes bombed three Bosnian Serb SA-6 surface-to-air missile batteries today after the sites locked their radar systems on the NATO planes flying overhead, NATO officials said.

title: THE POPE'S VISIT: LOGISTICS;From Skies To Flowerpots To Guests, All Is Secured
description: An elaborate carapace of security surrounded Pope John Paul II as he arrived at Newark International Airport yesterday for five days of prayers and ceremony.

title: USAIR CHIEF TO DELAY RETIREMENT DURING TALKS
description: USAir Group Inc. said yesterday that Seth E. Schofield would remain chief executive and chairman until the company concluded talks with the AMR Corporation and the UAL Corporation, the nation's two largest airline companies. Earlier this week, USAir said the three companies were discussing possible combinations. Mr. Schofield announced in early September that he intended to retire after 38 years at USAir. Mathias DeVito, the USAir director who headed the search committee for a new chief executive, said the committee had suspended its search.

title: How to Ruin a Safe Bet;Did Rockefeller Center Financiers Reach Too Far?
description: If a real estate investment could ever be a sure thing, a stake in Rockefeller Center Properties Inc. seemed to be it.

title: Yeltsin's Heir Bows Out of Race, Raising Doubts About Reforms
description: In a surprise decision that throws the future leadership of Russia in doubt at a time when stability seemed likely, Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin announced today that "I have never planned and I am not planning" to run for president next year.

title: Apple Official Steps Down In Board Feud
description: The executive vice president and chief financial officer of Apple Computer Inc. abruptly resigned his positions today, the apparent loser in a board room skirmish with the chief executive of the troubled computer maker.

title: HORSE RACING;Lukas Creating a Star-Spangled Banner Day at Belmont
description: Bill Mott and D. Wayne Lukas met on the Belmont Park track yesterday morning as both prepared their horses for two races in the next three weeks that will decide which one of their charges is Horse of the Year. And Lukas, who hatched one more surprise by entering Thunder Gulch in the Jockey Club Gold Cup, told Mott, the trainer of Cigar, "I brought Thunder Gulch here to make certain they weren't going to give anything away."

title: THE POPE'S VISIT: THE PRESS;Reporters Strain to See Big Picture, Vital Detail
description: A reporter from a small Catholic newspaper worried that his photo ID so little resembled him that he would be barred from papal events. A photographer from Bologna, Italy, demanded credentials to the choice picture-taking areas not allowed by her pass. A columnist for The Toronto Star strongly suggested posting notices to lay out the tight logistics of covering events for which reporters are required to arrive three hours or more in advance.

title: Shy of Votes for Term Limits, Senate G.O.P. Freshmen Ask Delay
description: Conceding that they lacked enough current support to win the Senate's approval of a constitutional amendment limiting lawmakers' terms in office, freshman Republicans asked the Senate majority leader today to postpone a vote on it until next spring.

title: Teachers Told to Stop Job Action
description: With early applications to most colleges due by Nov. 1, many of the 120 seniors at Madison High School are feeling a little less anxious this week after a Superior Court judge ordered teachers' union members to stop refusing to write letters of recommendation for students. The temporary order means that "teachers will have to start writing the letters as they have done historically," David Rand, a lawyer for the school board, said yesterday. The job action came during contract negotiations.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Mitchell Eases Way Back Into Jets' Mix
description: Johnny Mitchell, the Jets' big-play tight end, said it has been torture for him to sit around with a back injury the last four games and watch his team self destruct. Relief for himself and -- he hopes -- for his teammates is right around the corner.

title: Pre-Law Advisers Don't Conceal Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYOFFS 95;Braves Pull Away From Rockies for 2-0 Lead
description: During his nearly six years in the minor leagues, Mike Mordecai dreamed of one day making the winning hit in a championship game. He lived the thrill vicariously through a former minor league teammate, Francisco Cabrera, when Cabrera's pinch-hit single in the 1992 National League Championship Series propelled the Atlanta Braves into the World Series.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Ralph Lemon Troupe Opens Its Final Season
description: Ralph Lemon's choreography fills its austere frame with lush movement; behind his clearly formal structures, an emotional subcurrent vibrates with intensity. Above all, Mr. Lemon's works are compelling for their exploration of new ways of dancing.

title: McDowell Gets the Call for Game 3
description: Jack McDowell, who has not pitched since Sept. 21 because of a strained back muscle, will start Game 3 in Seattle for the Yankees tomorrow night.

title: More Blacks in Their 20's Have Trouble With the Law
description: The number of black men in their 20's who are imprisoned or on probation or parole has sharply risen in the past five years, and now 1 in 3 is under the supervision of the criminal justice system on any given day, according to a study being released today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The James Beard Foundation has LEONARD PICKELL as its new president. Mr. Pickell, who has been vice president of the foundation for the last five years, as well as the wine director, fills a post that was left vacant in June with the death of Peter Kump, a founder and the first president of the organization.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Tuesday's trading in the credit markets misstated the high for the December bond futures contract on Monday. It was 114 30/32, not 115 4/32.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Tuesday with an article about Germany five years after the unification of the former East and West Germany misidentified the river that forms the northern part of the German-Polish border. It is the Oder, not the Neisse.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Tuesday's trading in the credit markets misstated the high for the December bond futures contract on Monday. It was 114 30/32, not 115 4/32.

title: Not in Mayor's Pocket, Says Pivotal Board Member
description: William C. Thompson Jr., the Board of Education member from Brooklyn, chafes at the suggestion that he is now in Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's pocket.

title: PLAYOFFS 95;Leyritz's Blast in 15th Makes the Wait Worthwhile
description: It took 15 innings, it took over five hours and it took one amazing swing from Jim Leyritz to finally end the marathon, as his two-run homer off Tim Belcher lifted the Yankees to a dramatic 7-5 victory over the Mariners early this morning at Yankee Stadium.

title: THE POPE'S VISIT: DISSENT;For Some Disaffected Catholics, Visit Is Just Another Day
description: The first time Pope John Paul II visited New York City, young Daniel Durante cheered until it hurt. Then he and his brother Michael, both wearing the required blazers and ties of Cathedral Preparatory Seminary in Brooklyn, managed to get within a few feet of the pontiff.

title: When Third Parties Won the Presidency
description: To the Editor:

title: School Districts Face Loss of Aid
description: School districts whose spending on administrative costs far exceeded the state median are facing penalties totaling $10.3 million in state aid, the Department of Education said yesterday. Newark, the biggest district, with 47,500 pupils, could lose $4 million because its administrative cost was $1,414 per pupil, well above the state median of $1,030. Soaring administrative spending was one reason the state took control of the Newark district this year.

title: Finally Famous In Films, Back to Theater
description: In the last two years, Gary Sinise's movie career has taken off like a moonshot. After playing pivotal supporting roles in two Tom Hanks hits, "Forrest Gump" and "Apollo 13," and winning an Academy Award nomination for his performance in "Forrest Gump," he moved on to "Truman," incarnating the President in the HBO movie based on his life.

title: West Point Recruits Athletes, Not Minorities
description: To the Editor:

title: AT HOME WITH: Paul Auster;Chance of a Lifetime
description: WHEN Paul Auster creates his characters for novels and the screen, a chance meeting, a chance phone call often changes the course of a life. Just the sort of thing that happens to Paul Auster, too. Even happened to his dog.

title: Fiji Uproar Over Plan To Bring In Chinese
description: This may be a South Seas Eden, but a walk down Queen Street in Nadi offers a saffron-dusted vision of faraway India, the air stirred by the soft rustle of silk saris embroidered with golden thread, draped over women whose foreheads are painted with a red dot to signify marriage, and whose sidewalk conversations are in Hindi.

title: Pre-Law Advisers Don't Conceal Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Japan Companies Deny 'Dumping'
description: Three Japanese companies denied a United States Commerce Department allegation today that they are selling a chemical in the United States at below-market prices.

title: Countering Kinky Friedman
description: To The Home Section:

title: Research Group Hails Folic Acid As a Preventer of Heart Disease
description: The vitamin folic acid appears so valuable in preventing heart disease that clinical trials are urgently needed to confirm its life-saving potential, say researchers who analyzed 38 previous studies.

title: UAL EXPECTS EARNINGS TO EXCEED EXPECTATIONS
description: The UAL Corporation, the parent company of United Airlines, said yesterday that it expected third-quarter earnings to exceed Wall Street predictions. The Chicago-based air carrier attributed its outlook to higher domestic fares, strong traffic and efforts to control expenses. In the third quarter of last year, UAL earned $6.86 a share. A First Call Inc. consensus of 12 analysts' estimates forecasts a profit of $8.39 a share. UAL's stock rose $1.875 a share yesterday, to $168.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Cross Puts His Play Before The Pain
description: To understand just how tough Howard Cross is, all you have to know is this: The Giants' tight end has been playing with a torn ligament in his right knee.

title: Two Chilling Studies Of Extremism in Action
description: "Turning Point" turns back tonight to a crime spree that assumes disquieting relevance in the wake of the Oklahoma City bombing. "Inside the Hate Conspiracy: America's Terrorists" tells of a campaign of robbery and murder from 1983 to 1985 by members of The Order, a ragtag gang of ideological pretensions and violent propensities.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bonds Gain for Fourth Day; 30-Year Yield at 6.43%
description: Treasury prices extended their rally through a fourth consecutive session yesterday as reports showing subdued economic growth failed to change expectations of another cut in interest rates.

title: AMR AGREES TO CONTRACT WITH BAGGAGE HANDLERS
description: The AMR Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a tentative contract agreement last week with baggage handlers, who voted down a six-year contract in late September. The contract must be ratified by about 14,000 baggage handlers and ramp workers, who voted against the contract because of concerns about seniority. The ratification vote is scheduled for later this month. The contract is part of a plan by AMR to cut $1 billion in expenses. The remaining 13,000 Transport Workers Union members ratified the contract. "We did reach what we felt was a satisfactory conclusion," said Ed Koziatek, chief negotiator for the Transport Workers Union.

title: Flu Shot Found to Reduce Lost Work Days and Doctor Visits
description: A person need not be over 65 or chronically ill to benefit both medically and financially from flu vaccine, according to a new study of healthy, working adults.

title: Drug-Treatment Policy Is Revised
description: New Jersey courts will stop sending offenders to drug and alcohol clinics in New York and Pennsylvania without prior notice to its neighbors, a spokesman said yesterday. The announcement was prompted by a recent report in The Philadelphia Inquirer that New Jersey courts had sent about 1,000 offenders on parole or probation to chemical dependency centers in New York City and Philadelphia, often at heavy cost to those states' Medicaid and welfare systems.

title: International Briefs; Bids on Peru Utility
description: Four groups plan to present bids on Oct. 17 for 60 percent of Peru's state-owned electric utility, Empresa de Generacion Electrica de Lima S.A., or Edegel, according to the the committee organizing the sale, Ceprel. Edegel operates five hydroelectric power stations around the city of Lima, with a combined generating capacity of 700 megawatts. The 60 percent stake has a minimum price of $373 million, of which $100 million must be paid in foreign debt.

description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Pithy Recollections And Hints of Revenge
description: PALIMPSEST A Memoir By Gore Vidal Illustrated. 400 pages. Random House. $27.50.

title: Renaissance Inspiration For a Lamp
description: SCHOLARS don't know what to make of the egg-shaped object the Renaissance master Piero della Francesca dangled above the Virgin Mary in his painting for the Brera altar (inset). But the Milanese architect Achille Castiglioni knew what it could make: a great lamp. Made of translucent white glass, his Brera lamp for Flos is available as a ceiling fixture ($255), sconce ($240 to $260) or floor lamp ($420 to $470). For information: (516) 549-2745.

title: Executive Changes
description: DEAN FOODS CO., Franklin Park, Ill., appointed William R. McManaman vice president, finance, and chief financial officer. INTERSTATE BAKERIES CORP., Kansas City, Mo., named Michael D. Kafoure president and chief operating officer. SMITHKLINE BEECHAM P.L.C., Brentford, England, created a pharmaceuticals and consumer health care division and named J. P. Garnier, 47, to the position of chief operating officer and president of the unit. USG CORP., Chicago, said William C. Foote would become president and chief executive on Jan. 1. He is currently president and chief operating officer. Eugene B. Connolly, chairman and chief executive, will keep the position of chairman until April 1, when he plans to retire after 38 years of service.

title: Gongs, Chimes, Wood Blocks and Washtubs
description: More than 50 years ago, John Cage and Lou Harrison shook up the classical music establishment in New York by presenting concerts of percussion music. On Monday night, the impressive percussion quartet Talujon presented a concert that recalled those pioneering events, from the program (steeped in the traditions of the Far East) to the anti-establishment venue (the weathered Washington Square Church) to the fanciful array of instruments (gongs, chimes, wood blocks, washtubs, automobile brake drums, bowed saws and drums of every shape and size). And wouldn't you know that the most rewarding works on the program were by -- Cage and Mr. Harrison.

description: To the Editor:

title: William S. Cox, 82, A Sailing Innovator
description: William S. Cox, a well-known yachtsman and sailing innovator, died Monday in Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 82 and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: A Soggy Hello, With More to Come
description: Pope John Paul II arrived in Newark on a soggy day, and rain is in the forecast for today, tomorrow and Saturday.

title: Haley to Rejoin Bulls?
description: The newest San Antonio Spur in the Chicago Bulls court isn't DENNIS RODMAN. It is JACK HALEY, a former Bull who returns to Chicago as a buffer for the volatile Rodman, The Chicago Tribune reported yesterday.

title: The NATO Empire
description: NATO's plans for expansion into Eastern Europe, released last week, are the most significant and dangerous extension of United States security commitments since the late 1940's. Before Americans pursue this course, they should understand where it could lead.

title: 57% Watched the Verdict
description: About 107.7 million people, or 57 percent of the nation's adult population, watched the live telecast of the verdict in O. J. Simpson's murder trial on Tuesday afternoon, according to a survey commissioned by the Cable News Network.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Kidnap a Princess, Marry a British Lord
description: Two PBS institutions, both adding luster to the underwriting record of Mobil, are returning for new seasons. "Mystery!" opens its 16th year tonight at 9 with "Gallowglass," a three-part weekly presentation adapted from a psychological thriller by Barbara Vine, a pseudonym for Ruth Rendell. And on Sunday "Masterpiece Theater" begins gearing up for its 25th anniversary in January with a five-and-a-half-hour version of Edith Wharton's "Buccaneers," being broadcast over three consecutive nights. The BBC figures mightily in each series. Stock up early on snacks.

title: For One Day, a House Is Coming Out of Exile
description: THE elegant home-in-exile of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, an imposing stone villa in the Bois de Boulogne in Paris, will open its doors to the public for the first and only time on Dec. 10, the 59th anniversary of the Duke's abdication.

title: Limelight Goes Dark as Crackdown on Drugs Reaches Major Clubs
description: For more than a decade, the Limelight has been an enduring fixture on the fickle night life landscape, a place where rockers, ravers and drag queens mingled to techno or whatever the latest musical trend. This week, it has been dark and eerily quiet.

title: Charles Veach, 51, Shuttle Astronaut
description: Charles Lacy Veach, an astronaut who flew into orbit on two space shuttle missions in 1991 and 1992, died on Tuesday at his home in Houston. He was 51.

title: Eiji Okada, 75, Japanese Co-Star of 'Hiroshima, Mon Amour'
description: Eiji Okada, the Japanese actor who starred in "Hiroshima, Mon Amour" and "Woman in the Dunes" and who in his only Hollywood film appeared opposite Marlon Brando in "The Ugly American," died on Sept. 14. He was 75 and lived in Japan.

title: THE POPE'S VISIT: EN ROUTE;Pope Gives The Press Examples Of His Skill
description: Popes rarely hold news conferences, but Pope John Paul II has made it a habit on his foreign trips to come to the back of the plane for a brief chat with reporters.

title: Kotite to Shake Up Lineup
description: After watching the Jets offensive line give up six sacks in two games, Coach Rich Kotite has decided to shake up the lineup, as he had said he might. Everett McIver, a second-year offensive lineman who played mostly on special teams last year, will start at left tackle in place of Matt Willig.

title: Kiiti Morita, Mathematician, 80
description: Kiiti Morita, a mathematician who made fundamental contributions in algebra and geometry, died of heart failure at the Sakakibara Heart Institute in Tokyo on Aug. 4. He was 80 years old.

title: Coleman Arrives at Camp
description: Despite his agent's trade demand, Derrick Coleman has reported to Nets training camp, which begins Friday at Kutztown State University.

description: After sliding for the first three sessions this week, the stock market rebounded yesterday from its recent losses.

title: Ex-A.I.G. Executive To Insurance Broker
description: The Marsh & McLennan Companies said yesterday that it had hired Jeffrey W. Greenberg as a partner in its investment unit, four months after he resigned as a potential successor to his father as chairman of American International Group Inc.

title: Assembly Speaker Offers Plan to Stop Subway Fare Rise

title: Peace and Peacekeeping in Bosnia
description: In the most significant step yet toward ending the 42-month-old Bosnian war, the two sides have agreed to a cease-fire beginning next Tuesday. That is to be followed two weeks later by the start of intensive negotiations in the United States, conducted through American intermediaries. These negotiations are meant to prepare the way for face-to-face bargaining at a peace conference in Paris, and completion of a formal peace treaty.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Revival Both Familiar and New
description: IT has finally happened: "Company," Stephen Sondheim's innovative musical-comedy classic, has returned to Broadway for the first time since its Tony Award-winning premiere engagement in 1970. There have been concert versions and at least one Off Off Broadway production, but no Broadway revival until last night, when Scott Ellis's enthusiastic, glittery production opened at the Roundabout Theater. The occasion is long overdue, as well as something of a shock.

title: Festival of an Art for Life's Dirtier Nooks

But the rebellious stepchildren in any establishment tend to be subversive. And in engendering video art, a do-it-yourself form that seems invented to probe life's dirtier nooks and crannies, commercial television may have created the antidote to its own high-gloss sales pitch.

title: An Irishman Reflecting on Mankind's Strivings
description: Robert Lowell once hailed Seamus Heaney, the newest Nobel laureate in literature, as "the greatest Irish poet since Yeats," a tribute that in retrospect seems to do both men an injustice. Yes, Mr. Heaney's work remains rooted in his native Ireland, in the unforgiving landscape of its fields and bogs and rocky shores, and yes, his work grapples with the violent legacy of the Irish troubles. And yet his work is no more merely "Irish" than the work of Joyce -- or of Yeats himself. As Yeats once observed: "If we understand our own minds, and the things that are striving to utter themselves through our minds, we move others, not because we have understood or thought about those others, but because all life has that same root."

title: Lessons of Simpson Case Are Reshaping the Law

title: DIME BANCORP BUYS MORTGAGE BUSINESS ASSETS
description: Dime Bancorp Inc. said yesterday that it had bought most of the assets of a Georgia-based mortgage bank and planned to buy most of the assets of a mortgage lender in Virginia, stepping up its expansion beyond the Northeast. Dime, which operates Dime Savings Bank of New York, bought the lending operation of the National Mortgage Investments Company of Griffin, Ga., and agreed to buy the mortgage business of the James Madison Mortgage Company, a unit of First Commonwealth Savings Bank of Alexandria, Va. It did not disclose the terms of the deals. Dime is not buying the closely held companies' liabilities, a spokesman said. The mortgage lenders will become part of Dime's mortgage banking division.

Holding, the German insurance company, said yesterday that its earnings had improved in the first half of 1995 as premium income rose 3.1 percent, to 36.5 billion marks ($25.5 billion). For the full year, Allianz expects premium income to rise 5 percent, to about 70 billion marks, the chief executive, Henning Schulte-Noelle, said at the company's annual meeting. The gain would have been higher if several major currencies had not depreciated against the mark, he said. (Bloomberg Business News)

Richard Ruffalo, 44, who is legally blind, teaches five classes a day. A gold medalist in track and field in Paralympics for the physically handicapped, he is also an assistant track coach, said Joseph Petrillo, the principal. Mr. Ruffalo even demonstrates his technique for shot-put, discus and javelin throwing for students, the principal said. TERRY PRISTIN

The one concern with Alexander is his right ankle, which he broke twice in the last two seasons. He now has two screws holding it in place. title: Nice Vikings Sail to America And Find New-Age Indians
description: "Kilian's Chronicle," a squishy-headed, low-budget epic about a 10th-century Irish slave, his Viking captors and the American Indians who shelter him when he escapes, is awash in the kind of vague, elevated dialogue that makes Hollywood's biblical movies of the 1940's and 50's a hoot to watch today. The difference in tone between those films and this one is that the language of "Kilian's Chronicle" might be described as New Age Indian instead of Hollywood ancient Roman. The movie, which opens today at Cinema Village, has more than one sermon about how "land does not belong to people, people belong to the land."

title: Sports of The Times;Baseball's Clock Kept Ticking
description: IN scorched-earth policy, major league baseball has cleverly arranged that the public does not receive too much of the product. By lumping all four playoff games into the same time slot, the headless horsemen who run the business made sure that most of the country never saw more than highlights of the classic game in Yankee Stadium on Wednesday night and yesterday morning.

title: Exuberantly Operatic, In Scale and Emotion
description: Jessica Stockholder's giant new installation opening today at the Dia Center for the Arts is the best work by her I have seen, and in its own raucous, helter-skelter way, gorgeous. Gorgeous may be an odd word to describe something made out of stackable plastic crates, extension cords and a swimming pool liner, among sundry detritus. But it is, well, stunning. Occupying a 3,600-square-foot room, even spilling outside it into the center's lobby and through the room's windows to the alley next door, its scale is operatic, and so is its emotional pitch. The colors are ecstatic blues, purples, pinks, yellows and reds, and they are juxtaposed, like the many textures of the materials Ms. Stockholder uses, in wild combinations.

title: Devils' Thomas Practices
description: STEVE THOMAS practiced with the Devils for the first time yesterday before taking his physical and will play against Florida in the season opener tomorrow at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. Thomas is expected to play on a line with NEAL BROTEN as his center and JOHN MacLEAN the right wing. Coach JACQUES LEMAIRE said after yesterday's practice that BOBBY CARPENTER's cut by a skate behind his right leg that required seven stitches would keep him out of the season opener. JIMMY DOWD will take his place on the team's top checking line. MARTIN BRODEUR, who joined the team last weekend after signing his contract, said after practice it was very unlikely he would play tomorrow. Defenseman KEVIN DEAN, who was sent to the minor leagues last week, is back with the Devils. Dean is on the team's protected list and cannot be sent to the minors unless he clears waivers.

title: W. R. GRACE CUTS DIVIDEND BECAUSE OF UNIT SPINOFF
description: W. R. Grace & Company said yesterday that it had sliced its quarterly cash dividend by 64 percent because of its pending spinoff of its National Medical Care Inc. subsidiary to its shareholders. Grace, which dropped its dividend to 12.5 cents a share from 35 cents, will distribute one share of National Medical stock for each Grace share held. The spinoff is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter. Grace, based in Boca Raton, Fla., also said it planned to repurchase as many as 10 million of its common shares, or about 10 percent of its stock. Grace now has about 97 million shares outstanding. Its shares closed yesterday at $66.25, up 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 2 Village Arts Festivals
description: There will be dancing in the streets, along with music, poetry and food, at two outdoor arts festivals this weekend. A fair to benefit the Circle Repertory Theater and a local community group will be held tomorrow, from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M., on Bleecker Street, from La Guardia Place to Avenue of the Americas, in Greenwich Village. On Sunday, from noon to 6 P.M., an arts festival sponsored by the New York Shakespeare Festival will take place on Lafayette Street, between East Fourth Street and Astor Place, in the East Village. It features performers from Theater for the New City, Performance Space 122, the World Music Institute and other ensembles.

title: MEXICO PAYS BACK PART OF U.S. LOAN
description: Mexico announced today that it had recovered enough from its crippling economic crisis to repay, a few weeks ahead of schedule, $700 million of the $12.5 billion it borrowed from the United States this year, a gesture that represents as much a political payback as an economic one.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;Looking for Love in 3 Different Places
description: You might describe "Flirt," Hal Hartley's smart, sexy, wafer-light new movie, as a jauntily romantic theme and variations on young love, international style. Hopscotching from New York to Berlin to Tokyo, the film flaunts the perilously cute concept of telling the same story in three different places with three sets of characters speaking three different languages. Watching the movie is like eating ice cream -- or is it ice milk? -- in three different flavors: vanilla, chocolate and green tea. They go together nicely.

title: FILM REVIEW;Marriage, Betrayal and Turning Points

As her clearsighted, no-nonsense attitude suggests, this exceptional film takes the makings of a limp "women's weeper" and as if by magic, spins them into gold.

title: Nobel in Literature
description: Seamus Heaney, the Irish poet, was awarded the 1995 Nobel Prize in Literature yesterday. The committee cited this poem in its announcement. Article, page C30. The annals say: when the monks of Clonmacnoise Were all at prayers inside the oratory A ship appeared above them in the air. The anchor dragged along behind so deep It hooked itself into the altar rails And then, as the big hull rocked to a standstill, A crewman shinned and grappled down a rope And struggled to release it. But in vain. 'This man can't bear our life here and will drown,' The abbot said, 'Unless we help him.' So They did, the freed ship sailed and the man climbed back Out of the marvelous as he had known it.

title: Robbins & Myers Inc.(ROBN,NNM) reports earnings for 4th qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $ 1,332,000, or 25 cents a share, from refinancing of debt.Robbins & Myers said results for the latest year included a full year of operations of its Pfaudler, Chemincer & Edlon unit, which it acquired in July 1994, as well as one-half year results from the acquisition of Pharaoh, Cannon and the UPE partnership.The company attributed the increased earnings to the smooth integration of its acquisition and strength in its markets. Robbins & Myers said it also improved its debt-to-total capital ratio through strong cash flow from operations.The company said it refinaced a portion of the outstanding subordinated debt in the latest quarter. The one-time gain from this transaction was offset almost entirely by its write-off relating to Hazleton Environmental.

title: MERGER OF 2 LARGEST HOSPITAL CHAINS CLEARED
description: The Federal Trade Commission concluded an agreement yesterday permitting the merger of the nation's two largest hospital chains, the biggest hospital merger in United States history. The commission gave final approval to a consent agreement with the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation to insure that the company's $3 billion merger with Healthtrust Inc. would not impair competition. The merger would create a corporation with 320 hospitals and more than 100 outpatient surgery centers in 36 states, England and Switzerland. As a condition for approval, Columbia/HCA, based in Carrollton, Tex., agreed to sell seven hospitals and end a joint venture with another hospital. Details of the proposed agreement were announced in April.

Then Robert shoots the man, without bothering to wipe his own fingerprints off the gun. Beyond neglecting to explain why audiences ought to admire a murderer or spend two-and-a-quarter hours watching his world-weary adventures, "Assassins" also raises a few questions about how he ever got to be No. 1.

title: New York City's Capital Needs
description: With its crumbling bridges, collapsing schools, crowded prisons and deteriorating public buildings, New York City faces major infrastructure investments in the next several years. The resources available for the task are shrinking, however, because of the city's budget problems. Two decades ago New York's last fiscal crisis led to a long and disastrous period of low public investment. To avoid a recurrence, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani must find other ways to meet the city's needs.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;Of Those for Whom the Bell Tolled
description: The audience for political movies can probably be split between those who prefer "Mausoleum," a mordant short about reviving Lenin's corpse that will be shown tonight at the New York Film Festival, and those who prefer "Land and Freedom," the feature on the program. "Land and Freedom," Ken Loach's story of an Englishman who joins the anti-Fascists in the Spanish Civil War, is ambitious, often fascinating and full of intense front-line action. It is also at times excruciatingly earnest and as pedantically talky as a meeting of a high school debating society. But even those of us who prefer our films on the mordant side will find "Land and Freedom" as admirable and intelligent as any film around. The program will be shown tonight at 9 and tomorrow at 11 A.M. at Alice Tully Hall.

title: The Press Be Hanged! Britain's Judges Prefer Order in the Court
description: In a move that contrasts markedly with the way the court handled the news media in the O. J. Simpson trial, a judge here has thrown out an assault case and threatened editors of eight newspapers with contempt charges because of pretrial publicity.

title: An Irishman Reflecting On Mankind's Strivings
description: Robert Lowell once hailed Seamus Heaney, the newest Nobel laureate in literature, as "the greatest Irish poet since Yeats," a tribute that in retrospect seems to do both men an injustice. Yes, Mr. Heaney's work remains rooted in his native Ireland, in the unforgiving landscape of its fields and bogs and rocky shores, and yes, his work grapples with the violent legacy of the Irish troubles. And yet his work is no more merely "Irish" than the work of Joyce -- or of Yeats himself. As Yeats once observed: "If we understand our own minds, and the things that are striving to utter themselves through our minds, we move others, not because we have understood or thought about those others, but because all life has that same root."

title: ART REVIEW;A Pop Absurdist Who's a Happening All by Himself
description: IT'S hard to reconstruct the position that the Pop artist Claes Oldenburg occupied in the fast-changing New York art scene of the late 1950's and early 60's, when Abstract Expressionism was on the wane and everything was up for grabs. But judging from the thick catalogue that accompanies the impressive if not totally satisfying overview of his career at the Guggenheim Museum, Mr. Oldenburg's polymorphous talent took up a breathtaking amount of space.

title: Casual Gag Orders, Constitutional Farce
description: A Federal judge in Cincinnati has refused to back away from his gag order against a magazine with a story to publish. This ruling, in a case involving Business Week, Procter & Gamble and the Bankers Trust Company, is dangerous to a free press precisely because it casually approves suppression of information in an ordinary commercial trade case. Unless reversed, it will open the way for censorship in many garden-variety disputes. The Supreme Court demands strong proof of imminent, irreparable harm to the highest national security interests, but here there was not even proof of such risk to private interests.

title: Homes for the Invisible
description: A quiet victory is taking place beneath the streets of New York City. Homeless people who for 20 years have occupied a two-mile stretch of unused railroad line under Riverside Park are packing up their belongings and moving into permanent housing. Their departure is a triumph of decency, but it also points out the dilemmas arising from government plans to help the homeless.

Mr. Fuentes, the author of "Terra Nostra," is a member of his country's National Commission on Human Rights.

title: Graf Questioned for 8 Hours in Tax Matter
description: STEFFI GRAF underwent a day of questioning for alleged tax evasion, a state prosecutor said yesterday in Frankfurt. It was the first time Graf had been called in for questioning since her father and manager, PETER GRAF, was arrested in August for allegedly failing to report some $35.2 million of his daughter's earnings. PETER WECHSUNG, the chief prosecutor, said Steffi Graf was questioned for eight hours Thursday. Wechsung said that his office still had no grounds to arrest the world's No. 1-ranked player, even though her father and her tax adviser, JOACHIM ECKARDT, remained in investigative custody. (AP)

title: DART GROUP IN PACT WITH ITS FORMER PRESIDENT
description: The Dart Group said yesterday that it had reached a settlement with Ronald Haft, its former president, that will end at least some of the disputes among the feuding Haft family. Under the terms of the settlement, Mr. Haft will step down from his posts at Dart and its Crown Books and Trak Auto units. He will also sell all of his interest in the company to Dart or third parties. Mr. Haft will also drop a lawsuit against his father, Herbert, that had been part of his battle to wrest control of the company from its aging founder. "I'm hopeful that if not the end, this is the beginning of the end of the Haft family feud as it relates to Dart," said Larry Schafran, chairman of the board's executive committee. The settlement is subject to approval by a judge, the company, based in Landover, Md., said.

So it looks as though the 25-year-old Indian grandmaster has reconciled himself to bowing out with respectable draws.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: KEY GAMES OF TOP TEAMS No. 2 Ohio State (4-0) at Penn State (3-1) Penn State could not run or protect the passer or stop the pass in last Saturday's 17-9 loss to underdog Wisconsin, and its 20-game winning streak died. Ohio State is good, and its defense is opportunistic. No. 3 Florida (4-0) at No. 24 L.S.U. (3-1-1) L.S.U. struggled against South Carolina before it tied the score on a touchdown pass with 66 seconds left. Florida was good but not overwhelming against Mississippi, but its offense had a possession advantage of 39 minutes 20 seconds, and it has the edge here. No. 11 Northwestern (3-1) at No. 4 Michigan (5-0) Two teams that did not figure to be among the Big Ten's elite. Michigan has too many weapons, including quarterback Brian (son of Bob) Griese, who made his first start last week and passed for two touchdowns. No. 9 Iowa (3-0) at No. 19 Michigan State (2-1-1) Two more Big Ten contenders. Todd Schultz, starting for Iowa because Tony Banks was injured, passed for two touchdowns against Boston College. Michigan State rolled up 610 yards against New Mexico State, a soft touch. EAST Pittsburgh (2-3) at Boston College (1-3) Pitt is in deep trouble because Billy West, its heavy-duty tailback, broke his left leg and is lost for the season. Princeton (3-0) at Brown (2-1) An even game matching Marc Washington of Princeton (219 yards and 3 touchdowns rushing last week) and Jason McCullough of Brown (324 yards and 5 touchdowns passing). Penn (3-0) at Columbia (1-1-1) Penn, with 24 straight victories, has too many weapons, and Columbia's defense is too inconsistent. MIDWEST No. 22 Oklahoma (3-1) at Iowa State (2-2) Even if Troy Davis of Iowa State reaches his nation-leading rushing average of 228 yards a game, his Cyclones should be blown out. Missouri (2-2) at No. 21 Kansas State (4-0) Kansas State has beaten Temple (0-4), Cincinnati (1-4), Akron (1-3) and Northern Illinois (2-3). Missouri seems no threat, either. SOUTH No. 10 Virginia (5-1) at North Carolina (2-2) Both teams like to pass, but Mike Groh of Virginia (335 yards last week) is too good. Mississippi State (2-3) at No. 18 Auburn (3-1) This game was postponed from Thursday night because of Hurricane Opal. Auburn has a 223-yard rushing average and a four-wideout passing attack. North Carolina State (1-4) at No. 20 Alabama (3-1) In shutting out Georgia, Alabama scored on returns of a blocked field goal (90 yards), interception (26 yards) and fumble (25 yards). No. 25 Maryland (4-1) at Wake Forest (1-4) This should be easier for quarterback Scott Milanovich of Maryland, still rusty from a four-game gambling suspension. Mississippi Valley (0-4) at Grambling (2-2) Eddie Robinson of Grambling goes for his 400th coaching victory in his 54-year career. SOUTHWEST No. 8 Texas A&M (2-1) at Texas Tech (1-2) Texas Tech lost to Penn State by a point and Baylor by 2 points, both on the road, but the Aggies should be too much. No. 15 Tennessee (4-1) at Arkansas (4-1) Tennessee should win if it stops Madre Hill, who rushed for 200 yards and two touchdowns last week. FAR WEST Kansas (4-0) at No. 1 Colorado (5-0) Colorado has beaten Wisconsin, Texas A&M and, on backup John Hessler's five touchdown passes, Oklahoma. Kansas has not played a tough team yet. No. 16 Notre Dame (3-2) at Washington (3-1) In losing to Ohio State, Notre Dame dropped punts, muffed snaps and fumbled on a kick-return reverse. Washington gave up 488 yards in beating weak Oregon State. No. 8 Southern California (4-0) at California (1-3) Southern California has too many weapons, notably Keyshawn Johnson with 12 straight 100-yard receiving games. No. 13 Stanford (3-0-1) at Arizona State (2-3) Stanford has no big rusher or passer or defense, just good timing and special teams that have returned two kickoffs for touchdowns. MISMATCHES Miami (1-2) at No. 6 Florida State (4-0) In recent years, this game often had bearing on the national championship. Florida State's offense is frightening (59.5 points and 634.5 yards a game), and Miami is small, young and inexperienced. Temple (0-4) at No. 17 Syracuse (3-1) Syracuse's freshman quarterback, Donovan McNabb, is becoming a sophisticated option runner. Temple has lost 12 straight. Rankings by the New York Times computer.

Has Giuliani gone mad? Hudson Street hasn't been paved since Indians sold the town for peanuts. Always suspected Hudson Street was why they sold so cheap. All those horses busting their axles between the tunnel and Spring Street -- the Indians probably said, "Let's sell and move to Jersey before we run out of horses."

title: Making Poe's Glints and Shadows Sing
description: To study the musical influence of Edgar Allan Poe is to travel some interesting historical byways. For decades after Poe's death, the idea of setting him to music seems to have occurred to no one. Then, toward the end of the 19th century, Baudelaire and the French Symbolists urged Poe's world of "indefinite sensations" on European readers, and composers paid heed. Chief among them was Debussy, who named Poe his favorite writer and died before he could complete an operatic double-bill of "The Devil in the Belfry" and "The Fall of the House of Usher."

title: DELPHI FINANCIAL GROUP TO ACQUIRE SIG HOLDINGS
description: Delphi Financial Group Inc. will acquire SIG Holdings Inc., a provider of workers' compensation insurance, for at least $175 million. Delphi Financial, which underwrites life, disability and personal accident insurance through its Reliance Standard Life Insurance unit, said late on Thursday that it would exchange 4.4 million shares, valued at roughly $75 million, and $55.5 million in cash for SIG. Delphi will also assume $45 million of SIG's debt. Delphi, based in Wilmington, Del., could make an added payment of as much as $20 million if SIG meets certain earnings objectives. SIG provides insurance through its Safety National Casualty unit, which is based in St. Louis. Delphi's stock rose $2.25 yesterday, to $20.25 a share, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Fear Intrudes on the Fun As AIDS Joins the Party
description: When the rapper Eric (Eazy-E) Wright died of AIDS in March, the macho world of hip-hop stopped dismissing AIDS as a "gay disease," and rap moguls started to think about raising money for AIDS research and education. The result was Urban Aid 4 Lifebeat, which filled Madison Square Garden on Thursday night for five hours of hip-hop and rhythm-and-blues. A two-hour excerpt will be shown on MTV today at 3 P.M. and tomorrow at 7 P.M. Profits from ticket sales, merchandising and contributions will support Lifebeat, a music-business AIDS charity.

Priests said he possessed a magic in relating to people. His superiors noticed how he connected with suffering, considering it almost mystical. Bishop Moore, said John Cardinal O'Connor, "was the most popular preacher in town."

title: JAMESWAY CONSIDERS FILING FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: The Jamesway Corporation, which emerged from bankruptcy in December, said yesterday that it was considering filing for bankruptcy protection again. The company, a discount retailer based in Secaucus, N.J., said it might file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection because of weak sales, poor results and constricted trade credit. The company made the announcement after the stock market closed. Earlier on the New York Stock Exchange, its shares fell 25 cents, to $1, their lowest price since the company emerged from Chapter 11. The company, which has lost money in 16 of the last 20 quarters, filed for bankruptcy in July 1994, emerging in December with a $115 million line of credit.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;A Complex Taiwan Tale Needs a Key
description: In a series of eloquent, dazzling and demanding films, the director Hou Hsiao-hsien has depicted the history of Taiwan through individuals with deeply moving life stories. The island itself -- a Japanese colony before World War II, then controlled by the Nationalist Chinese with violent repression during the cold-war years -- has come to seem his most treasured character. "City of Sadness," shown at the New York Film festival in 1989, tells Taiwan's story as a family saga. The poetic "Puppetmaster," shown at the festival two years ago, layers Taiwan's history with the biography of an aged puppet maker. Now, in "Good Men, Good Women," Mr. Hou depicts Taiwan in an even more complex way, blending history with fiction, and juxtaposing the present with recent memories. He even includes a fact-based, black-and-white movie within this elegantly shot film. "Good Men, Good Women" will be shown as part of the New York Film Festival this afternoon at 2. It is one of the most richly imagined and also one of the most difficult films in the series.

Set in an ancient Spanish convent, the film, which the New York Film Festival is showing at Alice Tully Hall tomorrow at 9 P.M., is an X-ray into the morality of a bourgeois married couple who find themselves on territory designated "sacred space."

title: THE POPE'S VISIT: THE MESSAGE;Pontiff's Positions Defy the Usual Political Labeling
description: It is a measure of how much the political climate in the United States has changed in recent years that Pope John Paul II, who has built a reputation as a staunch conservative, has often sounded like an old-style liberal this week, at least in an American context.

title: Heliport: New Lease And Quiet?
description: Residents of the high-rises along First Avenue in the 30's enjoy sweeping East River views. But for years, they have endured the staccato thunder of helicopters taking off and landing at the East 34th Street Heliport. Every few minutes, all day and late into the night, the whomp-whomp-whomp of propellers cutting the air halts conversation and drowns out televisions and stereos.

title:
ON THE TOWNS: ART REVIEW;
The Dream Time Glimpsed in the Here and Now
description: THE perennial dynamic between the individual artist and tradition especially comes into play when an indigenous people meets the modern, complex urban world. In this country, American Indians are proving that age-old motifs can be harnessed for tart social commentary. At the Ben Shahn Galleries of William Paterson College, viewers are exposed to the Australian version of this meeting in "The Urban Aboriginal."

(+) Rankings reflect sales figures, for the week ending Sept. 23, at 3,050 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 28,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent sales in all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders for a book. And Bear in Mind (Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest) THE BRONTES, by Juliet Barker. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $35.) A whopping compilation that aims to do justice to the whole family, dispelling its myth as a caldron of cranks and loonies that squeezed out the occasional great novel whenever the pressure got too high to bear. THE CHESS GARDEN: Or, The Twilight Letters of Gustav Uyterhoeven, by Brooks Hansen. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) An improbable, brilliant novel about a 19th-century Dutch physician who embodies many spiritual and scientific disturbances of then and now; he's a vitalist, a mystic and an enemy of determinism. CITY LIFE: Urban Expectations in a New World, by Witold Rybczynski. (Scribner, $23.) Why our cities aren't like Paris, explained by a witty and subtle architect; mainly, their democratic vistas give no special focus to kings or bishops. THE END OF AFFLUENCE: The Causes and Consequences of America's Economic Dilemma, by Jeffrey Madrick. (Random House, $22.) A journalist turned economic historian argues that historical changes have killed the prosperity many Americans remember, and that no economic or political nostrums can bring it back. FIRE IN THE MIND: Science, Faith and the Search for Order, by George Johnson. (Knopf, $27.50.) Careful, balanced explorations of the places where scientific understanding of this extremely strange universe and religious and philosophical perceptions of it may illuminate each other. A GOOD LIFE: Newspapering and Other Adventures, by Ben Bradlee. (Simon & Schuster, $27.50.) A memoir by the former editor of The Washington Post, who was, during Watergate, the world's most famous editor; his comfortable prose makes his accomplishments look easy. MRS. TED BLISS, by Stanley Elkin. (Hyperion, $22.95.) The title character of the prodigious Elkin's final novel, an elderly widow in Miami, is occupied with death, disability and a million other subjects that fill her life with activity but not action; as for plot, don't ask. PANAMA, by Eric Zencey. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) Henry Adams (yes, the Henry Adams) turns private investigator in this complex, ambitious detective novel, which starts in Panama but moves to the Paris of the 1890's. PRAIRIE REUNION, by Barbara J. Scot. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $21.) This engaging, thoughtful memoir of a return to the scene of the author's Iowa childhood confirms that places and people have the power to change gracefully if they try. WILLIAM MORRIS: A Life for Our Time, by Fiona MacCarthy. (Knopf, $45.) A witty, shrewd, learned full-scale biography of the great 19th-century English designer whose amazing versatility (propaganda was one of his skills) has always made his center hard to find. WRITING HOME, by Alan Bennett. (Random House, $25.) Notes, prefaces, diary entries and fugitive pieces, charming and insightful, by the slyest of contemporary British playwrights.

title: MISS COUGHLIN, MR. WILLIAMS
description: Meaghan Anne Gerard Coughlin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Joseph Coughlin Jr. of Baltimore, and Timothy David Williams, a son of Carolyn A. Williams of Pittsburgh, and Ronald L. Williams of Reading, Pa., were married yesterday at the Basilica of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary in Baltimore. Msgr. W. Francis Malooly, a cousin of the bride who is the vicar general and the chancellor of the Archdiocese of Baltimore officiated. The Rev. John G. Allen, an uncle of the bridegroom who is pastor of St. Margaret Mary Church in Harrisburg, Pa., took part in the ceremony.

title: By Golly, It's Dolly Again
description: WHO COULD FORGET THAT MOUTH -- LIKE THE FRONT grille of a 50's roadster. And those headlight eyes. It must be Dolly Levi a k a Carol Channing: the two have never been far apart since the actress opened in the original "Hello, Dolly!" on Broadway in 1964. The Yonkers matchmaker is setting up shop at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, where previews of the Jerry Herman musical begin on Wednesday. It opens on Oct. 19. Al Hirschfeld has chronicled a chorus of Carol Channings over the years, including that first David Merrick production in which the performer was followed by, among others, Pearl Bailey and Ethel Merman.

title: Alice J. Blank, David S. Udell
description: Alice Jo Blank, an architectural designer, and David Stuart Udell, a lawyer, were married last evening in New York. Rabbi Emily Korzenik performed the ceremony at the Civic Center Synagogue.

title: As Pontiff Visits, An Ailing School Is Seeking Hope
description: Beaming, the 15 sixth, seventh and eighth graders bounded into the St. Brigid School office on Wednesday to pick up buttons that bore the smiling countenance of Pope John Paul II. The students, who were to see the Pontiff in Central Park yesterday, seemed as carefree as any children who live in a neighborhood as poor and pockmarked as Alphabet City.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: POP GOES THE CLOWN BOY
description: In the fall of 1957, I was 9 years old and attending Children's Paradise School in Santa Monica, Calif. The place was a dump site for disturbed kids; the hours of confinement stretched from 7:30 A.M. to 5:00 P.M. daily. Children's Paradise was unaccredited and featured a large play area and a swimming pool.

title:
SOAPBOX;
The World of a Child in an Old Chair
description: MY wife's great aunt passed away, and we were given a chance to look over her old furniture before it was sold. So off we went to Aunt Gertie's apartment way up in the Bronx where we chose a beautiful mahogany bedroom set from the 1920's. We were heading toward the door when Linda stopped before a big old comfortable chair. It had wooden legs and arm rests and was upholstered in a beige, green, peach and orange floral pattern.

title: THE CHAIN GANG SHOW
description: What the hell is wrong with America? Who infused us with the idea that this sort of oppression is O.K.? This "chain gang show" strips criminals of the basic human rights that everyone is guaranteed. This is a racist movement that emulates if not celebrates the slavery of the South. I am thoroughly appalled.

title: For Board of Education, Another Live Saturday Night
description: For the second week in a row, parents and others who care about the schools found themselves spending Saturday night in an ornate hearing room of the Board of Education headquarters in Brooklyn, talking about yet another candidate for schools chancellor.

title: THE NATION;And Now, the Audience Rests
description: BY nightfall on judgment day, the national throng of juror-voyeurs was discovering that justice can be tempered with mercy, for it looked, at long last, as if the end of the O.J. spectacle was in sight. Fresh ephemera began flickering across the tube: the pending arrivals, live and in color, of Pope John Paul II, Hurricane Opal and the divisional playoffs in baseball, a game that used to be called the national pastime before the O.J. Simpson trial squandered so much of the nation's curiosity.

title: A Child and His Computer Banishing Loneliness
description: SOMEWHERE along the line in American culture, the television set replaced the hearth as the place around which families typically gathered in the evenings.

title: FOOD;Perfect Okra, a Farmer's Market Fall Treasure
description: ONE of the joys of summer and fall is the farmer's market. Recently, in addition to great apples, fall raspberries and tiny string beans, I found the most perfect okra I have ever seen: emerald green in color and without a blemish.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: GREENWICH;
Four Acres of Farm, a Holdout in Suburbia
description: If ever there were a secret garden for children and the young at heart in the middle of Greenwich, it would be in the backyard at David Wierdsma's place. It is no ordinary backyard, situated as it is two miles from downtown Greenwich, at the corner of Lake Avenue and Round Hill Road in an area in which the Rockefellers and DuPonts once were neighbors.

title: RESTAURANTS;Rich and Richer
description: IN the moderate price range, New Jersey probably has more notable Italian restaurants than any place except Italy and lower Manhattan. But what happens when you move into the more expensive realm? What happens when you look for the state's best Italian food?

title: FALL AND WINTER CRUISES;IN FRANCE, A BOAT OF ONE'S OWN
description: THE part of France I had my eye and heart set on merited no more than a paragraph or two in the guides I kept pulling from the four shelves of books on Gallic tourism at my travel bookstore. The galaxy of stars that blanket the country in the Guide Michelin restaurant maps showed my region of choice to be a black hole. The local drink was the robust Arbois of the Jura, a wine the color of a fruit bruise with a bracing, brow-furrowing character that few foreigners have ever acquired a taste for. And the only people who brightened at the mention of the river I planned to navigate, the Saone, were neither gourmets nor oenophiles. They were crossword puzzle addicts.

title: Ancient Culture, Modern Campers
description: HOW often can you go on a retreat where the ghosts of saints have been seen walking the beach, monks in clifftop monastaries tell stories of miracles and the culture outside the camp gates is 4,000 years old?

title: Nancie J. Rudy, Daniel M. Rosen
description: Nancie Jill Rudy, the daughter of Dr. Kathie Kramer Rudy and Charles G. Rudy, both of Great Neck, L.I., is to be married today to Dr. Daniel Marc Rosen, a son of Susan and Hank Rosen of San Diego. Rabbi Jerry Winston is to officiate at Beaulieu Gardens in Rutherford, Calif.

title: The 'Big Guy' With the Beard
description: I used to think God was this big guy with a hairy beard," Annie Levitt, 12, says, laughing. She reaches over to grab a chicken wing from a serving platter. There's supposed to be enough food for 400 kids at tonight's Reform Judaism Sabbath youth service and dinner at Camp Swig in Saratoga, Calif., but you can never be too sure.

title: Sales Tax At Issue In Election In Suffolk
description: WITH elections for Suffolk County Executive and all 18 seats in the County Legislature next month, a retiring incumbent has altered the political landscape by questioning whether Suffolk can do without $35 million in sales-tax revenue next year.

title: Ms. Rotanelli And Mr. Baehrle
description: Christine Marie Rotanelli, the daughter of Joanne M. Ficaro of Bayside, Queens, and the stepdaughter of John McElligott of Floral Park, L.I., was married on Friday to Philip James Baehrle, the son of Mary B. Baehrle of Floral Park. Msgr. James Cooney performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Victory Church in Floral Park.

title: The Arts of Norway From Film to Folk
description: A program of Norwegian cultural events called "Norwegian Visions" will run in New York and Washington throughout this fall, with a few events continuing into 1996. Among the program's sponsors are Kraft Freia Marabou, S.A.S. and the Royal Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

title: Of, by and for the Public
description: Now that Shakespeare in the Park has ended its season, the Joseph Papp Public Theater is presenting its performances outdoors in an entirely different setting.

title: HOCKEY;The Devils, And Fans, Ignite First Match
description: The memory of the Stanley Cup triumph was fresh for the Devils and their fans. Just three months and 13 days after they paraded the coveted trophy around the ice amid pandemonium at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the Devils raised their first Stanley Cup banner in the south end of the arena here this afternoon.

title: THE DNA WE'VE BEEN DEALT
description: As the science of genetic testing continues to improve, many more healthy people will be found to have a gene or a combination of genes predisposing them to illness ("The DNA We've Been Dealt," by Charles Siebert, Sept. 17). In fact, if every American were to undergo genetic testing, we would discover that each of us possesses some type of faulty DNA. However, such a diagnosis should not also put us at risk of losing our health insurance or our jobs simply because of the possibility of a pre-existing condition. We must enact legislation to prohibit discrimination based on genetic status. JENNIFER L. HOWSE President, March of Dimes Defects Foundation White Plains

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;Family in Tow, A Budding Diva Turns to Song
description: A GLEAMING GRAND PIANO AND a multicolored playpen vie for dominance in Heidi Grant Murphy's spacious living room on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, seeming to define her struggle to maintain a vital balance between home and career. The piano urged its supremacy recently, as Ms. Murphy, a 29-year-old soprano, prepared for her first New York recital on Friday at Weill Recital Hall.

title: Victor/Vittorio
description: IN A GLASS HOUSE By Nino Ricci. 275 pp. New York: Picador USA. $22. NINO RICCI was born in 1959 in Leamington, Ontario, and holds dual Canadian and Italian citizenship. His first novel, "The Book of Saints," won Canada's Governor General's Award and a host of other honors, and it was easy to see why, for "The Book of Saints" was a brilliant, brooding, beautifully written, hard-edged rendering of the Italian Apennine village of Valle del Sole and the clannish, fiercely pious, omen-fearing families who inhabit it.

title: Gay Blacks in Quandary Over Farrakhan's March
description: Not certain that they are welcome, not even sure they will be safe, black homosexuals are uneasily asking themselves whether they belong inside or outside the Million Man March in Washington.

description: A DECADE after General Motors created the Saturn Corporation as a separate company to build and sell small cars in a new way, there is considerable evidence of its success.

title: OUT OF ORDER;The Soul of the Island Set to Verse
description: ON the surface Long Island life seems to be all prose. Just under the surface, it is vibrating with poetry. Fall is a specially rich time for poets, being sad and damp, and full of regrets about unfinished summer tasks, like cleaning the pond. As the evenings draw in, libraries and bookstores all over Long Island will offer hundreds of poetry readings, to help us push away the winter darkness.
