The girls at Lauren's slumber party are all chattering at once, but at that command -- which according to their self-styled code of friendship can be issued by anyone who feels the group is out of control -- they break off, some in midsentence, and suck in lungfuls of air.

title: MUSIC IN WARTIME;Britten and Owen: A Second Look
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE TOWNS: THEATER REVIEW;Casting a Fresh Eye On a 43-Year-Old Hit
description: ONE friend saw it at Middlesex County College in Edison in the 1980's. Another recalls the old Paper Mill Playhouse production in Millburn; that must have been in the 70's. And then there are those who were in it. A teacher played Major Metcalf at one community theater in Princeton. A writer had a go at Christopher Wren with one amateur group, at Detective Sergeant Trotter with another.

title: To Be Small and Adorable For Another 'Nutcracker'
description: FOUR at a time, the would-be mice scampered across the floor in their tutus, leotards and blue jeans. Then they posed with hands curled under their chins while a panel of judges from the Purchase College division of dance scrutinized them. Being small and adorable might be enough to get you into the college's yearly production of "The Nutcracker," but bright eyes and lively, staccato movements also helped.

title: Florida Lags as Other States Recover Quickly From Hurricane
description: While beach towns on the Florida Panhandle have been slowly digging out from the devastating legacy of Hurricane Opal, recovery has been quick in Georgia and Alabama, where the storm affected the greatest number of people.

title: Goodbye, Dali
description: SURREALISM IN EXILE And the Beginning of the New York School. By Martica Sawin. Illustrated. 466 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $45. NO decade in American art was livelier than the 1940's, in part because its most influential figures were not American at all. Rather they were French Surrealists, who sailed to New York as refugees from World War II and stayed on until the war's end. Moving into fifth-floor walk-ups in Greenwich Village or run-down farmhouses in western Connecticut, the exiled artists grumbled about the New World, which seemed to lack everything from a good loaf of bread and a comfortable cafe to any semblance of high culture.

title: Study Discounts the Role of Drug Users in Gun-Related Crime
description: Contrary to popular belief, drug users are not likely to carry guns and are not responsible for the rapid rise in violent crime committed with guns, according to a new nationwide study of why criminals carry guns.

title: FOSSILIZING
description: We old fossils are always delighted when we encounter one of Jack Rosenthal's language fossils (On Language: "Fossilizing," Sept. 10). These expressions magically conjure up the days of our youth, the style, the slang, the atmosphere of fun, the air we breathed.

title: HOME CLINIC;Fibers, Glues, Padding and Other Carpeting Secrets

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MADISON SQUARE/STUYVESANT SQUARE;Tripping Up the Hawkers' Foothold on First Ave.
description: It's 4 P.M. on a mild autumn day. Along a two-block stretch of First Avenue, between 14th and 16th Streets, 10 vendors stand behind bridge tables laden with socks, sweaters, dresses, leggings and lingerie. Others hawk apples and oranges from pushcarts.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;The High Cost Of Sailing Alone
description: SINGLE supplements, like taxes or cold sores, are always unwelcome. But when it comes to cruises, the penalties for traveling alone are particularly annoying: steep and difficult to understand.

title: CONFESS, EARLY AND OFTEN
description: The term my grandmother used for my grandfather was "impatient." What I and the other grandchildren knew was that even though our grandfather indulged us with candy bars, teased us by grabbing our legs under the table and exclaiming, "Snakes! Snakes!" and taught us everything from diving to poker playing, he was quick to anger and a little unpredictable. It was therefore with horror that I watched my 9-year-old friend Susan Clayton rip one of the bridge cards while we were playing a forbidden game of slapjack. The point of the game was to slap one's hand down on the pile whenever a jack was turned over, and thereby claim the pile. The game was forbidden because we'd torn a card before. I had, in fact, climbed on a chair, and then the dining-room table, in order to get the cards down from the dish rail near the ceiling where my grandfather had put them. Now another card, from the deck bought to replace the damaged one, was torn. My grandfather believed in corporal punishment, and my grandmother, too. I was not too old to be switched, at 9. I had recently been switched for leaving my glasses in the mailbox, where they were broken by a heavy package. I gathered up the cards, including the torn one, and stuffed them back in their case beside the second, similar deck that was also ruined, then I climbed the chair and the table, and set them on the dish rail, exactly in the spot and the position where I'd found them. It was the middle of the afternoon, late summer. My friends and I went outside to find something else to do.

He gave away more than $100 million -- about $1 billion in today's dollars -- mainly to schools, the University of Rochester and local hospitals. He helped start the organization that became the United Way in Rochester. One year he even paid to remove the tonsils of every child in town.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;Biber, Zelenka and How The Baroque Got a 'Bad' Name
description: THE WORD "BAROQUE" has wandered far from its original meaning. It once conveyed a taste for the irregular, the bizarre, the grotesque; the French critic Noel Antoine Pluche used it to pour scorn on a musical style "pulsating with speed and noise," and early English translations rendered it as "rough." But in popular usage, it became synonymous with enlightened extravagance, a style more monumental than bizarre. The vast popularity of Vivaldi, Telemann and others on classical radio has caused a further mutation: the Baroque now stands for soothing regularity, a continuo massage for tired commuter ears.

It has a scent we want to take inside to make us feel warm. Its color -- a deep amber, almost burnt -- is a perfect distillation of the supernova explosion of autumn's palette, and its taste combines the sweetness of the summer just past with the sharpness of the winter to come.

title: FALL AND WINTER CRUISES;AFTER THE STORMS, SHIPS SAIL ON
description: AFTER operating close to capacity almost every summer, the cruise industry usually pauses in autumn to reposition fleets to warm winter climes and to catch its collective breath. But there will be no rest for the weary this fall. That's because Hurricane Luis tore into the Caribbean in early September, causing damage ranging from drastic to minor in Anguilla, Antigua, Barbuda, Montserrat, St. Barthelemy, St. Kitts and St. Martin-St. Maarten. And just days later, Hurricane Marilyn barreled through the U.S. Virgin Islands, devastating the popular cruise port of St. Thomas and damaging parts of St. John; St. Croix suffered relatively minor damage.

Somebody's in My Grave
description: WHEN my best friend, Pearl, came North, she drove me to the cemetery for my first visit since my mother's name was added to my parents' double stone. As we climbed flights of crumbling cement steps, then walked off-balance across a steep incline, I told Pearl stories of the families whose headstones line the old Jewish graveyard on Mc Bride Avenue, just as their homes lined Paterson's streets. Little did I know that before our visit was done, my friend from North Carolina would adopt the woman resting next to my mother. This woman -- I'll call her Rosie -- was taking up the spot that was supposed to be eternally my own.

title: Great Pumpkin Lives! Here's Proof
description: WHAT: An 828-pound pumpkin. WHERE: Gancarz Farm, Jacobstown, North Hanover Township, Burlington County. PLANTED: April 2, 1995, from four-year-old seed. COLOR: Light orange and green. BROTHERS AND SISTERS: Seventy to eighty pumpkins weighing 100 pounds or more, none of which end up in pies. All are sold for display at 25 cents a pound (for those up to 200 pounds) or 50 cents a pound for ones weighing more than that. The price for the 828-pounder is under negotiation. HOW LONG IT KEEPS: Until the first hard freeze if it's left outside. Up to a year if it's inside. HOW MANY PEOPLE IT TAKES TO LIFT AN 828-POUND PUMPKIN ONTO A SCALE: 10. TALE OF THE TAPE: Circumference, 14 feet 2 inches. BIGGEST EVER?: Sorry. It's the largest ever grown on the farm of Edward and Robert Gancarz (pronounced GAN-charz), but short of the current record, 990 pounds, and the 1,000-pound mark they hoped to break. In 1990, the brothers grew an 816-pound pumpkin. NEXT STOP: Contest this weekend in Anamosa, Iowa, sponsored by the Great Pumpkin Commonwealth. Possible prize, $1,000 for largest pumpkin displayed there. PRIZE THAT GOT AWAY: $50,000 from the World Pumpkin Confederacy for any pumpkin exceeding 1,000 pounds. If no one wins, the prize money carries over to next year. FARM MOTTO: There's always next year. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: I SPOTTED MY GRANDPA'S WATCH. . .
description: My maternal grandfather, Ernest Taylor, was born in 1866 in Waterbury, Conn. As a boy he was apprenticed to a local clockmaker, and when he had learned his trade, he moved to Waltham, Mass., to work at the watch factory there. A few years later, he opened his own shop, where, for the rest of his nearly century-long life, he repaired fine watches and heirloom clocks, manufactured and adjusted scientific instruments for professors at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and even set Admiral Peary's chronometers for his North Pole voyages. A rigorously ordered, meticulous man of exceptional intelligence, he was a widower after 1934, and by the late 1940's he seemed a solitary survivor of a long-gone time, when moral standards were stricter, clearer and somehow more easily kept than now. He was like one of his own handmade mahogany grandfather clocks, while the rest of us -- his four daughters, three sons-in-law and dozen grandchildren -- were mass-produced, unreliable tin wristwatches that had to be set and reset constantly against his perfect movement.

It has never been more threatening than in the new Chief Inspector Wexford narrative, one of the author's best, which comes to us bearing the curious title "Simisola." The weather, here as before, derives from the particular social disturbances at work. In some of Ms. Rendell's most ingenious earlier tales -- in "From Doon With Death" (1965) or in "A Sleeping Life" (1978) -- the drama turned on brilliantly managed uncertainties about sexual identity. In "Simisola," the mystery involves a matter of racial identity.

description: I agree with Paul Starr's comments about the potentially harmful consequences of managed-care expansion as part of the Republicans' program to control Medicare and Medicaid expenditures ("Look Who's Talking Health Care Reform Now," Sept. 3). Corporate America is appropriating health care in this country with the sole purpose of making profit, by brutally squeezing doctors and hospitals financially and by restricting, and even denying, high-tech care to patients. The irony of H.M.O.'s aggressively seeking Medicare patients is evident from the fact that Medicare pays less than 70 percent of actual cost. Obviously, the only way they can make a profit from these patients is to deny care. I can vouch from personal experience that this is increasingly taking place.

title: STILL AFRAID OF BEING CAUGHT
description: In a sense, all of life -- every action -- is a transgression. A child's undulled sensitivity picks up the cosmic background of danger and guilt. A child is in constant danger of doing something wrong. I was most severely punished, as I fallibly recall it, for being late in getting back home. At least once and perhaps several times my mother, her face red with fury, pulled a switch from the stand of suckers at the base of the backyard pear tree and whipped me on the backs of the calves with it, when I had been, let's say, a half-hour late in returning from the playground or some friend's house a few blocks away. Fear for my safety was, I suppose now, behind this stinging discipline, but at the time it seemed mixed up with her fear that, by playing late with some other boy, I would be on the road to homosexuality. She didn't like to see me wrestling with other boys, even on our own property. No doubt she was right, taking "homosexual" in its broadest meaning, about young male roughhousing, but to my prepubescent self her anxieties seemed exaggerated. She didn't like to see my father, a 6-foot-2 schoolteacher with, as far as I could see, normal tendencies, put his hand on his hip either. But whatever the psychological roots of her (as I saw it, with eyes full of tears) overreaction, it did its work on my superego: I have an unconquerable dread of being late for appointments or returning home later than promised, and what modest heterosexual adventures were mine in adulthood received the slight extra boost, from deep in my subconscious, of my mother's blessing. Better this than one more game of Parcheesi over at Freddy Schreuer's, as the clock ticked sinfully toward 5:30.

title: Around the World in 800 Pages
description: MILLENNIUM A History of the Last Thousand Years. By Felipe Fernandez-Armesto. Illustrated. 816 pp. New York: Scribner. $35. FELIPE FERNANDEZ-ARMESTO has accomplished a herculean task. In these days of cube-shaped books by logorrheic authors, he has managed to write the whole world, or at least to compress the world's last thousand years, into 737 pages of illustrated text, with terse but thorough notes, in a volume that is a pleasure to hold and read. One of his epigraphs comes appropriately from Jorge Luis Borges's story "The Aleph," about the discovery of a magical microcosm only an inch in diameter but containing the whole of creation. Perhaps I should say that Mr. Fernandez-Armesto has written a world, not the world, since "reality," as Vladimir Nabokov insisted, is a word that should always be restrained by quotation marks. A botanist dwells on a different earth from a geologist. Even historians of, say, Alexander the Great have been known to bludgeon one another with different versions of their pathological genius, a point the author acknowledges.

title: I SPOTTED MY GRANDPA'S WATCH. . .
description: My maternal grandfather, Ernest Taylor, was born in 1866 in Waterbury, Conn. As a boy he was apprenticed to a local clockmaker, and when he had learned his trade, he moved to Waltham, Mass., to work at the watch factory there. A few years later, he opened his own shop, where, for the rest of his nearly century-long life, he repaired fine watches and heirloom clocks, manufactured and adjusted scientific instruments for professors at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and even set Admiral Peary's chronometers for his North Pole voyages. A rigorously ordered, meticulous man of exceptional intelligence, he was a widower after 1934, and by the late 1940's he seemed a solitary survivor of a long-gone time, when moral standards were stricter, clearer and somehow more easily kept than now. He was like one of his own handmade mahogany grandfather clocks, while the rest of us -- his four daughters, three sons-in-law and dozen grandchildren -- were mass-produced, unreliable tin wristwatches that had to be set and reset constantly against his perfect movement.

title: The Trials of Dr. Sheppard
description: Early on the morning of July 4, 1954, in the Cleveland suburb of Bay Village, Marilyn Sheppard was beaten to death as she slept in an upstairs bedroom of her lakefront home. Around dawn, her husband, Sam Sheppard, called the Mayor, a family friend, and reported the crime. Sheppard claimed he had fallen asleep downstairs, was awakened by an intruder and knocked unconscious twice: once upstairs, and again as he struggled with a man fleeing along the beach. There was no sign of a break-in. The police caught Sheppard, an osteopath, lying about an affair with a lab technician, and he refused to take a lie detector test. Prosecutors were goaded by a shrieking press. One Cleveland newspaper ran 399 stories in six months, with headlines like "WHY ISN'T SAM SHEPPARD IN JAIL?" The trial judge failed to screen the jury from such reports and allowed the news media to pack the courtroom, with 20 reporters sitting in front of the bar. After a two-month trial, Sheppard was convicted of murder. In 1966, condemning the "carnival atmosphere," the United States Supreme Court granted Sheppard a new trial. He was represented by F. Lee Bailey, and he won acquittal. In MOCKERY OF JUSTICE: The True Story of the Sheppard Murder Case (Northeastern University, $24.95), Cynthia L. Cooper, a lawyer, and Sam Reese Sheppard, the Sheppards' son, provide a slanted but comprehensive review of this cause celebre. Nothing here proves Sam Sheppard's innocence. The authors soft-pedal his alcoholism and increasingly bizarre behavior. Mr. Sheppard even briefly raises a discredited theory that his mother was killed by a lover of her own. That's more than irresponsible; it's sad. ALLEN D. BOYER

title: STILL AFRAID OF BEING CAUGHT
description: In a sense, all of life -- every action -- is a transgression. A child's undulled sensitivity picks up the cosmic background of danger and guilt. A child is in constant danger of doing something wrong. I was most severely punished, as I fallibly recall it, for being late in getting back home. At least once and perhaps several times my mother, her face red with fury, pulled a switch from the stand of suckers at the base of the backyard pear tree and whipped me on the backs of the calves with it, when I had been, let's say, a half-hour late in returning from the playground or some friend's house a few blocks away. Fear for my safety was, I suppose now, behind this stinging discipline, but at the time it seemed mixed up with her fear that, by playing late with some other boy, I would be on the road to homosexuality. She didn't like to see me wrestling with other boys, even on our own property. No doubt she was right, taking "homosexual" in its broadest meaning, about young male roughhousing, but to my prepubescent self her anxieties seemed exaggerated. She didn't like to see my father, a 6-foot-2 schoolteacher with, as far as I could see, normal tendencies, put his hand on his hip either. But whatever the psychological roots of her (as I saw it, with eyes full of tears) overreaction, it did its work on my superego: I have an unconquerable dread of being late for appointments or returning home later than promised, and what modest heterosexual adventures were mine in adulthood received the slight extra boost, from deep in my subconscious, of my mother's blessing. Better this than one more game of Parcheesi over at Freddy Schreuer's, as the clock ticked sinfully toward 5:30.

title:
URBAN VISTA;
Lasting Impressions
description: THERE are ghost buildings all over lower Manhattan. They are still-tangible links to the New York of the early 19th century, when the city was taking its first, rapid leap northward. It was a booming town, thanks to the new Erie Canal - the conduit to the Great Lakes that gave New York easy access to Western markets, helping it beat close contenders like Boston and Philadelphia.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In: New City;Open Space, 30 Miles From the Big City

It is the site of the 565-acre High Tor State Park and contains three working farms, several nature preserves and the 200-acre Dellwood Country Club. The feeling of open space is enhanced by the fact that most of the building lots are half an acre or more.

title: Blind by Choice
description: ALBERT SPEER: HIS BATTLE WITH TRUTH By Gitta Sereny. Illustrated. 757 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $35. GITTA SERENY does not write about Albert Speer's battle for or against truth. As her choice of title suggests, Speer battled with truth from 1945 until his death in 1981 at the age of 76, locked in combat with a moving target, sometimes adversary, sometimes friend. In the shadow behind him has been Ms. Sereny, who has engaged in a lifelong effort to wrest a new understanding of the human condition from Nazi genocide. The contest in "Albert Speer: His Battle With Truth" centers not on what the man did but on what he knew. "Eventually," Ms. Sereny writes, "he had gained knowledge of the abominations and recognized that they originated with Hitler. What then kept this man in place? What had prevented him, whose possibilities for escape were unlimited, from taking himself and his family out of it?"

title: FROM THE DESK OF;My O.J. Problem: Just Who's the Underdog?
description: I CAN recall a long arid stretch in my early childhood when "The Lone Ranger" and "Hopalong Cassidy" had been suddenly, for no reason, replaced on television by an endless show of unspeakable dullness on which men sat at long tables, day after day, doing nothing but talking and occasionally refilling their water glasses. The Army-McCarthy hearings taught me, at the age of five, that what seems to be the order of things can change at any time -- and not necessarily for the better.

title: Diary
description: PARKING Delivered, Presumably, Dent-Free In a test run in Augsburg, Germany, an automatic rotating disc brought three cars to their parking slots. The promised waiting time at this fancy new garage: 2.5 minutes PUBLISHING Those Business Week Papers Let's see. First Procter & Gamble sued Bankers Trust, saying it had been led down a too-risky investment path. A mass of papers quickly piled up -- lawyers tend to be good at that -- and a judge decided some of them weren't quite ready for public consumption. Then Business Week got hold of the sealed papers and smelled a scoop, a judge said no, and all sorts of First Amendment hell broke loose. Last week some smoke cleared, as the judge unsealed the documents, which seemed to bolster P.&G.'s case by disclosing losses at other companies from derivatives sold by Bankers Trust. But the free-speech issue was left smoldering, for the judge also insisted he had the right to stop publication. Now it's in the lap of the appeals courts. CHARITY Throwing Big Money at Cancer It's all too familiar these days: a takeover, a merger, a little board-room back-scratching, and some executive walks away with a sum that would boggle the mind even if it lost a couple of zeroes. But last week came a stunning variation: the mind-numbing sum was going not to an executive but to science. Jon Huntsman, who made about $1 billion in chemicals, lost both parents to cancer and battled it twice himself. That was enough to prod him to say he'd give $100 million to a cancer research center at the University of Utah. That may be walking-around money to Ted Turner, but it's the largest individual gift ever to medical research. "It's been 26 years since a man walked on the moon," Mr. Huntsman said, and we're still battling cancer. He wants to win this one. AUTOS Speaking Out at Chrysler The seat belts are off at Chrysler. Last week the chairman, Robert Eaton, lashed out at those he said wanted to "trash" the company -- mainly Kirk Kerkorian and Jerome York. He said Mr. Kerkorian, who now owns nearly 15 percent of Chrysler, "has no real knowledge" about what's happening and is merely out for "personal gain." He said Mr. Kerkorian and Mr. York -- the former Chrysler executive who's now in Mr. Kerkorian's camp -- are merely harming other shareholders by trying to gain control.

title: SPINE TINGLERS

title: Bridgeport Casino Faces More Hurdles
description: GOV. JOHN G. ROWLAND'S selection last week of the Mashantucket Pequot Indians over Stephen A. Wynn's company, Mirage Resorts Inc., to build a casino along Bridgeport's waterfront is being hailed by some city and state officials as a catalyst to create 10,000 jobs and jump start both the city and region's long-ailing economy. But one major hurdle -- approval by the General Assembly -- still stands in the way of Bridgeport's long-fought battle to open a luxury gaming resort. Now that he has made his decision and has one comprehensive proposal to recommend to state legislators, who will meet in special session later this month, Mr. Rowland says he believes he has at least a 50-50 chance of persuading lawmakers to authorize gambling in Bridgeport.

title: ESSAY;Crimes Against Children: The Trend in Mysteries
description: WHY are so many children muscling their way into crime and detective fiction? Lawyers love to represent them in legal thrillers. Serial killers have made them their prey of choice. Kidnappers are passing up prize catches like international industrialists and spoiled heiresses and snatching their kids instead. Children are getting to be such a hot item that two novels published this fall have the same plot gimmick. In Jeffery Deaver's thriller "A Maiden's Grave," three escaped convicts kidnap eight deaf schoolgirls and their teachers from a school bus and hold them hostage in an abandoned slaughterhouse in Kansas. The religious fanatic who kidnaps 11 elementary-school children in Austin, Tex., in Mary Willis Walker's cliffhanger "Under the Beetle's Cellar" buries them underground, bus and all.

title:

We were heading toward the door when Linda stopped before a big old comfortable chair. It had wooden legs and arm rests and was upholstered in a beige, green, peach and orange floral pattern.

first arrest atage 11 for assaulting a police officer with a waterpistol, you and your best friend, the policeroughing you up at the station and feeling badabout it afterward at the juvenile court,one of them, the fat and stupid one who heldyou by the throat at the jail, sayingapologetically to the judge while twistinghis hat in his hands, "Shoot, he's prolly agood kid, shoot, when I wuz a boy we usedto throw taters at the mail truck."THOU SHALT NOT COMMIT ADULTERYnor seduce your jerky neighbor's new puppy, coaxing it out past the city limits and letting it chase chickens and bark at pigs until it is exhausted and you have to carry it home sleeping in your arms, the puppy always loving you for this day ina way it will never love your jerky neighbor.THOU SHALT NOT STEAL,not pocketknives you immediately lose norbullets for guns you do not own nor railroad flares you let get wet nor even the coins from your father's collection, which should not count because in the divorce he forgot them in the attic.THOU SHALT NOT BEAR FALSE WITNESSagainst thy jerky neighbor because the wholetown knows it was you anyway.THOU SHALT NOT COVETthy jerky neighbor's house nor anything hehas, and you know exactly what he has because when he and his family were on vacation theygave you a key to feed their dog and you and your best friend spent a leisurely afternoon inhis house playing in his room with his toys ina way you would not play with your own, maybebreaking one or two, until you heard a noise like akey scratching into a lock and you scrambledto fix things up, maybe put back a couple of littlethings you had stuffed in your pockets, andyou and your best friend ran out through thestale kitchen onto the back porch where the shadeswere down and you flung open the back doorand were stopped dead by the jerky neighbor'sdog whose paw was lifted in mid-scratch to comein, and you and your best friend turned andlocked the door and walked stiffly away feelingthe eyes of God and dog upon you.

title: American Psycho
description: ZOMBIE By Joyce Carol Oates. 181 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/Dutton. $19.95. DIVIDED into 57 mini-chapters, composed with typographical tics and oddities (many capitalized words, phrases and sentences; italics, ampersands and so forth), featuring crude and often pointless line drawings, "Zombie" is Joyce Carol Oates's effort to dramatize, in diarylike form, the psychotic, monstrous consciousness of a serial murderer. This creature is simultaneously intensely self-absorbed and extremely depersonalized and derealized. He speaks of himself indiscriminately in the first and third persons and uses his initials to refer to himself most of the time. Apart from his recurrent obsessions and fantasies, he is unable to retain either conscious inner stability or a reliably steady or coherent sense of the outside world.

title: Events Call Attention To Croton Aqueduct
description: IN October 1842, the opening of the Croton Aqueduct was cause for great celebration in New York City. Badly needed water was now flowing 26 miles from the town of Cortlandt through an underground pipe to a city that had been unable to extinguish its fires properly or maintain sanitary conditions.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nelson Could Use Crash Course in Geriatrics to Get Most Out of Knicks This Season
description: The National Basketball Association recently held a seminar for coaches in which players' tendencies were analyzed by computer. Statistics and performances were broken down, and the purveyors of the product made a strong case that playing time may be determined by -- someone fetch Red Auerbach a glass of water -- software.

title: Arts Groups Rally Around Federal Benefactor
description: WHETHER it is through a direct grant like the $5,800 that Long Island Traditions received to tell Freeport students about maritime folk arts or the trickle-down financing that presented the New York Philharmonic in a free concert for 60,000 listeners in Heckscher State Park, the National Endowment for the Arts is an important player on the Long Island cultural scene.

title: William White, 92, Former Bank Regulator, Dies
description: William R. White, an accidental banker who followed a circuitous path to become New York's youngest Superintendent of Banks during a critical period in the 1930's and then spent a quarter-century as a top officer of what became the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, died on Thursday at a nursing home in Lewisburg, Pa. He was 92.

title: Developmentally Disabled Are People, Nothing Else
description: To the Editor:

title: S. J. Cavanagh, Vincent Zeppie 3d
description: Stephanna Jones Cavanagh, a quality assurance nurse at the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, was married yesterday to Vincent M. Zeppie 3d, the president of Automated Business Systems, a software design company in Fort Lee, N.J. The Rev. Vincent McNally officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of the Presentation in Upper Saddle River, N.J.

title: For Gay Elderly, a New Haven
description: It was in the summer of 1990, after a gay man was brutally beaten to death in a Jackson Heights schoolyard, that Ed Sedarbaum decided to act. For too long, he said, gay men and lesbians had felt unwelcome in their own borough.

title: A Place to Get Shaved and Shorn, Surrounded by Porn
description: To occupy waiting customers, old-fashioned barbershops often set out a few dog-eared magazines like Esquire and Playboy. The Eighth Avenue Subway Barbershop needs no such diversions. For two years, the shop's brother barbers, Nicholas and John Drakakis, have shorn and shaved customers in a corner of the Times Square Peep Show, surrounded by 39 booths offering 128 channels of hard-core pornographic videos.

title: The Pope vs. the Culture of Death
description: It is probably not a coincidence that Pope John Paul II has come to America only six months after posting his sternest rebuke yet of modern -- essentially American -- mores and culture.

title: SCHOOLS;Recruiting Students For Path To Success
description: Nothing in this picture-perfect town reminds Daryl Williams of home. Not the elegant houses with circular driveways or the trees bearing fat apples, and certainly not Princeton Day School, where he started ninth grade last month. His native Trenton is 20 miles away, but the bus that comes for him each morning might as well take him to the moon.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;The Tenuous Times of Mort Berkowitz
description: At a recent street fair on Central Park West and 100th Street, Mort Berkowitz was dressed to be noticed. A large, affable man, he was packed into a snug-fitting, teal satin jacket and purple baseball cap. "Mort & Ray Productions" was stitched in red on both. Visibility -- for Mr. Berkowitz, his company and the dozens of street fairs it organizes for nonprofit community groups -- is, after all, the name of the game.

title: Innocents Abroad, Oxford-Style
description: How did Warnborough College in Oxford, England, convince dozens of American high-school seniors that it was part of Oxford University?

title:
Word for Word/Presidential Bellyaches;
Grouse Under Pressure: The White House Was No Picnic
description: NOW that the Presidential sweepstakes is well under way, with aspiring candidates all over the political landscape, they might be well advised to assess what former occupants of the White House had to say about this high office that has often been a bed of thorns, not roses. A few, like George Washington, had a presentiment of what they were getting into.

title: GARDENING;Shortening Days Bring On Fall's Fanfare
description: NORTHEASTERN gardeners are the lucky ones at this time of year. They have the privilege of seeing the fall scene, the turning of the foliage from its summertime green to its annual color parade. The unknown this year is whether drought will dull the colors. Some pundits say it will; others not.

title: THE MONUMENT GLUT
description: No one denies that America has heroes in science, the arts and industry ("The Monument Glut," by James Reston Jr., Sept. 10). Entire buildings dedicated to these accomplishments stand just a few blocks from the memorials in Washington that Reston objects to. But in no other realm do we find the sort of heroism that is represented by our veterans. The societal achievements that Reston refers to flourished because our democratic institutions and way of life have been preserved by men and women willing to die for them. JESSE BROWN Secretary of Veterans Affairs Washington

title: HOCKEY;New Season Is Extension of Old for Rangers
description: Tonight's game was the Rangers' season opener, but in some respects it seemed like the continuation of last spring's miserable playoff conclusion, when they were swept in the second round by the Philadelphia Flyers in four consecutive games.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-16

title: Inexorable Wave Coming Soon
description: One really feels pain and grief for the merchants' opposing the proposed opening of the Caldor in Smithtown ["Merchants Oppose Proposed Opening of Big Discounter in Smithtown," Aug. 27]. The sorrow is that they are trying to stop the inevitable, the advance and march of the discounting megaretailer into all corners of the area. People want bargains and low prices whether they pay real-estate taxes of $13,000 per year or rent a shack. The likes of Caldor, Kmart and Wal-Mart are part of the America of yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 27 about the making of "Stealing Beauty," a new film directed by Bernardo Bertolucci, included a film incorrectly among the past credits of the new movie's director of photography, Darius Khondji. He did not work on "Before the Rain"; its director of photography was Manuel Teran. An assistant to Milcho Manchevski, the director of "Before the Rain," reported the error on Sept. 26.

title: Mr. Milken's Expensive Advice
description: Only a small group of people continues to seek financial advice from Michael Milken, the junk bond champion who fell from grace at the end of the 1980's. But that group includes Ted Turner, Rupert Murdoch, Ronald Perelman and other communications titans who have been involved in some of the biggest deals in history. The reported multimillion-dollar fees recently earned by Mr. Milken for his advice are said to have drawn the attention of the Securities and Exchange Commission. The S.E.C. ought to look carefully to see whether there has been any violation of the ban on Mr. Milken's doing any work in the securities industry, imposed after he was convicted of fraud in 1990.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROWNSTONE BROOKLYN;After the Fire, Residents Smolder

But as Brooklyn Heights struggles to return to normal, the effects of the blaze on Aug. 26 gnaw at the nerves of many residents.

title: SOAPBOX;Somebody's in My Grave
description: WHEN my best friend, Pearl, came North, she drove me to the cemetery for my first visit since my mother's name was added to my parents' double stone. As we climbed flights of crumbling cement steps, then walked off-balance across a steep incline, I told Pearl stories of the families whose headstones line the old Jewish graveyard on Mc Bride Avenue, just as their homes lined Paterson's streets. Little did I know that before our visit was done, my friend from North Carolina would adopt the woman resting next to my mother. This woman -- I'll call her Rosie -- was taking up the spot that was supposed to be eternally my own.

title: MARYANN GULA, MARK BEAUMONT
description: Maryann Katherine Gula, a former special events manager manager in New York for the Cunard Line, is to be married today to Mark Alexander John BeaumontMark Alexander John Beaumont, the cruise line's senior vice president of commercial development. The Rev. Bruce Forbes is to perform the Episcopal ceremony at in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church in New York.

description: The Boston Red Sox won the American League East championship this season, but they did it by playing better against the A.L. West teams than the Yankees did. The curse of the balanced schedule lives.

title: Where There's Smoke: A Semi-Spontaneous Semi-Sequel
description: IN A TIME OF ESCALATING budgets and film shoots that can go on for months, not many movies are shot in less than a week. But when the director Wayne Wang and the novelist Paul Auster finished making "Smoke" last year, about a Brooklyn cigar store, they felt they had a quick, follow-up film in them, this one about the neighborhood's efforts to keep the store from closing. They called it "Blue in the Face," a not-quite sequel that shares a location and some actors (mainly Harvey Keitel) with its predecessor and that opens on Friday.

We were heading toward the door when Linda stopped before a big old comfortable chair. It had wooden legs and arm rests and was upholstered in a beige, green, peach and orange floral pattern.

title:
FILM VIEW;
Jane Austen And the Pride Of Purists
description: BUT HE HAS NOTHING TO RECOMMEND him but himself," says Lady Russell, tart and astonished, in the seductively pleasurable film of Jane Austen's novel "Persuasion," which opened late last month in New York. Thus Lady Russell (Susan Fleetwood) seeks to dismiss gallant Captain Wentworth (Ciaran Hinds) from the affections of lovelorn Anne Elliot (Amanda Root). What, no money, no title, no connections -- just himself? While the audience sighs in rapture at the old-fashioned prospect of love triumphing over likelihood.

title:
NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;
Cry of Betrayal At Use of Hotel For Homeless
description: In the first two weeks of September, the city moved 11 families into the Regent Hotel on Broadway between 104th and 105th Streets -- 11 more than the 140-family cap it agreed to a year ago. In some neighborhoods, such action would not make much of a ripple, but on the northern Upper West Side, where many residents and block associations feel besieged by social service clients, it is seen as abject betrayal.

title: Truth in Mortgages: Lenders Get Leeway

Ms. Rodash's mortgage lender had made a critical error when calculating the mortgage amount a few years earlier. It had included a Federal Express charge of $22 and an intangible tax of $204 -- charges the lender should have paid.

title: HERS;Why Boys Don't Play With Dolls
description: IT'S 28 YEARS SINCE THE founding of NOW, and boys still like trucks and girls still like dolls. Increasingly, we are told that the source of these robust preferences must lie outside society -- in prenatal hormonal influences, brain chemistry, genes -- and that feminism has reached its natural limits. What else could possibly explain the love of preschool girls for party dresses or the desire of toddler boys to own more guns than Mark from Michigan.

title: Fixing the Schools
description: For years, the ideal of reforming New York City's byzantine school structure seemed a political impossibility. But in the calm after the battle between the Board of Education and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, that goal appears within reach. In the last few days, the Mayor and the board have shown they can work together on the selection of a new schools chancellor. This week, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver is hosting a summit meeting on school governance in Albany. Gov. George Pataki and other state officials who have shown scant interest in the city's school structure before have joined in the debate.

title: PASSIONS SET IN STONE
description: In "Passions Set in Stone" (Sept. 10.), Paul Goldberger's tone seemed quite negative about the Charedim. The thrust seemed to be that liberal Jews fear that Jerusalem will become the capital of Jewish fundamentalism. Even though secular Jews have a different life style, at least they won't fear for their lives. In any case, knowing that the Charedim will most likely control Jerusalem in future is a comforting thought because it means that Jerusalem will remain in Jewish hands.

description: For a man who is planning a 24-hour news station almost single-handedly, Jeffrey Marks sounded strangely peppy last week.

title: You Could Look It Up
description: THE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF NEW YORK CITY Edited by Kenneth T. Jackson. Illustrated. 1,350 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press/ The New-York Historical Society. $60. NEW YORK CITY has five boroughs, straddles three islands and is governed by one mayor. But that's about it for single digits in the city of the big, big numbers. Bridges? New York has 2,027 of them. Its 26,000 acres of parkland constitute the largest urban parks system in the country. The city has 469 subway stations and more than 300 neighborhoods. Every day, approximately 758,000 vehicles enter Manhattan south of 60th Street. New York has everything, times one hundred.

title: They're Tried, They're True, But How Long Do They Stay?
description: When he patrolled the South Bronx, Officer Gerard Langan had to drive in every morning from Nassau County, a journey he remembers as a descent into endless shootings, domestic fights and street robberies.

The report, published last week, said 1 in 3 black men in their 20's is imprisoned, on probation or on parole.

title: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;Fun at Work? Boy, That's a Laugh
description: Q. I've now survived two layoffs in 18 months. I suppose I should feel lucky, but I'm finding that the workplace that I once enjoyed has become oppressive. Tell me, where do I find a fun job? R. NEDBOY New York A. Not in the Yellow Pages. I looked, and all I saw under "Fun" was "Fundraising" and "Funerals," so at the risk of sounding like your mom, take your fun where you find it.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Growing Things Q. Can you tell me why the Brooklyn Garden is called the Botanic Garden while the New York Garden in the Bronx is called the Botanical Garden? Is it a grammatical error? A. Not really; as time marcheth on, so doth grammar.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/1996 Saturn SL2;G.M.'s Satellite: A New Spin
description: I WILL not soon forget my first test drive of the original Saturn. In November 1989, at General Motors' Arizona test track, a wild boar darted in front of me as I gunned down a straightaway. Unable to avoid him, I clipped his hindquarters. The boar lay whimpering at the side of the road until a security guard put him out of his misery.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 1 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the stage musical "State Fair" misidentifies a cast member. The actor at the far left is Ben Wright, not James Patterson.

title: Corrections

title: 'A HORRID LITTLE RACIST'
description: It required my father to retrieve the details of that traumatic event, for I'd forgotten all but the miserable denouement, along with my humiliation. It was at least 30 years later, when he was well into retirement, that he brought up the matter and we were both able to take a whimsically lenient view of what, at the time, had been a major household crisis.

title: Portrait of The American Child, 1995

title: Why Did a Church Evict Legal Clinic?
description: Saint James' Episcopal Church was founded in 1810 as a resort parish for wealthy New Yorkers summering in country homes along the East River in what is today the Upper East Side. Besides its blue-blood history, the church, on Madison Avenue near 71st Street, also has a reputation for reaching out to help the poor, the hungry, the elderly, the sick, the uneducated, prisoners and others in need.

title: Victor/Vittorio
description: IN A GLASS HOUSE By Nino Ricci.275 pp. New York:Picador USA. $22.

title: 4 Line Up to Succeed Mount Vernon Mayor
description: FOR 11 years and "for better or worse," as he will tell you, this has been Mayor Ronald A. Blackwood's city. Only now he says the time has come to leave the distribution of I Love Mount Vernon pins to someone else -- along with the drug and crime problems of the city's south side, the million-dollar estates on the north side, the gunshot and stabbing deaths of city youths and the growing ranks of successful middle-class blacks.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN;Honolulu
description: Recent tough economic times caused by a drop in tourism and a slowdown in the rate of Japanese investment have put Honolulu residents in a back-to-basics mood.

title: SOAPBOX;Graffiti a la Giuliani
description: I KNEW Mayor Giuliani was really serious about his quality-of-life campaign when one of the city's most prolific graffiti writers, a 26-year-old man who used the tag "Cost," was arrested. A few months ago, a Queens judge found him guilty of vandalism and ordered him to perform 200 days of community service. That means he is now out there literally cleaning up his own mess. And what a mess it is. There's hardly a neighborhood in New York that has escaped his assault.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about trading stocks on Nasdaq referred incorrectly to the Snapple Beverage Corporation, which was included among examples of large Nasdaq issues that can be traded on the Chicago Stock Exchange. Snapple has not been listed on Nasdaq since Dec. 6, when it was acquired by the Quaker Oats Company.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Growing Things Q. Can you tell me why the Brooklyn Garden is called the Botanic Garden while the New York Garden in the Bronx is called the Botanical Garden? Is it a grammatical error? A. Not really; as time marcheth on, so doth grammar.

title: THE POPE'S VISIT: THE REIDYSOne Catholic Family In Central Park; An Affirmation of Faith on the Great Lawn
description: On the way to see Pope John Paul II yesterday, sauntering down a still-dark Fifth Avenue closed to traffic, 17-year-old Anne Reidy and her friends talked about the food in their backpacks, told a few Pope jokes and even stopped briefly to put on makeup.

title:
NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: QUEENS UP CLOSE;
After 29 Years, a Pioneer Woman Police Officer Is a Chief
description: As a young police officer in the 1970's, Gertrude LaForgia responded to a call for help and was met, she said, by a man who stared and said, "I called for cop, not a woman."

title: Mariah Carey Glides Into New Territory
description: VOLUPTUOUSLY ROMANTIC MAKE-OUT music is rarely taken seriously unless there is a cynical message buried inside it. That's why it would be easy to dismiss Mariah Carey's subtly innovative new album, "Daydream" (Columbia), whose best cuts bring pop candymaking to a new peak of textural refinement. At the same time, Ms. Carey's songwriting has taken a leap forward, becoming more relaxed, sexier and less reliant on thudding cliches.

title: Corrections

title: Karen Ball, David Von Drehle
description: Karen Janene Ball, the White House correspondent for The Daily News in New York, and David James Von Drehle, an assistant managing editor of The Washington Post, were married yesterday. The Rev. James C. Holmes performed the ceremony at St. Margaret's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title:
BEHIND THE WHEEL/1996 Saturn SL2;
G.M.'s Satellite: A New Spin
description: I WILL not soon forget my first test drive of the original Saturn. In November 1989, at General Motors' Arizona test track, a wild boar darted in front of me as I gunned down a straightaway. Unable to avoid him, I clipped his hindquarters. The boar lay whimpering at the side of the road until a security guard put him out of his misery.

title: Trouble in Paradise For Yellowstone Cutthroat
description: We were the only anglers for as far as the eye could see. Here and there a stand of evergreens interrupted the unbroken green lawn that covers the foothills of the Absaroka mountains. A lone bison, the bull of a small herd, grazed on the far bank of the river. Glacial boulders, deposited millennia past, caught our attention as we debated whether or not they were some of the grizzly bears who frequent the Lamar Valley and who occupy the rung above anglers on the food chain of Yellowstone Park.

title: The Robber Vanishes
description: SMOKE By Donald E. Westlake. 454 pp. New York: The Mysterious Press/ Warner Books. $21.95.

title:
The View From: The County's Parks;
Foliage and Festival Season Marks Last Gasp Before Winter
description: FALL began officially on Sept. 23, but for many people this weekend -- Columbus Day weekend -- signals the true kickoff to the foliage and festival season. As sure as the earth revolves around the sun, the days will shorten and the air will turn crisp, the leaves will change from green to gold and red and the annual cycle will take place once again.

title: Foreign Affairs; Foreign Policy 3.1
description: On the front page of The Financial Times the other day was a picture that caught my eye. It showed Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, holding talks with Jiang Zemin, the President of China. The caption made it sound like any meeting of world leaders. It said the two men held "very cordial" talks, in contrast with their "frosty" summit of 18 months ago.

title: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;The Migratory Patterns of Old World Folk Art
description: TWO LEANLY SCULPTURED, lightly speckled pheasants stand out like elegant aliens in a crowded display of highly decorative Norwegian folk art. The birds were carved and painted as part of a cigarette stand in the 1940's by Alfred Anderson, a Norwegian-born farmer and folk artist. He came to America at the age of 5 with his family, lived his life among Norwegian-Americans in Fosston, Minn., and died at 80 in 1956 without ever selling any of his works.

title: ENDPAPER;The Ten Commandments of a Childhood
description: THOU SHALT HAVE NONE OTHER GODS BUT ME, not James Bond nor Jeb Stuart nor Stonewall Jackson nor even Robert E. "Saint Bob" Lee.

title: A LA CARTE;Italian Food on a Budget With Upscale Finesse
description: UNTIL recently in Deer Park, Italian restaurant meant a pizza and pasta storefront. That changed a couple of months ago, when Orlando Ristorante, a sophisticated heavyweight from Huntington, opened a modestly priced branch there.

Lidabell L. Pollard performed the ceremony, in which the Rev. H. Lawrence Thompson 3d, an Episcopal priest, took part.

title: IN THE GARDEN;How Autumn's Fanfare Begins
description: NORTHEASTERN gardeners are the lucky ones at this time of year. They have the privilege of seeing the fall scene, the turning of the foliage from its summertime green to its annual color parade. This year, the unknown is whether drought will dull the colors.

Influential capitalists like Warren Buffett who recognize the need for a more selfless, team approach for the long-term good are making a giant step in the right direction. Political and business leaders ought to have the backbone to expand on this concept.

title: Garden Paths Built For Elderly Strollers
description: A MONARCH butterfly flutters around the purple, lacy buddleia; chirping birds perch on the branches of a sugar maple. A short distance away, an elderly woman sits on a teak bench with her daughter who is gazing at dogwood, spirea and the roses that border a white picket fence.

title: In Disguise, but Still Brothels
description: Galvanized by the closing of two massage parlors in Flushing, a citizens group called the Quality of Life Coalition is planning more protests over the next several weeks as it pushes forward with a brothel-busting campaign.

title: BACKTALK;The Fields of Screams: Not Even Bucolic Baseball Can Escape Untarnished
description: Some people think the hockey season opened last week in Yankee Stadium when bottles and batteries sailed out of the stands, and more fans than usual showed up to chant obscenities in Ranger rhythms. It was noted -- as it will be for a while -- that the fans were predominately youngish white males. This loutish behavior has been obvious for some time now. Anyone who sits in the stands and ignores George Steinbrenner's news releases feels safer out on the surrounding Bronx streets.

title: A Developer For the 90's: Big Projects, Little Flash
description: When power brokers like Donald Trump and George Steinbrenner met on a panel that developed plans to build a domed stadium in New York, the real estate developer Jerry I. Speyer was all but overshadowed. But he was quietly building his own empire. Although the stadium plan ultimately failed, Mr. Speyer made the most of the effort: he bought the midtown tower where the panel held its meetings.

title: When a Driver and a Lease Must Part Company
description: WHEN Vince Hayes died of cancer in 1992, the last thing his wife, Fran, needed to worry about was getting rid of his car. Since he had leased the Mazda 626 for three years in 1990 from a friend's dealership, Ms. Hayes of Birmingham, Mich., figured she could simply return the car a year early, with that much less wear and tear on it.

title: In the Region: New Jersey;Spelling Out Home-Sale Disclosure Requirements
description: THE issue of disclosure in residential real estate transactions moved into the political arena last month when Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a bill into law that defines the responsbility of a seller of a new home to provide the buyer with information about off-site conditions.

title: COPING;The Straphanger as Esthete
description: AT rush hour, we descended into Stan Fischler's theme park at his home station, 110th Street on the old IRT, the system with the narrowest tunnels and the richest history. As we jumped on the lead car of a No. 1 uptown, Mr. Fischler yelled, "First rule: capture the window," and I followed him to the very front. For the next three hours, on seven subway trains over five lines through three boroughs, we had a front window on an underground world that I had suffered daily only because it was the cheapest, fastest way to go.

title: Three Suggestions For Oil Tank Problems
description: The article about environmental issues facing homeowners with underground oil tanks did not report the success of an innovative program being implemented by Hoffman Fuel Company of Danbury, Bridgeport and Stamford that addresses this issue.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;The Tenuous Times of Mort Berkowitz
description: At a recent street fair on Central Park West and 100th Street, Mort Berkowitz was dressed to be noticed. A large, affable man, he was packed into a snug-fitting, teal satin jacket and purple baseball cap. "Mort & Ray Productions" was stitched in red on both. Visibility -- for Mr. Berkowitz, his company and the dozens of street fairs it organizes for nonprofit community groups -- is, after all, the name of the game.

title: THING;Shirt of the Moment
description: WHAT The Ghost Basic Man's Shirt, a rayon crepe shirt that Beau Brummell and Jim Morrison would have loved. The $183 shirt, designed by Tanya Sarne, the woman behind the popular British label Ghost, is the only article of men's wear included in every Ghost collection. And although the garment has been around since 1987, it remains obscure, even to fashion insiders. GHOST STORY The Basic Man's Shirt has a cult following and is popular among musicians and actors who are either married to models or who date them. The typical scenario: Model does Ghost fashion show. Model receives Ghost merchandise in lieu of cash. Model gives significant other Basic Man's Shirt as a gift.

NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;
Cry of Betrayal At Use of Hotel For Homeless
description: In the first two weeks of September, the city moved 11 families into the Regent Hotel on Broadway between 104th and 105th Streets -- 11 more than the 140-family cap it agreed to a year ago. In some neighborhoods, such action would not make much of a ripple, but on the northern Upper West Side, where many residents and block associations feel besieged by social service clients, it is seen as abject betrayal.

title: THE MONUMENT GLUT
description: No one denies that America has heroes in science, the arts and industry ("The Monument Glut," by James Reston Jr., Sept. 10). Entire buildings dedicated to these accomplishments stand just a few blocks from the memorials in Washington that Reston objects to. But in no other realm do we find the sort of heroism that is represented by our veterans. The societal achievements that Reston refers to flourished because our democratic institutions and way of life have been preserved by men and women willing to die for them.

title: Zoos Take Action on Antifreeze
description: Fluorescent green puddles tell knowing drivers that their antifreeze is leaking, but the sweet-tasting liquid is a deadly danger to pets and wild animals that die by the thousands each year from lapping it up.

title: From Huck Finn to Calvin Klein's Billboard Nymphets
description: The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn" has taught generations of Americans how to look at children, and children still learn from it how to look at themselves. Huck is the direct ancestor of thousands of fictional children, in every medium from books and movies to television, comic strips and advertising. The kid in the commercial who swipes the Eggo waffle is one of Huck's descendants, as are Macaulay Culkin in the "Home Alone" movies, wicked little Calvin of "Calvin and Hobbes" and all the children on "The Nanny," "Dave's World" and just about every other sitcom.

description: An article on Sept. 10 about Chicago, "In and Out of the Loop," referred incompletely to a sightseeing cruise. It is the Chicago Architecture Foundation River Cruise, not the Chicago Foundation river cruise.

title: THE BONUS HOLDUP
description: In reading Michael Lewis's "The Bonus Holdup" (The Capitalist, Sept. 10), it struck me that clients of the individuals in the Wall Street brokerage houses who receive outrageous sums of money ought to share the rewards with their customers. After all, we make possible the profitable commissions that provide the basis for the bonuses.

title: H.M.O. Leads in Relocation Surge
description: IT appears that the major corporate relocation boon in Westchester, which was so prevalent in the 1970's and early 1980's, is again in vogue. Earlier this year, Mastercard International and Heineken USA moved operations here, and last week, Oxford Health Plans announced that it would expand its operations and bring 800 workers to downtown White Plains.

title: FILM VIEW;Got Killer Chips on Our Minds
description: BACK IN 1968, IN "2001: A Space Odyssey," Hal the computer was programmed to think and talk like a person. No one expected that a human urge for self-preservation would creep into his circuitry. But when he began to malfunction, Hal refused to be shut down, staging a mutiny and killing a few astronauts before Keir Dullea eliminated his intelligence and reduced him to singing "A Bicycle Built for Two." Hal was then the eerie last word in computers, invented, according to the movie, in the distant future of 1992.

title: TELEVISION;Bob Costas Calls It as He Regretfully Sees It
description: IN A SEASON OF LINGERING discontent, Bob Costas of NBC will soon call his first World Series game. This blank spot on his lengthy resume is a surprise, considering Mr. Costas's intimate, outspoken ties to baseball, from his seven years as the No. 2 voice on the Saturday afternoon "Game of the Week" and his role as the reigning critic of the sport's serial mismanagement to his eloquent eulogy at Mickey Mantle's funeral in August.

title: My Parents' Bust-Up, And Mine
description: My parents stayed together for the sake of the children. When the children were grown and settled, my parents divorced -- for their own sake. My brother was 25 and single, studying for a graduate degree; I was 27 and newly married, about to publish my first book of stories. Because Mom and Dad had decided to tough it out (29 years in all), we faced their breakup not as vulnerable kids but as self-sufficient adults. You'd think it would have been easier that way: no custody battle, no child-support brouhaha, no change of schools, no teen-age identity crises.

title: Word for Word/Presidential Bellyaches;Grouse Under Pressure: The White House Was No Picnic
description: NOW that the Presidential sweepstakes is well under way, with aspiring candidates all over the political landscape, they might be well advised to assess what former occupants of the White House had to say about this high office that has often been a bed of thorns, not roses. A few, like George Washington, had a presentiment of what they were getting into.

title: Despite Nature's Fury Student Pursues M.D.
description: IT is going to take more than the forces of nature to keep William Jakobleff from getting his medical degree. But it is not as if those forces didn't try. So far, the Yonkers resident has contended with an active volcano and a violent hurricane, but even if an earthquake or a typhoon head his way, Mr. Jakobleff is determined to become a doctor.

title: 95 PLAYOFFS: ON BASEBALL;The Mariners' 10th Man May Be the Kingdome

title: Austen on the Net
description: Gripped by Austen fever but can't squeeze in a visit to the public library between fox hunting and your evening game of whist? Fear not. The Internet gives you instant access to four Web sites devoted to the British author, and two where new Austen films are being promoted.

title:
TECHNOLOGY VIEW;
Where Whispers Tell Tales, Loud and Clear
description: IN MY WANDERINGS ABOUT THEcountry to visit audio and video manufacturers and see trade shows, I have gleaned at least one tiny insight: subtlety doesn't sell. Or so, at least, the audio-video industry seems to think. And that commercial conviction apparently springs from another tenet: what doesn't sell in the first two minutes isn't going to sell at all.

title: Where Silicon Alley Artists Go to Download
description: AS a go-go dancer in white hot pants and a sheer top shimmied on a table, an impassive man gazed up at her, clenching an unlighted cigar in his teeth and wearing an empty television set on his head. A video cameraman photographed the pair, bouncing their images off the white walls of a SoHo loft, where hundreds of people had gathered for a mix of live performance, digital art and the low thrills of computer shoot-'em-up games.

title: Business Students Have Alternatives
description: The article on part-time M.B.A. programs [Sept. 24] referred only to Westchester branches of New York City-based universities. Students also have the alternative of taking the evening or weekend M.B.A. program at a Westchester-based college. The Hagan School of Business of Iona College is the only M.B.A. program offered in Westchester at the main campus of the institution. Iona has been offering its M.B.A. program in Westchester for more than 30 years -- much longer than any branch of a New York City school has been offering M.B.A. programs in Westchester.

title: Why the Market Likes Johnny-One-Notes . . . And Is Skeptical Of One-Man Bands
description: A FEW weeks ago, when Robert E. Allen, the chairman of AT&T, announced his plan to break the giant company into three pieces, he cited the stock market as one reason. "The market value of AT&T was being buried," he said. "Investors couldn't understand the strategy of the combined companies." And the market promptly agreed, sending AT&T's stock skyward.

title: Chestnut Trees Find a Friend
description: WHEN Phillip Gordon wants to show visitors a fine example of a new generation of American chestnut trees, which were wiped out by blight in New England by the 1930's, he takes them to see a seedling he planted at the Old Lyme-Phoebe Griffin Noyes Library five years ago. The seedling is now about 18 feet tall and has the straight trunk, symmetrical limbs and footlong saw-toothed leaves that distinguished its forebears, prized for their hardwood and plump, tasty nuts.

title: Laurels for the Lyrical
description: There have been years when the Swedish Academy's choice for the Nobel Prize in Literature has provoked as much head-scratching as it has applause. This was not one of those years. Seamus Heaney, almost routinely described as Ireland's greatest poet since William Butler Yeats, belongs to that charmed circle of writers for whom the Nobel question was not if but when. For starters, he wields the kind of moral heft that the prize demands. His meditations on Ireland's conflicts, both political and psychic, wrested meaning and beauty from a legacy of pain. At the same time, the "ethical depth" cited by the academy finds expression in a spare, polished, highly accessible language whose seductive simplicity has won Mr. Heaney a wide readership. Now, thanks to wise investment by the Swedish Academy and a favorable exchange rate, it has earned him upward of $1 million. WILLIAM GRIMES

title: LOOK WHO'S TALKING HEALTH CARE REFORM NOW

Corporate America is appropriating health care in this country with the sole purpose of making profit, by brutally squeezing doctors and hospitals financially and by restricting, and even denying, high-tech care to patients. The irony of H.M.O.'s aggressively seeking Medicare patients is evident from the fact that Medicare pays less than 70 percent of actual cost. Obviously, the only way they can make a profit from these patients is to deny care. I can vouch from personal experience that this is increasingly taking place.

What's to be done about enriching young lives with the soaring joy and intense discipline of great art and artists? One ambitious and generally laudable effort begins a four-part weekly run tonight on PBS.

John Pershing's 1916 mission to hunt down the Mexican outlaw Pancho Villa, she felt "a little panicked," afraid the images might be impossible to find. The National Archives had film of Villa, a company researcher was told, but the reels were being moved into the agency's new building in Maryland and were not available.

By some estimates, tens of thousands of New Jerseyans continue to own at least one of the 60 types of banned weapons, in violation of the 1990 law requiring that the guns be surrendered.

title: The Truth America Owes Honduras
description: In July the Honduran Government filed charges against 10 active and retired military officers, among them seven colonels, accused of attempted murder and the illegal detention of six Honduran citizens. The soldiers were part of the notorious Battalion 316, a unit the Central Intelligence Agency financed and trained in the early 1980's. Honduran investigators believe Battalion 316 was responsible for the disappearance of 140 people whose bodies have never been found.

New York's exciting season is over.

title: Tortured Repression in Wonderland
description: You've heard all about Victorian England, with its facade of strait-laced propriety masking a tortured sexual repression. Now comes the stage show. "Alice," Robert Wilson's breathtakingly elegant realization of "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" and "Through the Looking-Glass," presents a parade of the repressed and the morally bloodthirsty that is so stark it lives up to one's childhood nightmares of a sinister world bent on punishing every evil thought.

description: The president of Daiwa Bank, Akira Fujita, resigned his post today to take responsibility for a $1.1 billion bond trading scandal that has tarnished the reputation of Japan's beleaguered banking system.

title: Crime Bill Focuses on Parents
description: Parents who are found by a court to have neglected their offspring would be required to make restitution when these children commit crimes under a bill that will get its first Assembly committee test on Thursday. At present, parents only can be forced to make restitution for juvenile crimes involving motor vehicles. The bill, to be considered by the Judiciary, Law and Public Safety Committee, is one of a package of measures that would reform juvenile justice statutes in the state.

description: The dramatic turn toward peace in Bosnia has one fundamental cause: the reassertion of American leadership in Europe. After four feckless years, under two Presidents, the United States is fully engaged in the problems of the former Yugoslavia. It makes all the difference.

title: Puerto Ricans Fight U.S. Radar Plan to Cut Drug Traffic
description: Carlos E. Torres was stumped when the Navy wanted to reserve his farm in a bucolic valley in the southwestern part of the island for a radar antenna to snag drug traffickers from South America.

description: Hundreds of thousands of people saw Pope John Paul II during his four days in metropolitan New York. For the most part, however, their view was from a distance, over the heads of the crowd and behind tight security barriers.

title: Firefighter Dies in Search For Victims
description: A firefighter searching a blazing tenement for trapped residents was swallowed by a ball of flame and killed yesterday. The fire in Long Island City, Queens, also injured eight of his comrades and one civilian, officials said. They said the fire may have been deliberately set.

title: Arrest Triggers Search for a Link in 5 Unsolved Murders
description: The police said today that they are examining five unsolved murders of women involved in prostitution or drugs to see if the murders were committed by an Easton man arrested on Saturday and charged with stabbing and raping a woman in an abandoned building here.

description: The center of attention in the auction room at Christie's here is usually a painting or another work of fine art, and the crowd tends to be socially rarefied. But last Wednesday, rather motley technology buffs or their representatives crowded in to admire something that was little more than an assemblage of wheels and gears a bit tarnished and set on a wooden base.

description: Their quarterback was crushed, their offensive and defensive lines were crushed and, ominously, the Jets' spirits were crushed.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Plant Lore for Those Who Lack Patience
description: Time-lapse photography is the star of David Attenborough's new six-hour series, the first half of which will be shown tonight at 8 on TBS. By speeding up the workings of nature, packing into brief seconds long months of change, "The Private Life of Plants" reveals the ingenious ways that growing things go about spreading their seed. The unfolding of a flower, which takes months, occurs in a beautiful few moments. Rooted though the plants are, they do an astounding amount of traveling.

title: Protest Over Brazilian Wood
description: On the Boardwalk yesterday, passers-by were asked to think about the boards they were walking on. About 20 members of New Jersey Rain Forest Relief, a Red Bank conservation group, chanted slogans criticizing municipal officials for using wood from Brazil to reconstruct the Boardwalk.

description: In a Catholic High School Football League matchup yesterday, St. Anthony's (5-0), the league's two-time defending champion, defeated Kellenberg (2-3) by 46-24. St. Anthony's Bill Fowler rushed for 226 yards and 3 touchdowns on 18 carries.

description: In New York City, parents, union leaders and elected officials yesterday greeted the selection of Rudolph F. Crew as Chancellor of the city's public schools with elation and some trepidation but most of all with relief that the Board of Education's long, tortured search had finally come to an end.

description: The chairwoman of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People called upon the state leaders of the organization yesterday to encourage black voters to register so that they can influence their representatives in government.

description: The team was led down Central Street in Evanston, Ill., where the concept of a police escort for the Northwestern Wildcats was long ago dismissed as a foolish fantasy. Would this be the final image of Mattingly as a Yankee? No one knows yet. Not even Mattingly.

description: White House Chief of Staff Leon Panetta expressed wariness today about proposals by some Democrats and Republicans in Congress to ease the budget crunch by changing the formula the Federal Government uses to measure the cost of living.

title: New Home for Law School
description: The Board of Governors of Rutgers University has resolved to go ahead with plans to build a new $49 million law school building next to the university's downtown campus in Newark. The new building is needed because it would cost too much to improve and maintain the existing S. I. Newhouse Center for Law and Justice, university officials said on Friday.

title: Technology
description: WHEN the Internet's original creators decided to publish their networking standards -- called the Internet Protocol -- so that any computer could connect to the network, they certainly had no idea that almost 30 years later, their decision would provide the first real lever to pry the Microsoft-Intel duopoly from its leadership role.

title: THE POPE'S VISIT: THE SCENE;A Truly Public Parade for the Pope
description: Pratt Street was lined with people whose religion was still fresh and new, and with others whose faith was in mothballs, somehow out of style. There were Irish Catholics in something near to rapture, and Baptists who watched respectfully but with mild distrust of so much wild devotion to a mortal man. And there was an Episcopalian lawyer who said he wanted to feel again the way he felt years ago, in St. Peter's Square, when the same man had said a simple prayer.

title: GYMNASTICS;Miller's Uneven Finish Opens Vault for Others
description: The Shannon Miller era in women's gymnastics appears to be ending. And the field is wide open for the Summer Olympics in Atlanta, with any of a number of strong gymnasts able to win the gold medal.

title: The Bottle Bill's 10-Cent Solution
description: As the conservative revolution proceeds apace, one bit of social legislation has improbably avoided attack: container-deposit laws. Perhaps because bottle bills, as they are known, are not widely considered a strand in the social safety net, they have been left undisturbed. They quietly provide income in nine states to the poor, who scavenge discarded bottles and cans to claim the nickel deposit (10 cents in Michigan).

title: Lloyds Seeks Merger to Create No. 1 British Retail Bank
description: Lloyds Bank P.L.C. said today that it was involved in talks with the TSB Group P.L.C. about a merger that would create Britain's largest retail bank, with assets of $:150 billion, or $238 billion.

title: By Design
description: It's known as the "Friends" hairdo, as seen on the NBC show. Or the Gucci look, as worn by Amber Valetta in Gucci advertisements. Women are asking hair stylists for the look created by Julian D'Ys (pronounced DEEZ) for the Gucci runway last spring -- a mussed-up shoulder-length layered shag with bangs.

title: Incoming Head Of Schools Reaches Out To New York
description: Just after 6 A.M. Sunday, only hours after he had been named New York City's new schools chancellor, Rudolph F. Crew picked up the phone at a friend's home in Sacramento, Calif., and began placing calls to New York. He has not stopped since.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;Dark Strivings of New Zealand Movies
description: Not much about Sam Neill's ordinary leading-man roles (in films like "Jurassic Park") and even his better ones (in "The Piano" and "My Brilliant Career") is preparation for his tart, perceptive directorial voice in a very good film of his own. He makes a first-rate tour guide through "Cinema of Unease," the documentary about New Zealand cinema that he directed with Judy Rymer. Mr. Neill, who directed documentaries in the early 1970's before establishing himself as an actor, brings a lifetime's worth of film-related opinions to this instructive survey.

title: Grocer in Holdup Is Stable
description: A grocer who fatally shot a 16-year-old youth during a holdup at his store last weekend was in stable condition yesterday at University Hospital in Newark. Three people, including Erica Rivera, the sister of the dead youth, Steven Rodriguez, were in custody and were expected to be arraigned today on charges stemming from the robbery Friday night at the South America Grocery Store in Passaic.

title: Dow Falls 42.99 Points; Technology Issues Feel Pressure
description: The stock market stumbled badly yesterday, pulled down by many of the same technology stocks that have been the leaders of this year's rally.

description: Before voting against Dr. Rudolph F. Crew on Saturday night, one school board member, Sandra E. Lerner, said she did not know enough about the man selected to be the next chancellor of New York City's public schools.

title: Simpson Agrees to NBC Interview With No Question Limits or Pay
description: After extended negotiations, O. J. Simpson yesterday agreed to a live, one-hour interview with NBC News with no promise of payment or other considerations, NBC executives said last night.

title: Raising Aggression to an Art Form
description: LIKE their baboon and orangutan counterparts, male humans have been known to harass their females, but as always, they are considerably more refined in their approach. After all, even a wolf does not know how to wolf-whistle; and what baboon could figure out that if he stands next to a female in a crowded subway car and gives her a grope, he can make her wonder if it was just an accident?

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Succoth, alternate-side street cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

description: The Reynolds Metals Company, the maker of Reynolds aluminum and plastic wraps, said yesterday that it had placed in review its account, which has been handled by J. Walter Thompson New York for the last 23 years. The billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Silent for Months, Health Lobby Takes On G.O.P.

The transaction is expected to close early next year, said the Schaumburg-based Pioneer Financial, a provider of life and health insurance. Universal Fidelity provides health insurance to the elderly.
