description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day on Friday about an agreement by the MCI Communications Corporation to buy the assets of a digital imaging and information services company misidentified the company. It is Image Technology Inc. of Greensboro, N.C., not Image Technology International Inc. of Norcross, Ga.

title: Another Big Robbery in Diamond District
description: In the second million-dollar heist in four days in Manhattan's diamond district, three masked men brandishing machine guns walked into a jewelry store last night, handcuffed the owners to a door handle and fled with $2 million to $3 million in jewels, the police said.

title: Work on Body Design Of Fruit Fly Wins Nobel
description: TWO Americans and a German won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine yesterday for discovering how genes control the early structural development of the body. The research, which was done in fruit flies, helps to explain birth defects in humans.

title: Rookie Added to the Roster Will Start Opener for Seattle
description: His emotionally spent players took the day off today, but Lou Piniella got no respite from his decision-making duties. Faced with the forced absence of Randy Johnson, the Seattle Mariners' manager had to come up with a starting pitcher for the first game of the American League Championship Series Tuesday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Japan Knew of Daiwa Loss Weeks Before U.S. Officials The Japanese Government knew of a huge loss by a rogue trader at Daiwa Bank six weeks before American regulators were told of the $1.1 billion scandal. American officials are privately outraged by Japan's failure to disclose the scandal, which led to the resignations of top officials of Daiwa Bank. The issue of notification is just one aspect of the incident under investigation.

title: S.E.C. Said to Be Looking at Archer-Daniels
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an informal inquiry into the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company to determine if securities laws were violated when some executives received corporate money in overseas bank accounts, people with knowledge of the inquiry said yesterday.

title: Western Group Further Reduces Russian Role in Azerbaijani Oil
description: Western oil companies, in what appeared to be a further blow to Moscow, seemed today to marginalize Russia as a likely main route for the huge quantities of crude oil expected from this Asian republic in the next century.

title: In Florida, Retirees Watch Medicare Debate and Worry
description: At the Bond Hotel here, Lewis Osterman, 98, and Blanche M. Connor, 95, are living their last years in placid frugality. The couple met five years ago and now share all expenses 50-50, including the monthly $500 rent. They eat in for breakfast, skip lunch and have dinner at a nearby senior citizens center for $1.40 each.

title: A Close Call in Carolina
description: A small plane carrying East Carolina Coach STEVE LOGAN and Athletic Director MIKE HAMRICK made an emergency landing in a soybean field yesterday near Princeton, N.C., officials said.

title: GOLDMAN, SACHS IS SUED ABOUT A TRADING LOSS
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company has been sued in arbitration for $45 million by the Minebea Company about a trading loss the Japanese maker of bearings and machine parts said it suffered, people familiar with the case said yesterday. Minebea, of Tokyo, says that Goldman sold it $40 million of debt securities in 1989 that were backed by corporate loans and whose principal was guaranteed in writing by a Goldman trader. The company contends that Goldman did not disclose the risks of the securities.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Japan Knew of Daiwa Loss Weeks Before U.S. Officials The Japanese Government knew of a huge loss by a rogue trader at Daiwa Bank six weeks before American regulators were told of the $1.1 billion scandal. American officials are privately outraged by Japan's failure to disclose the scandal, which led to the resignations of top officials of Daiwa Bank. The issue of notification is just one aspect of the incident under investigation.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Earnings at Motorola Rose By 30.5% in Third Quarter
description: Motorola Inc. said yesterday that earnings rose 30.5 percent in the third quarter, less than what some analysts had expected.

title: Observer;Paradise For Infidels
description: The symptoms were worrisome. They included agonizing abdominal and chest pains, spinal numbness from top to bottom, and a brilliant chartreuse rash from clavicle to kneecap.

title: How 'To Die For' Managed to Open At Simpson Finale
description: On the closing day of filming "To Die For" in Toronto last year, the cast and crew gathered around a television set to watch the live broadcast of O. J. Simpson riding the Los Angeles freeways in his white Ford Bronco after Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman were murdered.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
description: Voters will decide today whether to build a new $49.9 million high school for 2,100 students that supporters say is needed to relieve overcrowding and cope with anticipated population growth. The existing high school, built for 1,350 students, has 1,500 students, 315 of whom are seniors, said Robert Gulick, Superintendent of Schools. Yet the district's first and second grades each have almost double the number of seniors, Dr. Gulick said. And 1,900 new homes are expected to be built in Hillsborough soon, officials said. A similar referendum was defeated last March.

title: France Rushes To Shore Up Plunging Franc
description: Nearly swamped with political and economic troubles, and faced with a nationwide strike on Tuesday by more than five million public employees, France rushed today to the rescue of a plummeting franc, by raising an important short-term interest rate, and at least temporarily halting the currency's plunge.

title: Big Quake Kills 34 On Mexican Coast; Resort Is Hard Hit
description: A powerful earthquake rocked Mexico's Pacific coast today, knocking down one resort hotel, heavily damaging several others and destroying hundreds of homes across two states. At least 34 people were killed and more than 100 injured, the authorities said.

title: Another Rally for Seattle
description: His team squeezed into a division title with a playoff victory over the Angels, then squeezed through the first round of post-season play with a comeback victory over the Yankees, and today Manager Lou Piniella told a noontime crowd of about 10,000 in downtown Seattle that his team would get past the Cleveland Indians, too, and make it into the World Series.

title: Restaurant Cigars Under Attack
description: Since 1994, 48 bills have been introduced in the Legislature that relate to smoking and tobacco. Assemblyman John E. Rooney, Republican of Northvale, recently added another that would ban cigar and pipe smoking in the restaurant dining sections statewide.

title: Sabotage Derails Arizona Train; One Is Killed and 100 Are Hurt
description: A stretch of track through a remote expanse of desert was sabotaged, causing an Amtrak train carrying 268 people to derail early today as it passed over a trestle spanning a gulch, the authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day on Friday about an agreement by the MCI Communications Corporation to buy the assets of a digital imaging and information services company misidentified the company. It is Image Technology Inc. of Greensboro, N.C., not Image Technology International Inc. of Norcross, Ga.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;A Sears, Roebuck fashion show, television news and insights into the creative process.
description: THE elusive art of winning in the marketplace, from advertising to retailing to media, was the focus of the final session of the 86th annual conference and business meeting of the Association of National Advertisers.

title: International Briefs; Big Merger Is Set In the Mining Industry
description: The RTZ Corporation agreed yesterday to merge with its Australian unit, CRA Ltd., in which it already holds 49 percent, cementing the London-based company's position as the world's largest miner. The new company, temporarily called RTZ-CRA, will come into being Jan. 1 with a market capitalization of about $20.5 billion if shareholders approve the merger in late December.

title: Graf Is Safe, for Now
description: STEFFI GRAF, who is under investigation for tax evasion, faces no immediate arrest, a prosecutor in the case said yesterday in Frankfurt.

Market Closed
description: The Treasury securities market was closed yesterday in observance of Columbus Day, and the Treasury delayed its weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills until today. Other financial markets were open, and there was limited trading in corporate bonds.

title: Gingrich Urges Churches To Play Bigger Social Role
description: In a speech to 8,000 religious leaders and students, Speaker Newt Gingrich tonight decried what he called the secularization of America and appealed to churches to reach out and help their neighbors.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Don't Mind the Knicks: It's Just Motion Sickness
description: With each dumbfounded stare, there are a few nods of comprehension. Each time one player forgets to pop off a screen, four of his teammates are running to exactly the spot Don Nelson wants them positioned in.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;The Dinosaurs Are Back, and So Is a Late Hero
description: THE LOST WORLD By Michael Crichton 393 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $25.95.

title: DART GROUP DEAL COULD END HAFT FAMILY CONTROL
description: The Dart Group Corporation said yesterday that its board approved a settlement with company president Ronald Haft that would remove voting control of the company from the feuding Haft family. Under the deal, Ronald Haft would resign his posts, sell his interest in the company and drop a lawsuit against his father, Herbert Haft, Dart's founder, chairman and chief executive. Herbert Haft, his ex-wife Gloria Haft, eldest son Robert Haft and daughter Linda Haft may challenge the agreement and it still requires court approval. As part of the deal, Dart would give Ronald Haft a $37.9 million loan and pay $11.6 million to Herbert Haft. Ronald Haft agreed to repay the loan to his father. Dart's treasury also would buy 172,730 class B shares from Ronald Haft. Herbert Haft had the voting rights to the shares, which represented about 57 percent of Dart's voting shares. Ronald Haft also had been president of Dart's Crown Books unit, and director of the Trak Auto Corporation.

description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League CHICAGO WHITE SOX -- Acquired Jeff Darwin, pitcher, from Seattle to complete the July 18 trade that sent Warren Newsom, outfielder, to the Mariners. National League FLORIDA MARLINS -- Reinstated Bryan Harvey, John Johnstone and Vic Darensbourg, pitchers, and Darrell Whitmore, outfielder, from the 60-day disabled list. Basketball National Basketball Association NEW YORK KNICKS -- Waived Greg Butler, center; Jamal Faulkner, forward; and Herman Alston, guard. Hockey American Hockey League BINGHAMTON RANGERS -- Announced Eric Flinton, left wing, was recalled by the New York Rangers and loaned to Charlotte of the ECHL.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK;Marino Will Be Out For a Game or Two
description: The Dolphins dropped their first game of the season on Sunday, blowing a 24-3 lead and losing to the Colts in overtime at Joe Robbie Stadium. If that wasn't unsettling, they were hit with the ton-of-bricks news that Dan Marino, the pilot for the team's Super Bowl drive, could be sidelined for two games following arthroscopic surgery to repair torn cartilage in his right knee.

title: Alliance Looks For an Agency
description: PCS Primeco, a newly formed alliance of four wireless communications service companies, said yesterday that it was searching for an agency to handle its corporate and regional advertising account. Though the billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated that spending could total as much as $50 million.

title: BMW Group Picks DeVito/Verdi
description: The Tristate BMW Advertising Association said yesterday that it had selected DeVito/Verdi in New York to handle the creative portion of its account, with billings estimated at $5 million. The account had been at Ally & Gargano in New York for almost three years until the association joined other clients in leaving the troubled agency.

title: Coffee Trading Move in Doubt
description: New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange Inc. canceled a special meeting that had been scheduled yesterday to vote on a proposed move to New Jersey, raising doubts about its relocation plans.

description: President Clinton challenged Congress today to send him a welfare bill that commands bipartisan support. Otherwise, he said, he will end the current welfare system himself, state by state.

description: Technology stocks fell sharply yesterday in a broad retreat that many analysts interpreted as the beginning of the long-awaited selloff in this high-flying group.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Succoth, alternate-side street cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

The existing high school, built for 1,350 students, has 1,500 students, 315 of whom are seniors, said Robert Gulick, Superintendent of Schools. description: His childhood dream had been to be a firefighter, but such dreams rarely consider that fate might catch you some sunny Sunday in a burning Long Island City tenement, just as a hot fist of fire bursts through the ceiling to leave you trapped.

title: Cable News Channel Planned
description: Suburban Cable, a cable television system based in Pennsylvania, plans to offer South Jerseyans a 24-hour-a-day news channel by early next year, a company spokesman said yesterday. The News Channel will carry condensed newspaper stories, with local coverage supplied by The Press of Atlantic City, said the spokesman, Thomas Gailey. Suburban Cable already serves customers in Gloucester, Cumberland and Salem Counties.

title: The Unruly (and Ruly) Beethoven
description: In his early music, Beethoven gives rococo elegance rough treatment. Predictable Alberti bass patterns veer off into eccentric shapes; sudden louds against sudden softs take on an edge of violence. Indeed, Beethoven's first piano sonatas behave a little badly. Think of a troublesome, if brilliant, guest in a Mozartean drawing room: he insults the host and spills food on himself, but turns polite conversation in highly original directions.

description: A public school safety supervisor in the Bronx was charged with smuggling nearly six pounds of cocaine into the United States after being questioned at an airport in Puerto Rico, officials said yesterday.

description: The first discovery came in August at Paradise Memorial Park, a cemetery in the working-class Los Angeles suburb of Santa Fe Springs, where visitors came upon a 10-foot-high mound of bones and splintered coffins.

title: Progress on Cuba
description: Neither Fidel Castro's Government in Havana nor hard-line Cuban exiles in the United States are happy with the Clinton Administration's eased policies on travel, humanitarian relief and cultural exchange with Cuba. But the new approach, incorporated in an executive order signed last week, well serves American interests. By letting ordinary Cubans receive more financial help from their American relatives and gain wider exposure to American ideas, Washington improves the chances for a liberalized political climate in Cuba.

title: The New Chancellor's Early Start
description: New York City's new Schools Chancellor, Rudolph Crew, received Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's endorsement even though he does not meet all of Mr. Giuliani's formerly non-negotiable demands. The Board of Education gave its blessing to Dr. Crew even though his background check had not been completed. Both sides may have feared that unless he could be hired quickly, the city would never find anyone to take the job.

title: DST Systems Inc. reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
description: DST Systems said its operating income was decreased by $ 2.1 million in the third quarter of 1995 by accruals for an incentive compensation program and transition costs associated with conversion of new accounts in its acquisition of operations from Kemper Service Company, a unit of Kemper Corporation's Kemper Financial Services Corporation.Third-quarter net income was hurt by a decrease in equity in earnings of unconsolidated affiliates and an increase in interest expense.

description: The disappointed members of the New York Yankees can take consolation in knowing that in a losing cause they helped win a big victory for the game of baseball. Baseball's thick-headed establishment did whatever it could last year to ruin interest in the game. The strike killed post-season play, left the fans in a mutinous frame of mind and led to a worrisome decline in attendance.

description: John A. Scali, the former ABC News correspondent whose secret role as a go-between made him a pivotal figure in resolving the Cuban missile crisis and who later served as the United States Ambassador to the United Nations, died yesterday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 77 and lived in Washington.

description: John Cairncross, the "Fifth Man" in a ring of British spies that gave Western secrets to the Soviet Union, died on Sunday at his home in the west of England. He was 82.

title: Champion International Corp.(CHA,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
description: Champion International attributed its increase in third-quarter net income to price increases for all of its major pulp and paper grades. The company said income from operations of its wood products segment fell to $ 34 million in the latest third quarter from $ 61 million in year-ago period. The decrease was due mainly to lower lumber prices.

description: The Gannett Company said yesterday that the costs associated with a strike against its Detroit newspaper coupled with a dip in revenues had trimmed about 15 cents a share from its third-quarter earnings.

title: OUR TOWNS;300 Years On, the Chips Fall Fast Where They May
description: CARS crawl along skinny, two-lane Route 2 into the parking lots -- another mess. But inside, the game room spins like a big mirrored ball. Every roulette wheel, every craps table, every row of one-armed bandits runs at full speed. Slots jingle, coins jangle. Lines form at the ice cream stand and the coffee bar, and women with cotton-candy-pink hair push through the smoky aisles, holding quarters in plastic cups the size of Big Gulps.

title: So Sweet, So Smooth, Such a King of Canto-Pop
description: Pop music has always been a benign invader, plundering and homogenizing wherever it treads. It takes rock, jazz, salsa, rhythm-and-blues -- whatever -- and cleans it up and smooths out the wrinkles, sometimes for the worse (Pat Boone) and sometimes for the better (the Pet Shop Boys). When it comes to the sheer sanitization of songs, the popular Hong Kong style known as Canto-pop reigns supreme, and on Friday the genre's biggest star, Jacky Cheung, came to the Paramount for a two-night stand.

title: The Rebellion in 'Pole City'
description: Two sets of poles carrying a welter of transmission lines run parallel down the narrow streets of this town -- one for the big regional power company, Toledo Edison, and the other, newer set for a municipal utility created six years ago, Clyde Light and Power.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about the violist and teacher Lillian Fuchs misstated the day of her death. She died on Thursday, not Friday.

title: Nunn, Model Southern Democrat, To Retire From Senate Next Year
description: Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, the leading Congressional authority on military affairs and the archetype for a vanishing breed of conservative Southern Democrat, announced today that he would retire after completing his fourth term next year.

title: International Briefs; Production Prices Rise in Britain
description: The prices of goods leaving British factories and the raw materials used by manufacturers rose in September, the Central Statistical Office said yesterday. Economists said the figures were disappointing and suggested there might be more inflationary pressure in the economy than they had realized. But the data were inconclusive as to whether interest rates should rise or fall in the coming months.

title: Coffins and Wedding Cake: Four Sitcoms Tie the Knot
description: In real estate, it's location, location, location. Increasingly in television, it's packaging, packaging, packaging. That encompasses stunts like having the star of one sitcom show up in another, much to the delight of the laugh track. Or then you get tonight's stretch on NBC in a two-hour sitcom linkup that has been advertised as "Three Funerals and a Wedding." They could also be called "Three Goofy Farewells and a Gay Caper."

title: Rookie Added to the Roster Will Start Opener for Seattle

Faced with the forced absence of Randy Johnson, the Seattle Mariners' manager had to come up with a starting pitcher for the first game of the American League Championship Series Tuesday.

title: Jail Time for Lassiter
description: ROY LASSITER, who sparked what may be the United States' team's greatest comeback, was sentenced yesterday in Raleigh, N.C., to 30 days in jail for breaking into a house while he was a student at North Carolina State.

title: Back to Her Roots
description: After a steady stream of defeats this year at the hands of the new Republican leadership in Congress on issues like toxic waste and wetlands, environmentalists are claiming at least one small victory: they have turned Sue Kelly around.

title: ALUMAX IN DEAL TO BUY CRESSONA ALUMINUM
description: Alumax Inc., a large aluminum producer, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Cressona Aluminum Company, a maker of extruded aluminum products, for $430 million in cash. Alumax, based in Norcross, Ga., will also assume or retire about $70 million in debt owed by the Cressona, Pa., company. Alumax said it expected to complete the deal in January, and that Cressona shareholders had approved it. Cressona has annual revenue exceeding $500 million and about 1,500 employees at plants in Spanish Fork, Utah; Franklin, N.H., and Elizabethton, Tenn., as well as in Pennsylvania.

title: Patric Walker, 64, Astrologer With an International Following
description: Patric Walker, an English astrologer who brought a sense of style and sophistication to the daily horoscope, died on Sunday in his London apartment. He was 64.

title: CHRONICLE

title: Government Expected to Review Turner-Time Warner Deal Soon
description: The Federal Trade Commission is expected to start a review of the deal between Time Warner and Turner Broadcasting System within the next several weeks, an executive familiar with the discussions said yesterday.

title: HORSE RACING;Thunder Gulch Officially Retires to a Life of Studded Bliss
description: Thunder Gulch, the winner of the Kentucky Derby, was officially retired yesterday and headed for a second career as a stallion in Kentucky, already assured of winning the Eclipse Award as the champion 3-year-old colt in America.

title: Honeybees Vanquish a Goliath Hornet With Thermal Warfare
description: THE Japanese honeybee has devised an unusual defense against mass attacks by a major predator, a giant hornet. Responding quickly and in large numbers, the bees engulf hornet scouts and generate enough heat to roast them to death, scientists say.

title: Blacks Look at Simpson In the Context of the Past
description: When Helen Giles looks at O. J. Simpson, she does not see a Heisman Trophy winner or a football commentator. Like many other blacks relieved by Mr. Simpson's acquittal on double murder charges, she sees a black man who managed to survive his passage through a rigged system of criminal justice.

title: Lord Home, 92, Humble Earl Who Became British Premier
description: Lord Home of the Hirsel, the languid aristocrat who, as Sir Alec Douglas-Home, was Prime Minister of Britain for 12 months in 1963 and 1964, died yesterday at his home in Berwickshire, Scotland, near the English border. He was 92.

title: No Headline
description: "This man spoke to me in a Swedish accent. I thought he probably had the wrong number. Maybe he did, but they're not going to take it back." DR. ERIC F. WIESCHAUS, a winner of the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. [ C3:6 ]

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;Columbia: Gem of the Ivy League
description: EVERY time a university with a reputation for academic excellence and football ineptitude suddenly begins to win games, or even a game, it makes some people nervous.

title: Sarajevo Still Without Fuel and Electricity
description: Sarajevo remained cold and dark tonight, waiting for the gas and electricity that the Bosnian Government had demanded before a United States-brokered cease-fire could begin.

title: LOCOMOTIVE UNIT MAY CUT AS MANY AS 1,500 JOBS
description: The Transportation Systems unit of the General Electric Company said yesterday that, as a cost-cutting measure, it might eliminate as many as 1,500 jobs in the next six to nine months because of a decline in freight locomotive and transit orders. It would use attrition and offer a voluntary job elimination program to help manage the cuts. David L. Calhoun, president and chief executive of the unit, which is based in Erie, Pa., said mergers among railroads was the primary reason for the drop in orders.

title: An Honorable Senate Career
description: Though anticipated, Senator Sam Nunn's decision not to run for re-election is a disappointment for President Clinton and his dwindling Democratic allies in Congress. But it is an even greater blow to the cause of bipartisanship on a host of tough foreign policy and defense issues, where Mr. Nunn wielded great influence by listening, asking questions and mastering his brief. We did not always agree with Senator Nunn's positions, but his departure will diminish the cause of reasoned discourse in Washington.

title: College Soccer Report
description: Big East

title: Price of Global Warming? Debate Weighs Dollars and Cents
description: IF the world's climate is warming because of the burning of fossil fuels, how much will it cost to fix the problem? And is the fix worth the cost?

title: PLAYOFFS '95: ON BASEBALL;These Indians Are True Survivors
description: Most of the sporting public knew little about the rebuilding Cleveland Indians when one event made the world focus on them in March 1993.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CAROL CHANNING, who opens on Broadway on Oct. 19 in a reprise of "Hello, Dolly!," will receive the first Ethel Merman Award of the Songwriters Hall of Fame on Saturday, and, she said yesterday, it will mean more than the usual honor.

title: The Bottle Bill's 10-Cent Solution
description: As the conservative revolution proceeds apace, one bit of social legislation has improbably avoided attack: container-deposit laws. Perhaps because bottle bills, as they are known, are not widely considered a strand in the social safety net, they have been left undisturbed. They quietly provide income in nine states to the poor, who scavenge discarded bottles and cans to claim the nickel deposit (10 cents in Michigan).

title: ResultsPlus
description: CROSS-COUNTRY Columbia Senior Is First Casey O'Shea of Columbia, a senior from Santa Fe, N.M., led from start to finish in winning the men's five-mile race in 25 minutes 29 seconds in the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Cross-Country championships yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. Margaret McPartland of Manhattan College outkicked Antoinette Fields of Fordham to capture the women's 3.1-mile title in 19:07. St. John's earned the men's team title for the first time since 1979, with 34 points. Rutgers won the women's crown for the third straight year. GYMNASTICS Last Chances for U.S. Shannon Miller and Dominique Moceanu were left with just two final chances for medals after a day of frustration for United States gymnasts at the world championships yesterday in Sabae, Japan. Five more specialty gold medals remain to be decided and Miller, the 1993 and 1994 world champion, and Moceanu, the United States champion, are in the finals of both the balance beam and the floor exercises. (AP) HOCKEY Bruins Win at Home Ray Bourque and Joe Mullen scored 70 seconds apart in the third period yesterday as the Boston Bruins won their first game at the new Fleet Center by 4-3 over visiting Buffalo. The Sabres took a 3-2 lead on Brian Holzinger's goal in the third, but his interference penalty allowed Boston to come back less. Thirty-seven seconds into the power play, the Bruins worked the puck around the perimeter to Bourque, who slapped it past Dominik Hasek to tie the score. A minute later, Mullen swiped a clearing pass and brought it over the blue line before putting it through Hasek's legs. (AP) TENNIS Early Exit for Hingis One year after reaching the quarterfinals in her second professional tournament, Martina Hingis made a first-round exit from the Porsche Grand Prix yesterday in Filderstadt, Germany. Hingis, a 15-year-old from Switzerland, lost, 6-4, 6-4, to sixth-seeded Natasha Zvereva of Belarus, who is ranked 14th in the world, two spots above Hingis. (AP)

title: JAPANESE DELAYED LETTING U.S. KNOW OF BIG BANK LOSS
description: The Japanese Government said today that it knew of a huge loss by a rogue trader at Daiwa Bank's New York operation six weeks before American regulators were told of the $1.1 billion scandal. The failure to inform Washington comes as both Governments have said that they are working closely on sensitive financial issues.

title: The Pope May Have Missed an Opportunity to Unite Polarized Church Leaders
description: To the enthusiastic parishioners who turned out in force at Giants Stadium, Aqueduct Race Track and the Camden Yards ball park in Baltimore, Pope John Paul II's visit to the United States appeared to bring a message -- and a concrete experience -- of unity in the faith.

title: Lilco Not a Typical Case In Public Takeover Drives
description: If the Long Island Lighting Company ends up being acquired by a New York State agency, overnight it would become the largest publicly owned local electric utility in the country.

World Bank Urges Congress To Restore Promised U.S. Aid
description: Finance ministers joined with the president of the World Bank today in pressing Congress to restore large amounts of money it is planning to cut from the United States' contribution to a key international development agency. They said such reductions would deal a severe blow to very poor nations.

description: While the rest of the Devils were skating in the National Hockey League SuperSkills competition here this afternoon, Bobby Holik was standing in a hallway underneath the stands at Byrne Meadowlands Arena explaining why he was wearing a cast on his left arm.

description: To the Editor:

title: PRO FOOTBALL;For Esiason, It Was a Sunday to Forget in a Forgettable Season
description: His eyes were trying to focus today, but Boomer Esiason had the glazed look of someone trying in vain to remember yesterday.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Webber Seems Willing To Lead Bullets' Way
description: Chris Webber wore a million-dollar smile today, and for good reason. Webber signed a six-year contract with the Washington Bullets believed to be worth $58.5 million, making him one of the National Basketball Association's highest-paid players. And with a nucleus of Webber, Mark Price, Juwan Howard, Calbert Cheaney, Gheorghe Muresan, Rasheed Wallace and Don MacLean, the Bullets may be the league's most-improved team.

title: New Tool To Control Chemical Reactions
description: MANY chemical reactions by which pharmaceuticals and other products are manufactured are ambivalent: they proceed simultaneously along more than one pathway to yield mixtures of very different compounds. But a research team at the University of Illinois believes that carefully tuned pairs of laser beams may offer a tool based on quantum mechanics that can nudge reactions into desired pathways.

title: King's Fraud Trial to Open
description: Opening arguments are to be heard today in Federal court in Manhattan in the wire-fraud trial of the boxing promoter Don King, who is charged with defrauding Lloyd's of London by submitting phony expenses and a fake contract from a canceled title fight between Julio Cesar Chavez and Harold Brazier.

title: For Mexico, Nafta's Promise Of Jobs Is Still Just a Promise
description: So many people expected this brawny city of steel and glass to become a showcase of free trade and open competition after the three nations of North America signed a trade pact in 1993 that Monterrey officials put up an eight-foot monument to the agreement called "A Hope for Development."

title: Dow Jones & Co. (DJ,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
description: Dow Jones & Co. said consolidated operating income fell 20.4 percent in the latest third quarter to $ 55,390,000, reflecting planned spending on new television operations, new electronic information services, and the industry-wide impact of sharply higher newsprint costs.Dow Jones also said newsprint costs rose 47.5 percent in the latest quarter to $ 38.3 million.Interests in associated companies resulted in earnings of $ 4.4 million in the latest quarter, compared with losses of $ 1 million in the year-ago period. This included earnings from Dow Jones' partial ownership of newsprint production facilities.The positive impact of foreign exchange fluctuations and investment gains resulted in other income of $ 1.8 million for the latest third quarter, against losses of $ 1 million in year-ago period.

title: Ruling on Employee Searches
description: The State Supreme Court is expected to decide today whether temporarily to block a policy at a metals factory that requires employees suspected of stealing to remove a layer of clothing. Two workers at the Degussa Corporation, which processes precious metals for electronic uses, sued the company after one of them, Carol Ann Murphy, was asked to take off her blouse.

title: BID RAISED TO $288 MILLION FOR ARAN ENERGY
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company raised its bid yesterday for the Irish oil company Aran Energy P.L.C. to 178 million Irish pounds, or $288 million, topping its previous offer by 13 percent. The announcement came just after Statoil, the Norwegian state oil company, said it was in talks with Aran that could result in a competing cash offer for the company. Aran, which has vigorously opposed the hostile bid by the Los Angeles-based ARCO, told shareholders to reject the revised offer, maintaining that the bid still undervalued it.

title: Accounts
description: Orlando/Orange County Convention and Visitors Bureau, Orlando, Fla., to Cramer-Krasselt, Orlando, as agency of record for its tourism and meetings account, previously handled in-house and by various agencies project by project. The billings were estimated at $3 million. Pittsburgh Penguins to Hallmark/ Tassone Inc., Pittsburgh, to handle advertising for the National Hockey League team, previously handled by Werner Chepelsky & Partners, Pittsburgh. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Rapt Singer, Rapt Audience At Recital by Jose van Dam
description: The Belgian bass-baritone Jose van Dam is a great artist, but he does not thrust his artistry upon you, as his remarkable recital at Carnegie Hall on Friday night made clear. During his performances of nine early Brahms songs and Hugo Wolf's melancholic Michelangelo Lieder, Mr. van Dam barely made eye contact with his listeners; rather, he seemed lost to himself in a contemplative state and sang with an eloquence and affecting directness that compelled you to listen. I have rarely been part of a more riveted audience.

title: Funds for Newark Bay Dredging
description: Representative Frank Pallone Jr., Democrat of Long Branch, said yesterday that he would introduce a bill to use Federal money to help pay for the dredging of Newark Bay. The state and environmental groups support a $120 million proposal that calls for putting any contaminated mud that is dredged into pits in the bay's floor. But Mr. Pallone said the plan might falter without Federal aid. Dredging, long the subject of environmental disputes, is needed to clear vital shipping lanes at the ports of Newark and Elizabeth.

title: ORACLE SAYS IT IS DESIGNING LOW-COST COMPUTER
description: The Oracle Corporation said yesterday it was designing a $500 computer using chips from an Apple Computer Inc. venture. Oracle's chairman, Lawrence J. Ellison, told shareholders that the new machine would be much simpler than personal computers costing three times as much and would provide functions like electronic mail, word processing and Internet access. The Oracle computer uses the ARM chip, from Advanced RISC Machines Group, in which Apple holds a controlling stake. Mr. Ellison declined to say who would build the machines.

title: Kasparov Retains Title in a Tense Draw
description: Whatever happens in the next few days, Gary Kasparov made sure yesterday that he would gain at least a tie in his match with Viswanathan Anand and thus retain the title of world chess champion for two more years. The 32-year-old Russian did so by fighting his way out of a tight spot and escaping with a draw in Game 17.

title: At First Shy Of Publicity, Juror No. 4 Speaks Out
description: After six days of dodging reporters and watching some of his fellow jurors give interviews on national television, David A. Aldana, Juror No. 4, the only Hispanic member of the O. J. Simpson panel, decided to break his silence over the weekend.

title: Immune System Trick Halts Diabetes in Mice
description: In what may be a step toward treating diabetes, researchers say they have successfully transplanted insulin-producing cells between unrelated mice by tricking the immune system into accepting the foreign tissue.

description: The Mets said yesterday that TODD HUNDLEY, their regular catcher, had undergone successful surgery on his left wrist and is expected to be ready for spring training. The operation was performed by Dr. RICHARD EATON at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan.

description: Less than two hours before a cease-fire was to take effect across Bosnia, troops of the Bosnian Army's 501st Brigade were taking up positions in the mountains to prepare themselves for what appeared to be a new offensive.

description: On the first day after Pope John Paul II's departure from this country, New Yorkers yesterday honored a pilgrim who used a less fleet mode of transportation and found a less intense media reception.

title: Bridge Teams Contesting World Titles
description: Three of the four American teams started well in the Marlboro World Bridge Championships here today, but the fourth is in trouble. After 3 of 14 qualifying rounds, the team captained by Jim Cayne was in last place in its pool.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants Set Sights on Winning Streak
description: The next few weeks will determine whether the Giants make the playoffs. They have a home game on Sunday against Philadelphia, then a bye week. A victory is vital because no one wants to sit on a loss before a bye week. Then comes a very winnable game at Washington followed by a very winnable game at Seattle.

title: DURACRAFT SHARES DROP AFTER POOR PROFIT FORECAST
description: Shares in the Duracraft Corporation plunged yesterday after the company said it expected that production and shipping delays would cause third-quarter earnings to drop more than 60 percent. The shares closed down $12.50, or 34 percent, at $24.75 in Nasdaq trading, after falling to $20.75 a share, their lowest level since July 1993. Duracraft, which is based in Whitinsville, Mass., and is the country's largest maker of heaters, fans and humidifiers, said it expected third-quarter net income to fall to $1.85 million to $2.1 million; a year ago, Duracraft reported profit of $5.25 million.

title: After 18-Game Championship, 'K' Still Means Kasparov
description: Less than a half-hour into yesterday's game in the world chess championship, the reigning title holder from Russia, Gary Kasparov, made his 12th move, sliding a bishop diagonally forward one square. He looked at his challenger, Viswanathan Anand of India, smiled, then offered a draw. Mr. Anand scanned the board for several minutes, then accepted with a characteristic lack of expression.

description: About 900 Palestinian men were set free from Israeli detention today amid official confusion and scenes of emotional reunions.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: NABISCO BUYS MARGARINE UNIT OF KRAFT FOODS Nabisco Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the North American margarine and table spreads business of Kraft Foods Inc., including the Parkay, Touch of Butter and Chiffon brands. The terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Nabisco is a unit of Nabisco Holdings Inc., which is 80.5 percent owned by the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation. Nabisco said the Kraft businesses had sales of $255 million last year; Kraft's margarine businesses outside the United States and Canada were not included in the sale. Nabisco, based in Parsippany, N.J., markets Fleischmann's, Blue Bonnet and other spreads. Kraft, based in Northfield, Ill., is a unit of the Philip Morris Companies. On the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Philip Morris fell 12.5 cents, to $84.75, while shares of Nabisco Holdings fell 25 cents, to $28.50. (Reuters)

title: Lakers Lose Eddie Jones for Up to 8 Weeks
description: Guard EDDIE JONES, who averaged 14 points and 3.9 rebounds a game as a rookie with the Los Angeles Lakers last season, will be out for up to eight weeks with an injury to his left thumb. Jones will undergo surgery tomorrow to repair a torn ligament in his thumb. He hurt it during an evening practice Monday at the Lakers' training camp at the University of Hawaii. Jones, a former Temple star, appeared in 64 games last season, and his 2.05 steals per game was tops among league rookies. (AP)

title: Bosnian Cease-Fire Is Delayed Once Again
description: The Bosnian Government, complaining that the restoration of gas and electricity to the besieged city of Sarajevo was inadequate, said tonight that it would delay a cease-fire in its war with Serbian rebels for at least another day.

title: Mexico's Political Crisis
description: Two years of upheaval in Mexico has cracked a once-monolithic political establishment, but the transition from authoritarianism to democracy is incomplete. President Ernesto Zedillo, who met with President Clinton yesterday, has demonstrated more commitment to political reform than any recent Mexican leader. But he has run into strong opposition within his own, ruling party.

title: International Briefs; India Venture Set
description: The General Instrument Corporation and the HCL Corporation of India said yesterday that they would form a joint venture to manufacture and sell broadband telecommunications equipment in India. The companies said they would initially invest $25 million in the venture. It will start up early next year with manufacturing operations expected to begin by the end of 1996. The venture will provide set-top devices for televisions that will allow consumers to increase the number of channels they receive. (Reuters)

title: A Mexican Star and His Son, Singing Songs of the Heart
description: Vicente Fernandez's fans came prepared to his sold-out concert on Friday night at Radio City Music Hall. They had cameras to flash, flowers and private notes to hand him. A family lifted a small child dressed in an embroidered mariachi's suit to the stage to be photographed on Mr. Fernandez's shoulder. Others rushed forward for handshakes; one tenacious fan pulled Mr. Fernandez down into the audience. And when a song mentioned "la botella," a bottle, a man in the front row had one ready. Mr. Fernandez held it aloft and took a swig; he later returned for refills.

title: Natalie Merchant, Barefoot, Dancing and Emoting

On "Tigerlily," Ms. Merchant, who left the band 10,000 Maniacs at the peak of their fame two years ago, stripped her songs to their intimate folk roots. Unfortunately, she stripped them too far, resulting in blandness instead of poignancy.

Its durable old production of "La Boheme" dated from 1966, the year the City Opera moved to the New York State Theater, and although it served the company well, it looked increasingly shopworn in recent seasons.

title: Jean Seberg's Life, Most of It True
description: Mary Beth Hurt, her hair cropped and a beauty mark added to her left cheek, creates a stirring impression of what Jean Seberg might have looked like had she lived past the age of 40. Playing Seberg, Ms. Hurt is a gamine turned wise with middle age who stands in front of familiar black-and-white film clips from Seberg's early years. As a teen-ager, fresh from Marshalltown, Iowa (which happens to be Ms. Hurt's hometown, too), Seberg won a nationwide talent search and the title role in Otto Preminger's "Saint Joan." That 1957 movie was a disaster; Seberg was a star. "People magazine didn't exist then, but if it did I would have been on the cover," says Ms. Hurt as Seberg, looking back on a life in which the Hollywood dream went hideously wrong. "From the Journals of Jean Seberg" is Mark Rappaport's smart blend of fiction, biography and sociocultural meditation, wrapped in a smoothly entertaining package. It will be shown at the New York Film Festival tonight at 9.

title: EMC SHARES FALL ON DISAPPOINTING EARNINGS

Shares of EMC fell $3, to $13.75, as almost 13.4 million shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange. EMC, a maker of computer storage systems based in Hopkinton, Mass., reported after the market's close on Monday that preliminary earnings for the quarter were $71 million, or 31 cents a share, up from $69 million, or 30 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. The results were lower than Wall Street's forecast of 37 cents a share, based on a survey of 10 analysts by Zacks Investment Research.

title: Black Identity, Examined in an Artist's Last Days
description: It is a measure of the integrity of "Black Is . . . Black Ain't," Marlon Riggs's passionate exploration of black identity in America, that his film redeems a cliched image often invoked to describe the American melting pot. Throughout the movie, which opens today at the Film Forum, are scenes of the preparation of gumbo. As the camera peers into a pot in which this Southern stew is simmering, you sense that the dish is a collection of strong, clashing tastes. So it is with American black culture. No matter what anyone says, it isn't one thing or another but many things cooking together.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: NABISCO BUYS MARGARINE UNIT OF KRAFT FOODS Nabisco Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the North American margarine and table spreads business of Kraft Foods Inc., including the Parkay, Touch of Butter and Chiffon brands. The terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Nabisco is a unit of Nabisco Holdings Inc., which is 80.5 percent owned by the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation. Nabisco said the Kraft businesses had sales of $255 million last year; Kraft's margarine businesses outside the United States and Canada were not included in the sale. Nabisco, based in Parsippany, N.J., markets Fleischmann's, Blue Bonnet and other spreads. Kraft, based in Northfield, Ill., is a unit of the Philip Morris Companies. On the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Philip Morris fell 12.5 cents, to $84.75, while shares of Nabisco Holdings fell 25 cents, to $28.50. (Reuters) MENTOR GRAPHICS TO ACQUIRE MICROTEC RESEARCH The Mentor Graphics Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire Microtec Research Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $130 million. Under the agreement, Mentor Graphics, based in Wilsonville, Ore., will exchange 0.693 share for each share of Microtec. Microtec, based in Santa Clara, Calif., is a supplier of software development tools. In Nasdaq trading, shares of Microtec rose $1, to $12.25, while shares of Mentor slipped 81.25 cents, to $18.25. (Bloomberg Business News) WAL-MART PLANS LARGE EXPANSION IN UNITED STATES Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said yesterday that it planned to open about 75 discount stores, 110 supercenters and 12 Sam's Clubs stores in the United States in its fiscal year that begins Feb. 1. Wal-Mart, based in Bentonville, Ark., said about 95 of the supercenters, which are much larger outlets with a wider selection of goods, would result from the relocation or expansion of discount stores. Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retailer, also said it would open 30 to 35 discount stores, supercenters and Sam's Clubs in Canada, China, Argentina, Brazil, Mexico and Puerto Rico. (AP) CHEVRON TO SELL 18,000 ACRES IN CALIFORNIA In one of the largest real estate transactions in recent California history, the Chevron Corporation has agreed to sell more than 18,000 acres to a builder and a Morgan Stanley investment fund, an adviser said yesterday. The price was not disclosed, but real estate experts said the Orange County land alone could be worth $400 million. The deal consists of more than 14,000 acres of ranch land stretching from San Diego to Calaveras County and 6,000 acres in Orange County, said John French, a partner in E & Y Kenneth Leventhal Real Estate Group in Newport Beach, Calif., a financial adviser to Chevron. The buying group includes the Morgan Stanley Real Estate Fund II L.P.; Christopher Gibbs, a Newport Beach developer, and other undisclosed investors. A Chevron spokeswoman declined to comment on a sale agreement, which was reported yesterday in The Los Angeles Times. (AP) DUKE POWER TO CUT 900 JOBS BY EARLY NEXT YEAR The Duke Power Company said yesterday that it would cut about 900 jobs, or nearly 6 percent of its work force, by early next year to reduce costs and make the company more competitive. A Duke spokesman said the company would take an undetermined charge against earnings to pay one-time costs associated with the job reductions. Duke has been reducing its work force since 1988, when the company laid off about 1,200 employees. It offered voluntary separation packages in 1993 and 1994, when a total of 1,700 people left the company. Duke, based in Charlotte, N.C., is a large electric utility serving about 1.7 million customers in North Carolina and South Carolina. It currently has 16,100 employees. Shares of Duke rose 37.5 cents, to $44.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. (Reuters) EMC SHARES FALL ON DISAPPOINTING EARNINGS Shares of the EMC Corporation fell 18 percent yesterday after the company said price-cutting by its competitors had helped to lower the company's third-quarter earnings below analysts' expectations. Shares of EMC fell $3, to $13.75, as almost 13.4 million shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange. EMC, a maker of computer storage systems based in Hopkinton, Mass., reported after the market's close on Monday that preliminary earnings for the quarter were $71 million, or 31 cents a share, up from $69 million, or 30 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. The results were lower than Wall Street's forecast of 37 cents a share, based on a survey of 10 analysts by Zacks Investment Research. (Bloomberg Business News) LOMAS FINANCIAL FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION The Lomas Financial Corporation filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday and said it would sell its mortgage banking subsidiary, Lomas Mortgage USA Inc., to a First Nationwide Bank unit for $150 million. Lomas and its advisers have also considered selling most of its businesses to a third party as part of several strategic alternatives, the company said in court papers. Lomas, based in Dallas, said it was forced to declare bankruptcy after the exceptionally high level of mortgage refinancings between October 1991 and August 1994 caused a rapid decline in the number of mortgages it services. Lomas said its deteriorating financial condition caused the risk of intervention by government agencies or private mortgage investors. (Reuters) DAKA INTERNATIONAL TO ACQUIRE CHAMPPS ENTERTAINMENT Daka International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Champps Entertainment Inc., causing the stock of both restaurant companies to drop sharply. Daka said it would issue about 2.1 million common shares in exchange for all of the Champps outstanding shares, giving the deal a value of about $57.5 million. Daka, based in Danvers, Mass., is the owner of the Fuddruckers restaurant chain. Champps, based in Minnetonka, Minn., operates theme restaurants and bars. Shares of Daka fell $5.875, or nearly 18 percent, to $27.375, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of Champps fell 50 cents, to $11.25. (Dow Jones) CELL GENESYS AND HOECHST TO DEVELOP AIDS TREATMENT Cell Genesys Inc. said yesterday that it was joining Hoechst Marion Roussel in a venture worth up to $150 million to develop a treatment to destroy cells carrying the AIDS virus. Shares of Cell Genesys gained $1.4375, to $7.50, in Nasdaq trading. The venture involves genetic engineering of T cells, which are used by the body to fight disease. Cell Genesys, based in Foster City, Calif., said its modified T cells, called "killer" T cells, were designed to selectively destroy cells infected with the AIDS virus. Hoechst, a unit of Hoechst A.G. of Germany, will buy a 13 percent stake in Cell Genesys for $20 million and pay up to $30 million for research and development during the next two years. (Dow Jones) HUGHES TO OFFER SATELLITE TV SERVICE IN CHINA The Hughes Electronics Corporation, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, said yesterday that it planned to set up a direct-to-home satellite television service in China. Investment in the next 10 years could total $1.1 billion if everything under discussion works out, the chairman of Hughes, C. Michael Armstrong, said in a statement in Beijing. Mr. Armstrong, who is meeting with Chinese Government officials this week, said Hughes saw business opportunities in China through joint ventures, technology sales and direct investment. (AP) -------------------- ACCLAIM ENTERTAINMENT INC., Glen Cove, L.I., a maker of entertainment software, said it had bought Sculptured Software Inc., Salt Lake City, and had agreed to buy Probe Entertainment Ltd., London. Financial terms of the acquisitions were not disclosed. The closings affect about 250 employees.
