title: Huge Photo Archive Bought By the Chairman of Microsoft
description: William H. Gates, the software billionaire and champion of 21st-century technology, has purchased the Bettmann Archive, whose millions of historical photographs are a visual chronicle of the 20th century.

title: GOLF: NOTEBOOK;Mechem Might Have Saved Best Act for Last
description: Charles S. Mechem, the outgoing commissioner of the Ladies Professional Golf Association, has effected a great deal during his five-year tenure. He has added stability to the tournament schedule, eliminating the gaping hole in April known as Spring Break. He has worked to increase television exposure and presided over an increase in purse money from $18.4 million when he took over to more than $24 million this season.

title: Desegregation Plan Is Opposed
description: A mostly white crowd of about 600 people spilled out of a middle school auditorium last night, many of them fiercely opposed to a regionalization plan meant to desegregate Englewood's Dwight Morrow High School. "Heck No, We Won't Go," read a sign carried by an Englewood Cliffs seventh grader, Ralph Bernardo, who said he had heard about drugs and violence at Dwight Morrow, which is 97 percent black and Hispanic.

title: Attendants At American Get Pay Raise Of 17% by '97
description: In a rare success for organized labor, flight attendants who struck American Airlines just before Thanksgiving in 1993, today won a pay increase of about 17 percent in a contract that runs until late 1998.

title: PLAYOFFS '95;Showalter Is Still Dwelling on the Past, Not His Future
description: Buck Showalter sat in his empty office, beside the empty clubhouse in an empty Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon. The gorgeous sunlight that shone over the Bronx could not filter into the office because he has no windows, and that made the setting appropriate. Gloom filled the room.

title: CHRONICLE
description: What do the ice skaters NANCY KERRIGAN and PAUL WYLIE have in common besides Olympic Silver Medals?

title: Simpson Interview Drawing Interest, and Protest
description: NBC's interview tonight with O. J. Simpson, which is expected to attract an audience of tens of millions, has drawn widespread protests from angry viewers and feminist groups, scared off advertisers and forced other networks to change their prime-time schedules.

title: MENTOR GRAPHICS TO ACQUIRE MICROTEC RESEARCH
description: The Mentor Graphics Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire Microtec Research Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $130 million. Under the agreement, Mentor Graphics, based in Wilsonville, Ore., will exchange 0.693 share for each share of Microtec. Microtec, based in Santa Clara, Calif., is a supplier of software development tools. In Nasdaq trading, shares of Microtec rose $1, to $12.25, while shares of Mentor slipped 81.25 cents, to $18.25.

title: International Briefs; German Trade Surplus
description: Germany's trade surplus narrowed in July to 5.9 billion marks, or $4.2 billion, from 8.5 billion marks in June, the Federal Statistics Office reported yesterday. The deficit in the current account, which includes trade in services and some capital flows, soared to 5.9 billion marks in July from 900 million marks in June. The current account has been in deficit for much of the year, in large part because many more Germans are taking trips abroad than foreigners are visiting Germany. (Reuters)

title: Sports of The Times;No Luxury to Be a Nets Rookie
description: SHORTLY after practice yesterday morning, Ed O'Bannon, the Nets rookie forward, headed to the cafeteria for lunch. He was in the middle of a conversation when someone playfully interrupted: it was Scotty Thurman. The two exchanged greetings, and Thurman hurried ahead.

title:
Business Travel;
New computer software programs will put executives directly in control of their bookings.
description: A REVOLUTION is about to begin for executives who like to be in control when they book their business travel. In the next few weeks, three major airlines and one hotel company will start giving their top customers special floppy disks that can be inserted into a laptop computer to book a plane ticket, hotel room or rental car directly from one of the largest airline reservations systems.

title: International Briefs; Merger Plan Depresses German Retailers' Stock
description: Shares in the German retail companies Kaufhof Holding A.G. and Asko Deutsche Kaufhaus A.G. fell more than 5 percent yesterday because of concern over the proposed merger with their majority shareholder, the Swiss company, Metro. Terms of the share exchange, which was announced on Monday, will not be fixed until independent auditors value both companies.

title: Colorado Is Engine in Anti-Gay Uproar
description: Here in a new stronghold of the religious right, volunteers knocked on doors today, soliciting signatures for a petition that instructs county commissioners: "Our community must unconditionally advocate heterosexuality only."

title: DAKA INTERNATIONAL TO ACQUIRE CHAMPPS ENTERTAINMENT
description: Daka International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Champps Entertainment Inc., causing the stock of both restaurant companies to drop sharply. Daka said it would issue about 2.1 million common shares in exchange for all of the Champps outstanding shares, giving the deal a value of about $57.5 million. Daka, based in Danvers, Mass., is the owner of the Fuddruckers restaurant chain. Champps, based in Minnetonka, Minn., operates theme restaurants and bars. Shares of Daka fell $5.875, or nearly 18 percent, to $27.375, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of Champps fell 50 cents, to $11.25.

title: When Great Composers Find Themselves
description: The programmatic conceit behind Daniel Barenboim's recital on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall was that each of the works he played caught its composer at the moment of a stylistic breakthrough. Beethoven's Sonata in C (Op. 2, No. 3), shows the composer pulling free of the orbit of Haydn and Mozart, though not escaping their influence entirely. Schoenberg's Three Pieces (Op. 11) were written during his first burst of composition in the 12-tone style. And the Sonata No. 3 in F minor (Op. 5) shows Brahms marshaling grand forces and large forms with a maturity that had previously eluded him.

title: Stepping Out From the Lens Of History;Frozen Moments Alter Lives Of Subjects of 2 Famous Photos
description: The 100 young photographers had come to a hillside in Sullivan County to learn from masters, to show off their talent, to make connections and perhaps to win their first big assignment. All that is possible at the Eddie Adams Workshop, where each October, veteran news photographers and editors gather for a weekend to tutor and to test the eye of the next generation.

title: Doctors Are Warned About Eye Treatment
description: In a warning to eye doctors, Federal health officials said yesterday that patients who suffer bacterial infections after surgery to remove cataracts and implant lenses need treatment with antibiotics that are injected only into the eye and not systemically through a vein.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GYMNASTICS Mo, 16, Picks Up Gold on the Beam

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday about the president of Adelphi University, Peter Diamandopoulos, referred imprecisely to his annual compensation of $523,636. That figure represents salary and deferred bonuses, not salary alone.

title: PLAYOFFS '95: NOTEBOOK;Braves' Pitching Remains in Order
description: Manager Bobby Cox of the Braves made no big, bold pronouncements about his rotation for the National League Championship Series -- Tom Glavine and John Smoltz in the first two games in Cincinnati, then Greg Maddux when the series moves to Atlanta for Game 3 on Friday night.

title: INSIDE
description: Nobel to Chicago Economist

title: International Briefs; Compagnie de Suez Loss
description: Compagnie de Suez said early today that it lost $800 million in the first half of the year as a result of a charge involving its exposure to the depressed French property market. Suez, one of the pillars of the French financial establishment, reported a loss of 3.98 billion francs, in contrast to a profit of 795 million francs, or $353 million, in the period a year earlier. The results included a one-time charge of $820 million on its property business. Suez took a similar $353 million charge in the first half of 1994. (Reuters)

title: Foreign Affairs; Proceed With Caution
description: With the cease-fire coming in Bosnia, attention is now shifting to the question of which countries should contribute peacekeeping troops to consolidate an end to the war. I've got the perfect choice: the Germans.

title: Plain and Simple;A Stew For a Chef In a Rush
description: This homey, simple, straightforward dish is the cook's quick version of a stew. The seasonings bring out the flavor of the tomatoes and zucchini without competing with them. Serve it with corn on the cob, which has been particularly delicious this year, and for a slight twist, sprinkle the corn with a little cumin.

title: Taming the 'Stinking Rose' (but Not Too Much, Please)
description: It seems now as if garlic had always been popular, but the taste for it ebbs and flows.

title:
Real Estate;
Fidelity is reversing strategy and moving 2,500 workers out of Boston to a site 40 miles west.
description: WHEN Fidelity Investments, the mutual fund giant with headquarters in the financial district here, completes the move of 2,500 employees to Marlborough, Mass., it will be a departure in several ways.

title: A Nobel Award for a University of Chicago Economist, Yet Again
description: Robert E. Lucas Jr., a 58-year-old professor at the University of Chicago, was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science yesterday -- the fifth winner in economics from the University of Chicago in the last six years.

title: Many Heart Patients Failing to Seize a Lifeline
description: More than two-thirds of Americans suffering from heart disease fail to enroll in cardiac rehabilitation programs that could improve the length and quality of their lives, an expert panel said today.

title: Reviews/Fashion;Strong Mystiques Wrap Up Milan
description: It is the sort of thing that only a satirist could invent: on the final day of the fashion shows here, just when fashion editors were going to see Prada, the house they most recently anointed as the leader, there is a bomb scare there.

title: Siberia
description: Before New York's restaurant owners and managers, maitres d'hotel and headwaiters ask for the best tables in heaven, they have a lot to answer for. Even St. Peter, who manages the front of the house, is baffled by a mystery that bedevils diners. When they arrive at empty restaurants, why are they so often taken to the worst table -- to Siberia, as we call it?

title: Real Estate;Fidelity is reversing strategy and moving 2,500 workers out of Boston to a site  40 miles west.
description: WHEN Fidelity Investments, the mutual fund giant with headquarters in the financial district here, completes the move of 2,500 employees to Marlborough, Mass., it will be a departure in several ways.

title: Discovery of Internet Flaws Is Setback for On-Line Trade
description: Newly publicized weaknesses in the basic structure of the Internet indicate that the worldwide computer network may need a time-consuming redesign before it can be safely used as a commercial medium.

title: U.N. Chief Recalls His Envoy in the Balkans as U.S. Applauds
description: In a major shuffle of its envoys in the Balkans, the United Nations announced today that Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali is recalling his special representative in the region and replacing him temporarily with the official now responsible for all peacekeeping operations.

title: Corrections
description: A caption yesterday with a picture of a graveside scene in Bosnia incorrectly described the Bosnian Army soldier who was being mourned. He was a Christian, not a Muslim.

title: Stalking the Elusive Healthy Diet;At Health Clubs, a Range of Choices for Better Nutrition
description: IT wasn't so long ago that seeing a nutritionist at a health club was like going to a snake oil salesman for a headache: the advice you got was questionable, and you left the office with an armload of weird-smelling, useless products.

title: Bias in Doctors' Offices May Harm Gay Women's Health, Study Finds
description: THE trouble often begins with a woman's initial visit to a doctor. The doctor asks, "Are you sexually active?"

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Federal Farm Credit Banks is selling $45 million of notes due in 2000 through Merrill Lynch & Co. The notes, which are callable in six months, carry an interest rate of 6.730 percent and are priced at par.

title: Now Take Next Step to Cuba Dialogue; Chernobyl's Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Salvadoran Sweatshops
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYOFFS '95;Just 41 Years Between Losses
description: Look at it this way: The Indians hadn't lost a post-season game in 41 years, and they had to lose sometime, which they did, 3-2, to the Mariners tonight.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JUDITH S. KAYE, the Chief Judge of the State of New York, is to participate this afternoon in a symposium called "Confronting Breast Cancer in the 90's" at Fordham University Law School. She and three other judges plan to grill six health-care experts, including Dr. Susan J. Blumenthal, an Assistant Surgeon General, along with an official of Empire Blue Cross/Blue Shield and a lawyer who specializes in suits involving breast cancer. .

title: A Rockefeller Center Bid May Be Reduced
description: An investor group that includes David Rockefeller, Goldman, Sachs & Company and Tishman Speyer Properties L.P. said yesterday that it might lower its bid for Rockefeller Center.

title: My Husband Pays for His White House'
description: To the Editor:

title: Cotton Board Unit Favors Jersey
description: The 30-member Board of Managers of the New York Cotton Exchange voted unanimously yesterday to move its operation to New Jersey, the exchange's president, Joe O'Neill, said. The board based its decision on the fact that it is cheaper to conduct business in New Jersey, Mr. O'Neill said. The Cotton Exchange and the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, whose approval is needed before the move can take place, are expected to vote on the matter today, the deadline imposed by a letter of intent signed by the two exchanges on July 12.

title: Robber Convicted of Murder
description: A jury in Elizabeth convicted a Linden man of murder yesterday, after one of a dozen robberies of elderly women he committed in late 1993 ended in the death of an 82-year-old who struck her head when he shoved her to the ground, said Robert O'Leary, an assistant prosecutor in Union County. The woman, Esther Feldman, died two days after Paul Rappisi, who was 19 at the time, robbed her in front of her home in Clarke, Mr. O'Leary said. Mr. O'Leary said Mr. Rappisi's conviction for felony murder -- causing someone's death, intentionally or not, during a different crime -- depended largely on testimony against him by his accomplice, James Della Bella of Bayonne, who pleaded guilty to robbery charges only.

title: Amoco Plans Joint Venture With Shell Oil
description: The Amoco Corporation and the Shell Oil Company, long rivals in the oilfields of the Permian Basin of West Texas and southeast New Mexico, where huge gushers helped them become industry leaders, announced yesterday that they have decided to form a joint venture.

title: Theater Review;Decadence, Ferns and Facades
description: The gods are not being kind to Circle in the Square, but, to paraphrase Euripides: whom the gods would destroy, they first tease without mercy.

title: Niagara Mohawk Dug Its Own Financial Hole
description: To the Editor:

title: Schools Make a Better Investment Than Prisons
description: To the Editor:

title: Upbeat White House Visit For the President of Mexico
description: The rescued came to thank the rescuer today, as President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico met President Clinton for the first time since the Administration sidestepped Congress to bail out the Mexican economy. The two leaders declared that jobs and prosperity had been saved on both sides of the border.

title: A.M.A. Backing Republicans In Plan to Overhaul Medicare
description: After receiving assurances that Medicare payments to doctors would be cut less than originally planned, the American Medical Association tonight expressed support for a House Republican proposal to redesign the medical plan for the elderly.

title: Longer Hospital Stays for Childbirth Are Needed, Pediatricians Say
description: Most mothers and babies need to stay in the hospital at least 48 hours after childbirth, the nation's largest group of pediatricians said today, bucking a trend toward shorter stays that save money.

title: CELL GENESYS AND HOECHST TO DEVELOP AIDS TREATMENT
description: Cell Genesys Inc. said yesterday that it was joining Hoechst Marion Roussel in a venture worth up to $150 million to develop a treatment to destroy cells carrying the AIDS virus. Shares of Cell Genesys gained $1.4375, to $7.50, in Nasdaq trading. The venture involves genetic engineering of T cells, which are used by the body to fight disease. Cell Genesys, based in Foster City, Calif., said its modified T cells, called "killer" T cells, were designed to selectively destroy cells infected with the AIDS virus. Hoechst, a unit of Hoechst A.G. of Germany, will buy a 13 percent stake in Cell Genesys for $20 million and pay up to $30 million for research and development during the next two years.

title: Simpson Trial Shows Need for Proper Use of Forensic Science, ExpertsSay
description: If ever there was a criminal case in which scientific evidence should have taken center stage, it was the O. J. Simpson case. It was the DNA found in blood at the crime scene and in Mr. Simpson's home and Ford Bronco that carried prosecutors beyond motive, means and opportunity to the point where they could say they had direct physical proof that he was the killer.

title: Healthsouth Plans to Buy Surgical Care in Stock Swap
description: The consolidation in the health care industry continued yesterday, as the Healthsouth Corporation announced that it would acquire Surgical Care Affiliates Inc., a provider of outpatient surgery, for about $1.2 billion in stock.

title: Harry Hurwitz, a Screenwriter, Film Director and Painter, 57
description: Harry Hurwitz, a film director, screenwriter and painter, died on Sept. 21 at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 57.

title: For Cortines, an Early Departure
description: Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines quietly ended his tenure yesterday, three days earlier than expected and the day before his replacement, Rudolph F. Crew, arrives in New York City.

title: Salvadoran Sweatshops
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;A California savings and loan takes some shots at the big banks, and meets with  apparent success.
description: IN the typically genteel world of financial-institution advertising, tradition remains important. Messages suggest stability and financial might, most making no claim bolder than "Our C.D. Rates Add Up to Big Numbers." Comparisons are indirect, if at all.

title: Opponents of Gay Topics Press Crusade
description: Buoyed by fresh victories at local school boards in New Hampshire and Iowa, conservatives who believe that homosexual topics have no place in public-school curriculums are preparing to make their case to Congress.

title: International Briefs; Czech Banks' Outlook
description: Ceska Sporitelna A.S. and Ceskoslovenska Obchodni Banka A.S., two of the Czech Republic's largest banks, said yesterday that they endorsed the idea of merging, but denied any specific plan is under discussion to combine the two institutions into the nation's largest bank. The banks, with combined assets of about 520 billion koruna, or $19.7 billion, said they needed to grow, possibly through a merger, to compete outside the Czech Republic. Any decision about a merger or ownership change in the banks is in the hands of the Czech Government. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday with an article about the impact of the North American Free Trade Agreement incorrectly described the data shown. The graph showed the number of American workers who have qualified for a Federal job retraining program intended to cushion the effects of Nafta, not the number of jobs lost as a result of the accord.

title: Director of Playwrights Horizons Resigns
description: Don Scardino, who became the artistic director of Playwrights Horizons nearly four years ago, is leaving the job at the end of the year, the theater announced yesterday. The company's associate artistic director, Tim Sanford, is to replace him.

title: MORE EXPULSIONS BY SERBIAN FORCE REPORTED BY U.N.
description: As a long-sought cease-fire was delayed yet again, ethnic Serbs were reported today by United Nations officials to be undertaking a huge new "ethnic cleansing" campaign around their stronghold, Banja Luka, expelling thousands of women, children and the elderly and leading thousands of men away to uncertain fates.

title: An Enigma Wrapped in a Mystery
description: The immense success of Robert Harris's first novel, "Fatherland," enabled him to give up his job as a newspaper columnist and buy a rambling Victorian mansion in an idyllic corner of Berkshire 60 miles west of London. It also left him with the challenge of writing a second novel that would not be considered a letdown.

title: Selloff Becomes 'Opportunity' as Stocks Reverse a Plunge
description: Investors dived into a rapidly falling stock market yesterday morning to snatch up shares of stocks -- particularly those of computer, software, communications and other technology companies that had plunged more than 5 percent in less than three days.

title: Sports of The Times;Buck Should Fire George And Leave
description: THERE is no reason William Nathaniel Showalter 3d should feel so wretched -- except the perverse ability of George M. Steinbrenner 3d to make others feel cheap.

title: Journal;Why Foster Lives
description: On Sunday night Mike Wallace of "60 Minutes" proved once again that, yes, Vincent Foster did commit suicide in Fort Marcy Park, Virginia, in July 1993.

title: Jury Selection in Assault Case
description: Jury selection will begin today in the trial of an Edison police sergeant who is charged with sexually assaulting a woman in 1991 and attempting to conceal his misconduct by getting two other officers to file bogus reports. The original grand jury that looked into the woman's complaint against the sergeant, Charles Fekete, did not return an indictment. But the Edison Police Department conducted an independent investigation in which the two officers admitted that they had lied about the incident, said Edward Costello Jr., the Police Chief. The incident took place after police responded to a noise complaint at the woman's home, Chief Costello said.

title: Disability Themes Win Praise
description: ITT Hartford Life, Kraft Foods and the Saturn Corporation shared top honors last night at the sixth annual National Easter Seal EDI Awards ceremony in New York, honoring communications that enhance the independence of people with disabilities.

title: Wine Talk
description: A DEATH in California, an anniversary in Maryland, a winery closing in France: three events, none directly related, but all of them worthy of note for anyone interested in wine as a cultural and social phenomenon and as a part of history.

title: Say, Can You See an End to This Job?
description: Louis Armstrong never tried a chop-buster like this: playing 55 national anthems in a single day.

title: Candidates Make History With Early Ads in New Hampshire
description: Former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee has been advertising on television here since late June. Yet in most recent polls, the level of support for him in New Hampshire barely exceeds the surveys' statistical margin of error.

title: Compensation for Chiron
description: The Chiron Corporation and Johnson & Johnson said this week that Akzo Nobel N.V.'s Organon Teknika N.V. unit had agreed to pay them compensation for infringing Chiron's European patent for a hepatitis C blood screening test. Chiron, which is based here, discovered the hepatitis C virus in 1987 and, together with its marketing partner, Johnson & Johnson's Ortho Diagnostic Systems, began selling the first blood test for the virus in 1989. The amount of the payment was not disclosed.

title: All a Matter of Perspective
description: To Ronald and Bridgette Lathern, Nationsbank is guilty of racial discrimination, a biased lender that unfairly rejected their mortgage application because they are black. That rejection, they said, caused them to miss out on the tidy three-bedroom home in suburban Maryland they had their hearts set on.

title: 4th Graders, Congress to Interact
description: Fourth graders at the Arbor Road School will have a chance today to show off their interactive video communications learning system to two committees of the United States House of Representatives.

title: If Johnson Gets Help, Lewis Wants It, Too
description: If world track officials alter the Olympic schedule to benefit MICHAEL JOHNSON's gold-medal hopes in the 200 and 400 meters, they should do the same for CARL LEWIS. That's the gist of a letter from JOE DOUGLAS, manager of Lewis's Santa Monica Track Club, to the International Amateur Athletic Federation. The I.A.A.F. has already added 55 minutes between the 200 semifinals and the 400 semifinals at next year's Atlanta Olympics, leaving a gap of 2 hours 35 minutes. But Johnson said that is not good enough.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ACCLAIM ENTERTAINMENT INC., Glen Cove, L.I., a maker of entertainment software, said it had bought Sculptured Software Inc., Salt Lake City, and had agreed to buy Probe Entertainment Ltd., London. Financial terms of the acquisitions were not disclosed.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Buried Under a Barrage by Maple Leafs
description: If defense was supposed to be the Islanders' hallmark this season, Coach Mike Milbury could not have liked what he saw here tonight.

title: KERR GROUP CONSIDERS SALE AS IT PREDICTS LOSSES
description: Kerr Group Inc. said yesterday that it was expecting a third-quarter loss and was considering selling some or all of the company. The container company said it had hired Lehman Brothers Inc. to review ways to increase shareholder value amid consolidation in the packaging industry. The company said it was expecting losses in the third quarter and full year. The company's stock rose $1.625, to $8.125. Its 23 percent gain was the best of the day on the New York Stock Exchange. Kerr Group operates a plastics and consumer products division. It manufactures child-resistant and tampering-evident seals, jars and plastic parts for the pharmaceutical, food, cosmetics and household chemicals markets.

title: High Court Examines, Gingerly, Issue of Punitive Damages' Limit
description: The Supreme Court wrestled once again today with the question of what limits the Constitution places on punitive damages. And as has happened a half-dozen times in the past eight years, the Justices surveyed this contested legal landscape, now littered with false starts and inconclusive decisions, and appeared deeply uncertain as to how to proceed.

title: Dispute Over Indy Qualifying
description: Championship Auto Racing Teams has confirmed it is considering a race the same day as the Indianapolis 500 unless the Speedway president, TONY GEORGE, reinstates the traditional Indy qualifying format. The dispute is over George's plans to reserve 25 of the 33 starting spots for regulars in the new Indy Racing League, providing they qualify at a minimum speed based on a percentage of the pole position. (AP)

title: OLYMPICS;Atlanta Officials Resolve Budget Issue
description: Atlanta Olympic officials declared today that their long battle over the 1996 Summer Games budget was over and that the money had been found to present what they have called "the best Olympic Games ever."

title: WTA Gets a Main Sponsor
description: As expected, the WTA Tour has reached agreement with the Canadian software company Corel to be the women tennis group's first main sponsor in two years. ANNE PERSON WORCHESTER, the head of the WTA Tour, said yesterday that the agreement was for a long term, but was not specific. The contract will cover some 60 tournaments, including the four Grand Slams and the Fed Cup. It becomes effective with the WTA Championships, Nov. 13-19 at Madison Square Garden. (AP)

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK GREETS CHANCELLOR-DESIGNATE The next New York City schools chancellor, Dr. Rudolph F. Crew, arrived from Tacoma, Wash., like a politician on a carefully choreographed victory lap, doling out bear hugs at a Queens elementary school in front of television cameras he had invited to record the visit. And the city provided its own inimitable kind of welcome. [ Page A1. ] The Republicans who control the State Senate joined Governor Pataki in endorsing much of Mayor Giuliani's plan to abolish the New York City Board of Education. [ B3. ] Dr. Crew's decision to spend $1.6 million on motivational training for teachers in Tacoma was the subject of debate, and drew charges of conflict of interest. [ B3. ] As he made one last visit to the schools he would be leaving behind, friends said that Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines was having some regrets about leaving. [ B3. ] Police officials told a special commission set up by the Mayor that the school system's security division was unequipped to protect students. [ B2. ] NEW YORK CITY POLICE RECONSTRUCT SHOOTING OF OFFICER A police officer who was shot four times in an East Village bodega was caught in a hail of gunfire between the police and drug dealers, the police said, and two of the bullets that struck him were fired by fellow officers. Investigators are trying to reconstruct a robbery gone awry. [ B4. ] ALLEGATIONS OF POLICE CORRUPTION DROP Allegations of police corruption in New York City fell by 17 percent the first six months of this year compared with the same period in 1994, according to a Police Department survey. But officials said they were still troubled by the high concentration of complaints in minority neighborhoods plagued by drug dealing. [ B4. ] TURNING TABLES ON CITY WELFARE ADVISER Most of the questions were taken directly from the pages of a new city handbook for welfare inspectors. But the questioners in front of the apartment of Richard J. Schwartz, the senior adviser to Mayor Giuliani on welfare reform, were not with the city. [ B4. ] BRONX DISTRICT ATTORNEY FOCUS OF SIT-IN Family members of two young men killed in confrontations with the police staged a boisterous sit-in outside the Bronx District Attorney's office, demanding prosecution of officers in the deaths of their loved ones. [ B4. ] CHINATOWN LEADER SENTENCED IN MURDER The powerful former president of a Chinatown fraternal and business organization was sentenced to life in prison for a murder and racketeering conviction that prosecutors called their first victory against the top ranks of Chinese organized crime in New York City. [ B4. ] ADDRESS BOOK NAMES TERROR SUSPECTS An address book belonging to the wife of a Palestinian political leader being held in New York City contains the names of several suspected terrorists in the Middle East, an F.B.I. document says. [ B5. ] REGION EXCHANGE DELAYS MOVE The 19-member board of the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange postponed voting on a plan to move to Jersey City, after New York officials made a last-minute attempt to convince it to remain in lower Manhattan. [ B5. ]

title: LaRoche Industries reports earnings for 2d qtr to Aug 31

title: A Hard-Hearted Tax Bill
description: The Senate Finance Committee is debating a tax bill that does everything wrong. It promotes consumption rather than savings. It cuts taxes on the rich and raises them on the poor. It creates tax shelters for corporations. It widens the deficit by $245 billion, meaning that important social programs would be vulnerable to later efforts to reduce that deficit.

title: Crime, Violence and Pessimism (Not in America)
description: In France, Mathieu Kassovitz's "Hate" ("La Haine"), is the best-known and most successful of a new genre known as "banlieue" films, a reference to their settings in the suburbs of Paris, in the volatile, interracial housing projects there. The first of these films to arrive here, "Hate," is the kind of strong but narrowly focused work that might have had problems in translation. Yet for American viewers, the eeriest part of Mr. Kassovitz's precise and troubling film is how easily it reflects our own social problems. It will be shown at the New York Film Festival tonight at 9 and Saturday at 2 P.M., and is to open in theaters in January.

Appearing at a news conference in Wembley Stadium -- even the venues for their briefings are huge -- they discussed plans for their tour, which starts next summer.

title: Wanted: A Hideaway To Hatch A Peace
description: Forget about constitutional principles and the status of eastern Slavonia. The crisis du jour of American officials struggling to end the four-year-old war in Bosnia is how to house, feed, entertain and contain the Presidents of Serbia, Croatia and Bosnia -- and presumably their wives, advisers, personal physicians and cooks -- as they talk about peace.

Shares in Suez closed 8.9 francs lower at 183 francs, or $37, after falling as low as 180.7 francs. The French holding company was sold to the public in 1987.

title: Civil Cases Mean Simpson's Legal Troubles Are Far From Over
description: O. J. Simpson walked away from the courtroom last week a free man, but his legal problems are hardly over as he faces several costly civil suits that legal experts say could take years to resolve.

title: International Briefs; Reliance Industries' Profit Jumps 33%
description: Reliance Industries Ltd, a petrochemical and textiles manufacturer and India's largest private sector company, said yesterday that its first-half profit rose 33 percent, as a result of a rise in international polymer prices. Profit totaled 6.33 billion rupees ($187 million) for the six months through Sept. 30. The percentage rise was exaggerated because the company had restated the prior year's earnings to 4.77 billion rupees from 5.10 billion previously.

title: Drug Suspension for Jockey
description: SEAN McCARTHY, an apprentice jockey who became the first rider in Britain to fail a drug test, was suspended for two months yesterday. McCarthy, 22, who tested positive for marijuana and amphetamines at Folkestone on Aug. 15, had his license withdrawn by the Jockey Club's Disciplinary Committee. McCarthy, who has ridden five winners, was ordered to undergo rehabilitation and pass another test before he can reapply for his license Dec. 14. (AP)

title: HALLIBURTON TO SPIN OFF HIGHLANDS INSURANCE
description: The Halliburton Company said yesterday that it planned to spin off its Highlands Insurance Group to shareholders by year-end, completing its exit from the insurance business. The company, which provides oilfield services and engineering and construction services, plans to give stockholders one Highlands common share for every 10 Halliburton shares. After the spinoff, Insurance Partners L.P., a private investment group, and members of Highlands management are expected to invest $60 million in Highlands in exchange for bonds and warrants. If these securities are exercised, Insurance Partners could invest up to $130 million for a 43 percent stake in Highlands. Halliburton's shares rose $1.625, to $43.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Saving the Tarrytown Riverbank
description: The Hudson River, with its breathtaking panoramas, is one of the world's great waterways. But its riverbanks suffer the legacy of an era when the Hudson was valued more as an industrial site than as a natural wonder. As industry moves out, local and state governments need to move forcefully to see that these big pieces of riverbank are used well. They are a natural resource of great potential.

Thomas, 52, would receive a severance package valued at $117.9 million, if First Financial is taken over by the First Data Corporation, according to a recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Cassels took a pass in front of Ducks goalie Guy Hebert from Geoff Sanderson. Hebert stopped Cassels's first shot, but Cassels slid the rebound beneath the fallen goalie. Whalers goalie Sean Burke stopped 32 shots to earn the victory. (AP)

title: The Details Illuminate The Whole
description: Mary Chapin Carpenter has a gift for details. In her lyrics she hears the way an old staircase groans, sees a cup of coffee growing cold, recalls how a young bride wore her mother's lace. And when she brought her band to the Paramount on Tuesday night, the music was full of subtleties, as when the country-rock of "I Take My Chances" faded down to a ticking cymbal and veiled guitar chords. Her straightforward voice rarely calls attention to itself; she warms melodies, enunciates words and lets ballads grow tender but not sentimental. Her attention to small things serves a larger purpose: to illuminate everyday lives by showing them clearly.

Uunet shares rose $1.875 to close at $40.875 in Nasdaq trading. Uunet, which provides Internet access to the Microsoft Network users, offered to acquire Unipalm after two months of negotiations. Under the offer, which has been recommended by Unipalm's board, Uunet said it would exchange 0.1671 share of its common stock for each ordinary share of Unipalm, valuing each Unipalm share at $6.83.

Even Mr. Lauren runs out of storage space. Yesterday, he sold 443 lots of European and American furniture -- some antiques, others vaguely old -- for $2.5 million (including buyers' premiums) at Sotheby's in New York.

description: Charles G. Gomillion, who led the fight that brought political power to the black majority in Tuskegee, Ala., with the assistance of a landmark Supreme Court case that bears his name, died on Oct. 4 at a hospital in Montgomery, Ala. On Dec. 21, CSX plans to distribute two shares for every one share held to holders of record as of Dec. 4. After the 2-for-1 split CSX's quarterly dividend rate will be 26 cents a share. Mr. Hung jolts his audience with the cacophonous din of Ho Chi Minh City, where the film's nameless 18-year-old protagonist works backbreakingly hard pedaling a bicycle-driven taxi. As he weaves anonymously through traffic, pushing a rickshaw seat for paying customers, this orphaned boy remembers his father's wish that his son have a good life. But the father was a cyclo killed in traffic, and the son's prospects are even more hauntingly grim.

title: PLAYOFFS '95;Indians' Ramirez Finds Stroke, And With It, Some Souvenirs

The outfielder from New York and the Dominican Republic hit two homers and two singles to help the Cleveland Indians beat the Seattle Mariners, 5-2, and tie the American League Championship Series at one game apiece.

title: Two Nations, Separate and Hostile?
description: Depressing episodes in race relations come and go, but the O.J. Simpson verdict may have an enduring impact. Troubling images have crossed our television screens: cheers, hugs and high-fives among blacks; silence and dismay among whites; anti-black graffiti in Brentwood, the wealthy neighborhood where Nicole Simpson lived.

title: Liberties;The Crisco Kids
description: You can't find them anywhere.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The "three tenors," LUCIANO PAVAROTTI, PLACIDO DOMINGO and JOSE CARRERAS, who have sung for billions of people in the last five years in joint concerts, videos and recordings, are taking the show on the road to five countries, they announced in London yesterday. Appearing at a news conference in Wembley Stadium -- even the venues for their briefings are huge -- they discussed plans for their tour, which starts next summer.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Fall Color at Your Feet

title: UNION PACIFIC RESOURCES SELLS 37 MILLION SHARES
description: Union Pacific Resources Group Inc. said yesterday that it had raised about $777 million through an initial sale of 37 million shares to the public at $21 a share. Union Pacific Resources, a natural gas and oil company, is a unit of the Union Pacific Corporation of Bethlehem, Pa., a rail-transportation company. The subsidiary's shares closed at $22 after 8.9 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Julius Monk Memorial
description: A memorial for Julius Monk is to be held at 11 A.M. tomorrow at St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church, 239 West 49th Street, in the theater district. Mr. Monk, the impresario of cabaret revues, died on Aug. 17 at age 82.

description: The share earnings and shares outstanding were restated for 25 percent stock dividends in August 1995 and November 1994.

OLYMPIA'S U.S. UNIT FILES FOR CHAPTER 11 PROTECTION
description: Olympia & York Companies (U.S.A.), the American subsidiary of Olympia & York Development Ltd., filed yesterday for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors as part of its proposed restructuring of $5 billion worth of debt. Yesterday's filing at Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan follows approval by the company's board on Sept. 21 of a restructuring plan that may give control of the company to a group of creditors led by the Bronfman family of Toronto. The plan, which will be presented at a bankruptcy court hearing scheduled for Oct. 26, is opposed by a group of creditors seeking control of the reorganized company, led by the Apollo Real Estate Investment Fund and Tishman Speyer Properties Inc.

title: Love of Learning Won't Feed a Family
description: To the Editor:

title: Defending Deal For Turner, Time Warner Sues U S West
description: In the clearest sign yet that its partnership with U S West Inc. is on the rocks, Time Warner Inc. yesterday accused the telephone company of "fraudulent, reckless, or negligent" conduct.

title: Coltec Industries(COT,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Included a special charge of $ 27 million ($ 17.6 million after taxes, or 25 cents a share), primarily to cover the costs of closing the company's Walbar compressor blade facility in Canada, and to a lesser extent, the charge also covered selected work-force reductions throughout the company and write-downs of unutilized assets.c-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 177,000.Sales are net sales.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Busy Mixture of Cuisine and Comedy
description: Just as water seeks its true level, the peripatetic entertainment titled "Pomp Duck and Circumstance" will probably find its true home when it takes up permanent residence at the MGM Grand Hotel in Las Vegas after a trip to Atlanta for the Olympics next year.

title: Company Briefs
description: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC., Cincinnati, has completed its $541 million acquisition of Broadway Stores Inc., Los Angeles.

title: PLAYOFFS '95;Extra Innings Are Extra Nice for Braves
description: The Atlanta Braves and Cincinnati Reds tested their bullpens and benches with a second straight extra-inning game in their mirror-image National League Championship Series.

title: Kansas City Power & Light Co.(KLT,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
description: Kansas City Power & Light said its third quarter earnings reflected a reduction in the first quarter gain on the sale of rail cars to $ 5.4 million from $ 7.8 million.

title: Close To Home;In Dance of Friendship, Waltzes Get Harder to Come By
description: MY 5-year-old daughter, Rebecca, found a new friend last spring, in the last few weeks of preschool. Evidence of her feelings first emerged as she sat absorbed at her small table, turning out letters to her classmates on construction paper. She painstakingly copied from her class list the names that she had come to cherish: Maggie, Jeremy, Allegra, Max, Camille -- children she has known for half of her sweet, short life. Though the lettering was crude and sometimes backward, the feelings were forthright and true: "DEAR MAGGIE, I LOVE YOU. REBECCA R."

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the awarding of the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine to three scientists, including Dr. Eric F. Wieschaus, misidentified the university where he was an undergraduate. It was Notre Dame, not Yale. (He did graduate study at Yale.)

title: VIACOM TO TEST PHONE SERVICE ON CABLE SYSTEM
description: Viacom Cable, a unit of Viacom Inc., said yesterday that it would test a system to route phone calls through cable television lines to residences in Castro Valley, Calif., just east of San Francisco. The trial is scheduled to begin on Jan. 1, 1996, and follows the company's filing last month to become a competitive local telephone carrier. The test of the system will the first for Viacom. Tele-Communications Inc. and Time Warner Inc. are already conducting tests of cable delivery of phone services. Viacom Cable controls about 50 percent of the cable business in the San Francisco Bay area and has more than 600,000 cable subscribers throughout the state.

title: OLYMPICS;Test Said to Detect Growth Hormone
description: After years of research, a Swiss medical team says it has finally developed a reliable test to detect human growth hormone, long believed to be the performance-enhancing drug of choice by many athletes, especially in track and field and weight lifting.

title: Chief of I.B.M.'s Lotus Resigns 99 Days After Takeover Deal
description: How long is the long haul?

title: All 36 of Pataki's Nominees Confirmed by State Senate
description: The State Senate today confirmed 36 of Gov. George E. Pataki's nominees -- many of them his political supporters and campaign contributors -- to an assortment of posts, rejecting none.

NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: Teleflex Inc.(TFX,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 24
TRANSITION IN THE SCHOOLS: THE PAST;A Discreet Final Day for Cortines
description: Early Tuesday morning, senior administrators at the Board of Education gathered in a 10th-floor conference room to bid farewell to Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines over bagels and Danish. But the Chancellor never showed up. Instead, he was spending the morning of his last day much as he began his administration in September 1993: touring schools and talking with children and teachers.

title: Network Equipment Tech.  (NWK,N) reports earnings for 2d qtr to Sept 24
THEATER REVIEW;Priestley Crosses the Sea and Becomes Mamet
description: Taking J. B. Priestley's 1933 psychological drawing-room comedy, "Dangerous Corner," which is very English, David Mamet, the playwright and director, who is very American, has conceived his own distinctive variation, also called "Dangerous Corner." The result of this collaboration across sea and time is something quite special and unexpected. It's both a rewarding theater exercise and a fascinating example of drama deconstruction: aware, appreciative and rock hard.

title: Seagate Technology Inc.(SEG,N) reports earnings for 1st qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Included $ 43 million in write-offs of in-process research and development.

title: Sports of The Times;Higher-Priced Views Of Same Knick Cast
description: THE suddenly loquacious Patrick Ewing is the only Knick these days who seems capable of speaking the whole truth, and nothing but. Ewing may be stating the obvious, but that's a whole lot better than the Knicks' organization, which is trying to convince us that there is no more "York" in New York Knicks.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Chrysler Posts Drop in Profit As Kerkorian Hones Attack
description: As Kirk Kerkorian turned up the heat on the Chrysler Corporation today by accusing it of complacency and highhandedness toward shareholders, the company reported sharply lower earnings for the third quarter, citing the costs of introducing new mini-vans and of priming a reluctant market with rebates.

title: TRANSITION IN THE SCHOOLS: THE CRITICS;Training Program Raised Conflict-of-Interest Issue
description: Two years ago, Rudolph F. Crew persuaded the Tacoma, Wash., school district to spend $1.6 million on motivational training for its teachers and staff members. At Dr. Crew's urging, the school district hired the Efficacy Institute of Lexington, Mass., to conduct the training.

title: Ornda Healthcorp (ORND,NNM) reports earnings for 4th qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss, which included charges of $ 35,511,000, or 82 cents a share, on the sale of hospitals, and $ 4,105,000, or 9 cents a share, related to debt financing. Earnings before the items were 25 cents a share in the quarter.The year included charges of $ 77.8 million, or $ 2.05 a share, on the sale of hospitals, merger expenses and special executive compensation, and $ 12.3 million, or 32 cents a share, on debt extinguishment. Earnings before the items were 73 cents a share.(Loss)The company said its fiscal 1994 results included the results of American Healthcare Management, with which the company merged on April 19, 1994 in a pooling-of-interests. The results of Summit Health Ltd., also acquired on April 19, but accounted for as a purchase, have been included in the company's operations since the merger date.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Forty-three years ago, KIM HUNTER played one of the two schoolteachers whose lives are destroyed by a child's false allegation of lesbianism in the play "The Children's Hour." Tonight, Ms. Hunter, who starred with Patricia Neal in the 1952 Broadway version of the Lillian Hellman play, opens in it again, this time in a 12-performance run at the Connecticut Repertory Theater at the University of Connecticut in Storrs.

title: Simpson Cancels TV Interview, But Talks of Life Since Verdict
description: In his first detailed interview since his acquittal on murder charges last week, O. J. Simpson said yesterday that he had pulled out of a television interview with NBC News, scheduled for last night, because his lawyers had convinced him that answering questions about the case might make it more difficult to defend himself against civil suits that he still faces.

title: Children's Software for Navigating Tropics and Alphabet;Discovering the living delights of a rain forest
description: FOR many children, the Amazon and its rain forest have become familiar turf, the subject of nature programs on television, classroom discussions and books. Three new pieces of software try to satisfy their curiosity through vivid colors, lush sounds and multimedia power, and two of them succeed admirably.

title: Hunting's Not Answer For Bear Nuisances
description: To the Editor:

title: SGS-Thomson Microelectronics NV(STM,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
Not Just for Show: A House Drops the Act
description: DESIGNER show houses are typically convention writ large. Lush and bland, they are triumphs of advertising over artistry, cavalcades of plutocratic fantasies -- English country, French palatial, Park Avenue posh -- tricked out in the latest $150-a-yard fabrics and the trendiest, costliest antiques. They are also, admittedly, a boon to charities, which benefit from the entrance fees. Unfortunately, these pretty diversions rarely advance the cause of design.

title:
OLYMPICS;
Atlanta Officials Resolve Budget Issue
description: Atlanta Olympic officials declared today that their long battle over the 1996 Summer Games budget was over and that the money had been found to present what they have called "the best Olympic Games ever."

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants Bench Corey Miller On Odd Day
description: The day began when Coach Dan Reeves walked into the Giants' weight room and pulled the linebackers into a small meeting room for one-on-one talks. Just about each starter got a lecture that basically said: "Play better, or you won't be playing at all."

title: Within the Foster-Care System, a Bewildering Paradox
description: AT 17, Jessica Lopez is not officially responsible for herself, but she is responsible for her year-old son, Tareek Kirkland. Because she is a child of foster care, her custody lies with New York City's Child Welfare Administration. But her son's custody lies with her.

title: I-287 Ahead of Schedule
description: Drivers who have been fuming since spring because of construction on a five-mile stretch of Interstate 287 northbound in Morris County will get relief in December. A road-widening project from Maple Avenue in Bernards Township to South Street in Morristown will be completed six months ahead of schedule, State Senator Gordon MacInnes, Democrat of Morris Township, said yesterday.

title: Chrysler Financial Corp. reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
description: Chrysler Financial is a unit of the Chrysler Corp.

title: G.O.P. Candidates Try to Raise Voices Above Dole's in TV Forum
description: In the first nationally televised forum of the 1996 campaign, Senator Bob Dole sought tonight to reaffirm his conservative credentials while his nine rivals struggled to emerge from his shadow.

title: Fisons Tells Holders to Take Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Bid
description: Fisons P.L.C. surrendered yesterday to a hostile takeover bid by Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, the big French-American drug company. Fisons advised its shareholders to accept Rhone-Poulenc Rorer's latest offer of $2.89 billion.

title: Ryan's Family Steak Houses Inc.(RYAN,NNM) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 27
PLAYOFFS '95;Looking to '96 Season, Steinbrenner Sees Leaner Yankee Payroll
description: The Yankees will be a younger group in 1996, and George Steinbrenner also wants them to be restless. They will be cheaper, and Steinbrenner might want them to be Buck-less. They will feature some new faces and hope next season is boundless.

title: College Letters for Students Used as Chips in Labor Dispute
description: In their final year at Verona High School, Todd P. Piro and Nicole R. Savino push themselves through merciless schedules in the hope of getting into the most competitive colleges in the United States.

title: Arabs Joyous As Israelis Quit Hot Spot
description: Jubilant Palestinians fired pistols into the air and mobbed a vacated army base today minutes after the last Israeli soldier left this town, a militant stronghold of anti-Israeli resistance during a seven-year uprising in the occupied territories.

title: Amazon Is Burning Again, as Furiously as Ever
description: Three years after Brazil was host to the Earth Summit, shepherding ambitious international accords on biodiversity and climate change, burnings in the Amazon region appear to be approaching the worst levels ever, while information on the country's most explosive ecological issue -- the extent of forest clearing in the Amazon -- has virtually dried up.

title: Eleanor Aller, 78, A Cellist and Part Of a Musical Family
description: Eleanor Aller Slatkin, a cellist admired in her own right and as part of a celebrated musical family, died yesterday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. She was 78.

title: Article 198895 -- No Title
description: The stretch of Irving Place from 17th Street to 19th Street has become a regular restaurant row. People cross from one side of Irving Place to the other to read menus that range from the venerable Sal Anthony's to the homey Friend of a Farmer to the trendy new Verbena. Indecision is perhaps greatest in trying to select one of the three Japanese restaurants in the vicinity.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day last Friday, with an article about recent problems at Apple Computer Inc., misstated the name of an Apple hand-held computer. It is the Newton Messagepad, not the Newton Thinkpad.

title: Japanese Wins Bernstein Competition
description: Yutaka Sado, a 35-year-old conductor from Japan, was declared the winner of the first Leonard Bernstein Jerusalem International Music Competition today. Mr. Sado, a native of Kyoto, was chosen over 16 other finalists. The Leonard Bernstein Jerusalem competitions focus on different aspects of music each year. Next year's will be for composers, followed by singers. The winner receives a prize of $25,000.

title: Gingrich Calls Whitman a Pioneer Tax-Cutter
description: House Speaker Newt Gingrich journeyed by helicopter from Washington this evening to praise New Jersey as the cradle of the Republican revolution in Washington and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman as a pioneer in the party's tax-cutting and government-trimming policies.

title: Data Recorder Malfunctions In Spacecraft
description: Engineers have discovered an apparent malfunction in the tape recorder aboard the Galileo spacecraft that could greatly reduce the return of data from its exploration of Jupiter, a mission official said today.

description: Chris Wilder Roger Merians Gallery 76 Greene Street SoHo Through Oct. 21

title: Devils, Authority Request Extension
description: The Devils don't have a deal yet for a 12-year lease at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. Along with their landlords, they are requesting that today's deadline for signing a new agreement be postponed while they continue to talk.

description: Faced with an uphill battle to win legislative approval for a casino in Bridgeport, Gov. John G. Rowland today started using the tool that so often wins votes: He began promising people money.

title: Abroad at Home; Racist Chic
description: Two years ago Ruth Shalit, a writer for The New Republic, heard that Harvard Law School had bent its rules to favor a black professor. She was told that a law review article of his, required for tenure, had actually been written by the review's student editors.

description: To the Editor:

title: George Osterman; Playwright Was 42
description: George Osterman, an actor and playwright best known for his work with the Ridiculous Theatrical Company, died on Tuesday in Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan. He was 42 and lived in Manhattan.

description: b-Included gain of $ 2.2 million, or 5 cents a share, from the sale of Systems Control Inc.

title: 10,000 Gather to Mourn a Firefighter Who Died Too Young
description: Firefighter Peter McLaughlin returned today to this village of rolling streets and hillocks on Long Island's North Shore -- the place where he raced along the beach as a boy, was confirmed by his parish pastor and once tacked a composition on his bedroom wall declaring that one day he would be a Marine and a firefighter.

description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Texas Instruments' Earnings Inspire Technology Rally
description: Texas Instruments Inc., proving to skittish investors that what goes up can stay up, reported today that its third-quarter earnings jumped 55 percent on soaring demand for computer chips around the world.

An African Nation's Path to Democracy Takes a Detour
description: When Henri Konan Bedie succeeded this country's founding father, Felix Houphouet-Boigny, as President two years ago, many Ivoirians thought that their country, already the region's most stable and prosperous, would soon also rank among the most democratic.

title: North Fork Bancorp (NFB,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago quarter was restated to include Metro Bancshares Inc., which was acquired in a pooling-of-interests transaction on Nov. 30, 1994.

title: Sports of The Times; On Leaving Well Enough Alone
description: OF the 1,001 things George Steinbrenner has never understood about baseball, the most obvious is that he doesn't know how to leave well enough alone.

title: INSIDE
description: In Death, Nicole Simpson Counters Domestic Violence

title: It's All Semi-Permanent (Just Passing Through)
description: The New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo might be called the flower child of New York museums. Founded in 1977, it emerged in the wake of the counterculture's heady ferment, when institutions of all kinds were suspect and artists were abandoning traditional art objects for more dematerialized zones of endeavor like video, installation and performance art.

title: A Lothario Meets His Match
description: Kit (Bruce Ramsey), the Elvis-worshiping teen-ager who generates most of the laughs in Adam Dubov's twisted comic spoof, "Dead Beat," is a junior Don Juan who will stop at nothing to make a conquest. Preparing for a date, he spends hours in front of the mirror slicking back unruly strands in his oversized pompadour and daubing on thick Elvis-style eye makeup. Kit has never been known to remove his boots, which elevate him several inches up to average height.

title: Kenyan Woman to Defend New York Title
description: Kenya's TEGLA LOROUPE, the youngest female winner of the New York City Marathon, will try to become the first female repeat champion since GRETE WAITZ won five straight from 1982-86.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Star Perils

title: Scripps (E.W.) Co.(SSP,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
Diner's Journal
description: They sell caipirinha by the pitcher at Riodizio, which may be why so many people seem to be having so much fun at this attractive new restaurant next to the Joseph Papp Public Theater. The national drink of Brazil is a potent blend of limes, sugar and cachaca, the sugar-cane liquor. But you can't blame it all on the booze: the food's a lot of fun, too.

title: For Some, Midnight Madness Isn't So Maddening
description: The clocks will start ticking on campuses from coast to coast late tomorrow evening, when the magic date for college basketball players, coaches and fans -- Oct. 15 -- falls on the best possible day. From as far away as Pauley Pavilion at U.C.L.A., where the defending national champion Bruins will celebrate the first Midnight Madness in school history, a season that will end next April at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena in New Jersey will have a loud, unofficial beginning.

title: Georgia-Pacific Corp.(GP,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
Society Caterer Hires More Men, Waitress Says In a Bias Suit
description: It is no secret in New York City's elite social circles that many of the poshest private parties feature only male waiters in a kind of modern-day outgrowth of a butler culture.

title: About a Woman on the Verge Of a Personal Meltdown
description: Pedro Almodovar seems to have been under a black cloud for the past few years, turning out movies like the relentlessly mean-spirited "Kika" and the often bitter "High Heels." What a relief that he has finally cheered up. In his new film, "The Flower of My Secret," he returns to the mordant but sympathetic comedy of his early, best work. Though the new film is not as antic as "Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown," it is funny and free of the nasty undertone that has made him seem tired and tiresome lately. The film will be shown at the New York Film Festival tonight at 9 and tomorrow at 11 A.M., and will open in theaters in March.

title: ARTS IN REVIEW
description: Judy Linn Feature Gallery 67 Greene Street SoHo Through tomorrow

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the growing business in archival film misstated when a documentary, "Villa and Pershing," will appear on the Discovery Channel. It will be shown as part of the "Rivals!" series today and tomorrow.

title: An A-Plus Woman, Downbeat and Feeling Stranded
description: Sunday on TNT, Wendy Wasserstein's prize-winning "Heidi Chronicles" comes to television with a somewhat more downbeat spin than the play when it opened at Playwrights Horizons in 1988 and moved to Broadway the next year. As Ms. Wasserstein also wrote the teleplay, the shift is presumably intentional. Times and writers do change. The play's wit remains intact, but now it seems more pointed, less tolerant of fools, even if they happen to be best friends.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Newark Mayor Fined $44,000
description: Mayor Sharpe James has been fined $44,000 for turning a charitable group that he founded into a political fund-raising arm and failing to disclose how its money was gathered or spent, said Frederick Herrmann, executive director of the New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission.

title: Strengthening in Stocks Continues, With Dow Rising 29.63
description: The stock market moved up strongly for the second straight day, as a sharp decline in interest rates helped to reinforce expectations of lower inflation.

title: Sincerest Flattery: Imitations and Rembrandt
description: WITH its marquee name not once but twice in its title, "Rembrandt/Not Rembrandt" at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is attracting the expected crowds. Never mind that it is a show about a largely technical business: deciding which paintings in the museum's collection Rembrandt painted and which ones he did not. For years now, the debate over his works has captured the imagination of a public that does not ordinarily seem to care much about such disputes. Scholars are always reattributing works that have big names attached to them, but the same ballyhoo rarely attends the announcement that a Rubens, say, is really a Theodoor van Thulden.

title: Polygram Venezuela Deal
description: The Dutch entertainment company Polygram N.V. has agreed to acquire Rodven Records of Venezuela for $57 million. Polygram said the acquisition would raise its share of the $2-billion-a-year Latin American music market to 16 percent from 13.5 percent. The purchase will also double Polygram's share of the Latino-music market in the United States.

title: SPS OFFERS TO BUY HI-SHEAR FOR $50 MILLION
description: SPS Technologies Inc. offered yesterday to buy Hi-Shear Industries for $50 million, bettering a bid that the unprofitable company agreed to last week with GFI Industries S.A. SPS, a fastener maker, said it topped GFI's $46 million offer because Hi-Shear would give it some attractive proprietary properties. SPS did not announce a per-share price for its offer, but Hi-Shear has reported it has almost 5.9 million shares outstanding, giving the offer an indicated value of about $8.50 a share. The stock closed yesterday at $7.375, up 62.5 cents a share.

A Magnet Whom Men And Misery Can't Resist
description: When Bella Ford (Embeth Davidtz), an English Victorian woman in deep trouble, arrives on foot and exhausted in a grimy industrial town, the place is a soot-stained tintype of Dickensian shabbiness. Here is where she believes the man who impregnated and abandoned her resides. With its ugly brick factories and cobblestone streets littered with horse manure, the town is so forbidding that it projects a palpably ominous presence in "Feast of July," even when it is subsequently shown in more flattering light.

title: CIT Group Holdings Inc. reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
description: CIT Group Holdings is based in New York and is 60 percent owned by Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd. and 40 percent owned by the Chemical Banking Corporation.

title: Follow the Leader
description: In September 1993, Arnold P. Cohen arrived in Eldersburg, Md., as chief executive of the London Fog Corporation, the raincoat maker. He soon announced that he was closing the company's five plants there, moving production overseas and the headquarters to Darien, Conn.

title: In America; In Deep Denial
description: Some of the women who had dared to fight back against the exploitative maquiladora factory system that helps sustain the profits of large apparel companies like the Gap and Liz Claiborne met last week in a small room in a decrepit building in downtown San Salvador. Some had their babies with them.

title: International Briefs; GE Capital Bids For Sovac of France
description: The GE Capital Corporation said yesterday that it had bid to acquire Sovac, a French consumer business credit company, for 610 francs, or about $123, a share. A GE Capital spokesman would not disclose the total amount of the offer but a French newspaper report valued the bid at 7.7 billion francs, or about $1.55 billion.

title: Home Video
description: On Tuesday, the romantic comedy "While You Were Sleeping," starring Sandra Bullock, will be available for rental in video stores. These days dealers complain about a shortage of hits, so a big title like this one, which took in about $81 million at the box office, is welcome. Paradoxically, though, it can also cause problems.

title: Star Banc Corp.(STB,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
description: Star Banc attributed its improved earnings in the latest third quater to increases in net interest income, higher fee income and diligent expense control. description: With one Navy officer who had been awaiting promotion to admiral already being court-martialed on charges of sexual harassment, the promotions of two others to admiral's rank have now been killed as a result of similar episodes.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Turner Said to Defend Milken's Advisory Fee
description: Ted Turner, the chairman of Turner Broadcasting System, acknowledged at an investment conference on Wednesday that huge sums would be at stake for himself and others in the planned acquisition of his company by Time Warner Inc. But he defended the tens of millions of dollars that are to be paid to his friend, Michael R. Milken, for advising on the takeover, people who attended the conference said yesterday.

description: Two members of what prosecutors described as a south Florida gang with anti-Government sentiments were arrested early Wednesday in West New York with a cache of weapons, including two loaded assault rifles and a shotgun. Five others, including a teenage girl, were also arrested.

description: The AT&T Corporation, in its first concrete step toward splitting itself into three companies, named one of its top executives yesterday to run the core communication company and a surprise outsider to head the $20 billion equipment business that will be spun off next year.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Allmerica Financial Corp., Worcester, Mass., is selling $200 million of senior notes due in 2025 through Merrill Lynch & Co. The notes are priced at 99.73 to yield 7.648 percent. The issue is rated A2 by Moody's Investors Service, A- by Standard & Poor's and A+ by Duff & Phelps.

title: How a Boy Grew Into the Man He Became
description: At the end of John Kelly's "Constant Stranger," people may disagree about whether they were drawn into Mr. Kelly's mind or he stepped into theirs. Either way, the effect of this unusually intimate performance piece, which combines dance, song and monologue, is at once amusing, unsettling and moving. Taking the many meanings of "constant" into account, the performer sees the stranger of the title as himself, but viewers are likely to think he means them. He may.

title: Mirage Resorts Inc.(MIR,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 2,773,000, or 3 cents a share, on early retirement of debt.

title: RUSSELL SHARES DROP 10% ON PROFIT ESTIMATE
description: The shares of the Russell Corporation fell 10 percent yesterday, a day after the company, an athletic-wear maker, said its report on third-quarter earnings would be 50 percent below the comparable period a year earlier. Russell, based in Alexander City, Ala., said sales would be up 5 percent for the period, but its profit margins had been hurt by competitive pricing pressures and higher costs for raw materials. In the quarter a year earlier, Russell earned $24.2 million, or 60 cents a share, on sales of $317.1 million. Russell's shares were down $2.75, to $23.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

description: The share earnings reflected the March 1995 3-for-2 common split and the September 1995 2-for-1 common stock split.

title: Shortchanging Inmates on Death Row
description: In their zeal to limit death penalty appeals, both houses of Congress have approved legislation that is apt to have the perverse effect of dragging out appeals and increasing their cost to the taxpayer. Worse yet, the legislation will increase the chance that innocent defendants, or defendants whose trials were constitutionally flawed, will be executed.

title: But What if Butch and Sundance Had Kissed at the End?
description: The basis for "The Celluloid Closet" is Vito Russo's invaluable 1981 book examining the patterns in Hollywood's treatment of gay characters on screen. What a shame that Russo, who died of AIDS in 1990, never saw his research transformed so skillfully by Rob Epstein and Jeffrey Friedman, whose other credits include the Oscar-winning "Times of Harvey Milk" and "Common Threads: Stories From the Quilt," into such a funny and informative documentary using the film clips he could only describe on the page. Celebrity interviewees and glossy graphics further turn this into a colorful overview with the popular appeal of a "That's Entertainment!" and with an even more interestingly gay agenda than the history of Hollywood musical comedy. "The Celluloid Closet" ranges from obscure film clips -- two men dancing together a hundred years ago in an experimental film of Thomas Edison's -- to scenes that are eminently familiar.

title:

description: ON KILLING The Psychological Cost of Learning to Kill in War and Society 367 pages. Little, Brown. $24.95.

description: During the last three and a half years, the Brkonic family could look about and count their blessings. Not a child had been killed, and their apartment had survived the war without a scratch.

description: The road to -- and from -- opening night was fraught with mishaps for the Paul Taylor Dance Company this week.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Memorial for Revolution's Poet
description: Philip Freneau (1752-1832) is known as the Poet of the American Revolution, or, sometimes, as the Father of American Prose. Yet Freneau, a roommate of James Madison's at Princeton, doesn't have a rest stop named for him on the New Jersey Turnpike, and the site of his home is currently occupied by an 18th Century-style shopping center.

description: A 32-year-old woman told the police that she had been sexually assaulted by a man in Central Park Wednesday night, officials said.

title: BRE PROPERTIES TO BUY REIT OF CALIFORNIA
description: BRE Properties Inc. has agreed to acquire Real Estate Investment Trust of California for stock and debt totaling about $266 million based on BRE's closing stock price on Wednesday. The company said late on Wednesday that it would exchange 0.57 of a BRE share for each share of REIT of California, totaling about $178 million. BRE will also assume about $88 million in REIT of California's debt. BRE, based in San Francisco, and REIT of California, based in Los Angeles, both are REIT's that specialize in apartment complexes in the Western United States. REIT of California's stock was up $1.375, at $17.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. BRE's stock rose 12.5 cents, to $33.50.

title: The G.O.P.'s Costly Electricity
description: If Congress has its way, the Government will no longer be able to push manufacturers to make more energy-efficient appliances -- a change that will rob consumers of billions of dollars of energy savings, and hurt the environment. Because of efficiency standards, today's typical refrigerator consumes two-thirds less electricity than one sold 20 years ago -- and is larger and has more features. The latest air-conditioners and furnaces consume less energy than ever before.

title: Cash Needed For Investing, Chrysler Says
description: To rally support against Kirk Kerkorian, the Chrysler Corporation has prepared a detailed defense for stockholders that illustrates how the company has broadened its justification for a $7.5 billion cash reserve, judging by a draft report of the presentation.

description: b-Included after-tax loss of about $ 4.5 million, or 7 cents a share, for the sale of its California newspaper subsidiary, the Times Advocate Company on July 28. Excluding the loss, primary net income in the latest quarter was 86 cents a share.The Tribune Company's share of QUNO's 1995 third quarter net income was $ 11.2 million, or 17 cents a share, compared with $ 3.9 million, or 6 cents a share, in 1994. The 1995 improvement was due to increased newsprint prices and higher sales volume, and offset slightly by a smaller foreign currency exchange gain.Tribune has a 34 percent equity interest in QUNO. QUNO's results are reported by Tribune in United States dollars under U.S. accounting principles, while QUNO reports its earnings in Canadian dollars under Canadian accounting principles.The results were after preferred dividends of $ 4.6 million in both the latest and year-ago third quarters.Revenue is total operating revenues.

The F.D.I.C. reduction added about $ 750,000 to net income in the quarter, the company said.

description: Though the combination of Linda Fiorentino, Chazz Palminteri and David Caruso promised "Jade" some fire, it winds up with no more spark than a doused campfire. That may be because the more significant threesome here is Robert Evans (producer), William Friedkin (director) and Joe Eszterhas (smut-obsessed screenwriter), joining forces to give some desperate kinks to an otherwise unremarkable mystery.

description: A bill designed to force health maintenance organizations to give consumers more fee and service information would cost businesses, individuals and the state more than $700 million, the New Jersey H.M.O. Association said yesterday.

description: Brian Williams of the Giants has quietly become one of the better centers in the league, even if few people have heard of him.

description: Petrie Retail Inc., a privately held women's apparel retailer formed last December by an investor group from the retail operations of the Petrie Stores Corporation, sought protection yesterday from its creditors in a bankruptcy-law filing.

title: Cloistered Japanese Banks
description: The recently disclosed trading loss of $1.1 billion at Daiwa Bank will not hasten the collapse of the bank itself. Nor will the losses seriously damage Japan's banking system or economy. But Japan's long delay in informing American regulators of a scandal involving the bank's New York branch has impaired the trust that was developing between the two countries on economic issues. The arrogant and clumsy way the matter was handled in Tokyo also raises doubts about the sincerity of Japan's promised effort to open up its economic system.

title: FORD INCREASES ITS DIVIDEND BY 13%
description: The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday that it had raised its quarterly dividend and that it would buy back $2 billion of preferred stock. The dividend was raised 13 percent, to 35 cents a share from 31 cents, giving it the highest stock yield of the Big Three auto makers. The company also said it planned to put two nonautomotive financial units up for sale. The auto maker said it was considering selling all of the USL Capital Corporation and a stake in the Associates Corporation of North America. The two commercial finance and leasing companies have total assets of $48 billion. The buyback plan would save $130 million in dividends, Ford said. Ford's share price gained $1.875 yesterday, to $31.875, on volume of 7.8 million shares.

title: Accounts
