TBWA Chiat/Day, Venice, Calif., a unit of the Omnicom Group, resigned the creative portion of the L.A. Gear account last week. The billings were not disclosed. Tristate BMW Advertising Association, Mount Kisco, N.Y., to DeWitt Media, New York, to handle the media portion of its account, previously handled by Ally & Gargano, New York, which is closing. DeWitt was also named to handle media duties for the Philadelphia dealers association. The billings were estimated at $5 million. The media assignment came after DeVito/Verdi, New York, was named to handle the creative portion of the account, also previously at Ally; DeVito/Verdi was also awarded the creative duties for the Philadelphia dealers account.

title: U.N.-Backed Drive to Restrict Land Mines Fails at Talks
description: An attempt sponsored by the United Nations to halt the spread of land mines, which kill or maim more than 20,000 people a year, has foundered because China and a handful of other countries refused to accept proposed restrictions on the manufacture and use of mines.

title: In Hip Brooklyn, Take 2 On That Old Cigar Store
description: When they finished shooting "Smoke," Paul Auster and Wayne Wang were in no hurry to pack up and go home. And Mr. Auster wasn't even far from home, since the Brooklyn Cigar Company, the Park Slope store in which much of "Smoke" was set, is part of the neighborhood in which he lives, the one "Smoke" observed so fondly. So they stayed in the store. They invited celebrities to drop by. They let the camera roll for long takes without interruption.

title: Executive Changes
description: ACC CORP., Rochester, named David Laniak chief executive, succeeding Robert T. Aab, who will continue as chairman. ASTROTECH INTERNATIONAL CORP., Pittsburgh, appointed T. Richard Mathews president and chief operating officer.

description: Amid trade rumors and following a bitter arbitration case, goaltender JOHN VANBIESBROUCK has agreed to a new three-year, $6.5 million contract with the Florida Panthers today.

description: The Paul Taylor Dance Company has revived two major works this season. Mr. Taylor's "Arden Court" from 1981 and his "Speaking in Tongues" from 1989 were performed on Wednesday evening at the City Center (131 West 55th Street), along with the comic "Funny Papers" from last year.

description: Dwight Gooden, seeking employment as a pitcher, visited Yankee Stadium today, but the fax from the Player Relations Committee that is expected to arrive at the offices of the 28 major league clubs Friday will halt such visits, at least for now. Gooden is not yet a Yankee. He is in baseball limbo.

title: International Briefs; Gartmore Shares Rise On Reports of Buyers
description: Shares of Gartmore P.L.C., a British fund manager, rose 4.3 percent yesterday as speculation mounted about who would buy the 75 percent stake in the firm held by Banque Indosuez. The shares are up 29 percent since Sept. 29, when Gartmore announced that Banque Indosuez sought a buyer for its stake.

title: CEASE-FIRE HOLDS IN MOST OF BOSNIA FOR THE FIRST DAY
description: Much of Bosnia remained calm today on the first day of the latest declared cease-fire, but the sounds of continued war boomed through this valley in the northwest, where Bosnian and Serbian forces have been battling for strategic territory over the last few weeks.

title: Dollar Is Weaker Amid Doubts About Central Banks' Intentions
description: The dollar was weaker yesterday as currency traders decided to test the leading central banks' commitment to a stronger dollar.

title: Producer Price Index Is Up, But Increase Is Discounted
description: The Labor Department reported today that prices paid to American producers rose in September by the biggest amount in eight months, but economists dismissed the jump as the result of only temporary factors and quirks, not accelerated inflation.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;J.P. Morgan's Third-Quarter Net Rose 10%
description: Posting its best results since 1993, J. P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that it earned $360 million in the third quarter, up 10 percent from the comparable period a year earlier.

title: Robert E. Hall, 70, Campaigner For Liberalized Abortion Laws
description: Robert Elliott Hall, a New York obstetrician and psychiatrist who helped lead the campaign that resulted in the 1970 New York State abortion statute, at that time the country's most liberal, died Oct. 6 in Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 70 and lived in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: 6 Guards in New Jersey Charged With Beating Jailed Immigrants
description: Six Union County corrections officers were arrested before dawn today on charges of beating and taunting illegal immigrants brought to their jail last June.

title: Bloomsbury's Many Kinds Of Love
description: "The world is rather tiresome, I must say -- everything at sixes and sevens -- ladies in love with buggers, and buggers in love with womanizers, and the price of coal going up too. Where will it all end?" So wrote Lytton Strachey in the mordantly arch, inexhaustibly witty voice that cast what is arguably the Bloomsbury group's longest shadow, since his influence has been social as well as literary.

title: Asian Volcano Said to Damage Red Sea Coral
description: A team of scientists in Israel has found evidence that a 1991 volcanic eruption in the Philippines severely damaged a coral reef under the Red Sea, some 6,000 miles away.

description: After more than a year of experimenting, the McDonald's Corporation and the Amoco Corporation have concluded that consumers like one-stop fill-ups for their gas tanks and stomachs.

title: 6 Companies Lose Control At Market
description: In its boldest move yet to break the Mafia's grip on the Fulton Fish Market, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's administration has decided to remove six companies that have long controlled the flow of fish into the market, officials said yesterday. It plans to replace them with a new company that has no experience in the seafood-distribution business.

title: Daiwa Scandal: As Serious a Question as Barings
description: When Barings P.L.C. collapsed last spring after a trader in Singapore lost more than $1.3 billion, some regulators and financial analysts worried out loud about a possible threat to the stability of the international financial system.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Latest Data On Economy Lift Bonds
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, as some investors decided that the latest economic reports meant the door was still open to another interest-rate cut by the Federal Reserve this year.

title: International Briefs; Texas Utilities Quit Norweb Bidding
description: Texas Energy Partners, jointly owned by Houston Industries and the Central and South West Corporation, said yesterday that it was withdrawing from a bidding war for the British regional electricity company Norweb P.L.C. Analysts had expected Texas Energy to back down from the first battle for one of Britain's 12 regional electricity companies, which were privatized in 1990, after a rival bidder, North West Water, raised its offer for Norweb to $:1.83 billion ($2.9 billion).

description: Setting up a showdown with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a group of Democratic political and educational leaders convened by Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver said today that they were not prepared to support legislation that would give the Mayor control over the school system.

title: Way Up in the Stands And Down on the Field, Reds Get Empty Feeling

Alan Sobba is director of tax and trade for the National Cattlemen's Association, not the Meat Importers Council of America.

title: Albany's Gift to the Police Union

title: A Giant Leap Backward
description: Now it's official. The Republican House plans to cut a total of $452 billion out of Medicare and Medicaid over the next seven years. Medicaid would lose $182 billion, even though it covers a disproportionately large number of children as well as elderly people who have spent themselves into destitution to qualify for it. Later this month, the measure is to be voted on as part of the budget reconciliation package, and Speaker Newt Gingrich plans to block a Presidential veto by forcing the country to the verge of default on our national debt. International markets await news of this potential disaster with thousands of pairs of hands poised over keyboards.

title: Corrections

title: CHRONICLE
description: BARRY SCHECK, one of the lawyers on O. J. Simpson's defense team, encountered some legal challenges of his own yesterday after a police officer spotted him making a U-turn on West 57th Street at 1 A.M. He received three summonses: one for the turn, one for driving with an expired license and one for having an improper car registration.

Honoring the 50th anniversary of Roberto Rossellini's great, ground-breaking films about the devastating effects of World War II, the Film Society of Lincoln Center will present newly restored prints of "Open City" (1945), "Paisan" (1946) and "Germany, Year Zero" (1947), which constitute his legendary war trilogy.

description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan gallery shows:

title: Wachovia Corp.(WB,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
description: Wachovia said the earnings increase for the latest third quarter reflected healthy gains in net interest income and other operating revenue as well as continued good expense management moderated by higher credit loss provisions.

title: Dole Puts Off Vote on Term-Limit Amendment
description: At the request of various supporters of term limits, including a majority of freshman senators, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas today postponed a scheduled vote on a Constitutional amendment to limit the terms of members of Congress.

title: DISPLEASURE AMONG ARCHER-DANIELS SHAREHOLDERS
description: Some large Archer-Daniels-Midland Company shareholders will vote against directors at next week's annual meeting, saying the board has not responded appropriately to a widening federal criminal investigation. New Jersey already sent in a proxy voting its 6 million shares against re-electing the 17 directors at the Oct. 19 meeting because "they haven't done their duty," said Roland Machold, director ofthe state's division of investment. The New York City Comptroller, Alan Hevesi, recommended yesterday that the city's funds, which hold 2.8 million shares, do the same. A final vote on that will come Monday.

title: GIULIANI IS DEFIED BY STATE SENATE OVER POLICE UNION
description: Defying Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the State Senate yesterday passed and sent to the Governor a bill that would effectively unravel one of the Mayor's proudest accomplishments: the merger of the housing and transit police forces into the New York City Police Department.

title: CHRONICLE
description: NICOLA PAONE is not normally one to make a big fuss, but he is marking his 80th year by singing on Friday evenings in the restaurant on East 34th Street that bears his name.

title: Weeks Shy of 53, Cordero Takes Another Turn at Belmont
description: For the first time in three years and eight months, the "overnight" sheet at Belmont Park yesterday listed this legendary name under the jockeys for tomorrow's races: Angel Cordero Jr. Not once, but five times.

title: Simpson Trial Undoes Progress by Police
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Colin Powell Can't Win as Independent; Paving the Way
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: Avis Rent a Car Picks an Agency
description: Avis Rent A Car System Inc. in Garden City, L.I., said yesterday that it had further expanded its relationship with Bates Worldwide by naming that agency to handle outbound advertising in Japan and Latin America -- that is, print campaigns aimed at potential customers traveling to the United States. The billings were not disclosed.

title: Taxation With Representation = Ball Park
description: Gov. TOMMY THOMPSON of Wisconsin signed legislation yesterday that provides financial help from taxpayers for a new $250 million stadium for the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Good Is Bad And Bad Is Good
description: Score, score, score. Win, win, win. The Devils are in a rut. They won the Stanley Cup last spring by finishing the playoffs with six consecutive victories.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Times Mirror to Eliminate 125 Jobs at Its Magazines
description: In the continuing shake-up at the Times Mirror Company, the magazine division announced yesterday that it would eliminate 125 of 611 jobs by the end of the year. The aim of the cost-cutting program, in addition to increasing profitability, is to decentralize corporate functions and give greater authority to the individual magazines.

title: Xerox Is Introducing a Line Of Digital Copier/Printers
description: The Xerox Corporation yesterday introduced the first of a new line of digital copier/printers that are designed to be connected to office computer networks.

title: Officers in Brooklyn Drug Case Acquitted of Rights Charges
description: Three New York City police officers were acquitted last night of charges that they violated the civil rights of Brooklyn residents and drug dealers by systematically stealing cash and drugs and making false arrests to gain overtime.

title: Vital Game for Mariners, So Johnson (Who Else?) Gets the Call
description: Randy Johnson and the Seattle Mariners are relatively new to baseball's post-season, but the American League's premier pitcher has already discovered its fringe benefits.

title: MOORE RAISES ITS BID FOR WALLACE COMPUTER
description: The Moore Corporation, based in Toronto, said yesterday that it had raised its offer to buy Wallace Computer Services Inc. by 7 percent, to $1.39 billion in cash, and moved up the bid's expiration date to Nov. 3. Moore had previously offered $1.3 billion for Wallace, which is based in Hillside, Ill. The earlier offer was to have expired Nov. 8. Wallace said it would review the sweetened bid over the next five business days. Both companies provide business forms and other information products and services. If shareholders do not turn over a significant percentage of Wallace shares by Nov. 3, Moore said, it will give up its hostile effort to acquire Wallace. Wallace's shares rose $2.25, to $58.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Official Is Selected to Insure Safety of U.S. Blood Supply
description: Responding to Congressional criticism and a report prepared last year by the National Academy of Sciences, the Secretary of Health and Human Services said yesterday that a top agency official was being designated as the Government's blood-safety director. That person will have overall responsibility for the nation's blood supply when there is a serious danger of its contamination.

title: Apology or No? U.S. and Japan Differ on Daiwa
description: Days after Japan acknowledged that it had failed to notify American banking authorities for six weeks after it learned of a $1.1 billion scandal at the Daiwa Bank in New York, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and his Japanese counterpart talked on the telephone on Wednesday to resolve their differences. But accounts of the conversation that emerged yesterday differed considerably.

title: Graf Case Transfixes Germans
description: Her father and her tax adviser sit in jail. She was grilled for eight hours last week by German tax officials. Her agent and a major sponsor are fighting with each other. She has dropped out of tournaments, emotionally drained and suffering from a back injury. There is endless speculation that she will leave professional tennis, move away from Germany or be arrested.

title: Sampling Imogen Cunningham's Vibrant Diversity
description: By the end of her long career, Imogen Cunningham had become one of the most colorful and revered figures in photography. Stooped and white-haired, with a camera around her neck, she was a familiar sight around San Francisco until her death in 1976 at the age of 93. To young photographers, she seemed the embodiment of the medium's rich history, and living proof of the important role women have played in it.

title: For the Jets, Training Is a Mistake
description: Mistakes, bobbles and, tellingly, penalties have conspired to mire the Jets in a 1-5 start. And unless they snap out of a funk that has led to 52 penalties (only 1 fewer than the league's most penalized team, the Pittsburgh Steelers), the Jets will continue to have problems Sunday against the Carolina Panthers.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Sybase's Profit Plunges 95% To $1.1 Million in 3d Quarter
description: Sybase Inc. said yesterday that its earnings fell 95 percent in the third quarter, far more than what Wall Street had expected.

title: On My Mind; Upwardly Mobile Bigotry
description: The Nation of Islam and the white-supremacist gangs are merely fringes of American society. Give the country a bit of time and they will be blown away by public distaste and boredom.

title: Restaurants
description: Rocco DiSpirito isn't a name you are likely to forget. But you are bound to be hearing a lot of it, because Mr. DiSpirito is turning out food so personal and intense you can't help asking, "Who's the chef?"

title: Hibernia Corp.(HIB,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
description: Hibernia said its third-quarter earnings were helped by a $ 3.6 million increase in net interest income and a $ 3.6 million reduction in F.D.I.C. insurance premiums. Hibernia said these items were partly offset by a $ 1.4 million accrual for an office automation project.Third-quarter earnings included $ 1.6 million in securities gains and a $ 16.1 million charge for the impairment of goodwill.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Frank Gohlke Bonni Benrubi Gallery 52 East 76th Street Manhattan Through tomorrow

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Coast Guard Center to Stay
description: Responding to pleas from New Jersey's congressional delegation, the Clinton Administration has decided to retain the Coast Guard Training Center in Cape May, United States Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, announced yesterday.

title: Fraud Ring Thrived Off Garbage, Authorities Say
description: Federal authorities announced today that they had smashed a sophisticated fraud ring that from its base here stole more than $10 million in dozens of states, at least partly by recovering discarded checks, deposit slips and credit-card receipts from Dumpsters and trash cans.

title: INSIDE
description: In Death, Nicole Simpson Counters Domestic Violence

title: STOP AND SHOP TO ACQUIRE MELMARKETS
description: The Stop and Shop Companies agreed yesterday to acquire Melmarkets Inc. in a transaction valued at about $87 million. Melmarkets operates 17 Foodtown supermarkets on Long Island and had 1994 sales of $386 million. Stop and Shop said it expected the deal to be completed later this year. The supermarket operator also said it expected to reach an agreement with the Federal Trade Commission and the Massachusetts Attorney General's office to complete the acquisition of Purity Supreme Inc. Stop and Shop expects to shed 17 stores in Massachusetts under the agreement. In April, Stop and Shop agreed to buy Purity Supreme, a supermarket operator, for about $255 million.

title: Queen of Emotion Surveys Her Career
description: Had Patti LuPone played Norma Desmond in the Broadway production of "Sunset Boulevard," at least one major song might have been performed as a ferocious mad scene, replete with sudden mood swings and a momentary spasm of tears.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: IMAGES OF THE COLD WAR IN ALBANY The Lieutenant Governor wandered around the Capitol in Albany, befuddled but determined, as she searched for the meeting the Assembly Speaker had convened to discuss the future of New York City's public schools. A group of Democratic political and educational leaders said that they were not prepared to support legislation that would give the Mayor control over the school system. Four days before officially taking over the New York City school system, Dr. Rudolph F. Crew partook in something that had eluded his predecessor: a friendly dinner at Gracie Mansion with Mayor Giuliani. SIX CORRECTIONS OFFICERS ARRESTED Six Union County, N.J., corrections officers were arrested before dawn on charges of beating and taunting illegal immigrants taken to their jail in June. SENATE VOTES TO UNDO POLICE MERGER Defying Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the State Senate passed and sent to the Governor a bill that would effectively unravel one of the Mayor's proudest accomplishments: the merger of the housing and transit police forces into the New York City Police Department. NEW YORK CITY FIREFIGHTER BURIED IN HIS HOMETOWN Firefighter Peter McLaughlin returned to Northport, a village of rolling streets and hillocks on Long Island's North Shore -- the place where he raced along the beach as a boy, was confirmed by his parish pastor and once tacked a composition on his bedroom wall declaring that one day he would be a Marine and a firefighter. THREE OFFICERS ACQUITTED IN DRUG CASE Three New York City police officers were acquitted of charges they stole cash and drugs from Brooklyn residents and drug dealers and made false arrests to gain overtime. SIX COMPANIES OUT AT FISH MARKET The Giuliani administration will remove six companies that have long controlled the flow of fish into the Fulton Fish Market. REGION STAGE IS SET FOR CASINO FIGHT Faced with an uphill battle to win legislative approval for a casino in Bridgeport, Conn., Gov. John G. Rowland started using the tool that so often wins votes: He began promising people money. PATAKI PLANS TO CUT STATE SPENDING With New York State facing a huge budget gap next year, Governor Pataki issued a plan to cut state spending by nearly $150 million through several belt-tightening measures. GINGRICH PRAISES WHITMAN AS TAX CUTTER House Speaker Newt Gingrich journeyed to Plainsboro, N.J., to praise New Jersey as the cradle of the Republican revolution in Washington and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman as a pioneer in the party's tax-cutting and government-trimming policies. THE GRAVEYARD VOTE WON'T HELP Donald Cresitello didn't expect much trouble in his race for the Town Council in Morristown, N.J. But the political reality shifted when Mr. Cresitello's Republican opponent died of a heart attack. Suddenly Mr. Cresitello is facing challenges he never dreamed of.

title: A Nobel Prize With Political Punch
description: As the anti-environmental tide courses through Congress and talk radio, even the most commonly accepted scientific wisdom is often debunked as scaremongering. Some conservative critics complain, for example, that the threat posed to the Earth's protective ozone layer by man-made chemicals has been grotesquely exaggerated and that the worldwide push to phase out ozone-eating chlorofluorocarbons should therefore be slowed. Just last month a House subcommittee held hearings on the "myths and realities" of the stratospheric ozone crisis, with a heavy emphasis on the supposed myths.

title: Unimpressed by '96 Flock, Some Voters Are in No Hurry
description: Tom and Evelyn Dinan stood in a drizzle outside this city's Center Square the other day trading names of prospective Presidents. But like many other voters here, they were more certain of whom they did not want in the White House than whom they wanted.

title: 3 More Qualify for WTA Championships
description: Almost half of the 16-player field of the WTA Championships has been set after three more players qualified this week. The three latest qualifiers are MARY PIERCE, the Australian Open champion; GABRIELA SABATINI, the defending champion, and KAMIKO DATE. They joined STEFFI GRAF and MONICA SELES, the co-No. 1 players, ARANTXA SANCHEZ VICARIO and CONCHITA MARTINEZ in the year-ending event, which will be held Nov. 13-19 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Student Loan Marketing Assn. (SLM,N) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
International Briefs; Opel Seeks Polish Plant
description: The General Motors Corporation's German unit, Adam Opel A.G., has offered to spend 400 million marks ($280 million) to build a car factory in Poland, but formal talks have not started. An Industry Ministry spokeswoman, Beata Nawracka, said yesterday that the ministry received a letter from Opel earlier this week on plans to invest in Poland to produce about 100,000 vehicles annually beginning in 1998. G.M. has apparently lost a race to take over Poland's state-owned car maker, FSO, to the Daewoo Motor Company of South Korea. (Reuters)

title: Jerry Jones Has An Ally In Fight Against the N.F.L.
description: The war between Paul Tagliabue's nation and Jerry Jones's breakaway republic escalated today on a second major front, drawing the sovereign players association into the conflict.

title: SFX to Buy 5 Stations
description: SFX Broadcasting Inc. said this week that it planned to buy five North Carolina radio stations and had an option to buy a sixth from an affiliate of Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. for a total price of $39 million. SFX, based in New York, will acquire WTRG-FM and WRDU-FM of Raleigh for $28 million, and WWWB-AM, WMFR-AM and WMAG-FM of Greensboro for $6 million.

title: Joseph F. Wall, 75; Wrote Biographies Of Business Leaders
description: Joseph Frazier Wall, who chronicled the lives of Andrew Carnegie and the du Ponts, died on Monday at Grinnell General Hospital in Grinnell, Iowa. He was 75 and lived in Grinnell.

title: Arafat Says Hamas Has Decided to Join in Palestinian Election
description: Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said today that the militant Islamic group Hamas had decided to take part in planned Palestinian elections in the West Bank and Gaza, although this was not confirmed by the movement itself.

title: Drought Along the Mohawk;Dairy Farmers May Have to Sell Parched Cows for Slaughter
description: All over the Northeast, state and local governments have declared various levels of drought watch, warning or emergency, but here, in an extraordinarily dry belt along the Mohawk River, people are facing disaster.

title: Two Looks at the Spell Picasso Cast on America
description: History is already chipping away at the sprawling edifice that was Pablo Picasso's career. And as his personal presence retreats ever further in time (he died in 1973), the unstinting output of more than 70 years gradually settles and takes a shape.

title: American Bridge Team Drops to Seventh Place
description: One of the four American teams here seems headed for elimination in the Marlboro World Bridge Championships.

title: Passion, Nudity, Puritans and, Oh, Yes, That Scarlet Letter 'A'
description: "God help me, Hester, I love thee!" declares the Rev. Arthur Dimmesdale, that passionate, skinny-dipping Puritan. "God help me, I love thee, too!" pants Hester Prynne, before melting into his arms, only to break away abruptly from their first kiss. "Nay! We could be hanged for this," she realizes. Hanging, in this case, is no deterrent. Hester and Arthur, played by Demi Moore and Gary Oldman as if they were in "The Red Shoe Diaries" instead of "The Scarlet Letter," are soon rolling around the barn on a pile of grain.

title: International Briefs; Ciba-Geigy Sales Fall
description: Ciba-Geigy A.G., the Swiss chemical and pharmaceutical company, said yesterday that sales in the nine months through Sept. 30 fell 4 percent, to 15.91 billion Swiss francs, or $13.76 billion, from the comparable period a year earlier. The decline was attributed primarily to the effect of the strong Swiss franc on currency exchanges. Excluding that effect, sales were up 5 percent, Ciba-Geigy said. For the full year, the Zurich-based concern said it expected further improvements in its profit from operations. Net income, it said, should also be higher. (Dow Jones)

title: OUR TOWNS;Joyless Rider Feeds a Habit in Newark
description: ON the evening the Pope and the President prayed in Newark, Larry P. scuttled his plans to steal a car.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Anderson & Lembke seeks global reach in its agreement to be acquired by the Interpublic Group.
description: IN an unexpected move, Anderson & Lembke, a fast-growing agency that specializes in business-to-business advertising for information-technology marketers, announced yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the Interpublic Group of Companies. The deal, the terms of which were not disclosed, is another example of the accelerating, seemingly relentless consolidation of the agency industry.

title: Ruth W. Lidz, 85, Yale Professor, Dies
description: Ruth Wilmanns Lidz, a clinical professor of psychiatry at the Yale University School of Medicine, died on Monday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. She was 85 and lived in Woodbridge, Conn.

But last month, in an attempt to bring the building full circle, sales began.

description: Pixar Inc., an animation company headed by the computer entrepreneur Steve Jobs, plans an initial public offering to raise as much as $84 million.

description: Just because the Yankee season is over doesn't mean that the Yankee fans' season is over. I am determined to enjoy the playoffs and the World Series despite Don Mattingly's absence; I am talking gut emotion here, not just inside baseball appreciation.

description: Paine Webber Group Inc., long considered a laggard among the nation's retail brokerage firms, surprised Wall Street yesterday by reporting that earnings in the third quarter more than tripled.

title: A Candidate the Graveyard Vote Won't Help
description: Donald Cresitello didn't expect much trouble in his race for the Town Council here. He won the Democratic primary handily in June. As a former Mayor and longtime councilman, he is well known in this community of 16,500.

description: COULD this be the democratization of one of the most rarefied art and antiques shows in America?

title: Peter Wisher, 84, Who Created a Dance Genre for the Deaf, Dies
description: Peter R. Wisher, a former Gallaudet University athletic coach who was so struck by the graceful flow of his students' sign language that he choreographed their hand movements into an acclaimed genre of dance for the deaf, died on Sunday at the Veterans Hospital in Washington. He was 84.

description: Four days before officially taking over the New York City school system, Dr. Rudolph F. Crew partook of something that had eluded his predecessor: a friendly dinner at Gracie Mansion with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: New York Makes Staying Put Irresistible to Coffee Exchange
description: Offering one of the most lucrative packages of subsidies ever provided in New York City, state and city officials persuaded the board of the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange yesterday to cancel plans to move the exchange to Jersey City, and instead to build a new trading center in Manhattan.

title: Richard A. Donnelly, Financial Writer, 64
description: Richard A. Donnelly, a former writer and editor for Barron's, died on Monday at his home in Navesink, N.J. He was 64.

description: Sales are net sales.

title:
COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
Stanford Coach Was Ready for Call
description: Want to hear a great college football story? Listen closely. If you do, it becomes clear why Tyrone Willingham, the surprise replacement for Bill Walsh, has quietly made Stanford into one of the surprise teams of the season.

title: Michigan State Sued
description: GEORGE PERLES, who was dismissed as Michigan State's football coach last November, is suing the university and its president, The Detroit News reported yesterday. A university spokesman, TERRY DENBOW, said he was not familiar with details of the lawsuit, but said he believes Perles is charging age discrimination, The News said. Perles, 61, was fired by the university's new president, PETER McPHERSON, following a 73-62-4 record in more than a decade as coach. Perles's contract called for the university to pay him a $211,179 annual salary to coach football. Perles made another $276,000 per year from broadcasting and endorsement contracts. Settlement negotiations apparently broke down over how much of that outside income the university may owe Perles, The News reported. (AP)

title: Red Sox Grab Pitcher
description: The Boston Red Sox have claimed right-hander JOHN THOBE on waivers from the Montreal Expos. Thobe, 24, made 55 relief appearances at Class AAA Ottawa last season, going 5-8 with a 3.27 earned run average. (AP)

title: Symbols of Exile Bloom in Jews' Yards;More Families Build Succahs as Ritual Reminder of Desert Huts
description: Chaya Munk was born at 9:10 P.M. 10 days ago at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. Her father, Ezriel Munk, was back at work before 10. No, Mr. Munk is not a night watchman or an investor who plays the Japanese stock market; he's in the prefabricated succah business, and it was the climax of the season in this ultimate niche market.

title: Regions Financial Corp.(RGBK,NNM) reports earnings for 3d qtr to Sept 30
description: Regions Financial said 1995 third-quarter earnings were benefited by a reduction in F.D.I.C. deposit insurance rates. The company said its strategy of ''steady'' internal growth, supplemented by acquisitions, continues to work ''well.''

title: Bridge
description: In a tense finish to qualifying play here today at the Marlboro World Championships, three of four American teams survived and will begin playoffs on Saturday.

title: Two Violinists Beat I.R.S.: Bows Are Tools, Not Art
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan decided yesterday in favor of two New York Philharmonic violinists, ruling that their rare antique bows were tools of the trade, not art objects, and could be depreciated on their Federal tax forms. The ruling was 2 to 1.

title: Dole Is Reopening Issue Of U.S. Embassy in Israel
description: Senator Bob Dole today reintroduced a bill to move the American Embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem by May 1999, but he dropped his earlier provision that groundbreaking should begin in 1996.

description: It may be forward of me to offer advice to O. J. Simpson. We are different in so many ways. He owns a Ferrari and a Bentley and until recently was kept freshly supplied with Ford Broncos by a large corporation.

At Boeing, a War Over Job Exodus
description: The last time production workers at the Boeing Company went on strike, in 1989, the issue was too much work. Turning out airplanes at the rate of nearly one a day, they said they were exhausted by forced overtime and wanted some relief.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 5 about unease in Hong Kong before the British colony's transfer to Chinese rule referred incorrectly to a Hong Kong television report -- cited in the article as an example of intimidation of the Hong Kong press. Reporting on a local rally in June to mark the anniversary of the 1989 crackdown on the pro-democracy movement in China, station TVB included the rally organizers' estimate that 30,000 demonstrators attended, as well as a police report that 16,000 attended; it did not assert that only 2,500 attended. TVB wrote to The Times in July about the error. A check of the station's transcript and videotape in Hong Kong was improperly delayed.

title: Black Women Are Split Over All-Male March on Washington
description: A handbill for a play by Judy Shepherd-King, which reopened this week in Harlem, features a drawing of a young black man's face framed by the cross hairs of a rifle's sight. It is a telling image. The 44-year-old Brooklyn playwright and educator says the theme of her drama, "Endangered Species," is the struggle of black men to survive in spite of an America that she says has targeted them for extinction.

description: A German court sentenced four young men to prison terms of 10 to 15 years today for an arson attack in 1993 that killed five Turkish women and girls from the same family in Solingen. It was the worst killing in a wave of rightist violence since Germany's reunification in 1990.

title: Kasparaitis Tells Isles He'll Skate By Himself
description: Darius Kasparaitis, who had been skating with the Islanders since the beginning of training camp even though he is a restricted free agent, informed the team before yesterday's practice in Syosset, L.I., that he will now work out on his own.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a damaged facade in Sarajevo misstated the sequence of events. The building was hit by a rocket-propelled grenade before the picture was taken, not afterward.

description: In percent

title: SYMS ENDING PLANS TO REPURCHASE ITS STOCK
description: The Syms Corporation said late yesterday that it was abandoning plans to buy back the company's stock. The company had previously announced that stockholders holding a majority of the shares proposed to buy the shares at $8.75 each. The stock of the company, an off-price apparel retail chain based in Secaucus, N.J., closed unchanged yesterday at $9.

title: Why I'm Marching in Washington
description: On Monday, maybe a million black men will march on Washington. Coming after the O.J. Simpson verdict, the march promises to be a pivotal moment in our nation's life. As the writer Greg Tate has rightly noted, the verdict "may represent the first time in history that a majority black jury has wielded an apparatus of state power against the will of the nation's white citizenry."

description: Jay Buhner walked up and down the dugout shaking his head and losing the battle against the tears that slipped forth after his three-run homer in the 11th inning. It was the same dugout that was silent when he appeared following a devastating error in the eighth that enabled the Indians to tie the score.

description: Carol A. Gresser, president of the Board of Education, said yesterday that she would welcome the appointment of a former police chief to lead the school system's security force, and added that the board would release its plan to revamp the much-criticized division in two weeks.

description: Any team that plays the Atlanta Braves in October must fear the little-used catcher.

title: Haiti's Prime Minister Resigns After Disputes Over Economy
description: Frustrated by his inability to gain the support of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide for economic reforms backed by the United States, the Prime Minister of Haiti has submitted his resignation, Haitian officials and foreign diplomats said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about efforts by the Kazakhstan Government to revive a huge oil project in the Tengiz oilfield misstated the composition of the Caspian Pipeline Consortium, which is seeking to build a pipeline from Tengiz to the West. It is made up of Russia, Kazakhstan and the Oman Oil Company. Amoco, Pennzoil, Unocal, Exxon and McDermott International are not members, but are part of a consortium of 11 companies that is seeking to export oil from offshore fields in the Caspian Sea that belong to Azerbaijan.

title: Editorial Notebook; A Royal Funeral
description: The photographs of the girls in their summer dresses, flitting like white butterflies across a broad lawn, or sitting with their parents and little brother for a family portrait, are haunting. But then all the photos of the Romanov family are haunting, especially those of the children. Four pretty girls, a sickly boy -- even if we did not know their fate, we would pause at their pictures. They all look so rich, so grand and so impossibly innocent.

Reporting on a local rally in June to mark the anniversary of the 1989 crackdown on the pro-democracy movement in China, station TVB included the rally organizers' estimate that 30,000 demonstrators attended, as well as a police report that 16,000 attended; it did not assert that only 2,500 attended.

title: The Plundering of Adelphi
description: Elite universities play an important role in American education. But even more important are the community and commuter schools that give students of modest means and modest learning a taste of higher education that often propels them to greater things. These institutions are an important national resource.

title: 'Mischief Night' Arson Watch
description: More than 2,000 volunteers have signed up to help the police patrol Camden again on Oct. 30, in what has become an annual "mischief night" campaign to scare off arsonists. City officials began the volunteer project after arsonists set more than 100 fires on Halloween Eve in 1991. Last year, there were four mischief night fires -- fewer than on an average night, the police said.

title: What Barnum Did Before The Three-Ring Circus
description: Step right up, folks, and have a gander at the bearded ladies, the midgets, the giants and the other "living curiosities" collected and celebrated by Phineas T. Barnum. "America's greatest showman," as the Discovery Channel's three-hour biography calls him, with more accuracy than some of his claims for his stars, is filled with pictures of the unfortunates who made his fortune.

description: Basketball National Basketball Association HOUSTON ROCKETS -- Released Tony Watson and Tremaine Wingfield, guards.

title: Study of Wife-Killing Trials Shows a Small Acquittal Rate
description: Only 2 percent of the men charged with killing their wives are acquitted at trial, according to a study of spousal murder cases resolved in 1988 in 75 of the nation's largest urban counties. The results of the study, released today by the Justice Department, seem to suggest that the verdict in the O. J. Simpson trial was an anomaly.

title: Cutting Class
description: This spring, my friend Shawn, a 10th grader failing all but one of his classes, smashed his book bag through a window at Seward Park High School, in downtown Manhattan, and threatened to beat up a teacher. One might expect the school system to do its all to change Shawn's ways. But unable to find a quick fix, it seems to have given up on him and on a lot of troubled students like him.

title: Does This Shoe Fit?; Reebok Marketing Ace Stamps His Style on Rockport
description: He dreamed up the aerobics shoe that made Reebok International the world's No. 2 athletic shoe company, with about 35 million pairs sold. He created lucrative markets for tennis, basketball, walking and fitness shoes and championed Reebok's identification with human-rights causes. He even persuaded Cybill Shepherd to wear bright orange Reeboks at the Emmy awards.

title: Denyce Graves, From the Choir to 'Carmen'
description: Before she made her Metropolitan Opera debut last Saturday in the title role of Bizet's "Carmen," Denyce Graves kept telling herself that the Met was simply another opera house. After all, she had already sung the role at the Vienna State Opera, at the Bastille Opera in Paris and at Covent Garden, 21 productions in the last two years alone.

title: BMW's $2 Million Paint Job

Dr. Gore, after all, was content with his luxury vehicle until he learned that the BMW he bought "new" had been repainted to cover undisclosed damage in shipping.

title: I.R.S. Examiner Is Arrested
description: An Internal Revenue Service tax examiner was arrested yesterday and charged with taking money from a taxpayer to assist in filing false returns, The Associated Press reported. Dolores Bailey, 42, was working in the I.R.S. office in Edison when she received $650 from an acquaintance whom she helped to file fraudulent returns, according to court papers. In all, the taxpayer received about $5,000 in unwarranted refunds for 1988, 1992 and 1993, the Federal complaint read. Ms. Bailey, who was released on $10,000 bail, could not be reached for comment.

title: Henry Roth Is Dead at 89; Wrote Novel 'Call It Sleep'
description: Henry Roth, who in 1934 wrote "Call It Sleep," a novel acclaimed as an American classic for its powerful portrayal of a Jewish immigrant boy struggling to survive in the slums of the Lower East Side, died yesterday at Lovelace Hospital in Albuquerque, N.M.

title: SYBASE SHARES GAIN ON PREDICTION OF REVENUE GROWTH
description: Shares of Sybase Inc. rose yesterday after the software company's executives told investors that they expected a coming product to sell well in the next few quarters. The rise occurred even though the company said late on Thursday that its third-quarter net income had fallen 95 percent, far more than Wall Street expected. But the company's executives said that a coming product, System 11, would fix shortcomings of the company's chief product and that they expected revenue growth to accelerate after the first quarter of next year, analysts who listened to a conference call said. Shares of Sybase, a software company based in Emeryville, Calif., were up $1.875, to $34, in Nasdaq trading of 9.1 million shares yesterday.

title: PP&L PLANNING TO CUT 11 PERCENT OF ITS WORK FORCE
description: PP&L Resources Inc. announced a big cost-cutting plan yesterday and said it planned to cut about 11 percent of its jobs in the next couple of years. The electric utility, which is the parent of the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company, plans to cut its work force to about 6,000, from its current staff of about 6,780, according to a company spokesman, Jim Marsh. The company said it would slash its capital expenses by $671 million in the next five years. About two-thirds of those savings will come from dropping a plan to install scrubbers at its Montour power plant in Pennsylvania. Scrubbers take sulfur dioxide out of a plant's exhaust emissions. The company also will reduce operation and maintenance costs by 8 percent, or $56 million, by the year 2000.

title: Journal;The Second Wind
description: No, O. J. Simpson did not show up to tell Tom Brokaw and Katie Couric exactly what he was doing when his wife and her friend were slaughtered. But his non-appearance on "Dateline NBC" was invaluable. The flurry of highly charged emotion that preceded and followed Mr. Simpson's misadventure in prime time says a lot about what is going on in America in the aftermath of the verdict of the century even if it added zilch to our knowledge about what happened in Brentwood on the night of June 12, 1994.

title: STARWOOD LODGING TO BUY TWO ATLANTA HOTELS
description: Starwood Lodging Trust and the Starwood Lodging Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire two hotels in Atlanta for $36.9 million. The real-estate investment trust and the hotel management company will acquire the 364-room Terrace Garden Inn for $27.9 million and the 180-room Lenox Inn for $9 million. The Starwood Lodging entities plan to renovate the hotels, which are adjacent to each other in the Buckhead area of Atlanta. The acquisitions are expected to be completed by the end of this month.

title: Assessing Both Sides in Tiananmen Square Massacre
description: Among the millions mesmerized by television coverage of the student uprising in Beijing six years ago, who can forget the image of a lone protester blocking the movement of a Chinese Army tank in the middle of Tiananmen Square? That heart-stopping moment of video is replayed in "The Gate of Heavenly Peace," Richard Gordon and Carma Hinton's enthralling documentary film of those events. But by the end of the three-hour movie, which the New York Film Festival is showing at Alice Tully Hall this evening at 8, the image is just a speck in the sprawling history and complex human drama surrounding it.

Court Backs Rutgers in Dismissal
description: A Federal jury decided yesterday that Rutgers University's dismissal of a tenured chemistry professor in 1988 did not violate his First Amendment rights. In a lawsuit, Professor Joseph San Filippo asserted that he had been fired because he spoke out against unsafe laboratory conditions and financial irregularities in the chemistry department. Rutgers said he had been fired for using lab technicians to do his yardwork. "I'm afraid it means the administration can target a faculty member for being a whistleblower or a gadfly and get away with it," Mary Gibson, president of the faculty union, said. The Rutgers general counsel, David R. Scott, said, "The jury verdict shows that there are limits to tenure."

title: Pinson Still in a Coma
description: The former major league outfielder VADA PINSON, unconscious since suffering a stroke, remained in a coma yesterday at Summit Medical Center in Oakland. Pinson, 57, whose last season was in 1975, was taken to the hospital Oct. 5 when his daughter found him in a coma at his Oakland home. Pinson played for St. Louis, Cleveland, California and Kansas City. (AP)

title: CARR-GOTTSTEIN SHARES SURGE ON BUYBACK REPORT

The company, a food and drug retailer based in Anchorage, said late on Thursday that it would buy back up to 7.5 million shares, or about 49 percent of its outstanding stock. The stock closed up $2.375, at $8.50 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: KEY GAMES OF TOP TEAMS No. 1 Florida (5-0) at No. 16 Auburn (4-1) In drubbing Mississippi State, Auburn got 274 yards passing from Patrick Nix and 162 rushing from Stephen Davis. It has upset Florida the last two years, but Florida should have too much now. No. 2 Ohio State (5-0) at No. 17 Wisconsin (2-1-1) Another big test for Ohio State, which faces one almost evey week. Last Saturday, the Buckeyes upset Penn State on Bobby Hoying's passing (24 of 35 for 354 yards), Eddie George's rushing (105 yards) and big plays. No. 4 Northwestern (4-1) at No. 19 Minnesota (3-1) For 23 years, Northwestern has averaged two victories a season. This year, it has beaten Notre Dame and Michigan. As Coach Gary Barnett said after the upset of Michigan, "I dream of those things, but it's hard to pull them off." No. 10 Tennessee (5-1) vs. No. 20 Alabama (4-1) at Birmingham, Ala. Peyton Manning should be the difference. In beating Arkansas, Tennessee's sophomore quarterback completed 35 of 46 passes for 384 yards and 4 touchdowns. EAST No. 11 Notre Dame (4-2) vs. Army (1-2-1) at East Rutherford, N.J. The Irish needed three big plays in the last three minutes to beat Washington. This should be easier, even with its two best tailbacks injured. Eastern Michigan (4-1) at No. 21 Syracuse (4-1) Although Syracuse's injured tailback, Malcolm Thomas, will not play, the Orangemen will be the toughest foe of the season for Eastern Michigan. This looks like a blowout. West Virginia (2-3) at Boston College (2-3) Boston College plays a tougher schedule than its Big East rival and moves the ball better (199 yards rushing against Pitt). It held Pitt to minus 11 yards rushing. Lafayette (1-3-1) at Princeton (4-0) Princeton can run the ball (132 yards a game for Mark Washington alone) and stop the run, allowing only 100.3 rushing yards a game. Lehigh (3-2) at Columbia (2-1-1) Columbia upset Penn with an opportunistic defense. Now it must stop the passing of Bob Aylsworth (21 of 31 for 291 yards in beating Bucknell). Dartmouth (2-2) at Yale (2-2) Dartmouth's defense is fine, and it can win unless its shaky offense keeps turning the red zone into a dread zone. MIDWEST Indiana (2-3) at No. 6 Iowa (4-0) Iowa should win, especially since Indiana's quarterback, Chris Dittoe, is out for two weeks with an injured knee. Penn State (3-2) at Purdue (2-2-1) This could be easy for Penn State, but the Nittany Lions are not the smooth powerhouse of last year. Iowa State (2-3) at No. 8 Kansas (5-0) Kansas by a ton. After Mark Williams had passed for 299 yards in a 40-24 upset of Colorado, he said, "We knew we would win, so it wasn't an upset." SOUTH No. 18 North Carolina (3-2) at Georgia Tech (3-2) Is Carolina really better than Virginia, its upset victim last week? Probably not. It should get tested here. Penn (3-1) at William & Mary (4-2) The Quakers's 24-game winning streak is over, and they face a buzzsaw in a stronger Division I-AA foe. Rutgers (1-3) at Miami (1-3) Two big disappointments in the Big East, but Miami has better prospects short range and long range. SOUTHWEST Texas (4-1) vs. No. 22 Oklahoma (4-1) at Dallas As usual, a nice matchup, with the edge to Oklahoma. Texas gave up 428 yards to a poor Rice team. No. 12 Kansas State (5-0) at Oklahoma State (1-4) Although Kansas State has been playing patsies, it has three straight shutouts and has allowed only six possessions inside its 20 yard line. FAR WEST Washington (3-2) at No. 15 Stanford (4-0-1) Stanford, a prospective doormat in the Pacific 10, is off to its best start since 9-0 in 1951. This should be a real test. Washington State (3-2) at No. 13 Southern California (5-0) Chad Davis of Washington State beat Oregon State, completing 21 of 28 passes for 274 yards and 3 touchdowns. Not this time. Arizona (3-2) at No. 24 U.C.L.A. (3-2) U.C.L.A. can pass. The last time out, its freshman quarterback, Cade McNown, went 18 for 22 for 274 yards and 3 touchdowns against Fresno State. MISMATCHES Missouri (2-3) at No. 5 Nebraska (5-0) Nebraska has won 16 straight from Missouri. The Huskers are six-touchdown favorites and may win by more. Wake Forest (1-5) at No. 7 Florida State (5-0) Florida State has won 12 straight, and Warrick Dunn is averaging 184 yards rushing. Look for a blowout by six or seven touchdowns. Rankings by The New York Times computer; all times Eastern.

description: THEY vaulted into office as outsiders spouting reform slogans and pledging to upset the liberal apple cart that has been big-city politics for most of this century. The very thought, at the time, seemed downright revolutionary: the Mayors of the nation's two largest cities, overwhelmingly Democratic cities to boot, were Republicans.

title: Carnegie Mansion Exposed, but Only Briefly
description: When Andrew Carnegie built his 64-room "chateau" on Fifth Avenue and East 91st Street in 1901, he probably never imagined that his residence would become a world-class art museum, although as one of the nation's greatest philanthropists, he would most likely be pleased to find the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum occupying his home.

title: INVESTING IT;For Investors, Rationed Facts May Replace Feast of Footnotes
description: TO many investors, they are a bore and a chore -- the footnotes that stud annual reports and sometimes seem to go on forever. Still, the notes speak volumes about the quality of a company's earnings. They also offer important clues as to whether a company is cooking its books.

title: Margaret Hart, Alan H. Oshiki
description: Margaret Alison Hart, a daughter of Sarah and Herbert B. Hart Jr. of Liverpool, N.Y., was married yesterday to Alan Hagestad Oshiki, a son of Jean and Kaz Oshiki of Banning, Calif. The Rev. Emily G. Holcombe performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Stamford, Conn.

title: Bringing Downtown Back Up
description: FOR the last 40 years, whenever lower Manhattan needed a shot in the arm, it came in the form of enormous new projects, each larger than the one before: Chase Manhattan Plaza in the 1950's, the World Trade Center in the 70's, Battery Park City in the 80's.

title: Trea Hoving and Colin D. Leventhal
description: Petrea Bell Hoving, the executive vice president of acquisitions and co-productions at Miramax Films in New York, is to be married today to Colin David Leventhal, the director of acquisition at Channel Four Television Corporation in London and a managing director of its film and television sales. The Rev. Stephen Chinlund, an Episcopal priest, is to officiate with Rabbi Roy Rosenberg at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.

title: Airport Terminal Isn't Finished but That Doesn't Spoil the Party
description: THE Police Emerald Society bagpipes played, the 319th Army Band from Fort Totten struck up the National Anthem and the pledge of allegiance was recited by a Civil Air Patrol cadet under brisk autumn skies as Westchester's long-delayed terminal was formally dedicated -- prematurely -- in a ceremony at the airport last Sunday.

title: Who Picks the Apples on Rainy Mondays?
description: FOR 22 years Renford Fagan has left his native Jamaica, his wife and 12 children and his own 12-acre farm to work at Bishop's Orchards in Guilford as a seasonal laborer.

title: Articulating Functions; LINES OF MODERN POETRY
description: SHAKER BUILDERS believed that once a design had been stripped to the essentials, it was then fitting to make it as beautiful as possible. For this house on eastern Long Island, the architects Peggy Deamer and Scott Phillips took inspiration from the Shaker canon -- natural light, symmetry and above all, simplicity -- then let loose their poetic imaginings.

title: Stuck in The Throat
description: Drugs are no good. Sex is dangerous. But rock-and-roll? Researchers at Wake Forest University recently conducted a study to see what sorts of singing are most damaging to the vocal cords. Rock won.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Sept. 17 about Montpelier, Vt., misidentified a pillared court building on State Street. It is the Washington County Superior Courthouse, not the Federal Courthouse.

title: Divine Solution to School Crowding
description: The new home of the Renaissance School in Astoria still bears a few obscure remnants of its past: fancy tiled bathrooms, for instance, and the shadow of a cross that once hung on the canary-colored wall of an empty second-floor classroom. For years, when this was a school run by the adjacent St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church, crosses hung on every wall and the Lord's Prayer could be heard in the hallways.

title: SUNDAY VIEW;Listen to 'Company,' Tune Out the Book
description: I SUPPOSE THERE'S NO POINT IN A musical's being a musical unless the songs are worth more than the script. The better scripts aim to be timely, the better scores aim to be timeless, and it's usually a nice arrangement. But when the story begins to work against the best interests of the score, an audience has every right to wish the two would split up and go their separate ways.

title: Character Development
description: IN THE ARENA An Autobiography. By Charlton Heston. Illustrated. 592 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $27.50 MOONLIGHT. The old family home, deserted-looking. The hero goes inside and walks through a dusty room. That's the shot. The director, William Wyler, keeps doing retakes, until the actor -- Charlton Heston, as Judah Ben-Hur -- says, "You have to give me a clue here." Wyler's method was to seek clues, not give them; the first take, he tells the actor, was ruined by a camera error but "your toe ticked into that broken pot on the steps" and made "the only sound in the shot, a good accent. I thought it might happen again." The actor sighs: "Willy, I put the damn pot there, just to try it. If you like it, it'll happen again, believe me. That's what you pay me for."

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;Videotapes That Tell the Harlem on Their Minds
description: Harlem Diary," a documentary film in which nine young people tell their life stories, is also the autobiography of a neighborhood, a Harlem that is a backdrop for tears, temptation and tragedy and, at times, nourishment. These young artists express ambivalence -- they want to leave Harlem but somehow they are drawn back to it.

title: Fame, Money, Lust, Murder, Lawyers. . .
description: The country not only talked about the trial, it was obsessed with it -- and not just for a day or two, but for week after week after week. This murder trial involving a glamourous celebrity seemed to crowd everything else out of the newspapers, which gleefully printed every detail they could get their hands on. There were so many reporters covering the trial that there was no room for the public in the courtroom. "The trial is being reported to the ends of the globe," observed The New York Times.

Instead, like others unfamiliar with Kansas City, she has been pleasantly surprised by its broad boulevards, bubbling fountains and Spanish architecture on the Country Club Plaza.

title: Civil Wars
description: NIGHTLINES By Neil Jordan. 194 pp. New York: Random House. $21. NEIL JORDAN -- the Irish director of such films as "Mona Lisa," "The Crying Game" and, more recently, "Interview With the Vampire" -- has written a novel. To some, this could not be more shocking than the news that Francis Ford Coppola had published his first collection of poetry ("The distant flutter of overhead choppers; / The flecks of foam on speckled surf; / The smell of napalm in the morning"). But it is no surprise to those who have had the good fortune to come across Mr. Jordan's fiction before. His well-received volume of short stories, "Night in Tunisia," was published in 1976. And he is also the author of two previous novels: "The Past," an ambitious family drama set against the Irish political upheavals of the 1930's, and "The Dream of a Beast," a fever dream of a book that took Joyce's Dublin and handed it over to Franz Kafka.

title: FILM VIEW;A Festival Of Much Art, Little Glitz
description: WHEN THE SCHEDULE FOR THIS YEAR'S New York Film Festival was announced, you could practically see and hear the reaction all over town: eyes rolling in disbelief and the best-informed cinephiles wondering, "Huh?" The advance word suggested that this was a bad year for festivals everywhere (look how drab Cannes was). Short on glitz, New York was reportedly crammed with featherweight works by familiar directors like Zhang Yimou, Manoel de Oliveira and Pedro Almodovar. It was, the predictions went, a series bound to leave viewers yawning and drowning in subtitles.

title: BOOKEND;At the Russian Newsstand: Suits, Sunglasses and Sex
description: OUR magazine," says Lev Gushchin, editor of the illustrated Moscow weekly Ogonyok (Little Flame), "is no longer aimed at the intelligentsia -- those people dedicated to the cause of Leninism, and whose exit from history will be a blessing for all concerned." An athletic-looking man in his early 50's whose photograph adorns the first page of each issue, Mr. Gushchin is enthusiastic about his new readers. They represent, he says, the "nascent middle class," whose guiding lights are "pragmatism, private property, capitalism and freedom of speech."

title: Word for Word/Cereal Boxes; Sold Not by Intellectual Weight But Lots of Volume
description: AH, those dewy, yawn-filled childhood morns at the breakfast table, when a glazed perusal of the cereal box during milky-sweet crunches of flakes was just the ritual to clear the brain's cobwebs for a new day of rascality. Such nostalgia powerfully stokes today's $8 billion market for breakfast cereal, which is eaten by an estimated 80 million adults, adolescents and children daily. It's not surprising, given such numbers, that the cereal box has become practically a metaphor for artifice and packaging in modern American life. Yet it's the stuff inside that usually gets all the publicity, especially from nutritional critics who say a lot of it is just vile, sweet, overpriced junk. They overlook cereal boxes' cultural value.

When young, he pushed "his explorations into sex, drugs," and had a lengthy affair that was one of "those delicate, lovely and exploratory romances that flourished like sensuous flowers on slender stems, those marijuana romances of the 50's and 60's in America where lovers found ultimates in a one-night stand, and on occasion stayed together." title: Patisserie Woes: Cafe May Lose Its Lease and a Klatch Its Cafe
description: For more than a decade, Patisserie Lanciani has drawn a trusty group of 15 or so locals -- artists, photographers, writers, academics and lawyers -- who meet nearly every morning over coffee (a dollar a cup with unlimited refills) in the glass-fronted cafe at 271 West Fourth Street and discuss everything from promotions to deconstruction. "I call it a Penny University," said Eric Darton, a writer. "For the price of a cup of coffee -- a metaphorical penny -- you could get all sorts of knowledge."

title: For Homes With Shallow Wells, a Dry Summer Takes Its Toll
description: IN the McVeety household in Woodbridge, water pouring from the faucets has become a treat. In recent months, if one of the three children took a shower in the morning, that meant the rest of the family was out of luck for a couple of hours. One use of the dishwasher would render the water supply dry. And a washing-machine load that finished before the water ran out was a special event.

title: Riders on the Storm
description: The O. J. Simpson case has produced a hot blast of racial disaffection in the country, and no one should be surprised that charlatans of all hues want to use that blast to lift unworthy careers and causes to new heights. Similarly, it is no surprise that Louis Farrakhan is foremost among the callous self-promoters. It is also unsurprising that the Rev. Benjamin Chavis Jr., whose disgraceful behavior almost wrecked the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, should have signed on as director of Mr. Farrakhan's Million Man March.

Mr. Shorter, 62, is arguably the most influential living jazz composer. Like his peers who inhabit jazz's loftier realms -- Herbie Hancock, Ornette Coleman, Chick Corea, Sonny Rollins -- he has spent the last quarter century flashing bits of his grand talent, then finding the nearest drain down which to dump the rest.

I did the only thing I could do.

title: ON THE TOWNS: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;At Princeton, a Survey Course in Beauty
description: THE casual visitor to "What Photographs Look Like" at the Art Museum at Princeton University may feel like something of an intruder. The show was mounted in conjunction with an undergraduate course in the history of photography taught by Dr. Peter Bunnell, faculty curator of photography at the museum, and a professor's lectures seem necessary to illuminate it.

title: What Shoreline? Public Can Never See It
description: "Owners Hope History Can Save Cottages" [ Sept. 24 ] on Stony Brook's West Meadow Beach cottages is an unfortunate example of false objectivity in journalism. Your reporter mainly interviews the defendants in the conflict, the cottage homeowners, and the plaintiffs, private individuals intent on removing the now illegal cottages. The article leaves the impression that the conflict is largely a private one and essentially a wash between the two sides.

description: Kate Connelly, 31, is the co-host of "Robin Leach Talking Food," a live, quirky show that ran on the Television Food Network until last month. Guests on the show included everyone from sophisticated sommeliers to a lady who collects refrigerator magnets. Ms. Connelly often cooked on the air, gamely coping with mishaps like watery hollandaise sauce and champagne corks that bounced around the studio like Super Balls.

description: To the Editor:

title: In Sam Spade's Footsteps
description: A PALE sun struggled to break through San Francisco's dense morning fog as we set out in search of Miles Archer's cold-blooded killer. Three hours later, tagging behind our trench-coated operative, we caught up with the culprit in a dark alley near Union Square. A brass plaque at the entrance to the narrow street memorializes the heinous crime: "On approximately this spot, Miles Archer, partner of Sam Spade, was done in by Brigid O'Shaughnessy." There is nothing more by way of explanation, but fans of Dashiell Hammett's "Maltese Falcon" know that in the alley, on a clammy San Francisco night, Archer was plugged with a .38 by the dangerously alluring Miss O'Shaughnessy. The hunt for the black bird was on.

title: Paintings That Go 'Little Bit' Beyond the Image
description: BERNARD STERN'S painting is a pictorial idiom that reaches out beyond art, said Edward Lucie-Smith, a European art critic.

title: Sports of The Times;Baseball's Ultimate Lobby Job
description: IN politics, it is called a "dog-and-pony show." When strip-mine legislation is being discussed, angry mountaineers show up bearing pails of ugly sediment that washed off the hillsides while some cheery strip-mine lobbyist shows up with a jar of pristine water from a well at the very same site.

title: In the Computer Age, Fox Devils Still Prowl
description: Doctors thought kidney disease killed Hideo Hiraiwa, but one of the secrets murmured as the evening darkness hurtles in from the surrounding forests to envelop this little town is that he was really murdered by a fox devil.

title: INVESTING IT;Yes, Virginia, Microsoft and Intel Can Be Disappointing
description: THIS week, Intel and Microsoft, twin gorillas of the technology industry, will tell shareholders how much money they earned in the quarter just ended. The amounts undoubtedly will be impressive.

title: Visiting A Room Upstairs To View The Man Upstairs
description: Most of the week, Flora Redondo's apartment is an unremarkable place, the modest home of a retired dressmaker in Elmhurst, Queens. A rickety ceiling fan creaks in the living room, dishes clatter in the kitchen and a shelf in the hallway is lined with curios and bottles of multivitamins.

title: Habitats: West 17th Street;A Brother-and-Sister Act on the Real Estate Stage
description: ZOE SIEGEL and her brother, Ben, graduate students and up-and-coming real estate moguls, stood chest deep in the rubble of the third apartment they have either bought or rented in the group of pre-war apartment houses on West 17th Street between 9th and 10th Avenues in the hinterlands of Chelsea.

title:
NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Videotapes That Tell the Harlem on Their Minds
description: "Harlem Diary," a documentary film in which nine young people tell their life stories, is also the autobiography of a neighborhood, a Harlem that is a backdrop for tears, temptation and tragedy and, at times, nourishment. These young artists express ambivalence -- they want to leave Harlem but somehow they are drawn back to it.

title: In Japan's Facade Of Control
description: When the main measure of power in the world was military might, great and small powers dissembled with statistics inflating or minimizing their arsenals. Nowadays, in the struggle to attract capital or keep investors from fleeing, countries are perfecting the art of dissembling by omission.

title: Handmade House
description: ON A recent Sunday, Geoffrey Carter and his wife, Marion, with their 7-month-old daughter, Franziska, and his father, Norman, were gathered on the lawn of their Hudson Valley property as though for a picnic. But no one was passing sandwiches. The adults were sanding triglyphs -- the decorative blocks that punctuate the Doric frieze of a classical building. There were 63 of them. The bells, or conelike ornaments that finish the triglyphs at the bottom, had already been made. Using white cement, Carter had cast them in Dixie cups. Three guinea hens in noisy chorus crossed the yard where the family worked. Behind them was what appeared to be a Greek temple in progress.

title: Salome': A Tony Dinner Party Run Amok?
description: STEPHANE MALLARME WROTE in 1893 to Oscar Wilde: "While everything in your 'Salome' is executed in endlessly dazzling strokes, there also arises, on each page, the unsayable and the Dream." Mallarme was one of the first to take "Salome" seriously, and one of the few. After a burst of popularity in the wake of Wilde's disgrace and death, this Francophone melodrama on biblical themes became a lurid curiosity at the fringe of the theatrical repertory. Wilde remains known as the master of brilliant drawing-room comedy, not unutterable Symbolist drama.

title: Antiques Amid Flowers, Talks and a Party
description: THE annual antiques show at the Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum in Norwalk is one of those rare shows held in a historic mansion. (Others are held on the grounds).

title: For 'Hidden Child' of the Holocaust, a Sense of Hope
description: WHAT is hope? Does it change? Is an adult's way of hoping different from a child's?

title: A School's Pride Suffers a Blow
description: HADDAM and Killingworth -- nestled in Middlesex County, between Long Island Sound and Middletown -- could well have inspired Norman Rockwell paintings, those that capture the essence of small-town New England. Although many of their residents commute to jobs in Middletown, Hartford and New Haven, the towns are far more close-knit than bedroom communities elsewhere. In the two communities people share a pride in the area's rustic charm and its respected regional school system, including Haddam-Killingworth High School, where the girls' field hockey team won a the state championship last year.

title:

I Hate Purses
description: I WAS seated at a table in the Citicorp Center mall, and I carefully put my shoulder bag on the back of the chair and leaned against it. I'm a New Yorker born and bred and I know you can't fool around with your pocketbook in this town. But I wasn't worried; I could feel the bag against my back.

title: IN THE GARDEN;Tidy Impatiens Beds Hover and Take Off
description: THANK goodness for impatiens. At this time of year, the color from these seemingly ubiquitous flowers is truly spectacular.

description: To the Editor:

title: CLAUDE STEELE HAS SCORES TO SETTLE
description: Having named and carefully explored the terrain of racial vulnerability (among blacks and whites) years before the term even appeared in my brother's work, I have found it distressing to watch my racial vulnerability become his "stereotype vulnerability," my anti-self become his "patient predator," my inferiority anxiety his "whisper of inferiority," my objective correlative his "trigger of vulnerability" and so on and on -- an entire framework of ideas lifted without attribution ("Claude Steele Has Scores to Settle," by Ethan Watters, Sept. 17). This has stood between us for some time. I wanted no part of the Magazine profile, to avoid a public bloodletting. But my brother and the writer, Ethan Watters, refused to keep me out of the article because neither had faith that it would happen without my presence, and it was to be a Times debut for them both. The harder I fought to be left alone, the more entitled they felt to use me.

title: Layering Textures; OVER THE EDGE
description: CHRISTINE Van Der Hurd and her husband, David Hurd, are the ultimate example of the couple who bring their work home. She designs carpets and decorative accessories; he owns the Manhattan furniture gallery Modern Age. Unlike some art dealers, who yearn for a different esthetic once they leave their shops, Van Der Hurd and Hurd surround themselves with the hand-finished objects and intricately wrought surfaces that are their bread and butter. Such pieces are also sustenance for their souls, especially in a house that was once the antithesis of well made.

title: Ministry of Faith for the Wrongly Convicted
description: MONEY and celebrity prevailed at the Trial of the Century, and perhaps nothing else. In the backlash, an assumption gains momentum that the bar for convicting even the evidently guilty has been raised a couple of notches. And alongside sweeps an unspoken corollary, that the demonstrably innocent have nothing to fear.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Elkington to Face Els Steve Elkington, the P.G.A. champion, and Ernie Els, the defending champion, won semifinal matches at the world match play championships yesterday in Virginia Water, England. Elkington defeated Costantino Rocca, 3 and 1, in their 36-hole match, taking a one-hole lead at the 13th. Els took an even tighter match over Bernhard Langer, winning 1 up. Langer had a chance to force a playoff on the final hole, but missed a 9-foot birdie putt after Els had made par. (AP)

title: GORE VIDAL RECEIVES A VISITOR
description: Gore Vidal's villa in Ravello, though not particularly big or grand, is as enchanting as he makes it sound: white stucco anchored miraculously into the sheer face of the cliff, 12 acres of vertical stone and terraced gardens, a pool that commands the same panorama as the house, an extra balcony for cocktails just along the rock face. Vidal's forthcoming memoir, "Palimpsest," which I have finished over breakfast, overflows with this place and its vistas: being here now is like being received at Elsinore the morning you finish "Hamlet."

title: Dance Therapy Beyond Its 'Flower Child' Image
description: IT was 53 years ago that Marian Chace began using dance to help severely disturbed psychiatric patients in a Washington hospital. Her pioneering work and teaching lay the groundwork for the new field of dance therapy, which its practitioners define as the guided use of movement to bring about changes in feeling, cognition, physical functioning and behavior.

The article also misstated the number of subsidized housing units arranged by the Desperados. It is about 2,100.

title: EARNING IT;Overworking? Overeating? Telecommuting?
description: A FEW years ago, the lights were often on at 3 A.M. in Garret Sheldon's home office. There were plenty of computer chores to do, and lots of calls from clients traveling in Asia. But even those long weeknight hours were not enough to keep Mr. Sheldon from working weekends, too -- to complete projects, to talk to clients and to meet with the other members of the Potomac Group, his information-technology and management consulting firm in Arlington, Mass.

title: H.I.V. Test Disclosure to Mothers Is Welcomed
description: A month ago, 18-year-old Alejandra Hoyos learned she was pregnant. When she first became sexually active, she had considered being tested for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, though she put it off. But when her baby is born next spring, she said, she will want to know the results of her newborn's state-mandated test.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
My Father's Black Pride
description: I AM BLACK. MY MOTHER is black. My father is white. This wouldn't necessarily be important, but we live in a country where conflict runs deep between blacks and whites. We live in a country where white male slaveholders casually disavowed the black children they had sired. We live in a country where the worst of human traits -- laziness, violence and irrationality -- are seen as defining characteristics of those of African descent. This makes my being a mixed-race person whose ethnic identity is black somewhat complicated. There is a dissonance between who I say I am -- a proud black man trying to do something positive with his life -- and who society says I am. Yet I feel strong, and I embrace my black heritage. I've often reflected on how I learned to keep my positive self-image. The answer is, my white father.

title: Leader Spurs the Lagging Tories, Vowing a Fifth Straight Victory
description: Conservatives returned today from the coastal town of Blackpool, where their annual party conference ended on Friday with an address by Prime Minister John Major in which he proclaimed that the Tories were "united, healed, renewed and thirsting for the fight with Labor."

title: Henry Roth, 89, Who Wrote of an Immigrant Child's Life in 'Call It Sleep,' Is Dead
description: Henry Roth, the novelist known for his masterpiece "Call It Sleep," an exact, unsparing portrait of the lives of poor Jewish immigrants in New York City in the early decades of this century, and then for experiencing perhaps the most mysterious career in modern American letters, died on Friday at Lovelace Hospital in Albuquerque, N.M. He was 89 and had lived in Albuquerque for many years.

For his employer, though, it was business as usual: Economists from the University of Chicago have brought home Nobels in five of the last six years, and eight of the 22 economics prizes ever awarded to Americans.
