title: Russian Seizes 27 Koreans In Moscow
description: Firing into the air, Russian commandos swarmed onto a tour bus near the Kremlin early today, freeing four South Koreans and a Russian driver who had been held hostage for 10 hours by a rifle-carrying gunman. The gunman died in the attack.

title: Proposed Cuts in Indian Programs Hit Those Who Rely Most on FederalAid
description: With a gray autumn sky clamped like a steel colander over this bleak prairie reservation, Maxine Running Hawk recently talked about how she would keep her 10 children warm in their Government-supplied house this winter, by plugging wall holes with rags and by running the oven with the door off its hinges.

title: THE DNA WE'VE BEEN DEALT
description: I was struck by the similarity between Siebert's quest to discover his own genetic fate and the intense soul-searching of the early American Puritans to determine whether they were to be saved or damned.

title: BOOKSHELF;Play Not the Peacock (Except on Halloween): Advice for the Socially Challenged
description: Americans have been preoccupied with manners at least since the first settlers began arriving. In the 17th century, according to Arthur M. Schlesinger, "people were punished, usually in public, for scandalmongering, cursing, lying, name-calling, even for flirting, jeering, 'finger-sticking' and making ugly faces." Since then, the offenses have become subtler, and so have the punishments. Herewith, a miscellany of advice and observations from a variety of authors.

title: A Block Patrol That's Taking A Different Tack
description: Along Tompkins Boulevard in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the series of once-majestic old brownstones, pockmarked with burned-out windows or boarded-up doors, is suddenly broken by an oasis of kempt storefronts with banners on the walls and benches on the sidewalk. A large mural proclaims, "Bed-Stuy Block Patrol, It's time for a change."

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: WHAT I LIVED FOR By Joyce Carol Oates. William Abrahams/Plume, $14.95. Jerome (Corky) Corcoran, an Irish-American businessman of modest means, has never felt at home in the world since the murder of his father when he was 11. In this novel he seeks the meaning behind another death, the suicide of a young black woman. The result is "an engrossing, moving study of desperate, lonely and lost souls," James Carroll said here last year.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Black Men Say the March in Washington Is About Them, Not Farrakhan
description: At the Update Barber Salon in a tiny mall here, outside the District of Columbia, no one questions whether Monday's planned march in the capital by thousands of black men is a good thing.

title: CLASSICAL VIEW;This Riverboat Gambler Was Also a Giver of Gifts
description: Christopher Keene took a lot of the New York City Opera with him when he died last Sunday. Anyone who wanted to know what was right about this company, and why a lot of what it did didn't work, had only to follow him around for a while. Mr. Keene had a way of staking his opera house on ventures that never had much chance of succeeding in the first place, but ones that had to be tried just the same. The cards dealt him when he took over the job of general director in 1989 were for the most part losing ones, but how cheerfully and gracefully he bluffed and sometimes won.

title: The Inside Story
description: A PIECE of furniture need not be a rare antique or a one-of-a-kind art object to have a complex inner life. Whether it's a sculptured wood frame hidden beneath the upholstery, or mahogany veneers carefully selected to recall the fine cabinetry of early Moderne styles, there is often more to a contemporary piece than meets the eye of even the most scrutinizing observer. Here we reveal the techniques -- some old, some new -- that define well-made furniture today. Although the results are sometimes costly, these works, like their predecessors, are made to be handed down to future generations.

title: F.Y.I.

In the first half of this century, the Collyer brothers, Homer and Langley, were perhaps the most famous eccentrics in New York, a pair of recluses who lived in a booby-trapped, junk-stuffed, and yes, Mr. Koch, newspaper-packed brownstone until their mysterious demise in 1947, according to "Manhattan '45" by Jan Morris (Oxford University Press, 1987).

Moreover, the written and spoken forms of a poem provide two distinct experiences for the reader and listener. How it looks on the page and how it sounds to the ear both influence a poem's meaning.

And Bear in Mind (Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest) ALBERT SPEER: HIS BATTLE WITH TRUTH, by Gitta Sereny. (Knopf, $35.) The author, a lifelong student of the Nazi bosses and for years a friend of Speer, who served Hitler as Minister of Armaments, examines his stratagems to avoid knowing exactly what it was that he knew. CASINO: Love and Honor in Las Vegas, by Nicholas Pileggi. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) The unease and aimlessness of the gangster life, captured fly-on-the-wall fashion and conveyed in the perceptions of the crooks themselves. EDWARD HOPPER: An Intimate Biography, by Gail Levin. (Knopf, $35.) Ms. Levin's sixth book on Hopper only peripherally concerns Hopper's art; it's a nearly flawless account of the life of a great American painter whose temperament, especially in respect of his weirdly long-suffering and combative wife, was simply abominable. THE END OF AFFLUENCE: The Causes and Consequences of America's Economic Dilemma, by Jeffrey Madrick. (Random House, $22.) A journalist turned economic historian argues that historical changes have killed the prosperity many Americans remember, and that no economic or political nostrums can bring it back. FIRE IN THE MIND: Science, Faith and the Search for Order, by George Johnson. (Knopf, $27.50.) Careful, balanced explorations of the places where scientific understanding of this extremely strange universe and religious and philosophical perceptions of it may illuminate each other. HEART: A Memoir, by Lance Morrow. (Warner, $22.95.) A moving work of literal introspection: in the wake of his second heart attack and second bypass operation, Mr. Morrow tries to find out what's really wrong with his life and himself. THE HUSBANDS: An Account of Books 3 and 4 of Homer's "Iliad," by Christopher Logue. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.) A heroic, often brilliant, portion of the author's long-term project of bringing this distant, uncomfortable, alien poem closer to readers of contemporary poetry. PALIMPSEST: A Memoir, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $27.50.) As Mr. Vidal recalls his first 39 years (1925-64), his abundant self-admiration escapes self-absorption, and many people he did not care for receive at least the tribute of his keen attention. Too bad for them! PANAMA, by Eric Zencey. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) Henry Adams (yes, the Henry Adams) turns private investigator in this complex, ambitious detective novel, which starts in Panama but moves to the Paris of the 1890's. WILLIAM MORRIS: A Life for Our Time, by Fiona MacCarthy. (Knopf, $45.) A witty, shrewd, learned full-scale biography of the great 19th-century English designer whose amazing versatility (propaganda was one of his skills) has always made his center hard to find. WRITING HOME, by Alan Bennett. (Random House, $25.) Notes, prefaces, diary entries and fugitive pieces, charming and insightful, by the slyest of contemporary British playwrights.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: WHAT I LIVED FOR By Joyce Carol Oates. William Abrahams/Plume, $14.95. Jerome (Corky) Corcoran, an Irish-American businessman of modest means, has never felt at home in the world since the murder of his father when he was 11. In this novel he seeks the meaning behind another death, the suicide of a young black woman. The result is "an engrossing, moving study of desperate, lonely and lost souls," James Carroll said here last year. LOUISA MAY ALCOTT: A Modern Biography By Martha Saxton. Noonday/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $15. There was much more to Louisa May Alcott than can be gleaned by reading "Little Women." Although this book, originally published in 1977, portrays her as eager to sacrifice for her peculiar parents, it also reveals her as a person whose emotional needs had little to do with self-denial. It is "an absorbing, powerful interpretation of a tormented woman," Patricia Meyer Spacks wrote in the Book Review. More of Alcott's complexity emerges in THE SELECTED LETTERS OF LOUISA MAY ALCOTT, edited by Joel Myerson and Daniel Shealy (University of Georgia, $19.95). In her correspondence she is strong, spirited and cheerful, able to write prolifically despite the demands placed upon her. This is "a brave and vivid life in letters," Barbara L. Packer said in these pages in 1987. Just how brave and vivid can be seen in A MARBLE WOMAN: Unknown Thrillers of Louisa May Alcott, edited by Madeleine Stern (Avon, $11). The two novellas and three stories in this volume, originally titled "Plots and Counterplots," represent the Gothic adult fiction Alcott wrote for added income and, one suspects, pleasure. As our reviewer, Diane Johnson, put it in 1976, "The heroines are forceful, independent, sexually demanding, smoke dope and don't do housework."

title: SOAPBOX;Operation Scapegoat
description: ONCE upon a time, in a city beside the waters, a wonderful transportation system efficiently carried millions of people above and below the ground. But for no apparent reason, the system began to deteriorate, slowly and painfully. The people had to wait longer and longer for buses and trains that were more and more overcrowded, and meanwhile the fares went up and up.

title: In Nepal, Paradise Partly Lost
description: MY first encounter with Nepal came in the early 70's, when I spent a year there teaching English under the British Voluntary Services Overseas program. Then only a decade or two out of prolonged isolation, the little kingdom seemed to invite the visitor to step back a few centuries. There was the pristine green of the Katmandu Valley, a shade more luminous than even that of English meadows. There were the street scenes that, set against a backdrop of medieval buildings, possessed the color and vitality of a Bruegel painting. The air, a heady cocktail of wood smoke, incense and farmyard aromas, betokened adventure; and such was the visibility that come October and the retreat of monsoon clouds, the high ranges of the Himalayas materialized beyond the valley's rim as a white wall of splendor.

title: A Room of Their Own
description: Gavin Y. used to drink every day. Alex V. wishes her parents were "a little more straight," and Andreen B. is obsessed with the length of her fingernails. They and 40 other adolescents appear in Adrienne Salinger's IN MY ROOM: Teenagers in Their Bedrooms (Chronicle, paper, $16.95). For most of them, life seems as narrow as their twin beds. Ms. Salinger, who teaches art media studies at Syracuse University, met them at malls, restaurants or gyms, but photographed them in their bedrooms because, as she writes, bedrooms "become the repository for our memories and the expression of our desires and self-image." All the teen-agers are pretty weirded out (unlike, of course, previous generations), as the grown-up world seeps down into theirs. Take Krissy P., a cherubic-looking girl who rambles on about ganja cookies. Many of the young people have suffered because of their parents. Carlos C.'s divorced when he was a child and his father died of AIDS. Then Carlos moved in with his "Uncle Bill," a family friend who is gay and has a male roommate. Yet Carlos is one of the few adolescents smiling in the book (his room is a comfortable mess) and the only one who seems approachable and kindly. "I grew to love my uncle, and I can relate to him better than anybody," he says. Adult problems may be stumbling more and more into teen-agers' lives, but at least the young people can still retreat to their rooms. DULCIE LEIMBACH

title: Montclair's Ms. Manners
description: FRAN LISCIO made up her mind that her children would never eat candy, play with toy guns or watch television. Of course, that was before she had children. Over the six years she has been a parent, all those vows have gone by the wayside. "Now I hand out M&M;'s as bribes," she said. "So I can finish a phone call."

title: DINING OUT;Entering a Masculine Atmosphere in Rye

But the pleasantly fussy lace curtains on two walls suggest another presence in this mountain-camp environment and assure the diner that canned beans are not the evening's fare. Indeed, on our recent visit, as one sophisticated rendering after another reached our table, we saw the studied rusticity as pure stage set. On another visit, however, we thought wistfully about that can of beans. Thus our rating reflects the averages of some winning efforts and some that were inedible.

title: MATERIAL RICHES
description: OBJECTS SPEAK to us most directly about what it means to be well made. While interior spaces and architecture are rendered successful through the expression of abstract notions like proportion, context and juxtaposition, objects offer the more immediate rewards of texture and utility. It is easy to appreciate how well something is put together when you can touch it, feel its heft and move it around to catch the light. On the following pages, we focus on pieces that afford these pleasures; they also capture both a contemporary spirit and a commitment to traditional craftsmanship.

title: IN THE WELL-MADE PLACE
description: AS we approach the millennium bombarded with forecasts that the electronic revolution is poised to dematerialize the world into byte-sized digital signals, our instinctive response is to reach for an antidote in the intense physicalities of the home. In fact, the home may be evolving into the last preserve of the well-made object. Whether it is through the geometry of a perfectly proportioned window or through the texture of a worn leather sofa, well-made things reassure us that the material world still thrives. While we moderns are more accustomed to mass-produced than custom-made, we still crave the luxury of richly realized spaces and things. The following interiors share an attitude about excellence that guarantees that traditional or contemporary, spare or layered, they are exciting to experience. In a Manhattan apartment, the interior designer John Saladino applied his knowledge of classical proportions to manipulate and enrich every surface. With their craftsmanlike obsession with details at every scale, Peggy Deamer and Scott Phillips introduced a high level of conceptual integrity to a modern house in the Hamptons. Layers of brilliant color and texture endow the home of Christine Van Der Hurd and David Hurd with visual depth and complexity. Johnny Grey, a designer-philosopher, has brought ideas about furniture and finishes from the ateliers of 18th-century craftsmen into the kitchen. These homes proclaim and celebrate the many ways it is possible to live in a well-made place.

title: DIARY
description: OMERTA, JAPANESE STYLE Who Knew What When? The Daiwa Bank's loss of $1.1 billion because of one employee's unauthorized trading in U.S. Treasuries left egg all over the bank's top executives. Now the stain has spread: six weeks weeks before Daiwa notified American regulators of its problem, it told the Japanese Government -- which decided this was not information it had to share with Washington. At best, Tokyo's secrecy was a serious breach of protocol at a time when the two Governments were trying to sort out various financial issues -- and when concerns about the shaky underpinnings of some Japanese banks had reached the point that American institutions were charging a premium for lines of credit extended to Japan. A phone call between Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Japan's Finance Minister, Masayoshia Takemura, seemed to do little to mend the fence: Treasury officials said the Japanese had expressed regret; the Japanese insisted that they had not apologized and that American regulators were upset because of "cultural differences." In any event, said the Vice Minister of Finance, Kyosuke Shinozawa, it was Daiwa's responsibility to inform the United States, not the ministry's. THE HIGH-TECH YO-YO Which Way to Jump? In the latest pang for all those heavily invested in high technology, the sector took a nose dive on Monday, with the Nasdaq composite down 2.7 percent, precipitated by Novell's announcement of anticipated lower earnings, followed by Motorola profits that disappointed some investors. By Tuesday's opening, the Dow had been dragged down 65 points. But then investors dived back in, and yet again The Selloff had become The Buying Opportunity. By week's end the markets were setting or flirting with records. LABOR Flight Attendants Win a Round In a rare success for organized labor, arbitrators awarded the flight attendants union at American Airlines a 17 percent salary increase over four years and maintained vacation time at current levels. The 20,000 flight attendants at American struck just before Thanksgiving 1993; they returned to work five days later after President Clinton twisted the arm of Robert L. Crandall, the chairman of AMR, which owns the airline, until he agreed to arbitration. The arbitrators did grant American the right to reduce staffing on some flights. GOODBYE Manzi Bails Out at I.B.M. In the credit markets, three months is short term. But that's not how Jim P. Manzi, chief executive of Lotus Development, sees things. After quickly giving in to I.B.M.'s takeover offer last summer, Mr. Manzi pledged to stay with Big Blue for "the long haul." Ninety-nine days later, he has walked away, saying he was not "the right person" to run a division at I.B.M., where no one seemed to be crying at the news. If Lotus's software geniuses were to follow Mr. Manzi out the door, that could change quickly. CYBERSPACE Roadworks Ahead Weaknesses in the structural integrity of the Internet could allow a criminal to divert documents or transactions transmitted over computer networks, researchers at the University of California warned. The problem requires more than a hot patch on the information superhighway, the experts say, urging businesses to contain their enthusiasm for digital commerce until adequate safeguards are in place. BANKING New Week, New Merger Forging a combination that would dominate banking in metropolitan Philadelphia, Core states Financial agreed to acquire Meridian Bancorp for $3.2 billion in stock. As banking mergers grew to fever pitch earlier this year, Meridian held out. But Corestates turned up the heat after an unsuccessful pass at the Bank of Boston. Corestates said the combined company would close or sell 115 branches and trim nearly 2,000 jobs, about 10 percent of its staff. BORDER WAR Coffee Exchange to Stay Put Grabbing the gold ring offered by New York city and state officials, the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange said it would remain in Manhattan and build a new home, rather than move to Jersey City as it had planned. New York officials hoped the Cotton Exchange would similarly reverse course. By agreeing to put up $91 million in subsidies, the officials said, they were saving 5,000 New York jobs. WAR CHEST A Reserve Against Speculators Finance ministers from the world's richest nations agreed to set up a $50 billion fund to combat currency crises. The money would be available to the International Monetary Fund to make loans to countries suffering from capital flight. Even as the pool was established, brush fires flared in Europe, where speculators pressured the French franc and the lira. NOBEL PRIZE A Rite of Fall It's a harbinger of the season, like leaves turning colors: Each year -- five of the last six, anyway -- the Nobel jurors look to the University of Chicago to award the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics. This time around the winner was Robert E. Lucas Jr., whose influential research in macroeconomics encouraged skepticism about the ability of Government policy makers to fine-tune the economy. A man for the times.

description: What Christopher Matthews saw in the corrida in Barcelona was the height of mediocrity (About Men: "Gored," Sept. 24). Bullfighting has lasted hundreds of years. Would you stop seeing theater for all the bad plays or movies? ALLAN RICH Los Angeles

title: ABOUT MEN;My Father's Black Pride
description: I AM BLACK. MY MOTHER is black. My father is white. This wouldn't necessarily be important, but we live in a country where conflict runs deep between blacks and whites. We live in a country where white male slaveholders casually disavowed the black children they had sired. We live in a country where the worst of human traits -- laziness, violence and irrationality -- are seen as defining characteristics of those of African descent. This makes my being a mixed-race person whose ethnic identity is black somewhat complicated. There is a dissonance between who I say I am -- a proud black man trying to do something positive with his life -- and who society says I am. Yet I feel strong, and I embrace my black heritage. I've often reflected on how I learned to keep my positive self-image. The answer is, my white father.

title: JUDGE HAYDEN'S FAMILY VALUES
description: IT HAS TAKEN ALMOST FOUR YEARS TO GET to this afternoon in a muggy Newark courtroom. That's how long the parents have been duking it out over their son, each trying to win the judge over, each saying, Your Honor, you decide because we can't. Just let me be the one to keep the child. Yet no matter how she calls the custody fight, Judge Katharine Sweeney Hayden knows that one parent will bless her and the other will curse her. She shrugs. It's not my job to make happy endings, she thinks. If a couple is so anger-locked that they have to ask a stranger to make their most intimate decisions, well, too bad: I'm it, I'm what you've got.

title:
SOAPBOX;

description: ONCE upon a time, in a city beside the waters, a wonderful transportation system efficiently carried millions of people above and below the ground. But for no apparent reason, the system began to deteriorate, slowly and painfully. The people had to wait longer and longer for buses and trains that were more and more overcrowded, and meanwhile the fares went up and up.

title: FOOD;An Autumn Meal With an Italian Flavor
description: OSSO BUCO is an Italian dish especially suited for fall. Made with veal shanks simmered in white wine and stock, it is traditionally served with risotto Milanese (rice flavored with saffron, which makes each grain look as though it had turned to gold). The name osso buco means hollow bone; the high point is eating the marrow inside the bones, which can be scooped out with a special elongated silver spoon; a coffee spoon, narrow teaspoon or even a knife will also do the trick.

title: INVESTING IT;Our Portfolios, Ourselves
description: NO one would ever confuse the women of New York's 008 Investment Club with the Beardstown Ladies. The Ladies became famous last spring for their homespun and highly successful investing style, even though they have never ventured far from their tiny Illinois farm community, where you can still leave your car door unlocked. Many of them never went to college, some never worked outside their homes -- and they are all small-town enough to have put recipes for broccoli casserole and angel food cake in their best-selling book about their experiences.

title: CLAUDE STEELE HAS SCORES TO SETTLE
description: Having named and carefully explored the terrain of racial vulnerability (among blacks and whites) years before the term even appeared in my brother's work, I have found it distressing to watch my racial vulnerability become his "stereotype vulnerability," my anti-self become his "patient predator," my inferiority anxiety his "whisper of inferiority," my objective correlative his "trigger of vulnerability" and so on and on -- an entire framework of ideas lifted without attribution ("Claude Steele Has Scores to Settle," by Ethan Watters, Sept. 17). This has stood between us for some time. I wanted no part of the Magazine profile, to avoid a public bloodletting. But my brother and the writer, Ethan Watters, refused to keep me out of the article because neither had faith that it would happen without my presence, and it was to be a Times debut for them both. The harder I fought to be left alone, the more entitled they felt to use me.

title: Thou Shalt Not Covet Thy Neighbor's Lawn

Suddenly I was steaming. I knew that if I had to ask one more time, the thin veneer of civilization that reins in the raving lunatic inside me would crack, and with it would crumble an entire network of social relationships up and down the block. I did the only thing I could do.

Entering a Masculine Atmosphere in Rye

But the pleasantly fussy lace curtains on two walls suggest another presence in this mountain-camp environment and assure the diner that canned beans are not the evening's fare. Indeed, on our recent visit, as one sophisticated rendering after another reached our table, we saw the studied rusticity as pure stage set. On another visit, however, we thought wistfully about that can of beans. Thus our rating reflects the averages of some winning efforts and some that were inedible.

title: New Electronics: To Be Heard and Not Seen
description: THIS may be the heyday of high-tech product design, but industrial designers won't mind if you fail to notice. As if to temper the promise of ever-better surround sound and 500-channel interactive television, many have adopted an esthetic that is quiet and unobtrusive, deliberately self-effacing. Engineers and designers are no longer inclined to show off by lining up arrays of buttons and blinking lights. Instead, they have set out to tame technology and, when possible, to relegate it to the background.

The system that was briefly damaged was meant to warn of a rare but deadly weather condition, wind shear, that has caused several crashes in the nation over the years.

title: GORED

I am still haunted by those thousands of faces that seemed brought to orgasmic exhilaration by the suffering of that innocent beast slowly succumbing to a humiliating death. I wonder what disturbs me most -- the senseless slaughter or how much everyone seemed to enjoy it?

It is appearing in both genuine material and bogus copies of the type seen in Paris last year worn by young people as a spoof against establishment design. In New York the authentic plaid is part of the fall fashion picture, as evidenced by the slim trousers, kilts and sleeveless sheath dresses shown here. The House of Burberry was founded in the mid-19th century by a tailor, Thomas Burberry, in England. His active women's golf clothes gained popularity early in this century, followed by his all-weather trench coat designed for British troops in World War I.

title: Urban Arcadia
description: MURDERS, PROSTITUTES, vagrants and portents of doom. That was Bryant Park just 10 years ago. Today, thanks to an $8.9 million renovation completed in 1992, it seems almost impossible to believe that this Arcadian oasis was a drug den reviled throughout the 1970's and early 80's as "Needle Park." On a fine day, it is filled with office workers, shoppers and other visitors, with some reclining on a carefully tended lawn, others unwinding on dark green slatted folding chairs, and still others strolling along neat gravel paths in the dappled shade of more than 200 majestic plane trees.

title: New Electronics: To Be Heard and Not Seen
description: THIS may be the heyday of high-tech product design, but industrial designers won't mind if you fail to notice. As if to temper the promise of ever-better surround sound and 500-channel interactive television, many have adopted an esthetic that is quiet and unobtrusive, deliberately self-effacing. Engineers and designers are no longer inclined to show off by lining up arrays of buttons and blinking lights. Instead, they have set out to tame technology and, when possible, to relegate it to the background.

"Local passions" for the sport run at such a low ebb that the bullring is more often used for political rallies, concerts and other large public events. On weekends, crowds of German, English, French, Japanese and American tourists pay to have their worst prejudices about the Spanish character confirmed. Matthews is no different. SUSAN M. Somehow, years of classroom French, plus regular visits since the 1960's to my country of choice, hadn't done the trick, and so I resolved to try total immersion: French on the bus, in the drugstore and at the cafe, as well as in class. I would live as English-free a life as I possibly could on an 18-day vacation with a non-French-speaking spouse.

title: A Shoe Of One's Own
description: WHAT: The Air Swoopes basketball shoe for women from Nike Inc., the company that brought Air Jordan to American locker rooms. Named after Sheryl Swoopes, the former Texas Tech all-American, 1993 Collegiate Player of the Year and a member of the 1994 Goodwill Games gold-medal basketball team. Arriving in stores this week, for the suggested retail price of $85. THE BIG DEAL: Nike last named a shoe for an athlete 10 years ago, when it introduced the Air Jordan basketball shoe for men, named after Michael Jordan. The shoe propelled Nike to dominance in the athletic-shoe market. Ms. Swoopes, considered one of the best college players ever, man or woman, is the first female athlete to have a shoe named in her honor. Robin Carr-Locke, a spokeswoman for Nike, said the line was part of the company's commitment to women's sports. "And we thought the name was cool," she said. But there is also a growing interest in women's basketball and a new generation of Sheryl Swoopes and Rebecca Lobo wannabes. HER AIRNESS: Born March 25, 1971, in Brownfield, Tex. Nicknamed the Texas Tornado, Ms. Swoopes (rhymes with hoops) scored 47 points to lead the Red Raiders to the N.C.A.A. championship in 1993. She averaged 23 points a game with a professional women's team in Italy, but left after three months -- homesick and unpaid. Ms. Swoopes, a six-foot shooting guard, is a member of the United States national team that has been in training for the 1996 OlympicGames. Shoe size: 10 1/2. THE HARD SELL: To promote its latest commodity, Nike set up a toll-free number -- (800) 650-6936 -- so that fans can call to hear Ms. Swoopes talk about her new shoes and life on and off the courts. A sample: "It's probably one of the same old stories you heard before -- only girl in the family, growing up, playing with my two older brothers, got beat up all the time, they didn't want me to play because I was a girl." THE LOOK: No delicate pinks or baby blues here. The shoe comes in black with a white stripe and red Nike logo for winter, and white with black stripe and red Nike logo for spring. ("Black is a symbol of toughness to me," Ms. Swoopes said.) Designed with input from Ms. Swoopes, the shoe has a basketball encircled by a signature S at the top of the tongue and a big "S" on the sole. A midfoot stability strap with structural stitching was specifically designed with Ms. Swoopes's flat, narrow feet and weak ankles in mind. HANG TIME: When Ms. Swoopes skies for a slam dunk, her opponents on the hardwood will see only the bottoms of her shoes. That "S" in your face stands for Swoopes. LENA WILLIAMS

title: In Sam Spade's Footsteps
description: A PALE sun struggled to break through San Francisco's dense morning fog as we set out in search of Miles Archer's cold-blooded killer. Three hours later, tagging behind our trench-coated operative, we caught up with the culprit in a dark alley near Union Square. A brass plaque at the entrance to the narrow street memorializes the heinous crime: "On approximately this spot, Miles Archer, partner of Sam Spade, was done in by Brigid O'Shaughnessy." There is nothing more by way of explanation, but fans of Dashiell Hammett's "Maltese Falcon" know that in the alley, on a clammy San Francisco night, Archer was plugged with a .38 by the dangerously alluring Miss O'Shaughnessy. The hunt for the black bird was on.

title: FILM;Jean Valjean in Vichy France
description: ON A TRAIN TRAVELING through Nazi-occupied France from Nice to Paris, a police officer checks the identity papers of a young Jewish woman and her 5-year-old son and spots that they are false. The woman slips him a watch as bribery, and he lets them go. "A real Thenardier, that one," the woman whispers to the boy. "Thenardier?" he asks, puzzled. And with that, as the train moves slowly through the night, she recounts the story of "Les Miserables."

title: AMONG THE BELIEVERS
description: Rosenbaum makes a melancholy connection between Elvis's song "Hurt" and chronic Weltschmerz among Elvis fans. But there is a simpler answer to why the song is such a favorite: "Hurt" is a virtuoso showpiece, akin to Puccini's spectacular tenor aria "Nessun dorma," from "Turandot." I sang it myself, or tried to, as one of 60 entrants in this year's Elvis Impersonators Contest in Memphis. Thirty or forty other contestants must have also sung it, and always, at the bravura finish, there was a whopping surge of delight at the sheer power-theatrics of the song. These people weren't hurting any more than a crowd of football fans reacting to an 85-yard touchdown pass hurt. WILLIAM MCCRANOR HENDERSON Chapel Hill, N.C.

title: Books in Brief; Family Dinners
description: Barry Gifford has been chronicling the decline of Western civilization for 25 years: as America goes, so goes Mr. Gifford. Not surprisingly, his books have become increasingly twisted and senseless, their plots fractured by random acts of madness, anxiety and desperation. Still, no matter how far into weirdness Mr. Gifford wanders, his characters often remain less bizarre than those we see in the tabloids. His latest novel, BABY CAT-FACE (Harcourt Brace, $20), opens with a conversation about a woman who bludgeons her husband, then chops him up and cooks him. Many short chapters later, it closes with talk about an elderly woman decapitating her daughter. In between, characters lose limbs and lives and say things like "You don't cry over anything you have to give up, because you eventually must give up everything." Much of the narrative makes little sense, a trait for which Mr. Gifford is commonly criticized. Sailor and Lula, the lead characters from his best-known novel, "Wild at Heart," randomly appear: "To be 18 years old zooming along in a terrific car with an almost perfect girlfriend who can't hardly get enough of you on a breezy spring afternoon in the South was just about it, thought Sailor Ripley. . . . And he was glad as hell he had the good sense to realize it." Indeed. Mr. Gifford's characters face the ridiculousness of life with existential gusto -- and in this, at least, there is perfect sense. MARK LINDQUIST

description: RAISED BY WOLVES By Jim Goldberg in collaboration with Philip Brookman. Illustrated. 320 pp. New York: Scalo Publishers/Distributed Art Publishers. Paper, $45. THE pitfalls faced by Jim Goldberg as he began "Raised by Wolves," his project on teen-age runaways in Los Angeles and San Francisco, must have been daunting. How does a middle-aged photographer with a home, a wife and daughter, a good job and access to grant money infiltrate the fugitive, hand-to-mouth lives of street kids? What is the right distance from which to look at trouble? The photographer Larry Clark seems to have become a kid before he made "Kids," his faux documentary about teen-age amoralists in New York. Whereas Sebastiao Salgado, in "Workers," his book on the plight of laborers around the world, ignored individuals in the hope that deeper patterns in the carpet would emerge.

title: Anxious in Dreamland
description: THE UNCONSOLED By Kazuo Ishiguro. 535 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25. KAZUO ISHIGURO, the author of "The Remains of the Day" (1989), has acquired a reputation as a penetrating psychological realist and a luminous stylist. It is entirely undeserved. The characters in Mr. Ishiguro's books are papier-mache animations. They don't have feelings; they simulate feelings, which they seem to have learned about by reading some sort of technical manual on the emotions. And Mr. Ishiguro's prose is a confection of banality and cliche, presented in a manner that tends toward woodenness. His landscapes are sets from inferior Walt Disney pictures; his narratives have a kind of tour-bus quality; and his single insight into the human condition is that people need love but continually spoil their chances of getting it, a piece of wisdom slightly below the level of Dr. Joyce Brothers.

title: The Future of the Well Made
description: I RECENTLY held a newly made drapery tieback, a heavy rope of finely spun blue silk that was knotted according to the traditions of the 18th century (the golden age of tiebacks) with the most extraordinary delicacy. It cost about $1,200 and filled me with awe and unease. I admired the fabulous display of detail -- row upon row of minute passementerie -- and appreciated the talent of the people, Italian women in their 60's, I imagine, still capable of executing such fine workmanship. But I was also keenly aware that there is no place in my life for such an exquisite anachronism. It felt like a piece of the past that had somehow slipped through time. I put it down gingerly.

title: In Nepal, Paradise Partly Lost
description: MY first encounter with Nepal came in the early 70's, when I spent a year there teaching English under the British Voluntary Services Overseas program. Then only a decade or two out of prolonged isolation, the little kingdom seemed to invite the visitor to step back a few centuries. There was the pristine green of the Katmandu Valley, a shade more luminous than even that of English meadows. There were the street scenes that, set against a backdrop of medieval buildings, possessed the color and vitality of a Bruegel painting. The air, a heady cocktail of wood smoke, incense and farmyard aromas, betokened adventure; and such was the visibility that come October and the retreat of monsoon clouds, the high ranges of the Himalayas materialized beyond the valley's rim as a white wall of splendor.

I sang it myself, or tried to, as one of 60 entrants in this year's Elvis Impersonators Contest in Memphis. Thirty or forty other contestants must have also sung it, and always, at the bravura finish, there was a whopping surge of delight at the sheer power-theatrics of the song. title: Handmade House
description: ON A recent Sunday, Geoffrey Carter and his wife, Marion, with their 7-month-old daughter, Franziska, and his father, Norman, were gathered on the lawn of their Hudson Valley property as though for a picnic. But no one was passing sandwiches. The adults were sanding triglyphs -- the decorative blocks that punctuate the Doric frieze of a classical building. There were 63 of them. The bells, or conelike ornaments that finish the triglyphs at the bottom, had already been made. Using white cement, Carter had cast them in Dixie cups. Three guinea hens in noisy chorus crossed the yard where the family worked. Behind them was what appeared to be a Greek temple in progress.

title: Science Fiction
description: Part of the fun of reading Ursula K. Le Guin is trying to sort out the myriad historical and anthropological sources that lend weight to her densely imagined fictions. In FOUR WAYS TO FORGIVENESS (Harper Prism, $20), the immediate focus is on the neighboring worlds of Werel and Yeowe. Social organization on Werel seems to combine the least appealing traits of feudalism and capitalism; rich Werelians, known as the Owners, possess slaves known as assets. Women's lives are controlled by men. When the Werelians export their rigid plantation system to the colony world of Yeowe, the assets eventually rebel. To the astonishment of Werel's hereditary warrior class, the rebels overcome their oppressors, with the indirect assistance of the Ekumen, a federation of civilized worlds that figures in much of Ms. Le Guin's science fiction.

description: Some investors believe Netscape Communications could become "the next Microsoft." Other people believe that Netscape, the upstart Internet software company, could become the next Microsoft victim, and that the next Microsoft is none other than Microsoft itself.

description: Curators at the Edison National Historic Site say they have found a wax cylinder bearing the first known recording of Thomas Alva Edison's voice, the A.P. reported.

title: Picture This: An Alomar In Pinstripes
description: Roberto Alomar, who is attending the American League Championship Series to watch his brother, Sandy Jr., play for the Indians, said he will file for free agency after the World Series and would be interested in playing for the Yankees if they had interest in him.

title: We Must Test Mothers of Newborns for H.I.V.; No Change Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Voyage Through Moscow and the Mind
description: Unshaven, his graying hair lank and unkempt, Venichka Yerofeyev (Tom Courtenay), called Venya, has the look of a messiah who has abandoned his flock and now wants only to put his own frayed life in order. He's that special kind of serious drunk: volcanic in his feelings, but fastidious to the point of daintiness in his choice of language and gesture. It's not a matter of keeping up appearances, heaven knows, but of maintaining his bearings in a rude and careless universe.

title: METRO MATTERS;What Battered Women Would Say to Simpson: Get Some Help
description: O. J. SIMPSON says he wants to meet some battered women to talk about how he "got physical" with Nicole Brown Simpson. That raises an interesting question: What would abused women tell the country's most famous former defendant?

description: In an effort to sharpen its competitiveness in electronics, Japan is planning a large Government-financed program to develop advanced techniques for manufacturing semiconductors, displays and computers, officials said on Friday.

description: The masked guerrillas of the Zapatista National Liberation Army remained out of sight during local elections today in the southern state of Chiapas. But their impact was seen in many villages where the voting took place against a backdrop of political polarization and violence.

description: To the Editor:

title: Bosnian Village Fears 500 Captives Were Killed by Serbs
description: As many as 500 civilian men were killed or taken away as prisoners by Serbian forces in the days before the Bosnian Army captured this town last week, Muslim and Croat residents said today.

title: The New Watchdogs of Digital Commerce
description: Think of them as a truth squad of cyberspace.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knick Quiet Man Is Making Noise
description: The interview process has been long and arduous. The tryout phase has begun. Charlie Ward has never been incredibly vocal about anything, much less selling himself. He wants the job in the worst way, but he refuses to campaign with his mouth.

title: No Headline
description: I didn't want my patient contact to be mostly while they were under anesthetic. I would see these great general doctors, and their patients loved them and depended on them. I wanted that. -- DR. KRISTEN FLESS, who forsook surgery for internal medicine. [ B2:1. ]

title: Fly Away Home
description: A bird appeared. It circled once, twice, three times, then flew away. "I'll die!" Sal Spera wailed. It was the Joe Papa Futurity, crown jewel of pigeon racing for the South End District Homing Pigeon Club of Bensonhurst. First prize was $15,000, a sum multiplied by side bets complicated enough to stun a country-club hustler. Thus it was that pigeon fanciers across the metropolitan area anxiously prowled far-flung rooftops in a century-old ritual.

title: Evergreen to Buy Station
description: The Evergreen Media Corporation is planning to buy the country-music radio station WKLB-FM (105.7) of Boston from Fairbanks Communications Inc. for $34 million in cash. This year, Evergreen Media, the radio station owner based in Irving, has purchased or announced plans to purchase 25 radio stations, bringing its total to 36 stations. Evergreen said it expected to close the WKLB purchase in the first quarter of 1996.

title: Bridge
description: Two American teams survived in the Bermuda Bowl contest at the Marlboro World Championships here today, but the focus was on another quarterfinal match. It was heartache for the Chinese supporters, who watched in the Viewgraph theater as their young team played brilliantly against an experienced French squad. China led by 9 imps with four deals remaining, but then lost 10, very unluckily, and lost the 96-deal match by 3.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;Wuerffel Keeps His Poise, and the Gators Keep Winning
description: On the road, in the noise, on a wet field, Danny Wuerffel's first two possessions were about as bad as bad can get. Wuerffel fumbled a snap the first time the Florida Gators had the ball, a mistake created by the noise at Auburn, and the touchdown on the fumble return left the Gators behind after 25 seconds. Then came an interception, an Auburn field goal, and a 10-0 Florida problem.

title: Not All May Enter Brave New E-World
description: To the Editor:

title: Eisenhower Was Horrified by Interstates
description: To the Editor:

title: Fall Foliage
description: The leaves are past their prime in Vermont, but these notable Central Park trees are just reaching peak color. Estimates for individual trees, however, are highly speculative. Columbus Day is usually peak time in New York, but because of the drought, the peak is coming later and may be less spectacular. Some trees, like the American elms have already dropped a few leaves.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Jesuit Installed as College Head
description: Thirty years ago, a young Jesuit taught his first class, in philosophy, at St. Peter's College. Today, after a long academic career at various Roman Catholic colleges, that Jesuit, the Rev. James N. Loughran, starts his first day as president of the 3,500-student school. Father Loughran, 55, was installed on Saturday.

title: HOCKEY;Domi Must Explain His Knockout Punch
description: Facing the possibility of a long suspension as a result of his attack on the Rangers' Ulf Samuelsson on Saturday night, Tie Domi of the Toronto Maple Leafs will explain himself to National Hockey League authorities at a formal hearing. It will take place either today or tomorrow, possibly in New York, perhaps in Toronto.

title: Gloomy Day for the Islanders
description: The Islanders have had enough trouble winning without adding a travel odyssey to their roadblocks. Inclement weather prevented them from flying here Saturday night, and New York didn't arrive for its game against the Florida Panthers until midafternoon today.

title: An Old Sport, Still Aloft
description: Sal Spera paced his roof, squinting at a steely October sky. He waited, fidgeted, phoned other roofs and dreamed of one of his 11 pigeons hurtling out of the heavens and winning everything.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The last time DANIELE BARIONI, an Italian tenor who was a highly regarded singer at the Metropolitan Opera in the 1950's, and JOE LOMBARDO , an insurance broker, saw each other, it was at Mr. Lombardo's wedding in June 1967.

title: Taking In the Sites;  A Bit of Critical Guidance, When Serendipity Won't Do
description: Quantity or quality? On the World Wide Web, the distinction can be difficult to draw.

title: Frank Lilly, a Geneticist, 65; Member of National AIDS Panel
description: Dr. Frank Lilly, a geneticist at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx and one of the first openly gay Presidential appointees, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 65.

title: Man Dies in a Fall at Detectives' Office
description: A 24-year-old man fell or jumped to his death yesterday from the fifth-floor window of a police detectives' office on Staten Island, where he was being questioned about two burglaries, a spokeswoman for the Police Department said.

title: Newspapers Cut Spanish-Language Publications
description: In the last few years, the surge in the country's Hispanic population and the success of Spanish-language radio and television have caused newspaper publishers across the nation to try to cash in. Start new Spanish supplements and Spanish editions, they ordered. Then they sat back to wait for the advertisements and dollars to roll in.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: MORE DOCTORS CHOOSE GENERAL PRACTICE Facing a marketplace glutted with out-of-work specialists and managed-care companies beckoning for general practitioners, young doctors are increasingly choosing careers in which they will tend to patients' basic health needs. Three years ago, 14.6 percent of the seniors in the country's medical schools wanted to become general internists, general pediatricians or family practice physicians, the lowest percentage in history.

title: Pinter Confronts His Shadows
description: With a newly grown mustache, and wearing a black shirt and black jacket, Harold Pinter looked as if he had stepped out of a film noir. His appearance was in keeping with his role as the head of a mental hospital in his dark comedy "The Hothouse." A revival of that play recently opened in London after a summer's engagement at the Chichester Festival.

title: We Must Test Mothers of Newborns for H.I.V.
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert F. Korns, 82, Researcher Who Helped Test Polio Vaccine
description: Robert F. Korns, an epidemiologist and former assistant commissioner of the New York State Department of Health who helped direct the nationwide field trial of the Salk polio vaccine during the early 1950's, died on Oct. 3, a day before his 83d birthday. He lived in Glenmont, N.Y.

title: In America;Harmony or Discord?
description: Martin Luther King's dream was on television last week, and will be on again tonight.

title: In Paris, the Outsiders Are Officially In
description: It is a season that will be remembered as the official changing of the guard, when one-time fashion outsiders stole center stage from an older generation of French houses. As Helmut Lang's show began and Madonna swept in and people were muttering about tidbits of Mr. Lang's life from his November Vanity Fair magazine profile, it was obvious that, for the first time, this show had become part of the nucleus.

title: A Visitor Of Substance
description: The big news at the New York Philharmonic concert on Thursday evening was that the audience greeted a living composer, Eino Tamberg of Estonia, not only warmly but also enthusiastically. The response was largely warranted, although Mr. Tamberg's Concerto Grosso of 1956 may have seemed inordinately grand for being the only substantial work on the program, at least after the destruction of Rachmaninoff's Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini.

title: For the Hard of Hearing, A Dose of Digital Audio
description: Digital audio is headed for a new market, where computer-tuned sound could find its most eager audience yet: the hard of hearing.

title: Apple Rejects Request to Put Operating System on I.B.M.'s
description: Apple Computer Inc. has rejected a request by a small Swiss company to license its version of the Macintosh operating system for use on computers made by the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: More Illegal Immigrants Released Since Melee Shut New Jersey Jail
description: Almost four months after a New Jersey detention center for illegal immigrants was closed by a melee, the number of aliens detained at New York area airports has dropped sharply, largely because immigration officials who have little space to hold detainees are allowing them to go free if they promise to return for hearings.

title: 'Gump Fiction' vs. Stars Vs. Parody of Talk Shows
description: "Be a clown," the song says. "All the world loves a clown." But it ain't easy. The competition is fierce, especially on television these days, as cable comedy specials go up against network sitcoms, and upstarts like Fox take aim even at the NBC institution "Saturday Night Live."

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit on Saturday with the obituary of Jack D. Weiler, philanthropist and real estate developer, carried an incorrect date. The picture was made in 1985, not 1965.

title: Bridge
description: Two American teams survived in the Bermuda Bowl contest at the Marlboro World Championships here today, but the focus was on another quarterfinal match. It was heartache for the Chinese supporters, who watched in the Viewgraph theater as their young team played brilliantly against an experienced French squad. China led by 9 imps with four deals remaining, but then lost 10, very unluckily, and lost the 96-deal match by 3.

title: Company Takes Over Unloading At Market
description: With a dozen displaced workers looking on angrily, and under a heavy police guard, a newly hired company began unloading fish and seafood last night in the latest phase of the city's campaign to rid the Fulton Fish Market of organized crime.

title: Clinton Asks Men to Pledge Not to Strike Women
description: President Clinton called on the nation's men on Saturday to pledge to "never, never lift a hand against a woman for as long as we live."

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Students in Million Man March
description: Students at Trenton High School will be permitted to skip classes today to participate in the Million Man March in Washington, The Associated Press reported. Last week, the Camden school board voted to close the city's schools because many employees had requested the day off.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;D.M.B.& B. revamps its board to more closely resemble the real world of advertising.
description: D'ARCY MASIUS BENTON & BOWLES is significantly revamping its board by adding creative, international and female executives.

title: Sports of The Times;Steinbrenner Trapped In a Mets Time Warp
description: DOWN in Port St. Lucie, on Florida's Atlantic coast, the spirit of renewal is in the humid air.

title: Italy's Hopes for Political Reform Give Way to the 'Interim' Reality
description: If Italian politics has a Holy Grail, it is a two-party system -- a seductive idea that promises clear-cut electoral choices, coherent parliamentary majorities and, with luck, governments that stay in office more than a year.

title: Car in Tipper Gore's Motorcade Stoned in Haiti
description: Angry Haitians stoned a vehicle in Tipper Gore's motorcade today, smashing its windows and injuring an American soldier, United States officials said.

title: Midas Switches To Thompson
description: Two consumer product marketers are changing agencies.

title: Mr. Chirac's Troubled Start
description: Jacques Chirac's presidency of France began last spring with a burst of energy and high public expectations. But the initial mood was deflated when the new Government could not deliver on its beguiling campaign promises of swift and painless economic revival. Mr. Chirac, whose term runs until 2002, still has plenty of time to turn things around. But he needs to begin making the tough economic policy decisions he evaded as a candidate and in his first few months.

title: Multimedia Ventures Pursue Different Paths
description: Steven A. Weiswasser and Howard Stringer plan to have lunch this week to compare notes on their new jobs. Mr. Weiswasser, a longtime executive at Capital Cities/ABC, just took the helm of a new programming venture started by four telephone companies and Walt Disney. Mr. Stringer, late of CBS, joined a similar venture eight months ago.

title: With the Gawkers Gone, Martha's Vineyard Goes Fishin'
description: When the Simpson verdict was announced, Janet Messineo was fishing.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Colts Power Their Way To Year's Biggest Upset
description: A field goal in overtime decided the first Colts game, a loss to Cincinnati. A field goal in overtime decided the second Colts game, a victory over the Jets. And a field goal in overtime had decided the last Colts game, a stirring victory over Miami.

title: Making the Law Colorblind
description: Earlier this month, a troubling report by the Washington-based Sentencing Project, a research organization, showed that 1 in 3 black men in their 20's are either imprisoned or are on probation or parole. In the midst of much soul-searching over this figure, part of the explanation for it has received insufficient attention: disparities in Federal drug laws.

title: Debate on March, and Farrakhan, Persists as Black Men Converge on the Capital
description: A stream of black men began arriving here today for the Million Man March conceived as a demonstration of black unity, even as many prominent supporters of the rally continued to wrestle with the debate that has sprung up over the role of the event's chief organizer, Louis Farrakhan.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is limited to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING

title: Shuttle Delayed Again
description: Cloudy weather today prevented launching of the space shuttle Columbia on a 16-day science mission, tying, at six, the record number of delays for a shuttle mission. The next attempt will be on Thursday, officials said. The problems also forced the delay of the scheduled Nov. 1 launching of the shuttle Atlantis to about Nov. 10.

title: In Arizona Politics, a Personal Fiscal Crisis
description: Despite his name, J. Fife Symington 3d, and his social pedigree as a great-grandson of the New York coal baron Henry Clay Frick, the saga of Arizona's Governor sounds more like South America than Southwest United States.

title: HOCKEY;Devils Erase a Deficit And Stay Undefeated
description: The Devils fell behind tonight for the first time this season, but the outcome remained the same: They rallied to beat the Buffalo Sabres by 4-3 and remain undefeated.

description: To the Editor:

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;'Murder of the Century,' And It Happened in 1906
description: Murder of the Century"? Can PBS be succumbing to O. J.-itis? No fear. It's another murder, and practically another century.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Jets Are Beyond Help After Hitting Bottom
description: The Jets hit one of those low points today that define their franchise history far more than the Super Bowl victory of another generation.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today for Shemini Atzereth, which concludes the harvest festival of Succoth, and tomorrow for Simchas Torah, which ends the annual cycle of the public reading of the Torah. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: AUSTERE FUTURE LOOMS FOR F.A.A.
description: The Federal Aviation Administration, struggling to keep order in the crowded sky and falling years behind schedule in modernizing air traffic control equipment, is facing a Congress that demands it do better in the future with a budget billions of dollars smaller, even as air traffic is expected to grow sharply.

title: Specialty or General Practice: Young Doctors Change Paths
description: Kristen Fless grew up certain that she would become a surgeon. She got top grades at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, shining evaluations from her teachers and strong encouragement that a coveted surgical residency was hers for the asking.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets View Exhibition Victory as First Step
description: It was a preseason game in which the opposition employed only a few of its star players. Still, when you have tasted success as rarely as the Nets have over the last 12 months, you can be excused for some giddiness.

title: We Must Test Mothers of Newborns for H.I.V.;It's Not Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents;In the struggle to alleviate the pain of rheumatoid arthritis, a doctor says he  has taken a step forward.
description: A NUMBER of drug companies are pressing to develop an inflammation-blocking drug that will alleviate, without side effects, the symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis, a chronic disease that afflicts two million Americans. Such a drug could be worth hundreds of millions of dollars annually and might be prescribed to treat other autoimmune diseases like multiple sclerosis.

title: Once a Disgraced Senator, Dodd Gets a Presidential Salute
description: Surrounded by the heirs and archives of a Democratic dynasty, President Clinton came to this Connecticut college town today for a sentimental tribute to Thomas J. Dodd, whose career took him from work as a prosecutor at the Nuremberg war trials to censure by his colleagues in the United States Senate before his death a quarter-century ago.

title: Book Deals: Losing Nothing in Translation
description: Just before 10 o'clock on the opening morning of Frankfurt's annual book fair, Marcella Berger took a last sip of coffee from her Styrofoam cup, armed herself with a smile and greeted the two Italian editors waiting to discuss Simon & Schuster's coming books.

title: Patients Pay High Price in Cuba's War on AIDS
description: The doctor knocked at Raidel Burgos's home early one summer afternoon, interrupting lunch. He said there was a problem at the lab where Mr. Burgos had gone for a blood test after one of his friends was found to have AIDS.

description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

title: Panel Presses to Combat Drug Use in Pregnancy
description: Every year for the last five years, a special panel of experts on child abuse has urged New York City's Human Resources Administration to view drug use by pregnant women as proof of child maltreatment. Every year, the administration has declined, arguing that drug-taking alone does not constitute abuse.

title: Eisenhower Was Horrified by Interstates
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Stocks Higher
description: Stocks traded higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 226 issues was up 135.61 points, or 0.76 percent, at 18,016.44. On Friday, the Nikkei fell 90.57 points, or a half-percent.

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit on Saturday with the obituary of Jack D. Weiler, philanthropist and real estate developer, carried an incorrect date. The picture was made in 1985, not 1965.

title: At Lacroix Show, Excess Is a Minus
description: The sequins glittered, the fabrics glowed, the lace was exquisite and the embroidery sublime. Yet for all its resplendent elements, the collection Christian Lacroix showed here today did not add up.

title: Trimming 110 Livingston Street
description: Like many chancellors before him, Dr. Rudolph Crew has swept into New York promising an instant transformation at the Board of Education headquarters, with staff cuts and transfers beginning the minute he walks through the door. His instincts are the right ones. With crowded schools and classrooms, there is a continuing need to chop down the support bureaucracy and put employees back into teaching.

title: PLAYOFFS '95;Braves' Pitching Turns Foes' Bats Into Sawdust
description: The last National League team in the World Series, the pitching-poor 1993 Philadelphia Phillies, were anything but armed and ready.

title: PLAYOFFS '95;After 41 Years, Power and Pitching Pull Indians Within a Game
description: Jim Thome's swing was majestic. He had spied a 2-0 fastball from Chris Bosio and sent it sailing into the second deck in right field for a two-run home run. He flipped the black bat aside, pumped his fist and raised his arms high as he rounded first base. The result of his work was magical to the Indians because it enabled them to beat the Mariners tonight, 3-2, in Game 5 of the American League Championship Series.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Position Available: Must Play Quarterback
description: The first sign that something was up came when Giants quarterback Dave Brown stood on the sideline with a baseball cap on. Since Brown does not play first base for the Yankees, there was definitely something wrong with this picture. It was the third quarter, the Giants were trailing by 8 points and Coach Dan Reeves was looking for something to spark his team.

description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said it had reached a settlement with the Government of the Philippines that ends litigation over an idled nuclear-power plant and lifts that nation's ban on Westinghouse products.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PEGGY NOONAN, the author and speechwriter for Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush, is aiming her pointed pen in a new direction. She will write a monthly column for Good Housekeeping magazine starting with the January issue, ELLEN LEVINE , editor in chief of the magazine, said.

title: Corrections
description: The caption with a picture from Agence France-Presse yesterday, about bodies of civilians found in Sanski Most, Bosnia, misidentified them. They were those of Muslims, not Serbs.

title: Loporot Journal;Fiercest of Warriors, Crushed by a Savage Land
description: On the dry riverbed here, the wind whipped up the sand and blasted it against the palm trees, tugging at the loose piece of cloth that Ekuwam Lotukoi uses to cover his muscular body.

title: GUERRILLAS KILL 6 ISRAELI SOLDIERS IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: Six Israeli soldiers were killed and a seventh was wounded today in the deadliest attack by Muslim guerrillas in southern Lebanon this year.

title: R. L. Solomon, 77, Pioneer Psychologist
description: Richard L. Solomon, an experimental psychologist, scientist and a professor, died on Thursday in Boston at age 77. The cause of death was complications from cardiac surgery, said his brother, David Solomon.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Asking Big Questions On Science and Meaning
description: FIRE IN THE MIND Science, Faith And the Search for Order By George Johnson 379 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50.

description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: A close call for Business Week shows the weakness in journalists' protective armor.
description: PROTECTING confidential informants by not disclosing their identities is a foundation of a free press. Protecting journalists from prosecution for not disclosing such informants' identities is a far more ambiguous matter, however, as reporters and editors at Business Week are now keenly aware.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer malfunction, part of an article yesterday about President Clinton's weekly radio address was replaced in some copies by extraneous material from an article about college football. A corrected copy of the article appears today on page B5.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Motor Vehicles Head Dismissed
description: The director of the Division of Motor Vehicles in Elizabeth was dismissed last week after she was accused of abusing her position when she was charged with driving while intoxicated, the A.P. reported. The director, Zoila Castillo, threatened to have a police officer's driving record altered and to erase from her own record any mention of her Oct. 8 arrest, agency officials said.

title: The 'Season' in New York
description: "I always think of this as the start of the season," an audience member said as the curtains parted on the first entry of the New York Film Festival a few weeks ago. She did not mean the film season. Or the going-to-Lincoln-Center season. She meant the season when New Yorkers make lists of things to see and begin to wonder whether this tenor or that director can live up to the hype.

title: Western Voices Break Into the Debate Over Sterling Forest
description: For more than a decade, there have been two competing visions for Sterling Forest, the privately owned woodland that blankets an area the size of Manhattan with hemlock and alder, providing a home to black bears and otters and even a few rare northern cricket frogs.

title: CD-ROM's Are the Latest in Corporate Training
description: Many workdays at noontime, Holly Grady sits at the computer in the employee lunchroom at the Fred Meyer discount superstore here, munching a homemade sandwich and tapping a touchscreen.

title: ON BASEALL;Indians Make a Strong Pitch, Too
description: As the Indians moved one victory away from winning the American League championship last night, the specter of scoreless World Series games loomed larger.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Panthers Savor a Franchise First
description: Carolina center Curtis Whitley headed for the shower tonight puffing a cigar.

title: A Fascination With Things American
description: In a Germany already flush with American influence, this banking center on the Main River is so dominated by new office buildings and English-language signs that locals often refer to it disparagingly as "Mainhattan."

title: Sports of The Times;The Giants' Problem: No QB and No Touchdowns
description: IT'S as if the Giants were a car without an engine or a jetliner without fuel. They're a football team without a quarterback.

title: Carnegie Hall Introduces Itself to the Young
description: On Saturday afternoon, Richard Stoltzman took the stage at Carnegie Hall as the featured performer, as he has often done. This time, however, he didn't enter solemnly from stage right. Instead, after the lights were dimmed, he strolled down the right aisle from the back of the hall to the front, took a left, then went up the steps to the stage, all the while playing "The Swan" from Saint-Saens's "Carnival of the Animals" on his clarinet.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Hearing on Campaign Donations
description: In 1993, limits were placed on the amount of money individuals and groups can give to candidates for the Legislature and for county and local offices. The Election Law Enforcement Commission will hold a hearing on Friday to determine what effect the law has had on elections and on campaign donations. Under the law, individuals and groups can give up to $1,500 to a candidate in each primary or general election. Political action committees can give $5,000 to each candidate in each election.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Changes in Divorce Law Studied
description: A State Senate committee will meet on Thursday to consider whether New Jersey's divorce laws should be changed, so that a parent who does not have custody would no longer be forced to pay for a child's college education. The proposal is one of the more contentious recommendations made this year by a legislative commission that studied the existing divorce laws. The bill has already passed the Assembly.

title: Dole Builds Loyal, if Uninspired, Support

title: Helen Vlachos, Greek Publisher And Foe of the Junta, Dies at 85
description: Helen Vlachos, a publisher who closed her newspapers and fled Greece rather than submit to censorship under the military junta that ruled from 1967 to 1974, died on Saturday, Reuters reported yesterday from Athens, quoting officials at the press ministry. She was 85.

title: Police Labs Under a Microscope
description: The potential value of DNA evidence as an identification tool in criminal cases has been clear for a decade. A person's highly individual genetic code is carried in the DNA of every cell. But the bumbling of the scientific evidence in the O. J. Simpson case highlighted glaring deficiencies in how DNA evidence gets collected and tested -- a problem, unfortunately, that is not isolated to the astonishingly inept police lab in Los Angeles.

Three years ago, 14.6 percent of the seniors in the country's medical schools wanted to become general internists, general pediatricians or family practice physicians, the lowest percentage in history.

title: No Aid for Flood Basin Buyout
description: Buyouts of 6,300 homes and businesses built in the Passaic River flood basin do not qualify for Federal financing under current rules, according to an Army Corps of Engineers report released yesterday. The buyout plan, favored by some critics of a corps proposal to build a $2 billion tunnel to divert river floodwater, would cost $2.3 billion, the report said. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, an opponent of the tunnel project, said she would "act expeditiously" on the matter once a 60-day comment period on the report ended. Governor Whitman has proposed buying 800 homes in the most heavily flood-prone areas at an estimated cost of less than $200 million.

title: Big Surplus at Newark Schools

Peter Peretzman, a spokesman for the New Jersey Board of Education, said the Newark surplus is so big that it probably exceeds limits set by state law.
