Which explains Steinbrenner's staging of the revival of the 1986 world champion Mets.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: GTE TO NOTIFY 4,700 WORKERS ABOUT LAYOFFS The GTE Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 4,700 jobs by the end of the year as part of a previously announced revamping of telephone operations that will cost a total of 17,000 jobs. Most of the 4,700 employees losing their jobs will start getting notices today. In January 1994, GTE said it would cut 17,000 jobs -- nearly a quarter of its telephone operations workers -- over three years, mostly through layoffs. By the end of this year, about 12,000 will have been cut. Telephone operations employment has dropped from 100,000 in 1988 to 68,000. The company took a $1.8 billion charge because of the layoffs in the fourth quarter of 1993. GTE has said it expects to save $1 billion a year in expenses. (AP) HEALTHSOUTH AGREES TO ACQUIRE CAREMARK UNIT The Healthsouth Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the orthopedic rehabilitation business of Caremark International Inc. for $127.5 million. Healthsouth said Caremark Orthopedic Services Inc., has more than 120 outpatient centers in 13 states. The company expects revenues of nearly $80 million this year. Healthsouth, based in Birmingham, Ala., had revenues of $1.1 billion last year and currently operates nearly 600 outpatient and rehabilitation centers. Caremark is based in Northbrook, Ill. (Dow Jones) S.E.C. REVIEW DELAYS GENENTECH's RESULTS Genentech Inc., a unit of Roche Holding Ltd., said yesterday that it had delayed the release of its third-quarter results as a result of discussions with the Securities and Exchange Commission about the accounting for its severance agreement with G. Kirk Raab, a former president and chief executive of Genentech. In July, Genentech announced Mr. Raab's ouster, citing his attempt to secure a $2 million personal loan guarantee from Roche, which owns 66 percent of Genentech's stock and has the option to buy the rest. In August, Roche extended its option for shares of Genentech. Genentech previously said it expected to incur charges against third-quarter earnings for its agreement with Roche and for its severance with Raab. "We don't want to have to change these again, so we decided to conclude the discussions with the S.E.C. before we report our earnings," a spokeswoman said. (Reuters) PENTAIR TO BUY FLECK CONTROLS AND FRENCH UNIT Pentair Inc., a maker of power tools and lubrication systems, agreed yesterday to buy Fleck Controls Inc. for about $130 million. Fleck Controls, based in Brookfield, Wis., makes valves for residential water softeners and water-conditioning systems for businesses. The deal includes Fleck Europe, the privately held company's subsidiary, based in France. Pentair, based in St. Paul, did not disclose Fleck's annual sales but said the company was profitable. Pentair sold its paper operations in the second quarter to focus on other businesses. It had 1994 sales of $1.3 billion and has about 8,700 employees. Pentair's stock rose $1.875 to $47.875 in Nasdaq trading. (Reuters) AMERICAN EXPRESS TO KEEP GLOBAL BANKING UNIT The American Express Company has ended talks with potential buyers for its global banking unit and has decided to keep the operation, which caters to wealthy clients, the company said yesterday. The company said it had been in talks with several large United States and foreign banks about selling American Express Bank. The unit also serves other banks around the world. Its revenues have lagged behind in recent quarters. American Express shares slipped 25 cents yesterday, to $44.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. (AP) LEVITZ LOSES MONTGOMERY WARD INVESTMENT OFFER The Montgomery Ward Holding Corporation has decided against investing in Levitz Furniture Inc., the companies said yesterday, leading to a selloff in the stock of Levitz, the nation's largest furniture store chain. Levitz's shares tumbled $1.375, or 24.4 percent, to $4.25 on the New York Stock Exchange. Montgomery Ward, the privately owned retailer based in Chicago, concluded that its goals and objectives could not be achieved with an investment in Levitz, the companies said in a joint statement. Levitz, based in Boca Raton, Fla., has cut about 1,000 jobs since January. Savings are expected to reach $20 million a year. Levitz has 132 furniture stores in 25 states. (Reuters) TEXAS UTILITIES STOCK RISES AFTER DIVIDEND CUT Shares of the Texas Utilities Company jumped yesterday after the company took an expected dividend cut and wrote off $802 million in impaired assets when it announced its third-quarter earnings on Friday. The electric utility's stock climbed $1.375, to $36, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The company cut its quarterly dividend to 50 cents from 77 cents a share and at least four Wall Street firms raised the company's ratings. Texas Utilities, an electricity provider based in Dallas, reported a quarterly loss of $441.7 million, or $1.96 a share, because of the write-off of uncompleted coal-fired generating units, coal reserves and other assets. (Reuters) MICROSOFT TO TEST PRODUCT SALES ON INTERNET The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that it was starting a pilot program to test sales of software over the Internet. The company said it was in negotiations with a group of several retailers for a test of electronic sales that will begin shortly and run through the end of the year. Microsoft products that will be for sale at wholesale prices as part of the program include Microsoft Word and Microsoft Flight Simulator. But analysts said the experiment would have little appeal, because of the long download time required for most programs on standard telephone modems. "The reality is that very few people buy software electronically, especially the first copy," said Jeffrey Tarter, editor and publisher of Softletter, an industry newsletter. (Reuters) SYMS SHARES DIVE AS BUYBACK OFFER WITHDRAWN The Syms Corporation's stock fell nearly 17 percent yesterday after its chairman and chief executive, Sy Syms, withdrew his offer to take the company private, saying it would cost too much. Shares of Syms, a discount apparel retailer based in Secaucus, N.J., fell $1.50, to $7.50. On Aug. 30, Mr. Syms and the other shareholders, including his daughter, Marcy Syms, president of the company, agreed to buy company shares they did not already own for $8.75 each. At that price the buyout would have cost about $31 million. The Syms family owns about 80 percent of the company. (Bloomberg Business News) MARK TWAIN BANCSHARES IN MERGER TALKS The stock of Mark Twain Bancshares Inc. jumped yesterday after the company said it was in talks about a possible merger. John P. Dubinsky, president and chief executive of the bank holding company based in St. Louis, would not comment further on the talks. Mark Twain has assets of $2.83 billion. The company has been discussed as a possible buyout candidate, particularly since recent changes in Federal banking regulations eliminated protection from out-of-state suitors for Missouri banks. Mark Twain shares jumped $2.875, to $37.875, in Nasdaq trading yesterday; the company's market value exceeded $600 million. Earlier, the shares rose to a 52-week high of $39. title: COMPANY NEWS

Most of the 4,700 employees losing their jobs will start getting notices today. In January 1994, GTE said it would cut 17,000 jobs -- nearly a quarter of its telephone operations workers -- over three years, mostly through layoffs. By the end of this year, about 12,000 will have been cut. Telephone operations employment has dropped from 100,000 in 1988 to 68,000. The company took a $1.8 billion charge because of the layoffs in the fourth quarter of 1993. GTE has said it expects to save $1 billion a year in expenses. (AP)

title: The World's Deep, Cold Sea Floors Harbor a Riotous Diversity of Life
description: FRIGID and lightless, the floors of the deep oceans have long been considered a biological desert. So it is with no little astonishment that marine biologists are now discovering that the supposed desert seethes with a riot of life. The diversity of species is so high that it may rival that of tropical rain forests, often seen as the pinnacle of biological richness.

title: Pere Ubu and the Many Faces of Rock
description: David Thomas, who performed with his band Pere Ubu on Sunday night at Wetlands, is one of rock's most eccentric figures. With a black overcoat, top hat, goatee and some 300 pounds of body weight, he looked like a collection agent for a loan shark. But in reality he is a Jehovah's Witness, with a legendary underground band that has been playing neurotically intellectual art-rock for 20 years.

title: John Walker, Washington Curator, Dies at 88
description: John Walker 3d, the patrician art connoisseur who as chief curator and then director of the National Gallery of Art in Washington shaped the museum into a world-class institution, died on Sunday at his home near Arundel in Sussex, England. He was 88 and had lived in England since his retirement from the gallery in 1969.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;For Children, a Way to Paint a Tune
description: Morton Subotnick, the pioneering composer of electronic music, has given much thought to the role of computers in the musical realm. "Now, theoretically," he remarked in a 1985 article in The New York Times, "a composer can learn music without ever having to master an instrument." Making Music, his new multimedia CD-ROM, is designed to turn that theoretical possibility into a reality, making children (and perhaps a few adults) budding composers even if they cannot tell a clef from a note. It is available from the Voyager Company, (800) 446-2001, for about $40.

title: Hopes Are Slim to Avert Fare Rise as Vote Nears
description: In late 1989, transit officials warned that the price of a subway token would have to rise from $1, to $1.25, but, lo and behold, the fare rose only to $1.15. The threat in late 1991 was $1.40; the reality in 1992 was $1.25. A year ago, a $1.40 fare was again suggested, but the blow was postponed.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Action-Packed Future for Internet
description: THE Internet's World Wide Web is a vast electronic library, made up of millions of pages of information stored in hundreds of thousands of linked computers around the globe. With the proper computer software and the right Internet connections, personal computer users can flip from page to page and browse from one electronic document to another just by pointing and clicking on the computer screen.

title: THE MARCH ON WASHINGTON: THE ORGANIZER;In the End, Farrakhan Has His Day in the Sun
description: A sea of black men at his feet, the Capitol at his back and millions watching him on cable television, Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, delivered the kind of speech today that he often makes to his religious faithful on a lazy Sunday afternoon back home in Chicago. It was part inspiration, conspiracy theory and numerology, with a good dose of black nationalism and the joys and necessity of bootstrap capitalism. He attacked white supremacy in one breath and then turned around and condemned what he called the failures of black manhood.

title: Cablevision Reins Passed By Founder
description: Charles F. Dolan has always run the Cablevision Systems Corporation like a family store -- employing all three of his sons in the cable television company. Yesterday, on his 69th birthday, Mr. Dolan turned over the reins to one of them: James L. Dolan.

title: PORT-AU-PRINCE JOURNAL;Protest Singer Is Now Mayor, but Still Protesting
description: For two decades, Manno Charlemagne has been the conscience of Haiti and the country's most admired singer, denouncing injustice, inequality and corruption with all the fervor of a biblical prophet. Good training, as it turns out, for his new job: Mayor of Port-au-Prince.

title: Market Place;Coram Healthcare surges after a reprieve from its creditors.
description: INVESTORS who bought the Coram Healthcare Corporation's shares on Friday for $3.125 found themselves with a hefty profit yesterday when Coram's creditors gave the troubled home health care company a five-month chance to straighten up. But even at yesterday's closing price of $4.75 a share, Wall Street analysts said Coram remained a risky bet.

title: Earnest Crowd, Empty Leader
description: The Million Man March produced a huge crowd hungry for great oratory. But instead of something like the crystalline 19 minutes of Martin Luther King's "I Have a Dream" speech, this crowd got a rambling, self-obsessed two hours from Louis Farrakhan. By the time the Nation of Islam leader got through such arcane matters as numerology and Masonic lore, his adjurations against violence in black neighborhoods seemed almost perfunctory. He seemed more interested in continuing his personal negotiations with the press and the Jewish community over his past racist statements than in answering the expectations that drew such a large and earnest crowd to the Mall. As his speech wore on, it was clear that the potential of the event and the opportunity to lead with a dramatic personal atonement had both escaped him.

They chanted their resolve to look after one another, to take responsibility for their lives, to become a political force and cleanse their communities of crime and drugs.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Happy Birthday, Miami City Ballet
description: The Miami City Ballet is 10 years old this season, and, surely, every dancegoer who saw it this afternoon was ready to wish it the happiest of birthdays. The company is directed by Edward Villella, the former star of the New York City Ballet, and its collective style is much like the personal style that made Mr. Villella's dancing appealing. As he did for so many years in New York, the Miami dancers are able to unite virtuosity with charm, wit and dramatic fervor.

ROGER SHOPE, regatta chairman for the annual fall series of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club in Port Washington, L.I., said that the lead bulbs on two Melges 30 yachts fell off while the sailboats were under way. Although no one was injured, the crews from both boats were forced to scramble onto their upside-down hulls to be rescued.

title: First Bank System in Index
description: The shares of First Bank System Inc. rose today after being added to the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index after the close of trading on Friday. Shares of the bank holding company, which is based in Minneapolis, rose $1.625, to $51.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Some mutual funds invest only in stocks listed in the S.& P. 500 index, and inclusion in the index broadens the number of investors likely to be interested in a company. First Bank replaced the First Mississippi Corporation, a specialty chemicals company based in Jackson, Miss., whose shares fell $1, to $39.875.

title: Surprise Source Found for Tar Balls in Alaska Spill Area

But a comprehensive new Federal investigation has found that most of the tar balls still fouling the sound's shores and islands have nothing to do with the Exxon Valdez but were formed from oil imported from California.

title: Foreign Affairs;Egypt Runs for The Train
description: John Page, the World Bank's chief Middle East economist, likes to say that the difference between the global economy of the 1950's and the 1990's is the difference between two trains. The global economy of the 1950's, he says, "was like the old train from Heliopolis [a Cairo suburb] to Cairo. That train stopped at every station, and if you missed one, you could always catch another. It was so slow that if you missed the last one, you could ride your bike and catch up at the next station. If you couldn't afford a ticket, you could always ride on the roof. The global economy of the 1990's, by contrast, is like the bullet train from Tokyo to Osaka. If you miss it, it's gone -- goodbye -- and you can't catch up."

Compumed, which is based in Manhattan Beach, Calif., said in a Federal filing that it would get between $2 and $4 a test under its agreement with Merck, which runs from 1996 to 2000.

title: Prognosis Is Good for Bills' Levy

There is a 60 percent to 80 percent chance the surgery will result in a complete cure if the tumor was confined to the prostate, said Dr. ROBERT HUBEN, chairman of the urologic oncology department at Roswell Park. Levy is expected to stay in the hospital about a week, and hopes to rejoin the Bills on Nov. 12 for their game against Atlanta. The assistant head coach, ELIJAH PITTS, has stepped in for Levy until he recovers from the surgery. (AP)

description: NEW YORK CITY A SALUTE TO A HARBOR OASIS When Capt. Kevin Ray first heard eight years ago that he would be transferred from his Coast Guard posting in New Orleans to Governors Island, at the foot of Manhattan, his heart plummeted like an anchor. But as word spread around the hushed, campus-like haven of Governors Island that the Coast Guard had decided to close the base after 29 years, Captain Ray allowed that there were more than a few things he would miss about the place. [ B3. ] CAMPAIGN TO AVERT FARE RISE HEATS UP The last-ditch campaign to avert a 25-cent transit fare increase heated up as a State Assembly member from Queens, in protest, blocked $280 million worth of transportation capital projects. [ B3. ] CHANCELLOR OUTLINES PLANS TO CUT STAFF New York City's new Schools Chancellor outlined his plan to drain the system's central administration, saying he was planning to reassign or lay off "a considerable portion" of the 3,300 people who work for him at headquarters. [ B6. ] JUDGE TO RECONSIDER CROWN HTS. RULING A Federal appeals court directed a judge to reconsider whether to try a young man as an adult or a juvenile in a civil rights case stemming from the 1991 stabbing of a Hasidic scholar in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. [ B4. ] TWO FOOD MOGULS CONCOCT A MERGER In a culinary collaboration joining two of the nation's most prominent restaurateurs, Warner LeRoy, the owner of Tavern on the Green, and David Bouley, an owner and the chef at Bouley, will join forces. [ C1. ] REGION RACING POSSIBLE FOR STEWART In Newburgh, N.Y., an economically languishing area 60 miles north of Manhattan, racing enthusiasts are revved up like 500-horsepower hot rods at the news that a mysterious group of promoters wants to build a $70 million automobile race track right next door, inside the vast Stewart International Airport property. [ B7. ] PROBLEMS PERSIST AT INDIAN POINT 3 For nearly two and a half years, the Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant in Buchanan, N.Y., was shut down for a complete overhaul of its management and operating procedures. Now, three months after the plant resumed generating power, potentially dangerous management problems persist, officials said. [ B7. ] POLICE SEEK CLUES IN A DISAPPEARANCE It was a week ago that Anna Cabezas last heard from her husband, Kleber, when he called to say he was heading home from his job as a handyman at a children's center in Queens. His white van was found the next morning in West New York, N.J., but not Mr. Cabezas. [ B7. ] WOMAN TELLS POLICE SHE SHOT HER RAPIST Last month, the Suffolk County police found the body of Imagio Santana lying on a street corner in Brentwood. He had been fatally shot. Homicide detectives arrested a 21-year-old woman who told them she lured Mr. Santana to the street corner and shot him to death because he had raped her. [ B7. ] GORE VISITS DEMOCRATS IN NEW JERSEY Vice President Gore traveled to mostly Democratic Hudson County, N.J., to denounce right-wing extremism in Congress and sound some themes for the Presidential campaign. [ B6. ]

AT&T PLANS TO SELL PARADYNE SUBSIDIARY
description: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it was putting its Paradyne unit up for sale. Paradyne, based in Largo, Fla., develops and makes products that provide network access for multimedia communications like modems. It has annual sales of about $300 million, less than 1 percent of the $75 billion in 1994 sales for AT&T. "By separating from AT&T, Paradyne avoids possible conflicts in selling to AT&T's competitors," said John Berndt, president of AT&T multimedia ventures and technologies. In August, AT&T announced a restructuring of Paradyne, saying that it would cut 225 jobs and offer an additional 750 employees jobs in other AT&T businesses.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER REJECTS ANOTHER BID BY MOORE
description: Wallace Computer Services Inc. said yesterday that it had rejected the Moore Corporation's sweetened $1.4 billion hostile takeover bid as too low, citing strong growth prospects. The board of Wallace, based in Hillside, Ill., met Tuesday night to decide on the bid, which Moore sweetened to $60 a share, up from $56 on Oct. 12. The offer expires Nov. 3. Wallace said it was worth more than $60 a share and cited a forecast of a 50 percent increase in first-quarter earnings and a 33 percent rise for the fiscal year. Moore, of Toronto, had threatened to end attempts to acquire Wallace if "a significant percentage" of Wallace stockholders did not tender their shares before Nov. 3.

description: Amre Inc. said yesterday that it would market its home-improvement services under the name Century 21 as part of a 20-year contract licensing the name from HFS Inc., the owner of the Century 21 real estate brokerage operation. title: Acquisition by Conmed
description: The Conmed Corporation, based in Utica, agreed this week to acquire substantially all of the business and assets of New Dimensions in Medicine Inc., except for its international wound-care business, for about $32 million in cash. New Dimensions said it had terminated its previously reported discussions with Tyco International Inc. because it believed the Conmed transaction would result in significantly higher value to its shareholders. New Dimensions expects to distribute about $5 a share to its shareholders from the Conmed transaction and the sale of its international wound-care business to another buyer.

title: Starts Fell For Housing Last Month
description: The rate at which builders broke ground on homes slowed in September for a second month, the Government said today, while new unemployment claims rose last week. The data underlined the economic expansion's slow pace.

title: For Children
description: There are no typical children in New York City, but there are plenty of children doing typical things. A random sample found that some young New Yorkers spend their weekends going to movies, shopping, watching television, playing soccer or baseball, visiting museums and running around in the neighborhood park. They also do offbeat things: Max Beron, for example, who is 7 and lives in SoHo, studied the panpipe, the primitive reed instrument. Here is what children from three families say they like to do on the weekend. Carla and Julio Barrios Fordham, the Bronx

description: The New Jersey State Senate held its first voting session since June today to pass a package of laws that would deal more harshly with youthful offenders, deny worker's compensation payments to illegal aliens and deny state business to any company that employs illegal aliens.

description: Attention deficit disorder is the mouthful of a name for a collection of symptoms -- particularly an inability to focus on schoolwork -- that is said to be afflicting two million American children and spreading fast.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: M.T.A. VOTE RAISES TRANSIT FARES After a year of diminishing city, state and Federal support, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's board voted to raise New York City subway and bus fares 20 percent, to $1.50, and increase most Long Island and Metro-North railroad fares 9 percent. [Page A1.] With the fare increases, New York's political hierarchy decided to join the rest of America in putting tax cutting ahead of everything else. Metro Matters by Joyce Purnick. [B4.] The fare increase, experts say, will ripple through the New York regional economy in ways unpredictable -- but if thousands more cars are driven, they say, the cost will be heavy. [B4.]

title: GILLETTE AGREES TO BUY A MAKER OF EAR THERMOMETERS
description: The Gillette Company agreed to buy Thermoscan Inc., a maker of infrared ear thermometers, for $105 million in cash, Thermoscan said yesterday. Thermoscan, based in San Diego, makes thermometers that measure body temperature by measuring the light energy generated by the eardrum and surrounding tissues. As part of the transaction, Gillette will assume an unspecified amount of debt. Gillette, which is based in Boston, will merge Thermoscan with a subsidiary.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A Federal jury in Los Angeles made CLINT EASTWOOD's day when it ruled yesterday that a report about him in The National Enquirer had been fabricated and awarded him $150,000, The Associated Press reported.

title: FILM REVIEW;Jean Valjean and Nazis
description: With impressive ambition but less finesse, Claude Lelouch's "Miserables" tries to emphasize the timelessness of Victor Hugo's "Miserables" by transposing it to different times. Mr. Lelouch has re-imagined Hugo's Jean Valjean as an illiterate French boxer named Fortin, enlisting Jean-Paul Belmondo to give this conceit something more than mere literary cachet. Fortin is meant to come gradually to an understanding of Hugo's masterwork, which he enjoys having read to him. "Tell me about Jean Valjean," he says on several occasions. "People always say I'm like him."

description: Every four years, a group of citizens is asked to form a commission to examine the salaries of New York City's mayor, City Council and other local elected officials. title: Review/Fashion;Lagerfeld Proves His Staying Power at Chanel
description: There are designers who revel in their provinciality. They speak one language and surround themselves with sycophants of their own nationality, so isolated by their celebrity they rarely go out. Regaled in their homelands, they turn their backs on what is outside and worry very little about how their clothes fit the changing world. They are self-referential to a fault. These are the designers who are plunging into irrelevance.

description: The Philadelphia Phillies want JIM FREGOSI to manage through the 1997 season, so General Manager LEE THOMAS intends to pick up his option year. The National League team also picked the former Red Sox manager BUTCH HOBSON to take over its Class AAA farm team in Wilkes-Barre-Scranton next season.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Hollywood Innocent Who's Anything But
description: IF you'd like to know who Chili Palmer is, he has a solid answer: "I'm the one telling you how it is." That describes not only the no-baloney hero of Elmore Leonard's "Get Shorty," played to suave perfection by John Travolta in Barry Sonnenfeld's bright new movie, but also Mr. Leonard himself. The author's sardonic voice has been lost in most films based on his fiction, but this one nicely captures that unruffled Leonard authority. And since "Get Shorty" is about Hollywood, it invites the sneaky self-mockery that gives this film its comic punch.

title: F.B.I. Director Says Agency Blundered in Idaho Standoff
description: Contrite and somber, Louis J. Freeh told a Senate panel today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had blundered in the deadly standoff at Ruby Ridge, Idaho, and that as Director of the bureau he had committed a serious misjudgment when he disciplined, and then promoted, a close associate involved in the incident.

title: HORSE RACING: NOTEBOOK;Filly Challenge Fizzles Amid Specter of Cigar

title: Greenspan Says Fears Over Jobs Have Held Down Wage Growth
description: Americans who feel that the economic recovery has not done much for their paychecks had their worries confirmed today by an unlikely official: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve.

title: Alitalia's Board Ousts an Executive
description: The managing director of Alitalia S.p.A., Roberto Schisano, was relieved of his duties yesterday by the board. The board said the move was a result of the "progressive deterioration" of the company's financial position compared with initial expectations, Alitalia said. Renato Riverso, currently Alitalia's chairman, will assume Mr. Schisano's position.

title: Tucker Award Concert
description: Hildegard Behrens, Renee Fleming, Denyce Graves, Dmitri Hvorostovsky, Kristjan Johannsson, Sherrill Milnes, Carol Vaness and Dolora Zajick are to sing arias by Bizet, Puccini, Mascagni, Verdi and others during the Richard Tucker Music Foundation concert on Sunday at 6 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall. The 1995 Richard Tucker Award winner, Paul Groves, will also sing. Steven Mercurio is to conduct members of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and the New York Choral Society, and Robert Merrill, the guest of honor, is to offer reminiscences about the foundation's namesake, a longtime colleague, who died in 1975.

description: Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, blocked all ambassadorial appointments again today, charging that the Administration had not taken seriously his proposal to reorganize the foreign policy bureaucracy.

title: Hills Stores Names Chief
description: The Hills Stores Company named E. Jackson Smailes chief executive today, continuing a shift in management brought on by a proxy fight for control of the company this summer. Several top Hills executives, including Mr. Smailes, resigned in July when the investment group Dickstein Partners Inc. won control of the retail chain's board. But Mr. Smailes, who had been an executive vice president, soon after accepted an offer to return and run the company. Since then, he has served as president and acting chief executive. Hills Stores, based in Canton, Mass., is a regional discount retailer operating 159 stores in the Midwest and Mid-Atlantic regions.

title: MAYTAG TO INCREASE DIVIDEND AND BUY BACK SHARES

The appliance manufacturer will now pay a quarterly dividend of 14 cents a share, up from 12.5 cents The dividend will be paid on Dec. 15 to shareholders of record as of Dec. 1. Maytag said it planned to buy back up to 10.8 million of its 108 million shares currently outstanding. The shares rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $18.75, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

description: The American General Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Independent Insurance Group Inc. for $27.50 a share, or $362 million. Independent, which is based in Jacksonville, Fla., and is the parent company of the Independent Life and Accident Insurance Company, said its shareholders can receive $27.50 in cash, American General common stock or American General preferred stock. No more than 50 percent of the shares may be converted into cash, and no more than 50 percent may be converted into preferred stock. Independent's stock shot up $3.25, to $26.25, in Nasdaq trading. American General's shares were up 62.5 cents, at $38.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. American General, based in Houston, is a financial services company that has been following a strategy of growing through acquisitions.

title: Whiling Away the Day At the Shopping Center
description: Steeped in comics, television shows, theme park rides and junk food, the slackers in Kevin Smith's "Mallrats" have found the ideal place to while away their time. They roam a New Jersey shopping center with the same jokey contentiousness that animated Mr. Smith's "Clerks" and turned the director into a convenience-store Cinderella. No longer working at the Quick Stop where he shot "Clerks" for lunch money, Mr. Smith now finds himself in a bigger arena, with props, sets, color film and even the Easter Bunny as a walk-on extra. METRO DIGEST
description: M.T.A. VOTE RAISES TRANSIT FARES After a year of diminishing city, state and Federal support, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's board voted to raise New York City subway and bus fares 20 percent, to $1.50, and increase most Long Island and Metro-North railroad fares 9 percent. [ Page A1. ] With the fare increases, New York's political hierarchy decided to join the rest of America in putting tax cutting ahead of everything else. Metro Matters by Joyce Purnick. [ B4. ] The fare increase, experts say, will ripple through the New York regional economy in ways unpredictable -- but if thousands more cars are driven, they say, the cost will be heavy. [ B4. ] CHANCELLOR TAKES OVER 16 SCHOOLS On his fourth day as Chancellor of the New York City Schools, Dr. Rudy Crew said he was taking direct control of the city's 16 most troubled schools, where a vast majority of children cannot read at grade level. [ A1. ] Often, in a bad school, a weak principal coexists with a patronage-ridden local school board, making a turnaround doubly difficult. [ B7. ] AT 50, U.N. STILL A STRANGER IN NEW YORK On Tuesday, the United Nations celebrates the 50th anniversary of the ratification of its charter. It celebrates, too, its long association with New York, a relationship that began in great hope but has since been tempered by the realities of politics and parking tickets. [ A1. ] NEW YORK CITY FERRY SERVICE TO AIRPORTS? Transportation officials are looking closely at starting ferry services to smooth the way of travelers between Manhattan and La Guardia and Kennedy airports. [ B3. ] 4 BOROUGHS STILL PROTEST SEX ZONING Residents and politicians from all the boroughs except Manhattan argued that proposed zoning changes for sex-related businesses did not go far enough to protect their communities from the spread of such activities. [ B3. ] COALITION FIGHTS SALE OF WNYC-TV A petition asking the Federal Communications Commission to block the transfer of WNYC-TV's license from the City of New York to two corporations has been filed by a coalition that broadcasts on the station. [ B3. ] REGION SENATE VOTES IN NEW JERSEY The New Jersey State Senate held its first voting session since June to pass a package of laws that would deal more harshly with young offenders and illegal immigrants. [ B6. ] PATAKI AIDE CRITICIZES CUOMO AGENCIES The election for Governor may be nearly a year past, the campaign buttons consigned to the memorabilia pile, but the Pataki and Cuomo people were at it again. [ B6. ] GLEN COVE STARTS SUPERFUND CLEANUP After 10 years of delays, thousands of rusted and corroded barrels are being moved from a factory in Glen Cove, L.I., to a warehouse. [ B6. ] A bookkeeper was granted special probation after embezzling up to $250,000 from the widow of the aviator Charles A. Lindbergh. [ B6. ] The project to build a new Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan's old General Post Office took a step forward on Capitol Hill. [ B6. ]

description: Some news travels, some doesn't. This thought traverses the mind more than once in the eye-opening early sections of the exhibition of the French artist Annette Messager at the Museum of Modern Art. Whatever one thinks of Ms. Messager's work -- and my final assessment is mixed -- her art was inexplicably absent from the New York scene in the early and mid-1970's, when other European Conceptualists and Post-Minimalists like Hanne Darboven, Jean Le Gac and Christian Boltanski had a regular presence. Ms. Messager has had only three solo shows here since the early 80's, efforts that raised her profile without exposing her early efforts.

title: Recalling Four Girls And How They Grew
description: A lot of big-name clout and glamour shows up at the start of "Now and Then." Melanie Griffith, as a much-married actress named Teeny, wears a tiny white skirt and rides in a large white limo that appears at the door of a girlhood friend. Demi Moore is Samantha, a writer, who also drives back to their hometown, Shelby, Ind. You can see that Samantha is serious because she wears black, chain-smokes and has her braids pinned severely on top of her head. Hers is the narrative voice that quotes Thomas Wolfe as she goes home again to join the friends who stayed behind: Rosie O'Donnell as Roberta, the town doctor, and Rita Wilson as Chrissy, who has called these friends to be with her at the birth of her first baby. The situation is strained and contrived, but the adults soon vanish from the screen.

title: CREATOR OF 'AMAZING DISCOVERIES' INFOMERCIALS IS SOLD
description: The National Media Corporation agreed to buy Positive Response Television Inc. in a stock swap valued about $26 million. Positive Response's shareholders will receive 0.524 shares of National Media for each share of Positive Response. If all of the shares are converted, former Positive Response shareholders will own about 7 percent of National Media. Positive Response's shares slipped 25 cents, to $6.375, in Nasdaq trading. National Media dropped 37.5 cents, to $14.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Positive Response, based in Sherman Oaks, Calif., is the creator of the "Amazing Discoveries" infomercial format and has annual revenue of about $42 million. National Media, of Philadelphia, is the world's largest infomercial programming company.

title: HANOVER COMPRESSOR BRANCHING OUT WITH RENTAL UNIT
description: The Hanover Compressor Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Astra Resources Compression Inc., the natural gas compressor rental subsidiary of Western Resources Inc., for $55 million in stock. With the addition, Hanover will operate a compression equipment business with a branch network throughout the Southwestern and Rocky Mountain states. After the transaction, Western would hold about a 20 percent stake in Hanover. Hanover, a privately held company based in Houston, is owned by a group of investors that includes members of its management team and GKH Investments L.P. Western Resources, of Topeka, Kan., is a diversified energy company.

title: CHARTER MEDICAL ACQUIRING STAKE IN GREEN SPRING
description: The Charter Medical Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire a majority stake in Green Spring Health Services Inc., a provider of managed-care behavioral health services, for $73.2 million in cash and stock. Charter, based in Atlanta, will buy 51 percent of Green Spring, which is based in Columbia, Md. The six Blue Cross and Blue Shield organizations that own Green Spring will continue as key customers, and will retain a 49 percent stake. Charter also said it would change its name to Magellan Health Services Inc. and would operate three primary units: Charter Behavioral Health Systems, Green Spring Health Services, and a newly created Magellan Public Solutions. Shares of Charter were up 87.5 cents, at $19.25, on the American Stock Exchange.

Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan gallery shows: MARISOL, Marlborough Gallery, 40 West 57th Street, Manhattan (through tomorrow). This Pop artist's distinctive style -- the direct carving, the drawing on wood, the squared-off assemblage technique that suggests Cubism called to order in real space -- is almost as entertaining as ever. It's the American West imagery of cowboys and Indians that feels hollow through and through. (Roberta Smith) SOPHIE RIVERA, Wilmer Jennings Gallery at Kenkeleba, 219 East Second Street, East Village (through tomorrow). These large double-exposure photographs of children on Manhattan playgrounds carry surprises beneath their charm: apparitional figures hide behind other figures, faces emerge from faces, and the dense patterning of cyclone fences and jungle gyms looks like an entrapping mesh. (Holland Cotter) POWER BOOTHE, Stephen Haller Gallery, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo (through Oct. 28). The syncopated patterns of Power Boothe's handsome abstractions, emblematic of a style that he has cultivated since the late 1960's, create intimations of the cinematic in the suggestion of a gentle, slow-motion light moving across a meticulously made surface that is still very much a painting. (Smith)

Multicare said the Glenmark purchase would add 21 long-term care centers with 1,700 beds, an institutional pharmacy and a mobile X-ray business to the 60 nursing centers and 6,900 beds it already operates. Under the deal, Multicare will pay $26 million in cash, repay $20 million of Glenmark debt and assume another $21 million of debt. Louis P. Urcinoli had confessed to his uncle, Bernard Mancuso, while on the run after the killing, said Daniel Carluccio, Prosecutor for Ocean County. The new charge is based on information provided by one of Mr. Urcino's fellow inmates, who told authorities that he was offered $5,000 to kill Mr. Mancuso, The Associated Press reported.

title: Singapore Exchange Tightens Regulations
description: The Singapore financial exchange, where errant trades led to the collapse of the Barings Bank, said yesterday that it was tightening trading rules in an effort to prevent similar problems. The steps were recommended by a consultant, Roger Rutz, who was hired by the Singapore International Monetary Exchange Ltd. in the wake of the Barings debacle earlier this year. Barings collapsed on Feb. 27 after a Singapore-based trader, Nicholas W. Leeson, lost $1.3 billion on Asian futures markets, wiping out the bank's cash reserves. The Internationale Nederlanden Groepe acquired the remains of Barings.

Journal; The Log Cabin Lesson
description: Bob Dole wishes that his less-than-excellent adventure with the gay Log Cabin Republicans would just go away, and no wonder. This farcical affair -- during which Mr. Dole accepted a campaign contribution from Log Cabin, then returned it, then this week said returning it had been a mistake -- branded him not only as a flip-flopper but also as a hypocrite (why didn't he return any contributions to Time Warner?), a buck-passer (he blamed all the pratfalls on his staff) and a procrastinator (he let the embarrassing mess drag on for two months). It's hard to imagine how anyone could make a worse case for himself as a potential chief executive of anything, let alone the U.S.A.

description: Dime Bancorp Inc., parent company of the Dime Savings Bank of New York, said yesterday that its board had approved a "poison pill," a measure that can make a hostile takeover prohibitively expensive. Dime, the fifth-biggest savings institution in the United States, said it did not take the action in response to any proposed takeover. "It was designed to deter any abusive takeover tactics that might be used in the future," said James Large Jr., Dime chairman. The plan would let Dime shareholders, except a would-be acquirer, buy additional shares at a discount, diluting a hostile acquirer's stake.

Terror in Paris
description: Everyone in Paris, rich or poor, native or tourist, rides the Metro. Hence the special malevolence of terrorist attacks that target subways or linked suburban lines, as in the explosion Tuesday that injured 29 commuters, 5 of them gravely. Adding to the outrage is a threat of more violence unless France bows to such impossible demands as closing its embassy in Algiers.

The word is used by punk and skinhead bands in Germany, where it has anti-Semitic overtones. A symbol for the Aryan Nation neo-Nazi cult and the word "die" also were painted on his fence. The Raritan police said yesterday that they were investigating. Earlier this week, three Hasbrouck High School musicians were reinstated after being suspended for chanting "oy," a Yiddish word, during a performance. Their use of the word was called anti-Semitic, but they denied that they had any such intent.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Pause After Week Of Good Technology Profits Shares paused for breath after a week of generally positive earnings. Strong reports from Microsoft, Sun, Intel and others helped reassure jittery investors, although the week also saw disappointments. Some analysts saw a move toward defensive stocks over technology issues. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 7.59 points, to 4,794.86, but was up 1.08 for the week. The S. &P. 500 fell 3.19, to 587.46. The Nasdaq composite fell 7.44. [ Page 37. ] Bond Prices Retreat Bond prices came under pressure as the dollar fell and investors reacted with concern to remarks by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan. Some market participants interpreted his comments as dampening the prospects for a rate cut. [ 46. ] The dollar tumbled to an 11-week low against the mark, which also gained strength against the pound and Italian lira. [ 43. ] CNN and Pressler Object to Ads Cable News Network has a legislative ally in its refusal to carry commercials opposing the bill to deregulate the communications industry. Senator Larry Pressler, the sponsor of the bill, tried to squelch the advertisements, too. He met privately with Robert E. Allen, the head of AT&T, asking him to withdraw the ads, saying they were "misleading." [ 35. ] Smith Barney Moves Researcher Smith Barney reassigned the head of its research department after Institutional Investor magazine ranked the firm's research at eighth place in the industry. [ 47. ] Sales of an Amgen Drug Falter Amgen shares fell 8.4 percent after sales of an important new drug were lower than expected. The drug, Neupogen, helped make Amgen a top biotechnology company. The drug's sales rose 7 percent in the third quarter, while 10 percent or more was expected. [ 35. ] A Health Fair on a Mass Scale Under Republican proposals for Medicare, the Government would hold a health fair next year to publicize the private health plans available to elderly people as alternatives to the current Federal program. [ 8. ] An Era Ends in Bethlehem A way of life is coming to an end in Bethlehem, Pa., where basic steelmaking is shutting down after more than a century. The demise also ends a chapter in business history; the single piece H-shaped girder -- the building block of all skyscrapers -- was first made there in a financial gamble that was as daring for the early 20th century as silicon-chip plants are today. [ 35. ] Some Democrats Irate at Clinton Democrats in Congress are still irate over President Clinton's statement this week that he raised taxes "too much" in 1993. Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska was so angry that he scribbled out a speech accusing Mr. Clinton of running for re-election "on a platform of apology." He later cooled off, and decided not to make the remark. Mr. Clinton went out of his way to backtrack from the comment, saying he was proud of the budget. [ 1. ] Freshman Republicans in the House have started to veer out of the control of House Speaker Newt Gingrich. [ 1. ] When a Law Firm Stops Flourishing Jacoby & Meyers flourished in the 1970's after it became legal for law firms to advertise. It offered flat rates for simple bankruptcies, divorces and other services. But competition intensified since then, and the firm downsized. Now the founders find themselves at opposite ends of a legal suit. [ 10. ] Soybean Prices Increase Soybean prices rose sharply, and orange juice climbed to a 10-month high as inventories appeared to be low. [ 43. ]

title: Pilots at Iberia Plan Series of Strikes
description: Pilots at Spain's struggling state airline, Iberia, have voted to hold eight one-day strikes in November to protest what they say is management's failure to win approval for a European Union subsidy. The pilots said the company would not survive unless it won approval for the full 130 billion peseta ($1.05 billion) subsidy. European Union officials have said they could see their way to approving only about a third of the amount.

title: Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Gets 67% of Fisons
description: Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. declared victory yesterday in a two-month takeover battle for Fisons P.L.C., saying it now controlled 67 percent of the shares in Britain's fourth-largest drug maker. Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, based in Collegeville, Pa., is a subsidiary of Rhone-Poulenc S.A. of France. It called the takeover "an important milestone," creating an international pharmaceuticals powerhouse with $6.1 billion in sales. The Fisons board recommended acceptance of the $:1.83 billion ($2.87 billion) bid last week. Rhone-Poulenc Rorer will gain a major foothold in asthma and allergy treatment by expanding its line of products in those areas.

The sale is part of a contract that Valujet Airlines Inc. of Atlanta signed yesterday to buy 50 of the twin-engine commercial aircraft from McDonnell Douglas. It is the third major sale of BR715 engines made by the BMW Rolls-Royce joint venture since it was formed in 1990 and expands the engine's use into commercial aircraft. Early yesterday morning, he returned home from work to find the horror he had never foreseen: his wife and teen-age son were lying face down in the master bedroom, both shot once in the head. His daughter, whom he discovered in her room, had also been shot in the head.

title: UNOCAL TO SIGN PACT WITH TURKMENISTAN
description: The Unocal Corporation said yesterday that it would sign an agreement with the former Soviet republic of Turkmenistan as a first step in an $18 billion project to transport natural gas and oil across Afghanistan to Pakistan. The company, which is also involved in an $8 billion oil development in nearby Azerbaijan, said the project would unlock huge gas reserves in Turkmenistan that the republic developed and has not sold. Unocal and its partner, Delta Oil Company of Saudi Arabia, will spend $10 million during the next year on engineering and marketing studies to determine where a pipeline could be built and who would buy the gas. An agreement on that will be signed with the Government today in New York. But analysts noted that the project faced many risks. There is no agreement with Afghanistan, and the country's mountainous territory would make building a pipeline difficult.

The company said it had repurchased 41.1 million shares, for $939.3 million, since its repurchase program started in 1991. With the new authorization, there now is a total of about $257 million approved for share purchases.

description: The trial of Jesse Timmendequas, the twice-convicted sex offender accused of sexually assaulting and murdering 7-year-old Megan Kanka in 1994, will be moved to Camden County because of intense media coverage in Mercer County, a judge ruled yesterday. At the time of the killing, Mr. Timmendequas lived across the street from the victim's family in Hamilton Township. Outrage over the crime caused the State Legislature to pass "Megan's Law," requiring authorities to notify neighbors when a person with a sex-offense conviction moves nearby.

BP Chemicals, the United States chemicals unit of the British Petroleum Company, plans to expand the plant 33 percent.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Resurrecting a Daydream of the Exotic East
description: Kinkakuji" arrived at the New York City Opera on Thursday night bearing a curious pedigree of time and place. It is a "new" opera that is actually 20 years old. Its composer and literary source are Japanese; its librettist is German. The English translation from the German original is by Christopher Keene, an American, who brought a near-forgotten piece to life and was, until his death this month, to have conducted Thursday's performance.

title: Gambler's Ups and Downs

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: Some of the choice films on television this week are sleepers. Hollywood isn't depicted as the usual jaded jungle in Jack Sher's FOUR GIRLS IN TOWN (1956). The sensible, balanced tone of this unpretentious yarn about aspiring starlets was a mild jolt back then; it's a nice surprise now. The appealing quartet are Elsa Martinelli, Julie Adams, Marianne Cook and Gia Scala, flanked by George Nader and Sydney Chaplin. There's a super, haunting score by Alex North -- Monday at 4:30 P.M. on American Movie Classics. Fans of the occult should pounce on Herk Harvey's CARNIVAL OF SOULS (1962), a strange, riveting mystery sleeper set in Kansas (of all places) with no stars and not much of a budget. A pretty young woman (Candace Hilligoss) drives off a bridge, into a river. Next, she's calmly walking toward a distant, large tent with lights and music. Your move -- Tuesday at 9 P.M. and 1 A.M. on SCI-FI. James Stewart's strong performance is the reward of Andrew V. McLaglen's SHENANDOAH (1965). He's a widowed southern pacifist caught up in the Civil War through his family. The persuasive cast includes Doug McClure, Rosemary Forsyth, Patrick Wayne and Katharine Ross -- Monday at 9 P.M. on the movie map with a small boat and a cast of exactly three: Leon Niemczyk, Jolanta Umecka (in photo) and Zygmunt Malanowicz. Hang on; Polanski makes very little go a long way -- Sunday at 9 P.M., Friday at midnight on CUNY. For amusing nostalgia, try a blissfully brisk and tacky old Fox musical spotlighting Alice Faye -- a spoof of radio glory titled SING, BABY, SING (1936) which she does, nicely. The songs are neat and her colleagues are game: Adolphe Menjou and Gregory Ratoff. And Patsy Kelly and Ritz Brothers never hurt any picture. Sidney Lanfield directed -- Wednesday at 8 A.M. on Cinemax. HOWARD THOMPSON

title: Cultural Divide
description: BEYOND THE FOUR CORNERS OF THE WORLD A Navajo Woman's Journey. By Emily Benedek. Illustrated. 343 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25. THE Navajos may be among the most studied people on earth. Bookshelves the world over sag beneath the literature the tribe has inspired and informed, and yet one searches almost in vain for a sense of day-to-day life as it is actually lived by Navajo people. The methodologies of social science rarely catch the tenor of a day, the tone of a family or the yearning of an individual heart. Least of all do they capture a sense of what it is like for Navajo people to stand today with one foot planted in a world of tribal traditions and the other washed by the eddies and currents of mainstream America.

As far as paleontologists could tell, nature waited another 70 million years before producing the first bird without teeth and with a decidedly avian beak.

title: Islands of the Incas
description: STANDING beside Lake Titicaca on a bitter cold morning last June, I could well understand why the Incas worshiped the sun. A mere 15 degrees of latitude south of the equator, the Andean Altiplano, because of its dryness and high altitude, nevertheless loses heat rapidly. Like a microwave oven, the sun just as quickly re thaws the highlands each day. But for the Incas, who considered themselves direct descendants of the sun, there was more to the sun's power than just its warmth. Shining down from its many stations in the sky, the sun is what gives Lake Titicaca its sense of mystery, its heart-tugging sublimity.

The hearing is to continue on an unspecified date. Here are some comments.

title: Intelligence Gathering
description: Along with prostitution and drugs, gambling used to be included among China's "six evils." These days, however, Guangzhou (formerly Canton), a model of Chinese free enterprise, flaunts a race track and Jockey Club permitted by the Government. Officials say betting on horses is not really gambling, it's "intelligence competition." The $336 million track attracts some 40,000 wagerers and spectators on the two days it's open each week, entrepreneurs sell overpriced soft drinks and sometime next year an entertainment complex is scheduled to open at a nearby lake. For now, the handle at Guangzhou is between $600,000 and $1 million per racing date. But like gamblers the world over, the losing intellects in this competition grumble that the horses are less than Thoroughbreds and that the races are fixed. And like raceway operatives the world over, the club managers say the jockeys are untouchable. Here, though, they mean it literally. The riders sleep in dorms at the track, which is under 24-hour guard.

title: They're Speaking English Up There Now
description: All the characters in Thomas Mann's masterpiece THE MAGIC MOUNTAIN (Knopf, $35) come considerably closer to speaking English in John E. Woods's version than they did in its predecessor, by H. T. Lowe-Porter, first published by Knopf in 1927. Lowe-Porter's apology -- "better . . . an English version . . . done ill than not done at all" -- was exaggerated, but his vocabulary was wholly Victorian, and he missed Mann's voice. Mr. Woods makes Mann talk much as we do, if always more intelligently, and he captures the irony and humor in all but a few passages. Little things count greatly. Here the words chosen for medicines, food, furniture, gestures and sounds put us in familiar surroundings, which makes the artificiality of Hans Castorp's situation in the sanitarium even more ominous. When despair breathes on his neck as he lounges in a loggia (Lowe-Porter) we hardly notice; when it startles him as he sits on a balcony (Mr. Woods) we are shocked. For a larger comparison, look at the "Operationes Spirituales" section at the center of the novel -- the historical, theological and philosophical argument that opens the fatal battle between Leo Naphta and Settembrini. Mr. Woods captures perfectly the superior but not malicious tone of the author; Lowe-Porter gets little of it. Of course, the pleasure of going through any translation is to catch lapses, and in a work so long and learned there are chances to mock any version. For instance, do we know more about Settembrini's appearance when Mr. Woods has him wear an "ineluctable petersham coat" than we did when Lowe-Porter clad him in an "inevitable pilot-coat"? This garment is meant to reveal something of the man's politics and philosophy; it was often the garb of free thinkers in European cartoons and drawings early in this century. We would know it instantly if the translators just called it a peacoat. D. J. R. BRUCKNER

title: ART VIEW;Brancusi Reveals His Human Side
description: Constantin Brancusi: 1876-1957," newly arrived at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, is a first-rate exhibition of an exalted figure. Exhibitions are supposed to alter your ideas about an artist, which this one does. If you imagine Brancusi creating icons of distilled beauty, you are right, of course. He spent weeks, even months, polishing his sculptures by hand until they achieved an incorporeal sheen. He ended up producing versions of his famous "Bird in Space" that look like pure, almost disembodied slivers of radiant light. His works became ethereal masses of compressed form that referred, though less and less explicitly, to the natural world.

title: IN THE BEGINNING;A TRANSLATION THAT HAS BOTH PERILS AND REWARDS
description: FEW TRANSLATIONS OF THE BIBLE ARE demanded by every generation, and for good reasons. The language of an earlier generation may come to sound tired or awkward, no longer satisfying our desire for transparency, for a close-up view of the original. Dissatisfaction is not confined to sacred texts, as anybody can see by comparing Pope's or Chapman's translation of Homer with the contemporary version by Robert Fagles. Most people would choose Fagles's, not merely because his work is admirable in itself but because they feel there is more in all the others that comes between us and Homer: they interpose Jacobean, Augustan, Victorian opacities. And where the Bible is concerned, the need for transparency is more urgent; this is not merely an esthetic matter.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Do Trains Wait? Q. I take the 1/9 train from the Upper West Side to Times Square every day. Sometimes the 2/3 express seems to wait for passengers from the local in the morning, sometimes not. When am I most likely to find a train waiting? A. Nighttime is the right time, said Charles Seaton, a spokesman for the Transit Authority. During the morning and evening rush hours, train operators are instructed not to wait for incoming locals or expresses on the opposite track. But at night the schedule is designed to allow transfers between trains. It may seem as though the trains are waiting in the morning simply because there are more trains, Mr. Seaton said. There is no communication between trains regarding a transfer, so if you catch one at rush hour, you can chalk it up to luck. Only Temporary Q. I noticed a new bright blue street sign at the corner of 52d Street and Fifth Avenue reading "Liz Claiborne Avenue." I thought honorary street names were saved for great benefactors. A. You can't notice it now because it's gone. The sign was put in place Aug. 17, opening day for the new Liz Claiborne store at that corner. It came down last month. Liz Sherfin, a spokeswoman from the Mayor's office, said that such temporary signs are often put up to mark "significant" events, including business events. The honoree pays the $250 cost, which includes the sign's production and installation. Most temporary signs are granted a shelf life of one month. Jury Duty Calls Q. Each time the two-year grace period for jury duty ends, and sometimes before, I start getting summoned to duty -- two, three, four times a year. In spite of all my letters to Centre Street, I keep getting called for the wrong times: I'm a graduate student and cannot serve during the school year. Am I just randomly unlucky? Is there no limit to the number of times I can be called? A. Right on both counts. You may be randomly unlucky, and as long as you maintain permanent residency in New York, there is no limit to the number of times you can be summoned for jury duty. But if your letters have yielded no satisfaction, your best bet may be to go to the New York County Clerk's office and deal with the situation in person.

title: IN THE BEGINNING;IT'S NOT ALWAYS ENGLISH, BUT IT CAPTURES THE HEBREW
description: THE GREAT VIRTUE OF EVERETT FOX'S ENGLISH version of the Bible is that with the model of Buber and Rosenzweig's German translation before him, he boldly swims against the tide of insipidness of all the other modern English versions. English translators of the Bible in our century have concentrated on two related and equally misguided goals: to make the ancient text more accessible to modern readers and to make its meanings perfectly transparent. In an effort to achieve the former aim, translators have repackaged the idioms and syntax of the Bible in a pedestrian English style that wanders uncertainly between the language of the daily newspaper and that of a bureaucratic manual. In pursuit of clarity, what is pungent and concrete in the Hebrew is made bland and abstract, and the mystery and purposeful ambiguity of the original evaporates in explanatory paraphrase masquerading as translation.

description: In South Korea, the familial roadblocks to marriage make a walk down the aisle more difficult than getting across Seoul during a student demonstration. Unions between descendants of the same forefather are prohibited. In this nation of 44 million, however, a few names, and no one knows how many forefathers, go a long way. There are, for example, nearly 9 million Kims distributed among 285 pongwans, or clans. While a Kim from one clan can marry a Kim from another, this is also a nation with a 2,000-year history of written records: you climb any family tree high enough and everyone's related to everyone. Thus, many couples, unrelated but unable to prove it easily, simply dwell in unregistered marital bliss.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Do Trains Wait? Q. I take the 1/9 train from the Upper West Side to Times Square every day. Sometimes the 2/3 express seems to wait for passengers from the local in the morning, sometimes not. When am I most likely to find a train waiting? A. Nighttime is the right time, said Charles Seaton, a spokesman for the Transit Authority. During the morning and evening rush hours, train operators are instructed not to wait for incoming locals or expresses on the opposite track. But at night the schedule is designed to allow transfers between trains. It may seem as though the trains are waiting in the morning simply because there are more trains, Mr. Seaton said. There is no communication between trains regarding a transfer, so if you catch one at rush hour, you can chalk it up to luck. Only Temporary Q. I noticed a new bright blue street sign at the corner of 52d Street and Fifth Avenue reading "Liz Claiborne Avenue." I thought honorary street names were saved for great benefactors. A. You can't notice it now because it's gone. The sign was put in place Aug. 17, opening day for the new Liz Claiborne store at that corner. It came down last month. Liz Sherfin, a spokeswoman from the Mayor's office, said that such temporary signs are often put up to mark "significant" events, including business events. The honoree pays the $250 cost, which includes the sign's production and installation. Most temporary signs are granted a shelf life of one month. Jury Duty Calls Q. Each time the two-year grace period for jury duty ends, and sometimes before, I start getting summoned to duty -- two, three, four times a year. In spite of all my letters to Centre Street, I keep getting called for the wrong times: I'm a graduate student and cannot serve during the school year. Am I just randomly unlucky? Is there no limit to the number of times I can be called? A. Right on both counts. You may be randomly unlucky, and as long as you maintain permanent residency in New York, there is no limit to the number of times you can be summoned for jury duty. But if your letters have yielded no satisfaction, your best bet may be to go to the New York County Clerk's office and deal with the situation in person.

title: 'Things Nobody Else Would See'
description: Paradoxes abound in UNTITLED (Aperture, $50), the third volume of Diane Arbus's photographs and the only one devoted to a single subject -- the mentally retarded. Most of these pictures have never been exhibited or published before. Arbus began taking them in 1969 and continued until her suicide in 1972. Of this work she once wrote: "They are blurred and variable, but some are gorgeous. FINALLY WHAT I've been searching for." These images are gorgeous, if gorgeous can be defined as both unsettling and ecstatic. Arbus's daughter Doon Arbus (who edited the book with Yolanda Cuomo, a designer) explains in an afterword: "She believed there were things nobody else would see unless she photographed them. . . . She wasn't talking about who or what she saw, but about the experience of seeing it and the power of her photographs to make the experience visible." Every image is a variation on that theme -- whether it's a pouty little boy sticking his thumb in his eye or a line of dumpy masked women looking as if they're waiting to get past the gates of hell. Nobody photographed less "beautifully" than Diane Arbus; nobody photographed more memorably. Such pictures give us an unyielding sense of our own limits -- limits that can be raised only by death. PATRICIA BOSWORTH

title: And Now for Something Completely Offensive
description: GOD BLESS JOHN WAYNE By Kinky Friedman. 253 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22. THERE are two basic attitudes toward mystery stories. The first combines contempt and puzzlement: why should so many intelligent people be devotees of such a demotic form of literature? The great critic Edmund Wilson articulated this position in two stinging essays in the mid-1940's, "Why Do People Read Detective Stories?" and (in a reference to a novel by Agatha Christie) "Who Cares Who Killed Roger Ackroyd?" title: Islands of the Incas
description: STANDING beside Lake Titicaca on a bitter cold morning last June, I could well understand why the Incas worshiped the sun. A mere 15 degrees of latitude south of the equator, the Andean Altiplano, because of its dryness and high altitude, nevertheless loses heat rapidly. Like a microwave oven, the sun just as quickly re thaws the highlands each day. But for the Incas, who considered themselves direct descendants of the sun, there was more to the sun's power than just its warmth. Shining down from its many stations in the sky, the sun is what gives Lake Titicaca its sense of mystery, its heart-tugging sublimity.

title: RETURN OF THE PUNK PANTHER
description: Thank you for Philip Weiss's article on Julie Andrews and her husband, Blake Edwards ("Return of the Punk Panther," Oct. 1). I was reminded of a show I saw in London in 1948. It was a revue called "Starlight Roof." One of the acts was Ted and Barbara Andrews. (He played the piano and they both sang.) In the middle of the performance, Ted and Barbara announced that they would like us to meet Julie, their daughter. And there she was, this long-legged child with a terrific voice. I now feel that I was in on the ground floor of a great theatrical career. HAROLD FREEMAN Coram, L.I.

title:
IN THE BEGINNING;
A SCRUPULOUS AND ADMIRABLE MIRROR OF THE ORIGINAL
description: THOUGH I'VE ATTEMPTED TRANSLATIONS OF MY OWN FROM the Hebrew Bible (which Christians call the Old Testament), I don't know Hebrew. But that failing has deterred me no more than it did translators like Alexander Pope and Ezra Pound, who derived their versions of Homer and the Chinese poets from the legwork of better scholars. In my own efforts, I've worked from scholarly word-by-word translations and from the nearly verbatim fourth-century Latin Vulgate translation of St. Jerome. So my sense of the verbal, intellectual and sonic fidelity of Everett Fox's profoundly informed new version is hardly authoritative, but I can at least compare his work with the voluminous suggestions of my own early guides. And such a comparison indicates that Fox has attempted the most ambitious English translation of Genesis since the King James Version of 1611.

And Bear in Mind (Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest) ALBERT SPEER: HIS BATTLE WITH TRUTH, by Gitta Sereny. (Knopf, $35.) The author, a lifelong student of the Nazi bosses and for years a friend of Speer, examines his stratagems to avoid knowing exactly what it was that he knew. ALL GOD'S CHILDREN: The Bosket Family and the American Tradition of Violence, by Fox Butterfield. (Knopf, $27.50.) A Times correspondent's painful examination of social pathology from generation to generation, always getting worse, told with a novelist's determination to see it whole. CASINO: Love and Honor in Las Vegas, by Nicholas Pileggi. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) The unease and aimlessness of the gangster life, captured fly-on-the-wall fashion and conveyed in the perceptions of the crooks themselves. EDWARD HOPPER: An Intimate Biography, by Gail Levin. (Knopf, $35.) Ms. Levin's sixth book on Hopper only peripherally concerns Hopper's art; it's a nearly flawless account of the life of a great American painter whose temperament, especially in respect of his weirdly long-suffering and combative wife, was simply abominable. HEART: A Memoir, by Lance Morrow. (Warner, $22.95.) A moving work of literal introspection: in the wake of his second heart attack and second bypass operation, Mr. Morrow tries to find out what's really wrong with his life and himself. THE HUSBANDS: An Account of Books 3 and 4 of Homer's "Iliad," by Christopher Logue. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.) A heroic, often brilliant, portion of the author's long-term project of bringing this distant, uncomfortable, alien poem closer to readers of contemporary poetry. LOVING WANDA BEAVER: Novella and Stories, by Alison Baker. (Chronicle, $16.95.) Fine and sturdy Southern Gothic humor for the New Age, where every fate is worse than death and folks put ancho chili on the lime Jell-O and pears. PALIMPSEST: A Memoir, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $27.50.) As Mr. Vidal recalls his first 39 years (1925-64), his abundant self-admiration escapes self-absorption, and many people he did not care for receive at least the tribute of his keen attention. Too bad for them! SAVAGE ART: A Biography of Jim Thompson, by Robert Polito. (Knopf, $30.) Exhaustive research and critical acumen adorn this life of the wildly original (some of his narrators are dead, e.g.) American crime novelist who died in 1977. SAVAGES, by Joe Kane. (Knopf, $25.) A superb report on life among the Huaorani, a virtually intact Amazonian tribe whose resolve to stay as and where they are confronts the resolve of governments and energy companies to pump the earth from under their feet. THE UNCONSOLED, by Kazuo Ishiguro. (Knopf, $25.) This successor to "The Remains of the Day" concerns a pianist who is called to visit a land whose citizens yearn for validation of their culture, which depends on shared understandings of modern musical composition. He can't help.

title: Class Conflict in Washington
description: How touching it was for House Speaker Newt Gingrich to appeal for brotherly love at the end of the titanic debate over Medicare last week. "We want no class warfare," he declared. "We want no conflict between generations." Even by Mr. Gingrich's standards, this was a remarkable statement. The Republicans are rushing through Congress the greatest attempt in modern history to reward the wealthy at the expense of the poor. They are also sacrificing the health needs of the elderly to pay for a tax cut for the affluent. Incredibly, Mr. Gingrich was accusing the Democrats of fomenting class and generational resentments by pointing this out. President Clinton can do no less than veto the Republican legislative package that is roaring toward passage in Congress.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: Some of the choice films on television this week are sleepers. Hollywood isn't depicted as the usual jaded jungle in Jack Sher's FOUR GIRLS IN TOWN (1956). The sensible, balanced tone of this unpretentious yarn about aspiring starlets was a mild jolt back then; it's a nice surprise now. The appealing quartet are Elsa Martinelli, Julie Adams, Marianne Cook and Gia Scala, flanked by George Nader and Sydney Chaplin. There's a super, haunting score by Alex North -- Monday at 4:30 P.M. on American Movie Classics. Fans of the occult should pounce on Herk Harvey's CARNIVAL OF SOULS (1962), a strange, riveting mystery sleeper set in Kansas (of all places) with no stars and not much of a budget. A pretty young woman (Candace Hilligoss) drives off a bridge, into a river. Next, she's calmly walking toward a distant, large tent with lights and music. Your move -- Tuesday at 9 P.M. and 1 A.M. on SCI-FI. James Stewart's strong performance is the reward of Andrew V. McLaglen's SHENANDOAH (1965). He's a widowed southern pacifist caught up in the Civil War through his family. The persuasive cast includes Doug McClure, Rosemary Forsyth, Patrick Wayne and Katharine Ross -- Monday at 9 P.M. on the movie map with a small boat and a cast of exactly three: Leon Niemczyk, Jolanta Umecka (in photo) and Zygmunt Malanowicz. Hang on; Polanski makes very little go a long way -- Sunday at 9 P.M., Friday at midnight on CUNY. For amusing nostalgia, try a blissfully brisk and tacky old Fox musical spotlighting Alice Faye -- a spoof of radio glory titled SING, BABY, SING (1936) which she does, nicely. Some students went the literary route, with corduroy jackets and afternoon play readings by the river, while others chose the "Hooray Henry" persona and braying in restaurants. The options, like the summers, appeared endless: punk and veganism or blazers and boating, white tie, black tie, thespian, politico, bohemian, baby don, poet, drunk or any combination of the above.

title: THE PRIME-TIME NOVEL;THE TRIUMPH OF THE PRIME-TIME NOVEL

On average, 54.4 million Americans tune in every night, remember. Some of them are even card-carrying intellectuals who, if they haven't graduated yet to a 60-inch screen with wall projection and Dolby sound, nevertheless keep a little cable-ready Sony wedged up there in the bookcase, next to Rilke and Heidegger. If you're telling the truth, though -- if you really haven't looked lately -- you should give it another chance. You're missing out on something. TV is actually enjoying a sort of golden age -- it has become a medium you can consistently rely on not just for distraction but for enlightenment.

title: DIARY
description: PROFITS The Black Ink Flows Freely A tide of rising earnings washed over the markets but did not quite lift all boats. Allaying Wall Street's biggest fear, Microsoft reported that Windows 95 was selling very well indeed and that its earnings were up 58 percent. Intel, Sun Microsystem, Silicon Graphics and I.B.M. were also strong performers; Apple Computer was the major disappointment, down 47.6 percent. Pharmaceutical companies and brokerage houses also had strong quarters, and General Motors beat expectations. But Ford Motor took a stiff loss, its profits down 68 percent as costs rose and overseas sales slipped. The Dow, the S. & P. 500 and the Big Board composite rode the news to record highs. ALARM BELLS So Much for Oversight The Federal Reserve and Daiwa Bank's management won no applause for their review of trading problems at the bank's New York branch. A former Fed official disclosed that nearly two years before Daiwa disclosed its $1.1 billion loss from unauthorized trading, the president of the New York Fed had met with Daiwa to discuss the employee, Toshihide Iguchi, and his trading practices. Clearly the followup left a lot to be desired. As Mr. Noguchi pleaded guilty in Federal court to a variety of charges, both he and prosecutors said two senior executives at Daiwa conspired to conceal the loss. Daiwa said only that it was continuing its own investigation. SAFETY NET Dialing for Dollars Concerns about Japanese banking go far beyond Daiwa. The Federal Reserve put in place a system to provide Japanese financial authorities with billions of dollars in cash, almost instantly, in exchange for U.S. Treasury bonds and bills held by the Japanese. The goal is to avert a catastrophic bank collapse that would ripple around the globe. And because the Treasury would receive its own issues in exchange for the cash, the safety net appears to be risk free. TAXES Stumbling on the High Wire First President Clinton told a group of business executives that he had raised taxes "too much" in his first budget, providing comfort to Republican critics and infuriating Democrats who had stood by him at the time. A day later, he backtracked and said he was "very, very proud of what I did."

description: THOUGH I'VE ATTEMPTED TRANSLATIONS OF MY OWN FROM the Hebrew Bible (which Christians call the Old Testament), I don't know Hebrew. But that failing has deterred me no more than it did translators like Alexander Pope and Ezra Pound, who derived their versions of Homer and the Chinese poets from the legwork of better scholars. In my own efforts, I've worked from scholarly word-by-word translations and from the nearly verbatim fourth-century Latin Vulgate translation of St. Jerome. So my sense of the verbal, intellectual and sonic fidelity of Everett Fox's profoundly informed new version is hardly authoritative, but I can at least compare his work with the voluminous suggestions of my own early guides. And such a comparison indicates that Fox has attempted the most ambitious English translation of Genesis since the King James Version of 1611.
