title:
IN THE BEGINNING;
IT'S NOT ALWAYS ENGLISH, BUT IT CAPTURES THE HEBREW
description: THE GREAT VIRTUE OF EVERETT FOX'S ENGLISH version of the Bible is that with the model of Buber and Rosenzweig's German translation before him, he boldly swims against the tide of insipidness of all the other modern English versions. English translators of the Bible in our century have concentrated on two related and equally misguided goals: to make the ancient text more accessible to modern readers and to make its meanings perfectly transparent. In an effort to achieve the former aim, translators have repackaged the idioms and syntax of the Bible in a pedestrian English style that wanders uncertainly between the language of the daily newspaper and that of a bureaucratic manual. In pursuit of clarity, what is pungent and concrete in the Hebrew is made bland and abstract, and the mystery and purposeful ambiguity of the original evaporates in explanatory paraphrase masquerading as translation.

title: The Spirit of Hyde Park
description: The White House picked Hyde Park as the site of yesterday's meeting between Boris Yeltsin and Bill Clinton because the Roosevelt homestead is a symbol of the wartime alliance between Moscow and Washington. The more relevant symbolism of the Hudson River estate might have been Franklin Roosevelt's acute instinct for balancing politics and diplomacy. It is a commodity that will be much needed in the months ahead as Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin try to guide the volatile relationship between their countries through the heat of Presidential elections in both the United States and Russia.

title: Race and the Curse of Good Intentions
description: In the furor over the O. J. Simpson verdict and the Million Man March, Americans seem to have forgotten something that was more obvious during the civil rights movement: that race, though a biological fact, is a dangerously empty distinction because it can carry whatever meaning we give it without the support of reason or evidence. This freedom from reason is what makes the idea of race so perniciously convenient. Make the color black mean inferior and, without ever having to prove inferiority, you've got a couple of centuries of slavery.

title: Records Show Flows From Archer Executive's Account
description: Days after Mark E. Whitacre, a former executive with the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, confessed to illegally accumulating corporate money in a Swiss bank account, almost $1 million was transferred from the account for Mr. Whitacre's purchase of a new home, according to bank records, court documents and interviews.

title: CHIEF OF LIGHTING UNIT IS NAMED G.E. VICE CHAIRMAN
description: The General Electric Company named John D. Opie vice chairman yesterday. He had been president and chief executive of the company's GE Lighting unit. Mr. Opie, 57, joins G.E.'s other vice chairman, Paolo Fresco, as one of the top two executives under John F. Welch, the company's chairman and chief executive. Frank P. Doyle, 64, who as executive vice president had been the company's No. 3 executive, is retiring, G.E. said. Mr. Opie's promotion appears to elevate another potential successor to Mr. Welch, who turns 60 next month. Mr. Welch has said repeatedly that he has no plans to retire early.

title: Neutrinos Have Mass, Panel Says
description: ONE of the most important questions in physics and cosmology is whether the elusive particles called neutrinos have any mass. Eight months ago, scientists working at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico talked of experiments showing that, yes, neutrinos appeared to have a slight but not inconsequential mass. But they kept putting off publication of a formal technical report of such a major discovery.

He had had the robe patterned after one worn by the Lord Chancellor in a local production of Gilbert and Sullivan's "Iolanthe," and he has proudly worn the stripes in court ever since.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Notification System for Victims
description: For the last two years, the Attorney General's office has required jailers to notify victims of violent crimes when the people accused in the attacks are released on bail. Complying with this requirement can pose "a serious resource problem" for law enforcement, said Ronald S. Fava, the Prosecutor for Passaic County. But today, Mr. Fava will announce that Passaic is the first county in New Jersey to use an automated notification system, which can dial a victim's number at any time and deliver the message in English or Spanish. In domestic violence cases, the victim must punch a secret numerical code to confirm that the victim, and not the spouse, received the message.

title: Park Administrator Resigns Her Post

Imasco, based in Montreal, is Canada's largest drugstore operator, with 718 stores across the country. B.A.T. Industries of Britain owns 44 percent of Imasco. Big V, which is closely held, operates 135 drugstores in Ontario. Under the purchase agreement, Big V shareholders would receive $10 (Canadian) a share in cash, or that amount in notes and Imasco common shares if they wanted a tax deferral.

title: Race and the Curse of Good Intentions
description: In the furor over the O. J. Simpson verdict and the Million Man March, Americans seem to have forgotten something that was more obvious during the civil rights movement: that race, though a biological fact, is a dangerously empty distinction because it can carry whatever meaning we give it without the support of reason or evidence. This freedom from reason is what makes the idea of race so perniciously convenient. Make the color black mean inferior and, without ever having to prove inferiority, you've got a couple of centuries of slavery.

description: Jerry Bowe, a Conservative Party candidate for the Assembly, filed a complaint with the Federal Communications Commission yesterday accusing a municipal access television station of censorship because a program that featured the founder of his party was canceled. Tom Blomquist, Conservative Party founder, was interviewed for "On Society," but Channel 29 in Old Bridge never broadcast the show. Mayor Barbara Cannon of Old Bridge said the program was canceled because the station manager considered it too political. But she acknowledged that Assembly candidates from both major parties have appeared on the program. TERRY PRISTIN

title: MELLON AGREES TO BUY KEYCORP'S BOND SERVICES UNIT

The business has 9 offices in 13 states. Including the acquisition, Mellon's corporate trust group will service more than 9,100 trustee and agency accounts, with outstanding securities of more than $146 billion. Mellon said it would hire most of the Keycorp unit's administrative staff.

title: Lottery for the Arts: Over the Rainbow Or Under a Cloud?

It's Britain today, where 5 percent of the revenue from the new national lottery -- roughly $10 million a week -- is dedicated to fine arts.

title: Sonic Youth's Reward: Fans Know the Noises
description: Pop music progresses through a process of conditioning. If an audience is exposed to a new song or sound for long enough -- grunge or hip-hop, for example -- what seems noisy at first often starts to seem pleasantly familiar. For 14 years, Sonic Youth has been conditioning audiences to its own noise, that of guitars retuned to intervals not compatible with rock's normal arsenal of chords and riffs and of pop and punk song structures pried open by free improvisation. As an opening act for R.E.M. and Neil Young in recent years, an influence on countless college-rock bands and the headliner of this year's Lollapalooza tour, Sonic Youth has been bringing its dissonance to larger and larger audiences.

title: Espy Inquiry To Bring Plea From Lobbyist
description: In the first tangible result of the investigation of former Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy, a lobbyist and prominent figure in Republican political circles has agreed to plead guilty to making illegal contributions to Mr. Espy's brother, the lobbyist's lawyer said today.

description: As other visiting heads of state and government hobnobbed with one another yesterday, President Fidel Castro of Cuba, Communist stalwart, made the rounds in New York City, meeting with the likes of David Rockefeller on Park Avenue and a group of Puerto Rican businessmen in the South Bronx.

title: Governor of California Endorses Dole's Campaign for the White House
description: Gov. Pete Wilson of California, whose abortive try for the Republican Presidential nomination failed to attract sufficient money, excitement or public support, today endorsed the candidacy of Senator Bob Dole.

The Cowboys and their owner, Jerry Jones, said the contracts with Nike, Pepsi, Dr Pepper and American Express that made the league file suit were to sponsor Texas Stadium and did not violate league policy.

description: A mother's cry of agony over the death of her 14-year-old son shattered the stillness of a Manhattan courtroom yesterday at the trial of three suspected members of a feared Manhattan drug gang, the Young Talented Children.

title: Review/Fashion;In London, Straining for Consistency
description: One of the great fashion traditions is the presentation of flowers to the designer at the end of the runway. The flowers are not for an exceptional show; bouquets are ordered far in advance. They are flowers for the triumph of presenting a show at all.

description: The number of homicides in the United States fell in 1994 for the third consecutive year, the Government said today.

description: b-Included charge of 12 cents a share related to future state income tax rates on tax benefits required in prior years, and a gain of $ 191,000, or one cent a share, related to a preferred-stock buyback.The latest quarter's results were after payments of $ 131,000 for preferred-stock dividends, compared with payments of $ 747,000 for preferred-stock dividends in year-ago period.

title: Unwanted Seat for Frustrated Thurman
description: Moments after the Nets had captured a 118-110 preseason victory over the Phoenix Suns last Friday night at Rutgers University, Scotty Thurman sat in a corner of his team's locker room wearing a look of dejection and frustration.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Revives as German Bank Hints at Move to Weaken Mark
description: The dollar recovered slightly yesterday after the president of the German central bank said the bank was "ready for meaningful international cooperation" to stabilize currency markets.

title: Gory Kitsch in a Parody of Teen-Age Road Movies
description: Production notes for Gregg Araki's "Doom Generation" say it is "Araki's first big-budget feature and marks the end of his film adolescence." Well, not exactly. After a promising debut with "The Living End" followed by the angrier, more marginalized "Totally F***ed Up," Mr. Araki is still sounding a note of self-congratulatory teen-age rebellion in a film gruesome and obvious enough to make "Natural Born Killers" look like a model of restraint.

description: Debt

title: Perot Claims Enough Signatures to Qualify His Party in California
description: Ross Perot said today that his new political party had signed up more than enough members to achieve its first and most difficult goal -- getting on the 1996 Presidential ballot in California, the nation's richest treasure of electoral votes.

title: Governments Bypassing Banks to Pool Money in Fund
description: Francie M. Heller was a school administrator in Ossining, N.Y., in the mid-1980's when she realized that school districts like hers might be better off pooling their spare cash with other districts rather than following the traditional paths of buying securities on their own or relying on local banks.

title: WORLD SERIES '95
description: Eddie Murray, without a hit in his first five at-bats, drove in the winning run with an 11th-inning single.

description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Times Mirror, Citing Expense Of Cutbacks, Takes a Charge
description: The Times Mirror Company said today that the thousands of job cuts at its newspapers and the closing of several operations resulted in a $360.1 million charge in the third quarter. The company added that it would suffer as much as $180 million in additional charges in the fourth quarter as it struggled to rebuild.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the two candidates for president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. reversed their identities in some copies. Thomas R. Donahue, wearing glasses and a dark suit, was on the left; John J. Sweeney was on the right.

title: PFIZER TO SELL FOOD SCIENCE GROUP TO FINNISH COMPANY
description: Pfizer Inc. said yesterday that it planned to sell its food science group to Cultor Ltd. of Finland. The terms of the sale were not disclosed. Pfizer, based in New York, said the sale of the unit, which develops specialty food ingredients, was part of the company's plan to refocus on its health care businesses. Sales of the food science group rose 26 percent in the third quarter compared with the corresponding period in 1994. Through the first nine months of the year, the group reported $232 million in sales, up 7 percent from the year-earlier period, Pfizer said. Cultor had sales of about $1.5 billion in 1994.

title: THE U.N. AT 50: CLINTON AND JIANG;CHINA'S PRESIDENT AND CLINTON MEET TO REPAIR FENCES
description: Meeting on the sidelines of the United Nations anniversary celebration, President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin of China made their best effort yesterday to repair a relationship that has been seriously strained by disagreements over Taiwan and human rights.

title: Bills' Thomas Is Injured
description: THURMAN THOMAS, the Buffalo Bills' star running back, hobbled into Rich Stadium in Orchard Park yesterday and said he expected to miss at least two weeks with a pulled hamstring sustained in a 27-14 loss to the New England Patriots on Monday night.

description: To the Editor:

description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: 268 Pounds Slimmer, and Counting
description: Two years ago, Lucy Lustig Curtis weighed 663 pounds, a number she hid even from her husband. She was unable to move or bend much, so tying her shoes was impossible, and sustained exercise was out of the question. Walking at even a leisurely pace was difficult. Climbing stairs made her lose her breath.

title: INSIDE
description: Vote on Israel Embasy

title: ON BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Just Being There Is Not Enough for the Indians
description: When the Indians limped home from Atlanta after losing the first two games of the World Series, a theory sprouted on these shores of Lake Erie: The Indians had already achieved their psychological goal of reaching the World Series, and subconsciously, at least, they were just happy to be here and had no challenges remaining.

description: International A3-13

description: BACK at the dawn of culinary history, even before some cave-dwelling Escoffier thought of suspending food over flames, a more primitive culinary theorist threw some food into the coals of a dying fire and left it there to cook.

title: 95 WORLD SERIES;Braves' Pitching Staff Taken Down a Peg
description: Who felt worse on the Braves this morning Alejandro Pena, Mark Wohlers or John Smoltz? It was pretty close. Pena probably felt worse because he surrendered Eddie Murray's run-scoring single in the 11th inning to catapult the Indians to a 7-6 victory over the Braves in Game 3 of the World Series early today at Jacobs Field.

title: New Method of Dry Cleaning Taints the Air, Study Finds
description: Even as dry cleaners across the country are using a new cleaning method that cuts chemical vapors, a new study in New York City has found that the method does not prevent a potentially harmful chemical from reaching apartments in buildings that house cleaning operations.

title: Labor Adopts a Symbol: The Sun (a Rising One)
description: Wherever delegates to the A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention go around their midtown Manhattan hotel this week, they are surrounded by the bright yellow rays of the rising sun, emblazoned on T-shirts, silk-screened onto placards and printed on campaign literature.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Camden Deadlier Than Newark
description: The 48th person this year was murdered last Sunday on the streets of Camden, an impoverished city of 87,000 that has become known as the homicide capital of New Jersey. Yesterday, Governor Whitman said she was considering sending in state troopers to patrol the city.

title: Yeltsin's Nondisaster
description: To the Editor:

title: SHARES OF THOMAS NELSON FALL ON LOWER EARNINGS
description: Shares of Thomas Nelson Inc. fell 36 percent yesterday after the company reported a 39 percent drop in its second-quarter net income. The company, a publisher of Bibles and religious books based in Nashville, attributed the lower earnings to reduced profit margins and larger-than-expected expenses in its music, direct marketing and media divisions. The company said it had cut salaries, reduced expenses and eliminated redundant businesses in an effort to improve its financial condition. Shares of Thomas Nelson fell $9.125, to $15.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Crowning the Comeback King
description: Though there are still four years to go in the 90's, business and government leaders in New York honored Donald J. Trump yesterday for pulling off what they called "the comeback of the decade."

title: Italy's Leader Faces a Vote To Remove Him
description: A tumultuous political crisis, set in motion late last week, closed in on Prime Minister Lamberto Dini today as Parliament opened debate on a vote to topple his nine-month-old Government, Italy's 54th since World War II.

title: Chase Official to Quit
description: Kathylynn O'Donnell will resign as executive vice president and co-head of global markets at the Chase Manhattan Corporation after the bank's $11 billion merger with the Chemical Banking Corporation, she said in an internal memo. Speculation that Ms. O'Donnell would leave Chase emerged the day the merger was announced, when Chemical officials received most of the top positions in the new bank. Ms. O'Donnell joined Chase in 1979.

title: At New York's Bad Schools, Problem Wasn't Just Money
description: Last year, only 12 percent of Public School 304's third graders were reading at or above grade level, among the lowest levels in the city. The school, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, has had four principals in four years. Despite several years of intervention by the state, the city, the Federal Government and nationally known educators, P.S. 304 has never made it off the state's list of the city's worst schools.

title: G.O.P. Seek Compromise on Welfare Bill
description: House and Senate negotiators met today for the first time to draft a compromise welfare bill amid indications that Republicans were more interested in striking a deal than in maintaining ideological purity on the issue.

title: BOXING
description: The key witness in the wire-fraud case against Don King testified yesterday that the promoter directed him to create $350,000 in training expenses to justify an insurance claim for a Julio Cesar Chavez-Harold Brazier fight that was canceled.

title: Dairy Farmers Lose If Deregulation Wins
description: To the Editor:

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Jonathan Kozol; Listening to the South Bronx
description: MY friends tell me: 'You look worn out, Jonathan. I'm worried about you,' " said Jonathan Kozol, perched on a battered counter stool, its cover worn to the wood, at B&V pizza and doughnuts in the South Bronx.

title: BASEBALL;Showalter Has No Answer To Steinbrenner's Offer
description: Buck Showalter's voice was filled with confusion and doubt today regarding questions about his future as manager of the Yankees, a future that remained on hold after Showalter received a phone call from George Steinbrenner today and indicated that he would get back to the owner on Wednesday.

title: Sports of The Times;Time to Give Game Back to Abused Fans
description: THERE are other ways in which to kill a World Series besides going on strike. We are finding out about that this week in New York, where a member of baseball's very own executive council has almost managed to knock the Braves and Indians all the way out of town.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bond Yield Falls to 6.32% On Hopes of a Rate Cut Treasury yields tumbled, as credit market traders renewed hopes of an interest-rate cut soon. Alan S. Blinder, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, propelled the market when he said that interest rates were excessive for the long term, and that the Fed should begin to lower them, but not necessarily "imminently." The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.32 percent, from 6.39 percent. [Page D18.]

title: The U.N. at 50: An On-Line History
description: Articles and photos from the archives of The New York Times on the birth of the United Nations in 1945 are available on @times, the Times service on America Online. Software and information: (800) 548-5201.

title: Early Opponents Will Take The Measure of Manhattan
description: Manhattan is the preseason pick among the coaches to win the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference men's basketball title, and for good reason. With all but one starter returning, the Jaspers should be even better than last year's squad, which reached the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Agency Chosen For Genderm Drug
description: Genderm Health Care in Morristown, N.J., a unit of the Genderm Corporation, said yesterday that it had selected Carrafiello Diehl & Associates in Irvington, N.Y., to handle advertising for Zostrix, a topical analgesic cream, previously handled by Sudler & Hennessey, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York. The billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million. Carrafiello Diehl was chosen after a four-month review that included at least two agencies based in New York City, which Genderm declined to identify.

description: Croatia will use military force to retake the last slice of its territory in Serb hands if it is not returned through negotiations by the end of November, President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia said yesterday.

title: THE U.N. AT 50: UP CLOSE;A Wistful Little Land Savors World Stage
description: Just outside the fanfare that surrounded the United Nations with a womb of security on Sunday, the Foreign Minister from the tiny nation of Bhutan sat unnoticed at a booth in a coffee shop at 48th Street and First Avenue. He had a cup of Lipton tea and no armed guard.

title: 1995 WORLD SRIES: NOTEBOOK;Avery Is Savoring The Chill
description: While just about everyone else was concerned tonight about low temperatures for the World Series games here, Steve Avery offered a different perspective.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Renewed Hope for Rate Cut Sends Bond Prices Higher
description: Yields on Treasury securities tumbled yesterday, with the market getting plenty of mileage out of renewed hopes for an interest-rate cut in the near future, thanks to comments by Alan S. Blinder, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt U S West Capital Funding, a unit of U S West Inc. of Englewood, Colo., is selling $250 million of notes due in 2005 through Merrill Lynch & Co. The notes are priced at par to yield 6.31 percent. The notes have a one-time put option on Nov. 1, 2000, at par, and are rated A2 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by Standard & Poor's Corp. and Duff & Phelps Credit.

title: At the Nation's Table: Mill Valley, Calif.;Where an Olive Press Entertains the Diners
description: When Roberto Zecca decided to open a restaurant in Marin County, California, he scouted around San Francisco and found that micro-brew pubs and restaurants with exposed pizza ovens and rotisseries were drawing crowds.

title: People
description: Eugene P. Beard, chief financial officer of the Interpublic Group of Cos., New York, was named to the additional new position of vice chairman for finance and operations. Jeff DeJoseph, executive vice president and director for account planning and strategic services at Bates USA, New York, has resigned to join the New York office of the J. Walter Thompson Co., a unit of the WPP Group, in the new post of executive vice president and account planning director. At Bates, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., Sarah Hatch was named to assume Mr. DeJoseph's responsibilities on an interim basis, in the new post of senior vice president and account planning director. She previously held a similar post at Gold Greenlees Trott, London.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;RJR Nabisco Falls Short of Expectations
description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation announced disappointing third-quarter earnings yesterday that showed declining profits in both its tobacco and food businesses from the corresponding period last year.

title: Witness in Gang Trial Cites Officer Payoffs
description: A New York City police officer was placed on administrative duty yesterday after a "lieutenant" in a Manhattan drug gang testified that the officer had taken payoffs to protect gang members.

description: The General Motors Corporation's victory in Shanghai, where Chinese officials have apparently selected the big American auto maker as a partner in a $1 billion assembly plant, is only one step in a long, tortuous process of negotiation.

title: GUCCI SHARES GAIN 22 PERCENT IN FIRST DAY OF TRADING
description: The Italian luxury goods maker Gucci Group sold 24.5 million shares in a $539 million initial stock offering yesterday. In New York Stock Exchange trading, shares of Gucci, priced at $22, gained 22 percent to close at $26.75. About 11 million shares changed hands. Most of the money raised in the offering will be used to repay debt owed to the company's parent, Investcorp International. Gucci operates 63 stores worldwide that account for 70 percent of its sales. Its products, which include leather handbags and shoes, are also sold in 75 franchise stores, 74 duty-free boutiques and 60 department stores.

title: Wine Talk
description: SOMEONE, it seems, has come up with a way to avoid the unpleasant task of dissecting a frog. Squeamish high school students and teachers can simply work on a virtual frog: call the creature up on a computer screen and effortlessly cut away by clicking an electronic mouse.

title: 2 Harlem Murder Suspects Are Facing Capital Charges
description: Two Manhattan men became the first criminal suspects formally charged with a capital crime under the state's new death penalty law when they were arraigned yesterday in the execution-style slaying of three members of a Harlem family.

description: Eugene P. Beard, chief financial officer of the Interpublic Group of Cos., New York, was named to the additional new position of vice chairman for finance and operations.

description: Wheat prices fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday as traders grew concerned that high prices were deterring sales for export.

title: Harold Cammer, 86, Champion of Labor And Rights Lawyer
description: Harold I. Cammer, a lawyer who championed the rights of workers, labor unions, accused Communists and victims of racial bigotry, died on Saturday at his home in Mamaroneck, N.Y. He was 86.

title: No Surgery for Webber
description: CHRIS WEBBER, the Washington Bullets' leading rebounder and scorer last season, decided yesterday to begin physical rehabilitation immediately on his injured left shoulder instead of undergoing surgery. (AP)

title: Julie Andrews, With Tough Edges
description: Tonight, with far too much calculation, PBS is broadcasting a "Great Performances" special called "Julie Andrews: Back on Broadway." This is the same night, of course, that Ms. Andrews officially opens on Broadway in the musical "Victor/Victoria." Featuring several numbers from the show, the television documentary has the unpleasant sheen of a glossy commercial. And that's unfortunate. Ms. Andrews's life in show business has indeed been rather extraordinary and is very much worth reviewing.

title: Reebok in Deal With the N.B.A.
description: Reebok International Ltd. and N.B.A. Properties, the licensing and marketing division of the National Basketball Association, said yesterday that they had signed an agreement under which Reebok would design and produce N.B.A. apparel featuring team logos. The agreement is for a minimum of three years, but other terms were not disclosed.

title: Youth Who Pleaded Guilty Describes Slaying
description: A teen-ager who pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the Brooklyn beating death of a homeless Ecuadorean immigrant testified yesterday that two other young men being tried on murder charges took leading parts in the attack.

title: Judge Apologizes for Ordering Girl to Re-enact Sexual Abuse
description: A Manhattan Criminal Court judge who ordered a 15-year-old victim of sexual abuse to re-enact her molestation in court apologized to the mother of the girl yesterday before sentencing the convicted attacker.

title: A Halloween Menu That's Suitably Spooky
description: AT the Jekyll & Hyde Club, 1409 Avenue of the Americas (57th Street), the wait for the horror show, with food and drink, can sometimes be an hour or more. Usually, there are no reservations accepted. But this Halloween is an exception; tables can be reserved for special seatings at 7, 9:15 or 11:30 P.M. The menu includes such frightening creations as cinnamon-nutmeg chicken breast with peach Frangelico sauce, garlic monster mash and "mummified monster burgers." The three-course dinner with an open bar and a free T-shirt is $89.95; $59.95 for children under 16. There will also be a costume contest. For reservations: (212) 989-3743.

title: HOCKEY;Healy's Stock Goes Up a Few Points
description: Glenn Healy didn't beat the Vancouver Canucks all by himself last night, but the veteran goalie looked good in the Rangers' 5-2 victory.

description: An article yesterday about Fidel Castro's stay in New York referred incorrectly in some copies to the restaurant he visited on Monday night. It was Jimmy's Bronx Cafe (not Freddy's), at 281 West Fordham Road.

description: The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, reported very strong third-quarter profit yesterday, well exceeding Wall Street's expectations.

description: I met Jesse, strangely enough, through Ross Perot," said Felix Rohatyn this week, recalling the "Six Degrees of Separation" coincidence that led him into an unexpected alliance with Jesse Jackson.

description: At Columbia University in New York, the flash point was a virulently anti-Semitic newspaper column praising the Million Man March. At the University of Southern California, it was a racist flier calling on whites to arm themselves against blacks.

title: After Apology From Prodigy, Firm Drops Suit
description: A Long Island investment firm said yesterday that it had agreed to drop a $200 million libel lawsuit against the Prodigy Services Company, in return for Prodigy saying it was sorry.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: SCENE: A theater district boite.

title: Capital Charges Filed in Deaths
description: Two Manhattan men accused of murdering three members of a Harlem family became the first criminal suspects formally charged with a capital crime under New York State's new death penalty law. But the decision whether to seek the death penalty for the two men will rest with the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, who had opposed the death penalty legislation.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Princely House Sale in Baden-Baden
description: The desire for a memento of princely history, even if it's just an empty picture frame or a cuckoo clock with the noble coat of arms, is compelling, and Sotheby's played on that desire at a huge recent auction in Germany to draw crowds so large and prices so high that it surprised even itself.

title: For Many Visiting Journalists, a Different Perspective on New York
description: Sure, the Clinton-Jiang meeting was of some interest to the reporters from all over the world who converged on New York to cover the anniversary of the United Nations, as was Yasir Arafat's snub by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Fidel Castro's visit to Harlem.

title:
BREEDERS' CUP' 95: NOTEBOOK;
Reverence for Cigar Isn't the Same as Fear
description: Cigar may have everyone's vote for Horse of the Year -- save for D. Wayne Lukas -- and he has won 11 consecutive races, but there is no shortage of owners and trainers willing to send their horses into battle against him in Saturday's $3 million Breeders' Cup Classic at Belmont Park.

title: Authorities Arrest Suspect In Michigan Kidnapping Case
description: Two young brothers who vanished 10 days ago after going to a store for potato chips were found safe today here and the suspect in their abduction was arrested, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;CHEVRON CORP. (CHV,N)
description: The Chevron Corporation reported a 33.6 percent drop in profits yesterday because of the one-time costs of putting its real estate business up for sale, but results were helped by strength from chemical operations.

title: Bengals Sign Foster
description: BARRY FOSTER, a Pro Bowl running back while with the Pittsburgh Steelers, signed yesterday with the Cincinnati Bengals. The Bengals declined to reveal contract terms. The Cincinnati Enquirer reported yesterday that the Bengals hoped to sign Foster to a two-year contract. Foster, 26, an unrestricted free agent, turned down a reported one-year, $1 million offer from the Bengals three weeks ago. (AP)

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's a girl for KIM BASINGER, 42, and ALEC BALDWIN, 37.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a gas explosion at the Marlboro Houses apartments in Brooklyn misstated their location. They are in Bensonhurst, not Coney Island. (Because of an editing error, the erroneous location also appeared in an article on Sunday.)

title: COMPANY REPORTS;DEAN WITTER, DISCOVER & CO. (DWD,N)
description: Dean Witter, Discover & Company said its third-quarter earnings rose 18.5 percent, bolstered by booming brokerage profits and an increase in revenue from its credit card business.

title: Real Estate;Signs of an improving market: a 12-story office building is going up in Washington.
description: A 12-story building rising in the heart of Washington's central business district is the first major structure built here for the general office market, rather than a specific tenant, in the last five years.

title: SMITH CORONA TO BE SOLD TO EMPIRE CAPITAL GROUP
description: The Smith Corona Corporation, the nation's last typewriter manufacturer, agreed yesterday to be sold to a group led by the Empire Capital Corporation for about $38.4 million. In connection with the agreement, Smith Corona filed a reorganization plan and a disclosure statement in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del. Under Federal bankruptcy law, the offer by Empire Capital is subject to higher bids. Smith Corona, based in New Canaan, Conn., filed for Chapter 11 protection on July 5. Empire Capital, based in Southport, Conn., specializes in acquisitions and corporate turnarounds.

title: On Campus; Journalism Dropped
description: The University of Michigan, which has offered courses in journalism since 1890, announced earlier this month that it would stop enrolling students in its master's degree program in journalism beginning next fall.

title: THE U.N. AT 50: ARAFAT;White House Condemns Giuliani for Ejecting Arafat From Concert
description: A day after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani expelled Yasir Arafat from a concert for world leaders at Lincoln Center, the Clinton Administration sharply criticized the Mayor yesterday for what Washington officials called an embarrassing breach of international diplomacy.

title: U.N. Warns Against Delay in Cutting Carbon Dioxide Emissions
description: Delaying action to rein in emissions of heat-trapping atmospheric gases like carbon dioxide could increase the rate and magnitude of future climatic changes and make the world more vulnerable to costly and possibly irreversible damages, a United Nations scientific panel says in a new report.

title: Foreign Affairs; Almost Egypt
description: There was a very revealing cultural flap here last month. Magda el-Roumy, the immensely popular Lebanese singer who first came to fame crooning in Egyptian Arabic in Cairo in the 1980's, decided not to take part in last month's Cairo International Song Festival. She and her band said they weren't coming to Cairo because, well, it was no longer hip -- no longer the Big Apple of the Arab world. The Egyptian musicians' union was so insulted it voted to ban her from performing in Egypt.

title: A Jamaican Way Station in the Bronx;Community of Striving Immigrants Fosters Middle-Class Values
description: There is the odd hole-in-the-wall serving up fiery jerk chicken, or a greengrocer with 10 kinds of exotic yams on his shelves. Cricket matches can be glimpsed in Van Cortlandt Park on summer afternoons. But it is difficult to identify overt signs of West Indian culture among the neatly kept, modest brick houses of Williamsbridge and Wakefield.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Rutgers Paper to Press Charges
description: The editorial board of The Rutgers Review, a student-run weekly newspaper at Rutgers University, said yesterday that it would press charges under the university'scode of conduct against six students accused of destroying 3,500 copies of the paper on Sept. 26. The students were part of a group denouncing a column in the paper that called for the death penalty against Mumia Abu-Jamal, whose conviction for the murder of a Philadelphia police officer has rallied protesters who maintain that Mr. Abu-Jamal was framed by the police because he is black.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;Sometimes Mashed Is Best
description: Whenever I think of sweet potatoes, I think of ovens and baking. Nothing there for a quick meal. But just as white potatoes can be prepared quickly if cut into small enough pieces, so can sweet potatoes. This mixture with cider, sour cream and yogurt produces a sweet puree with a hint of tartness.

title: Clumsy Diplomacy by Mr. Giuliani
description: It is fortunate that New York City does not need a foreign policy, because Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, who evicted Yasir Arafat from a city-sponsored concert for United Nations dignitaries on Monday night, clearly lacks the diplomatic touch.

title: Airline Did Not Know of Pilot's Troubled Past
description: When Michael P. Hillis applied for a job as a pilot at American Eagle in late 1990, he was on the verge of being dismissed from a smaller commuter airline for poor performance. But American Eagle never checked his job reference, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday misstated the comparative accuracy of a new map of the global sea floor and maps of Venus. The ocean map remains less accurate. The surface of Venus was mapped by the Magellan spacecraft to reveal objects as small as hundreds of feet across, while the new sea floor map can make out only features that are miles in diameter.

title: EASTERN COLLEGE REPORT
description: Boston College

title: Cable TV Continues Its Steady Drain Of Network Viewers
description: In a trend that may signal permanent changes in Americans' prime-time television watching habits, cable television continues to attract viewers steadily away from the broadcast networks.

title: Business Travel; Fees for guests who check out of their rooms early may become standard for the hotel industry.
description: CORPORATE travel departments are not going to like it, but Westin and Hyatt hotels have decided to charge guests who check out one or more days ahead of schedule.

title: Prosecution Won't Return Simpson Items
description: Lawyers for O. J. Simpson have filed a motion seeking the return of personal belongings seized in the double-murder case because balky prosecutors refused a routine request to release them.

title: The Pumpkins of '95 Are Big and . . . Light
description: PEOPLE who venture to pick-your-own pumpkin patches are finding a noticeable difference this fall. The pumpkins are generally as big and bright as in past years but, because of the drought, not quite as heavy.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GENE WILDER handed out awards at the "Gilda's Club Comedy Gala" on Monday evening to Ann S. Moore, the president of People magazine, and Peter J. Velardi, the retired chairman of Vanity Fair Lingerie.

title: AEG Businesses for Sale By Daimler-Benz
description: GEC-Alsthom said it was in talks with Daimler-Benz A.G. to sell AEG's power-transmission business, which has annual sales of about 2 billion marks ($1.4 billion). GEC-Alsthom is a 50-50 joint venture between GEC of Britain and the Alcatel Alsthom Company of France. AEG is an unprofitable unit of Daimler-Benz.

title: HOCKEY;Versatile Albelin Brings Devil Victories
description: Tommy Albelin, a Devils defenseman, was the team's most effective performer the night the Stanley Cup champions played their best game of the young season. Playing left wing instead of defense against the Detroit Red Wings last Thursday night, Albelin scored the second goal of the game and made the pass that set up the fourth one.

title: Stocks Stage a Comeback, With the Dow Rising 28.18 Points
description: Major stock averages rose yesterday for the first time in three days, with large-capitalization and transportation issues sharing the spotlight.

title: Prospective Labor Leaders Set to Turn to Confrontation
description: Frustrated by declining wages and an erosion of political power, the nation's labor movement is expected to turn today to a new corps of leaders who say they are willing to adopt the tactics of civil disobedience and confrontation, largely abandoned in the 1960's.

title: W.D. Campbell, 88; Promoted Scouting In the Third World
description: William D. Campbell, a philanthropist and elder statesman of the Boy Scouts of America and World Scout Committee in Geneva, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EATON CORP., Cleveland, which makes products for the automotive, industrial and military markets, said it planned to buy Figgie International Inc.'s Hartman Electrical Manufacturing unit in Mansfield, Ohio, for undisclosed terms.

title: Market Place;Investors frown, but Snapple distributors see a new age.
description: WHEN Philip A. Marineau resigned abruptly as president and chief operating officer of the Quaker Oats Company on Monday, many on Wall Street assumed he was walking the plank for what Business Week had recently rated as the worst billion-dollar deal of the 1990's -- the acquisition of Snapple, the iced-tea and fruit-drink subsidiary that has sorely disappointed Quaker and Wall Street since Quaker paid $1.7 billion for it last year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bond Yield Falls to 6.32% On Hopes of a Rate Cut Treasury yields tumbled, as credit market traders renewed hopes of an interest-rate cut soon. Alan S. Blinder, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, propelled the market when he said that interest rates were excessive for the long term, and that the Fed should begin to lower them, but not necessarily "imminently." The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.32 percent, from 6.39 percent. [ Page D18. ] Stock averages advanced, led by large-capitalization and transportation issues. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 28.18 points, to 4,783.66. The transportation index had its best day since July. [ D8. ]

title: Khijuri Journal;Science Can't Eclipse a Magic Moment for Millions
description: Before dawn today, Stephen A. Kolodny positioned himself under a stand of eucalyptus trees here and settled down to wait. By the time the Sun was a red orb on the rim of the north Indian plain, a crowd of villagers had gathered around him, putting his counseling skills in heavy demand.

title: Sports of The Times;Cleveland Stays Alive At Midnight
description: UP until game time, it was still a delight for the locals just to be holding the World Series in Cleveland for the first time in 41 years -- just to have the downtown all lit up on a chilly October evening. Then it all got serious, even grim.

title: With Trial Looming, Japanese Sect Still Thrives
description: The 2,000 cows in this sleepy town at the foot of Mount Fuji have rich grass to feed on, but when hundreds of members of a religious cult moved into the village they stopped producing milk.

description: With the Legislature to begin a special session on Wednesday, Gov. John G. Rowland's proposal for a casino in Bridgeport appears to be flagging, and many lawmakers are wondering how he will avoid an embarrassing defeat.

title: Olympic Coach Named
description: For years, while becoming a highly successful soccer coach at the University of Virginia, BRUCE ARENA dreamed of coaching the Olympic soccer team. Yesterday, he got that wish. At a news conference at R.F.K. Stadium in Washington, HANK STEINBRECHER, executive director of the United States Soccer Federation, officially appointed Arena to head the United States team for the Olympic Games next summer in Atlanta.

title:
At the Nation's Table: Mill Valley, Calif.;
Where an Olive Press Entertains the Diners
description: When Roberto Zecca decided to open a restaurant in Marin County, California, he scouted around San Francisco and found that micro-brew pubs and restaurants with exposed pizza ovens and rotisseries were drawing crowds.

Fletcher, previously managing director of the consulting firm Fletcher Associates Inc., Mamaroneck, N.Y., to the new position of senior vice president. REEBOK INTERNATIONAL LTD., Stoughton, Mass., named Robert Meers, president of Reebok's specialty business group, to the positions of president and chief executive of the Reebok brands division. Paul Fireman, the company's chairman and chief executive, and Paul Duncan, executive vice president, had temporarily been handling the duties.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Melville Plans To Split Into 3 Companies
description: Weary of institutional shareholders gnawing at its heels, the Melville Corporation, one of the 10 largest retailers in the country, said yesterday that it planned a major reorganization by selling two of its chains and packaging the other seven into three separate, publicly traded companies.

title: Proof of a Breast Implant Peril Is Lacking, Rheumatologists Say
description: THE American College of Rheumatology took a firm stance yesterday in the bitter battle over the safety of silicone breast implants, saying there was no evidence that the devices caused diseases that had been attributed to them.

description: A former City Council President who was arrested Friday while taking photographs at City Hall for a weekly newspaper said yesterday that he would seek a change of venue when his case comes to trial.

title: Olivetti Contract
description: The computer maker Ing. C. Olivetti & Company and Hughes Network Systems have won a contract to provide a satellite telecommunications network for Adam Opel A.G. and Vauxhall Motors, the German and British operations of the General Motors Corporation. The contract is worth $50 million to $70 million, said people familiar with the deal. The contract places Hughes Olivetti Telecom, the telecommunications joint venture between the two companies, among the top operators of satellite communications systems in Europe. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Father Wins U.S. Apology In Son's Death
description: After a two-year crusade investigating his son's death in a grain silo accident, Ronald Hayes today got part of what he wanted: a formal and extraordinary apology from one of the highest ranking officials in the Labor Department.

title: Suffolk Debate Centers on Sales Tax and Lilco
description: In the first major debate in the race for Suffolk County executive, the incumbent, Robert J. Gaffney, found himself on the defensive today as his opponent, Tony Bullock, attacked his record on spending, taxes and efforts to take over the Long Island Lighting Company.

title:
At the Nation's Table: Homestead, Fla.;
A Produce Stand Shows Longevity
description: Thirty-five years ago Robert Moehling's father left him at a crossroads bordering the family avocado grove in Homestead, Fla., to sell surplus cucumbers. The 7-year-old boy sat roadside all afternoon but failed to make a sale. The next day, his father sent Robert back with two rough wooden signs that read: ROBERT IS HERE. The signs caught the attention of passers-by, and Mr. Moehling has been selling produce on that corner ever since. But the stand has grown considerably.

title: A Tip Yields Fresh Clues To a Killer
description: The crime shocked the region in the spring of 1966. Seven-year-old Wendy Sue Wolin, walking down an Elizabeth, N.J., street to meet her mother, was attacked by a man who seemed to come out of nowhere. He stabbed her once. She thought she had been punched, but within minutes she bled to death.

title: U.S. Doesn't Really Want Iraqi Leader to Go; Voters Chose Survival
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;DIGITAL EQUIPMENT (DEC,N)
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that it made a $48 million profit in its first quarter -- the computer maker's fourth consecutive profitable quarter after posting a loss of $131 million a year earlier.

title: Applause for Castro? Why?
description: It is hard to know what is more disturbing the thought of business leaders like David Rockefeller sitting down to a lunch with Fidel Castro or the sight of hundreds of people at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem cheering the fatigue-wearing Cuban revolutionary.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about the human immune system misspelled the given name of an immunologist at the University of Maryland in Baltimore who commented on a new mathematical model of how the system works. He is Dr. Garnett Kelsoe, not Garrett.

title: Memphis Journal;Elvis's Other Home: Unenshrined and All but Uninhabitable
description: It is not uncommon for tourists to show up at Annette Neal's apartment at a public housing project here and ask to look inside. Dutifully, she walks them through her ant- and roach-infested kitchen, past an oven that does not work, and then down a dark, damp hallway to what remains of a bedroom.

title: Justice, of Sorts, in Chile
description: The retired general Manuel Contreras has finally gone to prison, five months after Chile's supreme court ordered him there for the 1976 car-bomb murders in Washington of a leftist Chilean official, Orlando Letelier, and Ronni Moffitt, his American assistant. Mr. Contreras headed the secret police during the first, most murderous years of Gen. Augusto Pinochet's dictatorship. His incarceration is a relief, but now Chile's struggle to control the military shifts to other fronts.

title: Springing Vows On the Guests
description: ERICA MEISEL and Scott Donner held what was billed as an engagement party in August on a rented 167-foot yacht docked on the West Side of Manhattan. After the guests had sipped champagne and dipped sushi, the couple emerged from the yacht's cramped bathroom, along with a rabbi, two friends, a photographer and a video man.

title: Sanders to Face Falcons Despite Contract Woes
description: DEION SANDERS has been cleared by the National Football League to play in Sunday's game against the Atlanta Falcons even though the league has ruled his contract invalid, the Dallas Cowboys' owner, JERRY JONES, said yesterday.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Illness Sidelines Tarpley
description: Forward ROY TARPLEY will not play for the Dallas Mavericks in the immediate future.

title: ALLIANCE CAPITAL TO BUY BRITISH BUSINESSES
description: Alliance Capital Management L.P. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Cursitor-Eaton Asset Management Company and Cursitor Holdings Ltd. of Britain for $141.5 million. The purchase of the Cursitor businesses will raise Alliance's total assets under management to $154 billion. Cursitor, a closely held money-management company based in London, manages $10 billion in assets, about 80 percent of which come from United States pension funds. The company has offices in London, Paris and Boston. Alliance, a mutual-fund and money-management company based in New York, is 59 percent-owned by the Equitable Companies. Shares of Alliance gained $1, to $21.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: William Ellis, Educator, Dies at 55
description: William Ellis, an educator who helped develop national strategies for working with children with dyslexia and other learning impairments, died on Thursday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 55 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Panel Votes Zoning Rule On Sex Shop
description: The City Council's Land Use Committee overwhelmingly approved strict zoning regulations on sex-related businesses yesterday, paving the way for changes that supporters said would benefit the city as a whole but that opponents complained would leave some neighborhoods worse off.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13 CLINTON MEETS CHINESE LEADER President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin of China met and made their best effort to repair a relationship that has been strained by disagreements over Taiwan and human rights. A1

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;Nebraska Allows Phillips to Return
description: Six weeks after his dismissal from the University of Nebraska football team, Lawrence Phillips returned to practice this afternoon.

title: The Risks of Lettting Russia Disengage
description: The meager results of this week's lunch-hour summit between President Clinton and President Boris Yeltsin will strengthen skeptics in both countries who say we should stop pretending to be "partners."

title:
Real Estate;
Signs of an improving market: a 12-story office building is going up in Washington.
description: A 12-story building rising in the heart of Washington's central business district is the first major structure built here for the general office market, rather than a specific tenant, in the last five years.

title: CORDIS CHANGES BYLAWS IN RESPONSE TO TAKEOVER BID
description: The Cordis Corporation responded to a hostile $1.6 billion takeover bid from Johnson & Johnson yesterday by changing its bylaws to require that its board receive advance notice before any potential suitor can make a direct appeal to its shareholders. Johnson & Johnson answered Cordis promptly by serving Cordis with the appropriate request. The change in Cordis's corporate bylaws was small, but the effect could be to delay an unwanted bid from Johnson & Johnson or other unfriendly buyers. Johnson & Johnson, based in New Brunswick, N.J., offered on Thursday to acquire Cordis for $100 a share. Cordis, based in Miami, has said it will consider the offer.

title: Suspect's Lawyers Want an Alias for 'Megan's Law' Victim
description: The brutal rape and slaying of 7-year-old Megan Kanka, allegedly by a neighbor with a hidden past of sex offenses, so outraged the public that her name became a household word and three states named community notification laws for her.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Detroit's Japan-Friendly Cars Go to Tokyo
description: In years past, American automobile executives came to the Tokyo Motor Show to see the latest competitive challenges they would be facing from Japan. But at this year's show, which opens on Wednesday, the American auto makers will be exhibiting as much as looking.

title: Leno Signs a Contract For 5 Years on 'Tonight'
description: NBC has signed Jay Leno to a new five-year contract as host of the "Tonight" show, the network announced yesterday.

title: AMERICAN GENERAL SHARES FALL DESPITE RECORD EARNINGS
description: Shares of the American General Corporation, a Houston-based insurance company, fell in heavy trading yesterday even though the company reported record quarterly earnings. Shares of the company fell $3.625, or 9 percent, to $35.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. The company said net income in the third quarter rose nearly 14 percent, to $181 million, from $159 million in the corresponding period a year earlier. American General said it was hurt by increased delinquencies and defaults in its rapidly expanding consumer loan subsidiary, causing the company to charge $47 million against profits to cover loan losses. About 3.75 percent of the company's $8.4 billion of loans were delinquent by 60 days or longer at the end of September, up from 3.04 percent at midyear and 2.77 percent a year ago.

title: Snowstorm Stares Down Denver's New Airport; Airport Blinks
description: Battered by the first major blizzard of the ski season, Denver's new $4.9 billion, high-tech airport proved to be a weak match for human error and Mother Nature.

description: SHARON STONE, the seductive star of "Basic Instinct" and the forthcoming "Diabolique," has a tony new title: Chevalier of Arts and Letters.

title: Linda Goodman, Writer Turned Astrologer, Dies
description: Linda Goodman, whose down-to-earth insights into character traits were credited with bringing astrology out of the occult section and onto the best-seller lists with the 1968 publication of "Sun Signs," died on Saturday at Penrose Hospital in Colorado Springs. She was about 70 and lived in Cripple Creek.

title: Nasdaq Posts Rise of 3.9% In Uncovered Short Sales
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that the number of open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq market rose 3.9 percent in the month that ended Oct. 13 to a new peak.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Fidel Castro's stay in New York referred incorrectly in some copies to the restaurant he visited on Monday night. It was Jimmy's Bronx Cafe (not Freddy's), at 281 West Fordham Road.

title: ON PRO FOOTBALL;Raiders and Chiefs Raise A.F.C's Hopes
description: National Football League owners told us during the off season that the playoff system did not need revamping. They told us that setting up a system in which Dallas could battle San Francisco in the Super Bowl was not necessary. They said that they love the National Football Conference versus American Football Conference bowl thing. They said that the N.F.C.'s 11 consecutive Super Bowl drubbings over the A.F.C. was a cyclical thing. In essence, they said four words: Be cool. Be patient.

title: Clinton and Hollywood Producer Met on Contract, a Memo Shows
description: President Clinton directed aides to pay attention after the Hollywood producer Harry Thomason suggested a business partner to him for a consulting contract, memorandums at a Congressional hearing showed today.

title: Congress Backs Israel Embassy Switch, but Gives Clinton an Out
description: Finding a compromise on a delicate foreign policy question, Congress overwhelmingly approved legislation today to move the United Sates Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem by 1999 after adding a provision that would allow the President to delay the move indefinitely.

title: Don't Let the Broadcasters Off Free
description: Congress plans to take $270 billion out of Medicare, almost $200 billion out of Medicaid and about $40 billion out of tax credits for low-paid workers. Yet it apparently has enough cash to send politically powerful broadcasters a gift worth perhaps $40 billion. The gift will come in the form of free licenses to use newly available frequencies to broadcast digital television programs and services.

description: Cigar may have everyone's vote for Horse of the Year -- save for D. Wayne Lukas -- and he has won 11 consecutive races, but there is no shortage of owners and trainers willing to send their horses into battle against him in Saturday's $3 million Breeders' Cup Classic at Belmont Park.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Water Rationing May Be Eased
description: Because of recent heavy rainfall, state officials may soon end the drought emergency that brought mandatory water rationing to seven northern New Jersey counties starting Sept. 13. Governor Whitman said yesterday that the State Department of Environmental Protection was assessing reservoir levels, which rose significantly after last weekend's downpours, the A.P. reported.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Wrong Turns at Motor Vehicles
description: Both the state police and the Division of Motor Vehicles said yesterday that they were investigating the disappearance of about $2,000 in cash receipts from a Motor Vehicles agency on Route 46 in Wayne. Authorities said the money disappeared sometime after Gov. Christine Todd Whitman turned State Motor Vehicles offices over to private management from state control in July. Last February, five state workers at another Motor Vehicles agency in Wayne were arrested and charged with stealing thousands of dollars from receipts.

title: THE U.N. AT 50;Words of Warning, Words of Hope as Marathon Reaches Finish Line
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by heads of state and other leaders yesterday at a special session of the General Assembly marking the 50th anniversary of the United Nations, as compiled by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription service:

title: Speaker Silver's Craven Maneuver
description: The New York State Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, has thrown his manipulative powers behind a labor relations bill urgently promoted by New York City's police union. The measure is very good for the powerful Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and very bad for the city.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a gas explosion at the Marlboro Houses apartments in Brooklyn misstated their location. They are in Bensonhurst, not Coney Island. (Because of an editing error, the erroneous location also appeared in an article on Sunday.)

title: George Keane, 78, Stage and TV Actor
description: George Keane, an actor who made his Broadway debut in Maurice Evans's 1940 production of "Hamlet" and went on to win praise in such contemporary works as "Brigadoon" and "The Seven Year Itch," died on Oct. 10 at his home in Riverdale, the Bronx. He was 78.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Uta Hagen Returns, Tossing Wine
description: There is probably no sight more exhilarating, or unnerving, on a New York stage these days than that of Uta Hagen throwing a drink in Laila Robins's face.

title: 268 Pounds Slimmer, and Counting
description: Two years ago, Lucy Lustig Curtis weighed 663 pounds, a number she hid even from her husband. She was unable to move or bend much, so tying her shoes was impossible, and sustained exercise was out of the question. Walking at even a leisurely pace was difficult. Climbing stairs made her lose her breath.

title: WESTINGHOUSE PLANNING TO ELIMINATE 225 JOBS
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 110 jobs at its headquarters in Pittsburgh and eliminate 115 jobs at its science and technology research center in Churchill, Pa. The cuts will eliminate 16 percent of the 670 jobs at the company's headquarters before the end of the year under a reorganization plan based on a three-month study by Arthur Andersen Consulting. In addition, about 170 employees in Pittsburgh will be transferred to other offices, leaving a staff of 390 people, a spokesman said. The cuts at the science and research center will affect about 13 percent of the center's 890 employees.

title: BREEDERS' CUP '95;Distaff Commands Top Billing, Too
description: The name on the marquee may read Cigar, racing for his 12th straight victory and for acclaim as the Horse of the Year, but the betting at Belmont Park is that the show stopper on Breeders' Cup day will star the three best fillies in America dueling for $1 million and two championships.

title: Wine Talk
description: SOMEONE, it seems, has come up with a way to avoid the unpleasant task of dissecting a frog. Squeamish high school students and teachers can simply work on a virtual frog: call the creature up on a computer screen and effortlessly cut away by clicking an electronic mouse.

title: Mexican Rebel Leader's Arrest Raises Questions on Peace Talks
description: News of the arrest of a reputed top guerrilla commander has drawn an outcry of opposition protest and raised doubts about the Government's commitment to peace talks with the rebels.

title: Personal Health;The forgotten child in treating pain is the child.
description: CHILDREN'S aspirin has been on the market for decades, joined more recently by children's acetaminophen. Both are mild pain relievers, although mainly used to reduce fevers. But when it comes to quelling severe pain, the kind, for example, associated with sampling bone marrow, setting a broken arm or sewing up a bad cut, children have long been therapeutic orphans.

title: Suspects Flee Court By Breaking a Door
description: Two men, including one accused of murder, with a history of escaping from police custody, escaped from a courtroom holding cell in Brooklyn yesterday by breaking through a narrow opening in a wall, the authorities said.

title: Fearing Bankruptcy, 2 SUNY Hospitals Are Seeking to Go Private
description: The State University of New York is seeking permission to set up private, nonprofit corporations to run two of its three teaching hospitals, where for decades students who would not otherwise have been able to afford a medical education have trained as physicians and nurses.

title: Corrections
description: Subheadings for obituaries on Monday about the singer Maxene Andrews and the writer Kingsley Amis were reversed in some copies. The reference to "a onetime radical" applied to the obituary of Mr. Amis; the one to a "last role" in "a Manhattan revue" was for Miss Andrews's.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Timely Calls to Battered Women
description: Thanks to a new computer phone-notification system that goes into operation today, battered women in Passaic County will be informed within hours after an assailant is released from county jail. The $14,000 system, called Victim Information and Notification Everyday, will operate around the clock and is expected to make more than a thousand calls in its first year. It generates a phone message that alerts a battered woman to call back for specific information.

title: SLM Files Chapter 11
description: SLM International Inc., a maker of sporting goods and apparel, filed for Chapter 11 protection today in United States Bankruptcy Court here.

title: On Campus; Unabomber: Notoriety Becomes Celebrity
description: The Unabomber is one of the most-wanted men in America, having killed 3 and injured 23 in 16 bombings since 1978, and there is a million-dollar reward for his capture.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: SCENE: A theater district boite.

title: Move Over, Iceman! New Star From the Andes
description: On an icy, 20,700-foot summit of the Peruvian Andes, archeologists have found the well-preserved frozen remains of a young woman who apparently had been sacrificed to the Inca gods about 500 years ago. Her body was wrapped in finely woven wool, and she was wearing an elaborate feather headdress. Around her were rare ceramics and statuettes, artifacts of the religion that took her life on the sacred mountain.

title: Feast for the Dead Celebrates Life
description: FOR Mexicans, whether in New York City, Mexico City or Los Angeles, the Days of the Dead, Nov. 1 and 2, are not for mourning and fasting, but for celebrating and feasting. It is the time when the dead return, in spirit, to their family homes, where they find their favorite foods waiting on altars strewn with marigolds. Corn, the foundation of Mexican cooking, is omnipresent.

title: 1995 WORLD SERIES;After 47 Years and 11 Innings, Indians Win One
description: The Cleveland Indians entered Game 3 of the World Series clinging to a life preserver known as Jacobs Field, a cozy park that has been home to many a heroic comeback for them, but nothing but horrors for visitors.

title: Cutting School Bureaucracy Won't Put Money in Classroom;Skilled Trades Program
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: SHARON STONE, the seductive star of "Basic Instinct" and the forthcoming "Diabolique," has a tony new title: Chevalier of Arts and Letters.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Relief From Oxygenated Gas
description: Drivers in Mercer County and most counties in southern New Jersey will not have to buy special oxygenated fuel this winter, after all. The Environmental Protection Agency yesterday issued a revised plan for controlling carbon monoxide pollution in southern New Jersey, doing away with the sale of the special fuel, which has been in use across the state in winter since 1992. JOE SHARKEY

title: Groups Urge Use Of Audited Media
description: The American Association of Advertising Agencies and BPA International, which audits the circulation of business and consumer publications, are joining to urge agencies and clients to use media with audited circulations.

title: Werner Herzog's Vision Of a World Gone Amok
description: Werner Herzog adopts the outlook of an extraterrestrial visitor for "Lessons of Darkness," his otherworldly 1992 look at Kuwait after the gulf war. A consummate poet of doom, Mr. Herzog finds much here to affirm his apocalyptic premonitions. Oil fires rage, blackening the skies. Bomb craters attest to the recent damage. Implements of torture can still be found, in a place where even an old toaster carries sinister implications. A mother holds her traumatized son and says, "When my child wept, his tears were black."

title: At the Nation's Table: Brushtown, Pa.; This Schoolhouse Serves Home Fries
description: The alarm rings at 4:30 A.M. Sharon Kerchner threads her way past the wooden stands holding three or four quilts she's working on, past the shelves crammed with goblets and candlesticks. She pushes open the swinging louver doors and strolls into the kitchen -- to oil the old iron skillet for the home fries and to chop onions for the chipped beef gravy she serves to truckers and tourists, farmers and retirees, the judge and the mayor who drop by her Little Red Schoolhouse Restaurant in the south-central Pennsylvania hamlet of Brushtown, near Gettysburg.

title: Routine Electronic Monitoring Of Fetuses Is Challenged in Study
description: Electronic fetal monitoring during labor and delivery, used with a majority of births in this country, offers little significant benefit to justify its routine use, according to researchers reviewing the practice.

title: Japanese May Close Mortgage Company
description: Seven major Japanese commercial banks may close an indebted home mortgage company they own and write off billions of dollars in loans, a spokesman for one of the banks said today.

title: THE U.N. AT 50: GENERAL ASSEMBLY;Birthday Celebration Winds Up With Speeches Pledging to Help the U.N. Do Better
description: Fifty years to the day after the United Nations was officially born, its 185 member states wound up their marathon birthday celebration today with a unanimous pledge to revitalize the often criticized, financially strapped organization and make it more efficient, more relevant and more responsive to a world much changed since 1945.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EATON CORP., Cleveland, which makes products for the automotive, industrial and military markets, said it planned to buy Figgie International Inc.'s Hartman Electrical Manufacturing unit in Mansfield, Ohio, for undisclosed terms.

title: Sheppard Is Traded
description: The Detroit Red Wings traded right wing RAY SHEPPARD, a 52-goal scorer in 1993-94, to the San Jose Sharks yesterday for center IGOR LARIONOV, a two-time Olympic gold medalist. Larionov, 34, joined the N.H.L. in 1989 with Vancouver. (AP)

title: Chromosome Damage in the Lab Is Tied to a Chromium Supplement
description: CHROMIUM picolinate, a dietary supplement popular among fitness buffs and people trying to lose weight, has been shown in tests done on cells grown in the laboratory to cause severe damage to chromosomes. Although no animal studies of the supplement's cancer-causing potential have yet been done, the genetic changes observed in the laboratory suggest that this widely sold supplement could be carcinogenic.

title: Seeking Statesmanship, Farrakhan Softens Tone
description: In the week since hundreds of thousands of black men heeded his call and poured into Washington for a day of prayer and protest, Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, has begun to moderate his language in an apparent campaign to broaden his political support.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's a girl for KIM BASINGER, 42, and ALEC BALDWIN, 37.

title: Traffic Tie-Up Abets Thefts From Gallery
description: Thieves took advantage of the gridlock caused by the 50th birthday of the United Nations to steal $220,000 in sculptures, including two small bronzes by Henry Moore, from a gallery in midtown Manhattan on Monday.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Beattie Is a Candidate To Be Expos Executive
description: The Montreal Expos are considering Jim Beattie, a former Yankees pitcher, for their vacant general manager's position. Beattie is the director of player development for the Seattle Mariners.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: Tools to Smooth The Grain of Life
description: TOOLS were a part of life when I was a boy in blue-collar Brooklyn after World War II. Men carried their tools to work in the dark mornings, jammed into leather belts, or slung over shoulders, or gripped in gloved hands against the cold. They carried those tools with a certain pride, like prizefighters with gym bags; they were symbols of work and skill.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PEOPLES HERITAGE BUYING BANK OF NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: Peoples Heritage Financial Group Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the Bank of New Hampshire Corporation for about $168 million in stock. The agreement calls for Peoples to exchange two shares for each Bank of New Hampshire share. The acquisition would give Peoples, based in Portland, Me., an expanded presence in New Hampshire, with branches serving 80 percent of the state, instead of 40 percent now. In Nasdaq trading, shares of Bank of New Hampshire fell $1, to $34.25, while shares of Peoples Heritage fell 25 cents, to $20.75.

title: Ralph Herbert, 86, a Baritone With the City and Met Operas
description: Ralph Herbert, a baritone who sang with the New York City Opera and the Metropolitan Opera, died on Saturday at Riverview, a nursing home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 86.

title: Kerkorian's Strategist Delivers A List of Demands to Chrysler
description: After weeks of hints and barbs, Jerome B. York, Kirk Kerkorian's strategist and spokesman, presented his list of demands today to the Chrysler Corporation, asking the company to: appoint him to its board, give Mr. Kerkorian veto power over two more directors, and weaken its antitakeover provision to permit Mr. Kerkorian to buy more stock.

title: Bridge
description: Becoming a life master has grown easier, but explaining the rules has gone the other way.

title: A Temple of 80's Chic Gets a Corduroy Makeover
description: COULD it be true? Could it be that Morgans Hotel -- the harbinger of Eurostyle in New York, the prototype "designer hotel" when it opened in 1984 -- had become tired? Or -- as its French designer, Andree Putman, put it, "use jusqu'a la corde" -- threadbare?

title: Wireless Auction Cleared
description: A Supreme Court Justice cleared the way today for an auction of licenses for wireless personal communications services, or P.C.S. Associate Justice John Paul Stevens set aside an appeals court order that had postponed the scheduled Dec. 11 auction. The Cincinnati-based 6th Federal Circuit Court of Appeals had ordered the postponement so it could study a challenge to regulations that prevent Radiofone Inc. from bidding on some of the licenses because of limits on the amount of the P.C.S. spectrum one company may own.

title: HOCKEY;Vancouver Outskates, Outscores New Jersey
description: The Canucks induced the Devils into playing Vancouver's style of hockey tonight, which is skate, skate, skate and attack, attack, attack. Unable to keep up, the Devils were handed a 4-2 setback before a crowd of 13,980 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Getting 'Get Shorty' Off the Page to the Screen
description: Novelists have often been treated shabbily in Hollywood. F. Scott Fitzgerald and William Faulkner hated the place. Nathaniel Hawthorne wasn't around to take breakfast meetings at the Four Seasons, but look what Hollywood just did to his classic "The Scarlet Letter": added sex, violence and a happy ending.

title: 4 Win Prizes for Coverage of the Americas
description: Four journalists have won the 1995 Maria Moors Cabot Prizes from Columbia University for promoting press freedom and inter-American understanding.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Heating Oil Prices Jump Sharply Amid Concern Over Low Supply
description: Heating oil prices rose sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday as traders grew concerned over low supply.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 15 about corruption charges against a former Italian Prime Minister, Silvio Berlusconi, misidentified the meeting at which he was served court papers informing him of a judicial inquiry. It was a United Nations crime conference in Naples in November 1994, not a meeting of the Group of Seven industrial democracies in Naples in July 1994.

title: Prospects Fading in House For Repeal of Glass-Steagall
description: The prospects for broad financial deregulation this year dimmed considerably today as House Republic leaders abandoned a proposal for a $4.8 billion fee on three Government-sponsored businesses that assist the housing industry.

title: BREEDERS' CUP '95: NOTEBOOK;The Setting at Belmont Is Suited for You and I
description: The winner of the $1 million Breeders' Cup Sprint at Belmont on Saturday will very likely be named the year's champion sprinter, and there are half a dozen horses who could lay claim to the prize, the most intriguing a California-based colt who was bred in Florida and does his best racing in New York.

title: BREEDERS' CUP '95;For Cigar, Low Odds But Long Trip in Classic
description: Eighty-four horses were entered yesterday in the seven races of the Breeders' Cup at Belmont Park on Saturday, with Cigar listed at 3-5 as the shortest-priced favorite in the 12-year history of America's richest race, the $3 million Classic.

title: A Latin Epidemic Spreads Horror, and Questions
description: With the rain, over the mountains, came the plague.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Pierce to Relieve Cross at Tight End
description: The crowd of reporters gathered around the locker of Aaron Pierce was so big that one would think Fidel Castro was giving a speech. Pierce, the Giants' quiet H-back, was talking about his new role on the offense -- tight end.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;A 20-Year-Old's Fight
description: TRAVIS ROY's orange practice jersey was hanging on the boards yesterday at Walter Brown Arena in Boston. Roy jumped over those boards to start his first shift for Boston University last Friday night. He slammed head-first into the same boards only 11 seconds later and did not get up after shattering the fourth vertebra in his neck.
