title: COUNCIL APPROVES PACKAGE OF CURBS ON SEX BUSINESSES
description: The City Council yesterday overwhelmingly approved a far-reaching package of restrictions on X-rated video stores, peep shows and topless bars in New York City, rejecting the concerns of civil libertarians and siding with residents who complained about the proliferation of sex businesses in their neighborhoods.

title: Transactions
description: Basketball

title: Gunfire and Balloons Greet Palestinian Police
description: To the sounds of Arabic chants and pistol fire, the first Palestinian police officers arrived in Jenin today to start the process to end 27 years of Israeli military rule in most of the Arab-populated areas of the West Bank.

title: Claiming Fraud, Florida Seeks to Bar E.D.S.
description: Florida's top law-enforcement official filed suit today against the Electronic Data Services Corporation, the computer services unit of the General Motors Corporation, saying it had defrauded the state by selling a troublesome system to track welfare payments.

title: An Officer Is Indicted In a Killing
description: In what prosecutors called a rare homicide indictment of a policeman, a Manhattan grand jury has charged an officer with murder in the shooting death last month of a 25-year-old woman hit by stray gunfire in a Washington Heights restaurant.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EMC BUYS MCDATA FOR $230 MILLION IN STOCK
description: The EMC Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the McData Corporation for $230 million in stock. EMC, which makes information storage and retrieval systems for computers, said it expected the acquisition to add 8 cents to 10 cents a share to earnings this year. McData, a closely held company based in Broomfield, Colo., makes products for use in computer networking. Its main product, the Escon Director, is marketed by the International Business Machines Corporation. EMC, based in Hopkinton, Mass., said it would operate McData as a wholly owned subsidiary. Jack McDonnell, McData's president and chief executive, will head the unit.

title: G.O.P. Avoids Senate Vote on Medicare
description: On the first day of Congressional debate on the Republicans' vast umbrella budget legislation that at a stroke would overhaul decades of Government social policy, Republican senators managed today to preserve their plan to place strict limits on Medicare spending while avoiding, at least for the time being, a direct vote on the matter.

title: Schering-Plough Picks New Chief
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation said today that its board had named the company's president, Richard J. Kogan, to the additional post of chief executive beginning Jan. 1.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Alcatel Alsthom Plans a Swap
description: Alcatel Alsthom S.A., the French telecommunications equipment company, will give all of its press holdings to the media company Havas S.A., in exchange for a 21.2 percent stake in Havas, the two companies said yesterday.

title: Mondrian's Esthetic In a Cafe
description: THE crowds making their way through "Piet Mondrian: 1872-1944," the exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, can extend their Dutch experience at the Garden Cafe. The restaurant has been refurbished by some of the Netherlands' most prominent interior, graphic and industrial designers.

title: Currents;This Surreal Way To Your Table
description: IT'S just what you would imagine an interior based on the Tower of Pisa would be: very Italian and a little quirky, humorous and, well, leaning.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the debate over the differences in severity of prison sentences for crack cocaine offenders and other drug offenders referred incorrectly in some editions to those who contend that last week's prison disturbances were related to Congressional refusal to narrow the disparities. They were advocates of prisoner rights, not prison advocates.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Julie Andrews Is Back, in Drag, in Drag
description: Thirteen years have passed since Blake Edwards made his cinematic chef d'oeuvre, "Victor/Victoria," but as far as Julie Andrews is concerned, 13 years is no more than the blink of an eye. That's gloriously apparent in Mr. Edwards's otherwise big, patchy stage adaptation, which opened last night at the Marquis Theater.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Helping Agapanthus Bloom

title: Jury Out on Sentence
description: The jury that convicted a fan on Monday of killing the Tejano music star Selena retired for the evening today without deciding on a sentence. The panel deliberated for five and a half hours on the punishment for Yolanda Saldivar before it was sequestered. Possible sentences range from probation to life in prison.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Truce Sought on Dwight Morrow
description: State education officials are renewing efforts to get Englewood, Tenafly and Englewood Cliffs to settle their 10-year feud about desegregation of Dwight Morrow High School in Englewood.

title: The Pop Life
description: Warning Stickers

title: Viveca Lindfors, Stage and Film Actress, 74
description: Viveca Lindfors, the tall, dark and square-shouldered Swedish actress whose towering presence made her a star in dozens of movies and plays, died yesterday in Uppsala, Sweden. She was 74.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Bozell Worldwide Leads the Boy Scouts Into a Memorable Campaign
description: IN the shining iconography of American advertising, there is Mom, there is apple pie and there is the Boy Scouts of America.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MANITOWOC TO BUY REFRIGERATOR MAKER FOR $126 MILLION
description: The Manitowoc Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Shannon Group Inc., a privately held refrigerator and freezer maker, for about $126 million. Manitowoc might also make an additional payment of up to $7 million, depending on Shannon's earnings. Shannon, based in Brentwood, Tenn., is expected to have 1995 sales of $125 million to $140 million. Manitowoc, based in Manitowoc, Wis., is a maker of construction cranes and refrigeration products.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Pepitone Is Arrested
description: The former Yankee JOE PEPITONE was released yesterday from Long Island Jewish Hospital, where he was treated for minor injuries sustained in a drunken-driving accident, the police said. The 55-year-old Pepitone was arrested and charged with driving while intoxicated after losing control of his car at 4:30 A.M. Tuesday in the Midtown Tunnel, said Detective DWIGHT CUNNINGHAM. The former first baseman was given a desk appearance ticket ordering him to appear in court on Nov. 30.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;State to Fight Presidential Poll
description: The state is seeking to overturn a ruling last week that allowed a nonpartisan Presidential preference poll called CityVote to be placed on Newark's Nov. 7 ballot. The Attorney General's office argued in an appeal filed yesterday that "a municipality cannot put a question on the ballot that the municipality is not legally authorized to act upon," said Chuck Davis, a spokesman for the office.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FULTON FINANCIAL CORP., Lancaster, Pa., a financial service company, signed an agreement to buy Gloucester County Bankshares Inc. Woodbury, N.J., for $32.8 million in stock.

title: G.I.'s Abroad: Bosnia on Their Mind
description: At a snack bar on the sprawling United States Army base here, several soldiers from an artillery unit were enjoying pizza during a break from their training for a possible peacekeeping mission in Bosnia.

title: On Quebec Border, Fear of Secession
description: Like many of his confreres, Raymond Durocher, 45, a quality control manager in an Ontario polyester yarn plant, commutes to work every day across the Ottawa River from this small border town in Quebec.

title: Exxon's President Is Planning to Retire
description: The Exxon Corporation said today that C. R. Sitter will retire as president and a director on Jan. 31.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Salt Water Defiling Cape May
description: Encroaching salt water from the Atlantic Ocean and Delaware Bay is contaminating wells in the Cape May area, causing the supply of drinking water to dwindle, officials say.

title: Labor Wakes Up
description: John Sweeney's victory over Thomas Donahue in the first contested election for the leadership of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. yesterday reflected the labor federation's recognition that it must change or continue to shrivel. But the campaign raised the possibility that Mr. Sweeney will waste his fresh start on convulsive organizing tactics when the federation needs not just energy but more sophisticated understanding of the global economy and the changing workplace to which it must adapt.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BRIAN HAMILL has been the still photographer on every Woody Allen movie since "Annie Hall" was made in 1977, and 200 of the 100,000 pictures he has taken since then have been compiled in a new book published by Harry N. Abrams, "Woody Allen at Work: The Photographs of Brian Hamill."

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * The Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, to the DDB Needham Dallas Group and Elgin Syferd DDB Needham, Seattle, both units of the Omnicom Group, to help handle marketing, communications and other tasks for the E.P.A.'s Energy Star Programs, intended to encourage a reduction in emissions of greenhouse gases and other pollutants. The Omnicom units will serve as partners in the project with ICF Inc. of Washington, owned by ICF Kaiser International. The billings were estimated at $30 million over five years. * Ekco Housewares, Franklin Park, Ill., a unit of Ekco Group Inc., to Cramer-Krasselt, Chicago, to handle its account, previously at Tassani & Paglia, Chicago. The billings were estimated at more than $3 million. * Callaway Gardens, Pine Mountain, Ga., to Fitzgerald & Co., Atlanta, to handle advertising and strategic marketing for the resort, previously handled by Robinson, Yesawich & Pepperdine, Orlando, Fla. The billings were estimated at more than $1 million. * Starsight Telecast Inc., Fremont, Calif., to Katsin/Loeb, San Francisco, to handle the account of the developer of an interactive television on-screen program guide, previously handled by Kresser Stein Robaire, Santa Monica, Calif. The billings have not yet been determined.

title: BASKETBALL;O'Neal and Webber to Miss the Season's Start
description: The Magic will begin defense of its Eastern Conference title without Shaquille O'Neal, the game's most powerful inside force. He is scheduled to undergo surgery today on his broken right thumb and could be sidelined eight weeks. It's an injury that is sure to have immediate ramifications on the National Basketball Association season.

title: Yeltsin Told to Wash Political Linen in Private
description: Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev responded today to a barrage of criticism from President Boris N. Yeltsin by saying he will stay in his job only if he is not treated as a servant.

title: Why Exclude Balkan Peacemaker?
description: To the Editor:

title: Miles to Go and Nowhere to Unload
description: IS there somewhere I can leave my luggage for a few hours?" a woman struggling with what looked like a small metal trunk asked at an information booth at Grand Central Terminal.

title: WORLD SERIES '95;Polonia Is Producing for the Braves and Crowing to the Yankees
description: Luis Polonia is in the World Series, and the Yankees are not. Tonight little Luis figuratively stuck out his tongue at his former employer.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Book Notes column yesterday about a collection of photographs commemorating the Million Man March in Washington misstated the name of the publisher. It is Crown Publishers, not Crown Books.

title: Life Sentence In the Killing Of a Woman
description: Reginald McFadden, the convicted murderer who convinced Pennsylvania prison officials that he had been rehabilitated, was sentenced to life in prison today for killing a Long Island woman three months after his parole.

title: High-Stakes Poker Put Lobbyists Close To D'Amato's Ear
description: Each Thursday night for years, a small group of influential lobbyists and other Washington insiders assembled in the office of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato for a private poker game. They ate Chinese food, smoked expensive cigars and told bawdy stories late into the night over pots that sometimes reached hundreds of dollars.

title: WORLD SERIES '95;Atlanta Shows Cleveland It Can Rock and Roll, Too
description: Mike Hargrove, the manager of the Cleveland Indians, has been the more scrutinized manager in the World Series because of decisions involving the removal of, or the failure to take out, his starting pitchers.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Philippine Court Upholds Seat for Imelda Marcos
description: The Supreme Court cleared the way today for Imelda Marcos to be declared a winner in legislative elections last May and allow her to take a seat in the House of Representatives.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: * Alexandra Tanner was named senior vice principal and strategic planning and research director at Publicis/Bloom New York, a unit of Publicis S.A., succeeding Stephani Cook, who joined Lowe & Partners/SMS, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., as executive vice president for strategic planning. Ms. Tanner was previously vice president and planning and research director at Ogilvy & Mather New York, owned by the WPP Group. * Strattan S. White was named to head the advertising and marketing group at Paradigm Communications, Tampa, Fla., succeeding Vince Fabrizzi, who will be responsible for new business and the overall operations of Paradigm's subsidiaries. Mr. White was previously a marketing and sales promotion consultant to Paradigm. * Roger Parry was named chief executive of More O'Ferrall Adshel, London, succeeding Russell Gore-Andrews, who on Feb. 1 will step down as chief executive and continue as chairman. Mr. Parry was previously president of Carat North America, owned by Aegis Group P.L.C., London. * Norman Rich was named to head the new interactive and direct-mail division of Arnold Advertising, McLean, Va., a unit of Arnold Fortuna Lawner & Cabot, as a senior vice president. He was previously president at Black Ink, New York, which closed. * Timothy O'Connor was named manager of global/corporate advertising for beauty and fashion at Hachette Filipacchi Magazines, New York, as part of the formation of a corporate beauty and fashion division. He was previously fashion and fragrance manager at Premiere magazine, New York, which is owned by Hachette Filipacchi, a unit of the Lagardere Group. * James O. Cox 3d was named to head Edelman Litigation Public Relations, New York, a new division of Edelman Public Relations Worldwide, while continuing as executive vice president and general manager of the New York public affairs division of Edelman Worldwide.

title: For the Debate On Debt Limit, No Usual Script
description: By anybody's standards, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin is plenty rich. But even his staff blanched a bit when one of his predecessors, James A. Baker 3d, suggested recently that a quirk of Federal law would make Mr. Rubin personally liable for any Federal debt incurred after the Government hits a $4.9 trillion ceiling on borrowing sometime in the next two weeks.

title: U.S. to Turn Over Troops Accused of Murder or Rape to Japan
description: Hoping to settle growing anger at crime by American soldiers in Japan, the United States agreed today to hand over troops accused of murder or rape.

title: COMPANY NEWS;JAPANESE COMPANIES TO BID ON DAM PROJECT IN CHINA
description: Hitachi Ltd. said yesterday that it had joined with three other Japanese companies to form a consortium to compete for bids to build hydropower generators for the Three Gorges Dam project in China. Backed by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry and the Export-Import Bank of Japan, the consortium -- Hitachi, the Toshiba Corporation, the Mitsubishi Electric Company and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd. -- met with Chinese officials on Monday and Tuesday to give a presentation on Japanese expertise in the construction of power stations, a Hitachi spokesman said. The Japanese Government's backing stands in contrast to the position taken by the Clinton Administration, which opposes the project because of environmental and human rights concerns and because of doubts about the dam's financial liabilities.

title: Father Disputes Daughter's Role in Slaying of His Family
description: William Batista kept a tight rein on his daughter, Arelis. So tight, he acknowledged yesterday, she sometimes yearned for more freedom.

title: Democrat Who's Not Docile in Defeat
description: Democratic lawmakers entering the Capitol this morning looked not just powerless but pole-axed at the prospect of a fresh round of defeat as the Republican's huge seven-year budget reconciliation bill was trundled forth for passage as a two-house juggernaut.

title: Economic Scene;Using Creative Accounting to Reduce the Federal Deficit
description: WHEN Congress sells an oilfield, should the proceeds count toward reducing the budget deficit? To most economists, such a move is "pure window dressing." in the words of William D. Nordhaus of Yale University.

title: Panel Meets On Telecom Bill
description: A conference committee of the House and Senate met today on a bill to overhaul the nation's communications laws, as both Republicans and Democrats signaled their desire to work out disputes over deregulating cable television prices and concentration of ownership in the media industry.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Monday headlined "Save Sterling Forest" said incorrectly that a $2 billion bond issue would be decided in next month's New York State balloting. No such measure will appear.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;New Base for Turnpike Police
description: State officials will unveil a new $12.5 million headquarters today for the State Police who patrol the New Jersey Turnpike. Troop D Headquarters has its own heliport and a computerized tracking system that can pinpoint a stranded driver, said John Hagerty, a spokesman for the State Police. The complex, owned by the Turnpike Authority, is next to the Molly Pitcher rest stop in Cranbury.

title: Kmart Official Said to Depart
description: In a move that may reflect even deeper turmoil at the Kmart Corporation than is already known, Charles Chinni, the newly appointed executive vice president of merchandising, is said to be leaving the company.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;SmithKline Profit Up 9%
description: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., Britain's second-largest drug maker, said third-quarter pretax profit rose 9 percent to L310 million, or $499 million, fueled by new-product growth. Last year, the company reported third-quarter pretax profit of L285 million. SmithKline said sales rose 16 percent, to L1.78 billion. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Stocks were trading lower here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 162.82 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, at 17,807.99. On Wednesday, the Nikkei fell 43.44 points.

title: Farris A. Flint, Americas Foundation Founder, 95
description: Farris A. Flint, the founder and honorary chairman of the Americas Foundation, died on Oct. 13 at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 95.

title: Feeard Journal;Beacon Draws Irish Fire (What's France Up To?)
description: A band of angry, anxious, defiant people here on the blustery Loop Head peninsula in western Ireland have effectively declared war, or at least a state of permanent hostility, on their Government 200 miles away in Dublin.

title: ON BASEBALL;Hargrove Fails to Realize That Change Is Good
description: If nothing else, Mike Hargrove was consistent. Precisely following the pattern last night that he practiced the night before, he let Paul Assenmacher continue to warm up in the bullpen and watched Luis Polonia stroke a run-producing hit against Cleveland's right-handed starting pitcher.

title: ON FOOTBALL;Columbia Now Feels Addicted to Winning
description: In 1993, when George Rupp became the 18th president of Columbia University, he surveyed the terrain of an outstanding institution and was generally pleased with what he saw. However, there was a glaring blemish that had been ignored and allowed to worsen: Columbia football.

title: RUSSIANS MAY GET SUPPORTING ROLE FOR BOSNIA PEACE
description: President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin have agreed that up to 2,000 Russian soldiers may carry out support functions in Bosnia to back up a peace agreement, senior NATO and Administration officials said yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Gore household is certainly busy churning out books these days. The new one by Vice President AL GORE, "Common Sense Government: Works Better and Costs Less" (Random House), goes on sale today. And yesterday Broadway Books announced plans to print a collection of photographs by TIPPER GORE.

title: T. J. Johnston, 72, Former Chairman Of Big Search Firm
description: Thomas J. Johnston, a former chairman of the executive search firm Heidrick & Struggles, died on Monday at Marin General Hospital in Greenbrae, Calif. He was 72, and had homes in California at Belvedere near San Francisco and Pebble Beach.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EQUIFAX PICKS CHIEF AND LIFTS DIVIDEND
description: Equifax Inc. said yesterday that it had named Daniel W. McGlaughlin, now president and chief operating officer, to replace C. B. Rogers Jr. as chief executive, effective on Jan. 1. The company, based in Atlanta, also reported a dividend increase as well as a planned stock split, antitakeover defense and a stock buyback. Equifax said Mr. Rogers, 66, would remain as chairman. Mr. McGlaughlin, 59, will retain the title of president. The position of chief operating officer will not be filled. Equifax, a provider of information to insurance, financial and health care companies, said it decided to raise its dividend 6.5 percent and repurchase up to $200 million of its shares. The company said its regular quarterly dividend would be increased to 16.5 cents a share from 15.5 cents. The company said its shareholder rights plan -- also called an antitakeover defense -- would be enacted if an unwanted suitor acquired a stake in the company of 20 percent or more.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Fujitsu Reports Earnings Jump
description: Fujitsu Ltd., Japan's largest computer maker, earned $309 million in the six months that ended on Sept. 30, the company said yesterday. The profit for the first half of its fiscal year was more than five times its profit of $58 million in the corresponding period a year earlier. Six-month sales amounted to $16.6 billion, up from $15.0 billion a year earlier.

title: Mrs. Clinton Redefines First Lady
description: To the Editor:

title: Worry Over Du Pont's Outlook Helps Push Dow Down 29.98
description: Stock prices slumped yesterday as concerns grew that earnings growth might slow in the fourth quarter and into 1996. It was the third decline in the last four sessions.

title: Executive Changes
description: SCHEIN PHARMACEUTICAL INC., Florham Park, N.J., named Michael D. Casey, former president and chief operating officer of Genetic Therapy Inc., Gaithersburg, Md., a division of Sandoz Pharmaceuticals, to the new position of executive vice president.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP. (UTX,N)
description: The United Technologies Corporation said Wednesday that its profit rose 12 percent in the third quarter, driven by higher revenues from international markets and strong performances in four core businesses.

title: Swissair Names New Chief
description: The Swissair Group announced this week that Philippe Bruggisser will take over as its chief executive in 1997. Mr. Bruggisser, 47, will succeed the current president and chief executive, Otto Loepfe, 59. Mr. Bruggisser, who joined Swissair in 1979, will become chief operating officer in January and serve as deputy to Mr. Loepfe for a year.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Seem to Suffer From a Power Shortage
description: If the Philadelphia Flyers are the benchmark for how to build a young team, the Islanders showed tonight that it will be quite some time before they are able to measure up.

title: Militant Is Elected Head of A.F.L.-C.I.O., Signaling Sharp Turn forLabor Movement
description: With the election of John J. Sweeney yesterday as the new president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. the American labor movement took a sharp turn toward militancy, rebuilding union membership, moving women and minorities into the policy-making ranks and tackling in hostile Congress.

title: Troopers Stop Cars and Find Duffle Bags Full of Cocaine
description: The state troopers were in Queens as part of a narcotics task force yesterday when they saw two cars being driven erratically. They followed and stopped the vehicles. In one, they made a catch: $20 million worth of cocaine, a haul that prosecutors said would put a significant dent in the borough's drug trade.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;Club Mediterranee Chooses 2 Agencies
description: Club Mediterranee S.A., the resort company based in Paris, said yesterday that it had selected two agencies to handle advertising and other assignments in Europe, which had been handled since 1991 by Publicis S.A. in Paris. The billings were estimated at $31.6 million.

title: G.O.P. Delays Debating Bills To Avoid Loss
description: House Republican leaders sidestepped two caucus-busting debates today on the eve of important voting on the budget, postponing action on two spending bills when it seemed that junior Republicans and some moderates might bolt and vote with Democrats.

title: New TV Shows: Not a Single Hit
description: The television season, now six weeks old, is being called everything from a slight aberration to almost Armageddon for the broadcast networks. But one thing is certain: Nobody would call the group of new shows they unleashed a bumper crop of blue-chip prospects. A record 42 shows were introduced in September, and so far there is not an unqualified hit among them.

title: Mary Wickes, 85, Character Actress for 50 Years
description: Mary Wickes, a tart-tongued character actress whose long career on the stage and in films extended from "The Man Who Came to Dinner" to the two "Sister Act" movies, died on Sunday at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center. She was 85.

title: LOOKING BACK;Foreign Policy, New York Style
description: Presiding over a city of immigrants, New York Mayors have always pursued their own foreign policy. "It's a long and glorious tradition," said Nathan Leventhal, a former deputy to Mayors John V. Lindsay and Edward I. Koch and president of Lincoln Center, where Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani played host to heads of state Monday night. "I don't think what Giuliani did is any worse." What Mr. Giuliani did was have Yasir Arafat evicted from a concert for world leaders, prompting embarrassment in Washington. Other Mayors have dabbled in diplomacy to similar results.

title: Focus Cancer Research on Prevention
description: To the Editor:

title: Currents;Classic Meets Modern
description: THE jackets, skirts, dresses and sweaters are classic in design; the interiors of the boutiques are anything but. There are white walls and a wide-plank oak floor, and the lamps, racks and tables are sculptural forms in welded steel.

title: Toasting the U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: Currents;Whimsical Attraction
description: A YEAR ago, Mitch Nash and his brother Seth, partners in Blue Q, in Pittsfield, Mass., introduced 55 sets of zany and entertaining magnets. By the end of this year, they expect to have 20 more.

title: Top Clinton Aides Spreading Message of Budget's Peril to Children
description: First on his schedule today was a quick call to a local radio station, so when Michael A. Stegman got off the plane from Washington this morning, he dashed for the nearest pay phone.

title: 18 Russian Soldiers Slain
description: Eighteen Russian soldiers were killed in an ambush on their convoy in the separatist region of Chechnya, Russian public television said today.

title: Purchase for Preservation Fills a Gap in Putnam County
description: Capping a four-year effort to preserve one of the last unspoiled tracts of woodlands and pasture in the lower Hudson River Valley, a private conservation group has purchased Glynwood Farm, a 957-acre estate here.

title: Jury Assesses Abortion Foes $8.6 Million
description: A jury in a Federal court here awarded an obstetrician-gynecologist $8.6 million today from abortion opponents who, the doctor said, drove him from his practice, followed and harassed him around the clock and repeatedly threatened his life and that of his wife.

title: Amoco to Sell Motor Club
description: The Amoco Corporation said today that it planned to sell its Amoco Motor Club to Signature Group, a unit of Montgomery Ward & Company. Terms were not disclosed. The transaction covers the long-term licensing of the Amoco Motor Club name. Signature Group, of Schaumburg, Ill., provides auto club services. It plans to keep Amoco Motor Club operations in Des Moines.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Insurgents in Sri Lanka Are Reported to Kill 36
description: Tamil Tiger guerrillas attacked a hamlet in east central Sri Lanka today, hacking or shooting to death 21 villagers, the police said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Anheuser-Busch to Sell Ball Club and Snack Unit Anheuser-Busch plans to sell the St. Louis Cardinals ball club and its Eagle snack-food business. "We are focusing on what we know best," said August A. Busch 3d, which is to say, the beer business and theme parks. Eagle Snacks expects a 1995 loss of $25 million. Separately, Anheuser said earnings rose 3.1 percent in the quarter. [D2.]

title: Cozy Is Not Comfy In High Point, N.C.
description: THE furniture community made its semiannual pilgrimage to the International Home Furnishings Market in High Point, N.C., this week to lick its wounds and search its soul.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;PROCTER & GAMBLE CO. (PG,N)
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that its earnings in the fiscal first quarter climbed 13 percent from a year earlier, benefiting from increased worldwide sales and shipments of its products, which include Tide detergent, Crest toothpaste and Pampers disposable diapers.

title: Studies Suggest That Genes Define a Person's Nutrient Needs
description: Researchers have found a gene that fosters spina bifida and other devastating fetal problems known as neural tube defects. The gene's malign effects come into play only if the mother does not consume high levels of folic acid, a B vitamin found in vegetables like spinach and broccoli.

title: New Ulster Leader Plans to Instruct Clinton
description: David Trimble, the outspoken new leader of the largest Protestant party in Northern Ireland, does not disagree with people who call him arrogant. When he makes his first visit to the White House next week, he says, he is ready to tell President Clinton what the United States should be doing, and not be doing, in his home province.

title: Henry A. Goldwater, Bridge Tournament Director, 94
description: Henry A. Goldwater, one of the leading directors of bridge tournaments in the United States, died on Tuesday at Goldwater Memorial Hospital. He was 94 and had lived on the East Side of Manhattan before being hospitalized for several years.

title: POP REVIEW;The Otherworldly, Romantic And Divine, Steeped in Jazz
description: When Jane Siberry asked for questions from her audience at the Fez on Monday night, she got one: "Do you have any idea what it is that you're channeling?" She deflected it with a laugh, but her songs invite speculation on the otherworldly. With sultry incantations and open-ended music, Ms. Siberry ruminates over humanity's place in the universe and over love in many forms: romantic, maternal, divine.

title: Bobby Riggs, Brash Impresario Of Tennis World, Dies at 77
description: The irrepressible chauvinist Bobby Riggs, a former Wimbledon champion who in 1973 reached a dual zenith of tennis fame and infamy as the 55-year-old braggart who was throttled by Billie Jean King in their landmark Battle of the Sexes bout, died last night in Leucadia, Calif., a suburb of San Diego. He was 77.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Graf's Missing Money Goes to Tax Authorities
description: A big chunk of STEFFI GRAF's supposed missing fortune has been found, and $14.3 million has been deposited with tax authorities, the tennis star's lawyer said yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: 5 Die as Train Hits Bus

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Asian Ladybugs Invading State
description: Asian labybugs, first brought to the Carolinas and Georgia to control plant-eating pests like aphids, are now invading New Jersey homes. Large swarms have been reported on home exteriors, with some making their way inside as the weather cools, said Edward Bradbury, president of the New Jersey Pest Control Association. The insects can be removed with a vacuum cleaner, he said. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Compromise on a Shareholder Suit Bill
description: After a series of private metings, a group of leading Congressional Republicans and Democrats have agreed on a compromise version of a bill that would make it far more difficult for shareholders to file lawsuits accusing stockbrokers, accountants or corporate official of fraud.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Retired Couple Haunted by the Past
description: Playwrights -- the gods, after all, of their own universes -- have been sending characters to hell for as long as there has been theater. There are, of course, the literal hells of philosopher-dramatists like Shaw and Sartre. But there are also the more disturbing hells of everyday life, waking nightmares with no promise of an ending.

title: A Director For Disney Once Jailed In Sex Case
description: For the last few days, the Walt Disney Company has been caught up in an uproar after disclosures that the director of its new film, "Powder," is a convicted child molester who served 15 months in prison in the late 1980's.

title: G.I.'s Weigh Role in Bosnia
description: Some G.I.'s in Germany say they look forward to a tour in Bosnia. But others have nagging doubts about such a mission. Page A8.

title: Emil Jonassaint, 82, Ex-Haiti President, Dies
description: Emil Jonassaint, the jurist who served last year as the puppet President of the military junta that overthrew President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, died on Tuesday at his home in Port-au-Prince. He was 82.

title: Pamela Ann Shaw, AIDS Lecturer, 31
description: Pamela Ann Shaw, who used her battle with AIDS to warn young people about the risks of unprotected sex, died on Tuesday at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 31 and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Man in the News: John Joseph Sweeney;New Fire for Labor
description: John J. Sweeney, the new president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., was not playing by Marquis of Queensbury rules when he told the Los Angeles Board of Supervisors in July that if it pushed through a plan to cut 18,000 workers from its payroll, his union would conduct "a massive campaign of resistance and retribution."

title: September Home Sales Reached Highest Rate in Nearly 2 Years
description: Sales of existing homes jumped to the highest level in 20 months in September as buyers took advantage of falling mortgage rates, a real estate group said today.

title: A Budget Democrats Should Vote For
description: The House is scheduled to vote today on a remarkably sensible, though tough, budget plan sponsored by Democrats, mostly conservative. The plan will not pass, but the vote still matters. President Clinton is likely to veto the initial budget that the Republican-controlled Congress puts on his desk. His negotiating strength will flow from today's vote. If Democrats line up behind their colleagues' plan, then Mr. Clinton can pull the G.O.P. toward its provisions. But if the Democrats flee, then he is left with no option to fight for.

title: S.E.C. Asks MCI For Documents On Milken Role
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has requested documents from the MCI Communications Corporation as part of an investigation into whether Michael R. Milken is honoring a 1990 order that barred him from the securities industry for life, people familiar with the matter said yesterday.

title: Speakers With Style
description: MOST stereo speakers are design nightmares. The plain black or brown boxes just sit there as resting places for potted plants and acrobatic cats, creating visual dead space.

title: Dinkins-Koch Team Assails Giuliani
description: Yesterday's joint news conference by former Mayors Edward I. Koch and David N. Dinkins, called to criticize the current Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, will be but the first in a series of appearances together, the two said.

title: Results Plus
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: Morris Bruckman, 81, Spacecraft Engineer
description: Morris Bruckman, an engineer who led a group that designed the landing gear for the first spacecraft on the moon, died on Tuesday. He was 81 and lived in Franklin Square, L.I.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Funds to Aid Sex Offenders
description: Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz said yesterday that the state would find money to pay expert witnesses hired to testify at hearings on behalf of indigent former convicts identified as dangerous sex offenders under "Megan's Law," according to a bar association official.

title: John McGill Krumm, 82, Episcopal Bishop
description: The Right Rev. John McGill Krumm, a firm Episcopalian voice for ecumenism, social advocacy and the ordination of women, died on Monday in Tustin, Calif., where he had been bishop-in-residence since 1983. He was 82.

title: Police Seek Escape Path And Escapees
description: As police and correction officers searched all five boroughs yesterday for two defendants who escaped Tuesday from a holding cell in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, investigators were trying to determine how they got free.

title: Essay;Let the Loser Lose
description: In a tie and suit, Fidel Castro, describing himself as a politician, flattered the media biggies gathered for lunch in Mort Zuckerman's Fifth Avenue apartment with: "You are the cream of the crop."

title: ON BASKETBALL;A Shoe of Her Own, But It's Time to Get League of Their Own
description: Not only does the name work, but the shoes also fit. Now Sheryl Swoopes, as in hoops, needs a permanent place to lace up her size 10 1/2's.

title: Free East Timor
description: When candidate Bill Clinton was asked about East Timor, he said, "We have ignored it so far in ways that I think are unconscionable." But as President, he has continued Washington's 20-year support of Indonesia's occupation of neighboring East Timor.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;First-Half Profits Rise at Volkswagen
description: Volkswagen A.G., Europe's largest car maker, reported better-than-expected results yesterday for the first nine months and said it expected "clearly better" results for 1995 than it had in 1994. Sales climbed 10.9 percent in the nine months to 65.2 billion German marks, or $47 billion, producing profits of 185 million marks, or $133 million. The car maker posted a loss of 73 million marks in the first nine months of 1994.

title: Greenwich Youth Linked To Racial Slur Is Attacked
description: One of the five white teen-agers accused of planting a racist slur in the Greenwich High School yearbook in June was punched by a group of black youths at a party on Saturday night, Greenwich officials said yesterday.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Placing Bets On a New Medicare
description: When an elderly person breaks a hip, the typical hospital stay is just seven days. That is at least three fewer days than was the case a decade ago, before Medicare switched to a flat payment system for each illness or injury.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the United Nations' 50th anniversary referred incorrectly to Macedonia in some copies. It is not the United Nations' newest member; Palau is.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices Steady, But Off Their Session Highs
description: Prices of Treasury securities were steady yesterday, but were off their session heights.

title: Daiwa Affair Turns Up Heat on Japan's Finance Ministry
description: In the volatile world of finance, where billions of dollars can cross the ocean in seconds, one pillar of strength has been the Japanese Ministry of Finance. This cluster of elite bureaucrats controls billions of dollars and can have a major influence on exchange rates.

title: Sports of The Times;Indians Must Beat Maddux To Survive
description: KENNY LOFTON was moving fast, with great purpose. Unfortunately for the Indians, the game was over. He was heading for the inner sanctum of the clubhouse, where seldom is heard an inquisitive word.

title: Dr. Lucjan Dobroszycki, 70; Wrote of Doomed Polish Jews
description: Dr. Lucjan Dobroszycki, who endured and then chronicled the life of Poland's doomed Jewish community before, during and after the Holocaust, died on Tuesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 70 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Giuliani? He Wouldn't Get Castro's Vote
description: Sitting at a polished oval conference table at The New York Times yesterday, Fidel Castro broke from his characteristic political discourse to make a pronouncement.

title: Dry Cleaners Admit Illegal Waste Disposal
description: Six dry cleaners in Westchester County pleaded guilty yesterday to illegally disposing of hazardous waste, District Attorney Jeanine F. Pirro announced.

title: Gerald Olanoff, Architect, 42
description: Gerald B. Olanoff, an architect who worked on the Brooklyn Botanic Garden and the Bronx Zoo, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 42.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Ferruzzi and Montedison Rise on Takeover Talk
description: Shares of Ferruzzi Finanziaria S.p.A. and its subsidiary Montedison S.p.A. rose yesterday on the Milan stock exchange for the second session in a row after the collapse of their proposed merger with Gemina S.p.A. prompted talk that they may be takeover targets. Shares of Ferruzzi, which gained 11 percent on Tuesday, were up another 12 percent, or 134 lire, to 1,208 lire. Montedison shares, which rose 5 percent on Tuesday, were up 18 lire, to 1,084.

title: Record S.E.C. Settlement by Merrill and Lazard Expected
description: In the largest settlement of its kind in municipal finance, Merrill Lynch & Company and Lazard Freres have each agreed to pay about $10 million to settle charges brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission over a secret fee-splitting contract that the two firms mantained.

title: New York Wins G.O.P. Concessions on Cuts in Medicaid
description: Republicans members of congress form New York won last-minute concessions from Speaker Newt Gingrich tonight on reductions in the Medicaid program, the single largest source of Federal money to the state and a major point of contention between Mr. Gingrich and his fellow Republican, Gov. George E. Patkai.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AFTER IMPROVED EARNINGS, TELEDYNE DECIDES NOT TO SELL
description: The board of Teledyne Inc. has decided against selling the company in light of four consecutive quarters of improved earnings, the company said yesterday. Since March, the company, one of the last sprawling conglomerates in American business, has been exploring whether to sell, but third-quarter earnings released last week nearly doubled from last year, mostly from a surge in sales of specialty metals. The board's decision was based on the recommendation of a special committee of outside directors, the company said. Teledyne, based in Los Angeles, makes aviation electronics equipment, tank engines and metals for aircraft and auto manufacturing, among other products.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Bridging a Generation Gap
description: Jam sessions are often the best places to hear how well two musicians who play the same instrument can improvise: back to back, the odd ticks and flashes that create a style are underscored. For pianists, the experience is as rare as finding a club with two pianos.

title: Study Finds City Hospitals At a Loss to Cope With Cuts
description: An independent study has found that huge budget cuts in the last year have had devastating effects on New York City's municipal hospital system, in some cases eroding its ability to provide care for New York's poor.

title: Now Cut Defense Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Cardinals and Snack Unit Are Put on Block by Busch
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies, in a surprise announcement yesterday, said that it would sell the St. Louis Cardinals baseball team and the Eagle Snacks subsidiary as part of a plan to concentrate on its beer business and theme parks.

title: BASKETBALL;Knicks' Problems Come in 3's
description: Hot head, hot hand. Vernon Maxwell, the often-troubled shooting guard acquired by Philadelphia in the off season, erupted for 10 3-pointers last night as the Knicks continued their preseason swoon under Don Nelson.

title: Shaw's Fair Lady
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;LCI INTERNATIONAL TO BUY 2 LONG DISTANCE BUSINESSES
description: LCI International Inc. signed letters of intent yesterday to acquire the long distance telecommunications businesses of Teledial America Inc. and an affiliated company, ATS Network Communications Inc., for about $115 million in cash. The company said the combined revenues for Teledial and ATS Network were $81 million in 1994. Teledial, based in Grand Rapids, Mich., does business as the US Signal Corporation. ATS is a regional long distance carrier based in Memphis. LCI said the acquisition would strengthen its market presence in the Midwest and south central United States, and would broaden its network and switching operations in those regions.

title: After Shootout, South Korea Police Hunt Infiltrator From the North
description: More than 20,000 troops and police officers scoured Puyo county today, searching for a North Korean infiltrator who survived a gunfight on Tuesday in which another infiltrator was wounded and captured, a police officer was killed and two other officers were wounded.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;DU PONT (E. I.) DE NEMOURS & CO. (DD,N)
description: The shares of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company fell yesterday after the company, the nation's largest maker of chemicals, reported third-quarter earnings that made investors nervous, even though they surpassed analysts' expectations.

title: Japanese Cult Leader Dismisses Lawyer, Gaining Delay in Trial
description: As 10,000 policeman were tightening security on the eve of Japan's trial of the decade, the guru of the Aum Shinrikyo religious sect abruptly dismissed his lawyer tonight and won an indefinite postponement of the trial.

title: Bausch & Lomb Panel to Review Practices
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. said today that it had appointed a committee of independent directors to review its management and control practices. The move comes in response to a recent article in Business Week magazine outlining questionable practices that certain managers may have used to increase sales figures.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Two Contradictory Views of Russia
description: 'THE RUSSIAN QUESTION' AT THE END OF THE 20TH CENTURY By Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn Translated and annotated by Yermolai Solzhenitsyn. 135 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15.

title: Stanley Learned, 92, Former Oil Executive
description: Stanley F. Learned, former president and chief executive of the Phillips Petroleum Company, died on Saturday at his home in Charlotte, N.C. He was 92.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Evacuees Return Home
description: Nearly 3,000 evacuees went home today after authorities neutralized a leaking toxic chemical that displaced residents for up to two days and sent 500 to hospitals to seek treatment for burning eyes and breathing difficulties.

title: Calpers, a Loud Corporate Critic, To Adopt System to Judge Itself
description: Following the advice that it gives to others, the California Public Employees Retirement system, the largest and most active public pension fund in the country, will announce today that it has adopted a set of corporate governance principles to help judge its own performance.

title: GOLF;Norman's Grip on Trophy Broken by a Technicality
description: Every weekend hacker knows that the game of golf isn't fair, but perhaps no one knows that better than the man who might be the best player in the world.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Sale of Cookson Unit
description: Cookson Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it would receive $92 million from the Ferro Corporation of Cleveland for its Synthetics Products Company, or Synpro. In August, Cookson, based in London, agreed to sell the company to Ferro but did not specify terms. Synpro, also of Cleveland, produces chemical additives used by plastics and rubber manufacturers and has operations in Ohio, Texas and Connecticut. The company had sales of $100 million in 1994. Cookson expects the sale to close on Tuesday. (Dow Jones)

title: Out of the Toolbox and Into Artworks
description: BARE walls often provoke people to cover them with art. John Hechinger, the chairman of the Hechinger Company, which owns 120 home center stores across the United States, turned out to be easily, and lastingly, provoked.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;Anti-Smoking Ads To Begin Tonight
description: The American Cancer Society will begin running a television commercial tonight that urges public support of the strict regulations on tobacco advertising proposed by the Clinton Administration.

title: Japan's Auto Makers Pumping Out Sport Vehicles
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation's Zaus, for Zooming Adventure Utility Sports, is a roofless Jeep look-alike that can be driven through water. The instrument panel is waterproof, and the bottom half of the doors are missing to allow water to run out.

title: COMPANY NEWS;OCCIDENTAL CONSOLIDATING ITS OIL AND GAS OPERATIONS
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it planned to consolidate its worldwide oil and gas operations into a single operating company, a move designed to save $100 million a year. Occidental could see 80 percent of the savings next year, with the full effect to be seen in 1997, according to the chief operating officer, Dale R. Laurance. Occidental, based in Los Angeles, plans to announce the full details of the move in January. The company said it would record a one-time expense against fourth-quarter earnings to reflect the changes, but Mr. Laurance declined to quantify the charge.

title: Telephone Records Lead to New Subpoenas in Whitewater Case
description: Asserting that newly available telephone records contradict testimony from two of Hillary Rodham Clinton's closest advisers, Republicans on the Senate Whitewater committee today began preparing broadly worded subpoenas for information from President and Mrs. Clinton and a number of other figures in the wide investigation.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Gas Stations Cheated on Taxes
description: Gurmit Singh, 61, and his son, Manbir Singh, 32, both of Holmdel, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court to defrauding the Government of $1.3 million by buying home heating oil without paying taxes and selling it at their five service stations and truck stops as diesel fuel, said Robert G. Stahl, an Assistant United States Attorney. Diesel fuel and one type of home heating oil are essentially the same, but there are no taxes on home heating oil.

title: Times's Durso To Be Honored
description: Joseph Durso, who covered major league baseball for 27 years for The New York Times, was named the 1995 winner of the J. G. Taylor Spink Award today at the World Series meeting of the Baseball Writers Association of America.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Tests for Bullets' Price
description: Washington Bullets guard MARK PRICE had his left foot examined yesterday and the team said results of the magnetic resonance imaging test will be available today.

title: The High Court's Fear of AIDS
description: About 40,000 people die annually of AIDS in the United States, but the Supreme Court doesn't seem to have noticed. Since 1989, the Court has been presented with six cases involving issues central to the AIDS epidemic, and it has refused to consider all six.

title: Reform Pledge Jump-Starts Mexican Talks
description: A pledge by the Institutional Revolutionary Party to eliminate the advantages that have helped it rule Mexico for more than 66 years -- the world's longest political winning streak -- leaves most Mexicans skeptical, but it was enough to bring opposition parties back to the negotiating table.

title: Currents;When the Tile Takes Center Stage
description: BEING upstaged by a floor treatment may not be every interior designer's dream. But Denis Colomb has taken it in stride. His part-Provencal, part-Turkish-bazaar Sun Room (above) on the fourth floor at the 1995 French Designer Showhouse (863 Lexington Avenue, at 65th Street), which continues through Nov. 12, is proving to be the perfect showcase for the intricate matte tiles made in France by Carocim.

title: No Headline
description: As your president, I will never forget that our movement grows by addition and multiplication, and not by division and subtraction." JOHN J. SWEENEY, the new president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. [A1:3.]

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;For Now, Qaddafi Halts Expulsion of Palestinians
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi said today that he intended to expel all Palestinians from Libya but that the expulsions would be temporarily halted.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;The Jets' Esiason Keeps Improving, but He Still Isn't 100 Percent
description: Trying to hasten his recovery from the concussion that has sidelined him for two games, Jets quarterback Boomer Esiason has been working with what doctors say is an innovative but unproved form of biofeedback therapy.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ONEX TO ACQUIRE VENCAP EQUITIES
description: The Onex Corporation of Toronto said yesterday that it planned to acquire Vencap Equities Alberta Inc. for $256 million (Canadian), or $187 million (United States), including the payment of $144 million (Canadian) in Vencap debt. Onex said it would buy all the shares of Vencap -- including the 30.5 percent stake in stock options the Alberta government holds -- for $8.50 (Canadian) a share. Onex, which owns interests in airline catering, food-distribution and delivery businesses, will also pay off Vencap's outstanding loan to the Alberta government. Vencap's stock reached a record high of $8.125 before closing at $7.875, up 37.5 cents, in trading on the Alberta Stock Exchange. Onex's stock was up 12.5 cents, to $14.125, in Toronto.

title: BALLET REVIEW;From St. Petersburg, 19th-Century Excerpts
description: The program that the St. Petersburg Ballet presented on Saturday night at the Queensborough Community College Theater was a display of sound classical schooling, which in itself was fine. Yet it was far from enough, for like any great art, ballet should mix creativity with technique.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;He Is Third, and Doesn't Mind
description: Cary Conklin had a dream to be a starting quarterback in the National Football League when he was drafted by Washington in 1990. But as the seasons passed and the missed opportunities became apparent, Conklin began to understand the importance of being a backup quarterback.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;A Nation of Readers, and That's Not Good
description: 48 Hours" reports tonight that some 50 million American women are reading books these days. Before you cheer this evidence of an intellectual explosion, however, note what they are reading. "Isn't It Romantic?" is a wry encounter with the people who consume, concoct and decorate the paperback romance novels that occupy so much bookstore shelf space and so much of their fans' time.

title: As Wells Fargo Tries to Buy First Interstate, Their Shares Fall
description: The stock prices of Wells Fargo & Company and the First Interstate Bancorp fell sharply yesterday, in part because a growing number of investors believe that First Interstate is likely to wage a long battle against Wells Fargo's $10 billion hostile takeover bid.

title: Scientists Oppose Approval Of Fat Substitute by F.D.A.
description: A fat substitute that could turn one of America's favorite foods, potato chips, into a seemingly guilt-free snack is in the final stages of being considered by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Schools Chief Seeks Increase In Attendance
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, outlining his goals for the next year and a half, said he wanted to raise student attendance to 95 percent, up from 85 percent, a target that would put about 100,000 more students in class every day.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Man Killed in Stolen-Jeep Crash
description: A Bloomfield police officer who followed a stolen Jeep Cherokee that was being driven erratically early yesterday pursued it into Newark, where the occupants of the car fired three shots at the officer before crashing into another Jeep and killing its driver, said Ray Weiss, a spokesman for the Essex County Prosecutor.

title: Rowland Tells Legislature Bridgeport Needs a Casino
description: Gov. John G. Rowland opened a special session of the legislature today with an impassioned plea to save Bridgeport, the state's largest city, by allowing the Mashantucket Pequot Indians to build an $875 million casino there.

title: Sports of The Times;Huskers Hardly Shun the Easy Way Out
description: IT was painful, to be sure, like making him sleep on a bed of nails, but Tom Osborne decided it was the right thing to do. Tom Osborne, the coach of the University of Nebraska football team, announced Tuesday that, after a lot of sweat and thought, he would reinstate his star running back, Lawrence Phillips, who had been suspended from the team for assaulting a former girlfriend and who just might lead the Huskers to the $8 million Fiesta Bowl.

title: The Return of the Traffic Officers;A New Division Chief Oversees Strategy in the Gridlock War
description: As Chief Michael Scagnelli prowled the city streets in a chauffeured car, he couldn't help but smile: on what could have been the worst day for traffic this year, cars were flowing smoothly through midtown Manhattan.

title: AMERICANS REJECT BIG MEDICARE CUTS, A NEW POLL FINDS
description: As Congress takes up the budget, the American public fears plans of the Republicans to curb Medicare spending, scoffs at their tax cut and flatly does not believe that the plan would produce a balanced budget by 2002, the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows.

title: Cuban Anachronisms
description: Fidel Castro moved through New York City this week like some vestigial presence from another era, meeting with businessmen, journalists, citizens and foreign diplomats but shunned by American political leaders from Bill Clinton to Rudolph Giuliani. He dropped by this newspaper yesterday, a startling cold-war apparition with a disarming sense of humor and an unbending allegiance to Cuban Socialism. It was a little like looking up from your desk and finding Mao Zedong or Nikita Khrushchev standing in the doorway.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DONALDSON, LUFKIN SHARES RISE ON FIRST DAY
description: The shares of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. rose yesterday on their first day of trading. The shares, which were priced at $27 each on Tuesday, opened at $31.50 on the New York Stock Exchange. They closed at $30, after more than 5.8 million shares were traded. The initial public offering consisted of 3.3 million shares offered by the company, a New York brokerage firm, and 5.9 million by its parent, the Equitable Companies of New York.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: LIMITS ON SEX BUSINESSES APPROVED The City Council overwhelmingly approved a package of restrictions on X-rated video stores, peep shows and topless bars in New York City. If they withstand the court challenge civil libertarians have promised, the new rules will sharply reduce the number and location of sex shops and theaters around the city. [Page A1.]

title: New York Already Keeps Watch for Nursing Home Abuses
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Testaverde Is Unhappy
description: VINNY TESTAVERDE said yesterday that the "the situation stinks" on the Cleveland Browns after the benching that makes him appear to be the scapegoat for the team's 3-4 record. Testaverde was named the American Football Conference player of the month for September as the Browns started 3-1, but consecutive losses to Buffalo, Detroit and Jacksonville led Coach BILL BELICHICK to decide on ERIC ZEIER as his quarterback for Sunday's road game against the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: ON KLICKITAT STREET WITH: Beverly Cleary;For 3 Generations, The Child's Choice
description: BEVERLY CLEARY'S children's books have sold 75 million copies in 20 countries in 14 languages, so she is an author accustomed to renown. Still, Mrs. Cleary was amused on the afternoon of Oct. 13, when 200 rapt librarians went on a bus tour of her old Portland neighborhood -- not coincidentally the setting for the small-time adventures of Henry Huggins and Ramona Quimby, Mrs. Cleary's most famous creations and two of the most comic and authentic characters in American children's books.

title: Latvia Election Gives No Cause for Alarm
description: To the Editor:

title: BOXING;Tape at King Fraud Trial Reveals Threat by Accuser
description: Don King's lawyer continued yesterday to question the credibility of a crucial Government witness in the promoter's Federal mail fraud trial.

title: Liberties;Talk Is Cheap
description: Emboldened by their success in getting Time Warner to dump gangsta rap, William Bennett and Senator Joseph Lieberman are going after America's true heart of darkness: daytime TV talk shows.

title: 5 Killed as Commuter Train Hits School Bus
description: The yellow bus was alive with the noise of teen-agers on their way to school today. It was 20 minutes late, and the driver, new to the route, had to ask some of the students for directions, but no one seemed to care as the bus stopped at a traffic light, its rear third extended over a set of railroad tracks in Fox River Grove, a small town about 40 miles northwest of here.

title: Pataki Order Halts Mailings for Group
description: Gov. George E. Pataki ordered two state agencies today to stop mailing membership forms for a consumer group that has been a thorn in the side of major utility companies.

title: Market Place
description: HISTORY never repeats itself. But that doesn't stop people from looking for historical patterns.

title: Political Memo;In Mayor's Arafat Snub, a Hint of Strategy
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani says he was motivated by principle and a long memory, rather than politics, in ejecting Yasir Arafat from a celebratory concert on Monday night, and his passion on the subject is clearly deeply held. But just as previous mayors have found, Mr. Giuliani's ventures into foreign policy dovetail quite nicely with his political needs in a city that is really a collection of ethnic principalities.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Portrait of the Artist as a Writer and a Crook
description: THE BLUE SUIT A Memoir of Crime By Richard Rayner 216 pages. Houghton Mifflin Company. $19.95.

title: Doner Acquires GGK of London
description: W. B. Doner & Company in Baltimore and Southfield, Mich., said yesterday that it had acquired GGK in London and merged it with Doner International in that city. The terms of the acquisition, which had been expected, were not disclosed.

title: Olivetti Considers Sale Of Its Computer Unit
description: The chairman of Olivetti S.p.A. said yesterday that he would sell the Italian computer maker's personal computer unit if it remains unprofitable at the end of next year. Olivetti's chairman and chief executive, Carlo De Benedetti, said he was committed to making the personal computer unit profitable. He said, though, that if the unit did not turn around by the end of 1996, he would consider getting out of it.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; 2 Plead Guilty in Carjacking
description: Two teen-agers from Montclair pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of attempted murder and carjacking in the shooting of Sheila Gillespie, 65, in the driveway of her home in West Caldwell last March. Mrs. Gillespie lost sight in one eye as a result of the attack, after which the assailants fled in her car. The teen-agers, Hassan Cousins, 18, and Earl Bethel, 19, could each receive prison terms of more than 30 years when they are sentenced Nov. 9, said the Essex County Prosecutor, Clifford J. Minor.

title: Bobby Riggs, Brash Impresario Of Tennis World, Is Dead at 77
description: The irrepressible chauvinist Bobby Riggs, a former Wimbledon champion who in 1973 reached a dual zenith of tennis fame and infamy as the 55-year-old braggart who was throttled by Billie Jean King in their landmark Battle of the Sexes match, died Wednesday night in Leucadia, Calif., a suburb of San Diego. He was 77.

title: Six People Away From a Ghost Town; Pahaquarry, New Jersey's Tiniest Municipality, Tries to Disappear
description: At this month's meeting of the township committee, Mayor Jean Zipser showed up and Committeeman Harold Van Campen did not. So the meeting was canceled; there was no quorum.

title: Yeltsin in Hospital After New Bout of Chest Pains
description: Within days of returning from the United States, President Boris N. Yeltsin was taken to the hospital today with his second painful episode of heart disease in the last three months.

title: Estee Lauder Forms Alliance
description: The Estee Lauder Companies, the prestige cosmetics maker that is preparing to sell shares to the public, said yesterday that it had established a strategic alliance with Bobbi Brown Professional Cosmetics Inc., a line of makeup-artist cosmetics.

title: Fearing G.I. Occupiers, Japan Urgesd Women Into Brothels
description: Governments have made plenty of outrageous requests of their citizens, but few are as remarkable as what the Japanese Government secretly requested of tens of thousands of Japanese women 50 years ago.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Borden Meadowgold Dairy, Ogden, Utah, to Tracy-Locke, a DDB Needham Agency, owned by the Omnicom Group, to handle the account of the new independent business unit of Borden Inc. The billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Oct. 18 headlined "The Bronx in Bloom" mistakenly referred to the Wildlife Conservation Society as the Wildlife Preservation Society. An editorial on Oct. 22 headlined "Fantasy at a Petting Zoo" stated that the society's proposal for a new Children's Zoo had been opposed by the Landmarks Committee of Community Board 8 and by some members of the Municipal Art Society. Neither the committee nor the Art Society has yet taken a formal position on the new zoo; they have only called for full public discussion.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about William D. Campbell, a New York philanthropist and elder statesman of the Scouting movement, misspelled his daughter's surname. She is Margot Bogert, not Borgert.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about negotiations on an international peacekeeping force for Bosnia misstated the proposed level of Russian participation. The proposal is for at least 2,000 Russian troops, not up to 2,000 Russians.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC. (AIG,N)
description: American International Group Inc. said yesterday that earnings rose 16.2 percent in the third quarter as the insurer collected more premiums and pared expenses.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COLE-TAYLOR FINANCIAL GROUP, Wheeling, Ill., has hired two investment banks to explore a possible merger or sale of the company.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League CLEVELAND INDIANS -- Extended the player development contract with the Buffalo Bisons through the 1998 season. YANKEES -- Buck Showalter, manager, resigned.

title: Medicare Shouldn't Pay to Train Doctors; Nursing Home 'Zoos'
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTHWEST AIRLINES RESTRUCTURES A $731 MILLION LOAN
description: The Northwest Airlines Corporation has restructured a $731.4 million loan against property it owns in downtown Tokyo, reducing its long-term debt. Northwest said yesterday that the interest rate on the 10-year financing agreement, denominated in Japanese yen, had been reduced to 3 percent from 4 percent and that the maturity had been extended from a single balloon payment due in February 2000 to three equal annual payments due in 2005, 2006 and 2007. The company also has an option to defer semiannual cash payments for up to three years.

title: WORLD SERIES 95;Thome and the Indians Showing Some Emotion
description: Perhaps it was the Greg Maddux pitch that the Cleveland Indians perceived to be thrown intentionally at Eddie Murray's chin. Perhaps it was the sheer audacity on the part of the Atlanta Braves, feeling they could come to Cleveland, win two games and take the World Series from the championship-starved Indians on the shores of Lake Erie.

title: No Headline
description: You would be hard pressed to find many people in the House, on both sides of the aisle, who have not in the last week or ten days met with the Speaker. Speaker Gingrich has more balls in the air than the Braves and the Indians." -- REP. SHERWOOD L. BOEHLERT, Republican of New York. [A1:5.]

title: INSIDE
description: Campaign Advice for Powell

title: Bosnian Serbs Agree to Let In Relief Groups
description: In the first direct talks between American and Bosnian Serb officials about human rights issues, the Serbs have agreed to allow international relief organizations access to areas where the Serbs are believed to have detained hundreds of Muslim men, a senior American official said today.

title: Jack Rose, 87, Comedy Writer And Producer of Movie Hits
description: Jack Rose, who parlayed a job writing radio jokes for Bob Hope into an acclaimed career as a comedy screenwriter and producer, died on Oct. 20 at Cedars-Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 87.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET;Excerpts From Debates in House and Senate on Budget Bills
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by lawmakers today during the House and Senate budget debates, as recorded and transcribed by The New York Times. IN THE HOUSE

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE STRATEGY;Of Touching Third Rails And Tackling Medicare
description: If messing with Social Security is like touching the third rail of American politics, as Speaker Thomas J. O'Neill Jr. used to say, then tinkering with Medicare is like throwing yourself in front of the train.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday about the 90th anniversary of the Staten Island Ferry misidentified two riders. They were not Joan Million and Louise Reverby; their identities were unknown.

title: Drought Easing Somewhat
description: New Jersey has lifted water-use restrictions, but in New York officials warned that reservoirs were still down 15 percent. Page B1.

title: BASEBALL;No Yankee Jacket Required: Is Showalter In or Out?
description: Buck Showalter ended the longest continuous run as Yankees manager under George Steinbrenner today. Or did he?

title: Youthful Dreams, in Harlem
description: Jermaine Ashwood has plans to be an architect. Nikki Matos hopes to make movies. Rasheem Swindell is training to be a boxer. Akida Bailey has had a taste of Wall Street. They are four of the nine youths, ages 12 to 26, who contribute to "Harlem Diary," an ambiguously inspiring movie about determination and dreams growing from the hard inner-city streets.

title: Gay Rights Don't Equal Civil Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: SARA LEE TO BUY BACK SHARES AND INCREASE ITS DIVIDEND
description: The Sara Lee Corporation said yesterday that it would buy back as many as 15 million shares, and it raised its quarterly dividend by 11 percent. Sara Lee, the maker of consumer products like Hanes stockings and Ball Park frankfurters, increased its quarterly dividend to 19 cents a share from 17 cents. The increased dividend is payable on Jan. 1 to shareholders of record on Dec. 1. The company, based in Chicago, said that it planned to buy back the shares on the open market and that it still had 2 million additional shares it could repurchase from an earlier authorization. Sara Lee shares slipped 37.5 cents, to $29.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Long Bond Tumbles After Report
description: Prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply yesterday, on a stronger-than-expected Government report of durable goods orders in September, and continuing concern about the effects of drawn-out budget negotiations.

title: 4 New Jersey Republicans Defy Party Leaders on Vote
description: Four New Jersey Republicans -- the same four who defied their party on the Medicare vote last week -- were among the 10 Republicans who voted against the House leadership today on the budget bill.

title: BREEDERS' CUP '95;Trainers Trade Jabs About Best Juvenile
description: Will the colt who wins the Breeders' Cup Juvenile tomorrow also win the Kentucky Derby next May?

title: 3 Surrender on Bribery Charges Tied to Theft of School Supplies
description: Three former Board of Education warehousemen surrendered to Queens prosecutors yesterday to face charges that they took bribes and stole more than $15,000 worth of school supplies.

title: Transit Fare Increase Affects Bicyclists Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Pacific Islanders Swindled of Unlikely Riches
description: This is about the people on a tiny Pacific island who make more money than they know what to do with from a source hardly anyone would think of. It is also about some outsiders who, the authorities say, tried to swindle the islanders of $28 million.

title: XEROX CORP. (XRX,N)
description: The Xerox Corporation reported a 27 percent rise in third-quarter earnings, but Wall Street was still unhappy with the results and shares of the company fell.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When MICHAEL BERMAN, a founder and the executive publisher of George magazine, rose to speak at a breakfast of the New York Leadership Conference yesterday, JEFFREY SACHS, a co-chairman of the organization, introduced him as a former member of the Bush Administration.

title: Special Ed Students Need a Class of Their Own
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman Who Murdered Singer Gets a Sentence of Life in Prison
description: Yolanda Saldivar, who was convicted on Monday of murdering the Tejano music singer Selena, was sentenced today to the maximum of life in prison with no possibility of parole for 30 years.

title: Awards Cite Government Innovations
description: In Maine, officials at the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration are inviting employers to identify health and safety problems and then to work with the agency to correct them, rather than having Government inspectors sweep through their businesses, finding violations and imposing fines.

title: Pension Pirates
description: Congress is playing politics with pensions and ignoring the financial risks to workers and taxpayers. A proposal in the House budget reconciliation bill, passed yesterday, would let any company with a strong pension fund take money out of it for any reason as long as the plan maintained a cushion of 25 percent more than the cost of paying current benefits. The Senate is debating a similar proposal.

title: Reeling, American General Purchases Some of Its Shares
description: The American General Corporation, rattled by a nearly 19 percent decline in its stock price since Monday, tried to calm the market yesterday by buying an undisclosed amount of its own shares and announcing a successor to its chief executive.

title: WORLD SERIES 95;Indians Solve Maddux and Come Back From the Brink
description: Mired in adversity for the first time in their wondrous season, the Cleveland Indians tonight played their last game at Jacobs Field this year, but they extended their year by at least one game.

title: U.S.C.'s Ifeanyi Drops Legal Action
description: Southern California defensive end ISRAEL IFEANYI has withdrawn his legal action against the university and the National Collegiate Athletic Association and will not play tomorrow when the 13th-ranked Trojans face No. 17 Washington in Seattle. That move followed the announcement by the N.C.A.A. that it was sticking by its ruling that Ifeanyi must sit out four games because he violated rules by accepting money from his Nigerian countrymen. (AP)

title: Kmart Official Leaves, Raising New Concerns
description: The abrupt departure of a senior executive at the Kmart Corporation, the second such exit in two months, has left many investors worried that the financially troubled discount retailer is in disarray in its executive suites just as it is entering the critical Christmas season.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Drifter, a Dog and Nonconformity in the 50's
description: Most life- and love-affirming family films are sugary enough to make your teeth rot and unbelievable enough to seem like messages from outer space. "Three Wishes" works magic in a more delicate and satisfying way. Set in 1955, it is a warm and sweet tale of a single mother and her two sons who are visited by a stranger. And though the story includes a dog who may be a genie, three magical wishes and a boy who can fly, the film is rooted in ordinary life, with all its family problems. In fact, there is nothing in Martha Coolidge's beautifully made movie that can't be explained by chance or flights of imagination.

title: MAXTOR SAYS IT RECEIVED BUYOUT OFFER
description: The Maxtor Corporation said yesterday that it had received a buyout offer from the Hyundai Electronics Industry Company, an affiliate of the Hyundai Corporation of South Korea, but that a committee of Maxtor directors had recommended rejecting it. The offer of $5.15 a share values all of Maxtor at $272.3 million, based on the 52.9 million shares Maxtor had outstanding as of Sept. 30. Hyundai Electronics and its affiliated companies already own 37 percent of Maxtor's common shares. Maxtor, a troubled maker of computer disk drives based in San Jose, Calif., that has about 7,700 employees, said it was considering further talks with Hyundai.

title: E.M.S. Merger Plan Wins an Approval
description: The board of directors of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which runs the city's ambulances, yesterday approved the Giuliani administration's plan to merge the Emergency Medical Service with the Fire Department.

title: About Real Estate;Condominium Tower, With Big Spaces, Is Planned for the Upper East Side
description: The partnership of Aby Rosen, Michael Fuchs and Trevor Davis, now building a rental tower at 64th Street and Second Avenue, is preparing to build a second residential tower, a 20-story condominium on 79th Street between York and First Avenues.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
