description: House Passes Budget Bill To Balance the Budget The House approved the foundation of the Republican revolution: a broad-ranging bill that would balance the budget in seven years, cut some taxes and diminish the Federal Government's role.

title: Critic's Choice;Adventures Of Arthur As a Youth
description: Where do all those skilled British actors come from? From institutions like the National Youth Music Theater of Great Britain, which is closing out a brief run at the City Center this weekend with performances of its epic "Pendragon" today at 2 P.M. and tomorrow at 8 P.M. (After putting on its repertory companion, "Threepenny Opera," tonight at 8 and tomorrow at 2 P.M.)

title: Russian Club Suspended Over Yashin
description: Russia's Central Army club was suspended from international competition by the International Ice Hockey Federation yesterday for playing the holdout National Hockey League star ALEKSEI YASHIN. The federation also banned Yashin from playing any more games for the Russian team during his contract dispute with the Ottawa Senators. (AP)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Williams's 'Streetcar,' Not Kazan's
description: Kept in the vaults for a while, a made-for-television film version of the 1992 Broadway production of Tennessee Williams's "Streetcar Named Desire" finally makes it to network television on Sunday, running on CBS from 8 to 11 P.M. Starring Jessica Lange as Blanche DuBois and Alec Baldwin as Stanley Kowalski, this version of the American classic, far more faithful to the original play than the 1951 Elia Kazan film starring Vivien Leigh and Marlon Brando, was produced and directed by Glenn Jordan.

title: Gems in a Recital Times 2
description: The duo-recital by the British soprano Felicity Lott and the Irish-born mezzo-soprano Ann Murray on Monday night at Alice Tully Hall was more than an exquisite demonstration of vocal artistry. It was also a good show, which explains why Ms. Lott and Ms. Murray, who clearly enjoy performing together, have successfully taken this program on the road.

title: Special Ed Students Need a Class of Their Own
description: To the Editor:

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE POLLS;Gingrich Attacks Times-CBS Poll, Claiming Bias Against G.O.P.
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich and other Republican leaders attacked a New York Times/CBS News Poll today, contending that it asked questions calculated to prompt unfavorable public reaction to Republican legislative proposals.

title: Art in Review
description: Faith Ringgold '40 Years of Selected Works' ACA Galleries 41 East 57th Street Manhattan Through Nov. 11

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: U.S. Inquiry Begins on Price For Newsprint
description: The Justice Department said today that it had begun a significant investigation into possible anticompetitive pricing practices in the newsprint industry.

title: Three Queens Men Charged in Kidnapping Plot
description: Three Queens men were arrested on kidnapping charges yesterday after abducting a factory worker and demanding that he pay $18,000 ransom, the police said.

title: Executive Changes
description: McCORMICK & CO. INC., Sparks, Md., which makes spices, extracts and convenience foods, said H. Eugene Blattman, its president and chief executive, would retire on Jan. 1 for health reasons. Charles P. McCormick Jr., its chairman, will add the title of chief executive, while Robert Lawless, executive vice president and chief operating officer, will become president and chief operating officer.

title: Senate Whitewater Panel Seeks More Documents From Clintons
description: The Senate Whitewater committee voted today to issue 49 subpoenas for records from President Clinton, Hillary Rodham Clinton and a variety of other Washington and Arkansas figures involved in the investigation.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Reshaping Hong Kong's Face
description: The Kwoks had just sat down to a meal of steamed fish and stir-fried pork. With a roar, the floor shuddered and the chopsticks in Kwok Tai-ming's hands clattered against his rice bowl. Overhead, seemingly skimming the roof of the tiny seventh-floor apartment, a Cathay Pacific 747 screamed past, banking amid apartment blocks toward Hong Kong's airport at Kai Tak. And then another, and another, every two or three minutes.

title: RESEVOIR TOWNS AND NEW YORK CITY REACH AGREEMENT
description: After decades of conflict between New York City and the upstate communities that supply its water, the city has agreed to spend $1 billion during the next five years to preserve the quality of its water while spurring economic growth in the towns and villages around its 19 reservoirs.

title: Foster Returns Bonus and Leaves Bengals
description: Two days after signing a $1 million contract, BARRY FOSTER changed his mind yesterday and left the Cincinnati Bengals. Foster, 26, out of football since the Carolina Panthers released him before the season began, complained that he felt like "a 60-year-old running back" after his first workout in pads with the Bengals on Wednesday. He returned his reported $300,000 signing bonus to the Bengals and left town. (AP)

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE SENATE;Pressured by Moderates, G.O.P. Leaders Agree to Keep Strict Rules on Nursing Homes
description: Bowing to intense political pressure from members of both parties, Senate Republican leaders said today that they had agreed to preserve tough Federal standards for nursing home care.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Why Australia's Directors Fit In So Well Here
description: YEARS before he went Hollywood, directing Harrison Ford as the ultimate C.I.A. agent in "Patriot Games," Phillip Noyce made one of the smartest and most Australian movies of the past few decades. "Newsfront" (1978) begins with documentary film of Chico Marx, in Sydney in 1948, leading a makeshift chorus of Australian military men. "How about a little song?" Chico asks. "It's something about a bum walking along the road and he meets some dame named Matilda." The soldiers laugh before they launch into "Waltzing Matilda," a decidedly unromantic song about a hobo who kills himself rather than go to jail as a sheep thief. Australians know Matilda is not a woman; it's a knapsack.

title: Mayor Offers 3 Hospitals For Lease
description: The Giuliani administration formally offered yesterday to turn over three public hospitals to private health care organizations. It also strongly suggested that the city would try to release the new operators from the terms of current labor contracts.

title: BASEBALL;Astros to Virginia? It's All in a Whirl
description: The Texas Rangers aren't the lone team in the Lone Star State. Not yet.

title: Some Sex Shops Vow to Fight City's New Rules
description: Standing between aisles of videotapes with unprintable titles and stacks of toys in unmentionable shapes, Shawn Goonetilleke surveyed his tiny empire of erotica on Eighth Avenue near West 47th Street and sighed.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;Found Photographs and Chance: Serendipity
description: Found photographs and chance play central roles in "New Photography II," the latest edition of the Museum of Modern Art's annual sampling of the medium. Three of the four photographers represented in this year's show incorporate these elements into their works in one form or another, while the fourth looks to older traditions of landscape and documentary photography.

title: At Home Abroad;Rumblings of Change
description: On the surface, British politics looks unchanged: a weary Conservative Government trying to distract the public from decline. But underneath, there are tremors that could signal an approaching earthquake.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers Muster a Rally But Can't Manage Escape
description: Coach Colin Campbell saw a trap coming tonight against the Tampa Bay Lightning and animatedly warned his Rangers team about it before the game.

title: Jazz Age Exuberance in a Single Ring
description: The trapeze isn't the only thing swinging at the colorful new edition of the Big Apple Circus that -- welcome back! -- has pitched its tent in Damrosch Park for a run through Jan. 7.

title: Signal Is Faulted in Bus Crash; Toll Rises to 7
description: The driver of the school bus crushed by a commuter train on Wednesday said that she had not heard or seen the train until it tore the bus off its chassis, the National Transportation and Safety Board said late today.

title: GOLF;Where Rich Get Richer and Par Is Rare
description: The $3 million Tour Championship is, when you get right down to it, sort of a year-end picnic for the top 30 players on the money list, a chance for the rich to get richer without breaking much of a sweat as they cruise around one of America's great golf courses in shirtsleeves.

title: INTERMET REJECTS BID BY GROUP INCLUDING FOUNDER
description: The Intermet Corporation said yesterday that its board had rejected a $337.5 million takeover bid by a group that includes the company's founder. Intermet, based in Troy, Mich., makes precision iron parts for the auto industry. The company's founder, George W. Matthews, and the New York investment bankers Kelso & Company made a bid of $13.50 a share on Oct. 1. Mr. Matthews, who retired in 1994, and a group of investors controlling 23.6 percent of the company's stock outstanding wanted to take the company private. John Doddridge, the chairman of Intermet, said the directors had voted unanimously on Wednesday night to reject the proposal. The company's stock fell $1.125, to $12.50, in Nasdaq trading.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COLE-TAYLOR FINANCIAL GROUP, Wheeling, Ill., has hired two investment banks to explore a possible merger or sale of the company. OWOSSO CORP., West Conshohocken, Pa., a maker of engineering and agricultural maintenance equipment, agreed to buy Stature Electric Inc., Watertown, N.Y., a closely held maker of electric gear motors, for $27.5 million in cash and securities.

title: Accounts
description: Borden Meadowgold Dairy, Ogden, Utah, to Tracy-Locke, a DDB Needham Agency, owned by the Omnicom Group, to handle the account of the new independent business unit of Borden Inc. The billings were estimated at $5 million. Chillingworth/Radding Inc., New York, was awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at $1 million: Ghurka, New York, to handle the creative and media portions of the account of the marketer of handbags, luggage and leather accessories, previously handled in-house, and B. H. Smith, New York, to introduce a print campaign for Smith's Samsonite handbags.

title: Herve Filion Among 3 Drivers Indicted
description: HERVE FILION and two other harness racing drivers who raced regularly at Yonkers Raceway were indicted yesterday by a Westchester County grand jury on charges involving a scheme to fix races, the district attorney's office announced.

title: S.&P. Lifts Rating Of Some G.M. Debt
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation increased its rating on the General Motors Corporation's senior debt yesterday, citing the auto maker's higher profits, as well as G.M.'s efforts to improve its product line, cut costs and reduce its unfinanced pension liabilities.

title: 7 Companies Seek to Offer Phone Service
description: Connecticut could become a battleground over local telephone service, with at least seven rivals drawing up plans to offer both residential and business service to compete with Southern New England Telephone.

description: A Name in Lights, Then Another

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about new restrictions on pornography businesses in New York City misstated the City Council vote total. The rules were approved 41 to 9, not 40 to 9.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;A poetic sneaker campaign features a stylish N.B.A. star turn.
description: FOR Fila USA, Grant Hill is alive with the sound of music -- and the sound of poetry -- in an ambitious effort to encourage the continued ringing of cash registers, otherwise known as the sound of money.

description: Michael Steiner Salander-O'Reilly Galleries 20 East 79th Street Manhattan Through tomorrow

title: Wild Child Goes Electric
description: When lightning strikes a pregnant woman, she dies but her child lives. The baby, the doctor says, has albinism, but that doesn't begin to explain the bizarre hero nicknamed Powder. Raised as a recluse, he is discovered as a teen-ager by the sheriff (Lance Henriksen) and a kindly teacher (Mary Steenburgen). Powder is hairless and mime white. He is also a genius who can recite "Moby-Dick" from memory. And his body is some kind of electrical force field. One look from Powder can make silverware fly.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Oct. 18 headlined "The Bronx in Bloom" mistakenly referred to the Wildlife Conservation Society as the Wildlife Preservation Society. An editorial on Oct. 22 headlined "Fantasy at a Petting Zoo" stated that the society's proposal for a new Children's Zoo had been opposed by the Landmarks Committee of Community Board 8 and by some members of the Municipal Art Society. Neither the committee nor the Art Society has yet taken a formal position on the new zoo; they have only called for full public discussion.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Environmental Rules Supported
description: New Jersey residents strongly oppose further relaxation of environmental standards, according to a poll released yesterday by the Center for Analysis for Public Issues, a Princeton research group. Neil Upmeyer, director of the center, said the poll showed only 47 percent approval of the environmental policies of Governor Whitman.

title: Restaurants
description: If restaurants were rated for niceness, Frontiere would get four stars. It is hard to imagine a cozier place than this brick-walled, open-fronted SoHo bistro, and it is constantly filled with regular clients.

title: The Sound Of New York: Ska. Ska? Yes, Ska.
description: THE hunt for thriving regional music scenes has become an important one in the record business. Music labels in New York regularly send talent scouts to places like San Diego and Louisville, Ky., to make deals with new cadres of bands hoping to replicate the success of the Seattle grunge scene that spawned Nirvana and Soundgarden and the Berkeley, Calif., punk scene that produced Green Day and Rancid. What most record companies do not consider, however, is that for a dozen years a scene has slowly been expanding right on their doorstep, and it is close to exploding. It is perhaps the only underground musical movement that New York can now call its own. T-shirts in record stores and cover artwork on compact disks proudly proclaim it in large letters: NYC SKA.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RENATA TEBALDI, the Italian diva, plans to return to the United States in December for the first time since 1976, when she gave a recital at Carnegie Hall.

title: Officer Sues His Superiors and Coleman
description: A police sergeant who arrested New Jersey Nets forward DERRICK COLEMAN in June is suing his superiors and Coleman, saying they slandered him. The officer, Sgt. JOHN PIETRZAK, a Detroit police officer for 23 years, contends in his lawsuit that Police Chief ISAIAH McKINNON and Executive Deputy Chief BENNY NAPOLEON ignored evidence and held a news conference with Coleman in an attempt to keep him from filing a lawsuit.

title: Warehouse Supervisor Guilty of Gun Theft
description: A jury in Federal court in Trenton convicted a United Parcel Service supervisor yesterday of stealing and selling 250 handguns from the company's warehouse in Parsippany, N.J.

title: Kohl Faces Criticism For Skipping U.N. Gala
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's absence from the United Nations 50th-anniversary observances this week has provoked some loud grumbling here, with several members of the German Parliament criticizing the Chancellor for choosing to stay home.

title: HOCKEY;Lemieux's 3 Goals Take Life Out of Isles
description: Finally showing some signs of life, the Islanders equaled their season high of four goals in a game with four in the second period alone tonight. And Wendel Clark responded to being benched Wednesday night with his first goal as an Islander.

title: Italian Premier Survives Confidence Vote With a Pledge to Quit
description: Prime Minister Lamberto Dini rescued his Government from near-certain defeat in a parliamentary no-confidence vote today with a last-minute promise to step down before Jan. 1, after the 1996 national budget is passed.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RENATA TEBALDI, the Italian diva, plans to return to the United States in December for the first time since 1976, when she gave a recital at Carnegie Hall.

title: Digital Seen Hiring I.B.M. Executive Behind the Thinkpad
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation has hired Bruce L. Claflin, a longtime I.B.M. executive who presided over the success of that company's Thinkpad line of notebook computers, to run its money-losing personal computer division, people familiar with Digital's plans said yesterday.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; No State Police in Camden
description: Despite a soaring homicide rate, Camden will not get state police patrols, state law enforcement officials said yesterday after a meeting with city officials. Instead, a state task force will analyze whether Camden's police are being used as effectively as possible, according to The Associated Press. On Wednesday, Mayor Arnold Webster said he wanted the state police to patrol Camden. The city of 87,000 recorded its 48th murder of the year last weekend; its record, 52 murders, was set in 1992.

title: Stocks Fall Amid Worries Over Earnings
description: The stock market tumbled again yesterday as traders and investors continued to find signs of consumer weakness in corporate earnings reports.

title: In America;The Republican Way
description: As Republicans in Congress continue to make great progress in their mission to dismantle the Medicare and Medicaid programs, keep in mind that this odious effort has nothing to do with any desire to reform the health-care system, or to improve the quality of services available to the poor, the elderly, the young or the disabled.

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan gallery shows: JANET FISH, Grace Borgenicht Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street (through tomorrow). The foregrounds of Janet Fish's still lifes are usually occupied by garish glassware and elaborate floral arrangements that dissolve into a whirlwind of brightly colored brush strokes; in her strongest paintings, these are set off against darker passages of smooth, sculptural modeling. This is the closing show for a distinguished gallery that has been carrying the banner for poetic realism since 1951 (Pepe Karmel).

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about negotiations on an international peacekeeping force for Bosnia misstated the proposed level of Russian participation. The proposal is for at least 2,000 Russian troops, not up to 2,000 Russians.

title: Russians Have Landed in Kansas! But They've Come to Make Peace
description: With a cold autumn sun flashing off their badges of double-headed eagles, a stern Russian color guard high-stepped today across the frigid Kansas steppes.

title: Article 791095 -- No Title
description: At one time, lacy curtains, dim lights, a wood floor and a pressed tin ceiling could win a following for an inexpensive French restaurant. But now, with stylish little French restaurants opening all over town -- from Casani's in the East Village to Country Cafe in SoHo to Le Zoo in the West Village to Metisse on the Upper West Side -- it's no longer good enough simply to decorate and then hang out a shingle saying bistro.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Bill Would License Counselors
description: Drug and alcohol treatment counselors would have to be licensed by a state board and meet education and competency requirements under a bill released yesterday by the Senate Commerce Committee after a hearing in Lakewood. The bill, which has already passed in the Assembly, makes exceptions for counselors affiliated with nonprofit groups like Alcoholics Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous, and for members of the clergy.

description: An obituary on Wednesday about William D. Campbell, a New York philanthropist and elder statesman of the Scouting movement, misspelled his daughter's surname. She is Margot Bogert, not Borgert.

title: Corrections

title: Reveal Computer Deal
description: Creative Technology Ltd. of Singapore said yesterday that it would acquire Reveal Computer Products Inc. for $65 million in stock and stock warrants. Reveal Computer is a privately held multimedia company in Woodland Hills, Calif. It is a major customer of Aztech Systems Ltd. of Singapore, a Creative Technology rival. Reveal was planning to order at least $250 million of merchandise from Aztech in the next two years. Creative Technology said it had "no obligation" to continue with such orders. (Dow Jones)

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Ban on Handgun Sales Is Urged
description: The sale of inexpensive handguns called Saturday night specials would be banned under recommendations made public yesterday by the legislative Law Enforcement Officers Study Commission, which was established this year to review ways to improve job safety for law enforcement officers. The commission, composed of five Republicans and two Democrats, also proposed a $5 surcharge on motor vehicles citations and criminal fines to purchase police cars and bulletproof vests.

title: Killing Wave Threatens Haitian Ties
description: The death of Brig. Gen. Henri Max Mayard came quickly, in a hail of bullets on a busy street here one early October afternoon. The political impact of his killing, by what the authorities are calling a professional hit team, threatens to linger and further sour relations between President Jean-Bertrand Aristide and his critics in Washington.

title:
BREEDERS' CUP '95;
Desert-Trained Halling Will Go After Cigar
description: In quest of riches made more alluring because of the moderate ability of this year's American-based grass runners, Europeans trainers have sent 17 horses here for the Breeders' Cup tomorrow at Belmont Park. A combined dozen European horses are entered in the $1 million Mile and the $2 million Turf, the two grass races on the seven-race Breeders' Cup program.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Water Restrictions Are Lifted
description: For the first time since summer's long dry spell drained them, the region's reservoirs are at nearly normal levels, prompting Gov. Christine Todd Whitman to lift the restrictions on outdoor uses of water that she imposed on three million northern New Jersey residents six weeks ago. [ Page A1. ]

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Saudis Sign $6 Billion Deal With Boeing and McDonnell
description: Putting some much-anticipated ink to paper, Saudi Arabia announced yesterday that it had signed contracts with the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to buy 61 passenger jets for about $6 billion.

title: ON BASEBALL;Hershiser Rebounds With an Epic
description: Orel Hershiser came to Cleveland at age 36 and built on his legend as winner of big games all season, vying nicely almost every outing with the notion that he must approach perfection, especially on the World Series stage he had all but made his own in 1988.

title: L'Oreal Earnings Rise
description: L'Oreal, the world's largest cosmetics company, reported yesterday that its first-half profit rose 5.5 percent, which was at the bottom end of expectations. The company, which makes of Lancome and Helena Rubinstein cosmetics, Cacharel perfumes and Vichy skin creams, reported a profit of 2.75 billion French francs, or $551 million, compared with 2.61 billion francs a earlier. The company said sales for the first nine months rose 15.3 percent, to 39.7 billion francs, from the year-earlier period. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: A Feast of Animated Shorts
description: Don't be surprised when "Nosehair" is mentioned at next year's Oscar show. Anyone who bets on the Academy Awards' animated nominees knows better than to laugh at a title like that. "Nosehair" happens to be a witty, imaginative short by Bill Plympton that takes a single black line -- the hair of the title -- and coaxes a wave, a clothesline, a microphone cord and a wild array of other images out of this one mutable source. And if the point of origin is actually a man's nose, well, animation does open up wide new realms of the bizarre.

title: New York City Is to Lose Jobs in Pataki Transfer
description: The Pataki administration is preparing to transfer several hundred state workers from New York City to the Binghamton area, state officials said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When MICHAEL BERMAN, a founder and the executive publisher of George magazine, rose to speak at a breakfast of the New York Leadership Conference yesterday, JEFFREY SACHS, a co-chairman of the organization, introduced him as a former member of the Bush Administration.

description: Robert Smithson 'Early Works' Lawrence Markey 55 Vandam Street South Village Through Nov. 4

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Tandem Posts Drop of 72% In Net Income
description: Tandem Computers Inc. reported a 72.1 percent plunge in quarterly net income yesterday and announced a reshuffling of its management team in an attempt to revitalize its day-to-day operations.

title: Car's Lack of Safety Devices Faulted in Subway Mishap
description: A subway car that dragged a 2-year-old child in his stroller into the tunnel and onto the tracks Wednesday evening was not equipped with door sensors or closed-circuit monitors, safety features that were recommended seven years ago by the Transit Authority's own task force.

title: A New Chief Named at Olin
description: The board of the Olin Corporation said today that it had named Donald W. Griffin as president and chief executive, effective on Jan. 1.

title: Mexico and U.S. to Patrol Border Trouble Spots
description: After a month of rising vigilantism along the border in Southern California, during which one illegal immigrant was shot and six others held captive by local ranchers, American and Mexican officials are creating a joint law-enforcement operation to protect Mexican aliens and patrol the area.

title: Philips Profits Up 50% But Below Expectations
description: Philips Electronics N.V. said yesterday that its nine-month profits had soared nearly 50 percent, but the gain did not meet expectations.

title: A Big Job For Labor
description: With words of militancy, the new president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is promising the third big surge of labor organizing in the nation's history, hoping to add millions of workers to union rolls just as the movement did during the Depression and after World War II.

title: Salvador Helps Refugees Filing for Asylum in U.S.
description: Three years after its civil war ended, the Republic of El Salvador has begun offering a highly unusual service to its refugees here: free help in filing claims for political asylum based on El Salvador's own history of persecution.

title: WORLD SERIES 95
description: One Defeat from elimination, Cleveland solved Greg Maddux and forces a sixth game in Atlanta tomorrow. Braves . . . 4 Indians. . . 5 Atlanta leads series, 3-2

title: FILM REVIEW;Lurching Through a Life Of Alcoholic Abandon
description: Ben Sanderson, played devastatingly by Nicolas Cage in "Leaving Las Vegas," is something other than the usual movie drunk. Nothing about him offers golden opportunities to the good Samaritan. Already in the terminal stages of alcoholism as the film begins, Ben seems to sense his fate and want to face it in his own way, with crazy bravado and a whiff of desperate romance. This small, searing film watches transfixingly as Ben plays out his final hand.

Powell, who has kept a sprawling field of Presidential candidates wondering whether he plans to run, has in the last few days sounded out several well-known Republicans about his prospects, the finer points of raising money and the personal toll a campaign could take.

title: FIGURE SKATING;Kwan, in a Rush to Adulthood, Is Given a Makeover at Age 15
description: In the same arena where Nancy Kerrigan was attacked two years ago by associates of Tonya Harding, another calculated attempt is being made by a figure skater to get ahead.

title: Single Black Vampire, New in Town
description: In a long black coat and flowing hair, Eddie Murphy looks as dapper and alluring as any vampire to glide across the screen lately. The last of a breed of smarter vampires who immigrated to Africa instead of Carpathia, his Maximillian has a seductive appeal, even when he grows fangs and his eyes turn golden. But like so many Eddie Murphy misfires, "Vampire in Brooklyn" has no idea how to capitalize on the actor's immense appeal. The film was directed by the horror master Wes Craven ("Nightmare on Elm Street"), and it turns out to be an Eddie Murphy-Wes Craven movie that is not funny or scary. Now that's a nightmare.

title: Stage Union in Tentative Agreement
description: Easing fears of a strike that would shut down the Broadway season, negotiators for theater owners and a union representing stagehands announced yesterday that they had reached a tentative agreement on a new four-year contract.

title: Lotus Loses More Executives Following Chief's Resignation
description: The fallout at I.B.M.'s Lotus Development software unit continues in the wake of the recent resignation by Lotus's chief executive, Jim P. Manzi.

title: Diner's Journal
description: If you called directory assistance in Orienta's first week in business, you were told it wasn't listed. But that didn't keep the small, chic restaurant from being so full that well-dressed people spilled out the door onto the sidewalk as they waited for tables. Inside, the tables are close together and the sound reverberates off the walls, so you had to lean into the middle of the table to hear what your companions were saying.

title: For Children
description: Some parents may be relieved to discover that Power Rangers costumes are slipping as Halloween favorites this year. Costume-rental stores report that other superheroes, from Batman to Spiderman, are now as hot as the Rangers. Here are some Halloween events in New York City , where cowgirls, ghosts, devils and all the rest are welcome.

title: Many Bids for 2 Stations
description: Park Communications Inc. said today that it had gotten more than 18 offers to acquire WPAT-AM and WPAT-FM, its radio stations in the New York City market. Park, based here, said it expected to negotiate a final deal within a few days.

title: State Court Forbids A Presidential Poll On Newark's Ballot
description: A state appeals court decided today that Newark could not include a presidential straw poll on its November election ballot, ruling that it would violate New Jersey law.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Jets Are Making Changes To Improve Running Game
description: The Jets have not been this bad in running the ball since 1963. And if they are to have the slightest hope of salvaging the season, they will have to begin churning out ground yardage on Sunday at Indianapolis.

title: Mishap Stirs Concern About Subway Doors
description: The subway car that dragged a child in his stroller onto the tracks on Wednesday night was not equipped with door sensors or closed circuit monitors, even though these features were recommended seven years ago by the Transit Authority's own task force. Critics say the authority has been too slow in installing the technology that would prevent such accidents.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; School Experiment Opposed
description: So-called charter schools lack accountability and foster elitism, public schools officials maintained yesterday in a meeting with sponsors of state legislation that would allow New Jersey districts to set up such schools. Often bypassing local school districts, they operate under state contracts that set forth specific performance goals.

title: Executive Changes
description: McCORMICK & CO. INC., Sparks, Md., which makes spices, extracts and convenience foods, said H. Eugene Blattman, its president and chief executive, would retire on Jan. 1 for health reasons. Charles P. McCormick Jr., its chairman, will add the title of chief executive, while Robert Lawless, executive vice president and chief operating officer, will become president and chief operating officer.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks' Victory Halts The Sniping, for Now
description: If it was not Patrick Ewing pointing out Anthony Mason's lack of a perimeter game on Wednesday, it was Mason sniping back today. If Derek Harper needed a contract extension, Don Nelson absolutely needed a victory.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Greek Chorus Warns, but Does Woody Allen Take Heed?
description: PLANETS spin, leaves fall, swallows return to Capistrano and Woody Allen sustains his amazing pace. The film industry offers no surer thing these days than the annual Allen comedy, dependably well made and not quite like any Allen film that came before. Nimble film making like this isn't necessarily geared to the magnum opus, but Mr. Allen can achieve fine, amusing results even while thinking small. He's a one-man testament to the idea that the artist, like the shark or the love affair, had better keep moving to stay alive.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;When Maddox Strolls Around the Lockers, He Catches a Chill
description: Since he came to New York, backup quarterback Tommy Maddox has had a difficult time making friends on the Giants. It is not because of his personality; he is an extremely nice and funny person. It is because he has been given a chilly reception by some of his teammates on the offense.

description: Germany's largest commercial bank, Deutsche Bank A.G., reported moderate growth yesterday in profit in the first nine months of 1995, while Commerzbank A.G. said its profits more than doubled.

description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Congressman B. F. Sisk, 84; Champion of California Farms
description: Former United States Representative B. F. Sisk of California, a prominent member of the House Rules Committee and a leading benefactor of the water supply of his state's Central Valley farmlands, died on Wednesday in San Joaquin Garden Hospital in Fresno, his hometown since 1937. He was 84.

title: 3 Agencies Win Top Health Care Awards
description: Three agencies have taken top honors, winning Grand Global Awards, at the second annual Global Awards competition for the best in health care communications sponsored by the New York Festivals in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: An Exhibit Comparing Norwegians
description: The distance between a good artist and a great one is repeatedly measured in "Edvard Munch and Harald Sohlberg: Landscapes of the Mind," the exhibition at the National Academy of Design, which is the sleeper of the fall season. It may seem harsh to begin with such a competitive assertion. After all, the aim of this complex show is at least partly revisionist. It seems intended to upgrade the reputation of Sohlberg, a little-known turn-of-the-century painter, in the direction of that of Munch, his vaunted contemporary and fellow Norwegian, and at the same time to emphasize the local roots of Munch's Symbolism.

title: The G.O.P.'s Wild Card Over at the White House
description: Once President Clinton had explicitly vowed to veto the Republicans' ambitious seven-year budget bill, the grand two-house debate today over the measure began to take on the air of another day at the office. Lawmakers grappled across the debating mat, but looked beyond passage toward some future, more melodramatic showdown focused on the constancy of the President and his promises.

title: A Role for Russia In Bosnia Peacekeeping
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Lifts Drought Controls, but New York Stays Wary
description: For the first time since summer's long dry spell drained them, the reservoirs in the New York region are being replenished, prompting Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey to lift the restrictions on outdoor uses of water that she imposed on northern New Jersey residents six weeks ago.

title: Some Progress Is Seen on Federal Initiative for Gun-Free Schools
description: A year after President Clinton called for zero tolerance of guns in the schools, 47 states and the District of Columbia have enacted laws or policies complying with the United States Education Department's mandatory suspension of gun-carrying students. And although the policies are helping to reduce violence in the schools, it remains a problem in parts of the country, Secretary of Education Richard W. Riley said yesterday.

title: Art in Review
description: Eugene Atget and Walker Evans Zabriskie Gallery 724 Fifth Avenue (near 56th Street) Through Nov. 25

title: Pension Pirates
description: Congress is playing politics with pensions and ignoring the financial risks to workers and taxpayers. A proposal in the House budget reconciliation bill, passed yesterday, would let any company with a strong pension fund take money out of it for any reason as long as the plan maintained a cushion of 25 percent more than the cost of paying current benefits. The Senate is debating a similar proposal.

title: Youthful Dreams, in Harlem
description: Jermaine Ashwood has plans to be an architect. Nikki Matos hopes to make movies. Rasheem Swindell is training to be a boxer. Akida Bailey has had a taste of Wall Street. They are four of the nine youths, ages 12 to 26, who contribute to "Harlem Diary," an ambiguously inspiring movie about determination and dreams growing from the hard inner-city streets.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Fiend as Deadly as He Is Derivative
description: Anyone who has helped make "Seven" the most popular film of recent weeks should be interested to know there is also a good serial-killer movie around. And a very good thriller it is, too. Tautly directed by Jon Amiel ("Sommersby," "The Singing Detective"), written and acted with unusual care, "Copycat" grippingly describes the hunt for a peculiarly modern monster, a murder groupie who has studied the techniques of past greats and replicates them to torment a star criminologist. Not only is he deadly, this fiend is also derivative, poisoned by the celebrity-worshiping mentality that's almost as sinister as the crimes themselves.

title: Massacre Survivor Begged for Her Life
description: Ana Figueroa desperately wanted to live, and yesterday she described how it was by the slimmest of odds that she survived.

title: INSIDE
description: Campaign Advice for Powell

title: Art in Review
description: Eugene Atget and Walker Evans Zabriskie Gallery 724 Fifth Avenue (near 56th Street) Through Nov. 25

title: ART REVIEW;Behind Folk Forms, Classical Modes
description: Alison Saar is a much better artist than her admirers think she is. They invariably place her in the context of folk art, stressing the impact of her childhood visits to the famous pilgrimage sites of Los Angeles funk: Simon Rodia's Watts Towers, encrusted with pottery, and Grandma Prisbrey's Bottle Village, constructed from bottles and cement.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about new restrictions on pornography businesses in New York City misstated the City Council vote total. The rules were approved 41 to 9, not 40 to 9.

title: DONALDSON, LUFKIN TO BUY A MAKER OF CHAIN SAWS
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc.'s merchant banking group said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the McCulloch Corporation, a maker of chain saws and lawn equipment, from the Shop Vac Corporation. The price was not disclosed. McCulloch, based in Tucson, Ariz., has annual revenue of more than $240 million. Donaldson, Lufkin said it expected the purchase to be completed in November.

title: Strong Profits Fail to Help Stock Market
description: American corporations are generally reporting better-than-expected profits for the third quarter, continuing a successful string that goes back two and a half years.

title: Bosnia Chief Sees No Hope For Pact if Karadzic Stays
description: The President of Bosnia and Herzegovina said yesterday that peace would never come to his country unless the current Bosnian Serb leaders, whom he called criminals, were removed.

title: No Rush to Deregulate Truck Safety
description: While Congress completes a bill to redesign the nation's 160,000-mile Interstate highway system, industry and consumer lobbyists are vying over provisions governing the safety of trucks that travel those roadways. Unless a Senate-House conference committee works carefully, midsized delivery trucks are in line for sweeping, overly broad exemptions from Federal safety regulation.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Bloomberg Business News in the Company News column on Wednesday about the prospective sale of the Smith Corona Corporation referred incorrectly to the rarity of typewriter manufacturers in the United States. Smith Corona is not the last; Lexmark International Inc. of Greenwich, Conn., also makes typewriters.

title: Former Partner at Lazard Is Indicted in Fraud Case
description: Mark S. Ferber, a former Lazard Freres & Company partner who was once one of the nation's most powerful municipal finance bankers, was indicted yesterday on 63 criminal counts -- including wire fraud, violation of bribery statutes and attempted extortion -- in connection with what the Government contends was a scheme to defraud clients of his firm.

title: Yeltsin Illness: Causes, Treatments, Puzzles
description: The "myocardial ischemia" that sent President Boris N. Yeltsin to the hospital yesterday for the second time in three months is a common, serious heart condition that affects millions of people around the world.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Princeton-Columbia

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Not-Guilty Plea in Heroin Case
description: A Paterson man and woman pleaded not guilty yesterday to drug charges. Samuel Brown, 38, and Madeline Muengion, 28, who the police said had 1,100 bags of heroin in their possession when they were arrested Wednesday, were released on bail. Passaic County officials said the arrests followed an eight-month undercover investigation. JOE SHARKEY

title: Restaurants
description: If restaurants were rated for niceness, Frontiere would get four stars. It is hard to imagine a cozier place than this brick-walled, open-fronted SoHo bistro, and it is constantly filled with regular clients.

title: ABC in Pact With Henson Productions
description: Hoping to grab more of an increasingly elusive product -- television programming that appeals to adults and children alike -- Capital Cities/ ABC Inc. yesterday announced a five-year agreement with Jim Henson Productions under which ABC will put up money, Henson will create programs and the companies will split the proceeds.

title: Philippine Leader Says He'll Leave in '98; Foes Have Doubts
description: When asked his plans after his term as President of the Philippines ends in 1998, Fidel V. Ramos tends to smile playfully and say something about spending the rest of his life on a golf course.

title: No Headline
description: "You would be hard pressed to find many people in the House, on both sides of the aisle, who have not in the last week or ten days met with the Speaker. Speaker Gingrich has more balls in the air than the Braves and the Indians." -- REP. SHERWOOD L. BOEHLERT, Republican of New York. [ A1:5. ]

description: House Passes Budget Bill To Balance the Budget The House approved the foundation of the Republican revolution: a broad-ranging bill that would balance the budget in seven years, cut some taxes and diminish the Federal Government's role.

title: Argentina's Enlightened Chief of Staff
description: Twenty years ago, the Argentine military personified state terror. In the "dirty war" that began in 1976, more than 10,000 Argentines vanished into the military's concentration camps, suffered unspeakable torture and were never seen again. Today the Argentine military is professional and respectful of human rights and civilian control. The largest challenge to Latin America's new democratic leaders is how to control their militaries; the Argentine transformation, led by Army Chief of Staff Martin Balza, deserves their attention.

description: Talks at Historical Society

title: Chancellor Battle Eroded Giuliani's Popularity, Poll Finds
description: A few weeks after the tumultuous selection of a new schools chancellor, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's approval rating has dropped, according to a poll released yesterday by Quinnipiac College.

title: Home Video
description: On Halloween, "Night Trap," a noted hobgoblin of the video-game realm, is to reappear as a CD-ROM for Windows. Two years ago, a violent scene in the game, and similar ones in other games like "Mortal Kombat," so disturbed several United States Senators that an alarmed game industry almost immediately devised a ratings system with designations like M (for mature, suitable for ages 17 and up) and A (suitable only for adults).

title: CHRONICLE
description: HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON has a secret and she won't tell anyone: the contents of a birthday card from her husband that made him blush.

title: On My Mind;How to Trade With Cuba
description: American businesses eager to do business with Cuba are pushing every pressure point they can to end the U.S. embargo, except the one that might work. They refuse to use their economic influence to pressure Fidel Castro to give Cubans political and human rights.

title: Nursing Home Rules
description: Republican leaders in the Senate agreed to retain tough standards for nursing home care, but the budget bill passed by the House eliminated most of them, leaving them to be sorted out later.

title: 25 and Under
description: At one time, lacy curtains, dim lights, a wood floor and a pressed tin ceiling could win a following for an inexpensive French restaurant. But now, with stylish little French restaurants opening all over town -- from Casani's in the East Village to Country Cafe in SoHo to Le Zoo in the West Village to Metisse on the Upper West Side -- it's no longer good enough simply to decorate and then hang out a shingle saying bistro.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE LEADER;Gingrich, Long Seen as a Purist, Shows His Worth as a Pragmatist
description: On a red-letter day of his Republican revolution, Speaker Newt Gingrich got up early, ate breakfast and then spent his time in the same way he had for much of the last week -- coddling and mollifying his troops to make sure that he would dine on Democrats for dinner.

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Stock prices were lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 389.49 points, or 2.20 percent, at 17,334.19. On Thursday, the Nikkei index fell 244.13 points.

title: Citing Violence, Abortion Clinics Sue Opponents Over Threats
description: Lawyers for several abortion clinics and doctors filed a class action lawsuit yesterday, asserting that the most extreme anti-abortion groups have violated Federal racketeering law and the Federal law that guarantees access to abortion clinics.

title: Tyson Says He Wants Low-Key Approach
description: MIKE TYSON, annoyed by the theatrics and what he described as the "glamour" of his first fight back last August after his prison term, has told the MGM Grand to tone down his meeting on Nov. 4 with BUSTER MATHIS Jr.

title: DILLON, READ INVESTMENT GROUP TO BUY UNIT OF FISONS
description: Saratoga Partners L.P. has agreed to buy J& W Scientific Inc., a maker of gas chromatography equipment, from Fisons P.L.C. for $35 million, Fisons said yesterday. Saratoga Partners is an arm of the investment bank Dillon, Read & Company, which is owned by Travelers Inc. Fisons, a British drug maker, was acquired this month by Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, a unit of Rhone-Poulenc S.A. of France. The J& W deal completes the disposal of the lab supplies division of Fisons as part of a move to sell noncore units. This month, Fisons completed the sale of Curtin Matheson Scientific International and Fisons Scientific Equipment to Fisher Scientific International for $310 million.

title: U.S. Is Said to Be Investigating Dan Dorfman on Insider Trading
description: Dan Dorfman, the market-moving financial journalist, and a New York stock promoter are under investigation by Federal prosecutors for "possible illegal insider trading" and other violations of securities laws, Business Week magazine is reporting in its latest issue.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET;How Representatives Voted on Plan to Balance Federal Budget in 7 Years
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 227 to 203 by which the House of Representatives today approved the Republican plan to balance the budget in seven years and cut taxes by $245 billion. A yes vote is a vote to approve the Republican budget. Voting yes were 4 Democrats and 223 Republicans. Voting no were 192 Democrats, 10 Republicans and 1 independent. X denotes those not voting. There are two vacancies in the 435-member House.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;DOW CHEMICAL CO. (DOW,N)
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that earnings nearly doubled in the third quarter, bolstered by higher prices for chemicals and plastics and lower costs.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;HOUSE PASSES BUDGET BILL, BEDROCK OF G.O.P. AGENDA; MUCH BARGAINING REMAINS
description: The House of Representatives today approved the foundation of the Republican revolution: a mammoth bill that would balance the Federal budget in seven years, cut the taxes of most families and significantly diminish the place of the Federal Government in the lives of Americans.

title: Sri Lanka Chief Sees Decisive Battle Soon
description: With the army of Sri Lanka inching toward the command center of separatist Tamil rebels in what could be the decisive battle of a 13-year civil war, the Sri Lankan President is calling on other nations to help cut supply lines to the rebels and force them to the negotiating table.

title: Limiting Sex Shops, Responsibly
description: New York City took a reasonable step to improve the quality of neighborhood life this week when the City Council approved strict new zoning regulations to limit the proliferation of sex-related businesses in the five boroughs.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Mexican Peso Dives, as Economy Treads Water
description: Although Mexico's major companies posted third-quarter earnings this week that were no worse, and in some cases noticeably better, than had been expected, a spasm of uncertainty sent the peso today into its deepest slide since March. It closed here at 7.2 pesos to the dollar.

description: The Amoco Corporation has promoted William G. Lowrie, head of exploration and production, to president.

title: Aim Higher, Forum Urges Talk Shows
description: In the hyperventilating world of daytime television talk shows, this topic just might have hooked a few producers: Cabinet secretaries who watch Sally Jessy Raphael.

title: Stiff Breezes in Tulsa Are No Bother to Bryant
description: When things get tough, when the winds start howling and the greens get as rough as his 5 o'clock shadow, Brad Bryant -- the golfer known as Dr. Dirt -- is at his best. And now, after two rounds of the $3 million Tour Championship at Southern Hills Country Club, his best is plenty good enough.

description: Attention, Coke and Pepsi: Arizona is stepping into your territory.

title: LASERVISION CENTERS IN PACT WITH SUMMIT TECHNOLOGY
description: Laservision Centers Inc., which operates laser systems for correcting nearsightedness, agreed yesterday to buy 15 Excimer laser systems from Summit Technology Inc. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Summit Technology received F.D.A. approval on Oct. 20 to market its Excimer laser for treating low to moderate myopia. Laservision's six United States centers will begin operating as soon as surgeon training and installation of upgraded software are completed, it said. The St. Louis-based company has said it plans to open up to 50 Excimer laser centers in the next 12 months.

title: Mr. Clinton Stands Up for Fairness
description: With his firm endorsement last week of legislation outlawing job discrimination against homosexuals, President Clinton made brave use of his Presidential pulpit to advance the nation's fight against bigotry. In 41 states it is now legal for a person to be dismissed from a job because of sexual orientation. The measure endorsed by Mr. Clinton, the Employment Non-Discrimination Act, would give homosexuals statutory protection against bias in hiring, promotion or dismissal, much as current Federal law bars discrimination on the basis of race, sex, religion, color or national origin.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the sentencing of a suspected serial killer, Reginald McFadden, for the murder of a Long Island woman, Margaret Kierer, misstated the site of the crime. Ms. Kierer was stabbed while walking home from the Long Island Rail Road Station in Floral Park, not at the station.

title: Murder Rate Fell 30% in First 9 Months of '95
description: New York City's murder rate dropped nearly 30 percent during the first nine months of 1995, according to preliminary Police Department statistics, as the overall crime rate continued its five-year decline.

title: Japanese Cite Merrill Lynch, and Some See Retaliation for Daiwa
description: Japanese securities regulators said today that Merrill Lynch Japan Inc. had violated a regulation to prevent brokerage firms from manipulating stocks during new-securities sales. They recommended that the Finance Ministry punish the brokerage house, a unit of the American firm.

title: Mexico Frees Jailed Leftist Tied to Rebels
description: The Government today freed a jailed leftist accused of being a guerrilla leader, shedding a political embarrassment that jeopardized peace talks with the rebels and destabilized Mexico's financial markets.

title: Corrections
description: A television review yesterday about "CBS Playhouse 90's A Streetcar Named Desire" referred incorrectly to the director, Glenn Jordan. He remains alive.

title: Economy Surged 4.2% in Quarter And Inflation Rate Slipped Again
description: Surpassing nearly all expectations, the economy rebounded vigorously over the summer to grow at a 4.2 percent pace while inflation, already low, subsided further, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Clinton Enters Battle Over Telecom Bill
description: President Clinton personally entered the battle over telecommunications today, attacking numerous features in the bill now pending before a House-Senate conference committee. At the same time, his top economic adviser emphasized the Administration's threat to veto the measure.

title:
What to Do With Governors Island?;
An Eco-Park
description: This month, the Coast Guard said it will close its base on Governors Island, in New York Harbor, off the southern tip of Manhattan, and the Federal Government has given New York City and the state the first option on buying the land. The 175-acre island, which the Manahatas Indians sold to the Dutch for two ax heads, a string of beads and some nails, has been valued at $500 million. The Op-Ed page asked urban planners, historians and writers to suggest ways in which the city might develop it. Here are their responses. The island should become the site of a new ecology park and convention center that would interweave New York's history and ecology. Exhibits in the restored landmark buildings would tell the story of the Lenape Indians, the original oyster shuckers, and of the Dutch settlers, who crossed the Atlantic to trap beavers on what is now Broadway.

title: Corrections
description: A profile in The Living Section on Wednesday about Jonathan Kozol, a writer who has been chronicling urban poverty for several decades, misstated the name of the publisher of his new book, "Amazing Grace: The Lives of Children and the Conscience of a Nation." It is Crown Publishers, not Crown Books.

description: Allied Signal Inc. said today that it would cut 3,100 jobs in its auto parts division, or about 3.7 percent of its total work force, and quit its car anti-lock brake business.

title: FOOTBALL;A Respectable Season, In Just Eight Easy Steps
description: In a football season with no clear-cut monster teams, the pipsqueak Jets could actually wind up having something to play for as they start the second half of their campaign Sunday at Indianapolis.

description: JIM FOWLER plans to take some friends along on Monday night when he goes to Roseland, the Manhattan dance club, to receive an award for educating young people about conservation issues.

description: With two rival Indian tribes proposing casinos in Sullivan County, visions of a new prosperity have gripped the Catskills.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets Down Charlotte To End the Preseason
description: A preseason that began in impressive fashion with four straight victories was heading toward a familiar tailspin for the Nets. Three consecutive road losses added more importance to tonight's finale here against the Charlotte Hornets than it deserved.

title: Two Rowan Players Suspended
description: Two white Rowan College football players charged with beating up two black students during a bar brawl were suspended yesterday by the college, officials said. The victims were not on the football team.

title: Corrections
description: A credit listing yesterday with a review of the musical "Victor/Victoria" omitted two cast members. Adam Heller played Henri Labisse, and Michael Cripe played Richard Di Nardo.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RUTH W. MESSINGER, the Manhattan Borough President, has become a grandmother again, thanks to her daughter, MIRIAM MESSINGER, 29, who gave birth on Tuesday to a 6-pound, 13-ounce girl at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. Miriam Messinger, a health consultant, will raise the child with her partner, FELICIA HAYES, 34, a computer instructor. The baby was named AMANI ARIEL HAYES-MESSINGER.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Drunk Toddler's Sitter Charged
description: A baby sitter was indicted on charges of child abuse and endangerment for allegedly feeding an 18-month-old rum-spiked Kool Aid and beer mixed with gin, The Associated Press reported. Gwendolyn A. Potts, 38, was taking care of the girl in April while the baby's mother was on vacation.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Guilty Plea in Cash Laundering
description: A Mount Laurel lawyer, Aaron Denker, pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal charges that he laundered $100,000 in drug trafficking proceeds in 1993, The A.P. said.

title: Passaic Track to Be Dedicated
description: In the early 1960's, SAM PERRY was a champion sprinter at Passaic High School in New Jersey. In 1965, running for Fordham, he twice equaled the world indoor record of 5.9 seconds for the 60-yard dash. He became a lawyer, the first black elected to the Passaic City Council and a member of the William Paterson College board of trustees. He is now vice president and general counsel of the American Kennel Club. Today, before a Homecoming Day football game against Bloomfield, his old high school will dedicate its new all-weather track at Boverini Stadium in his name.

title: For 1st Interstate, Possible White Knights
description: Several banks are moving closer to making friendly private offers for First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles, which appears to be looking for a white knight to rescue it from a hostile bid made last week by Wells Fargo & Company.

title: Auto Air Bags May Have Killed 8 Children, Safety Agency Says
description: Eight children who died in car crashes in recent years may have been killed by the cars' air bags, the Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today in announcing that the agency would begin considering next week whether there was a need to adopt a new standard of air-bag design.

title: Projecting Worries On the Stage
description: Sean Curran made a fine art out of anxiety in his dances on Thursday night at St. Mark's Danspace. He juxtaposed order and unpredictability in a new suite called "Five Points of Articulation," which was also the title for the program as a whole. Throughout its episodes, what at first appeared to be formal patterns grew increasingly dramatic in their implications. Thus, a duet for Shawn Mahoney and Mr. Curran began as a study in movements that somehow mirrored one another, and then became a love scene.

description: In her blackest moments, Loretta Ann Rosales can recall what it felt like as electrodes were tied to her fingers and toes, her body doubled over in a muscle-numbing convulsion from the jolt of electric current.

title: Compuserve Sets Plans for New Service
description: Compuserve Inc., the country's second-largest computer-based information network, said this week that it was planning to create an on-line service for novice computer users and people who want a "safe" on-line environment.

title: Questions of Justice in Okinawa
description: The abduction and rape of a 12-year-old schoolgirl in Okinawa, allegedly by three American servicemen, has stoked opposition to the presence of the 47,000 American troops stationed throughout Japan. The Clinton Administration has made an excellent start in assuring the Japanese that justice will be served, but more steps are needed to insure that the furor over this one ugly episode does not jeopardize the American security relationship with Japan. President Clinton should find time on his trip to Japan next month to demonstrate sensitivity to local concerns and reiterate the rationale for keeping American forces based there.

title: SINGER TO REPURCHASE UP TO 10% OF ITS SHARES
description: The Singer Company said yesterday that it planned to repurchase up to 10 percent of its 50.6 million common shares. Singer, a maker of sewing machines and other durable consumer goods, said it would buy the shares from time to time on the open market or in private transactions. Singer said it was buying the shares because it believed its stock was undervalued and because it was a means of increasing the company's value to shareholders. Singer shares closed at $23, down 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economy Grew in Summer At Surprisingly Brisk Pace The economy rebounded vigorously over the summer, growing at a 4.2 percent pace that surpassed nearly all expectations, the Commerce Department reported, while inflation, already low, subsided still further. "We're on the right track," President Clinton declared, trying to take advantage of the sunny report for his budget negotiations with the Congress. [ Page 1. ] Stock prices rebounded after Thursday's selloff as money managers took heart that inflation appeared to be under control. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 37.93 points, to 4,741.75. Bank stocks and technology issues were strong. [ 37. ] Bond prices swung widely as traders first feared that the strong economy would keep the Fed from lowering interest rates further, then tempered their reaction, seeing hope for a budget accord. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.35. [ 36. ] Allied Signal to Cut 3,100 Jobs Allied Signal reported a 15 percent rise in third-quarter net income but said profit in its automotive parts unit was off. The company said it would cut 3,100 jobs in that division, or about 3.7 percent of its total work force, and quit the car anti-lock brakes business. Allied's shares rose $2, to $43.375. [ 35. ] Aetna Earnings Jump 42% Aetna Life reported an unexpectedly large 42 percent gain in third-quarter earnings from operations, to $212.6 million, citing reduced costs for pollution cleanup. [ 35. ] Look Out Coke, Arizona Is Coming The small but feisty Arizona iced tea company is entering the cola wars. It is now making three flavored colas and a root beer. The line is being watched closely because of Arizona's record for smart product innovations. [ 35. ] Oil Partners Press Moscow Kazakhstan and its partner Chevron are trying to win Russia's agreement to ship more oil from their Tengiz fields. They are also planning to build a pipeline to connect to the Black Sea. If successful, Chevron could finally cash in on its $1 billion investment. [ 34. ] Airbags Tied to Childrens' Deaths Eight children may have been killed by airbags, according to a Government official, who said a redesign may be needed. [ 6. ] For TV Industry, a Cut-Rate Sale Buried in the budget bill is a plan to sell off a chunk of the nation's airwaves over the next seven years for an estimated $14 billion. It would give broadcasters licenses for "advanced television service," such as high-definition or interactive television, that Government economists say could be worth $70 billion. [ 9. ] The Senate veered away from the House in approving several changes to the bill to balance the Federal budget by 2002. It killed a provision to let corporations withdraw billions of dollars in surplus assets from their pension funds, retained the Federal guarantee of Medicaid coverage for a variety of poor people and kept regulations on nursing homes. [ 1. ] Tougher Limits on Lobbyists House Republicans plan a vote in November on tighter registration rules for lobbyists and on banning gifts to representatives and their staffs. The Senate adopted similar measures during the summer. [ 8. ] No Comment to the Japanese In an unusually tart exchange, the State Department told the Japanese Ambassador that it would not explain or confirm reports that the C.I.A. spied on Japanese negotiators during tense economic talks this year. [ 4. ] Japanese regulators accused Merrill Lynch Japan of violating a rule meant to prevent brokerage firms from manipulating stocks during new-securities sales. Some analysts saw the move as a retaliation for American criticism of the big loss at Daiwa Bank. [ 34. ] Smaller Awards in Implant Case The judge presiding over the silicone breast implant case disclosed details of a proposed settlement, including proposals that would further reduce awards to claimants. [ 10. ] Dollar Gains, Aided by Peso The dollar gained, benefiting from recoveries in the Mexican peso and French franc. It rose to 1.4090 German marks and 101.93 yen. [ 46. ]

title:
What to Do With Governors Island?;
Hanging Gardens
description: This month, the Coast Guard said it will close its base on Governors Island, in New York Harbor, off the southern tip of Manhattan, and the Federal Government has given New York City and the state the first option on buying the land. The 175-acre island, which the Manahatas Indians sold to the Dutch for two ax heads, a string of beads and some nails, has been valued at $500 million. The Op-Ed page asked urban planners, historians and writers to suggest ways in which the city might develop it. Here are their responses. New Yorkers don't have enough shaggy places. Sure, we have weedy lots in all five boroughs but not wild parks like Rome's Campagna, the Buttes-Chaumont in Paris or London's Hampstead Heath. Why not make Governors Island into New York City's Ninfa? In Ninfa, a ruined Italian village transformed into a garden, every roofless building is walled with roses. Gut the Governors Island Burger King, bowling alley, movie theater, beauty salon and hospital. (Contemplation of ruins is the best and healthiest recreation.) Shag up the abandoned buildings with rambler roses, porcelainberry vine and sweet autumn clematis. Turn naked interiors into walled courtyards. To cover maintenance and security, copy Britain's Landmark Trust, which rents out gazebos, hermits' huts and other garden follies. Governors Island, likewise, could rent out its motel, clapboard cottages and fancy brick houses at rates to suit every pocketbook. I have my eye on the early 19th-century fortress, Castle Williams: a single cell would do.

Hayes said yesterday that it would recapitalize through equity investments and new credit lines. Under the plan, Northern Telecom Ltd. and ACMA Ltd., a Singapore venture-capital firm, will together acquire 49 percent of Hayes. Dennis C. Hayes, the company's chairman, and the Hayes employee stock plan will own the remaining 51 percent. Hayes requested that the bankruptcy court schedule a confirmation date for its plan as soon as possible. Since Hayes filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy last November, it has attracted a number of potential suitors, including the U.S. Robotics Corporation, Diamond Multimedia Systems Inc. and Boca Research Inc.

From 1944 to 1945, Mike Siegelbaum wrote to his wife, Hazel, almost every day. His letters form the core of the film, read by a narrator, and their very ordinariness becomes the point. If ever there was a regular Joe (though a bit more devoted and thoughtful than most), it was Mike Siegelbaum.

title: Things They Weren't Expecting
description: The settings of the exuberantly varied short stories in Robert Flynn's second collection, LIVING WITH THE HYENAS (Texas Christian University, $22.50), range from the Vietnamese countryside to drowsy, prim American towns to a surly working-class bar in Paris. The protagonists include baffled children and men struggling to hold together uneasy marriages and uncertain careers, as well as two very different yet equally resilient women taking stock of their long lives. But while these 16 stories are in most ways insistently diverse, they do share one central feature: each turns on a sudden moment of self-revelation, inspired by accident, violence or loss. In "A Boy and His Dog," which takes place during the Vietnam War, a marine given an impossible job betrays with fatal consequences the one figure he can depend on -- the dog he uses to clear booby traps from jungle trails. "Defender of the Faith" is a bittersweet sketch of what happens when a naive adolescent discovers the irrational sway of desire. In the title story, Mr. Flynn traces with subtlety and humor how a widow, thinking back over her stifling history while visiting her husband's grave, is stunned into a realization of the possibilities that are still open to her. It's an exhilarating moment, entirely convincing. And it perfectly demonstrates how these wise, artful stories catch the ways in which we accept or deny what we see when the unexpected casts a bright light on our lives. RICHARD E. NICHOLLS

We'd like to get it over with and move on to the next bright day. This century feels old and tired; aerobics and Prozac can do only so much. The city, the country, the planet look as if they're ready for the nursing home. The air smells like an old bus. Even the symbols of the future have grown rusty. The plastic interiors of jet planes are yellowing; the metal is nearing fatigue; the flight attendants have wrinkles. Worst of all, our capacity for wonder has been diminished by too many hollow promises for the New and Improved, too much Spielberg: a whole century's worth of piled-up utopian hopes has come crashing down on the millennium's threshold.

title: Once Again, Huskymania
description: IT is an October afternoon and Jen Rizzotti is on the court at Gampel Pavilion in Storrs diving for a loose ball, shoving her way through traffic under the net and making a basket, then reaching in and grabbing a rebound. The new players on the UConn team, freshmen and transfers, stop momentarily as this whirling dervish called Rizzotti does her thing, then Rizzotti says, "This is basketball, let's move!" and everyone does. Jamelle Elliott, her co-captain, urges her teammates on, scolds them when they miss a shot but more often, like Rizzotti, shouts encouragement. "That's it baby. Good, Kara," Elliott says to Kara Wolters when she makes a graceful hook shot. It's only a scrimmage among teammates; it is four days before real practice can begin -- and the women's basketball season officially opens -- but Rizzotti goes after the ball with her trademark abandon. And Elliott has her game face on, a scowl that could strike fear in the heart of any opposing player, a scowl that doesn't leave her face until the nearly two-and-a-half-hour scrimmage is over, until her T-shirt is soaking wet, until she's exhorted all the other players to do their best. Only then, when she and Rizzotti share a few light-hearted words, do the lips turn up in a smile, does Rizzotti actually sit down and rest. "Nice work, J. J.," Rizzotti says to Elliott. Elliott nods her head. This is the follow-up to the 35-0, national championship dream season, the follow-up to the Hartford parade, the White House trip, the Letterman show, the season that brought Husky-mania to an all-time high, when fan mail arrived by the grocery cartful. But it is also the season without Rebecca Lobo, the National Player of the Year, the team leader who "did the work of three people on the court," said Kelley Hunt, a 6-2, sophomore. Lobo is now on the United States Senior National Team, gearing up for the Olympics. She will play for that team in an exhibition game against UConn next Sunday.

title: ART;'Primitive' No More, African Art Finds A Proper Respect
description: THE ROYAL ACADEMY OF ARTS heard all sorts of reasons for not organizing its new exhibition, "Africa: The Art of a Continent." The show would revive the debate about whether work done by anonymous African craftsmen was really art. It was certain to remind people that after centuries of plundering, much of Africa's best art is no longer to be found in Africa. And there was the big question: By tackling an entire continent, was not a former colonial power once again "talking down" to Africa?

Although, like many, it is on the sea, it does not have high-rises, shopping malls, miniature golf courses, mobile homes, bumper-to-bumper traffic, superhighways or traffic lights. The island does have two signs on the main street warning drivers about Raccoon Xings. It also has a long coral beach with a variety of gulls and swiftly stepping shore birds and great fishing. For those who care about night life or party glitz, Boca Grande is not the place to go. It lacks even the most rudimentary disco, and most of the town is in bed by 11.

title: FROM HUCK FINN TO CALVIN KLEIN'S BILLBOARD NYMPHETS
description: Walter Kendrick, in "From Huck Finn to Calvin Klein's Billboard Nymphets" (Oct. 8), made the point (among others) that adults do not remember the feel of childhood and that children are not about to reveal to them what they, the adults, do not remember. And most of your articles demonstrate the truth of this assertion. The novelists, except for Joyce Carol Oates, recall "transgressions," a word rather too melodramatic for the misdeeds described. The essayists cite statistics and dwell on the children who are in foster care or in therapy for kicking their mothers or being afraid to swallow food. Thus, the essays reveal more about adults in current social contexts than they do about children.

title:
MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;
The Final Voyage: Giving the Public What It Wants
description: Q. It cost a small fortune to give my father the funeral he always wanted, but I don't want to spend more than what's absolutely necessary on my own. What's the cheapest way to go?SHIRLEY LINDEMANNPendleton, N.Y. A. It depends on how much posthumous guilt you're willing to take with you into eternity. If you care nothing about the feelings of your friends or family, surely the most frugal approach is to become a street person and carry no personal identification. Then, when your body is found and nobody comes to claim it at the morgue, you're almost assured a numbered grave in the potter's fields on Hart Island overlooking Long Island Sound.

title: A Native American In Paris
description: Bunny McBride has stumbled across an irresistible story: beautiful, ambitious Indian girl flees backwater reservation in Maine for vaudeville, silent films, topless cabarets and a doomed romance with an earnest young Yale man -- then decamps for Josephine Baker's Paris, performing in buckskins at Fontainebleau, marrying a dashing French journalist and fulfilling her intellectual promise by attending anthropology lectures at the Sorbonne and working on a novel. Naturellement, fate soon strikes a heavy blow: the Nazis advance, and there's a desperate flight across the Pyrenees, during which our plucky heroine comforts her little daughter with the "ancient Penobscot Indian legends that had cheered her own childhood." More tragedy lies ahead, but in MOLLY SPOTTED ELK: A Penobscot in Paris (University of Oklahoma, $24.95) it's dished up in such kitschy style that you almost forget Molly Spotted Elk was a real person, not the star of a particularly inventive made-for-television mini-series. That may not be a tragedy, but it's certainly a shame. ALIDA BECKER

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;Stock Funds Can Survive a Rapid Flood of Cash
description: A STOCK fund growing rapidly causes investment advisers to shudder. The outstanding performance that attracted all that money in the first place is bound to suffer, they contend. "I wouldn't put money into funds that have doubled their assets" in a year, said John Rekenthaler, editor of the Morningstar Investor, a fund newsletter in Chicago. To find out if a cash flood truly hinders performance, Morningstar Inc. agreed to search its data base for fast-growing funds of the last decade. Just as Fidelity Magellan has turned in oversized returns even as it has ballooned, the funds in the study did not necessarily suffer because of rapid growth. The study looked at small-company funds and aggressive growth funds, types that tend to load up on small stocks and that generate the most concern when they swell.
