Halloween Redux on Jamaica Bay
description: IT was about 4 o'clock last Halloween when I set out in my kayak from a canoe club in Canarsie and paddled out into Jamaica Bay. It was warm, about 55 degrees, and a bit foggy. By the time I turned around to head back, the Manhattan skyline was gone. I was lost, enveloped in thick fog, and I spent that whole night on an island in the bay, ankle-deep in water. I haven't felt the same way about Halloween since.

title: WHAT GROWN-UPS DON'T UNDERSTAND
description: Why were all your distinguished writers fixated on the sadness of childhood today? Most children, even those who grow up in difficult environments, are still busy having fun, enjoying life and doing all the things that children have been doing for centuries.

title: Travel Advisory; Restored San Francisco Museum Opens Nov. 11
description: The California Palace of the Legion of Honor in San Francisco will reopen on Nov. 11 after a three-year, $36.5 million restoration. The project encompassed interior and exterior, a two-level expansion underneath the building and a seismic retrofitting.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: ALL MY SINS ARE RELATIVES By W. S. Penn. University of Nebraska, $25.

title: PORTRAIT OF THE AMERICAN CHILD, 1995
description: In Camille Sweeney's often fascinating compilation of statistics on American childhood, I believe the citation of figures on student-teacher ratios was misleading ("Portrait of the American Child, 1995"). New York City may have a ratio of 18 to 1, but in many actual classrooms, class size has ballooned well into the 30's. This is true across the nation because many specialists, coordinators and administrators are counted as classroom teachers, regardless of the class load they carry (if any).

title:
The View From: Greenwich;
Only the Ducks Really Like the Mianus River's Green Gunk
description: GOBS of green gunk can be scooped by the handful from the Mianus River, where the Town of Greenwich gets most of its drinking water. The question for a $100,000 study being conducted by the town's Conservation Commission is whether that goo is good for people to ingest. The commission is also looking at whether Mianus Pond, just downriver from the Connecticut American Water Company treatment plant, can be used as a regular source of water supply, not just in emergencies.

title:
NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Once Secret Hubs, Now Fancy Pubs
description: ON Monday nights, they rushed to Sally O'Brien's in Sunnyside, Queens, for the latest batch of daily newspapers from Ireland. On Fridays, at the Village Pub in the Bainbridge section of the Bronx, there was a line that stretched from the bartender to the street as construction workers and nannies waited to get their off-the-book paychecks cashed.

title: Giving Scallops an Edge Against Predators
description: THE only place in Connecticut waters where there are definitely large quantities of scallops is within the specially designed docks at Cedar Island Marina in Clinton. The scallops are grown inside wooden docks that are also used as slips for recreational boats.

title: Film;Move Over, Babe. Here Comes Pinocchio.
description: THE PINT-SIZE MOVIE STAR waited patiently for his next take, unperturbed by the raucous scene unfolding around him. "Allez! Allez! Allez!" a French animal trainer cried, imploring his most talented donkey to lift a front leg to unlatch a gate. Other donkeys brayed encouragement. But even talented donkeys . . . well, at least the young star would be ready when called. In fact, being an animatronic puppet, he was always ready.

title: THEATER;Laurence Fishburne's Does-It-All Performance
description: FOR SOME PLAYWRIGHTS, THE ACT OF creation can take months, even years. Not Laurence Fishburne. Sitting on a movie set in Florida in the summer of 1994, the actor wrote his first play in eight days.

title: Objects and Images in the Shaker Tradition
description: MOST people looking at Shaker furniture today are drawn to the austere beauty of the pieces. Handcrafted chairs and cupboards, tables and desks with spare, simple lines appeal to the contemporary eye.

title: Islanders Fight Their Way Back to a Tie
description: Their record may not be very good. But if the Islanders have shown anything the first nine games of this season it is this: This team does not quit. Mike Milbury apparently will not let them.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Pinot Meunier Duck Walk Vineyards, Water Mill, 1994. About $13.

title:
NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WEST SIDE;
Need the Police? Then You Need The Extension
description: Rapes have increased in the 24th Precinct since last year. Drug dealing continues to be a major problem. But at a recent meeting about crime in one precinct neighborhood, Manhattan Valley, the issue that drew the most attention was this: voice mail at the precinct station house. "Get rid of voice mail," resident after resident said.

title: Jordan Seeks To Be Like The Old Mike
description: A solitary figure was practicing moves against an imaginary opponent. Even with no defenders present, it was a captivating display. The tongue was out. The jumper was falling. Sweat glistened from his shaved head as he took one shot, then another, then another. Most of his teammates were still in street clothes. Some of them had not even arrived at the United Center.

title: 'ALAS FOR HAMELIN!'
description: In " 'Alas for Hamelin!' " (Word & Image, Oct. 8), Max Frankel is right to lament that "children spend more of their youth staring at the screen than attending school." But his proposed solution -- more Government-mandated education programming -- is of dubious constitutionality. Much as he and I might prefer the exchange of ideas to the hawking of products, the First Amendment makes no such distinction. His "free speech, but not that kind" argument, while well intentioned, is more dangerous than useful.

title: Columbia Turns Over Ivy Lead
description: It was a mistake-filled day for Columbia and a touchdown-filled day for Princeton.

title: Natalie Green, Douglas P. Giles
description: Natalie Green and Douglas Pope Giles, management consultants in New York, were married last evening. Rabbi Dan Isaac performed the ceremony at the Manhattan Penthouse, a catering space.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: Rock Concert Mementos And Clerks Dancing in a Cage Lusting after the gold lame bustier Madonna wore on her "Blond Ambition" tour, or perhaps a Samsonite suitcase once carried by Elvis? Both items are for sale at Gig Wear, a rock-and-roll paraphernalia store in SoHo that opened last Tuesday.

title: Miss Buckley, Mr. Marakovits
description: Cornelia Connelly Buckley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Buckley Jr. of Leeds Point, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Marakovits, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alois Marakovits. The Rev. Anthony Di Bardino performed the ceremony at the Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in Margate, N.J.

title:
IN PERSON;
The Don Quixote of Nutraceuticals
description: AS a young endocrinologist at St. Vincent's Hospital in Greenwich Village, Dr. Stephen L. DeFelice witnessed a minor miracle. Several times a month, women would walk into the clinic suffering from hyperthyroidism, a disease that causes emotional instability, weight loss and, if left untreated, death. On a hunch from a colleague, Dr. DeFelice, who was on a fellowship in clinical pharmacology, tried a new therapy for the thyroid disorder. The treatment, called carnitine, reversed the symptoms in a week -- much faster than the traditional thyroid medication, and just as effectively.

title: Pension's Pockets: Open for Business
description: The House of Representatives included in the budget bill it passed last week a provision permitting companies to take billions of dollars out of their pension funds. And while the Senate rejected this idea in the budget it approved Friday, all eyes are now turning to the conference committee, where the notion may well emerge in some form.

title: The Greening of the Humanities
description: I KNEW SOMETHING WAS UP when, a year ago, two of my best students at Middlebury College, in Vermont, told me sheepishly that they were abandoning English for environmental studies. They were not the first to go. "A few years ago, we had only a handful of students, maybe four or five majors per year," said John Elder, a professor of both English and environmental studies at Middlebury who has become a guru in the latter program. "Now we have a hundred or more majors, and it's growing."

description: If he is found guilty on Monday, a former member of Kenya's Parliament will be sentenced to death by hanging.

Even by the efficiency standards established in the Tom Osborne era, this Nebraska achievement was memorable.

Marketing the Vacated Corporate Office Campuses
description: FOR more than 25 years, the 200-acre International Business Machines Corporation campus was a fixture on Old Mill Road in Franklin Lakes. But late in 1993, as part of the company's restructuring, the six-building, 675,000-square-foot complex closed, leaving behind one of the larger blocs of vacant space in the 11-county northern New Jersey office marketplace.

description: NESTLED in a wooded area of Springs, the studio of the artist Li-Lan seems a long way from the economic dynamics of Taiwan, where a number of her meticulously painted compositions based on correspondence envelopes are on view at a major gallery, Lin & Keng.

description: RENEE BOOCKVOR, executive director of the Westchester Shore Humane Society here, believes every animal deserves a chance at life. That is why she recently ignored a veterinarian's recommendation to put to death a puppy born with nonfunctioning rear legs and sought another course of action.

title: KIDUAGE
description: Calling all kids"? Are you kidding? How do you expect to solicit "thoughts on this special issue" from "younger readers" when you haven't spoken to them? Doesn't it occur to William Safire, writing about kids' talk, to address the kids themselves as possible readers? Instead, he talks to their parents: "If your kids are unable to differentiate. . . . When your offspring. . . ." JESSICA YOOD Smithtown, L.I.

title: Murder a Growth Industry In Poor, Reeling Camden
description: Clarence Jones, who had a record as a small-time drug dealer, was shot to death on Sunday. The police said the drive-by shooting was probably an act of revenge or a territorial grab by other drug dealers. His killing would be unremarkable by urban standards except that it was the 48th homicide here this year.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about a Parks Department plan to turn a grassy area along the Shore Parkway in Sheepshead Bay into a parking lot misstated the day for the presentation of the plan to Community Board 15. It is this Tuesday; it was not last Tuesday.

description: He talks about the passport of a future independent Quebec as "a beautiful thing -- a symbol of what we are, the symbol of our people, the symbol of our state, the symbol of our identity -- and we'll be well received everywhere with a Quebec passport."

title: OCT. 22-28;Excuse Me, Do You Have the Right Time?
description: NO one in Vevay, Ind., turned the clocks back this morning when the rest of the nation switched to standard time after six months on daylight saving time. Vevay did not spring forward in April, either. Vevay is in a state that doesn't change its clocks but is on the border of Kentucky and Ohio, which do. No wonder everyone in Vevay spends a lot of time figuring out what time everybody else is on.

title: Suffolk Enforcing Ban On Smoking in Schools
description: EXCEPT for a cough that he stifled every few minutes, Jason Landusky, 16, listened quietly to the explanation of the antismoking law that he had broken. When asked whether he would promise, in writing, not to commit the offense again, he nodded and said, "Yeah."

title: Foreign Affairs; I Dial Therefore I Am

title: KIDUAGE
description: As a 13-year-old freshman at Princeton High School, I was bothered that William Safire and those he cited in "Kiduage" (On Language, Oct. 8) seemed to assume that there is a universal language for kids and teens. Depending upon where you live, and the cliques you are in, slang terms change. The preferred and universal language of kids is exactly what adults use when they're chillin' or hangin' -- the four- letter favorites.

More likely it will be the shift of power to state capitals, a fundamental realignment that is already unleashing unpredictable new forces.

title: Virginia Becomes Test Case for G.O.P. Revolution
description: A year after the Republican Congressional sweep, Virginia's usually staid local races have been transformed into high-stakes contests, stoked by money from the national parties and the chance that the state's Legislature could be the first in the South to turn Republican since Reconstruction.

title: SUNDAY, October 26, 1995; QUESTIONS FOR: Jim Rose
description: Q: What does fire taste like? A: Fire has no taste, so it depends on what you use on the torch -- gasoline, lantern fluid or rubbing alcohol. And all that stuff is spicier and hotter than any pizza, and it doesn't taste like watermelon. But I don't taste it, really. I've lost so many taste buds that now everything tastes like white bread. Q: What's your latest stunt? A: This year we're playing chain-saw football. It's probably the most dangerous sport since Christians were fed to the lions -- gives new meaning to the word "halfback." The blade's running and there's a hike. There's a lateral and then a tackle. To celebrate the touchdown, we throw heads of lettuce at a running lawn mower that's balanced on a guy's upper lip. Salad goes flying into the air.

title: THE WORLD;Powell Takes a Hit
description: WHEN Bosnia's three warring factions sit down to talk peace this week, it's only fitting that they will meet at a United States Air Force base. NATO air power, dominated by United States fighter jets, bombed the Bosnian Serbs to the bargaining table. A two-week bombardment this summer demolished their ammunition dumps, air defenses and command bunkers. It wrecked their will to wage wide-scale war and broke the siege of Sarajevo. But it stopped short of breaking their army.

Parents and children find themselves having to explain the unexplainable to each other.

title: Classroom Cable From the Tow Family
description: WHEN Leonard Tow was starting up a cable television company in the early 1970's, it was at a time when people didn't quite understand what cable was, when there were still plenty of homes with huge antennas on their roofs, when there was no such thing as CNN or MTV.

title: Pamela Goldman And Joel Telpner
description: Pamela Grant Goldman, a writer, and Joel Stephan Telpner, a lawyer, are to be married today at the New York Academy of Sciences in New York. Rabbi Steven H. Moskowitz is to perform the ceremony.

description: Wendy Sue Israel, the managing editor of Family Life magazine in New York, was married last evening to Joseph Jacobs, the curator of painting and sculpture at the Newark Museum. Rabbi Carole B. Balin performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: Medical Centers May Lease City Hospitals
description: At least three area hospitals seeking to expand their health-care networks are expressing interest in plans to lease three city hospitals, lured by their locations, the mix of patients and the kinds of services each provides.

title: UNIVERSITY PRESSES;Something to Sink Her Teeth Into
description: OUR VAMPIRES, OURSELVES By Nina Auerbach. 231 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $22. IN case anyone should think this book is merely a boring lit-crit exposition from a professor of English at the University of Pennsylvania -- or perhaps the product of a remote corner of new-wave, soft-option media studies -- Nina Auerbach sets matters straight in her very first paragraph. "What vampires are in any given generation," she writes, "is a part of what I am and what my times have become. This book is a history of Anglo-American culture through its mutating vampires."

title: A Town's Debate: Should Hanging Out Be Against the Law?
description: IT is 7 P.M. on a Friday evening, and there's some furtive activity in a parking lot off Main Street in Jewett City. When a police car cruises slowly by, a group of young people scatters. Two men in a parked car slide down in their seats.

title: Little Black Box Put Electronic Music on Map
description: IT looks like a shiny black lacquered box that has sprouted two metal antennae, one rising vertically from the top, the other a hoop extending horizontally out of the side -- something one might see in an old science-fiction movie.

title: WORLD SERIES '95: NOTEBOOK;Players and Owners Take Lesson In Geography of Labor Problems
description: Fort Lauderdale and Homestead don't quite live up to Munich and Potsdam in the context of historical significance, where agreements affecting the world's powers took on the names of geographical locations.

title: MUSIC;Baroque Masters, With Great Care
description: NEW HAVEN may corner the musical market this week, with concerts -- most of them associated with Yale -- arriving almost on a daily basis.

title: Through the Years, Plants Pretty but Poison
description: LOVERS of plants can learn which ones may be dangerous in "Pretty Deadly: Poisonous Plants of Forest, Field and Garden," on view through Nov. 8 at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich. The exhibition offers a show of botanical paintings as well as revelations of the toxicity of some plants.

title: POP VIEW;The Lonely Song of the 'Night Bird'
description: THE RECENT LOSS OF A FRIEND AND FORMER co-worker, the radio personality Alison Steele, the Night Bird, who died late last month of cancer at 58, caused me to reflect on how much the business has and hasn't changed for women since she became the first woman to win one of the industry's top awards in 1976. That was the year Ms. Steele, who had developed a tremendous following doing a late-night show on WNEW-FM in New York, was crowned Billboard's FM Personality of the Year.

title: ALAS FOR HAMELIN!'
description: In " 'Alas for Hamelin!' " (Word & Image, Oct. 8), Max Frankel is right to lament that "children spend more of their youth staring at the screen than attending school." But his proposed solution -- more Government-mandated education programming -- is of dubious constitutionality. Much as he and I might prefer the exchange of ideas to the hawking of products, the First Amendment makes no such distinction. His "free speech, but not that kind" argument, while well intentioned, is more dangerous than useful.

title: THE GREAT OUTDOORS;For Carlstadt, the Latest Meadows Plan Means a Court Date
description: The new state plan to redevelop the Hackensack Meadowlands isn't off the drawing board yet, but it has already provoked a lawsuit. Tomorrow, Carlstadt plans to file a motion in Federal District Court in Newark seeking to block an enormous mixed-use development that could triple the town's population.

title: 3d Hamptons Film Festival Fades Out
description: The lights are on again in East Hampton as the third Hamptons International Film Festival tucked away the last of 70 films shown through last weekend to an audience estimated at 30,000.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: THE SELECTED CORRESPONDENCE OF KARL A. MENNINGER, 1946-1965 Edited by Howard J. Faulkner and Virginia D. Pruitt. University of Missouri, paper, $29.95.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about restrictions that are placed on retired executives' exercise of stock options misstated the given name of the lawyer for Richard R. Collins, who is challenging his compensation agreement in court. The lawyer is Richard G. Elliott Jr., not Frank.

title: Making Odds on an OTB at Silver Palace
description: From a restaurant near the Manhattan Bridge, horse racing fans may soon be able to wager on American steeds by day and those running at Hong Kong tracks by night. For the last several months, officials of the Offtrack Betting Corporation and owners of the Silver Palace restaurant have discussed opening an upscale gambling parlor at the restaurant, which is struggling to recover from a labor dispute.

title: Court Decision Clears Way for Renovating Main St. IRT Station
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Queens has dismissed a lawsuit that sought to block the renovation of the Main Street station of the IRT No. 7 subway line. The decision clears the way for the $27 million renovation of the 70-year-old station to begin early next year.

title: MY PARENTS' BUST-UP, AND MINE
description: It was a letdown to read Kirn's self-serving nonsense after the moving and eloquent stories of the children featured in your special issue.

title: How to Succeed? Go to Wellesley
description: DETROIT and cars, Hollywood and films, Silicon Valley and chips. It's hard to think of one without the other. Here's a new link in the business landscape. Henceforth, when you hear Wellesley, Mass., the home of Wellesley College, think of top-level executive women.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: The Caribbean Is Cleaning Up
description: MUCH of the island of St. Thomas is decked out in blue these days. Blue is the color of the tarpaulins the Federal Emergency Management Agency, FEMA, has supplied to cover the many houses without roofs.

title: ON THE JOB;Ken Yew Spat the Air Or?
description: When The New York Times asked readers for examples of on-the-job spelling mistakes, one person asked why sign painters can't spell. The thought is worrisome. If sign painters were perfect spellers, the picky, picky people who inhabit all the other professions and never, ever spell a word wrong wouldn't have any fun. Keen-eyed drivers wouldn't enjoy the New England Thurway. No one would detect those miniscule -- or is it minuscule? -- errors in memos. And the world would not need that eagerly anticipated invention, the infallible spell checker.

title: Checking Flight Times On the Internet
description: Considering the Delta shuttle from New York to Washington this evening? The 7:30 P.M. flight was late twice as often as the 6:30 P.M. flight, according to statistics recently put on the Internet by the Department of Transportation, along with data on thousands of other flights by the nation's 10 biggest airlines.

title: A Crackdown on Police Criminality
description: Mark Fuhrman's boast that he and fellow officers fabricated evidence and beat black citizens for no reason has prompted the Justice Department to begin a "preliminary investigation" into civil rights violations by the Los Angeles Police Department. The investigation is warranted, but the Justice Department needs to intensify its efforts in several other cities as well. Los Angeles is by no means the only, or even the worst, example of police thuggery.

title: WHY BOYS DON'T PLAY WITH DOLLS
description: I am delighted that Katha Pollitt implies that we should lay the gender-role guilt trip on parents, where it belongs (Hers: "Why Boys Don't Play With Dolls," Oct. 8). Culture and genetics count for something, to be sure, but parentally transmitted values are key. After all, when Susie gives a Barbie doll to her friend Sally as a birthday present, that's one thing. But when a parent passes along the same gift, it's a loaded gesture. AMY L. BERNSTEIN Baltimore

title:
BACKTALK;
The All Very-East Squad, Courtesy of Phil Jackson
description: Professional basketball has all kinds of all-teams. You know, all-defense, all-rookie, all-out. But what about the all-Taoist team?

title: SUNDAY, October 26, 1995: GREAT BOOKS; The 'A' Team
description: High-school English teachers have succeeded where a naked Demi Moore has failed: they've propelled Nathaniel Hawthorne onto a best-seller list. In the fall, it seems, a teacher's fancy turns academically to thoughts of adultery and "The Scarlet Letter." (Perhaps more so this year, given the R-rated film version of the standard reading assignment.)

Yale as a Force on the Urban Front

That is the stated position of Henry Cisneros, the nation's Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and his department is putting money behind the thought: $2.4 million to Yale, for example, to help restore deteriorating neighborhoods beyond the brick-walled campus.

Once Secret Hubs, Now Fancy Pubs

On Fridays, at the Village Pub in the Bainbridge section of the Bronx, there was a line that stretched from the bartender to the street as construction workers and nannies waited to get their off-the-book paychecks cashed.

title: SUNDAY, October 26, 1995: INFRASTRUCTURE; Tunnel Vision
description: When planning first began for "Daylight," a swashing adventure movie starring Sylvester Stallone and featuring a cataclysm in the "New York Tunnel," it was clear that filming in a real New York tunnel would create a real cataclysm. The cinematic tunnel had to endure flooding of tidal-wave proportions, as well as major explosions. So the movie's executive producer, Raffaella De Laurentiis, decided to do her own tunneling, in Rome. After getting permission from the Port Authority to scrutinize the Holland Tunnel, De Laurentiis built a thousand-foot clone in three months for $1.7 million. (The genuine article took seven years, cost a whopping -- for then -- $48 million and opened in 1927.)

title: COPING;The Delicate Steps of the Junior High Dance
description: UNDER the nagging beat of "YMCA," the principal was muttering, "I don't like things like this," and a sixth-grade boy wondered aloud if he'd ever have a girlfriend, and two eighth-grade girls said it would be better if there were no sixth-grade boys around, and the gym teacher lobbied the parents to fix the gym windows. Just then, the soda and chips ran out, statistical proof that the Autumn Harvest Dance at Stephen A. Halsey Junior High School 157 in Rego Park, Queens, was the box-office hit of the school year.

title: THE WORLD;Iraqis Are Angry but Not Just at You-Know-Who
description: A LAH MUKHTAR, a ranking member of the ruling Baath Party, glanced at television sets tuned in to CNN, BBC and (of all countries) Israel in his office on a recent evening, watching for commentary about the imminent referendum on whether to retain Saddam Hussein as President. Not far away, in a teahouse near Al Kazem mosque, Malek, an unemployed 25-year-old Iraqi Shiite, watched the Qatar-Iraq soccer game -- for him, a far more interesting diversion from the hardships of life under economic sanctions.

Although details escape her now, she said she remembers that he exhorted the crowd to press the Government for change.

title: Familiarity Breeds Content
description: IF the biggest joy in travel is the thrill of discovery, the second biggest is the thrill of familiarity. A return trip to a favorite spot is heightened by happy memories of all your previous visits, and on top of that you have the pleasure of getting away without the angst of the unknown. How else can I explain why, when there are dozens of destinations within weekending range of Los Angeles, time and time again my husband, Duke, and I return to Desert Hot Springs, a remarkably unremarkable town on the wrong side of the Coachella Valley, opposite Palm Springs?

description: LEDOYT By Carol Emshwiller. Illustrated. 227 pp. San Francisco: Mercury House. Paper, $14.95. TWO strangers meet in a sunbaked, hardscrabble land. She is Oriana Cochran, who has fled there to bring up her illegitimate daughter. He is Bill (Beal) Ledoyt, a cowpuncher and handyman who occasionally drifts through the territory to visit his married brother. She is slender, beautiful, the only child of a cultivated New England family. He is bony, scruffy, the oldest son of a dirt-poor French-American farmer. Naturally, they fall in love.

description: WITH the Yankees season having ended this month and the New York football teams foundering, the Knicks, with their new coach Don Nelson here and their season opener at hand on Friday, are ready to take center stage in the hearts and minds of the metropolitan region's sports fans.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN;Phoenix
description: The snowbirds, those 200,000 visitors who flock to metropolitan Phoenix each fall and winter to spend the next several months basking in the Valley of the Sun's 75-degree days, this year will find a city in the midst of transition. The Phoenix City Council is trying to revitalize the heart of what has become a far-flung, decentralized metropolis.

title: Once Again, Huskymania
description: IT is an October afternoon and Jen Rizzotti is on the court at Gampel Pavilion in Storrs diving for a loose ball, shoving her way through traffic under the net and making a basket, then reaching in and grabbing a rebound. The new players on the UConn team, freshmen and transfers, stop momentarily as this whirling dervish called Rizzotti does her thing, then Rizzotti says, "This is basketball, let's move!" and everyone does. Jamelle Elliott, her co-captain, urges her teammates on, scolds them when they miss a shot but more often, like Rizzotti, shouts encouragement. "That's it baby. Good, Kara," Elliott says to Kara Wolters when she makes a graceful hook shot. It's only a scrimmage among teammates; it is four days before real practice can begin -- and the women's basketball season officially opens -- but Rizzotti goes after the ball with her trademark abandon. And Elliott has her game face on, a scowl that could strike fear in the heart of any opposing player, a scowl that doesn't leave her face until the nearly two-and-a-half-hour scrimmage is over, until her T-shirt is soaking wet, until she's exhorted all the other players to do their best. Only then, when she and Rizzotti share a few light-hearted words, do the lips turn up in a smile, does Rizzotti actually sit down and rest. "Nice work, J. J.," Rizzotti says to Elliott. Elliott nods her head. This is the follow-up to the 35-0, national championship dream season, the follow-up to the Hartford parade, the White House trip, the Letterman show, the season that brought Husky-mania to an all-time high, when fan mail arrived by the grocery cartful. But it is also the season without Rebecca Lobo, the National Player of the Year, the team leader who "did the work of three people on the court," said Kelley Hunt, a 6-2, sophomore. Lobo is now on the United States Senior National Team, gearing up for the Olympics. She will play for that team in an exhibition game against UConn next Sunday.

title: Linda M. Booth, John F. Sweeney
description: Linda Marie Booth, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Booth of Morris Plains, N.J., was married yesterday to John Francis Sweeney, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Sweeney of Rye, N.Y. Msgr. William J. Toohy, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at St. Paul Church in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Ten More Yards and Hampton Rushes Into Giant History
description: His approach to the record is like his personality. Rodney Hampton is quiet, very quiet. Few players on the team are close to him and few know a lot about him. His pursuit of the Giants' career rushing record has been equally quiet. There hasn't been much talk about it. No daily update in the news media. No Hampton Watch.

description: First Walt Disney announced plans to move into Times Square. Now, old standards like XXX-TASY Video and the Eros Theater face eviction by New York City.

title: Treks for the Tired
description: Age may be a state of mind, but that doesn't help much when you're trying to climb the Himalayas. Mid Life Adventures, a New Zealand company, offers an outdoor tour for travelers 35 or older in that country's North and South Islands. The 17-day excursion, geared to travelers who are not quite as fit as they used to be, includes bush walks, sea kayaking and a guided glacier walk. The price, from $3,895 to $4,195 a person depending on departure dates, includes air fare from Los Angeles, accommodations and most meals. Information and reservations: (800) 528-6129.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES;
Lolita & Company
description: THE MAGICIAN'S DOUBTS Nabokov and the Risks of Fiction.By Michael Wood.252 pp. Princeton, N.J.:Princeton University Press. $24.95.

title: THEATER;A Stage Magician, His Specialty Is Being Invisible
description: IN HIS APTLY TITLED autobiography, "Utopia and Other Places," Richard Eyre recalls an answer by Peter Brook when asked "What is directing?" Mr. Brook replied: "It's getting people on and offstage." The remark is a neat bit of reductionism ad absurdum -- like saying a sculptor chips away at marble. But for all the British affectation of refusing to be taken too seriously, and pretending to be a dabbler in a craft rather than a practitioner of high art, it does capture something of the essence of the thing. A director does get people on and offstage.

title: THE WORLD;Soldiering On, Without an Enemy
description: IN preparing to send 20,000 American troops to Bosnia, one of President Clinton's biggest problems is how to market the mission.

So when I planned to visit England in August, I decided to build an extra week into the trip to check on the offerings. My idea was to hunt around for a good deal on a package to some sunny spot in the Mediterranean -- Spain, the Turkish coast or a Greek island.

title: Keepers of the Tenure Track
description: IF you were a graduate student in the 80's and subject to the general delusion that held literary criticism to be the ne plus ultra of intellectual thrill, then you too probably owned one of these: an oversize paperback with an austere cover and small-type title that, grouped with three or more of its kind on your bookshelf, confirmed your status as an avatar of predoctoral chic. The object in question was a volume in the University of Minnesota series called "Theory and History of Literature" -- any volume, since they all looked alike and were each equally tantalizing, coming as they did in a wide variety of colors. There were Hans Robert Jauss's "Toward an Aesthetics of Reception" (pink), Paul de Man's "Blindness and Insight" (powder blue) and Jean-Francois Lyotard's "Postmodern Condition" (lurid aquamarine). There were Mikhail Bakhtin's "Problems of Dostoevsky's Poetics" (sunflower yellow) and Michel de Certeau's "Heterologies" (electric blue). No other books in all academia were quite so insistently chromatic, or had half as much cachet.

title: INVESTING IT;Nintendo? Bogus. But Investing? Bonus!

He reads Barron's, Forbes, Worth and Money and has spent hours daily hunched over computer screens glowing with company data.

title: The View From: Greenwich;Only the Ducks Really Like the Mianus River's Green Gunk

The question for a $100,000 study being conducted by the town's Conservation Commission is whether that goo is good for people to ingest. The commission is also looking at whether Mianus Pond, just downriver from the Connecticut American Water Company treatment plant, can be used as a regular source of water supply, not just in emergencies.

title: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;The Final Voyage: Giving the Public What It Wants
description: Q. It cost a small fortune to give my father the funeral he always wanted, but I don't want to spend more than what's absolutely necessary on my own. What's the cheapest way to go? SHIRLEY LINDEMANN Pendleton, N.Y. A. It depends on how much posthumous guilt you're willing to take with you into eternity. If you care nothing about the feelings of your friends or family, surely the most frugal approach is to become a street person and carry no personal identification. Then, when your body is found and nobody comes to claim it at the morgue, you're almost assured a numbered grave in the potter's fields on Hart Island overlooking Long Island Sound.

title: THE SOCIETY THAT PRETENDS TO LOVE CHILDREN

title: A Jeweler's Eye
description: THE STORIES OF VLADIMIR NABOKOV Edited by Dmitri Nabokov. 659 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $35. RETURN trips to Paradise are risky. The prose of Vladimir Nabokov did loom as a paradise for me when I began to read, in The New Yorker more than 40 years ago, the reminiscences that became chapters of "Speak, Memory" (1951) and the short stories about the touching Russian emigre professor Timofey Pnin, eventually collected in the quasi novel "Pnin" (1957). What startling beauty of phrase, twists of thought, depths of sorrow and bursts of wit! -- this was a rainbow prose that made most others look flat and gray. "Lolita" sensationally followed in 1958, and I settled into an enraptured readership as, capitalizing upon this breakthrough into best-sellerdom, the exquisite but industrious author mingled new productions in his adopted English with lovingly supervised translations from his large oeuvre in his native Russian. The publication now, 18 years after Nabokov's death, of his collected stories, under the editorship of his son and favorite translator, Dmitri Nabokov, offered a threat as well as a treat: a threat, that is, to dull and dampen a faithful reader's old ardor with a ponderous assembly of short fiction originally consumed in the four handy collections, of 13 items each, which the senior Nabokov had issued while alive.

title: IN PERSON;The Don Quixote of Nutraceuticals
description: AS a young endocrinologist at St. Vincent's Hospital in Greenwich Village, Dr. Stephen L. DeFelice witnessed a minor miracle. Several times a month, women would walk into the clinic suffering from hyperthyroidism, a disease that causes emotional instability, weight loss and, if left untreated, death. On a hunch from a colleague, Dr. DeFelice, who was on a fellowship in clinical pharmacology, tried a new therapy for the thyroid disorder. The treatment, called carnitine, reversed the symptoms in a week -- much faster than the traditional thyroid medication, and just as effectively.

title: Ghost Story
description: THE HUNDRED SECRET SENSES By Amy Tan. 358 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $24.95. THE tremendous success of Amy Tan's two previous novels, "The Joy Luck Club" and "The Kitchen God's Wife," lay in her capacity to evoke, vividly and with subtle humor, the cultural dislocation of America's Chinese community. She has conjured the tortuous lives of an older generation of women whose fate brought them from China to this country, as well as the frustration and fascination of their American-born daughters. It is not surprising, then, that in her latest book, "The Hundred Secret Senses," she should offer an apparent reworking of this theme.

title: Czech Center Renews Unity And a Facade
description: When proud immigrants built the Bohemian National Hall in 1896, no one foresaw the tumultuous century that would follow in their homeland overseas, and in the hall's internal affairs. The building became a magnet for Czech nationalists from Bohemia, a medieval kingdom that fell under Hapsburg rule. In the aftermath of World War I, the Czechs won independence, but Nazi Germany dismembered Czechoslovakia, which later fell to the Communists. Democracy was restored in 1989, and in 1992, the nation split into the Czech Republic and Slovakia.

title: A Sickness Unto Death
description: WALKING ON AIR By R. S. Jones. 253 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $21.95. THIS new novel by R. S. Jones is the story of a man named William Addams who is dying of AIDS in New York. William is almost 40, a big man with a powerful personality and a successful career as a stockbroker. He has two close friends, Henry, who is gay, and Susan, who is not. These two function as family to the ailing William, and their lives are changed in the process. Slowly but inexorably, the disease destroys William, attacking both his body and his identity, and at the end he dies. The novel's power resides in its almost total refusal to do anything but starkly describe this process, to trace the effects of the disease on this suffering man and his two friends. It rings true from start to finish.

title: This Fall, You Really Do Need a Scorecard

Some of the young single professionals in the ensemble sitcoms, for instance, don't even live in New York. Several of the good-looking photojournalists don't work for sleazy tabloids. And as for the characters who seem to be inspired by John F. Kennedy Jr. -- please. Not one has a sister named Caroline. But if not exactly alike, they're close to it. Here is a selective guide to the finite variety in prime time's new entries. ANITA GATES

Those on the island for two weeks can play a different course nearly every day, something few other islands in the Caribbean can boast. Puerto Rico doesn't just offer quantity either, as several courses are of championship caliber. But that quality comes at a price. Greens fees typically range from $50 to $150 (although one can play a nine-hole public course for less than $10), and the preponderance of resort courses means that players who are not guests at the respective hotels pay much more. And such courses usually require renting motorized carts, a policy that may or may not speed up play, but one that certainly irritates purists.

title: WINTER IN THE SUN;PAMPERED IN THE PHILIPPINES
description: I HAD almost believed Ferdinand Marcos Jr., the son of the late Philippine dictator, when he tried to convince me that there was no truth to all those rumors about secret Swiss bank accounts, the ones where the Marcos family had supposedly stashed away its plundered billions. He insisted that he was a middle-class guy, with middle-class values -- and a middle-class income. "I'm not rich," he said again and again. So imagine my surprise when, a few days after interviewing Mr. Marcos on the campaign trail last winter (he was defeated in his Senate race in May), I found him relaxing on the powdery white beach of what is without doubt the most luxurious and expensive beach resort in the Philippines: Amanpulo. Mr. Marcos and his wife were living in sybaritic splendor in one of the $500-a-night beachside cottages, while his infant son and a nanny slept in another $500-a-night cottage. He recognized me. "Pretty place," he said, without a trace of caught-in-the-act embarrassment. Yet while I might question Mr. Marcos's truthfulness about his bank balance, I do not question his taste in holidays. Amanpulo is one of those magic destinations in Southeast Asia that defy any common definition of luxury. It is a beach resort so comfortable, so beautiful, so secluded, so culturally and environmentally sensitive, and yet so understated and unstuffy, that you leave it with the fear that no place else will ever quite live up to its standards.

Sure, they say they love Satan and everything, but they're so lax, the only time they put on their black robes and go to coven is Halloween, and even then it's just to see what kind of cars their friends from the country club are driving now and to load up on the free bowlfuls of Milky Ways. title: SUNDAY, October 26, 1995: THE SPORTING LIFE; Before the Fall
description: Oil wrestling is a tradition that has helped define the national character of Turkey for six centuries. Until the inevitable intrusion of soccer, basketball and other Western sports, it was the country's only sport. But for three days each summer, newfangled games are forgotten and all attention focuses on the town of Edirne, where rollicking spectators watch greasy wrestlers lathered with olive oil (the better for reaches to exceed grasps) compete at the Kirkpinar festival. Edirne's glory dates from the Ottoman Empire's first thrust into Europe. As legend has it, a commander, Suleyman Pasha, decamped in a field near the town, and his squad of 40 men began wrestling to pass the time. Whether the warriors used oil is unrecorded, but as they competed, two wrestlers collapsed and died. The two were buried where they fell, and when a spring of clear water spouted from the site, it became known as Kirkpinar, "40 springs," in honor of the young Turks.

title:
BREEDERS' CUP '95;
The Year's Best Jockey? Not an Easy Choice
description: Jerry Bailey has never won an Eclipse Award. Neither has Gary Stevens. After yesterday's Breeders' Cup results at Belmont Park, they remain the two most logical choices for champion jockey. But voters are faced with an exceedingly tough decision, one Bailey made more agonizing by winning two races on a day when Stevens was shut out.

title: Ms. McCormick And Mr. Kalil
description: MaryAnne McCormick, a lobbyist and public policy manager in Washington for Corning Inc., the glassware company, was married yesterday to Thomas Amadeus Kalil, the director of science and technology for the National Economic Council at the White House. The Rev. Merrick Bednar, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Church in Washington.

title: SCHOOLS;When Walking to School Is Perilous
description: Margie Mercurio does not have a full-time job, but because her children are not bused to school, she spends much of her day playing chauffeur. Instead of letting them walk two miles along roads she considers treacherous, Mrs. Mercurio drives her daughter and sons to three schools in Middletown, a sprawling suburb in Monmouth County.

title: STYLE;Get Off My Back
description: I am sashaying down Seventh, the mink just reclaimed from storage, when I hear this otherworldly little voice coming from the collar, which is to say, right into my ear.

title: Long Island Q&A;: Jawn Sandifer;Scholar Who Became a Pioneer
description: THE judicial career of Jawn Sandifer began in 1964, when Mayor Robert F. Wagner appointed him to the New York City Civil Court. He served a total of 28 years on the bench, 10 years as deputy administrative judge of the State Supreme Court.

title: Mayfair's Sublime Putting Gives Him the Lead at Tulsa
description: When you're wielding a magic wand, neither wind nor chill nor greens more slippery than a wet terrazzo floor can keep you from your appointed round. Such was the case today with Billy Mayfair, who made putts from all over Tulsa County -- including one for birdie at the last hole -- to take a three-stroke lead over Brad Bryant, Corey Pavin and Steve Elkington after three rounds of the Tour Championship.

title: Salute to Barbie
description: How to make playing with a Barbie doll politically correct? Put it in the hands of more than 50 artists, architects and designers, and -- after they give it a make-over -- put the results together in a show entitled "Art, Design and Barbie: The Evolution of a Cultural Icon."

title: Alternative Rockers Think Big, Uneasily
description: WHAT HAS CYPRESS Hill been smoking? Millions of fans have a pretty good idea, since the group's leader, B-Real, made himself a virtual spokesrapper for marijuana use on "Cypress Hill" (1991) and its follow-up, "Black Sunday" (1993). Cypress Hill's new album, "III (Temple of Boom)," starts out praising "herb" and goes on to sling synonyms like cheeba, endo, mota, the chronic, sensi, Buddha and a dozen geographical names. The backing tracks are a spaced-out haze of slow, fuzz-covered bass lines and echoing keyboards.

title: DUSTY RIDES AGAIN
description: HE DARTS AROUND HER MANHATTAN HOTEL suite waving a can of Lysol, which she carries in her purse for occasions like this. Dusty Springfield, the 56-year-old pop legend and former convent-school girl, has been caught sneaking a smoke.

title: Helping Women Scale Heights in Business
description: IN today's downsized business world, more work is required of fewer employees. Now more than ever managers are being held accountable for results. To increase their effectiveness, they must accept more responsibility and risk. And, it is more difficult for female managers to take on a strong position of leadership, said Renee Karas, a White Plains consultant who specializes in management training and career development.

An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders for a book. And Bear in Mind (Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest) ALBERT SPEER: HIS BATTLE WITH TRUTH, by Gitta Sereny. (Knopf, $35.) The author, a lifelong student of the Nazi bosses and for years a friend of Speer, examines his stratagems to avoid knowing exactly what it was that he knew. ALL GOD'S CHILDREN: The Bosket Family and the American Tradition of Violence, by Fox Butterfield. (Knopf, $27.50.) A Times correspondent's painful examination of social pathology from generation to generation, always getting worse, told with a novelist's determination to see it whole. CASINO: Love and Honor in Las Vegas, by Nicholas Pileggi. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) The unease and aimlessness of the gangster life, captured fly-on-the-wall fashion and conveyed in the perceptions of the crooks themselves. EDWARD HOPPER: An Intimate Biography, by Gail Levin. (Knopf, $35.) Ms. Levin's sixth book on Hopper only peripherally concerns Hopper's art; it's a nearly flawless account of the life of a great American painter whose temperament, especially in respect of his weirdly long-suffering and combative wife, was simply abominable. HEART: A Memoir, by Lance Morrow. (Warner, $22.95.) A moving work of literal introspection: in the wake of his second heart attack and second bypass operation, Mr. Morrow tries to find out what's really wrong with his life and himself. THE HUSBANDS: An Account of Books 3 and 4 of Homer's "Iliad," by Christopher Logue. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.) A heroic, often brilliant, portion of the author's long-term project of bringing this distant, uncomfortable, alien poem closer to readers of contemporary poetry. LOVING WANDA BEAVER: Novella and Stories, by Alison Baker. (Chronicle, $16.95.) Fine and sturdy Southern Gothic humor for the New Age, where every fate is worse than death and folks put ancho chili on the lime Jell-O and pears. PALIMPSEST: A Memoir, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $27.50.) As Mr. Vidal recalls his first 39 years (1925-64), his abundant self-admiration escapes self-absorption, and many people he did not care for receive at least the tribute of his keen attention. Too bad for them! SAVAGE ART: A Biography of Jim Thompson, by Robert Polito. (Knopf, $30.) Exhaustive research and critical acumen adorn this life of the wildly original (some of his narrators are dead, e.g.) American crime novelist who died in 1977. SAVAGES, by Joe Kane. (Knopf, $25.) A superb report on life among the Huaorani, a virtually intact Amazonian tribe whose resolve to stay as and where they are confronts the resolve of governments and energy companies to pump the earth from under their feet. THE UNCONSOLED, by Kazuo Ishiguro. (Knopf, $25.) This successor to "The Remains of the Day" concerns a pianist who is called to visit a land whose citizens yearn for validation of their culture, which depends on shared understandings of modern musical composition. He can't help.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 15 about a Los Angeles urban renewal project known as A.R. City and about one of its components, the Samitaur Building, misstated their locations within the city. The project is intended for an area of Culver City adjacent to Baldwin Hills, not for South-Central. The Samitaur Building is situated in an unnamed district of Los Angeles between Culver City and Baldwin Hills, a site of riots after the Rodney King verdict in 1992 -- also not in South-Central.

title: Trying to Put the Power Grid On a More or Less Even Keel
description: These days, small wafers of silicon precisely control tens of millions of personal computers. But the electric system that powers those computers -- along with the lights, the telephones and most of the rest of the physical components of the economy -- still lumbers along with technology from the days of manual typewriters and mechanical adding machines.

description: The Power Computing Corporation, the first company to license Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh operating system, said it planned to introduce its newest line of Macintosh clones on Monday. The new Powerwave computers, which feature the fastest Power PC processors, cost between $3,199 and $4,499. The new 604 Power PC processors are manufactured by the International Business Machines Corporation and Motorola Inc. Power Computing, which is based in Austin, is planning to ship 100,000 units by May 1996, Stephen Khang, the founder of the company, said.

title: Higher Education Funds
description: New York is one of only four states putting less state money into higher education this year than two years ago, according to an annual study by the Center for Higher Education at Illinois State University. A sluggish economy and budget cutting by the Pataki administration caused 1995-96 higher education appropriations to drop 4 percent this year compared with 1993-94. This year's expenditures are only 12 percent higher than 10 years ago. For both the 2-year and 10-year period. New York ranks 48th in the nation in growth of state funding for higher education. In both New York and New Jersey, state financing for student aid was down 4 percent from two years ago.

The dead were identified as Curtis Whitting, a senior at the University of Rhode Island, and Chris Stanford of Hackensack.

title: ON PRO FOOTBALL;Hampton Is, and Will Be, Giants History
description: They gave Rodney Hampton the ball three straight times on the opening possession here at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium today. He picked up 5 yards the first time. He got 4 on the next carry. With the third, he gained 2 yards and established the career rushing record for the Giants, moving ahead of Joe Morris's mark of 5,296 yards in eight seasons.

title: The Newest Christian Fiction Injects a Thrill Into Theology
description: Wildlife biologist Steve Benson is alone and unarmed on a moonlit mountainside. He is being hunted. A lizardlike beast the size of a whale lurks nearby. It eats people.

title: Review/Fashion;The Old World via the Bay Area
description: In a study of successful entertainers a few years ago, it was determined that one thing they shared was the chance to develop their skill away from the hubs of their profession. The implication was that creativity was best nurtured away from potentially crushing competition and in an environment conducive to developing an individual point of view.

title: Winners of Whiting Awards
description: Ten writers have received the 1995 Whiting Writers' Awards. The awards, for "outstanding talent and promise," are worth $30,000 each and are distributed annually by the Mrs. Giles Whiting Foundation, created through a bequest by Flora E. Whiting.

title: Patents; The battle for office machine after-products, like ink and facsimile paper, moves to the courts.
description: BUSINESSES and consumers alike bargain hunt when it comes to buying office machines. But they often do not factor in the later costs of replacing broken parts or buying perishable components like facsimile paper or ink cartridges.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Languid Melodies, Leaping Triads
description: Otto Klemperer diligently produced seven symphonies; Wilhelm Furtwangler labored over Brucknerian orations; Felix Weingartner penned a dozen operas. Whether or not their works reverberated into history, conductors once deepened their involvement in musical life by strong devotion to composition.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Defense Does It As Giants Prevail
description: There has not been much to bring a smile to the face of Giants Coach Dan Reeves recently. Then, late in the second quarter tonight, came a 57-yard pass from quarterback Dave Brown to wide receiver Mike Sherrard for a spectacular touchdown. As Brown walked off the field, Reeves gave a half hug to the quarterback he had benched only two weeks ago. The man who is usually stone-faced on the sideline even laughed.

title: Drastic Remedies in Quebec
description: A new country could be born on New York's northern border if Quebec's voters decide today to separate from Canada. Polls suggest at least an even chance that the separatist side could win a narrow majority in today's referendum. Americans and their Government are duty bound to respect whatever Quebecers democratically decide and try to make it work for the best. But there is no mistaking Washington's strong preference for continued Canadian unity. Separation could complicate economic, political and human relations across the St. Lawrence.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Mexicans Reach New Pact On Wages and Prices The Mexican Government signed a new agreement with labor and business intended to control prices, limit salaries and cut public spending, in an attempt to restore stability and economic growth. The pact does not include any controls on exchange rates, an issue of concern to both foreign and domestic investors who have been hurt severely by instability in the peso-dollar exchange rate. [ Page D2. ] Praxair, a large producer of industrial gases, offered $2.1 billion for CBI Industries, the world's largest producer of carbon dioxide. Praxair, which was spun off from Union Carbide in 1992, said it would pay $32 a share, a 59 percent premium over the $20.125 closing price of CBI shares on Friday. Praxair made public its offer after six months of unsuccessful talks with CBI, which said it would review the offer. [ D2. ] Budget Conferees Gather Republican leaders in the House and Senate said they would meet today to start ironing out differences in the budget bills passed last week. President Clinton has said he will veto the bill, and Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska said the Republicans should negotiate with Congressional Democrats instead of focusing on Mr. Clinton. [ A1. ] Leeson to Return to Singapore Nicholas W. Leeson, the futures trader accused of ruining Barings of London, said he would return to Singapore to face forgery and fraud charges, ending his fight to prevent extradition from Germany, where he was arrested in March. [ D2. ] Good News for Insurers The cost of environmental cleanups is not quite the disaster for insurance companies that was once feared, a number of studies have found, in part because claims for restoration of natural resources, like lakes polluted by acid rain, have not materialized. [ D2. ] Cable Prices Climb Prices for cable television service have resumed their rise, even as Congress is completing legislation that would unfetter the industry. [ D7. ] All the Nostalgia, All the Time Hoping to capitalize on the success of its Nick at Nite cable channel, MTV Networks plans to offer a cable channel early next year that is devoted to nostalgic television shows. [ D7. ] Sybase Seeks a Turnaround Sybase is hoping that its latest version of its SQL Server will restore its competitive edge -- and its earnings growth. [ D4. ] Forget the Aston Martin BMW of North America and its new advertising agency have developed an aggressive campaign that features Pierce Brosnan, who as James Bond drives a BMW in the latest 007 film. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [ D10. ] Turning On the Lights Experiments are under way to demonstrate that chunks of silicon can be used to run the nation's electrical power network much the way a computer is operated. [ D5. ] When Systems Crash The Food and Drug Administration has spent $13 million on a computer system to help it identify tainted food and medicine from abroad, but the General Accounting Office said that the system doesn't work. title: Don't Raise the Taxi Fare
description: New York City's taxi industry has asked for a fare increase in order to raise the earnings and the quality of taxi drivers. The Taxi and Limousine Commission seems inclined to grant the request after a public hearing on Nov. 9. Too bad. A new increase will only do what past increases have done -- drive medallion prices higher -- without improving the earnings and quality of drivers. There is another way to get better drivers who will earn better income.

title: Essay;Dole vs. Powell: California Dreamin'
description: Let's assume Colin Powell declares his Republican candidacy in two weeks and takes a pass on the rightist Iowa caucuses. Let's assume New Hampshire independents register Republican to help Powell win there in February.

title: A Cautionary Tale Of a School's Woes
description: The story of a troubled school in the South Bronx is a cautionary tale for New York City as it tries to make sick schools well. Everybody wants that. But as Middle School 115 is learning, one person's advance is another's retreat. The hard and unanswered question at 115 is whether teachers can have their promising reforms and their old contract, too.

title: Discount books in Britain could reshape the industry.
description: TWENTY-FIVE percent off!" boasts the sign on the High Street bookshop, above an enormous pile of books. It is a common sight in the United States, which is why it is so startling to learn that before Oct. 1, bookstores in Britain were forbidden to sell books at reduced prices.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;James Bond opts for a BMW, while the car maker takes a new image out for a test  drive.
description: FROM cinemas to cyberspace and from the NBC late-night lineup to the 1996 Olympics, BMW of North America and its new agency are racing at autobahn speeds to accomplish a mission that might confound even James Bond.

title: City to Lend Phones and Alarms To Protect Battered Women
description: New York City officials said yesterday that they would lend cellular telephones and household alarm systems to 10 women on the Upper West Side as part of a pilot program to evaluate methods of combating domestic violence.

title: HORSE RACING;Bill Mott Is Nearing Training's Pinnacle
description: Jerry Bailey, after winning the last three Breeders' Cup Classics and four of the last five, considered the inevitable question: How do you do it? And he laughed and replied: "Fast horses."

title: A Talent Cradled in London And Nourished by New York
description: In 1993, Patrick Stewart went to London to perform his one-man version of "A Christmas Carol" for the hometown crowd. In New York, his performances of the work over the two previous Christmas holidays had been sold-out sensations, the audiences so thrilled at watching him act out an entire Dickens novel that they laughed even before the punch lines.

title: Fish Dealers Tell of Slump In Business
description: In the dense darkness before dawn, Herbie Ackerman peered gloomily at the mounds of 100-pound crates of unsold perch and salmon stacked in front of his Fulton Fish Market stall.

title: America's Favorite Virtual Pastimes
description: While most of America watched the the World Series last week courtesy of live televised images, a number of technologically adroit teen-agers and adults managed their own simulated version of the series -- a kind of electronic rotisserie league -- choosing their own lineups and plays and watching a virtual game.

title: ON BASEBALL;Braves' Ring Cycle Ends With Series Victory
description: For five years, the Atlanta Braves won more games than any team, collected more Cy Young Awards, represented the best modern-day model of a finely tuned baseball organization. They had almost everything, except a world championship and the redemption that would bring.

title: A Bigger Tent for the G.O.P.
description: The stereotype of Republican primary voters as overwhelmingly right wing and anti-abortion was not supported in a New York Times/CBS News poll. Page A11.

description: In the Greek tragedy that murder, intrigue and betrayal have recently made of Mexican politics, Manuel Camacho Solis is both hero and villain, a central character who dodges all attempts to kill him off.

description: American officials said today that they suspect Bosnian Serb soldiers may have tried to destroy evidence that they killed thousands of Muslim men seized in and around the town of Srebrenica in July.

title: METRO MATTERS;Success, and Trouble, in Turning Around a Troubled Bronx School
description: THIS is the unfinished story of a troubled school in the South Bronx, a cautionary tale for the city and the new Schools Chancellor as they try to make sick schools well. Everybody wants that. But as Middle School 115 is learning, one person's advance is another's retreat. The hard and unanswered question at 115 is whether teachers can have their promising reforms and their old contract, too.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Escape, Yearning And Return
description: The first thing surprising about "Drawn From Memory," tonight's "American Playhouse" presentation on PBS at 10, is that it opens with a quotation from Oscar Wilde: "Children begin by loving their parents. As they grow older they judge them; sometimes they forgive them." The second thing is to discover that this hourlong autobiography is an animated film.

title: Subway Fire Kills 300 in Caucasus Capital
description: Rescue workers recovered about 300 bodies today from the wreckage of a subway train that caught fire Saturday in Baku, the capital of Azerbaijan, officials said.

title: San Carlos de Bariloche Journal;In Nazi's Hiding Place, the Stain Won't Wash Away
description: Nestled in Argentina's snow-capped Andes, overlooking a vast pristine lake, this picturesque ski town has long been a favorite of Latin American jet-setters. No wonder it was chosen as the site for the recent annual meeting of presidents from Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking countries.

title: Al Schreiber, 63, Who Headed Supermarket Company, Is Dead
description: Al Schreiber, a New York supermarket executive who was a former chairman of Maimonides Medical Center and a philanthropist, died on Saturday at St. Rose's Home in Manhattan. He was 63 and lived in Mill Basin, Brooklyn.

title: A Matter of Trust: Two Titans of Charity Battle Over Millions
description: In an office on East 22d Street, a charity established by a few "friends of the poor" 150 years ago today spends about $8 million a year for the needy. Now known as the Community Service Society of New York, it is a titan in the small world of New York charities, with an endowment of $84 million.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will break ground this morning for a $41 million Veterans Memorial Home. The new building, to be completed by the fall of 1998, will replace a state-operated veterans home whose oldest section was built in 1932. SUSAN JO KELLER

title: Man Accused of Burning Wife
description: A Gloucester County man has been charged with dousing his wife with kerosene and then setting her on fire during a domestic dispute at their home. The man, William R. Johnston, 40, has been charged with attempted murder and was in the Gloucester County Jail yesterday on a $250,000 full-cash bail.

title: Pay Dispute on 'Megan's Law'
description: Since some lawyers have a problem with "Megan's Law," the Senate Judiciary Committee will meet today to try to sort things out. The law provides for community notification about the presence of certain sex offenders who have served their sentences. Lawyers fear that they will be forced to work without pay to file appeals for those who cannot afford an attorney.

title: Police Officer Says He Lied On the Stand
description: A crucial police witness for the Mollen Commission has admitted he lied under oath in several criminal court cases and has agreed to resign from the force rather than be prosecuted for perjury by the Manhattan District Attorney.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Those Freewheeling Guys Again
description: At first it's not easy to tell if David Shiner or Bill Irwin is the taller one. Both are of average height. Yet each has the magical ability to grow half a foot one minute and, in the next, to shrink into his suit without seeming to be seriously compacted. Ordinary men have feet of clay; these guys seem made of Silly Putty. That's just one of the talents that delights audiences at the Ambassador Theater, where "Fool Moon," their 1993 Broadway mime revue, opened its return engagement last night.

title: Study Rates Health Plans In 5 Areas Around U.S.
description: An independent research group has identified the health maintenance organizations with the highest levels of satisfied members in five areas around the nation in surveys conducted as part of new efforts by employers to determine which H.M.O.'s offer the highest-quality care.

description: The baseball season, which could not have started more badly, redeemed itself at the end. The playoffs -- a bit too drawn-out for our tastes -- nevertheless produced magnetic moments. Not the least of these was the series between the New York Yankees and the Seattle Mariners, an unforgettable duel that gave Yankee fans a welcome respite from the tiresome grievances of George Steinbrenner and gave Seattle fans hope that their troubled franchise would stay put.

title: MACROMEDIA'S MULTIMEDIA TOOL FOR INTERNET
description: Macromedia Inc., which develops software for animators and graphic artists, demonstrated a technology yesterday to let developers create interactive material, including animation and sound, for the World Wide Web. Sun Microsystems Inc. has a competitive programming language, Java. Macromedia's Shockwave requires no programming and is intended to help build home pages on the Web with motion and sound like television. Shockwave's multimedia material can be converted to run on the Web using a point-and-click program. Macromedia's stock soared $6 a share yesterday, to $36.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: MAXTOR CONSIDERS NEW TAKEOVER BID BY HYUNDAI
description: The Maxtor Corporation said yesterday that it was considering a new takeover proposal by the Hyundai Electronics Industries Company, which on Sunday raised its bid to acquire Maxtor to $6.15 a share. Last week Maxtor, a maker of computer disk drives based in San Jose, Calif., turned down an unsolicited bid by Hyundai of $5.15 a share, or about $273 million, for the Maxtor shares it did not already own. Maxtor officials were not available for comment on the new bid, but an estimate based on the number of shares for the first offer valued the offer at about $326 million. Maxtor said Hyundai, based in South Korea, is its largest shareholder with a roughly 37 percent stake. Maxtor's stock rose 43.8 cents, to $5.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: RTZ Will Sell Division
description: The RTZ Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its U.S. Silica division to D. George Harris & Associates, a New York-based chemicals and minerals company, for $120 million in cash and up to $20 million in future payments. RTZ said it was selling U.S. Silica, based in Berkeley Springs, W.Va., as part of its strategy to shed regional producers in favor of international market leaders. U.S. Silica had sales of $115 million last year and employs 725 people. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: The Powell Shake-Up
description: Pat Buchanan thought and he fumed and he called Colin Powell the meanest name he could conjure. This general everyone is so crazy about, he said, is nothing but a "Bill Clintonite." Mayor Rudolph Giuliani of New York was more analytical in his comments on the David Brinkley show. He said that Mr. Powell's entry into the Republican Presidential primaries would broaden the base and philosophy of the party. He is right, of course, and that is what has made Mr. Buchanan so testy and Bob Dole's handlers so resistant to an open G.O.P. primary in New York. The last thing Senator Al D'Amato and Gov. George Pataki want is for their heavyweight champ to get in the ring with the number-one contender.

title: Torn Hometown Resents the Premier
description: In this town of aluminum smelters and pulp paper mills, a small but potentially significant majority voted for a sovereign Quebec today, mirroring the broader support of the French-speaking towns and villages and articulating a resentment that Prime Minister Jean Chretien cannot afford to ignore.

title: Breeding Plan Helps Black Footed Ferrets In Making Comeback
description: Biologists at the Sybille Wildlife Research Center, where most of the world's remaining black-footed ferrets are housed, worry constantly about disease. Visitors must leave their street clothes behind and, after a shower and shampoo, don blue coveralls, a surgical mask and shoes that are periodically dunked in disinfectant.

In an astonishingly brief time, insects, earthworms, corals, sponges, mollusks and animals with rudimentary backbones -- all the major body plans of today -- made their first appearance in what is known as the Cambrian Explosion.

description: The Swiss biological and chemicals company Ciba-Geigy A.G. said yesterday that it was planning to spin off its Mettler Toledo division, a leader in weighing technology, through an initial public offering. A Ciba spokesman said plans to list stock ofMettler Toledo in Switzerland and possibly other countries were at an early stage. Analysts estimated the value of Mettler Toledo at around 1 billion Swiss francs ($875 million), but noted that very little is known about its accounts. (Reuters)

title: Company Briefs
description: PRINCIPAL HEALTH CARE INC., a privately held, managed health care company in Rockville, Md., agreed to acquire Admar Group Inc., Santa Ana, Calif., which administers managed health care services, for about $20 million in cash.

title: Readers of Romances Make No Apology
description: To the Editor:

title: Unisys Appoints Executive
description: The Unisys Corporation, the computer maker, named Lawrence C. Russell as president of its information services division and executive vice president of the company today. Mr. Russell, 57, had been an officer and management consultant at the First Manhattan Consulting Group, where he helped banks build and interpret customer data bases. Unisys's chairman and chief executive, James A. Unruh, has been acting head of the information services business. Earlier this month, Unisys said it planned to split into three businesses: information services, computer systems and global support services.

title: Hasn't the Day Arrived to Collect Tolls on New York's Bridges?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Sues Abortion Protesters In Test of Clinic Access Law
description: Under a new law that prohibits protesters from blocking access to abortion clinics, a suit was filed yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan against a retired Roman Catholic bishop and a Franciscan friar who sat down in front of cars at a clinic in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: 76ers' Maxwell Enters Plea in Drug Charge
description: The Philadelphia 76ers' VERNON MAXWELL pleaded no contest yesterday to a misdemeanor marijuana charge, stemming from an incident in Houston over the summer when the police stopped his car. A judge recessed the case until November so he could review Maxwell's probation department reports. Maxwell was cut by the Houston Rockets in June after he left the team during its playoff run. If convicted, Maxwell could face up to a $2,000 fine and 180 days in jail. (AP)

title: Terry Southern, Screenwriter, Is Dead at 71
description: Terry Southern, a novelist and screenwriter whose credits included "Dr. Strangelove" and "Easy Rider," two films that crystallized the anger and unease of the 1960's, died on Sunday at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 71 and lived in East Canaan, Conn.

title: New York Outlines a New Policy On Seizure of Buildings for Taxes
description: In the first major revision of New York City's housing policy in almost two decades, the Giuliani administration announced yesterday that it was ending the city's role as the landlord of last resort.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Return With Elbows And Attitude This Season
description: As Charles Oakley awaits his suspension and Anthony Mason recalls the medieval years of the franchise -- "We don't throw 'bows, we respond to them" -- one thing is clear: The much-advertised ballet season at Madison Square Garden has been canceled. It's back at Lincoln Center, far away from Oakley's forearms and Mason's elbows.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the listing of new equity issues in Business Day yesterday misidentified the lead underwriter for a preferred stock offering by the Cablevision Systems Corporation. It is Bear, Stearns & Company. (Merrill Lynch is the lead underwriter for a debt offering by Cablevision.)

title: Gearing Up for Halloween
description: Helicopters patrolled the skies, extra firefighters were on duty and 3,000 volunteers fanned out through Camden last night, trying to prevent vandals from setting Halloween Eve fires.

title: BPA to Expand Auditing to the Web
description: BPA International, which audits the circulation of business and consumer publications, plans to expand its auditing to measure use of sites on the World Wide Web belonging to publications whose circulations it also measures.

title: Survey Says Big Investors Are Not So Silent
description: When disgruntled shareholders take on corporate management -- recently at Archer-Daniels-Midland, Kmart and W. R. Grace, for instance -- just a few, like the California Public Employees' Retirement System or individual investors, seem to lead the charge. But a new survey of nearly 240 large investors shows that shareholder activism is much more widespread.

title: Thomas Murphy, Police Head And Prosecutor of Hiss, 89
description: Thomas F. Murphy, whose career in law and law enforcement brought him to the prosecutor's table in the Alger Hiss case, to the office of New York City Police Commissioner and ultimately to the Federal bench, died on Thursday at Noble Horizons, a nursing home in Salisbury, Conn. Mr. Murphy, who formerly lived in Sharon, Conn., was 89.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the possible demise of Pahaquarry, N.J., (population 6) reversed the names of municipalities involved in a 1952 merger that created the city of Vineland, N.J. They were Landis Township and Vineland Borough, not Landis Borough and Vineland Township.

title: The Power Mask
description: At the Halloween U.S.A. store in a nearby mall, my 9-year-old son, Gabriel, was looking for a mask to wear for trick or treating. We tried on hats and masks together and examined every costume on the rack. In the end, we spent almost two hours in the store. An anthropologist in an exotic site, I found myself scribbling field notes in a pocket pad.

title: Justices Explore Elusive Meaning of a Word That Seems So Simple
description: This was not one of those Supreme Court arguments that deploy the specialized vocabulary of the law, leaving casual spectators in the dark as the lawyers and the Justices carry on in a language of their own. Rather, a case argued before the Justices today turned on the meaning of a common, everyday, three-letter and -- this being the Supreme Court -- deceptively simple English word: use.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League BALTIMORE ORIOLES -- Signed Davey Johnson, manager, to a three-year contract.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Saturday, headlined "Questions of Justice in Okinawa," misstated recent charges against three American servicemen in Okinawa in some editions. The servicemen have been charged with the abduction and rape of a 12-year-old schoolgirl, not with rape and murder.

title: Free Speech Holds For Tobacco Ads Too
description: To the Editor:
