title: Corrections
description: A picture caption and credit in Business Day on Oct. 21 about the construction of the George Washington Bridge between Manhattan and New Jersey misstated the date. The photograph was taken in 1931, not 1935.

title: Sports of The Times;The Knicks Start Off On Bad Foot
description: FOR the Knicks, the new season will begin with consummate ignorance. One of their best players will not suit up. This is the starting forward appropriately nicknamed Oak, since his head sometimes appears made of wood.

title: Levitt Puts Aside a Change on Footnotes
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that he planned to put on hold a proposal to allow corporations to eliminate footnotes from the annual reports they send to shareholders.

title: Workers' Insurance to Cost Less
description: The median rate of workers' compensation insurance is going to drop next year, the first decrease since 1989. Elizabeth Randall, the Acting Insurance Commissioner, said yesterday that the 3.8 percent decrease would save 180,000 New Jersey businesses about $85 million a year, The Associated Press said. Ms. Randall also announced that the maximum weekly benefit would increase to $480, from $469, with the minimum benefit rising to $128, from $125.

title: No Headline
description: We've got a big environmental murder going on." DR. ROBERT E. JOHANNES, an American marine ecologist based in Tasmania, referring to the destruction of corals. [A1:6.]

title: A Food Fad's Ripple Effect On Reefs of Pacific: Cyanide
description: When diners in Hong Kong's famous waterfront restaurants savor fish picked live from a glass tank and steamed, a popular custom there and elsewhere in Asia, the price of the meal does not include what a new investigation says is a dreadful hidden cost: rampant destruction of the biologically richest marine ecosystems in the world.

title: ResultsPlus
description: N.H.L. Sakic Pushes Avalanche Past Stars

title: Swarming Halloween Bugs Eat Aphids, Haunt Humans
description: THE Halloween ladybugs are swarming -- in numbers suitable for a Hitchcock film. They came from Asia, to Louisiana, to Georgia, and now they are in New York. In fact, throughout the Northeast, houses have been invaded by hundreds or thousands of the orange and black pill-size beetles, causing the human inhabitants to rush to their telephones in alarm.

title: Bruins' Oates Is Out With a Knee Injury
description: The Boston Bruins' scoring leader, ADAM OATES, is expected to be sidelined two to four weeks with a right knee injury.

title: Coca-Cola Project For Cliff Freeman
description: The Coca-Cola Company has broadened its agency roster by naming Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York to handle an undisclosed project. The company also said yesterday that it would award an additional assignment to a shop already on its roster, Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore.

title: Real Politics: Why Suharto Is In and Castro Is Out
description: Fidel Castro never got so much as a smile or a handshake when he stepped into the same reception with President Clinton last week; the Secret Service deftly kept them from coming face to face.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Rappers Making Notoriety Pay Off
description: After all their skirmishes with those who want them silenced, rappers have learned at least one thing: how to make notoriety pay off. The politicians and public figures who pressed the Warner Music Group to dissolve its ties with Interscope Records have been, in essence, the warm-up act for "Dogg Food" by Tha Dogg Pound, which will be released today. Stores have ordered 1.7 million copies in advance.

title: 2 Media Giants Seen Forming A Rival to ESPN
description: In an effort to become major competitors to ESPN, Tele-Communications Inc. and the News Corporation are negotiating the formation of a new global sports network, two people with knowledge of the discussions said yesterday.

title: And One Who Tries to Work Things Out
description: Call Representative Sue Myrick a moderate and she immediately bristles. But the North Carolina Republican has emerged as one of the few moderating influences in the House freshman class, even though she holds a wide range of very conservative ideas.

title: HOCKEY;You Can't Score if You Don't Shoot
description: Just shoot, baby.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Halloween Parade tonight in Greenwich Village, which begins at 7 P.M., Sixth Avenue will be closed beginning at 6 P.M. from Spring to 22d Streets.

title: Corrections
description: A film review on Friday about "Harlem Diary: Nine Voices of Resilience" quoted Nikki Matos, an 18-year-old mother, incorrectly. Speaking of her worries about her infant son, Ms. Matos says in the film, "I gave birth to an endangered species" -- not "a dangerous species."

title: Filion Pleads Not Guilty to Fix Charges
description: One of harness racing's top stars pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that he fixed races at Yonkers Raceway.

title: People
description: * Adelaide Horton was named to the new position of president and chief operating officer at Wells Rich Greene BDDP Communications, New York, part of BDDP Worldwide. She previously held a similar position at TBWA Chiat/Day East, New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group. * Bill Stenton was named senior partner and executive creative director at Ogilvy & Mather Los Angeles, a unit of the WPP Group, succeeding Robert Chandler, who left to join the Seiniger Advertising Group, Beverly Hills, Calif., as the creative director. Mr. Stenton was previously a senior vice president and creative director at Ketchum Advertising Los Angeles, a unit of Ketchum Communications. * Bruce Martin, managing director at Leo Burnett/Bangkok, part of the Leo Burnett Co., was promoted to the new position of regional operations director for the Europe/Middle East/Africa region, based in London.

title: When It's Dangerous to Sing
description: It's not all glamour being in a rock band. Just ask Blake Schwarzenbach, who suffered through some bizarre torments when Jawbreaker, the California pop-punk band he sings and plays guitar in, performed with a similarly named band, Jawbox, on Friday night at Irving Plaza.

description: To the Editor:

title: Observer;From the Bad Place
description: Little Old Lady is inside her comfy home. Little does she realize what trouble has just ridden into town. No, it's not the Clantons, not the Daltons, not even the James brothers.

title: BOXING;Tyson Offers 3 Rounds and a Few Words
description: In a nine-minute flurry of speed, violence and craft, Mike Tyson held his first public workout in more than four years today.

title: On My Mind;Why Powell Should Run
description: Except for a relative handful of people, Americans have a great deal to gain from a Colin Powell run for the Presidency, and nothing to lose that is not worth losing.

title: Ad Pitches That Can't Be Fast-Forwarded
description: "High Stakes in Cyberspace" does not pretend to be a road map of the information highway. Instead, tonight's edition of "Frontline" provides a cautionary guide to some of the money-making incentives behind interactivity, virtual reality, digital technology and other fancily titled and much-touted tourist traps along the way.

title: The Power Mask
description: At the Halloween U.S.A. store in a nearby mall, my 9-year-old son, Gabriel, was looking for a mask to wear for trick or treating. We tried on hats and masks together and examined every costume on the rack. In the end, we spent almost two hours in the store. An anthropologist in an exotic site, I found myself scribbling field notes in a pocket pad.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Sterling Multimedia Computers, New York, to Korey Kay & Partners, New York, to handle its account, previously handled in-house. The billings were estimated at $8 million.

title: MERGERS FOR YEAR APPROACH RECORD
description: This year's wave of mergers and acquisitions in the United States is poised to set a record, continuing a feverish pace of global business consolidation that during 1994 and 1995 could see as many companies swallowed up as during the last three years of the 1980's, the decade of the takeover.

title: AMERICA ONLINE UNVEILS ITS INTERNET NAVIGATOR
description: America Online Inc. unveiled its Internet service, Global Network Navigator, yesterday. In August, America Online delayed the relaunch of the service because of the release of the Microsoft Corporation's Windows 95. In a statement America Online said the service is aimed at the segment of on-line consumers who seek full-feature, Internet-only access and the growing number of publishers interested in enhancing their presence on the Web. America Online said pricing for Global Network Navigator provides consumers with free unlimited use for the first month. Then, a monthly fee of $14.95 covers 20 hours of use. Each additional hour costs $1.95. America Online's stock rose $5.125 yesterday, to $79.375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: The Volpe Method: Perfection at the Met, or Else
description: Joseph Volpe had shed his scowl and was almost smiling. Nancy Reagan and le tout New York had turned out for the season opening of the Metropolitan Opera, the evening's star bill of Placido Domingo, Renee Fleming and James Morris had joined the black-tie benefactors for Champagne, caviar and quail on the Grand Tier, and the new Met Titles had flickered so flawlessly across the plush crimson seat backs that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani threatened to commandeer them for his State of the City speech.

title: TENNIS;A Family Tradition at Age 14
description: After 10 years of practice and a harrowing 15-hour trip through stormy skies, Serena Williams, the last of the 14-year-olds to sneak onto the women's tennis circuit, touched down at an obscure tournament over the weekend and, ostensibly without the blessing of her parents or the WTA Tour, began her professional career.

description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Sect Tried to Buy U.S. Arms Technology, Senator Says
description: A Japanese sect accused of releasing lethal nerve gas in a Tokyo subway made extensive efforts in the United States, Russia and Australia to buy materials for nuclear and chemical weapons, including laser technology that the United States refuses to sell to suspected terrorist countries, Senator Sam Nunn said today.

title: COLLEGE SOCCER REPORT
description: Big East

title: Gilbert Acquires XEL
description: Gilbert Associates Inc. said today that it had acquired the XEL Corporation for $30 million in cash. Gilbert may also make additional payments for the company, a maker of telecommunications equipment in Aurora, Colo., based on XEL's projected earnings.

title: Taxis Go Suburban
description: K-Mart is in New York City, and so is Pizza Hut. No wonder that another mainstay of life outside the five boroughs -- sport utility vehicles and mini-vans -- are on their way to becoming a standard of the taxi fleet. A Ford Explorer and two Honda Odysseys are expected to begin test runs today and could be common on city streets in a year.

title: Q&A
description: Mammoth Meat Q. I heard about explorers eating frozen mammoth. What was it like?

title: Pequots' Foxwood Casino
description: PLAYER: The Mashantucket Pequot Indian Tribe, Ledyard, Conn. PRODUCER: Robinson & Cole, Hartford, and Direct Response, Tolland, Conn. SCRIPT: Foxwoods -- the world's most successful casino. But that's only part of the story. The Mashantucket Pequots' Foxwoods Resort and Casino has become one of Connecticut's largest employers, providing jobs to over 10,000 people, strengthening thousands of additional jobs throughout Connecticut, while purchasing over $1 billion in construction, goods and services from large and small businesses and contributing over $300 million to the state. A success story born in the woods of Eastern Connecticut. Coming soon to the the city of Bridgeport: a new world-class casino, bringing over 9,000 new jobs to Connecticut. Mashantucket Pequots, committed to Connecticut's future and Connecticut's people. VISUAL: The commercial opens with an aerial view of Foxwoods, then cuts to 17 images of workers. After another scenic shot of Foxwoods, it cuts to a bleak shot of the Bridgeport skyline, followed by an artist's rendition of the proposed casino. It ends with a construction worker on a steel beam, accompanied by the tribe's logo. ACCURACY: The commercial accurately states the economic contributions Foxwoods has made. Its assumptions about the future in Bridgeport, however, are subject to debate. The ad says flatly that a casino will open soon, without acknowledging that the plan faces an uphill battle in the Legislature and that construction would take more than three years. Some legislators have questioned the claim that the casino will mean 9,000 jobs. SCORECARD: Facing intense opposition in the legislature, the tribe is trying to take the debate outside the Capitol and use Foxwoods's accomplishments to encourage support for the Bridgeport proposal. Such image-building advs are common at the start of electoral and legislative campaigns. But it may be too late to mobilize support to influence the Legislature.

title: Fujitsu and Sega Plan Computer Network
description: Fujitsu Ltd. and Sega Enterprises Inc. will set up a computer network offering on-line video games and shopping services that users of Sega's home video player can gain access to via their televisions. The link is the latest move by Sega to bring it closer to the personal computer world.

title: 'Indiscretions' Closing
description: "Indiscretions," a revival of the 1938 play "Les Parents Terribles" by Jean Cocteau, is to close after Saturday evening's performance at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, 243 West 47th Street, Manhattan. The Saturday evening performance of the play, directed by Sean Mathias, will be its 221st regular performance; it had 28 previews.

title: Q&A
description: Mammoth Meat Q. I heard about explorers eating frozen mammoth. What was it like?

title: Icahn and LeBow Seek a Spinoff of Nabisco Food Unit
description: Announcing that they now jointly own 4.8 percent of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, Bennett S. LeBow and Carl C. Icahn said yesterday that they would ask the company's shareholders to demand an immediate spinoff of the Nabisco Holdings Corporation, completely splitting the company's food business from its tobacco operations.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: GETTING INTO CO-OPS: THE MONEY BIAS Before a New Yorker can experience the ambiguous joys of co-op life, there is the matter of getting in: an effort that has always tended to be unpleasant, intrusive and exclusionary. But in these days of co-op angst, as the market struggles warily in the wake of the bankruptcies and defaults of the early 1990's, there is widespread agreement that the admissions process has become more onerous. [Page A1.]

title: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK;49ers' Injuries Hurt More Than Loss
description: The 49ers (5-3) have slipped two games behind the Cowboys (7-1) in the quest for home-field advantage in the National Football Conference playoffs. The wheels on the Super Bowl champions have fallen off.

title: Giuliani Urging Powell To Seek Spot on Ballot
description: In a continuing quest to crack open a Republican Presidential primary sealed by his political rivals, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday urged Gen. Colin L. Powell to embark on the obstacle course toward a spot on the New York State Republican ballot.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Esiason Is No. 3,Without The Bullet
description: Boomer Esiason is one angry quarterback and still a third-string quarterback at that.

title: JOHNSON CONTROLS AGREES TO BUY ROTH FRERES
description: Johnson Controls Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a majority stake in Roth Freres S.A., a French auto-interior maker, for about $175 million to $200 million. Johnson Controls would own 75 percent of Roth Freres, which expects 1995 sales of $600 million. The deal is expected to close in late November. Johnson Controls, based in Milwaukee, makes automotive seating, interiors and batteries. The companies have been joint-venture partners since 1988.

title: OUR TOWNS;A Parents Group in Pound Ridge Wrestles the Devil for Halloween
description: THIS town was built for trick or treating. It boasts all the classic fright-night ingredients. There are deep woods to run past, a few dark Victorians no one seems to live in, and more than a few monstrous mansions, cloaked by wide-limbed pin oaks and wrought-iron fences, that could be home to the likes of Count Dracula and Dr. Frankenstein.

title: No Headline

title: King Trial Heading Into Final Stages
description: The insurance-fraud trial of the boxing promoter DON KING is winding down, the judge confirmed yesterday when he told the jury the Government might rest its case today. United States District Judge LAWRENCE MCKENNA told the jurors the defense case might be completed as early as next week, leaving them to decide whether King is guilty of nine counts of mail fraud. If convicted, King could face up to five years in prison on each of the nine counts. (AP)

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;She Has an Ear for Slang and an Eye for Trouble
description: IN THE CUT By Susanna Moore 180 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $21.

title: NETSCAPE CUTS PRICES ON ITS INTERNET SOFTWARE
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation said yesterday that it had cut prices as much as 57 percent on some Internet server software because of a more competitive market. Its server software is used to publish and relay information on the Internet. The company, based in Mountain View, Calif., is known for its browsing software but plans to get most of its profits from the more expensive server software and said it wanted to speed up acceptance of its servers to lock in its position in the market. Netscape's shares gained $7, to $88.50, in Nasdaq trading yesterday.

title: Small Group of Doctors Supports Concept of Assisting in Suicides
description: For the first time since Dr. Jack Kevorkian began his campaign for doctor-assisted suicide in 1990, a small group of medical practitioners came forward today to endorse the concept publicly and to work on guidelines to determine how it could be medically and ethically carried out.

title: Talk With Farrakhan
description: The leaders of American Jewish groups should drop their failed boycott of Louis Farrakhan and take up his offer of dialogue.

title: Chess
description: By beating Jeroen Piket, 26, the 43-year-old Jan Timman proves he's still the old Dutch master.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Television section on Sunday about the "Masterpiece Theater" production "The Choir" misstated an acting credit. The role of Edward VIII in the television movie "Edward and Mrs. Simpson" was played by Edward Fox, not by his brother James.

title: TV SPORTS;For Ebersol: Just Another Game of the Week
description: Only four months ago, Dick Ebersol savaged baseball for being a double-dealing partner in The Baseball Network, and vowed not to deal with Bad Buddy Selig until the next millennium. The NBC Sports president raged that baseball had gone back on a promise to extend TBN's term with its partners, NBC and ABC, because the 1994 strike kept itfrom meeting its financial targets.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the listing of new equity issues in Business Day yesterday misidentified the lead underwriter for a preferred stock offering by the Cablevision Systems Corporation. It is Bear, Stearns & Company. (Merrill Lynch is the lead underwriter for a debt offering by Cablevision.)

title: Levy Won't Interfere With Buffalo Staff
description: Buffalo Bills Coach MARV LEVY, who watched his team lose two straight while recovering from prostate cancer surgery, will have little input until he fully returns to the team. Levy said yesterday that he was eager to return to the Bills but did not want to disturb the jobs of the acting head coach, ELIJAH PITTS, and Buffalo's other assistants. Levy is expected to miss at least another week.

title:
BASEBALL;
. . . And the Home of the Braves
description: Ted Turner was sedately waving to the estimated crowd of 600,000 lining Peachtree Street. His wife, Jane Fonda, was tomahawk chopping frantically with both arms. Then both looked down from atop an Atlanta fire engine and gave a thumbs-up sign to a fan holding a sign that read "Keep Fred."

title: Artillery Shell Is Found
description: A construction crew digging into reclaimed land near the World Trade Center came upon a rare find yesterday: an artillery shell that had apparently lain buried in landfill for decades.

title: Ruling to Bar Russian Party Brings Outcry
description: Outrage grew today over the Russian Central Election Commission's decision to ban the nation's leading liberal party from the Dec. 17 parliamentary elections, as politicians from every part of the political spectrum demanded that the decision be reversed.

title: Latin Rock at Radio City
description: It's hard not to imagine, sitting in the middle of thousands of adulatory fans from across Latin America, that the success of the group Mana suggests a cultural sea change.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;The Bears Learn To Like Mondays
description: Bad luck is all the Chicago Bears usually have on Monday night. Tonight, they finally got the break they needed.

title: Pequots Do Their Bidding on the Small Screen
description: The Mashantucket Pequot Indians stepped up their efforts today to overcome political opposition to their proposal to build a casino here, airing a television commercial that touts their promise to create 9,000 jobs.

title: World News Briefs; Dutchman Is Backed For NATO's Top Post
description: The leaders of France and Britain today endorsed the former Prime Minister of the Netherlands, Ruud Lubbers, to be Secretary General of NATO, making it increasingly likely that he will be approved by all 16 member Governments later this fall.

title: House Tells Clinton to Get Approval to Send Troops to Bosnia
description: Two days before peace talks on Bosnia open in Dayton, the Clinton Administration today found itself fighting an unwelcome political brush fire in the House, which passed a resolution stating that the United States should not send, or even pledge, American peacekeepers without permission from Congress.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets Can't Count On Coleman Yet
description: The Nets didn't come right out and say it officially. They didn't have to. Common sense and a strong hint by the team's head coach led to the conclusion that Derrick Coleman will likely miss more than the club's first five regular-season games.

title: Police Vest Saves Officer Who Is Shot
description: A New York City police officer was shot twice in the chest at point-blank range yesterday evening but was saved by his bulletproof vest.

title: Kentucky Man Is Held in Killing Of a Shopkeeper From Brooklyn
description: New York City detectives suspected the worst when a Brooklyn shopkeeper disappeared on Oct. 14 and blood was found near his usual parking space. Last night, they said a Kentucky man killed the shopkeeper, cut up the corpse with a hacksaw and disposed of the parts in several trash bins around Lexington, Ky.

title: Breeding Plan Helps Black Footed Ferrets In Making Comeback
description: Biologists at the Sybille Wildlife Research Center, where most of the world's remaining black-footed ferrets are housed, worry constantly about disease. Visitors must leave their street clothes behind and, after a shower and shampoo, don blue coveralls, a surgical mask and shoes that are periodically dunked in disinfectant.

title: Pataki Moves to Seal Illegal Dump With $250,000 in State Money
description: Charging that the courts are moving too slowly to clean up an illegal dump here, Gov. George E. Pataki said today that he would authorize spending $250,000 in state funds to seal off the site -- an abandoned warehouse overflowing with garbage.

title: Chilly Scenes for Winter;Retailers Brace for a Gray Christmas Selling Season
description: Mimi Cassin's Christmas list is not the stuff of traditional fantasy. It seems she would be happy with a salad bowl.

title: Fund for Gifts to Injured Actor
description: Besides good wishes, fans have been sending money to the actor Christopher Reeve, who is being treated at the Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation for injuries from a horse-riding accident. For now, the money is being held in a fund set up by the Reeve family. "It's not going to pay his bills," said Kathy Lewis, a spokeswoman for Kessler, who said the money might be used to support research. "It's a holding tank for checks that come in."

title: CHRONICLE
description: THOMAS SOBOL, the former New York State Commissioner of Education, has been named to a new professorship at Teachers College at Columbia University. Dr. Sobol, who has been at the school since July, shortly after he left the state post, is now the first Christian A. Johnson Professor of Outstanding Educational Practice.

title: A Cloud Over Trump's Parade
description: On a day when Donald Trump was glorying in the under-budget, ahead-of-schedule completion of 150 luxury rooms and suites in the new East Tower at Trump Plaza, a competitor to the north announced its plans to house more gamblers.

title: Killer's Death Wish Delayed
description: John Martini was scheduled to be executed Nov. 15, and he wanted to die, telling a judge that several "terrible years" in prison were enough. But he will not get his wish, at least for now.

title: Market Place;Does Grand Met have a grand plan to split up or be sold?
description: SHAREHOLDERS of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. have not had much to be excited about in the last few years. Since peaking in 1992 at L5.06, or about $8, the shares have bounced around at lower prices as the company went through a series of divestitures, acquisitions and cost-cutting programs.

title: Guggenheim Foundation, Long a Donor, Is Now Having to Seek Donations
description: For 70 years, the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation has bestowed grants on promising scholars, scientists and artists -- from Aaron Copland, Ansel Adams and James Baldwin to Henry A. Kissinger, Linus Pauling and Paul Samuelson -- 13,500 in all.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Television section on Sunday about the "Masterpiece Theater" production "The Choir" misstated an acting credit. The role of Edward VIII in the television movie "Edward and Mrs. Simpson" was played by Edward Fox, not by his brother James.

title: Japanese Sect Tried to Buy U.S. Arms Technology, Senator Says
description: A Japanese sect accused of releasing lethal nerve gas in a Tokyo subway made extensive efforts in the United States, Russia and Australia to buy materials for nuclear and chemical weapons, including laser technology that the United States refuses to sell to suspected terrorist countries, Senator Sam Nunn said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Circulation Drops at Many Large Papers
description: Continuing a recent trend, 7 of the country's 10 largest metropolitan newspapers lost circulation in the six-month period that ended in September, according to data released yesterday.

title: Promotion for Schools Overseer
description: Dr. Beverly Hall has been running the Newark schools since July, when the state took them over. Her boss, Education Commissioner Leo F. Klagholz, is ready to name her Superintendent through June 1999 and remove the "acting" from her title. Last night, he told the local advisory board about his recommendation, which must be approved by the State Board of Education, according to Peter Peretzman, a spokesman for the Board of Education..

title: Harmless Poker Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Protector of Central Park
description: Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux had the vision to create Manhattan's Central Park. But it took the efforts of another visionary, Betsy Barlow Rogers, to help restore it after years of inattention and decay.

title: Justice in Nassau Says Landlord May Evict Abortion Clinic
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that a landlord could evict a Garden City abortion clinic because anti-abortion protests posed a danger to other tenants in the building.

title: High Court to Rule on Racial Question in Crack Cocaine Case
description: Stepping at least partway into the debate over the Federal Government's prosecution of crack cocaine offenses, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Government must explain why nearly all those prosecuted for Federal crimes involving crack are black.

title: Patterns
description: Show-Week Opportunities

title: QUEBEC, BY RAZOR-THIN MARGIN, VOTES 'NO' ON LEAVING CANADA
description: By the slenderest of margins, voters decided today that Quebec would remain a part of Canada.

title: ON BASEBALL;Belle's Performance Is Indians' Concern
description: The most disappointing moment of the Cleveland Indians' first appearance in the World Series since 1954 might have occurred last Saturday night. But it wasn't the David Justice home run that beat them or their inability to get more than Tony Pena's single against Tom Glavine.

title: What H.M.O.'s Don't Want to Tell You
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Darden Sells Book on O. J. Simpson Trial
description: The harvest of O. J. Simpson books is in full swing.

title: Class Rankings Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: Sony Is Said to Be Considering A Stock Offering by Its U.S. Unit
description: The Sony Corporation has asked the Blackstone Group, an investment banking firm, to help it evaluate a possible public offering of a stake in some portion of its American operations, several people familiar with the discussion said yesterday.

title: Presentations by Kmart Chief Draw Only Mixed Reviews
description: Floyd Hall, the chief executive of the Kmart Corporation, met separately with analysts and investors yesterday to dispel rumors that the discount retailer faces a credit crunch and to describe a plan for improving sagging profits.

title: CAPITAL CITIES/ABC INC. (CCB,N)
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. said yesterday that its profit slipped 5 percent in the third quarter after $47.3 million in charges for merger costs and a litigation settlement.

title: HORSE SHOW;The '96 National: Shorter, Snappier and in Manhattan
description: The 112th National Horse Show, a Manhattan mainstay that made a controversial move to New Jersey seven years ago amid rumors of impending bankruptcy, opened last night at the Meadowlands for the last time. Next year, the National is returning to Madison Square Garden, the site of its first 105 stagings.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Increasingly, companies are cashing in on Halloween's monsters and ghosts.
description: FOR Halloween, Madison Avenue is serving up perhaps its most potent batch of pitches' brew ever.

title: CHRONICLE
description: THOMAS SOBOL, the former New York State Commissioner of Education, has been named to a new professorship at Teachers College at Columbia University. Dr. Sobol, who has been at the school since July, shortly after he left the state post, is now the first Christian A. Johnson Professor of Outstanding Educational Practice.

title: BASEBALL;Sandberg's Retirement Was Only Temporary
description: On a day that Roberto Alomar, Jose Canseco, Ron Gant and Rickey Henderson opted to become free to join other clubs, Ryne Sandberg decided to abandon retirement and rejoin the team he left in 1994.

title: Taxicabs Of the Future Hit the Road In Test Runs
description: There is a lot more head room and more cargo room, and you can have the air-conditioning blown directly on you, instead of cooling the air on the other side of a bulletproof partition. It may be the taxi of the future, and it is not a car.

title: Music With a Beat From the Heart
description: A YOUNG composer and his father, a cardiologist who believes that a healthy heart must "dance" rather than "march," have combined their ideas about art and biological complexity to produce a collection of songs based on heartbeats.

title: 3 Insurers Object to a Plan by Cigna
description: Three large insurance companies said yesterday that they objected to a reorganization plan announced earlier this month by the Cigna Corporation, another insurer, on grounds that the plan could create a Cigna subsidiary that might fail to meet its obligations and become a burden to other insurance companies.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Now, the Check Is in the Modem
description: Use the right software, and your computer can do some banking tricks that most automated teller machines cannot. The latest versions of two popular personal finance packages have arrived: Quicken version 5 from Intuit Inc. and Microsoft Money for Windows 95 from the obvious suspect. When connected to a modem and a participating bank, the programs can capture banking and credit card statements, transfer funds between accounts, tell you which checks have cleared, and pay bills automatically or on request.

title: American Visions Prevail
description: Fashion has had a bad habit in the last 10 years of wearing the burdens of the world on its sleeve, among other conspicuous places.

title: Fruit of the Loom to Close Six U.S. Plants
description: Fruit of the Loom Inc., the nation's largest underwear maker, said today that it would close six domestic plants and cut back operations at two others, laying off about 3,200 workers, or 12 percent of its United States work force.

title: INSIDE
description: Crack Charges and Race

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: AIDS Groups Fear Loss Of Health Care Benefits
description: AIDS care groups nationwide say they fear that the plan to give states more control over Medicaid, which pays the health costs of half of the nation's AIDS patients, will force thousands of people to forgo benefits like prescription drugs and home health care.

title: Harmless Poker Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Age Gracefully
description: Now, it should be said that age does matter. Designers' sensibilities are, after all, products of the social and cultural changes swirling around them as they mature. And some influences are reinforced daily, which is why Carolina Herrera, in her milieu, and Kenneth Richard, molding a vision of his world, both produced strong collections.

title: State Agency To Represent Sex Offenders
description: Lawyers in New Jersey, angered by the prospect of representing indigent sex offenders without a fee, got the relief they sought yesterday when the State Attorney General said she would create a new section in the Public Defender's office to handle hearings required under the statute known as Megan's Law.

title: Dutch Report Clears Troops In Fiasco at Bosnian Town
description: After conducting an exhaustive review of the United Nations mission that failed to protect the Bosnian town of Srebrenica in July, the Dutch Defense Minister said today that the small band of Dutch peacekeepers entrusted with policing the town could not have prevented the slaughter of civilians that took place there.

title: Executive Changes
description: DELCO ELECTRONICS CORP., Kokomo, Ind., a subsidiary of Hughes Electronics Corp., a General Motors Corp. division, named John Blahnik president and chief financial officer. FIRST OF AMERICA BANK CORP., Kalamazoo, Mich., said that Daniel R. Smith, chairman and chief executive, would retire effective May, 1. Richard F. Chormann was named to succeed him.

title: Tokyo Court Orders Disbanding of Sect in Subway Nerve Gas Case
description: A court today ordered the disbanding of the religious sect suspected of organizing the nerve gas attack on the Tokyo subway system. The ruling sets the stage for the liquidation of a religious and business empire that has fascinated and frightened the Japanese public.

title: Estee Lauder Opts To Stay With Bates
description: The Estee Lauder Companies said yesterday that it would keep its account, with billings estimated at $80 million, at the Bates Manhattan unit of Bates Worldwide in New York. The decision, after an 18-month review, was unexpected because trade publications had speculated that Lauder -- one of Bates's largest and most visible clients -- might leave the agency.

title: DREYFUS PRESIDENT TO RESIGN AFTER 10 MONTHS
description: Robert E. Riley plans to resign as president and chief operating officer of the Dreyfus Corporation, the mutual fund unit of the Mellon Bank Corporation, just 10 months after taking the job. Mr. Riley, 65, has been named president and chief executive at Leggat McCall Properties, a closely held commercial real estate company based in Boston, Mellon said yesterday. Mr. Riley will be succeeded by Christopher M. Condron, vice chairman of Mellon Bank, as of Nov. 30. Mr. Condron will supervise Mellon's investment management subsidiaries which, with Dreyfus, oversee about $200 billion in assets.

title: Powergen Extends Bid
description: The British power generator Powergen P.L.C. said yesterday that it had extended its offer of $:1.95 billion ($3 billion) for the regional distributor Midlands Electricity P.L.C. until Nov. 10. Powergen said that as of Friday it held a 64.5 percent stake in Midlands. (Reuters)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League BALTIMORE ORIOLES -- Signed Davey Johnson, manager, to a three-year contract.

title: Elsag Bailey to Buy Unit of Mannesmann
description: Elsag Bailey Process Automation N.V. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Hartmann & Braun group of companies from Mannesmann A.G. of Germany for about one billion marks ($712 million). Hartmann & Braun, which is based in Frankfurt, makes automation systems for energy production and other industrial processes. The company had 1994 revenue of about 1.3 billion marks.

title: A Congressional Stand
description: With Bosnia peace talks in two days, the Clinton Administration was battling with the House over sending peacekeepers. Page A9.

title: Civic Pillar Pleads Guilty In Slaying Plot
description: An influential businessman whose financial and political connections stretched from Chinatown to Albany admitted in Federal Court yesterday that he had used violence and murder to protect an illegal gambling operation run by his Chinatown fraternal organization.

title: ResultsPlus
description: N.H.L.

title: Softkey, in Separate Deals, Seeks 2 Educational Software Makers
description: Softkey International Inc. began a hostile takeover bid valued at $606 million yesterday for the Learning Company, which had previously agreed to be acquired by Broderbund Inc.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;McNabb Unfurls A Knack To Lead
description: Donovan McNabb is just a freshman at Syracuse, an 18-year-old freshman. "But we've never babied him," said George DeLeone, the Orange offensive coordinator.

title: British Patient Given Artificial Heart
description: A British-American team has implanted a permanent artificial electrically powered heart into a 64-year-old heart patient who had been given six months to live.

title: Dow Must Pay $10 Million In Damages For Implant
description: In one of the largest awards in a case involving silicone breast implants, a Nevada jury ordered the Dow Chemical Company yesterday to pay $10 million in punitive damages to a woman who said she was severely injured by the devices.

title: Peace in the Balkans Now Depends On the Man Who Fanned Its Wars
description: Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian President, is often to be found padding through the cavernous presidency building in Belgrade, alone except for a single faithful aide.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Merger Mania Nears Record-Setting Pace The wave of corporate consolidations is likely to set a record this year. The pace is as feverish as it was in the last three years of the 1980's, the decade of the takeover.

title: Patterns
description: Show-Week Opportunities

title: Swarming Halloween Bugs Eat Aphids, Haunt Humans
description: THE Halloween ladybugs are swarming -- in numbers suitable for a Hitchcock film. They came from Asia, to Louisiana, to Georgia, and now they are in New York. In fact, throughout the Northeast, houses have been invaded by hundreds or thousands of the orange and black pill-size beetles, causing the human inhabitants to rush to their telephones in alarm.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the possible demise of Pahaquarry, N.J., (population 6) reversed the names of municipalities involved in a 1952 merger that created the city of Vineland, N.J. They were Landis Township and Vineland Borough, not Landis Borough and Vineland Township.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: GETTING INTO CO-OPS: THE MONEY BIAS Before a New Yorker can experience the ambiguous joys of co-op life, there is the matter of getting in: an effort that has always tended to be unpleasant, intrusive and exclusionary. But in these days of co-op angst, as the market struggles warily in the wake of the bankruptcies and defaults of the early 1990's, there is widespread agreement that the admissions process has become more onerous. [ Page A1. ] GIULIANI TO END CITY'S LANDLORD ROLE The Giuliani administration announced that it was ending New York City's role as the landlord of last resort. The city will no longer take over ownership and management of buildings whose owners fall far behind on property taxes. Instead, it will give the owners advice and even financial help in paying their debt. [ A1. ] NEW YORK CITY GIULIANI URGES POWELL TO RUN In a continuing quest to crack open a Republican Presidential primary sealed by his political rivals, Mayor Giuliani urged Gen. Colin L. Powell to embark on the obstacle course toward a spot on the New York State Republican ballot. [ B3. ] TAXIS OF THE FUTURE GET A TRYOUT There is a lot more head room and more cargo room, and you can have the air-conditioning blown directly on you. It may be the taxi of the future, and it is not a car. [ B3. ] OFFICER IS SAVED BY BULLETPROOF VEST A New York City police officer was shot twice in the chest at point-blank range in Queens, but was saved by his bulletproof vest. [ B3. ] A Kentucky man was charged in the killing of a Brooklyn shopkeeper who disappeared on Oct. 14, the police said. [ B3. ] REGION SEX OFFENDERS REPRESENTED New Jersey lawyers, angered by the prospect of representing indigent sex offenders free, got the relief they sought when State Attorney General Deborah T. Poritz said she would create a new section in the Public Defender's office to handle hearings required under the statute known as "Megan's Law." [ B5. ] PATAKI MOVES TO CLOSE ILLEGAL DUMP Charging that the courts are moving too slowly to clean up an illegal dump in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., Governor Pataki said that he would spend $250,000 in state money to seal off the site: an abandoned warehouse. [ B5. ] CAMPAIGN FOR A CASINO MOVES TO TV The Mashantucket Pequot Indians stepped up their efforts to overcome opposition to their proposal to build a casino in Bridgeport, Conn., broadcasting a television commercial that touts their promise to create 9,000 jobs. [ B5. ] Only three days after the Federal Government essentially turned down New York City's proposal to push Medicaid patients into managed-care programs, New York State officials said they planned to press a similar proposal. [ B4. ] A suit was filed in Federal Court in Manhattan against a retired Roman Catholic bishop and a Franciscan friar who sat down in front of cars at an abortion clinic in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. [ B4. ] Throughout the Northeast, houses have been invaded by hundreds or thousands of Halloween ladybugs, causing the human inhabitants to rush to their telephones in alarm. title: A Freshman Who Doesn't Aim to Please . . .
description: Who among the ambitious Republicans in Congress would not yearn to become a trusted friend of Speaker Newt Gingrich, the field commander of the conservative assault?

title: Company Briefs
description: PRINCIPAL HEALTH CARE INC., a privately held, managed health care company in Rockville, Md., agreed to acquire Admar Group Inc., Santa Ana, Calif., which administers managed health care services, for about $20 million in cash. PRICELLULAR CORP., New York, said it planned to acquire a rural service in Pennsylvania from U.S. Cellular Corp. for about $23 million.

title: Talk With Farrakhan
description: The leaders of American Jewish groups should drop their failed boycott of Louis Farrakhan and take up his offer of dialogue.

title: Getting Into Co-ops: The Money Bias
description: They knew they were going to be rejected the second they walked through the door.

title: Committees Find Signs of Weak Leadership at Dana-Farber
description: THE Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston said yesterday that two committees had concluded that its top leadership was weak and that the quality assurance of its clinical care and training were seriously flawed.

title: Novell to Sell Wordperfect Software Line
description: Novell Inc. said today that it intended to sell its struggling Wordperfect line of software applications, which it acquired only 18 months ago in an $855 million stock swap.

title: Consumer Spending Shows A Slower Rate of Growth
description: Consumer spending rose in September at half the rate that incomes grew, the Government said today in reports that pointed to slower growth ahead.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Investors Allow Rockefeller Bid To Expire
description: The investor group led by Sam Zell, the Chicago financier, allowed its $1.16 billion offer for Rockefeller Center's mortgage to expire yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;People
description: * Adelaide Horton was named to the new position of president and chief operating officer at Wells Rich Greene BDDP Communications, New York, part of BDDP Worldwide. She previously held a similar position at TBWA Chiat/Day East, New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group.

title: Dole's Wife To Leave Job During Race
description: Elizabeth Hanford Dole has temporarily stepped down from her job as president of the American Red Cross. Officials of the organization said today that she wanted to devote more time to the Presidential campaign of her husband, Bob Dole, and that she feared her continued presence as head of the Red Cross would embroil the organization in politics.

title: Voting Project for Cities Finds Many Opponents
description: An innovative project to amplify the voice of urban voters in the selection of Presidential nominees has run into problems, from the hostility of the Democratic Party to restrictive election laws in some states to the refusal of most candidates to take part.

title: Washington Journal;For City's Strays, a New Life of Sorts
description: The District of Columbia is still going to the dogs, and for once in this financially strapped city, that's good news.

title: Accounts
description: * Sterling Multimedia Computers, New York, to Korey Kay & Partners, New York, to handle its account, previously handled in-house. The billings were estimated at $8 million. * Eggland's Best Inc., King of Prussia, Pa., to Harris Drury Cohen, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to handle the creative portion of its account, previously handled by N. W. Ayer & Partners, New York. The media portion remains at Western International Media, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos. The billings were not disclosed.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Heating Oil and Natural Gas Up On Chilling Weather Forecasts
description: Heating oil and natural gas prices jumped yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, bolstered by forecasts of wintry weather in the Midwest and Northeast, the major American markets for home heating fuels.

title: Gene Hunters Pursue Elusive and Complex Traits of Mind
description: It was just a handful of years ago that biologists were waving their spears, shields and pipettes in the air, boasting with full-throated glory of their success in capturing the legendary prey of molecular genetics. In a series of widely publicized discoveries, geneticists announced the isolation of the cystic fibrosis gene, the gene for Lou Gehrig's disease, the gene for Huntington's disease and a gene linked to the familial form of breast cancer.

title: In Capital, New York State Presses a Medicaid Care Plan
description: Only three days after the Federal Government essentially turned down New York City's proposal to push Medicaid patients into managed-care programs, New York State officials said today that they planned to press the Clinton Administration to act quickly on their own proposal, which is more ambitious but similar to the city's.

title: Molinari Runs, And a Borough Wonders Why;Will a Kingpin Abdicate?
description: From barber shops to bowling alleys, Guy V. Molinari is known on Staten Island as the borough's undisputed Republican kingpin.

title: Mexican Markets Applaud Plan for Economy
description: Mexico's economic managers got the initial reaction they wanted today as financial markets responded favorably to a new recovery plan to revive the battered economy.

title: What H.M.O.'s Don't Want to Tell You
description: To the Editor:

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Halloween Parade tonight in Greenwich Village, which begins at 7 P.M., Sixth Avenue will be closed beginning at 6 P.M. from Spring to 22d Streets.

title: Shady Deals in Municipal Bonds
description: The market for municipal bonds has been riddled with corrupt practices. Bond dealers have been caught bribing government officials to win business. They have also used a more subtle tactic -- contributing to the campaigns of local officials so as to win contracts to market a local government's bonds. In between the blatant and subtle forms of corruption fall a variety of other suspect practices.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: BASEBALL;Torre Waits for the Rumors to Prove Right
description: Joe Torre is the leading candidate and perhaps the only candidate to replace Buck Showalter as manager of the Yankees. But even Torre is eager to know just when General Manager Bob Watson will make his interest official and interview him for the position everyone keeps whispering is his.

title: Soweto Journal;Cricket's Message to Blacks: Your Turn at Bat
description: Ahh, cricket. Delightful game. Definitely not for the tractor-pull crowd, but absolutely spot on if you find yourself stuck sometime on a vast empty lawn with a broken canoe paddle, a rock-hard spaldeen and 21 other chaps in white ducks with four days to spare.

title: Readers of Romances Make No Apology
description: To the Editor:

title: The Sound of Music in a Revered Boston Hall
description: When Jordan Hall was built at the New England Conservatory in 1903, there were no acoustical consultants around to supervise the work. Acoustics as a science did not yet exist. Even today's experts admit that what makes a grand old concert hall sound grand is somewhat mysterious.

title: COMPANY EARNING;ITT CORP. (ITT,N)
description: The ITT Corporation reported yesterday that it had lost $174 million in the third quarter, reflecting costs related to its impending breakup into three entities.

title: Shift Seen in U.S. Stance on Loans in Poor Areas
description: Under pressure from bankers, the Clinton Administration's top bank regulator is taking steps to allow less rigorous enforcement of regulations requiring banks to lend in low-income neighborhoods, according to a Federal Reserve memorandum and Government officials.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When MORTON GOULD, the composer, was commissioned two years ago to write a work for the Pittsburgh Youth Orchestra, he started off the way he often does: by consulting his family.

title: Chess
description: By beating Jeroen Piket, 26, the 43-year-old Jan Timman proves he's still the old Dutch master.

title: Corrections
description: A film review on Friday about "Harlem Diary: Nine Voices of Resilience" quoted Nikki Matos, an 18-year-old mother, incorrectly. Speaking of her worries about her infant son, Ms. Matos says in the film, "I gave birth to an endangered species" -- not "a dangerous species."

title: A Plan for the Hospitalized Poor
description: The Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, thinks there is a better way to pay for hospital care for the working poor.

title: U.S. AND AUSTRALIAN UTILITIES BUY SOLARIS POWER
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation of Parsippany, N.J., and the Australian Gas Light Company have jointly bought Solaris Power, an electricity distributor, from the Australian state of Victoria for $717 million. Solaris supplies electricity to the northern suburbs of Melbourne. The purchase is General Public Utilities' first expansion into the Pacific Rim region.

title: Russian Democracy Blindsided
description: With President Boris Yeltsin sidelined by severe health problems and Russia entering its most important electoral season since the Bolshevik Revolution, the future of Russian democracy depends heavily on the performance of new institutions unpracticed in the ways of multi-party democracy.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Saturday, headlined "Questions of Justice in Okinawa," misstated recent charges against three American servicemen in Okinawa in some editions. The servicemen have been charged with the abduction and rape of a 12-year-old schoolgirl, not with rape and murder.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Small Yet Unstinting in Range or Thunder
description: North Carolina Dance Theater is both strong and versatile. Its dancers have to be, for the repertory is an eclectic assortment of classical and contemporary ballets. Since this Charlotte-based touring company has only 18 dancers, everyone must be at ease in every style and no one can be typed simply as "lyrical," "classical" or "dramatic," as sometimes happens in larger ballet troupes.
